It seems likely though, that the environment of our ancestors represented ecological, social and human conditions that are quite different from today. People were living in small villages where everyone knew everyone else and strangers didn’t show up often. There were enemies, predators and diseases. Limited resources created competition for food and mates.

男人和女人可能扮演什么不同的角色？男人负责狩猎，并保护群体免受掠食者和敌人的侵害。妇女们在家附近收集和准备食物，并照顾孩子。

What different roles did men and women likely play? Men were responsible for hunting, and defending the group from predators and enemies. Women gathered and prepared food near the home, and cared for the children.

如果这是环境，增加生存和繁殖可能性的适当行为是什么？在我们 99% 的历史中，什么行为是自然的？

If this were the environment, what would be appropriate behaviour to increase the likelihood for survival and reproduction? What behaviour has been natural during 99% of our history?

三：生存和繁殖的适应行为

Three: Adaptive behaviour For Survival and Reproduction

个人至上

The individual comes first

没有社会这样的东西。

有个别的男人和女人，也有家庭。

There’s no such thing as society.

There are individual men and women, and there are families.

——玛格丽特·撒切尔

（英国前首相）

- Margaret Thatcher

(Former British Prime Minister)

人们会做他们认为最符合他们利益的事情吗？

Do people do what they perceive is in their best interest?

是的，所有个人共有的一个基本特征是自利。我们有兴趣保护我们的亲密家人和我们自己。为什么？

Yes, one basic trait that all individuals share is self-interest. We are interested in protecting our close family and ourselves. Why?

由于自然选择是关于生存和繁殖的，而个体要么生存要么死亡并繁殖或不繁殖，因此个体倾向于以提高自身生存和繁殖前景的方式行事是有道理的。祖先的环境包括有限的资源，包括生殖资源和激烈的竞争。私利是自然而然的。

Since natural selection is about survival and reproduction, and individuals either survive or die and reproduce or not, it makes sense that individuals are predisposed to act in ways that enhance their own prospects for survival and reproduction. The ancestral environment consisted of limited resources, including reproductive resources, and fierce competition. Self-interest came naturally.

如果我们的祖先是由利他主义者组成的——以牺牲自己的利益帮助他人的人呢？利他主义的人处于劣势。他们总是容易受到一些利用他们的突变体的攻击。利他行为不能通过自然选择进化，因为自然选择有利于最擅长促进自身生存和繁殖成功的个体。只有自私或为了共同利益的行为才符合个人的自身利益，因此才会受到自然选择的青睐。有些行为在某些条件下可能看起来像利他主义，但通常可以用利己主义来解释。社会认可、声望、对社会不赞成的恐惧、羞耻、从痛苦中解脱、避免内疚、更好的来世或社会期望是“利他”行为背后的一些原因。

What if our ancestors were composed of altruists — individuals that helped others at their own expense? Altruistic individuals are at a disadvantage. They are always vulnerable to some mutants that take advantage of them. Altruistic behaviour cannot evolve by natural selection since natural selection favours individuals that are best at promoting their own survival and reproductive success. Only behaviour that is selfish or for the mutual good is in an individual’s self-interest and therefore favoured by natural selection. Some behaviour may under certain conditions look like altruism but can often be explained by self-benefit. Social recognition, prestige, fear of social disapproval, shame, relief from distress, avoidance of guilt, a better after-life or social expectations are some reasons behind"altruistic" acts.

但是我们的社会和道德品质是如何发展的呢？正如查尔斯·达尔文在《人类的由来》第四章中所写：

But how did our social and moral qualities develop? As Charles Darwin wrote in chapter four of The Descent of Man:

“为什么一个人应该觉得他应该服从一种本能的欲望而不是另一种？如果他屈服于强烈的自我保护意识，没有冒着生命危险去拯救同胞的生命，他为什么会痛苦地后悔；或者他为什么因为极度饥饿而后悔偷了食物？” 在该书的第五章，达尔文写道：“对社会美德发展的强大刺激，即我们同胞的赞扬和责备。”

对赞许的热爱和对耻辱的恐惧，以及对赞美或责备的给予，主要是由于……同情的本能；毫无疑问，与所有其他社会本能一样，这种本能最初是通过自然选择获得的……因此，我们可以得出结论，在非常遥远的时期，原始人会受到其同胞的赞扬和指责的影响。很明显，同一个部落的成员会赞成在他们看来有益于普遍利益的行为，而会谴责那些看似邪恶的行为。善待他人——己所不欲，勿施于人——是道德的基石。因此，无论怎样夸大粗暴时期爱赞美怕责难的重要性都不为过。一个不受任何深渊驱使的人，本能的感觉，为他人的利益牺牲自己的生命，然而被荣耀感唤醒，会通过他的榜样激发其他人对荣耀的同样愿望，并会通过锻炼高尚的钦佩感而加强。因此，他可能为他的部落做的好事远远超过生下有继承他高尚品格倾向的后代。

"Why should a man feel that he ought to obey one instinctive desire rather than another? Why does he bitterly regret if he has yielded to the strong sense of self-preservation, and has not risked his life to save that of a fellow creature; or why does he regret having stolen food from severe hunger?" In chapter five of the book, Darwin wrote that there is a:"powerful stimulus to the development of the social virtues, namely, the praise and the blame of our fellow-men."

The love of approbation and the dread of infamy, as well as the bestowal of praise or blame, are primarily due.. .to the instinct of sympathy; and this instinct no doubt was originally acquired, like all the other social instincts, through natural selection.. .We may therefore conclude that primeval man, at a very remote period, would have been influenced by the praise and blame of his fellows. It is obvious, that the members of the same tribe would approve of conduct which appeared to them to be for the general good, and would reprobate that which appeared evil. To do good unto others - to do unto others as ye would they should do unto you, — is the foundation-stone of morality. It is, therefore, hardly possible to exaggerate the importance during rude times of the love of praise and the dread of blame. A man who was not impelled by any deep, instinctive feeling, to sacrifice his life for the good of others, yet was roused to such actions by a sense of glory, would by his example excite the same wish for glory in other men, and would strengthen by exercise the noble feeling of admiration. He might thus do far more good to his tribe than by begetting offspring with a tendency to inherit his own high character.

高标准的道德也会使一个部落受益。达尔文继续说：

A high standard of morality would also benefit a tribe. Darwin continues:

不可忘记的是，虽然高标准的道德给每个人和他的孩子带来比同一部落的其他人更小的优势或没有优势，但是道德标准的进步和数量的增加有天赋的人肯定会给一个部落带来比另一个部落更大的优势。
It must not be forgotten that although a high standard of morality gives but a slight or no advantage to each individual man and his children over the other men of the same tribe, yet that an advancement in the standard of morality and an increase in the number of well-endowed men will certainly give an immense advantage to one tribe over another.

通常合作符合我们的最大利益

Often cooperation is in our best interest

如果人们天生不是无私的，他们会合作吗？

If people aren’t altruistic by nature, are they cooperative?

互助具有巨大的生存价值。但是人们在什么条件下合作呢？囚徒困境的游戏可能会阐明这一点：假设你和一个伙伴犯了入室盗窃罪。你们俩都被警察抓起来，然后一一盘问。除非你们中的一个人供认，否则没有足够的证据可以给你定罪。审讯者让你选择合作与否。

Mutual aid has tremendous survival value. But under what conditions do people cooperate? The game of the Prisoner’s Dilemma may shed light on this: Suppose you and a partner commit burglary. Both of you are picked up by the police who then question you one by one. There is not enough evidence to convict you unless one of you confesses. The interrogator gives you a choice to cooperate or not.

“如果你们都否认犯罪，还有足够的证据让你们都入狱一年。”

“如果你们都坦白，你们都会坐牢 3 年。”

“如果你承认但你的伴侣否认，你将获得自由，而你的伴侣将入狱 10 年。”

“如果你否认但你的伴侣承认，你将入狱 10 年。”

"If you both deny the crime, there is still enough evidence to put you both in jail for 1 year."

"If you both confess, you both go to jail for 3 years."

"If you confess but your partner denies, you will be free and your partner will go to jail for 10 years."

"If you deny but your partner confesses, you will go to jail for 10 years."

你该怎么办？对您造成的后果取决于您的伴侣的行为。从局外人的角度来看，似乎你们两个都否认犯罪（1 年）会更好。但从你的角度来看，似乎最好坦白（自由）。问题是你不知道你的伴侣会做什么。如果你的伴侣背叛了你，你最好也背叛他并被判入狱 3 年，而不是如果你否认你会被判 10 年，但你的伴侣最终会坦白。另一方面，如果您的伴侣否认，您最好承认，因为这样您将获得自由，而不是如果您否认，您将获得 1 年。

What should you do? The consequences for you depend on what your partner does. From an outsider’s perspective, it seems that both of you would be better off denying the crime (1 year). But from your point of view, it seems best to confess (freedom). The problem is that you don’t know what your partner will do. If your partner betrays you, it is better that you also betray him and get 3 years in prison, instead of the 10 years you get if you deny, but your partner ends up confessing. If on the other hand your partner denies, it is still better that you confess because this way you will be free, instead of the 1 year you get if you deny.

由于你和你的伴侣都遵循这个“逻辑”并坦白，你们都将入狱 3 年。做你认为符合你最大利益的事情比你合作和拒绝会导致更糟糕的结果。但这是两难境地。你不知道你是否可以信任你的伴侣。合作只有在您和您的合作伙伴可以相互信任时才有效。

Since both you and your partner follow this"logic" and confess, you will both go to jail for 3 years. Doing what you believe is in your best interest leads to a worse outcome than if you cooperate and deny. But here is the dilemma. You don’t know if you can trust your partner. Cooperation only works if you and your partner can trust each other.

测试表明，如果人们一遍又一遍地玩这个游戏，他们就会知道合作更有利可图。重复测试信任。信任是关键而脆弱的。它可以在一瞬间消失。正如 19 世纪的美国总统亚伯拉罕林肯所写：“如果你一旦失去同胞的信任，你就永远无法重新获得他们的尊重和尊重。”

Tests show that if people play the game over and over, they learn that it is more profitable to cooperate. Repetition tests trust. Trust is key and fragile. It can vanish in a moment. As the 19th Century American President Abraham Lincoln wrote:"If you once forfeit the confidence of your fellow citizens, you can never regain their respect and esteem."

另一种创造合作的方式是让伙伴在游戏过程中进行交流。谈话鼓励合作。由于人是群居动物，他们可能会改变自己的行为以保持他人的善意。归根结底，这是一个信任问题，并激励个人合作。

Another way to create cooperation is to let the partners communicate during the game. Talking encourages cooperation. Since people are social animals, they may change their behaviour to keep others goodwill. In the end, it’s a matter of trust and giving individuals an incentive to cooperate.

在《人类的由来》第三章中，查尔斯·达尔文写道：

In chapter three of The Descent of Man, Charles Darwin wrote:

在行动的那一刻，人无疑倾向于追随更强烈的冲动；虽然这偶尔会促使他做出最崇高的行为，但更常见的是会导致他以牺牲他人为代价来满足自己的欲望。但在他们的满足之后，当过去的、较弱的印象与永存的社会本能形成对比时，报应必将来临。然后，人会对自己感到不满，并会或多或少地下定决心为未来采取不同的行动。这是良心；因为良心向后看并评判过去的行为，引起那种不满，如果微弱，我们称之为后悔，如果是严重的悔恨。
At the moment of action, man will no doubt be apt to follow the stronger impulse; and though this may occasionally prompt him to the noblest deeds, it will far more commonly lead him to gratify his own desires at the expense of other men. But after their gratification, when past and weaker impressions are contrasted with the ever-enduring social instincts, retribution will surely come. Man will then feel dissatisfied with himself, and will resolve with more or less force to act differently for the future. This is conscience; for conscience looks backwards and judges past actions, inducing that kind of dissatisfaction, which if weak we call regret, and if severe remorse.

但我们也必须认识到，沟通可能具有欺骗性。人们可能会虚张声势。此外，沟通是不完美的——会犯错误或误解意图。

But we also have to recognize that communication may be deceptive. People may bluff. Also, communications are imperfect — mistakes are made or intentions are misunderstood.

从长远来看有效的策略是现代版的“以牙还牙”或以牙还牙。它说我们应该在第一次会议上合作，然后我们的“对手”上次做了什么就做什么。当我们的对手合作时，我们应该合作。当我们的对手不合作时，我们应该报复。然后原谅并回到下一轮合作。这会奖励过去的合作并惩罚过去的背叛。这假设游戏会一次又一次地重复。实际上，我们永远不知道将来是否会再次遇到对手。只要我们的对手和我们都不知道游戏何时结束，表现得友好一点就值得。当然，囚徒困境的博弈只是两人博弈。现实往往涉及多人互动。

The strategy that is effective in the long run is a modern version of"a tooth for a tooth" or TIT-FOR-TAT. It says that we should cooperate at the first meeting and then do whatever our"opponent" did the last time. When our opponent cooperates, we should cooperate. When our opponent doesn’t cooperate, we should retaliate. Then forgive and go back to cooperating next round. This rewards past cooperation and punishes past defection. This assumes that the game is repeated time after time. In reality we never know if we meet our opponent again in the future. As long as neither our opponent nor we knows when the game ends, it pays to be nice. Of course, the game of the Prisoner’s Dilemma is only a two-player game. Reality often involves many-person interactions.

科学家们说，我们对待一组人比其他人更好——我们的近亲。这就是亲缘选择。我们对我们的亲属表现出利他行为，因为他们共享我们的基因。研究表明，在所有社会性物种中，亲属之间更有可能互相帮助。两个人之间的遗传相关性程度越高，一个人就越有可能更好地对待另一个人。如果你为你的孩子牺牲一些东西，它可能会伤害你，但由于你的孩子分享你的基因，整体效果是积极的。科学家们说，亲属选择的一项测试是，如果亲戚和好朋友都快要溺水了，我们会怎么做。我们只能保存其中一个。如果其中一个是你一生只见过两次的远房表亲，而那个朋友是你每天都在一起的人呢？你会救哪一位？

There is one group that scientists say we treat better than others — our close genetic relatives. This is kin selection. We act altruistic to our kin because they share our genes. Studies show that in all social species, relatives are more likely to help each other. The greater degree of genetic relatedness between two individuals, the more likely it is that an individual treats the other individual better. If you sacrifice something for your children, it may harm you but since your children share your genes, the overall effect is positive. Scientists say that one test of kin selection is what we would do if a relative and a good friend were both close to drowning. We can only save one of them. What if one of them was a distant cousin that you’d seen only twice in your life and the friend was a person you spent every day with? Who would you save?

还有什么其他行为适合我们的祖先？

What other behaviour was appropriate for our ancestors?

恐惧倾向

A tendency for fear

我们的恐惧总是比我们的危险更多。

Our fears are always more numerous than our dangers.

- Lucius Annaeus Seneca

（罗马哲学家，c.4 BC-65 AD）

- Lucius Annaeus Seneca

(Roman philosopher, c.4 BC-65 AD)

乘客登上飞往芝加哥的651航班。起飞两小时后，空乘人员听到厕所里传来可疑的声音。乘客们开始议论纷纷。恐慌爆发了。

The passengers boarded flight 651 to Chicago. Two hours after take-off the flight attendant heard suspicious noise from the lavatory. The passengers started to talk among themselves. Panic erupted.

我们害怕戏剧性和威胁性的事件。我们害怕失去健康、家人、朋友、安全感、金钱、社会地位、权力或工作。我们也害怕暴力、犯罪、惩罚、拒绝、失败、未知、直接、不可预测或无法控制的事物。研究表明，即使目睹创伤性事件也会产生与亲身经历相同的恐惧反应。

We fear dramatic and threatening events. We fear the loss of our health, family, friends, security, money, social status, power, or jobs. We also fear violence, crime, punishment, rejection, failure, the unknown, the immediate, the unpredictable or the uncontrollable. Studies show that even witnessing a traumatic event can produce the same fear response as experiencing the event ourselves.

恐惧是我们最基本的情绪。恐惧已经进化到可以帮助我们预测危险和避免痛苦。正如科学作家 Rush Dozier 在Fear Itself中写道：“恐惧是根本，因为生命是根本。如果我们死了，其他一切都变得无关紧要。”

Fear is our most basic emotion. Fear has evolved to help us anticipate danger and avoid pain. As science writer Rush Dozier writes in Fear Itself:"Fear is fundamental because life is fundamental. If we die, everything else becomes irrelevant."

人类对恐惧产生了强烈的情感。我们祖先的环境充满了危险。对身体危险、社会反对、缺乏食物、没有伴侣、捕食者等的恐惧。自我生存是一种强大的激励。错误可能代价高昂。假设有两个人在灌木丛后听到奇怪的声音。其中一人往灌木丛后看，被毒蛇咬伤而死。另一个看到发生的事情，逃跑并幸免于难。总是假设灌木丛后面有威胁并逃跑可以挽救一个人的生命。在没有蛇的情况下犯错和逃跑的代价是最小的。但是，当有蛇出现时留在附近的代价可能会危及生命。未能检测到威胁通常比错误警报的代价更高。我们的祖先通过反复试验了解到，从长远来看，如果他们害怕，痛苦是可以避免的。他们在危险中幸存下来，因为他们学会了如何应对。

Humans have developed a strong emotion for fear. Our ancestors environment was fraught with dangers. Fear of physical danger, social disapproval, lack of food, no mate, predators, etc. Self-survival was a powerful incentive. Mistakes could be extremely costly. Assume two individuals heard a strange sound behind the bushes. One of them looked behind the bushes, was bit by a poisonous snake and died. The other one saw what happened, ran away and survived. To always assume there was a threat behind the bushes and run away could save an individual’s life. The cost of being wrong and running when there was no snake was minimal. But the cost of staying around when there was a snake could be life threatening. Failure to detect threats is often more costly than false alarms. Our ancestors learned through trial and error that in the long run, pain could be avoided if they were fearful. They survived the dangers because they learned how to respond.

如果痛苦和快乐是导致生存和繁殖的行为指南，那么恐惧就是我们避免痛苦的生物学警告信号。恐惧警告我们潜在的伤害，并阻止我们以自我毁灭的方式行事。它帮助我们避免威胁，并促使我们采取行动防止进一步的损害。恐惧引导我们避免过去行不通的事情。恐惧会导致担心和焦虑，这是对身体危险的正常反应。它会激活肾上腺素和皮质醇等荷尔蒙，让我们时刻注意伤害，因为我们需要全神贯注才能逃避威胁。

If pain and pleasure are guides to the behaviour that leads to survival and reproduction, fear is our biological warning signal for avoiding pain. Fear warns us of potential harm and keeps us from acting in self-destructive ways. It helps us avoid threats and makes us act to prevent further damage. Fear guides us to avoid what didn’t work in the past. Fear causes worry and anxiety, a normal response to physical danger. It activates hormones like adrenaline and cortisol, which keeps us attentive to harm since we need full attention to escape from a threat.

我们感到恐惧的程度取决于我们对威胁的解释和我们对控制的看法。我们越感到无助和脆弱，我们对恐惧的情绪就越强烈。

The degree of fear we feel depends on our interpretation of the threat and our perception of control. The more helpless and vulnerable we feel, the stronger our emotion for fear becomes.

假设你深夜独自走在纽约市一条空无一人的街道上。突然，你听到身后有脚步声。会发生什么？你立刻害怕最坏的情况——抢劫、攻击等。你的自主神经系统接管并为你准备战斗或逃跑。您的反应始于大脑并激活生化过程。您的心率、呼吸、血压、脉搏和血糖都会增加。当您成为压力的受害者时的正常行为，无论是感知的还是真实的。在荒凉的街道上，你的反应是恐惧，因为进化使你的大脑比其他任何情绪都更敏感地记录疼痛。你在使用你祖先过去的“记忆”——你原始的战斗或逃跑恐惧系统。

Assume that you are walking alone late at night on a deserted street in New York City. Suddenly, you hear steps behind you. What happens? Immediately you fear the worst — robbery, assault, etc. Your autonomic nervous system takes over and prepares you for fight or flight. Your response begins in your brain and activates a biochemical process. Your heart rate, breathing, blood pressure, pulse and blood sugar increase. Normal behaviour when you are the victim of stress, either perceived or real. You reacted with fear on the deserted street because evolution equipped your brain to register pain more sensitively than any other emotion. You were using the"memory" of your ancestral past — your primitive fear system of fight or flight.

我们害怕什么和我们反应的强度取决于我们的基因、生活经历和具体情况。一开始你可能会本能地做出反应，但如果这种情况是你以前经历过的（因为我们的大脑不断地被生活经历“重新布线”），最后的反应可能是冷静下来。你可以转身发现一位老太太在遛狗。或者你可能会逃跑，因为你避免了过去痛苦的情况。我们接触到的刺激越多，甚至是可怕的刺激，我们的恐惧阈值就越高。例如，如果你以前多次走过同一条荒凉的街道，但每次都发现噪音是老太太遛狗，你就不会那么小心了。直到可怕的事情发生了。

What we fear and the strength of our reaction depend on our genes, life experiences, and the specific situation. You may react instinctively at first, but if the situation is one that you’ve experienced before (since our brain is continuously being"rewired" with life experiences), the final reaction may be to calm down. You could turn around to find an old lady walking her dog. Or you may run away, because you avoid situations that in the past have been painful. The more we are exposed to a stimulus, even a terrifying one, the higher our threshold of fear becomes. If you for example had walked the same deserted street many times before but found out each time that the noise was the old lady walking her dog, you would be less careful. Until something terrifying happened.

通常，我们的情绪会提供情感信息，帮助我们做出更好的决定。例如，内疚可能会让我们后悔做错事，并改正它们。它还可能引发合作。厌恶似乎是对危险的反应，以保护我们免受疾病或伤害。羞耻可以帮助我们避免某些诱惑或减少群体冲突的风险。由于脑损伤而无法体验情绪反应的人似乎无法从错误中吸取教训或以连贯的方式做出选择。

Often our emotions provide affective information that helps us make better decisions. For example, guilt may make us regret doing wrong things, and correct them. It may also induce cooperation. Disgust seems to be a response to danger to protect us from disease or harm. Shame may help us avoid certain temptations or reduce the risk of group-conflict. People who can’t experience emotional responses because of brain damage seem unable to learn from their mistakes or to make choices in a coherent manner.

求解释

Seeking explanations

“我吃了一种植物，现在我感到恶心。因此，我认为这种植物对我不利。”

"I ate a plant and now I feel sick. Therefore, I believe the plant was not good for me."

在《人类的由来》第二章中，查尔斯·达尔文写道：“一旦想象力、好奇心和好奇心等重要的能力以及某种推理能力得到部分发展，人类自然会渴望了解什么是人类的起源。绕过他。”

In chapter two of The Descent of Man, Charles Darwin wrote:"As soon as the important faculties of the imagination, wonder, and curiosity, together with some power of reasoning, had become partially developed, man would naturally have craved to understand what was passing around him."

我们不喜欢不确定性或未知。我们需要对世界进行分类、分类、组织和构造。对想法和对象进行分类有助于我们识别、区分和理解。它简化了生活。了解和控制我们的环境有助于我们应对未来。我们想知道事情是如何发生的，为什么会发生，以及未来会发生什么。了解事件如何发生有助于我们预测它如何再次发生。这就是为什么我们总是在对象、行为和情况之间寻找模式和因果关系。这使得识别和理解事物以及根据模式的相似性做出预测变得更加容易。寻找和识别我们环境中事物和事件之间的联系有助于我们了解什么有效，什么无效。图案也给了我们安慰，

We don’t like uncertainty or the unknown. We need to categorize, classify, organize, and structure the world. Categorizing ideas and objects helps us to recognize, differentiate and understand. It simplifies life. To understand and control our environment helps us to deal with the future. We want to know how and why things happen and what is going to happen in the future. To understand how an event happened helps us predict how it could happen again. This is why we always look for patterns and causal relationships among objects, actions, and situations. This makes it easier to identify and understand things and to make predictions based on similarities in patterns. Finding and recognizing connections between things and events in our environment helps us to learn what does and does not work. Patterns also give us comfort, making our need to find them even more important.

要了解什么有效什么无效以及什么对我们有利或不利意味着我们必须探索。成功地探索我们的环境使我们能够生存和繁衍。

To learn what works and does not and what is good or bad for us means we have to explore. Exploring our environment successfully enables our survival and reproduction.

记住地点、事实和事件很重要。但有时，大脑似乎特别容易被新信息和新奇体验所吸引。最近的研究表明大脑对新奇事物有反应。未知可能是有益的，从而激励我们探索我们的环境并为未来学习。

Remembering places, facts and events is important. But sometimes, the brain seems particularly attracted to new information and novel experiences. Recent studies suggest that the brain responds to novelty. The unknown is potentially rewarding, thereby motivating us to explore our environment and learn for the future.

我们必须灵活应对不断变化和不可预测的情况。我们经常以随机的方式探索未知。例如，许多动物在觅食时，从随机搜索开始，只有在找到有益的刺激时才会改变行为。然后他们走向它。

We must be flexible in order to deal with constant change and unpredictability. We often explore the unknown in a random fashion. For example, many animals, when foraging, start with a random search, and only change their behaviour when they find a rewarding stimulus. Then they move towards it.

保持灵活性并学习多种选择来应对世界是很有价值的。这意味着找到应对世界的新方法优于过度训练旧模式。例如，对蜜蜂的研究表明，它们根据类似地图的空间记忆组织来导航。当蜜蜂过度训练以寻找单一的花蜜地点时，它们很容易从该地点找到返回蜂巢的路，但从其他地点则不太好。但是，当同一只蜜蜂被训练到许多花蜜地点时，它们就能更好地从一系列不同的地点找到回家的路。进一步的研究表明，当我们将新信息与已知信息相结合时，我们会学得更好。

Being flexible and learning a variety of options to choose from to deal with the world is of great value. This implies that finding new ways to deal with the world is superior to over-training old patterns. For example, studies of honeybees show that they navigate according to a map-like organization of spatial memory. When bees are over-trained to find a single nectar site, it is easy for them to find their way back to the hive from that site, but not very well from other sites. But when the same bees are trained to many nectar sites, they are much better in finding their way home to the hive from a range of different locations. Further studies suggest that we learn better when we mix new information with what we already know.

进行快速分类

Making fast classifications

有一个故事，讲的是一个人去他家拜访一位教授。屋外的草坪上有一只狗在玩耍。当教授打开门让那个人进来时，狗跑进了屋子。后来教授问那个人，“你总是带着你的狗旅行吗？” 那人回答说：“这不是我的狗。我以为是你的。”

There is a story about a man who went to visit a professor at his home. Outside the house a dog was playing on the lawn. When the professor opened the door to let the man in, the dog ran into the house. Later the professor asked the man, "Do you always travel with your dog?" The man replied,"It’s not my dog. I thought it was yours."

我们的大脑天生就是先感知再思考——先使用情感再使用理性。由于我们的恐惧倾向，快速分类是自然而然的。在危险和稀缺的环境中，有限的时间和知识使得草率的概括和刻板印象对于生存至关重要。等待和权衡证据可能意味着死亡。我们不是经常下结论、冲动行事、凭情绪快速形成印象和判断吗？

Our brain is wired to perceive before it thinks — to use emotions before reason. As a consequence of our tendency for fear, fast classifications come naturally. Limited time and knowledge in a dangerous and scarce environment made hasty generalizations and stereotyping vital for survival. Waiting and weighing evidence could mean death. Don’t we often draw fast conclusions, act on impulse and use our emotions to form quick impressions and judgements?

我们特别警惕会移动的东西。它们可能意味着危险。这就是为什么当我们检测到运动时，我们会自动承担责任——有人负责。安全总比后悔好。

We are especially wary of things that move. They may imply danger. That is why we automatically assume agency — someone was responsible — when we detect motion. Better safe than sorry.

男性和女性有不同的优先级

Males and females have different priorities

“大脑是干什么用的？” 神经科学教授 Michael Gazzaniga 在The Mind's Past中问道。“这个问题的聪明答案是性。更完整地说，大脑的存在是为了就如何提高繁殖成功率做出更好的决定。” 繁殖是每一种生物生命中的核心行为。一旦一个人活过了繁衍的年龄，这个人在进化上就没有用了。

"What is the brain for?" asked Neuroscience Professor Michael Gazzaniga in The Mind’s Past."The smart-aleck answer to the question is sex. Put more completely, the brain exists to make better decisions about how to enhance reproductive success." Reproduction is the central act in the life of every living thing. Once an individual has survived past the age of reproduction, the individual is evolutionarily useless.

繁殖的斗争有时会产生特殊的效果。在自然界中，事物并不总是它们看起来的那样。

The struggle to reproduce can sometimes have peculiar effects. In nature, things are not always what they seem.

一只蚂蚁爬到草茎的顶端，然后掉下来，然后一次又一次地尝试。.. 直到一只羊过来吃草（和蚂蚁）。为什么蚂蚁坚持要爬草？蚂蚁如何受益？

An ant climbs to the top of a grass stem, falls down and tries again and again. .. until a sheep comes along and eats the grass (and the ant). WHY does the ant persist in climbing the grass? How does the ant benefit?

对蚂蚁没有任何好处。它的行为是由一种寄生扁虫操纵的，这种扁虫需要进入绵羊的肠道才能繁殖。通过控制它的中间蚂蚁宿主爬到草叶的尖端，寄生虫增加了蚂蚁被食草动物吃掉的机会。好处是寄生虫的繁殖成功，而不是蚂蚁。另一种寄生虫弓形虫只能在猫体内繁殖。它使老鼠失去对猫的遗传恐惧（猫的气味），从而使老鼠更有可能成为猫的晚餐。另一种寄生虫导致鱼在浅水区游动，这样鸟类就可以吃掉它们，这是这种寄生虫的最终宿主。

There is no benefit to the ant. Its behaviour was manipulated by a parasitic flatworm that needed to get into the gut of the sheep in order to reproduce. By commandeering its intermediate ant host to climb to the tips of the grass blades, the parasite increased the ant's chances of being eaten by a grazing animal. The benefit was to the reproductive success of the parasite, not the ant. Another parasite, Toxoplasma, can only reproduce within cats. It causes rats to lose their inherited fear of cats (cat scent) and thereby makes the rat more likely to end up as cat dinner. Another parasite causes fish to swim in shallow waters so birds can eat them, this parasite's final host.

大多数动物（包括人类）都会做一些事情来吸引异性。由于自然选择最终是关于在一个配偶有限的世界中进行繁殖，因此有些人比其他人更善于找到配偶。在吸引潜在配偶方面具有优势的个体被“选中”。什么特征给了他们优势？哪些解剖学特征或行为特征吸引异性或恐吓对手？

Most animals (including humans) do something to attract the opposite sex. Since natural selection is ultimately about reproduction in a world of limited mates, some individuals were better at getting mates than others. The individuals that had an advantage in attracting prospective mates were"selected." What characteristics gave them the advantage? What anatomical features or behavioural traits attract the opposite sex or intimidate rivals?

达尔文意识到，许多解剖学和行为特征没有任何生存价值，但可以在吸引配偶方面发挥重要作用。力量和美丽就是这样的信号。他称这种机制为性选择。例如，已经表明颜色会激发蝴蝶之间的性兴趣。雌孔雀更喜欢长着五颜六色大尾巴的孔雀。

Darwin realized that many anatomical and behavioural characteristics didn't have any survival value but could play an important role in attracting mates. Strength and beauty were such signals. He called this mechanism sexual selection. It has for example been shown that colors spark sexual interest among butterflies. And peahens prefer peacocks with big, colorful tails.

在《父母投资和性选择》一书中，生物学家罗伯特·特里弗斯说，性选择背后的力量是父母投资，或者“父母对后代个体的任何投资，以增加后代生存机会（并因此繁殖成功）为代价父母投资于其他后代的能力。”

In Parental Investment and Sexual Selection, biologist Robert Trivers says that the force behind sexual selection is parental investment, or"any investment by the parent in an individual offspring that increases the offspring's chance of surviving (and hence reproductive success) at the cost of the parent's ability to invest in other offspring."

男人需要吸引女人。但他们也需要让其他男人远离“他们的”女人。一个女人必须投资于她的每个孩子。怀孕九个月，之后多年照顾孩子。她投入了时间和精力，增加了早逝的几率。她一生可以生育的孩子数量是有限的。一个人的生育成本较低。他可以与许多女性交往并生下大量的孩子。他不需要一直在身边。许多妇女可以在没有帮助的情况下抚养孩子。

Men need to attract women. But they also need to keep other men away from"their" woman. A woman must invest in each of her children. There is a nine month pregnancy and thereafter many years of child-caring. She invests time, energy and increases her chance of earlier death. There are limits to how many children she can produce during her lifetime. A man has less costs of reproduction. He can interact with many women and produce an enormous amount of children. He doesn't need to be around all the time. Many women can raise their children without help.

由于进化的目标是繁殖，所以男人应该想和尽可能多的女人发生性关系。这导致男性之间对女性的竞争。

Since the goal of evolution is reproduction, a man should want to have sex with as many women as possible. This causes competition among men for women.

一个人如何消除这种竞争？他可以让自己对女人更有吸引力，也可以消除或减少竞争。

How does a man eliminate this competition? He can either make himself more attractive to the woman or he can eliminate or reduce the competition.

女性的生育成功并不取决于她与多少男性发生性关系，而是取决于她为自己和孩子获得资源（如食物、住所和保护）的能力。因此，女性比男性更具歧视性。她不会挑第一个人。这导致妇女相互竞争以获取资源。一个被认为富有和有地位的人有优势。因此，交配选择（表现为无意识的偏好）受到女性比男性更危险这一事实的影响。

The reproductive success of women doesn't depend on how many men she has sex with, but on her ability to get access to resources (like food, shelter, and protection) for herself and her children. Women are therefore more discriminating than men. She won't pick the first guy around. This causes women to compete with each other for access to resources. A man that is perceived as wealthy and having status has an advantage. So mating choices (showing up as unconscious preferences) are influenced by the fact that women have more at stake than men do.

1989 年，心理学教授大卫巴斯发表了一项对来自全球 37 种文化的数千名男性和女性的研究，显示了在选择某人约会或结婚时最重要的品质排名。女性更看重潜在伴侣的经济前景。女人也更喜欢有野心和勤奋的男人。女人更喜欢年长的男人。男人更喜欢年轻的女人。男性对身体吸引力的评价高于女性。该研究还表明，当他的女人与其他人发生性关系时，男人会感到最嫉妒。当她的男人对别人产生感情时，女人会感到最嫉妒。

In 1989, Psychology Professor David Buss published a study of thousands of men and women from 37 cultures around the world showing the ranking of qualities that are most important in choosing someone to date or marry. Women placed more emphasis on a potential mate's financial prospects. Women also preferred ambitious and industrious men. Women preferred older men. Men preferred younger women. Men ranked physical attractiveness higher than women did. The study also showed that a man felt most jealous when his woman was having sex with someone else. A woman felt most jealous when her man became emotionally attached to someone else.

研究显示了两性之间的其他差异。女性不太愿意冒险。他们更容易受到损失机会的影响。他们缺乏竞争力和地位意识。其他研究表明，男性和女性在行为和认知能力方面存在差异。其中一些反映了荷尔蒙对大脑发育的不同影响。像大多数事情一样，这取决于上下文。

Studies show other differences between the sexes. Women are less inclined to take risks. They are more influenced by the chance of loss. They are less competitive and status-conscious. Other studies show that men and women differ in their behavioural and cognitive capabilities. Some of this reflects varying hormonal influences on brain development. Like most things, this is context dependent.

社会动物

The Social Animal

我们不在乎我们只是路过的城镇的声誉。

但是，当我们必须停留一段时间时，我们会很在意。

需要多少时间？一段与我们虚荣而微不足道的存在相称的时间。 

We do not care about our reputation in towns where we are only passing through.

But when we have to stay some time we do care.

How much time does it take? A time proportionate to our vain and paltry existence. 

- Blaise Pascal

（法国数学家和哲学家，1623-1662）

- Blaise Pascal

(French mathematician and philosopher, 1623-1662)

难道良好的声誉、地位、资源和被社会接受可能有助于我们的祖先生存、获得配偶和繁衍后代吗？

Isn't it likely that a good reputation, status, resources and being socially accepted helped our ancestors survive, get a mate, and reproduce?

在一个小型的狩猎采集社会中，对群体有利的事情往往对个人有利。在资源有限、个人弱点和许多危险的环境中，合作至关重要。与一个群体或社会隔绝可能意味着毁灭。人多安全。该群体保护个体免受掠食者的侵害，一起狩猎，交换有关食物位置的信息，合作保护食物免受敌人侵害，并且是配偶和帮助婴儿的关键资源。这群人在一起就有更大的生存机会。

In a small hunter-gatherer society, what was good for the group often paid off for the individual. Cooperation was critical in an environment with limited resources, individual weaknesses and many dangers. Isolation from a group or society could mean destruction. There was safety in numbers. The group protected the individual against predators, hunted together, exchanged information about where food was, cooperated to defend food from enemies, and was a key resource for mates and help with infants. Together the group stood a greater chance of survival.

如果我们帮助这个小社会的另一个成员，他可能会在我们需要的时候帮助我们。如果他不这样做，我们可能再也不会帮助他了。这种行为称为互惠——“我为你挠背，你为我挠背”的想法。可靠和值得信赖的声誉很重要，因为我们过去的行为方式是我们未来行为方式的唯一指南。如果我们愚弄某人，他告诉他的朋友，这会破坏我们未来与他人合作的可能性。这不就是为什么我们相信自己的朋友，却在遇到完全不认识的陌生人时小心翼翼吗？

If we help another member of the small society, he may help us when we need it. If he doesn’t, we may never help him again. This behaviour is called reciprocation — the idea of"I scratch your back and you scratch mine." A reputation for being reliable and trustworthy is important because how we acted in the past is the only guide to how we act in the future. If we fool someone, he tells his friends, destroying our future possibilities for cooperation with others. Isn’t that why we trust our friends but are careful when we meet strangers whom we know nothing about?

我们非常关注公平性。当事情不公平时，我们会感到沮丧。我们有时甚至会以牺牲自己为代价来惩罚他人。也许我们不想显得软弱或容易被利用。由于我们在反复互动的小社区中进化，因此建立不显得软弱的声誉是有意义的。我们想鼓励人们下次对我们更好。

We have a strong concern for fairness. We get upset when things are unfair. We sometimes even punish others at a cost to ourselves. Maybe we don’t want to appear weak or easily taken advantage of. Since we evolved in small communities with repeated interactions, it made sense to build up a reputation for not appearing weak. We wanted to encourage people to treat us better the next time around.

如果我们帮助了某人，但下次我们需要帮助时，这个人却随手消失了怎么办？不还人情的人怎么办？真正的互惠只有在（1）我们生活在同一个小社会中，所以我们互相认识，可以跟踪提供和接受的“服务”，并且有未来互动的机会，以及（2）行为的成本相当与接受者收到的未来恩惠大致相同。正如生物学教授 Lee Alan Dugatkin 所说，一次性遭遇鼓励自私：

What happens if we help someone but the next time we need help, this person conveniently disappears? What about people who don’t return favours? True reciprocity only works if (1) we live in the same small society so we recognize each other, can keep track of"services" given and received, and have future opportunities to interact, and (2) the cost of the act is pretty much the same as the future favour the recipient receives. One-shot encounters encourage selfishness as told by Biology Professor Lee Alan Dugatkin:

在一次小型晚宴上……一位晚宴客人指出，当他寻找机械师时，他总是远离高速公路上的车库和靠近“街道”的地方。他说，这样的机械师知道他们再也见不到你了，而且是臭名昭著的骗子。去附近的车库，那里的口碑起到了广告作用，他们知道您将成为长期客户。
At a small dinner gathering.. .one of the dinner guests noted that when he looked for a mechanic, he always stayed away from garages on big highways and near"strips." Such mechanics, he said, knew that they were never going to see you again and were notorious shysters. Go to a neighbourhood garage, where word of mouth serves as advertising, and they know you will be a long-term customer.

“别人看得见的时候做好事。”

"Do good when others can see it."

声誉很重要。当我们被监视或我们的身份被公开时，我们的行为是否有所不同？当别人在看的时候表现得很好是值得的。一项实验室研究表明，当人们被机器人的图像“注视”时，他们会为慈善事业付出更多。现实世界的设置表明，与带有鲜花图像的海报相比，当人们在海报上被一双眼睛注视时，他们在心理学系咖啡厅盒子里投入的钱几乎增加了三倍。进一步的研究表明，当我们的善行得到公众认可时，我们会捐赠更多。美国 20 世纪作家亨利·路易斯·门肯说：“良心是内心的声音，它告诉我们有人可能正在看。”

Reputation matters. Do we behave differently when we are watched or when our identities are made public? It pays to be nice when others are watching. One lab study showed that people gave much more to charity when they were"watched" by images of a robot. A real-world setting showed that people nearly trebled the amount of money they put in a psychology department coffee room box when they were watched by a pair of eyes on a poster, compared with a poster with an image of flowers. Further studies have shown that we donate more when we get public recognition for our good deeds. American 20th Century writer Henry Louis Mencken said:"Conscience is the inner voice that tells us someone might be looking."

害怕失败、失去社会地位或声誉等特征很重要，因为它们会影响个人在祖先狩猎采集社会中的地位。获得食物和性生活取决于此。生存和繁殖可能受到威胁。社会惩罚是危险的。它可能导致流亡。根据人类生态学教授 Garrett Hardin 的说法，今天也是一样：

Traits like fear of failure, losing social status or reputation were important because they affected an individual's standing in the ancestral hunter-gatherer society. Access to food and sex depended on it. Survival and reproduction could be threatened. Social punishment was dangerous. It could lead to exile. According to Human Ecology Professor Garrett Hardin, it is the same today:

害怕不赞成是保持社会完整的主要力量：害怕上帝，害怕警察，害怕邻居的判断。宗教当局希望对上帝的敬畏成为主要的控制者。民政当局希望对警察和法院的恐惧占主导地位。但是，洛克 [约翰] 说，邻居的意见胜过其他所有人。
Fear of disapproval is the major force that keeps a society intact: fear of God, fear of the police, and fear of the judgement of neighbours. Religious authorities want the fear of God to be the predominant controller. Civil authorities want fear of police and court to dominate. But, says Locke [John], the opinion of one's neighbours trumps all others.

提供资源是另一种增加生存机会和获得配偶机会的行为。我们提供的能力越好，我们在社区中的地位就越高。

Providing resources is another behaviour that increases chances of survival and getting a mate. The better our ability to provide, the higher our status would be in the community.

正如我们之前看到的，男人之间存在着对女人的竞争。妇女相互竞争以获取资源。女人想要可以照顾孩子的男人。吃、住、地位等资源吸引了他们。争取权威、支配、尊重、地位和尊重是财富的广告。查尔斯·达尔文说：“人类钦佩并经常试图夸大自然赋予他的任何特征。”

As we saw earlier there is competition among men for women. Women compete with each other for access to resources. Women wanted males who could take care of the children. Resources like food, lodging, and status attracted them. Striving for authority, dominance, esteem, position, and respect were advertisements for wealth. Charles Darwin said:"Man admires and often tries to exaggerate whatever characteristics nature may have given him."

还有什么其他证据表明人类是群居动物？对妻子患乳腺癌致死病例的一组男性进行的一项研究表明，鳏夫的免疫系统活性较低。另一项研究表明，社会孤立的男性比社会融合度更高的人更容易死亡。还表明，社会排斥感觉类似于身体疼痛。拒绝很痛！

What other evidence is there that humans are social animals? One study of a group of men whose wives suffered fatal cases of breast cancer showed that the widowers had lower immune system activity. Another study showed that men who were socially isolated were more likely to die than more socially integrated people were. It has also been shown that social rejection feels similar to physical pain. Rejection hurts!

啄食顺序也很重要。当我们争取地位时，等级制度就会出现。挪威动物学家 Thorleif Schjelderup-Ebbe 发现，在母鸡的世界中，有一个线性等级制度，每只母鸡都知道自己的位置。科学作家罗伯特赖特在The Moral Animal中说：“把一群母鸡放在一起，经过一段时间的动荡，包括许多战斗，事情就会平静下来。争论......现在将是简短而决定性的，因为一只母鸡只是啄对方，带来快速的推迟。”

Pecking order also matters. As we strive for status, hierarchies emerge. Norwegian zoologist Thorleif Schjelderup-Ebbe discovered that in the world of hens there is a linear hierarchy where every hen knows its place. Science writer Robert Wright says in The Moral Animal:"Throw a bunch of hens together, and, after a time of turmoil, including much combat, things will settle down. Disputes...will now be brief and decisive, as one hen simply pecks the other, bringing quick deferral."

啄食顺序决定了谁先有机会进食，以及哪只母鸡可以啄食其他母鸡。每只母鸡都知道它可以支配谁，反过来，谁将支配它。

The pecking order determines who gets the first chance to eat, and which hen can peck the other hens. Each hen knows who it can dominate, and in turn, who will dominate it.

地位等级制度不仅对母鸡有效。研究表明，当我们把一群孩子放在一起时，他们很快就会分成不同的年级。位于顶部的那些最受喜爱、最常被模仿和最服从。一旦获得地位，失去地位是痛苦的。

Status hierarchies aren’t only valid for hens. Studies show that when we put a group of children together, they will shortly fall into separate grades. The ones at the top are best liked, most often imitated, and most obeyed. It is painful to lose status once it has been obtained.

研究表明，我们在社会阶梯上所处的位置会影响我们的健康、福祉和寿命。我们在啄食顺序中的地位越高，我们可能越健康。

Studies show that where we stand on the social ladder influences our health, well-being and length of life. The higher our status in the pecking order, the healthier we are likely to be.

我们必须小心，不要将这些关于适应性行为的进化解释解释得太过火。行为的原因有很多。我们无法通过推断祖先环境的条件来解释每一种行为。祖传环境如何，无人知晓。与骨骼和组织不同，没有行为的化石证据。也没有任何神经学或遗传学证据支持或反对某些行为。关于大脑的进化解释无法通过实验检验。随处可见的特征不一定是基因指定的。但所描述的大部分行为与我们从其他生物体和记录的人类历史中获得的证据是一致的。

We must be careful not to carry these evolutionary explanations about adaptive behaviour too far. There are many causes for behaviour. We can’t extrapolate the conditions of the ancestral environment to explain every behaviour. No one knows what the ancestral environment was like. Unlike bone and tissue, there is no fossil evidence of behaviour. Neither is there any neurological or genetic evidence for or against certain behaviour. And evolutionary explanations about the brain can’t be experimentally tested. A trait that is found everywhere isn’t necessarily genetically specified. But much of the behaviour described is consistent with evidence we have from other organisms and documented human history.

让我们回到一百万年前，假设您生活在一个拥有 150 人的小社区中，每个人都彼此认识，而且交配机会有限。环境充满了危险和挑战。关键是要避免危险，获得食物并吸引伙伴。什么行为对生存和繁殖至关重要？

Let’s go back one million years and assume you were living in a small community with 150 people where everybody knew each other, and where the mating opportunities were limited. The environment was fraught with danger and challenges. The key was to avoid danger, get food and attract a partner. What behaviour was critical to survival and reproduction?

做出快速判断不是很有意义吗？——“如果灌木丛后面有声音，那就跑吧。” 冲动行事是一种自然倾向——在理性之前使用情感。在我们的进化史上对生存和繁殖至关重要的行为今天仍然适用。恐惧不会帮助你生存吗？社会失败代价高昂？维持地位、资源和社会认同有助于你生存并找到伴侣？

Isn’t it rewarding to make fast judgements? —"If noise behind the bush, then run." It is a natural tendency to act on impulse — to use emotions before reason. The behaviour that was critical for survival and reproduction in our evolutionary history still applies today. Wouldn’t being fearful help you survive? Social failure be costly? Maintaining status, resources and social approval help you survive and get a mate?

难道你不会表现得诚实、友善和值得信赖，这样别人就会与你合作吗？共同的威胁或共同的目标难道不会促使人们合作吗？遵守社会规范没有意义吗？你不会对损失有强烈的厌恶感，只有在受到威胁时才会冒很大的风险吗？难道你不关心自己和亲人的短期利益吗？

Wouldn’t you present yourself as honest, nice and trustworthy so others will cooperate with you? Wouldn’t a common threat or a common goal make people cooperate? Wouldn’t following social norms make sense? Wouldn’t you have a strong aversion to losses and only take big risks when you were threatened? Wouldn’t you be concerned with the short-term interest of yourself and loved ones?

我们的大部分心理是文化影响的结果

Much of our psychology is the result of cultural influences

人类社会不仅受到基因进化的影响，也受到文化进化的影响。对我们行为的演变很重要的实践、方法、工具、神话、道德和社会规范。我们从父母和其他人的经验中学到的习俗——无论是通过教导还是观察。

Human society is not only shaped by the evolution of genes, but also by cultural evolution. Practices, methods, tools, myths, ethics, and social norms that are important in the evolution of our behaviour. Customs that we learn from the experience of our parents and others — either by teaching or observation.

文化进化比基因进化更快，因为它允许我们所学的大部分知识得以传承，并与我们周围其他人所学的知识相结合。与生物进化不同，文化进化不是遗传的。我们不会继承父母的习惯。我们向他们学习。

Cultural evolution is faster than genetic evolution since it allows much of what we learn to be passed on and combined with what others around us have learned. Unlike biological evolution, cultural evolution is not inherited. We don’t inherit our parents’ habits. We learn from them.

从某种意义上说，遗传和文化进化相互作用。生物学影响着我们的文化。以语言为例。我们配备了解剖学、生理学和生物化学知识，使我们有能力学习语言。但我们并非天生就有语言。我们所说的语言是我们文化的产物。

In a sense, genetic and cultural evolution interact. Biology influences our culture. Take language as an example. We come equipped with an anatomy, physiology and biochemistry that give us the ability to learn a language. But we are not born with a language. The language we speak is a product of our culture.

我们的文化还通过创造测试自然选择的环境来影响我们的生物学。如果某种行为被证明对一代又一代有益，那么这种行为就会受到自然选择的青睐。假设个人随着时间的推移做出某些社会行为选择。这些选择是通过学习和文化传播的。随着时间的推移，它们将受到自然选择的青睐，因为它们对生存和繁殖产生积极影响。

Our culture also influences our biology by creating the environment in which natural selection is tested. If a certain behaviour proves to be beneficial generation over generation, that behaviour is favoured by natural selection. Assume individuals over time make certain social behaviour choices. These choices were transmitted through learning and culture. Over time, they will be favoured by natural selection since they positively influence survival and reproduction.

我们的基本性质

Our basic nature

人性相似；正是他们的习惯使他们相距甚远。

Men's natures are alike; it is their habits that carry them far apart.

——孔子

- Confucius

我们的基本本性是什么？

What is our basic nature?

我们的本性是我们生物和文化历史的产物。进化论解释了我们是如何被塑造和在生物学上受到限制的。就像我们的骨骼、肾脏、眼睛和腿一样，我们的大脑也是通过自然选择塑造的。自然选择为我们提供了增加生存和繁殖机会的特征。随之而来的是，我们有意识或无意识地根据我们认为最符合我们自身利益的行为行事。这是我们的生物本性。它会根据我们的生活经历而增强或减弱。如果我们假设人们的平均行为是出于自利，那么我们就不会比假设人们的平均行为是出于利他主义而感到失望。这并不意味着我们不能让事情变得更好。但这样做需要我们首先了解为什么我们是现在的样子。理查德道金斯说自私的基因：“请注意，如果你像我一样希望建立一个个人慷慨无私地为共同利益而合作的社会，你就不能指望生物本性提供什么帮助。让我们尝试教导慷慨和利他主义，因为我们生来就是自私的。”

Our nature is a product of our biological and cultural history. Evolution explains how we are shaped and biologically constrained. Like our bones, kidney, eyes, and legs, our brain has been shaped by natural selection. Natural selection equipped us with traits that increase our chances for survival and reproduction. It then follows that we consciously or unconsciously behave according to what we perceive is in our own best interest. This is our biological base nature. It is strengthened or weakened depending on our life experiences. If we assume that people on average act out of self-interest we’ll be less disappointed than if we assume that people on average act out of altruism. This does not mean that we can’t make things better. But doing so demands that we first understand why we are the way we are. Richard Dawkins said in The Selfish Gene:"Be warned that if you wish, as I do, to build a society in which individuals cooperate generously and unselfishly towards a common good, you can expect little help from biological nature. Let us try to teach generosity and altruism, because we are born selfish."

让我们总结一下影响我们判断的力量，并为我们的判断设定限制。

Let’s summarize the forces that influence and set the limits for our judgements.

基因- 环境刺激会引起我们基因的反应倾向。我们的基因已经进化，它们的功能主要基于狩猎-采集环境中有益的东西——人类大部分时间都在这个环境中度过。为了生存，我们必须避免所有对我们生存和繁衍的感知威胁。进化发展了一个基于痛苦和快乐的价值体系，帮助我们应对环境。由于祖先的环境包括有限的资源和危险，我们对损失产生了强烈的厌恶和恐惧的倾向。我们做出了快速的评估，成为了社会动物。我们倾向于通过恐惧来评估情况。不以恐惧回应可能比以恐惧回应并犯错的代价更高。我们还以奖励很重要且成本最低的方式行事。

Genes- environmental stimuli cause response tendencies from our genes. Our genes have evolved and their functions are primarily based on what was beneficial in the hunter-gatherer environment — the environment where humans spent most of their time. To survive, we must avoid all perceived threats to our survival and reproduction. Evolution has developed a value system based on pain and pleasure that help us deal with the environment. Since the ancestral environment consisted of limited resources and danger, we developed a strong aversion for loss and a tendency for fear. We made fast evaluations and became social animals. We were predisposed to evaluate situations by being fearful. To not respond with fear could be more costly than responding with fear and being wrong. We also acted in ways where the reward was important and the cost was minimal.

生活经历——教养、营养、教育、社会印记、物质、社会和文化环境创造了某些信念、习惯、价值观、态度和性格特征。这反过来又创造了我们个人的信念和假设。我们的判断受我们的心态影响。

Life experiences - upbringing, nutrition, education, social stamping, physical, social and cultural settings create certain convictions, habits, values, attitudes and character traits. This in turn creates our individual beliefs and assumptions. Our judgements are influenced by our state of mind.

当前环境——外部因素，如环境、上下文或情况，或特定情况。

Present environment — outside factors like the environment, the context or circumstances, or the specific situation.

随机性——我们准备好对新体验持开放态度，因为环境各不相同；应对新的挑战是适应的一种方式。

Randomness — we are prepared to be open minded to new experiences since environments vary; handling new challenges is a means of adaptation.

我们行为的后果强化了某些行为。如果结果是有益的，我们的行为很可能会重复。我们认为奖励是因人而异的。奖励可以是健康、金钱、工作、名誉、家庭、地位或权力等任何事物。在所有这些活动中，我们只做有效的事情。这就是我们适应的方式。环境选择我们未来的行为。

The consequences of our actions reinforce certain behaviour. If the consequences were rewarding, our behaviour is likely to be repeated. What we consider rewarding is individual specific. Rewards can be anything from health, money, job, reputation, family, status, or power. In all of these activities, we do what works. This is how we adapt. The environment selects our future behaviour.

但重要的不仅仅是发生在我们身上的事情。这就是我们认为发生的事情。当我们面对一种情况时，我们的大脑会产生一种期望。如果我们不了解后果，我们可能会以违背自身利益的方式行事。

But it’s not just what happens to us that counts. It’s what we think happens. When we face a situation, our brains create an expectation. We can act in ways contrary to our self-interest if we don’t understand the consequences.

我们的行为会产生来自环境的反馈。如果我们做了愚蠢的事情并承担了后果，即使它会造成痛苦，我们将来可能还会做愚蠢的事情。要么是因为我们不了解错误的原因，要么是这种痛苦没有其他行为那么痛苦。

Our behaviour creates feedback from our environment. If we do dumb things and suffer the consequences, we may still do dumb things in the future even if it causes pain. Either because we don’t understand the cause of our mistake, or the pain is less painful than other behaviour.

我们的经历存储在大脑中，并在未来影响我们。创建了神经元之间的新连接模式。

Our experiences are stored in the brain and influence us in the future. New connecting patterns between neurons are created.

有些决定不符合我们的最佳利益

Some decisions are not in our best interest

人性中肯定有大量的愚蠢，

否则人们就不会一千次地落入同样的陷阱，

当他们还记得他们过去的不幸时，继续诉诸法律并鼓励这些事业他们所欠的，并将再次产生他们。

There must certainly be a vast fund of stupidity in human nature,

else men would not be caught as they are, a thousand times over, by the same snare,

and while they yet remember their past misfortunes, go on to court and encourage the causes to which they are owing, and which will again produce them.

- Marcus Porcius Cato

（罗马政治家和作家，公元前 234-149 年）

- Marcus Porcius Cato

(Roman statesman and writer, 234-149 BC)

如果我们经常出于自身利益行事，为什么我们会做出明显不符合我们最佳利益的决定？

If we often act out of self-interest, why do we make decisions that are clearly not in our best interests?

我们的大脑适应的祖先世界与今天的世界之间存在脱节。我们的许多特征更适合祖先世界的需求，例如：远离掠食者、冒着被社会排斥的风险、寻找伴侣、获得足够的食物、维持关系、获得地位和安全的居住地以及生育孩子。

There is a disconnect between the ancestral world to which our brains adapted and today’s world. Many of our traits are better adapted for the demands of the ancestral world such as: keeping away from predators, risking social exclusion, finding mates, getting enough food, maintaining relationships, acquiring status and a safe place to live, and bearing children.

遗传和文化进化使我们具备了行为倾向（如恐惧倾向、互惠合作、快速分类、关注社会认同等），帮助我们与环境互动。平均而言，这些倾向比没有帮助更有帮助（否则我们今天不会在这里）。有时它们会让我们误入歧途，导致我们做出错误的判断。

Genetic and cultural evolution equipped us with behavioural tendencies (like the tendency for fear, reciprocal cooperation, fast classifications, concern for social approval, etc.) that help us interact with our environment. These tendencies are on average more helpful than not (otherwise we wouldn’t be here today). Sometimes they lead us astray and cause us to make misjudgements.

例如，我们可能会因为自动倾向于相信我们喜欢的人而产生偏见。喜欢往往基于第一印象。我们非常有能力阅读其他人是否值得信赖的迹象。我们观察他们的情绪状态——他们的声音和一般表情。然而，通常很难区分好演员和坏演员。一个人可能神秘而充满敌意，也可能热情而开放。这些不同的行为会对我们对那个人的看法产生什么影响？我们忘记考虑在评估一个人或一种情况时很重要的其他因素。外表可能具有欺骗性。最好的骗子总是表现得好像他们没有为自己的最大利益行事。16世纪意大利政治哲学家尼科罗·马基雅维利在《君主论》中说：“成就大事的君子，都是轻言轻语，懂得以狡诈欺人，最终战胜守信的人。”

For example, we may be biased by our automatic tendency to trust the people we like. Liking is often based on first impressions. We are superbly equipped to read other people for signs of trustworthiness. We look at their emotional state — their voice and general expression. However, it is often difficult to spot the difference between a good and bad actor. An individual may be secretive and hostile, or warm and open. What consequences would these different behaviours have on our perception of that individual? We forget to think about other factors that are important in evaluating a person or a situation. Appearances may be deceiving. The best con artists always behave as though they are not acting in their best interest. The 16th Century Italian political philosopher Niccolo Machiavelli said in The Prince:"Princes who have achieved great things have been those who have given their word lightly, who have known how to trick men with their cunning, and who, in the end, have overcome those abiding by honest principles."

在第一部分中，我们了解了我们的本性和局限性。有了这个背景，现在让我们看看我们的心理能力如何影响我们的决策。

In Part One we have learned about our nature and our limitations. With this background let us now look at how our psychological abilities affect our decision making.

沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 向我们介绍了为什么即使是聪明人也会得到糟糕的结果：

Warren Buffett gives us some introductory remarks on why even smart people get bad results:

它的自我。这是贪婪。是嫉妒。是恐惧。这是对其他人的盲目模仿。我的意思是，有多种因素会导致思维的马力在输出结果出现之前急剧下降。我想说，如果查理和我有任何优势，那不是因为我们聪明，而是因为我们很理性，我们很少让外来因素干扰我们的想法。我们不让别人的意见干扰它……当别人贪婪时，我们试图变得恐惧。当别人恐惧时，我们试图变得贪婪。我们尽量避免模仿他人的行为。这些都是导致聪明人得到坏结果的因素。
Its ego. It’s greed. It’s envy. It’s fear. It’s mindless imitation of other people. I mean, there are a variety of factors that cause that horsepower of the mind to get diminished dramatically before the output turns out. And I would say if Charlie and I have any advantage it’s not because we’re so smart, it is because we’re rational and we very seldom let extraneous factors interfere with our thoughts. We don’t let other people’s opinion interfere with it... we try to get fearful when others are greedy. We try to get greedy when others are fearful. We try to avoid any kind of imitation of other people’s behaviour. And those are the factors that cause smart people to get bad results.

我一直把智商和天赋看成是代表马达的马力，但是在输出方面，马达工作的效率，取决于理性。那是因为很多人都是从400马力的电机开始，然后得到了100马力的输出。最好有一个 200 马力的电机并将其全部投入输出。那么，为什么聪明人做的事情会干扰他们获得应有的产出呢？它进入习惯、性格和气质，真正进入以理性的方式行事。不妨碍自己。

I always look at IQ and talent as representing the horsepower of the motor, but then in terms of the output, the efficiency with which the motor works, depends on rationality. That’s because a lot of people start out with 400-horsepower motors and get a hundred horsepower of output. It’s way better to have a 200-horsepower motor and get it all into output. So why do smart people do things that interfere with getting the output they’re entitled to? It gets into the habits, and character and temperament, and it really gets into behaving in a rational manner. Not getting in your own way.

在第二部分、第三部分和第四部分中，我们使用了两个虚构人物，名叫约翰和玛丽。40 岁的约翰是 TransCorp 的高级管理人员；一家从事多种业务的美国公司。约翰与兼职教师玛丽结婚。

In Part Two, Three, and Four we use two fictional characters named John and Mary. At 40, John is a senior executive of TransCorp; a US company engaged in widely varied businesses. John is married to Mary, a part-time schoolteacher.

第二部分：

误判心理学

Part Two:

The Psychology of Misjudgements

为什么啊，为什么人类这么难教，却这么容易欺骗。

Why oh why are human beings so hard to teach, but so easy to deceive.

- Dio Chrysostom

（希腊哲学家和演说家，2 世纪）

- Dio Chrysostom

(Greek philosopher and orator, 2nd Century)

一：心理学解释的误判

One: Misjudgements Explained by Psychology

我几乎违背了自己的意愿来研究人类误判的心理学；我拒绝了它，直到我意识到我的态度让我损失了很多钱，并削弱了我帮助我所爱的一切的能力。

I came to the psychology of human misjudgement almost against my will; I rejected it until I realized that my attitude was costing me a lot of money, and reduced my ability to help everything I loved.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

第一部分向我们介绍了我们的行为、心理和局限性的背景。我们了解了痛苦和快乐如何引导我们的行为，我们如何倾向于对事件采取最有价值的观点，我们如何做出快速判断，以及我们是群居动物。我们还看到了我们如何对损失和不确定性产生强烈的厌恶，以及人们如何自然而然地以他们认为符合他们最大利益的方式行事。

Part One gave us a background of our behaviour, psychology and limitations. We learned how pain and pleasure guide our behaviour, how we tend to take the most rewarding view of events, how we make quick judgements, and are social animals. We also saw how we have developed a strong aversion to loss and uncertainty, and how it is natural for people to behave in ways they perceive is in their best interests.

查尔斯芒格说，“如果你想避免非理性，了解你自己心理线路中的怪癖会有所帮助，然后你就可以采取适当的预防措施。” 这部分探讨了 28 个可以用我们的心理构成来解释的误判原因。许多原因都源于心理倾向和偏见，这些倾向和偏见常常会在潜意识中影响我们。我们越情绪化、困惑、不确定、不安全、兴奋、分心、疲倦或压力越大，我们就越容易犯错误。不排除天才。

Charles Munger says,"If you want to avoid irrationality, it helps to understand the quirks in your own mental wiring and then you can take appropriate precautions." This part explores 28 reasons for misjudgements that can be explained by our psychological make-up. Many of the reasons are rooted in psychological tendencies and biases that often influence us subconsciously. The more emotional, confused, uncertain, insecure, excited, distracted, tired or stressed we are, the easier we make mistakes. Geniuses aren’t excluded.

下面列出了导致错误判断和错误的 28 个原因。它可以用作解释或预测行为的清单，也可以用作飞行员的清单来避免自欺欺人。列表中的每个项目将在下一章中解释。

Below is a list of 28 reasons for misjudgements and mistakes. It can be used as a check-lists to explain or predict behaviour or as a pilot’s check-lists to avoid fooling ourselves. Each item on the list will be explained in the next chapter.

  1. 单纯联想的偏见——自动将刺激与痛苦或快乐联系起来；包括喜欢或不喜欢与坏事或好事相关的事物。包括因为情况看起来相似而将其视为相同。还有来自波斯信使综合症的偏见——不想成为坏消息的传播者。

  2. Bias from mere association - automatically connecting a stimulus with pain or pleasure; including liking or disliking something associated with something bad or good. Includes seeing situations as identical because they seem similar. Also bias from Persian Messenger Syndrome - not wanting to be the carrier of bad news.

  3. 低估奖励和惩罚的力量——人们重复导致奖励的行为并避免他们受到惩罚的行为。

  4. Underestimating the power of rewards and punishment - people repeat actions that result in rewards and avoid actions that they are punished for.

  5. 低估来自自身利益和动机的偏见。

  6. Underestimating bias from own self-interest and incentives.

  7. 自利偏见——对我们的能力和未来过于积极的看法。包括过度乐观。

  8. Self-serving bias — overly positive view of our abilities and future. Includes over-optimism.

  9. 自欺欺人和否认——扭曲现实以减少痛苦或增加快乐。包括一厢情愿。

  10. Self-deception and denial — distortion of reality to reduce pain or increase pleasure. Includes wishful thinking.

  11. 来自一致性倾向的偏见——与我们先前的承诺和想法保持一致，即使在违背我们的最大利益或面对不确凿的证据时也是如此。包括确认偏差——寻找证实我们的行为和信念的证据，并忽略或歪曲不证实的证据。

  12. Bias from consistency tendency — being consistent with our prior commitments and ideas even when acting against our best interest or in the face of disconfirming evidence. Includes confirmation bias - looking for evidence that confirms our actions and beliefs and ignoring or distorting disconfirming evidence.

  13. 剥夺综合症的偏见——当我们喜欢和拥有（或几乎拥有）的东西被（或威胁被）带走或“丢失”时，会做出强烈反应（包括渴望和重视）。包括渴望和重视我们无法拥有或（或可能）难以获得的东西。

  14. Bias from deprival syndrome — strongly reacting (including desiring and valuing more) when something we like and have (or almost have) is (or threatens to be) taken away or"lost." Includes desiring and valuing more what we can’t have or what is (or threatens to be) less available.

  15. 现状偏见和无所事事综合症——保持现状。包括最大限度地减少工作量和对默认选项的偏好。

  16. Status quo bias and do-nothing syndrome - keeping things the way they are. Includes minimizing effort and a preference for default options.

  17. 不耐烦——看重现在甚于未来。

  18. Impatience - valuing the present more highly than the future.

  19. 来自嫉妒和嫉妒的偏见。

  20. Bias from envy and jealousy.

  21. 通过对比比较失真——判断和感知某物的绝对大小不是根据它本身，而是仅基于它与在时间或空间上紧密呈现的其他事物或与某些较早的适应水平的差异。也低估了随着时间的推移逐渐变化的后果。

  22. Distortion by contrast comparison — judging and perceiving the absolute magnitude of something not by itself but based only on its difference to something else presented closely in time or space or to some earlier adaptation level. Also underestimating the consequences over time of gradual changes.

  23. 锚定偏差——过度权衡某些初始信息作为未来决策的参考点。

  24. Bias from anchoring - over-weighing certain initial information as a reference point for future decisions.

  25. 受到生动或最新信息的过度影响。

  26. Over-influence by vivid or the most recent information.

  27. 遗漏和抽象盲——只看到我们遇到的或引起我们注意的刺激，而忽略了重要的缺失信息或摘要。包括在注意失明中。

  28. Omission and abstract blindness — only seeing stimuli we encounter or that grabs our attention, and neglecting important missing information or the abstract. Includes in attentional blindness.

  29. 来自回报倾向的偏见——以实物回报他人为我们所做的事情，例如恩惠、让步、信息和态度。

  30. Bias from reciprocation tendency — repaying in kind what others have done for or to us like favours, concessions, information and attitudes.

  31. 偏好倾向导致过度影响的偏见——相信、信任和同意我们认识和喜欢的人。包括因过度渴望喜欢和社会接受以及避免社会反对而产生的偏见。还有来自不喜欢的偏见——我们倾向于避免和不同意我们不喜欢的人。

  32. Bias from over-influence by liking tendency - believing, trusting and agreeing with people we know and like. Includes bias from over-desire for liking and social acceptance and for avoiding social disapproval. Also bias from disliking — our tendency to avoid and disagree with people we don’t like.

  33. 因社会证明的过度影响而产生的偏见——模仿许多其他人或类似其他人的行为。包括人群愚蠢。

  34. Bias from over-influence by social proof — imitating the behaviour of many others or similar others. Includes crowd folly.

  35. 来自权威过度影响的偏见——信任和服从公认的权威或专家。

  36. Bias from over-influence by authority - trusting and obeying a perceived authority or expert.

  37. 意义建构——构建符合结果的解释。包括过快下结论。还认为已经发生的事件比它们更容易预测。

  38. Sense making — Constructing explanations that fit an outcome. Includes being too quick in drawing conclusions. Also thinking events that have happened were more predictable than they were.

  39. Reason-respecting——仅仅因为我们得到了一个理由就遵守请求。包括低估给人们理由的力量。

  40. Reason-respecting - complying with requests merely because we’ve been given a reason. Includes underestimating the power in giving people reasons.

  41. 先相信后怀疑——相信不真实的东西，尤其是在分心的时候。

  42. Believing first and doubting later — believing what is not true, especially when distracted.

  43. 记忆力限制——有选择地和错误地记忆。包括建议的影响。

  44. Memory limitations — remembering selectively and wrong. Includes influence by suggestions.

  45. 做某事综合症——没有合理理由的行为。

  46. Do-something syndrome — acting without a sensible reason.

  47. 说话综合症引起的精神混乱——当我们无话可说时，觉得有必要说些什么。

  48. Mental confusion from say-something syndrome — feeling a need to say something when we have nothing to say.

  49. 情绪激动——在强烈情绪的影响下做出仓促的判断。包括夸大未来事件的情绪影响。

  50. Emotional arousal — making hasty judgements under the influence of intense emotions. Includes exaggerating the emotional impact of future events.

  51. 压力造成的精神混乱。

  52. Mental confusion from stress.

  53. 身体或心理上的痛苦、化学品或疾病的影响造成的精神混乱。

  54. Mental confusion from physical or psychological pain, the influence of chemicals or diseases.

  55. 由于许多心理倾向共同作用的综合影响而产生的过度影响的偏差。

  56. Bias from over-influence by the combined effect of many psychological tendencies operating together.

这些心理倾向（也相互作用）已被大量实验证实。有些人比其他人更容易受到伤害。但是我们不能独立于个人的价值观和情况来研究它们。从个人的角度来看，看似非理性的行为可能是完全理性的。总有一些行为有意义的背景。行为不能被视为独立于上下文的理性或非理性。我们生来就有一系列情绪，这些情绪视情况而定。如果我们改变背景或环境，我们就会改变行为。

These psychological tendencies (that also interact) have been verified by a number of experiments. Some people are more vulnerable to them than others. But we can’t study them independent of an individual’s values and the situation. behaviour that seems irrational may be fully rational from the individual’s point of view. There is always some background within which behaviour makes sense. behaviour can’t be seen as rational or irrational independent of context. We are created with a series of emotions that are appropriate depending on circumstances. If we change context or environment, we change behaviour.

下一章描述了我们做出错误判断和错误的 28 个心理原因。请注意，这些偏见和倾向往往不是相互独立的。有一些重叠。还要注意，特定行为的原因有很多。许多现实世界的插图可以用不止一种趋势和非心理因素来解释。误判往往是多种因素共同作用造成的。

The next chapter describes the 28 psychological reasons why we make misjudgements and mistakes. Observe that these biases and tendencies are often not independent of one another. There is some overlap. Observe also that there are many reasons for a given behaviour. Many of the real-world illustrations can be explained by more than one tendency and also by non-psychological factors. Misjudgements are often caused by many factors working together.

大多数解释都是基于查尔斯·芒格、心理学教授罗伯特·西奥迪尼、行为科学与经济学教授理查德·塞勒、心理学教授罗宾·道斯、心理学教授丹尼尔·吉尔伯特以及心理学教授丹尼尔·卡尼曼和已故的阿莫斯·特沃斯基所做的工作。

Most of the explanations are based on work done by Charles Munger, Psychology Professor Robert Cialdini, behavioural Science and Economics Professor Richard Thaler, Psychology Professor Robyn Dawes, Psychology Professor Daniel Gilbert, and Psychology Professors Daniel Kahneman and the late Amos Tversky.

二：犯错的心理原因

Two: Psychological Reasons For Mistakes

人是，而且一直是，一个笨蛋和笨蛋，比思考和考虑更容易去感受和消化。

Man is, and always was, a block-head and dullard, much readier to feel and digest than to think and consider.

- 托马斯·卡莱尔（苏格兰历史学家，1795-1881 年）

- Thomas Carlyle (Scottish historian, 1795-1881)

1. 单纯的联想

1. Mere Association

在珠宝精品店内，四周环绕着迷人的音乐和美丽的女人，约翰怎么忍心不给玛丽买下价值 5,000 美元的项链？

Inside the jewelry boutique, surrounded by enchanting music and gorgeous women, how could John resist not buying Mary the $5,000 necklace?

当我们将刺激（事物、情况或个人）与我们过去的经历或我们与生俱来的价值观或偏好联系起来时，我们会自动感到快乐或痛苦。正如我们所了解的，我们会转向与快乐相关的刺激，而远离与痛苦相关的刺激。我们最容易将其后果我们最常经历的事件和我们最容易记住的事件联系起来。事件越生动或戏剧化，我们就越容易记住它。

We automatically feel pleasure or pain when we connect a stimulus — a thing, situation or individual - with an experience we’ve had in the past or with values or preferences we are born with. As we’ve learned, we move towards stimuli we associate with pleasure and away from those we associate with pain. We most easily associate to the events whose consequences we have experienced most often and the ones we easily remember. The more vivid or dramatic an event is, the easier we remember it.

每次玛丽早餐吃培根时，她都会唱一首特别的旋律。过了一会儿，如果约翰听到她唱的旋律，他期待培根。

Every time Mary served bacon for breakfast, she sung a special melody. After awhile, if John heard her singing the melody, he expected bacon.

俄罗斯科学家伊万·巴甫洛夫 (Ivan Pavlov) 研究了狗的消化系统，他观察到与食物无关的刺激会使狗分泌唾液。在一次实验中，他在给狗喂食之前按了铃。他重复了几次，直到狗一听到铃声就流口水了。没有看到或闻到食物。钟声产生了与食物相同的反应。狗学会了将铃铛与食物联系起来。

The Russian scientist Ivan Pavlov studied the digestive system of dogs when he observed that a stimulus unrelated to food made the dogs salivate. In one experiment he rang a bell just before giving food to the dog. He repeated this several times until the dog salivated at the sound of the bell alone. No sight or smell of food was present. The sound of the bell produced the same response as the food. The dog learned to associate the bell with food.

实验表明，如果无害的刺激与不愉快的刺激相结合，我们可以学会害怕它。例如，如果老鼠在听到某种音调后持续受到轻度电击，老鼠就会学会只对这种音调产生恐惧。

Experiments have shown that we can learn to fear a harmless stimulus if it is paired with an unpleasant one. If for example rats consistently receive mild electrical shock after hearing a tone, the rats learn to develop a fear of the tone alone.

协会可以影响免疫系统。一项实验研究了老鼠的食物厌恶。老鼠喝了糖精味的水（糖精由于其甜味而具有激励价值）以及一种产生恶心的药物。老鼠下次单独喝糖精水时会出现恶心的迹象吗？是的，但是小鼠也发生了感染。众所周知，这种药物除了会产生恶心外，还会削弱免疫系统，但为什么单独使用糖精会有这种效果呢？仅仅是糖精与药物的配对就会使小鼠的免疫系统了解这种关联。因此，每当老鼠遇到糖精时，它的免疫系统就会减弱，使老鼠容易受到感染。

Association can influence the immune system. One experiment studied food aversion in mice. Mice got saccharin-flavored water (saccharin has incentive value due to its sweet taste) along with a nausea-producing drug. Would the mice show signs of nausea the next time they got saccharin water alone? Yes, but the mice also developed infections. It was known that the drug in addition to producing nausea, weakened the immune system, but why would saccharin alone have this effect? The mere pairing of the saccharin with the drug caused the mouse immune system to learn the association. Therefore, every time the mouse encountered the saccharin, its immune system weakened making the mouse vulnerable to infections.

John 的供应商带他去了镇上最好的牛排馆并领取了支票。下次购买新用品时，约翰将供应商与愉快的感觉联系在一起。

John’s supplier took him to the best steakhouse in town and picked up the check. The next time it was time to buy new supplies, John associated the supplier with pleasant feelings.

 人们可以通过将产品、服务、人、投资或情况与我们喜欢的事物联系起来来影响我们。很多时候，我们购买产品、建立关系并投资我们的钱仅仅是因为我们将它们与积极的事物联系起来。难怪广告商或政客将他们想要销售的东西与我们喜欢的东西联系起来，避免将自己与负面事件联系起来。将跑车与能产生积极感觉的事物（美丽性感的车型）配对，我们会自动将汽车与愉悦联系起来。

 People can influence us by associating a product, service, person, investment, or a situation with something we like. Many times we buy products, enter relationships, and invest our money merely because we associate them with positive things. No wonder advertisers or politicians connect what they want to sell with things we like and avoid associating themselves with negative events. Pair a sports car with something that produces a positive feeling - a beautiful and sexy model — and we automatically associate the car with pleasure.

约翰不敢向首席执行官传达坏消息。

John was afraid to deliver bad news to the CEO.

我们是否喜欢某人受与个人相关的事件的影响。坏消息是不受欢迎的。我们往往不喜欢那些告诉我们我们不想听到的东西的人，即使他们没有引起坏消息，即杀死信使。这使人们有动力避免透露坏消息。为了保护自己，他们以他们认为我们想听的方式讲述新闻。这种倾向被称为波斯信使综合症，其起源可追溯到古希腊。在安提戈涅 (Antigone)，一位信使担心自己的生命安全，因为他知道国王会对他带来的消息感到不快。

Whether we like someone is influenced by the events with which an individual is associated. Bad news isn’t welcome. We tend to dislike people who tell us what we don’t want to hear even when they didn’t cause the bad news i.e., kill the messenger. This gives people an incentive to avoid giving bad news. To protect themselves, they tell the news in a way they believe we want to hear it. This tendency is called the Persian Messenger Syndrome and traces its origins back to ancient Greece. In Antigone, a messenger feared for his life since he knew the king would be unhappy with the news he brought.

沃伦巴菲特在得知坏消息时说：“当人们为我们工作时，我们只给他们一些指示：一是像所有者一样思考。第二是立即告诉我们坏消息 - 因为好消息会照顾好自己。我们可以接受坏消息，但我们不喜欢迟到。”

Warren Buffett says on being informed of bad news:"We only give a couple of instructions to people when they go to work for us: One is to think like an owner. And the second is to tell us bad news immediately - because good news takes care of itself. We can take bad news, but we don’t like it late."

看到鱼沙拉，约翰想起了自己吃鱼沙拉生病的时候，再次感到恶心。

Seeing the fish salad, John remembered the time when he’d eaten fish salad and gotten sick, and once more felt nauseous.

我们看到了不存在的类似情况，因为这种情况类似于以前的经历。因此，我们相信未来如影随形，历史会重演。

We see similar situations where they don’t exist because a situation resembles an earlier experience. We therefore believe that the future mirrors the past and that history will repeat itself.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 根据自身的优点评估事物、情况和人。

  • Evaluate things, situations and people on their own merits.

  • 个人既不好也不坏，仅仅因为我们将他们与积极或消极的事物联系在一起。

  • Individuals are neither good nor bad merely because we associate them with something positive or negative.

  • 鼓励人们立即告诉你坏消息。

  • Encourage people to tell you bad news immediately.

  • 仅仅因为您将某些刺激与早先的痛苦或快乐联系在一起，并不意味着该刺激会在今天引起同样的痛苦或快乐。过去的经历通常取决于上下文。

  • Merely because you associate some stimulus with earlier pain or pleasure doesn’t mean the stimulus will cause the same pain or pleasure today. Past experiences are often context dependent.

  • 如果你想结束某种行为，就制造一种消极情绪。如果你想让某人戒烟，一种方法可能是让他们知道他们会失去什么。可怕的图片可能会使他们将吸烟与死亡联系起来。

  • Create a negative emotion if you want to end a certain behaviour. If you want someone to stop smoking, one way could be to show them what they stand to lose. Terrifying pictures may cause them to associate smoking with death.

2.奖惩

2. Reward and Punishment

大自然的铁律是：你得到你所得到的回报。

如果你想让蚂蚁来，你就把糖放在地板上。

The iron rule of nature is: you get what you reward for.

If you want ants to come, you put sugar on the floor.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

约翰的行为给他带来了赞美和金钱，使他继续他的行为。

Johns actions brought him praise and money, making him continue his behaviour.

我们做有益的事情，避免我们受到惩罚的事情。我们从我们行为的后果中学习——对与错。任何让我们重复某种行为的东西都是强化，而任何让我们停止的东西都是惩罚。有益或令人愉悦的行为往往会重复出现。我们不会继续做我们受到惩罚的事情。给人们他们想要的东西（或拿走不想要的东西），他们的行为就会重复。给他们一些不受欢迎的东西（或拿走他们想要的东西），他们的行为就会停止。一开始，奖励（或惩罚）人员在毫不拖延地执行并且每次重复该行为时是最有效的。

We do what is rewarding and avoid what we are punished for. We learn — right and wrong - from the consequences of our actions. Whatever causes us to repeat a certain behaviour is reinforcing and whatever makes us stop is punishing. behaviour that is rewarding or feels pleasurable tends to be repeated. We don’t continue doing what we’re being punished for. Give people what they desire (or take away something undesirable) and their behaviour will repeat. Give them something undesirable (or take away what they desire) and their behaviour will stop. In the beginning, rewarding (or punishing) people is most effective when it is administered without delay and each time the behaviour is repeated.

一旦学习了一种行为，可变的奖励就会加强这种行为。在不可预测的基础上获得奖励的行为具有最高的反应率，也最难消除。例如，这就是赌徒获得奖励的方式。当他们不知道奖励什么时候会到来时，他们会一次又一次地尝试。此外，奖励越大，行为对灭绝的抵抗力就越大。

Once a behaviour becomes learned, variable rewards strengthen the behaviour. behaviour that is rewarded on an unpredictable basis has the highest rate of response and is the most difficult to extinguish. This is, for example, how gamblers are rewarded. When they don’t know when the reward will arrive, they try again and again. Furthermore, the greater the reward, the more resistant the behaviour is to extinction.

我们将奖赏或惩罚建立在我们与过去的经历及其后果或我们与生俱来的价值观或偏好的联系上。

We base what is rewarding or punishing on our associations to past experiences and their consequences or with values or preferences we are born with.

随着时间的推移，一个被强化的动作会变得更强大。习惯、迷信和成瘾就是这样形成的。两者都很难改变。正如 18 世纪伟大的英国作家塞缪尔·约翰逊所说：“习惯的锁链太弱以至于无法被感觉到，直到它们太强而无法被打破。”

An action that is reinforced becomes stronger over time. This is how habits, superstitions and addictions are created. Both are hard to change. As the great 18th Century English writer Samuel Johnson said:"The chains of habit are too weak to be felt until they are too strong to be broken."

这是什么意思呢？这意味着人们做有用的事。就像蜜蜂对蜂蜜一样，他们会去有奖励的地方。这也意味着如果我们奖励我们不想要的东西，我们就会得到它。正如加勒特·哈丁 (Garrett Hardin) 在The Ostrich Factor中所说：“如果社会法律奖励抢劫银行，社会就会发生更多抢劫银行事件。如果我们挑选高位候选人的方法有利于愚蠢，我们就会得到愚蠢的政客。”

What does all this mean? It means that people do what works. Like bees to honey, they go where there is a reward. This also implies that if we reward what we don’t want, we get it. As Garrett Hardin says in The Ostrich Factor:"If the laws of society reward for bank robbing, society will get more bank robbing. If our methods of winnowing candidates for high positions favour stupidity, we will get stupid politicians."

瑞典的研究表明，疾病保险制度的变化会影响病假行为。意味着更慷慨的病假补偿的改革往往与每名雇员的病假总数永久增加有关。来自美国的其他有关医疗服务的研究表明，在由他人承担费用的情况下，患者往往会过度消费医疗服务。

Studies in Sweden show that changes in the sickness insurance system affect sick leave behaviour. Reforms implying more generous compensation for sick leave tend to be associated with permanent increases in total sick leave per person employed. Other studies from the U.S. regarding health services have shown that in cases where someone else picks up the costs, patients tend to over-consume the health services.

为什么人们滥用医疗保健和福利制度？如果不需要支付任何费用，人们使用该系统不是很自然吗？如果人们不必为福利付费，他们通常会过度使用它。从滥用该系统中获益的人越多，任何人就越不可能引起人们对实际发生的事情的关注。他们个人得到了很大的好处，而这对社会来说是一个小损失。直到每个人都开始有同样的想法。古希腊哲学家亚里士多德说：“为最多的人所共有的东西得到最少的关注。人们最关注自己的东西；他们不太关心共有的东西。”

Why do people abuse the health care and welfare system? Isn’t it natural that people use the system if they don’t have to pay anything? And if people don’t have to pay for a benefit, they often overuse it. The more people that benefit from misusing the system, the less likely it is that anyone will draw attention to what really happens. Individually they get a large benefit and it’s a small loss for society. Until everyone starts thinking the same. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle said:"That which is common to the greatest number gets the least amount of care. Men pay most attention to what is their own; they care less for what is common."

人为什么要偷？

Why do people steal?

研究表明，23% 的人表示，如果不被抓到，他们会偷窃。据估计，美国企业每年因欺诈而损失 4000 亿美元，其中约三分之一是由于雇员从雇主那里偷窃造成的。为什么？机会和回报。用查尔斯芒格的话来说：“最糟糕的虐待发生在人们面临最大诱惑的地方。” 如果我们让人们容易偷窃，他们就会偷窃（不良行为就会蔓延）。

Studies show that 23% of people say they would steal if they couldn’t get caught. It is estimated that U.S. businesses lose $400 billion a year from fraud and about a third of that is from employees stealing from their employer. Why? Opportunity and reward. In Charles Munger's words:"The worst abuses come where people have the greatest temptations." If we make it easy for people to steal, they steal (and bad behaviour will spread).

查尔斯芒格告诉我们糟糕的政策如何成为常态：

Charles Munger tells us how a bad policy can become the norm:

在纽约警察局，他们有一个简单的系统。您的养老金是根据您最后一年的工资计算的。所以当任何人到了最后一年，大家配合给他大约1000小时的加班时间。他退休时——在某些情况下仅仅服务了 20 年——就带着如此丰厚的收入。好吧，他的同事当然会帮助他欺骗系统。实际上，这就是发生的事情。但我向你保证的一件事是，没有人有丝毫的羞耻感。他们很快就会觉得自己有权这样做。每个人以前都这样做过，现在每个人都在这样做——所以他们只是继续这样做。
In the New York Police Department, they have a simple system. Your pension is based on your pay in your final year. So when anyone reaches the final year, everybody cooperates to give him about 1,000 hours of overtime. And he retires - in some cases after a mere 20 years of service - with this large income. Well, of course his fellow employees help him cheat the system. In substance, that’s what’s happened. But the one thing I guarantee you is that nobody has the least sense of shame. They soon get the feeling they’re entitled to do it. Everybody did it before, everybody’s doing it now — so they just keep doing it.

为什么网球运动员总是在决赛中穿上他的幸运衫？

Why does a tennis player always wear his lucky shirt in the finals?

在一项实验中，美国心理学家 BF Skinner 定期给鸽子喂食少量食物。一段时间后，鸽子开始表现出迷信的行为。如果一只鸽子在食物出现时摇头，它就认为是摇头让食物出现了。鸽子继续这种有效的行为——每次它们执行这种行为时，食物都会出现。但是食物似乎与鸽子的行为无关。斯金纳在鸽子的《迷信》中写道：“人类行为有很多类比……尽管有许多非强化实例，但仪式和有利后果之间的一些偶然联系足以建立和维持行为。”

In one experiment, American psychologist B.F. Skinner fed pigeons small quantities of food at regular intervals. After some time the pigeons began to behave superstitiously. If a pigeon was bobbing its head when food appeared, it got the idea that bobbing its head must have made the food appear. The pigeons continued with the behaviour that worked - every time they performed the behaviour, food appeared. But food appeared independent of what the pigeons did. Skinner wrote in "Superstition" in the pigeon:"There are many analogies in human behaviour.. .A few accidental connections between a ritual and favourable consequences suffice to set up and maintain the behaviour in spite of many non-reinforced instances."

正确的激励重要吗？

Are the right incentives important?

激励起到强化作用。查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 讲了一个关于正确激励的重要性的故事：

Incentives act as reinforcers. Charles Munger tells a story about the importance of getting the incentives right:

在所有企业中，我最喜欢的激励案例是联邦快递。他们系统的核心和灵魂——创造产品的完整性——是让他们所有的飞机在半夜到达一个地方，并将所有包裹从一架飞机转移到另一架飞机。如果出现延误，整个运营过程就无法向联邦快递客户交付完整无缺的产品。而且总是搞砸了。他们永远无法按时完成。他们尝试了一切——道德劝说、威胁，应有尽有。没有任何效果。最后，有人想出了一个主意，不是给所有这些人支付一个小时的工资，而是一个轮班的工资——当一切都完成后，他们都可以回家了。好吧，他们的问题一夜之间就解决了。
From all business, my favourite case on incentives is Federal Express. The heart and soul of their system — which creates the integrity of the product — is having all their air-planes come to one place in the middle of the night and shift all the packages from plane to plane. If there are delays, the whole operation can’t deliver a product full of integrity to Federal Express customers. And it was always screwed up. They could never get it done on time. They tried everything — moral suasion, threats, you name it. And nothing worked. Finally, somebody got the idea to pay all these people not so much an hour, but so much a shift — and when it’s all done, they can all go home. Well, their problems cleared up overnight.

约翰投资了一家生物技术初创公司，但失败了，他赔了钱。

John invested in a biotech start-up that went sour and he lost money.

成功后，我们会变得过于乐观，敢于冒险。失败后，我们会变得过于悲观和厌恶风险——即使在成功或失败仅仅是偶然的情况下也是如此。好的结果并不一定意味着我们做出了正确的决定，而坏的结果并不一定意味着我们做出了错误的决定。

After a success, we become overly optimistic risk-takers. After a failure, we become overly pessimistic and risk-averse — even in cases where success or failure was merely a result of chance. Good consequences don’t necessarily mean we made a good decision, and bad consequences don’t necessarily mean we made a bad decision.

下次有人向约翰提供生物技术初创企业的投资机会时，他很可能会拒绝。他将新提案与他早先的经历联系起来。由于人们倾向于相信未来反映了过去，他拒绝了。但是如果约翰的第一笔投资让他赚了很多钱会怎样呢？约翰不会将新求婚与他过去的愉快经历联系起来吗？他不是因此更有可能投资吗？这种对过去有效方法的自动联想导致人们对新的条件和环境反应不足。

The next time someone presents John an investment opportunity in a biotech start-up the chances are he will decline. He associates the new proposal to his earlier experience. And since people tend to believe that the future mirrors the past, he declines. But what happens if John’s first investment made him a lot of money? Wouldn’t John associate the new proposal to his old pleasurable experience? Isn’t he therefore more likely to invest? This automatic association to what worked in the past causes people to under-react to new conditions and circumstances.

马克吐温明白盲目相信过去的经验来应对未来的危险。“我们应该小心地摆脱经验，只留下其中的智慧，然后就此打住，以免我们像坐在热炉子上的猫一样-盖子。她不会再坐在热炉盖上了——但她也永远不会再坐在冷炉盖上了。”

Mark Twain understood the dangers of blindly trusting past experience for dealing with the future."We should be careful to get out of an experience only the wisdom in it, and stop there, lest we be like the cat that sits down on a hot stove-lid. She will not sit down on a hot stove-lid again — but also she will never sit down on a cold one anymore."

奖励或惩罚的大小或顺序是否重要？

Does it matter in which size or order rewards or punishments arrive?

玛丽从不把孩子们的圣诞礼物包装在一个盒子里。

Mary never wraps the kids Christmas presents in one box.

由于我们的经历被分成几个部分后看起来会更长，所以我们喜欢将愉快的经历分成几个部分，而将痛苦的经历组合在一起。这就是为什么玛丽把礼物放在许多盒子里的原因。频繁的奖励感觉更好。例如，两次获得 50 美元比一次获得 100 美元感觉更好，因为每次获得都是有益的。一次损失 100 美元比两次损失 50 美元感觉更好，因为每次损失都是痛苦的”

Since our experiences seem longer when broken into segments, we like to have pleasurable experiences broken into segments but painful ones combined. That is why Mary puts presents in many boxes.
