Frequent rewards feel better. For example, it feels better to gain $50 twice than $100 once since every gain is rewarding. It feels better to lose $100 once than $50 twice since every loss is painful"

我们更喜欢随着时间的推移而改进的一系列体验。先损失 100 美元然后获得 50 美元似乎比获得 50 美元然后损失 100 美元更有回报。我们想首先摆脱糟糕的经历。立即损失优于延迟损失。正如我们不喜欢糟糕的经历一样，我们也不喜欢等待它们。我们喜欢快速克服它们。

We prefer a sequence of experiences that improve over time. Losing $100 first and then gaining $50 seems more rewarding than gaining $50 and then losing $100. We want to get rid of the bad experiences first. Immediate losses are preferred over delayed ones. Just as we don’t like bad experiences, we also don’t like waiting for them. We like to get over them fast.

单纯的联想和强化都是条件反射的例子。查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 在描述非酒精饮料的发明时举例说明了如何使用这些力：

Mere association and reinforcement are both examples of conditioned reflexes. Charles Munger gives an example how these forces can be used as he describes the invention of non-alcoholic drinks:

饮料的食用价值等是强化剂。饮料的商品外观、商品名称和外观是兴奋剂……

然后，你继续进行第二种条件反射——那是直接的巴甫洛夫……好吧，你如何获得巴甫洛夫纯联想效应？显然，您将这种饮料及其商标与人们普遍喜欢的每一种美好事物联系在一起，包括庆祝活动、性对象、快乐时光——随便你怎么说。

The food value and so forth of the beverage is the reinforcer. And the trade dress, trade name and look of the beverage is the stimulant...

Then, you go on to the second kind of conditioned reflex — and that’s straight Pavlov... Well, how do you get Pavlovian mere-association effects? Obviously, you associate this beverage and its trademarks with every good thing that people like generally, exalting events, sex objects, happy times — you name it.

我们怎么能失去对我们有用的条件反射呢？查尔斯·芒格继续说道：

How can we lose a conditioned reflex that’s working for us? Charles Munger continues:

好吧，客户尝试了其他东西并发现它是一个很大的强化物。所以他改变了品牌。我们知道，在婚姻中，如果你总是有空，配偶就不太可能改变品牌。人们不倾向于组织婚姻以包括永久性的长期分居。同样，如果您销售的是一种产品并且它始终可用，那么人们就不太可能转向其他产品并因此而得到强化。

Well, the customer tries something else and discovers that it's a big reinforcer. So he shifts brands. We know, in matrimony, that if you’re always available, the spouse is less likely to shift brands. And people don’t tend to organize marriage to include permanent long separations. Similarly, if you’re selling a product and it’s always available, people are less likely to shift to some other product and get reinforced by it.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 美国政治家、科学家和哲学家本杰明·富兰克林告诉我们：“一匙蜂蜜比一加仑醋能捉住更多的苍蝇。” 表扬比惩罚更能改变行为。鼓励正确的事情比批评错误的事情更好。

  • American statesman, scientist and philosopher Benjamin Franklin tells us that:"A spoonful of honey will catch more flies than a gallon of vinegar." Praise is more effective in changing behaviour than punishment. It is better to encourage what is right than to criticize what is wrong.

  • 树立榜样。米歇尔·德·蒙田 (Michel de Montaigne) 说：“我们的司法习惯是惩罚一些人以警告其他人。因为正如柏拉图所说，惩罚他们做错事是愚蠢的：已经做了就无法挽回。目的是阻止他们重复同样的错误或让其他人避免他们的错误。我们不会改善我们吊死的人：我们通过他改善其他人。

  • Set examples. Michel de Montaigne said:"It is a custom of our justice to punish some as a warning to others. For to punish them for having done wrong would, as Plato says, be stupid: what is done cannot be undone. The intention is to stop them from repeating the same mistake or to make others avoid their error. We do not improve the man we hang: we improve others by him."

  • 不要过度学习你自己或他人的好或坏的经验。同样的动作在其他条件下可能会造成不同的后果。

  • Don’t over-learn from your own or others bad or good experience. The same action under other conditions may cause different consequences.

  • 区分技能和机会。查尔斯芒格说，“当你在竞争秩序中占据一些高利润的利基市场时，你必须知道你目前的繁荣有多少是由确保在新活动中取得成功的才能和动力造成的，有多少仅仅反映了在你现在的位置。”

  • Separate between skill and chance. Charles Munger says,"As you occupy some high-profit niche in a competitive order, you must know how much of your present prosperity is caused by talents and momentum assuring success in new activities, and how much merely reflects the good fortune of being in your present niche."

  • 美国小说家厄普顿辛克莱说：“当一个人的薪水取决于他不理解某件事时，很难让他理解某事。” 由于人们做的是有效的事情，所以一定要制定正确的激励措施。将激励与绩效以及决定您想要实现的结果的因素联系起来。让人们分享好处和坏处。并让他们了解他们的表现、奖励与您最终想要完成的目标之间的联系。例如，将经理的薪酬与（他控制下的单位的）商业价值收益减去用于产生该价值的资本成本因素联系起来。汽车保险公司 GEICO 的计划体现了 Berkshire Hathaways 的激励补偿原则。沃伦巴菲特说：

    目标应该是：

    1. 根据特定经营业务的经济状况量身定制；
    2. 性质简单，因此可以很容易地衡量它们的实现程度；和 
    3. 与计划参与者的日常活动直接相关。

    作为必然结果，我们避免了“彩票”安排，例如伯克希尔股票的期权，其最终价值——可能从零到巨大不等——完全不受我们想要影响其行为的人的控制。在我们看来，一个产生不切实际的回报的系统不仅对所有者来说是一种浪费，而且实际上可能会阻碍我们重视管理者的专注行为。

  • American novelist Upton Sinclair said:"It is difficult to get a man to understand something when his salary depends upon him not understanding it." Since people do what works, be sure to make the incentives right. Tie incentives to performance and to the factors that determine the result you want to achieve. Make people share both the upside and downside. And make them understand the link between their performance, their reward and what you finally want to accomplish. For example, tie a manager’s compensation to gain in business value (of the unit under his control) minus a cost factor for capital that is used to produce this value. The auto insurer GEICO’s plan exemplifies Berkshire Hathaways’s incentive compensation principles. Warren Buffett says:

    Goals should be:

    1. tailored to the economics of the specific operating business;
    2. simple in character so that the degree to which they are being realized can be easily measured; and 
    3. directly related to the daily activities of plan participants.

    As a corollary, we shun "lottery ticket" arrangements, such as options on Berkshire shares, whose ultimate value — which could range from zero to huge — is totally out of the control of the person whose behaviour we would like to affect. In our view, a system that produces quixotic pay-offs will not only be wasteful for owners but may actually discourage the focused behaviour we value in managers.

  • 奖励个人表现而不是组织的努力或时间，并在人们表现之后而不是之前奖励他们。

  • Reward individual performance and not effort or length in organization and reward people after and not before their performance.

  • 不要让金钱成为唯一的动力。如果我们奖励人们做他们喜欢做的事情，有时我们会把他们喜欢做的事情变成工作。奖励会改变他们的看法。他们不是因为喜欢做某事而做某事，而是因为得到报酬才做某事。关键是奖励意味着什么。对我们成就的奖励让我们觉得我们擅长某事，从而增加我们的动力。但是，一种让人感觉有控制力并让我们觉得我们这样做只是因为我们得到报酬才这样做的奖励会降低吸引力。Blaise Pascal 说：“我们通常更容易被自己发现的理由说服，而不是被别人给我们的理由说服。”

  • Don’t let money be the only motivation. If we reward people for doing what they like to do anyway, we sometimes turn what they enjoy doing into work. The reward changes their perception. Instead of doing something because they enjoy doing it, they now do it because they are being paid. The key is what a reward implies. A reward for our achievements makes us feel that we are good at something thereby increasing our motivation. But a reward that feels controlling and makes us feel that we are only doing it because we’re paid to do it, decreases the appeal. Blaise Pascal said:"We are generally the better persuaded by the reasons we discover ourselves than by those given to us by others."

  • 安装鼓励您想要的行为的系统和规则。永远不要让某人以您不希望的方式行事。拥有使人们难以摆脱不良行为的系统。使不良行为代价高昂。不良行为的痛苦后果必须超过其令人愉快的后果。例如，入狱的后果应该比入室盗窃而逃脱的快乐更痛苦。

  • Install systems and rules that encourage the behaviour you want. Never let it pay someone to behave in a way you don’t want. Have systems that make it hard for people to get away with undesirable behaviour. Make undesirable behaviour costly. The painful consequences of undesirable behaviour must outweigh its pleasurable consequences. For example, the consequences of spending time in jail ought to be more painful than the pleasure of getting away with burglary.

  • 正如沃伦巴菲特所观察到的那样，系统很难改变，“当手放在开关上的人从该系统中获益巨大，而且也许不成比例时，很难改变系统。”

  • Systems can be hard to change as Warren Buffett observes,"It’s very hard to change a system when the guy whose hand is on the switch benefits enormously and, perhaps, disproportionately from that system."

  • 决策者应对其行为的后果负责。美国哲学家查尔斯·弗兰克尔 (Charles Frankel)在《现代人案例》(The Case for Modern Man)中对责任下了定义：“当做出决定的人或团体必须对直接或间接受其影响的人负责时，该决定就是负责任的。” 查尔斯芒格补充道，“真正负责任的系统的一个例子是罗马人在建造拱门时使用的系统。当脚手架被拆除时，建造拱门的人站在它下面。这就像收拾你自己的降落伞。”

  • Decision-makers should be held accountable for the consequences of their actions. In The Case for Modern Man, American philosopher Charles Frankel defines responsibility:"A decision is responsible when the man or group that makes it has to answer for it to those who are directly or indirectly affected by it." Charles Munger adds,"An example of a really responsible system is the system the Romans used when they built an arch. The guy who created the arch stood under it as the scaffolding was removed. It’s like packing your own parachute."

3. 自身利益和激励

3. Self-interest and Incentives

“该死的，我们想弄清真相”[彼得·温西勋爵说]“你呢”英佩爵士干巴巴地说，“我不在乎。我不在乎真相的两便士。我想要一个案子。 “

"Damn it all, we want to get at the truth" [said Lord Peter Wimsey]"Do you" said Sir Impey dryly."I don’t. I don’t care two pence about the truth. I want a case."

——多萝西·塞耶斯

（英国作家，1893-1957）

- Dorothy Sayers

(British writer, 1893-1957)

网球锦标赛的组织者需要钱。他们找到了 TransCorp 的首席执行官，请他赞助比赛。

The organizers of a tennis tournament needed money. They approached the CEO of TransCorp and asked him to sponsor the tournament.

“多少？” 首席执行官问道。

"How much?" asked the CEO.

“一百万，”组织者说。

"One million,"said the organizer.

“这笔钱太多了，”首席执行官说。

"That is too much money,"said the CEO.

组织者说：“如果你考虑到你个人可以参加一场比赛，坐在总统家族成员旁边的名誉看台上并成为颁奖人，那就不是了。”

"Not if you consider the fact that you personally can play one match, sit at the honorary stand next to a member of the presidential family and be the one that hands over the prize,"said the organizer.

“我在哪里签字？” 首席执行官说。

"Where do I sign?" said the CEO.

人们会做他们认为最符合他们利益的事情，并且会受到激励的影响。例如，当发现第一本死海古卷时，考古学家希望找到更多的古卷碎片，他们会为每个碎片提供奖励。结果：碎片在上交之前被分成更小的碎片。

People do what they perceive is in their best interest and are biased by incentives. For example, when the first Dead Sea scrolls were discovered and the archeologists wanted more fragments of the scrolls to be found, they offered a reward per fragment. The result: the fragments were split into smaller pieces before they were turned in.

喜剧演员 Groucho Marx 曾经采访过一位美国参议员，谈到参议员发明的一种灵丹妙药维生素和矿物质滋补品。当格劳乔问他这有什么好处时，参议员回答说：“去年对我来说这对我来说是五五十万美元。”

The comedian Groucho Marx once interviewed a U.S. Senator about a miracle cure-all vitamin and mineral tonic that the Senator had invented. When Groucho asked him what it was good for, the Senator answered:"It was good for five and a half million for me last year."

决策者的激励决定行为。这意味着我们必须认识到他人的自利行为。

Incentives for the decision-maker determine behaviour. This means that we have to recognize self-interested behaviour in others.

顾问总是值得信任的吗？

Are advisors always to be trusted?

古语有云：“理发不问村里理发师”。我们和其他人一样，包括律师、会计师、医生、顾问、推销员、组织、媒体等，都会因我们的激励而产生偏见。对他们有利的可能对我们不利。顾问是有偿推销员，可能会诱骗我们购买我们不需要的东西。

There is an old saying:"Never ask the village barber if you need a haircut." We are biased by our incentives as are others including lawyers, accountants, doctors, consultants, salesmen, organizations, the media, etc. What is good for them may not be good for us. Advisors are paid salesmen and may trick us into buying what we don’t need.

对于律师来说，诉讼往往比和解更有利可图。律师 William F. Coyne, Jr. 在The Case for Settlement Counsel中说，“律师不接受提前和解的重大诱因……这些诱因包括推销服务的需要、不显得软弱的愿望、代表的义务一个热心的客户，对正义的渴望，但也许并非最不重要的是，对收入最大化的渴望。”

For an attorney, litigation is often more lucrative than settlement. Lawyer William F. Coyne, Jr. says in The Case for Settlement Counsel there are"significant incentives for lawyers not to embrace early settlement.. .These incentives include the need to market services, the desire not to appear weak, the obligation to represent a client zealously, the thirst for justice, but perhaps not least, the desire to maximize income."

沃伦巴菲特告诉我们，伯克希尔的一项薪酬安排是在“没有律师或薪酬顾问的“帮助”的情况下制定出来的。这种安排体现了一些非常简单的想法——而不是那些无法轻易发送大额账单的顾问所青睐的那种条款除非他们确定你有一个大问题（当然，还有一个需要每年审查一次）。”

Warren Buffett tells us that one of Berkshire’s compensation arrangements was worked out:"without the"help" of lawyers or compensation consultants. This arrangement embodies a few very simple ideas — not the kind of terms favoured by consultants who cannot easily send a large bill unless they have established that you have a large problem (and one, of course, that requires an annual review)."

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 告诉我们推销员的普遍倾向：

Charles Munger tells us about the common tendency of salesmen:

所有的委托业务员都有为交易服务而不是为真相服务的倾向。.. .1 将顾问归入同一类别，有时甚至是律师——有时尤其是律师。

许多年前，我的一个帕萨迪纳朋友制作了渔具。我看着这个渔具——它是绿色、紫色和蓝色的——我想我从来没有见过这样的东西。我问他“天哪！鱼会咬这些诱饵吗？” 他对我说，“查理，我不卖鱼。”

All commissioned salesmen have a tendency to serve the transaction instead of the truth. .. .1 put consultants in the same category, sometimes even lawyers - sometimes especially lawyers.

Many years ago, a Pasadena friend of mine made fishing tackle. I looked at this fishing tackle - it was green and purple and blue — I don’t think I’d ever seen anything like them. I asked him"God! Do fish bite these lures?" He said to me,"Charlie, I don’t sell to fish."

让我们看看经纪和投资银行业务。经纪人有强烈的动机让我们进行交易。他们建议我们买卖什么。交易量创造佣金。投资银行家鼓励定价过高的收购以产生费用。无论公司的质量如何，投资银行家都有完成首次公开募股 (IPO) 交易的各种动机。他们的报酬与交易带来的收入挂钩。分析师因帮助出售 IPO 而获得奖励。经纪人想要转移股票。Groucho Marx 说了什么？“几年前我在华尔街赚了一笔…….1 枪杀了我的经纪人。”

Let’s look at the brokerage and investment banking business. Brokers have a strong incentive to get us to trade. They advise us what to buy and sell. Volume creates commissions. Investment bankers encourage overpriced acquisitions to generate fees. Investment bankers have every incentive to get initial public offerings (IPO) deals done, regardless of the company’s quality. Their compensation is tied to the revenues the deal brings in. Analysts are rewarded for helping sell the IPO. Brokers want to move the stock. What did Groucho Marx say?"I made a killing on Wall Street a few years ago.. .1 shot my broker."

同样，在医学领域，一些心理学家通过告诉患者需要再次拜访来确保自己连续发薪日。他们不谈论他们知识的局限性。他们的职业生涯岌岌可危。正如美国演员瓦尔特马修所说，“我的医生给了我六个月的生命。当我告诉他我付不起账单时，他又给了我六个月的时间。”

Similarly, in the medical field, some psychologists ensure themselves successive paydays by telling their patients that another visit is required. And they don’t talk about the limits of their knowledge. Their careers are at stake. As American actor Walther Matthau said,"My doctor gave me six months to live. When I told him I couldn’t pay the bill, he gave me six more months."

为什么银行家会批准有风险的贷款？

Why do bankers approve risky loans?

因做傻事而受到奖励的人会继续做这些事。从他们的参照系来看，他们的行为是基于他们如何获得奖励的。奖励制度付钱让他们做错事。因此，如果市场份额而不是利润支付给银行家，他将尽可能多地发放贷款。他每年都会得到奖励，而不良贷款的净后果将在很长一段时间内无法实现。

People who are rewarded for doing stupid things continue to do them. From their frame of reference, they acted logically based on how they were rewarded. The incentive system paid them to do the wrong thing. So if market share rather than profits pay a banker, he will write as many loans as possible. He is being rewarded every year while the net consequences of the bad loans won’t be realized for a long time.

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 举例说明了劳埃德保险公司 (Lloyd's Insurance) 是如何奖励员工的：

Charles Munger gives an example of how Lloyd’s Insurance rewarded their people:

他们获得了通过的总量的一定百分比的报酬。当你真正感兴趣的是网络时，向每个人支付一定比例的总收入是一个系统 - 考虑到人类天生倾向于做符合他们自己利益的事情，即使这会对其他人造成可怕的后果 - 那劳合社真的加入了。

They were paid a percentage of the gross volume that went through. And paying everybody a percentage of the gross, when what you’re really interested in is the net, is a system - given the natural bias of human beings toward doing what’s in their own interest even though it has terrible consequences for other people - that really did Lloyd’s in.

小心你付出的代价，你可能会得到它。

Be careful what you pay for, you may get it.

新奥尔良市推出了一项计划，根据该计划，犯罪统计数据有所改善的地区将获得奖励，这些奖励可能会导致奖金和晋升，而没有面临裁员和解雇的地区。发生了什么？在一个警区，将近一半的严重犯罪被重新归类为轻微犯罪，并且从未得到全面调查。

The city of New Orleans introduced a program under which districts that showed improvement in crime statistics received awards that could lead to bonuses and promotions, while districts that didn’t faced cutbacks and firings. What happened? In one police district, nearly half of all serious crimes were reclassified as minor offences and never fully investigated.

研究表明，当学生的工作或加薪取决于考试结果时，教师会帮助学生在标准化考试中作弊。

Studies show that teachers help students cheat on standardized tests when their jobs or pay increases depend on the outcome of the tests.

约翰知道，如果他没有表现出好的数字，他的项目就不会得到资助，所以他伪造了这些书。

John knew that if he didn’t show good figures, his project wouldn’t be funded so he cooked the books.

为什么人们对现实有偏见？为什么他们让数字看起来比实际情况更好或伪造数据来支持某些事情？不可接受的行为，但源于人们倾向于按照他们认为符合他们最大利益的方式行事。

Why do people give a biased picture of reality? Why do they make figures look better than they are or fake data to support something? Behaviour that is not acceptable but results from the tendency of people doing what they perceive is in their best interest.

当人们试图出售项目时，可能会有强大的经济和声望相关的动机来低估成本和高估收益。例如，基于来自五大洲二十个国家的数百个大型交通基础设施项目的数据的研究发现，在许多情况下，数十亿美元项目的项目推动者和预测者故意歪曲项目的成本、收益和风险，以便让他们获得批准。

There may be powerful economic and prestige-related incentives to underestimate costs and overestimate benefits when people try to sell projects. For example, studies based on data from several hundred large transportation infrastructure projects in twenty nations and five continents found evidence that in a number of cases, project promoters and forecasters of billion-dollar projects intentionally misrepresented the costs, benefits and risks of projects in order to get them approved.

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 说应该谨慎处理预测：

Charles Munger says that projections should be handled with care:

马克吐温曾经说过，“地雷是地上的一个洞，上面是一个骗子。” 任何想赚取佣金的人或试图为特定行动方案辩护的高管所准备的预测通常都是谎言——尽管在大多数情况下这不是故意的谎言。这个人自己也开始相信了。那是最糟糕的一种。应该非常小心地处理预测——尤其是当它们是由有兴趣误导你的人提供的时候。”

Mark Twain used to say,"A mine is a hole in the ground with a liar on the top." And a projection prepared by anybody who stands to earn a commission or an executive trying to justify a particular course of action will frequently be a lie — although it’s not a deliberate lie in most cases. The man has come to believe it himself. And that’s the worst kind. Projections should be handled with great care - particularly when they’re being provided by someone who has an interest in misleading you."

沃伦巴菲特补充道：

Warren Buffett adds:

我对预测或预测毫无用处。他们创造了一种表面上精确的错觉。他们越细致，你就越应该关心。我们从不看预测，但我们非常关心并深入研究过往记录。如果一家公司的业绩记录很糟糕，但前途一片光明，我们就会错失良机……

我不明白为什么任何企业的买家都会看卖家或其代理人拼凑的一堆预测。您几乎可以说，认为这些预测有任何用处是天真的想法。我们只是不感兴趣。

如果我们自己对未来是什么一无所知，坐在那里听其他试图向我们出售业务或从中收取佣金的人告诉我们未来会怎样——就像我说的，这太天真了。

I have no use whatsoever for projections or forecasts. They create an illusion of apparent precision. The more meticulous they are, the more concerned you should be. We never look at projections, but we care very much about, and look very deeply at, track records. If a company has a lousy track record, but a very bright future, we will miss the opportunity...

I do not understand why any buyer of a business looks at a bunch of projections put together by a seller or his agent. You can almost say that it’s naive to think that those projections have any utility whatsoever. We’re just not interested.

If we don’t have some idea ourselves of what the future is, to sit there and listen to some other guy who’s trying to sell us the business or get a commission on it tell us what the future’s going to be — like I say, it’s very naive.

巴菲特还给我们做了一个测试：

Buffett also gives us a test:

当他们提供这些产品时，投资银行家展示了他们幽默的一面：他们为几个月前他们几乎没有听说过的公司分配未来五年或更长时间的收入和资产负债表预测。如果你看到这样的时间表，我建议你加入这个乐趣：向投资银行家询问他自己的公司在过去几年开始时准备的一年预算，然后将这些与实际发生的情况进行比较。

When they make these offerings, investment bankers display their humorous side: They dispense income and balance sheet projections extending five or more years into the future for companies they barely had heard of a few months earlier. If you are shown such schedules, I suggest that you join in the fun: Ask the investment banker for the one-year budgets that his own firm prepared as the last few years began and then compare these with what actually happened.

TransCorp 的顾问由公司聘用并支付报酬，以就如何支付报酬向 CEO 提供建议。“如果我告诉 CEO 他想听什么，他会给我高薪，重新雇用我，并将我推荐给其他 CEO。”如果我让它听起来很复杂，那么发送更大的账单会更容易。”

The consultant to TransCorp was hired and paid by the company to advise the CEO on how he should be paid."If I tell the CEO what he wants to hear, he will pay me well, rehire me and recommend me to other CEOs. And if I make it sound complicated it will be easier to send a larger bill."

我们如何作为员工？如果我们的老板想要一个特定的答案，我们会给出吗？引用一句德国谚语：“我吃谁的面包，唱他的歌。” 沃伦巴菲特说：

How do we act as an employee? If our boss wants a particular answer, do we give it? To quote the German proverb:"Whose bread I eat, his song I sing." Warren Buffett says:

我想说的是，典型的公司组织结构是为了以各种可能的方式强化 CEO 的意见、偏见和先前的信念。员工不会给你任何相反的建议——他们只会带着 CEO 想要的任何东西回来。而且董事会不会起到支票的作用，所以首席执行官几乎可以得到他想要的东西。

I would say that the typical corporate organization is structured so that the CEOs opinions, biases and previous beliefs are reinforced in every possible way. Staffs won’t give you any contrary recommendations - they’ll just come back with whatever the CEO wants. And the Board of Directors won’t act as a check, so the CEO pretty much gets what he wants.

TransCorp 的首席执行官说：“我不喜欢尴尬，也不喜欢让我的名誉受到耻辱的威胁。”

"I don't like to be embarrassed and have my name and reputation threatened with disgrace,"said the CEO of TransCorp.

我们怎样才能改变人？本杰明·富兰克林说：“你能不能说服，讲利益，不讲道理。” 由于失去的风险比获得的机会更有动力，如果我们诉诸人们害怕失去他们珍视的东西——工作、名誉、地位、金钱、控制等，我们就有更好的机会改变他们。

How can we change people? Benjamin Franklin said:"Would you persuade, speak of interest not of reason." Since the risk of losing is more motivating than the chance of gaining, we stand a better chance changing people if we appeal to their fear of losing something they value - job, reputation, status, money, control, etc.

通常最好避免我们需要改变人的情况。正如沃伦巴菲特所说，改变人是困难的，“我要说的是，查理和我在说服那些我们认为正在做愚蠢的事情的正派，聪明的人以改变他们的行动方针方面的历史很糟糕......当人们想做点什么，他们想做点什么。”

It is often better to avoid situations where we need to change people. Changing people is hard as Warren Buffett says,"I'd say that the history that Charlie and I have had of persuading decent, intelligent people who we thought were doing unintelligent things to change their course of action has been poor... When people want to do something, they want to do something."

改变人会影响他们的动机、责任感和回报倾向。当人们出于自己的自由意志行事时会更好。沃伦巴菲特举例说明：

Changing people affects their motivation, feelings of responsibility, and tendency to reciprocate. It is better when people act out of their own free will. Warren Buffett illustrates:

我们希望每个子公司的经理以他们认为最适合其运营的方式经营业务。.. .我们永远不会告诉子公司经理光顾哪个供应商或类似的事情。一旦我们开始为我们的经理做出这些决定，我们就会对运营负责，而他们不再对运营负责。他们对自己的运营负责。这意味着他们可以做出决定，这取决于他们为他们的子公司做最好的事情，而任何其他想要与他们的业务开展业务的公司向他们证明为什么这是最好的......这就是伯克希尔的方法。我认为，总的来说，我们的经理喜欢这种方式——因为他们不会受到质疑，也没有人会越过他们的头脑。

We want the manager of each subsidiary to run their business in the way they think is best for their operation. .. .we’ll never tell a subsidiary manager which vendor to patronize or anything of that sort. Once we start making those decisions for our managers, we become responsible for the operation and they’re no longer responsible for the operation. And they’re responsible for their operations. That means that they get to make the call, that it’s up to them to do what’s best for their subsidiary and that it’s up to any other company that wants to do business with their operation to prove to them why it’s best...That’s the Berkshire approach. I think, on balance, our managers like it that way - because they’re not going to get second-guessed and nobody will go over their heads.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 不要自动相信那些与你的决定有关系的人。问：兴趣是什么？谁受益？

  • Don't automatically trust people who have something at stake from your decision. Ask: What are the interests? Who benefits?

  • 了解人们的动机。金钱、地位、对工作的热爱、名誉、地位、权力、嫉妒？他们因什么受到奖励或惩罚？他们是从当前系统中受益还是受损？

  • Understand people's motivations. Money, status, love of work, reputation, position, power, envy? What are they rewarded or punished for? Are they benefiting or losing from the present system?

  • 人们的利益不仅仅是经济利益。它们也可以是社会的或道德的。例如，公众的尴尬、社会排斥、良心、羞耻或内疚可能会导致人们停止一些不良行为。例如，通过要求餐厅在前窗张贴卫生质量分数，洛杉矶县卫生部门极大地改善了餐厅卫生并减少了与食物有关的疾病。

  • People's interests are not only financial. They could also be social or moral. For example, public embarrassment, social exclusion, conscience, shame or guilt may cause people to stop some undesirable behaviour. For example, by requiring restaurants to post hygiene quality scores in their front windows, the Los Angeles county health department caused a dramatic improvement in restaurant hygiene and a reduction in food-related illnesses.

  • 古希腊哲学家柏拉图说：“不要以强硬和严酷的方式训练孩子学习，而要以他们喜欢的方式引导他们，这样他们才能更好地发现自己的爱好。” 向人们施压或给他们发号施令通常是行不通的。最好通过提出能说明后果的问题来说服人们。这使他们能够独立思考，并更有可能发现什么对他们最有利。

  • The ancient Greek philosopher Plato said:"Do not train boys to learning by force and harshness, but lead them by what amuses them, so that they may better discover the bent of their minds." Pressuring people or giving them orders often doesn't work. It is better to convince people by asking questions that illuminate consequences. This causes them to think for themselves and makes it more likely that they discover what's in their best interest.

4. 自利倾向和乐观

4. Self-Serving Tendencies and Optimism

人之所以受苦，是因为他追求太多，愚蠢地雄心勃勃，荒谬地高估了自己的能力

Man suffers much because he seeks too much, is foolishly ambitious and grotesquely overestimates his capacities

 - 以赛亚·伯林

（俄英哲学家，1909-1997）

 - Isaiah Berlin

(Russian-British philosopher, 1909-1997)

“发生在别人身上的事不会发生在我身上。”

"Things that happen to others don't happen to me."

我们认为自己是独一无二的和特殊的，我们对自己和我们的家庭有乐观的看法。我们高估了我们对事件的控制程度，而低估了机会。

We see ourselves as unique and special and we have optimistic views of ourselves and our family. We overestimate the degree of control we have over events and underestimate chance.

18世纪英国诗人爱德华·杨说：“所有人都认为所有人都会死，但他们自己”。我们中的大多数人都相信自己的表现更好，更诚实、更聪明，拥有更美好的未来，拥有更幸福的婚姻，比普通人更不容易受到伤害等等。但我们不可能都比普通人好。

The 18th Century English poet Edward Young said:"All men think all men are mortal but themselves." Most of us believe we are better performers, more honest and intelligent, have a better future, have a happier marriage, are less vulnerable than the average person, etc. But we can’t all be better than average.

我们往往高估了自己预测未来的能力。与不希望的事件相比，人们倾向于将更高的概率放在希望的事件上。例如，我们对计划行动的结果过于乐观。乐观是好的，但当涉及到重要的决定时，现实主义更好。

We tend to overestimate our ability to predict the future. People tend to put a higher probability on desired events than on undesired events. For example, we are over-optimistic about the outcome of planned actions. Optimism is good but when it comes to important decisions, realism is better.

在犯了一个大错之后，约翰说：“我很傲慢。我过去的成功让我相信我可以做任何事情。”

After making a huge mistake, John said:"I was arrogant. My past success caused me to believe I could do anything."

Marcus Porcius Cato 说：“人在盛世、富足、幸福时精神振奋，因此他们的骄傲和自大就会增长。” 当我们在某个主题上知识渊博、感觉处于控制之中或在我们取得成功之后，我们往往会高估自己的能力和未来前景。正如金融作家罗杰·洛文斯坦 (Roger Lowenstein) 在《当天才失败时：长期资本管理的兴衰》一书中写道：“没有什么比成功更能掩盖失败的可能性了。”

Marcus Porcius Cato said:"Men’s spirits are lifted when the times are prosperous, rich and happy, so that their pride and arrogance grow." We tend to over-estimate our abilities and future prospects when we are knowledgeable on a subject, feel in control, or after we’ve been successful. As financial writer Roger Lowenstein writes in When Genius Failed: The Rise and Fall of Long-Term Capital Management:"There is nothing like success to blind one of the possibility of failure."

什么会抬高 CEO 为收购支付的价格？研究发现了通过三个傲慢来源感染的证据：

What tends to inflate the price that CEO’s pay for acquisitions? Studies found evidence of infection through three sources of hubris:

  1. 最近成功后过度自信，
  2. overconfidence after recent success,
  3. 自我重要性感；认为与其他高级管理人员相比高薪意味着技能，以及
  4. a sense of self-importance; the belief that a high salary compared to other senior ranking executives imply skill, and
  5. 首席执行官对他们自己的新闻报道的信念。媒体倾向于美化 CEO，并将商业成功过度归因于 CEO 的角色，而不是其他因素和人。这使得 CEO 更有可能变得对自己的能力过于自信，并且更加致力于使他们成为媒体名人的行为。
  6. the CEO’s belief in their own press coverage. The media tend to glorify the CEO and over-attribute business success to the role of the CEO rather than to other factors and people. This makes CEO’s more likely to become both more overconfident about their abilities and more committed to the actions that made them media celebrities.

“它奏效了，因为我们做出了正确的决定。”“它没有奏效，因为商业环境不佳。”

"It worked because we made the right decisions.""It didn’t work because of a bad business climate."

实验表明，当我们成功时（无论是否偶然，我们都是独立的），我们相信自己的性格或能力。沃伦巴菲特说：

Experiments show that when we are successful (independent if by chance or not), we credit our own character or ability. Warren Buffett says:

就像 1997 年那样，当股票飙升时，任何投资者都可以赚取巨额回报。在牛市中，必须避免重蹈覆辙的鸭子的错误。

暴雨倾盆，自以为是它的划水功夫，使它扬名天下。一只思维正常的鸭子会在倾盆大雨后将自己的位置与池塘中其他鸭子的位置进行比较。

Any investor can chalk up large returns when stocks soar, as they did in 1997. In a bull market, one must avoid the error of the preening duck that quacks boastfully after a

torrential rainstorm, thinking that its paddling skills have caused it to rise in the world. A right-thinking duck would instead compare its position after the downpour to that of the other ducks on the pond.

当我们失败时，我们会责怪外部环境或运气不好。当别人成功时，我们倾向于将他们的成功归功于运气，而将他们的失败归咎于愚蠢。当我们的投资变成输家时，我们运气不好。当他们变成赢家时，我们就是天才。这样我们就会得出错误的结论，也不会从错误中吸取教训。我们也低估了结果的运气和随机性。

When we fail, we blame external circumstances or bad luck. When others are successful, we tend to credit their success to luck and blame their failures on foolishness. When our investments turn into losers, we had bad luck. When they turn into winners, we are geniuses. This way we draw the wrong conclusions and don’t learn from our mistakes. We also underestimate luck and randomness in outcomes.

在使用顾问时，如果结果很好，我们会把功劳归功于我们的技能。但如果结果不好，我们就会责怪顾问。

When using advisers and if something turns out well, we take the credit, assigning the outcome to our skill. But if something turns out bad, we blame the advisor.

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 告诉我们很少听到的敬酒词：

Charles Munger tells us about the toast we seldom hear:

.. Arco 正在庆祝他们从阿拉斯加的北坡油田赚了很多钱的巨大胜利。那里的众议院律师是一位爱尔兰人，他非常直言不讳，而且很有魅力。他受到高度重视。所以他可以坦诚相待。整个团队都在互相敬酒：“我们不是因为做了这件伟大的事情而成为伟大的人吗？” 这位爱尔兰众议院律师举起酒杯说：“好吧，我想为真正使我们取得胜利的人干杯。” 他说，“向费萨尔国王致敬……我们所做的每一次计算都偏离了 200%。所有的成本都比我们想象的要高得多，困难也比我们想象的要大得多。我们所做的所有预测都是完全愚蠢的，不会已经与我们预测的油价一起工作。但随之而来的是费萨尔国王和石油卡特尔，他们将石油价格抬得如此之高，以至于他们让我们所有人看起来都很好。让我们今晚在这里表彰合适的人。”

这是你在公司生活中很少听到的祝酒词——因为对于大多数人来说，这样的祝酒词会让你被解雇。一个把现实带进愉快的聚会，让人们面对自己的局限和错误的人，前途渺茫。

.. .Arco was celebrating their huge triumph of making a lot of money out of the North Slope oilfields in Alaska. And the house counsel there was an Irishman who was very outspoken and had a fair amount of charm. And he was highly regarded. So he could get by with talking frankly. And the whole group was toasting one another:"Aren’t we great people for having done this great thing?" and this Irish house counsel raised his glass and said"Well, I’d like to toast the man who really caused our triumph." He said,"Here’s to King Faisal.. .Every calculation we made was off by 200%. All the costs were way higher, and the difficulties way greater than we ever conceived. All the predictions we made were totally asinine and wouldn’t have worked with the oil prices we projected. But along came King Faisal and the oil cartel and raised the price of oil so high that they made us all look good. Let’s honor the proper man here tonight."

This is the kind of toast you will seldom hear in corporate life — because for most people, a toast like that will get you fired. And a guy who’s bringing reality into a pleasant party, and making people face their own limitations and errors, will have poor prospects.

比尔是一名外科医生，他总是使用手术来处理健康问题，即使这些问题可以通过侵入性较小的手术治愈。

Bill is a surgeon who always uses surgery to handle health problems even if they could be cured by a less invasive procedure.

正如那句老话所说：“如果你拥有的唯一工具是锤子，那么你就会像对待钉子一样对待每一个问题。” 我们对某个主题了解或自认为了解得越多，就越不愿意使用其他想法。相反，我们倾向于以符合我们专业领域的方式解决问题。一个给定的想法越有用——无论它是否适合手头的问题——我们就越对其有用性过于自信。在 Bill 的案例中，也可能有推荐医疗程序的经济激励。

As the old saying goes:"If the only tool you have is a hammer, you approach every problem as if it were a nail." The more we know or think we know about a subject, the less willing we are to use other ideas. Instead, we tend to solve a problem in a way that agrees with our area of expertise. And the more useful a given idea is - whether or not it’s appropriate to the problem at hand - the more overconfident we are about its usefulness. In Bill’s case, there may also be financial incentives to recommend a medical procedure.

专家喜欢将他们的想法从一个领域外推到所有其他领域。他们以适合他们工具的方式而不是与潜在问题一致的方式来定义问题。给某人一个工具，他们就会想要使用它，甚至过度使用它，无论是否有必要。

Experts love to extrapolate their ideas from one field to all other fields. They define problems in ways that fit their tools rather than ways that agree with the underlying problem. Give someone a tool and they’ll want to use it, and even overuse it, whether it’s warranted or not.

为什么“锤子综合症”总是存在？查尔斯·芒格回答说：“好吧，如果你停下来想想，那就是激励导致的偏见。他的职业声誉完全与他所知道的有关。他喜欢自己，喜欢自己的想法，而且他向其他人表达了这些想法——一致性和承诺倾向 [见 6.一致性]，

Why is man-with-a-hammer syndrome always present? Charles Munger answers:"Well if you stop to think about it, it’s incentive-caused bias. His professional reputation is all tied up with what he knows. He likes himself and he likes his own ideas, and he’s expressed them to other people — consistency and commitment tendency [see 6. Consistency],

“我聘请她做我的助理，因为她长得漂亮，口齿伶俐，大学毕业，给人的第一印象很好。”

"I hired her as my assistant since she was good-looking, articulate and had a university degree. She gave a great first impression."

我们在判断性格方面有多好？夏洛克·福尔摩斯在亚瑟·柯南·道尔的《四签名》中说：“最重要的是不要让你的判断受到个人品质的影响。我向你保证，我所知道的最成功的女人因毒害三个小孩而被绞死因为他们的保险金，而我认识的人中最令人反感的是一位慈善家，他在伦敦穷人身上花费了将近 25 万美元。”

How good are we at judging personalities? Sherlock Holmes says in Arthur Conan Doyle’s The Sign of Four that:"It is of the first importance not to allow your judgement to be biased by personal qualities. I assure you that the most winning woman I ever knew was hanged for poisoning three little children for their insurance-money, and the most repellent man of my acquaintance is a philanthropist who has spent nearly a quarter of a million upon the London poor."

我们会立即对人们进行分类，这会让人联想到许多联想。我们经常让一个特征影响所有其他特征，因此判断人们比实际情况更好或更差。关于某些人、种族、宗教或职业的先入为主的观念使我们不自觉地认为来自特定群体的个人具有特殊特征。

We immediately classify people which brings to mind a host of associations. We often allow one trait to color all other characteristics and therefore judge people as better or worse than they really are. Preconceived ideas about certain people, races, religions, or occupations cause us to automatically assume that an individual from a particular group has special characteristics.

物理学教授罗杰·牛顿 (Roger Newton) 在《科学的真相》(The Truth of Science)中观察到：“科学家也是人……他们有时会屈服于嫉妒、虚荣心等弱点，在极少数情况下，甚至会不诚实。” Gian-Carlo Rota 在Indiscrete Thoughts中说：“一个好的数学家不一定是一个好人。”

Physics Professor Roger Newton observes in The Truth of Science:"Scientists are human...they sometimes succumb to weaknesses such as jealousy, vanity, and, on very rare instances, even dishonesty." Gian-Carlo Rota says in Indiscrete Thoughts:"A good mathematician is not necessarily a nice guy."

“当我面试某人时，我已经通过阅读求职申请形成了印象。然后我只是试图在面试中找到确认证据。”

"When I interview someone I have already formed an impression from reading the job applications. Then I just try to find confirming evidence at the interviews."

 访谈对于预测潜在员工未来的行为通常作用有限。正如心理学教授 Robyn Dawes 在Rational Choice in an Uncertain World中指出的那样：“面试官可以在半小时到一个小时内学到申请人记录中没有的东西？”

 Interviews are often of limited use to predict a potential employee’s future behaviour. As Psychology Professor Robyn Dawes notes in Rational Choice in an Uncertain World:"What can an interviewer learn in a half-hour to an hour that is not present in the applicant’s record?"

一个善于表达的人可能比一个含蓄的人更有说服力，但后者可能知道他在说什么。

An articulate person may be more persuasive than a reserved person, but the latter may know what he is talking about.

为什么有些人似乎有评价人的直觉？也许他们的生活经历使他们有能力（通过提问和观察行为）寻找个人性格的线索。

Why do some people seem to have an intuition for evaluating people? Maybe their life experiences gives them the ability (by asking questions and observing behaviour) to look for clues to an individual’s character.

沃伦巴菲特谈到如何识别可能导致问题的人时说：“我并不是说你可以带 100 个人来看看他们并分析他们的性格或任何类似的东西。但我认为当你看到极端情况时案例 - 那些只会给你带来麻烦，而那些只会给你带来快乐 - 好吧，我认为你可以很好地识别它们。” 查尔斯·芒格补充道，“其实我觉得很简单：诚信、智慧、经验和奉献精神。这就是人类企业要经营好所需要的。”

Warren Buffett says on how to identify people that may cause problem:"I’m not saying that you can take 100 people and take a look at ‘em and analyze their personalities or anything of the sort. But I think when you see the extreme cases - the ones that are going to cause you nothing but trouble and the ones that are going to bring you nothing but joy — well, I think you can identify those pretty well." Charles Munger adds,"Actually, I think it’s pretty simple: There’s integrity, intelligence, experience, and dedication. That’s what human enterprises need to run well."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 德国传教士史怀哲博士说：“乐观者是处处都看到绿灯的人，而悲观者只看到红灯。真正聪明的人是色盲。”

  • German missionary Dr. Albert Schweitzer said:"An optimist is a person who sees a green light everywhere, while the pessimist sees only the red stop-light. The truly wise person is color-blind."

  • 过度自信会导致不切实际的期望，使我们更容易失望。

  • Overconfidence can cause unreal expectations and make us more vulnerable to disappointment.

  • 认识到你的极限。你对你不知道的事情了解多少？不要让你的自我决定你应该做什么。查尔斯·芒格说：“像我们这样的人通过始终不犯傻，而不是努力变得非常聪明，从而获得了如此多的长期优势，这是值得注意的。民间说法一定有一些智慧：‘游泳健将’谁淹死了。

  • Recognize your limits. How well do you know what you don’t know? Don’t let your ego determine what you should do. Charles Munger says,"It is remarkable how much long-term advantage people like us have gotten by trying to be consistently not stupid, instead of trying to be very intelligent. There must be some wisdom in the folk saying: ‘It’s the strong swimmers who drown.’"

  • 沃伦巴菲特说：“我们不会做任何我们认为我们不了解自己的事情。”

  • Warren Buffett says:"We won’t do anything that we don’t think we understand ourselves."

  • 关注可能出错的地方和后果。在决策中建立一些安全边际。知道如果事情出错你将如何处理。惊喜以许多不太可能的方式发生。问：我怎么会错？如果我错了谁能告诉我？

  • Focus on what can go wrong and the consequences. Build in some margin of safety in decisions. Know how you will handle things if they go wrong. Surprises occur in many unlikely ways. Ask: How can I be wrong? Who can tell me if I’m wrong?

  • 通过仅发展少数优势，我们拥有一个贫乏的工具箱 - 只有锤子。我们需要一个完整的工具包。由于问题不遵循地域界限，我们必须通过使用其他学科的重要思想来弥补一个思想的偏见。

  • By developing only a handful of strengths, we have an impoverished toolbox - only hammers. We need a full tool-kit. Since problems don’t follow territorial boundaries, we must compensate for the bias of one idea by using important ideas from other disciplines.

  • 考虑人们在很长一段时间内的实际成就和过去的行为，而不是第一印象。由于人们在生活中会留下记录，因此个人的纸质记录通常可以预测未来的表现和行为。

  • Consider people’s actual accomplishments and past behaviour over a long period of time rather than first impressions. Since people leave track records in life, an individual’s paper record is often predictive of future performance and behaviour.

  • 在比较记录或表现时，请记住，成功比失败更受关注。

  • When comparing records or performances, remember that successes draw far more attention than failures.

5. 自我欺骗和否认

5. Self-deception and Denial

没有什么比自欺欺人更容易了。对于每个人希望的，他也相信是真实的。

Nothing is easier than self-deceit. For what each man wishes, that he also believes to be true.

- Demosthenes

（希腊政治家，公元前 384-322 年）

- Demosthenes

(Greek statesman, 384-322 BC)

约翰不能向别人承认他做了一笔糟糕的交易。失去一些。”

John couldn’t admit to others that he’d made a bad deal."I was almost right! I lost money, but others lost more. It wasn’t my fault. It was out of my control! You win some, you lose some."

我们否认和歪曲现实以感到更舒服，尤其是当现实威胁到我们的自身利益时。引用奥地利心理学家西格蒙德·弗洛伊德的话：“幻觉向我们推荐自己，因为它们让我们免于痛苦，反而让我们享受快乐。” 我们以我们想要的方式看待事物。我们听到我们想听到的，否认与我们根深蒂固的信念不一致的东西。我们否认不愉快的消息，宁愿安慰而不是真相。我们选择合适的人来问。我们通过给自己讲安慰的故事来理解糟糕的事件，这些故事赋予了它们意义。

We deny and distort reality to feel more comfortable, especially when reality threatens our self-interest. To quote the Austrian psychologist Sigmund Freud: "Illusions commend themselves to us because they save us pain and allow us to enjoy pleasure instead." We view things the way we want to see them. We hear what we want to hear and deny what is inconsistent with our deeply held beliefs. We deny unpleasant news and prefer comfort to truth. We choose the right people to ask. We make sense of bad events by telling ourselves comforting stories that give them meaning.

“我希望该项目能按时并在预算内取得成功。”

"I hope the project succeeds in time and on budget."

希腊历史学家修昔底德 (Thucydides) 在讲述公元前 5 世纪主要对手雅典和斯巴达之间的战争事件时写道：“……他们的判断更多地是基于盲目的希望，而不是任何可靠的预测；因为人类习惯于将他们所渴望的寄托于漫不经心的希望，并使用至高无上的理性将他们不想要的东西搁置一旁。” 一厢情愿的想法植根于否认，为我们提供了一个更愉快的现实。在业务中，这是项目延迟和成本超支的原因之一。

In relating the events of the 5th Century B.C. war between the main adversaries Athens and Sparta, the Greek historian Thucydides wrote:"...their judgement was based more upon blind wishing than upon any sound prediction; for it is a habit of mankind to entrust to careless hope what they long for, and to use sovereign reason to thrust aside what they do not desire." Wishful thinking is rooted in denial, offering us a more pleasant reality. In business, this is one reason for project delays and cost overruns.

我们相信某件事是真的，因为它听起来可信，或者我们想相信它，尤其是在爱情、健康、宗教和死亡等问题上。这就是人们追随大师的原因之一。他们鼓励追随者相信他们的心，忘记他们的头脑。哲学家和数学家伯特兰·罗素在《怀疑论》中说 ：“需要的不是相信的意愿，而是求知的意愿，这恰恰相反。”

We believe something is true because it sounds believable or we want to believe it, especially with issues of love, health, religion, and death. This is one reason why people follow gurus. They encourage followers to trust their hearts and forget their heads. Philosopher and mathematician Bertrand Russell said in Skeptical Essays:"What is wanted is not the will to believe, but the will to find out, which is the exact opposite."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 美国物理学家理查德·费曼 (Richard Feynman) 在 1974 年著名的加州理工学院毕业典礼演讲中警告不要自欺欺人：“首要原则是你不能自欺欺人——你是最容易被愚弄的人。”

  • In his famous 1974 commencement address at Caltech, American physicist Richard Feynman warned against self-deception:"The first principle is that you must not fool yourself - and you are the easiest person to fool."

  • 奥地利哲学家路德维希·维特根斯坦在《文化与价值》中说：“没有什么比不欺骗自己更难的了”。我们必须如实看待世界。不是因为它是什么，也不是为了我们想要它成为什么。拒绝看不愉快的事实并不能使它们消失。真实的坏消息胜过错误的好消息。

  • Austrian philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein said in Culture and Value: "Nothing is so difficult as not deceiving oneself." We have to see the world as it is. Not for what it was or for what we want it to be. Refusing to look at unpleasant facts doesn’t make them disappear. Bad news that is true is better than good news that is wrong.

  • 否认必须与社会、经济、身体和情感成本进行权衡。当否认的代价大于面对现实的好处时，我们必须面对现实。

  • Denial must be weighed against social, financial, physical and emotional costs. When the cost of denial is worse than the benefit of facing reality, we must face reality.

6.一致性

6. Consistency

困难不在于新观念，而在于摆脱旧观念，对于我们大多数人来说，旧观念会蔓延到我们思想的每一个角落。

The difficulty lies not in the new ideas, but in escaping the old ones, which ramify, for those brought up as most of us have been, into every corner of our minds.

- 约翰梅纳德凯恩斯

（英国经济学家，1883-1946）

- John Maynard Keynes

(British economist, 1883-1946)

一旦我们作出承诺——承诺、选择、表明立场、投入时间、金钱或努力——我们希望保持一致。我们希望感觉到我们做出了正确的决定。我们对自己的行为投入的越多，就越难改变。

Once we’ve made a commitment — a promise, a choice, taken a stand, invested time, money or effort - we want to remain consistent. We want to feel that we’ve made the right decision. And the more we have invested in our behaviour the harder it is to change.

“我不能以与自我形象不一致的方式行事。我要维护声誉。我不想看起来软弱、愚蠢或丢脸。我想被视为友善、聪明和控制。”

"I can’t behave in a way that is inconsistent with my self-image. I have a reputation to uphold. I don’t want to look weak, dumb or lose face. I want to be seen as nice, smart and in control."

苏格兰哲学家和经济学家亚当·斯密在《道德情操论》中说：“我们对自己性格的看法完全取决于我们对过去行为的判断。对自己的看法很不愉快，因此我们经常故意转向使我们的观点远离那些可能使该判断不利的情况。”

Scottish philosopher and economist Adam Smith said in The Theory of the Moral Sentiments:"The opinion which we entertain of our own character depends entirely on our judgements concerning our past conduct. It is so disagreeable to think ill of ourselves, that we often purposely turn away our view from those circumstances which might render that judgement unfavourable."

我们希望保持积极的自我形象。当违反这一点时，我们会使用不同的防御措施来为我们的行为辩护。我们的行为方式也与他人对我们的看法一致。如果人们给我们贴上有才华的标签，我们就会努力表现得有才华，不管这是不是真的。

We want to maintain a positive self-image. When that is violated, we use different defenses in order to justify our behaviour. We also behave in ways that are consistent with how others see us. If people label us as talented, we try to appear talented whether or not it is true.

为什么我们会坚持一个坏主意、一段不愉快的关系或一笔失败的投资？为什么政客们在清楚战争是个坏主意之后还要继续打仗？

Why do we hang on to a bad idea, an unhappy relationship or a losing investment? Why do politicians continue fighting wars long after it is clear the war is a bad idea?

我们投入的时间、金钱、努力或痛苦越多，我们就越觉得有必要继续下去，我们就越重视某件事——不管它是否正确。我们不想浪费我们的努力。通过这种方式，我们可以保护我们的声誉并避免接受损失的痛苦。如果人们质疑我们的决定，我们会更加坚定，我们是对的。我们对承诺的个人责任感越强，就越难放弃。

The more time, money, effort or pain we invest, the more we feel the need to continue, and the more highly we value something - whether or not it is right. We don’t want to waste our efforts. This way we protect our reputation and avoid the pain of accepting a loss. If people challenge our decisions, we become even more committed we are right. And the more individual responsibility we feel for a commitment, the harder it is to give up.

在 Too Much Invested to Quit 中，心理学家 Allan Teger 谈到越南战争时说：“战争持续的时间越长，就可能取得胜利的价值而言，越难以证明额外投资的合理性。另一方面，战争持续的时间越长战争还在继续，要注销巨大的损失而没有任何可展示的东西就变得更加困难。”

In Too Much Invested to Quit, psychologist Allan Teger said about the Vietnam War:"The longer the war continued, the more difficult it was to justify the additional investments in terms of the value of possible victory. On the other hand, the longer the war continued, the more difficult it became to write off the tremendous losses without having anything to show for them."

约翰想聘请一位新的副总裁。他告诉每个人，这个人很棒，但新员工却成了一场灾难。约翰没有处理这个错误，而是留下了那个人，让他付出了很多钱，也让他很恼火。

John wanted to employ a new vice president. He told everyone that the guy was terrific but the new employee turned out to be a disaster. Instead of dealing with the mistake, John kept the guy, costing him much money and aggravation.

我们倾向于快速做出判断。很难改变第一个结论，因为改变意味着我们可能是错的（特别是如果我们需要向其他人解释改变）。我们将错误与对自身利益的威胁联系在一起。

We tend to make fast judgements. It is hard to change a first conclusion since a change implies we may be wrong (especially if we need to explain the change to others). We associate being wrong with a threat to our self-interest.

沃伦巴菲特说：“人类最擅长的是解释所有新信息，以便他们先前的结论保持不变。” 17 世纪的英国哲学家弗朗西斯·培根补充道：“人类智力特有且永久性的错误是，肯定比否定更能打动和激发人类智力；然而，它应该适当地对两者保持冷漠的态度。” 我们寻找可以证实我们的想法、信念和行动的证据。想出我们可能会犯错的原因并不容易。例如，当我们进行投资、建立关系或做出其他类型的承诺时，我们倾向于寻找证据来证实这是正确的决定，而忽略表明这是错误的信息。

Warren Buffett says:"What the human being is best at doing is interpreting all new information so that their prior conclusions remain intact." The 17th Century English philosopher Francis Bacon adds:"it is the peculiar and perpetual error of the human intellect to be more moved and excited by affirmatives than by negatives; whereas it ought properly to hold itself indifferently disposed towards both alike." We look for evidence that confirms our ideas, beliefs, and actions. Devising reasons why we might be wrong doesn’t come easily. For example, when we’ve made an investment, entered into a relationship, or made other types of commitments, we tend to seek out evidence confirming that it was the right decision and to ignore information that shows it was wrong.

“我不想卖掉这只下跌的股票并面临亏损。我投入了 10 万美元。我必须向别人和我自己证明我的选择是正确的。”

"I don’t want to sell this declining stock and face a loss. I put $100,000 into this. I must prove to others and myself I made the right choice."

买入股票后，我们比投资前更有信心这是一笔不错的买入。我们希望感觉我们做了正确的事，并使我们的信念与我们所做的保持一致。但一切都没有改变。之前和之后都是一样的生意。

After we buy a stock, we are more confident it was a good buy than before the investment. We want to feel we did the right thing and keep our beliefs consistent with what we’ve done. But nothing has changed. It is the same business before and after.

“我认为放弃一个已经投入 1000 万美元的项目是愚蠢的。” TransCorp 的首席执行官说。

"I think it’s foolish to abandon a project on which $10 million has been sunk." said the CEO of TransCorp.

为什么我们仅仅因为付出了代价就做某事？

Why do we do things merely because we’ve paid for them?

假设约翰为会议支付了 1,000 美元的不可退还费用，但他不想再参加了。他觉得他不能浪费已经花掉的 1,000 美元。因为他已经花了 1,000 美元，他应该去参加会议吗？他应该支付 1,000 美元去做他不想做的事情吗？钱永远丢失了。说已经花掉的1000美元是做他真正想做的事情的成本不是更好吗？花钱做自己想做的事不是更好吗？

Assume John paid a $ 1,000 non-refundable fee for a conference, but he no longer wants to participate. He feels he can’t afford to waste the already spent $ 1,000. Should he go to the conference because he already spent $ 1,000? Should he pay $ 1,000 to do something he doesn’t want to do? The money is lost forever. Isn’t it better to say that the already spent $ 1,000 is the cost of doing what he really wants to do? Isn’t it better to pay to do what you want?

约翰和玛丽只是因为买了票才看完一部糟糕的电影。他们不能拿回他们花掉的八美元，所以他们离开与不离开应该没有什么区别。结果是一样的——钱已经花光了。选择是享受美好时光还是糟糕时光。

John and Mary sit through a lousy movie simply because they bought the tickets. They can’t get the eight dollars they spent back so it shouldn’t make a difference whether they leave or not. The consequences are the same - the money has already been spent. The choice is between having a good time or a lousy time.

“我们根据战略计划中规定的产量增加投资了一台新机器。不幸的是，产量下降了。”

"We invested in a new machine based on the volume-increase set out in the strategic plan. Unfortunately, volume decreased."

当我们做出公开的、努力的或自愿的承诺时，我们是最一致的。决定越公开，我们更改它的可能性就越小。书面承诺是强有力的，因为它们比口头承诺需要更多的努力，而且还可以公开。

We are most consistent when we have made a public, effortful or voluntary commitment. The more public a decision is, the less likely it is that we will change it. Written commitments are strong since they require more effort than verbal commitments and can also be made public.

做有意义的事情难道不是比坚持行不通的战略计划更好吗？沃伦巴菲特说，“我们确实有一些优势，也许最大的优势是我们没有战略计划。因此我们觉得没有必要朝着既定的方向前进（这一过程几乎总是导致愚蠢的购买价格）但可以而不是简单地决定什么对我们的所有者有意义。” 查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 谈到长期计划的价值时说：

Isn’t it better to do what makes sense than to stay consistent with a strategic plan that isn’t working? Warren Buffett says,"We do have a few advantages, perhaps the greatest being that we don’t have a strategic plan. Thus we feel no need to proceed in an ordained direction (a course leading almost invariably to silly purchase prices) but can instead simply decide what makes sense for our owners." Charles Munger says on the value of long-term plans:

我们非常认同威廉·奥斯勒爵士 (Sir William Osler) 将约翰霍普金斯医学院 (John Hopkins Medical School) 从一个非常贫穷的开端建设成为全世界模范医学院时所持有的企业理念。威廉·奥斯勒爵士说——他引用了卡莱尔的话——是：“人的任务不是看远处模糊的东西，而是做眼前清楚的事情。”

我们试图每天、每周、每月、每年对手头的信息和挑战做出明智的反应——必须转移的可怕攻击、必须摆脱的事情、随之而来的不寻常的机会——而且只是尽我们所能应对这些挑战。显然，您会尽可能向前看。但这不是很远。但是，如果您对摆在您面前的挑战做出明智而勤奋的反应，我们认为您最终会得到一个相当不错的机构。

We have very much the philosophy of building our enterprise that Sir William Osler had when he built the John Hopkins Medical School from a very poor start into a model medical school for the whole world. And what Sir William Osler said - and he quoted this from Carlyle — was:"The task of man is not to see what lies dimly in the distance, but to do what lies clearly at hand."

We try to respond intelligently each day, each week, each month, each year to the information and challenges at hand - horrible assaults that have to be deflected, things that have to be scrambled out of, the unusual opportunities that come along — and just do the best job we can in responding to those challenges. Obviously, you look ahead as far as you can. But that’s not very far. But if you respond intelligently and diligently to the challenges before you, we think you’ll tend to end up with a pretty good institution.

德国物理学家马克斯·普朗克在他的科学自传和其他论文中说：“一个新的科学真理并不是通过说服它的对手并让他们看到光明而取得胜利，而是因为它的对手最终死去，而新一代熟悉的人成长起来它。”

In his Scientific Autobiography and Other Papers, German physicist Max Planck said:"A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing its opponents and making them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die and a new generation grows up that is familiar with it."

沃伦巴菲特补充道：

Warren Buffett adds:

我想是凯恩斯说的，“大多数经济学家对想法最经济 - 他们使他们在研究生院学到的东西终生受益。” 发生的事情是您花了数年时间获得博士学位。在财务上。而且[在这个过程中]，你会学到很多普通外行无法做到的数学理论。所以你变成了一个大祭司。就自我而言，甚至是职业安全感，你最终会投入大量的精力在这些想法上。因此，在给定点之后很难退缩。

I think it was Keynes who said,"Most economists are most economical about ideas - they make the ones they learned in graduate school last a lifetime." What happens is that you spend years getting your Ph.D. in finance. And [in the process], you learn theories with a lot of mathematics that the average layman can’t do. So you become sort of a high priest. And you wind up with an enormous amount of yourself in terms of your ego — and even professional security - invested in those ideas. Therefore, it gets very hard to back off after a given point.

“我已经为此投入了 15 年的生命，所以我现在不会走开。”

"I have invested 15 years of my life in this, so I wont walk away now."

假设一对夫妇的婚姻不佳，但他们已经在一起生活了 15 年。他们应该离婚还是应该“留在那儿”并因为他们已经投入了 15 年的生命而保持不快乐？

Let’s say that a couple is in a bad marriage but have spent 15 years together. Should they get a divorce or should they"stay in there" and remain unhappy because they have invested 15 years of their life?

一致性可能会让我们陷入哪些其他陷阱？

What other traps may consistency cause us to fall into?

约翰和他的家人决定买一辆新车。他们选择了一家同意以比竞争对手低 1,000 美元的价格出售汽车的经销商。然后销售员改变了条款。他发现了一个错误。最后，价格比竞争对手高出 200 美元。

John and his family decided to buy a new car. They chose a dealership that agreed to sell the car $1,000 below the competition. Then the salesman changed the terms. He had discovered an error. In the end, the price ended up $200 above competition.

在低球技术中，销售人员激励客户签订协议，意图改变条款以对卖方有利（通过消除优势或添加不受欢迎的内容）。一旦约翰做出决定并花时间和精力购买新车，他就承诺购买。否则他会显得前后矛盾。他没有退出交易，而是找到了新的理由来证明他购买这辆车是合理的。政治家在选举中经常使用低球。

In the low-ball technique, the salesperson gives the customer an incentive to enter into an agreement with the intention of changing the terms to the seller’s advantage (either by removing the advantage or adding something undesirable). Once John made the decision and took the time and effort to buy a new car, he committed to the purchase. Otherwise he would appear inconsistent. Instead of backing out of the deal, he found new reasons to justify his purchase of the car. Low-ball is often used by politicians in elections.

“买冰箱真是太划算了，”玛丽读着广告说。

"What a great deal for a refrigerator," Mary said, reading the advertisements.

当她到达商店时，销售人员告诉她，他们的特价商品已售罄。但是他们有类似的存货。而且只多了150美元。她买了冰箱。她已经下定决心要买一台冰箱，而销售人员只是强迫她保持一致。

When she gets to the store, the salesperson tells her that they ran out of the advertised specials. But they have a similar one in stock. And it is only $ 150 more. She buys the refrigerator. She is already committed to buying a refrigerator and the salesperson only forces her to be consistent.

坐在谈判桌上，对手问约翰，“你知道你和 TransCorp 的经理们以合作和公平着称吗？”

Sitting at the negotiation table, the opponent asked John,"Did you know that you and the managers of TransCorp are widely known to be cooperative and fair?"

在标签技术中，人们试图通过首先给我们的个性或价值观贴上与他们希望我们采取的行为一致的标签来让我们做出承诺。我们通常会遵守与标签一致的后期请求。这就是为什么约翰的对手给了约翰一个维护的声誉。

In the labelling technique, people try to get us committed by first applying a label to our personality or values that is consistent with the behaviour they want us to take. We often comply to later requests that are consistent with the label. That is why John’s opponent gave John a reputation to uphold.

“你今天会送我的孩子上学吗？” 玛丽的邻居问道。一个月后，玛丽发现自己仍在开车送邻居的孩子上学，甚至开车去看电影。

"Will you take my kids to school today?" Mary’s neighbour asked. One month later, Mary found herself still driving her neighbours’ kids to school and even to the movies.

人们如何在经济、政治或性方面引诱我们？他们让我们首先同意一个小请求，小到没有人会拒绝。这样他们就做出了承诺。然后他们提出第二个更大的要求（他们一直想要的那个）。这样我们就更有可能遵守。这种“登门拜访”的原则是，如果人们要求我们做出小承诺，我们就更有可能同意更大的要求，因为我们希望表现得始终如一。

How do people seduce us financially, politically or sexually? They make us first agree to a small request, so small that no one would refuse. This way they create a commitment. Then they make a second and larger request (the one they wanted all along). We are then more likely to comply. This"foot-in-the-door technique" is based on the principle that if people ask us to make a small commitment, we are more likely to agree to a larger request because we want to appear consistent.

一项研究表明，76% 的房主同意在他们家门前的草坪上放一块大广告牌，上面写着“小心驾驶”。两周前，其他研究人员联系了房主，要求他们在车窗上放置一个写着“安全驾驶”的小标志。他们现在将自己视为关心的公民和足够关心驾驶员安全的人，以表态。他们还相信其他人就是这样看他们的。后来与他们接洽时，76% 的人同意张贴大标志只是为了保持一致。相比之下，只有 17% 没有接受过较早访问的受试者同意张贴大牌子。

One study showed that 76% of a group of home-owners agreed to put a large billboard on their front lawn, saying"Drive Carefully." Two weeks earlier, the home-owners had been approached by other researchers, asking them to place a tiny sign saying"Be a Safe driver" on their car windows. They now saw themselves as concerned citizens and people who care enough about driver safety to take a stand. They also believed that was how other people saw them. When they were later approached, 76% agreed putting up the large sign just to be consistent. In contrast, only 17% of subjects who hadn’t received the earlier visit agreed to put up the large sign.

当人们让我们做出承诺时，我们就会变得负责任。一项实验安排了一场盗窃，以了解旁观者是否会冒着人身伤害的危险来制止犯罪。一位研究人员坐在沙滩毯上，在距离随机选择的人的毯子五英尺的地方收听他的便携式收音机。过了一会儿，研究人员离开毯子去海滩散步。几分钟后，另一名研究员假装是小偷，抓起收音机就跑了。二十个人中有四个人通过挑战小偷而使自己受到伤害。但当程序有所不同时，有 19 个人成为治安维持者，并试图阻止小偷。区别？在散步之前，研究人员要求受试者“请看好我的东西”，他们都同意这样做。

When people get us to commit, we become responsible. One experiment staged a theft to find out if onlookers would risk personal harm to stop a crime. A researcher sat on a beach blanket and listened to his portable radio five feet from the blanket of a randomly chosen person. After awhile, the researcher left the blanket to stroll the beach. A few minutes later a second researcher, pretending to be a thief, grabbed the radio and ran away. Four people out of twenty put themselves in harm by challenging the thief. But when the procedure was tried somewhat differently, nineteen people became vigilantes, and tried to stop the thief. The difference? Before taking his stroll, the researcher asked the subject to"please watch my things" which they all agreed to do.

17 世纪的英国诗人塞缪尔·巴特勒写道：“违背自己意愿而服从的人，仍然坚持自己的观点。” 我们如何让人们对自己的行为负起内心的责任？让它成为自愿的。当我们受到满足或兴趣的内在激励，当我们感到一切尽在掌控之中，以及当我们不受激励或外部压力影响时，我们就会对自己的行为负责。

The 17th Century English poet Samuel Butler wrote:"He that complies against his will, is of his own opinion still." How do we get people to take inner responsibility for their actions? Make it voluntary. We take responsibility for our behaviour in cases when we are internally motivated by satisfaction or interest, when we feel in control, and when we are free from incentives or outside pressure.

坚定的信念可能很危险。

Strong convictions can be dangerous.

德国哲学家弗里德里希·威廉·尼采写道：“信念比谎言更危险地成为真理的敌人。” 对政治、宗教或哲学思想的强烈承诺会造成意识形态偏见。具有各种政治、宗教和哲学兴趣的人有动力去寻求证实这些兴趣的真理。永远不要低估意识形态的力量。它们可以充当为战争和暴力辩护的工具。正如布莱斯·帕斯卡 (Blaise Pascal) 所写：“人们做恶的时候，从来没有像出于宗教信仰时那样彻底和愉快。”

The German philosopher Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche wrote:"Convictions are more dangerous enemies of truth than lies." Intense commitments for political, religious or philosophical ideas create an ideological bias. People with various political, religious, and philosophical interests are motivated to seek the truths that confirm these interests. Never underestimate the power of ideology. They can act as a device for justifying war and violence. As Blaise Pascal wrote:"Men never do evil so completely and cheerfully as when they do it from religious conviction."

查尔斯芒格告诉我们意识形态的危险：

Charles Munger tells us about the danger of ideology:

沉重的意识形态是对人类认知最极端的扭曲者之一。看看这些伊斯兰原教旨主义者，他们刚刚枪杀了一群喊着“上帝的杰作！”的希腊游客。

意识形态做了一些奇怪的事情，严重扭曲了认知。如果你年轻时就有很多沉重的意识形态——然后，你开始表达它——你真的把你的大脑锁定在一个非常不幸的模式中。你会扭曲你的一般认知。

如果您以沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 作为世俗智慧的例子，那么有一段非常有趣的历史：沃伦崇拜他的父亲——他是一个了不起的人。但他是一个非常沉重的理论家，（右翼，恰好是），与其他非常沉重的理论家混在一起，（右翼，自然）。沃伦小时候观察到这一点。他认为意识形态是危险的——他要远离它。他一生都有。这极大地帮助了他认知的准确性。

我以不同的方式学到了同样的教训。我父亲讨厌意识形态。所以，我只要效法父亲，走自己认为正确的路。像右边的多曼或左边的纳德这样的人显然有点愚蠢。它们是意识形态会对你做什么的极端例子——尤其是暴力表达的意识形态。因为它灌输想法比说服它更好，所以这是一件非常危险的事情。

Heavy ideology is one of the most extreme distorters of human cognition. Look at these Islamic Fundamentalists who just gunned down a bunch of Greek tourists shouting,"God’s work!"

Ideology does some strange things and distorts cognition terribly. If you get a lot of heavy ideology young - and, then, you start expressing it - you are really locking your brain into a very unfortunate pattern. And you are going to distort your general cognition.

There’s a very interesting history if you take Warren Buffett as an example of worldly wisdom: Warren adored his father — who was a wonderful man. But he was a very heavy ideologue, (right wing, it happened to be), who hung around with other very heavy ideologues, (right wing, naturally). Warren observed this as a kid. And he decided that ideology was dangerous — and that he was going to stay a long way away from it. And he has throughout his whole life. That has enormously helped the accuracy of his cognition.

I learned the same lesson in a different way. My father hated ideology. Therefore, all I had to do was imitate my father and, thereby, stay in what I regard as the right path. People like Doman on the right or Nader on the left have obviously gone a little daft. They’re extreme examples of what ideology will do to you - particularly violently expressed ideology. Since it pounds ideas in better than it convinces out, it’s a very dangerous thing to do.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 一个决定必须是活跃的。Lucius Annaeus Seneca 说：“当情况发生变化时改变计划并没有错。” 爱尔兰作家乔纳森·斯威夫特说：“一个人永远不应该为承认自己错了而感到羞耻，换句话说，这只是在说，他今天比昨天聪明。” JM 凯恩斯说：“当有人说服我说我错了，我就会改变主意。你会怎么做？” 有时事情并不像我们相信的那样发展。解决办法是面对它并采取行动。查尔斯芒格说：“我们已经做了很多这样的事情——从错误的决定中逃脱出来。我认为这是拥有合理生活记录的重要组成部分。你无法避免错误的决定。但如果你及时认识到它们对它们做点什么，你经常可以把柠檬变成柠檬水。”

  • A decision must be active. Lucius Annaeus Seneca said:"There is nothing wrong with changing a plan when the situation has changed." Irish writer Jonathan Swift said:"A man should never be ashamed to own that he has been in the wrong, which is but saying, in other words, that he is wiser today than he was yesterday." J.M. Keynes said:"When somebody persuades me that I am wrong, I change my mind. What do you do?" Sometimes things don’t go the way we believe they will. The solution is to face it and act. Charles Munger says:"We’ve done a lot of that — scrambled out of wrong decisions. I would argue that that’s a big part of having a reasonable record in life. You can’t avoid wrong decisions. But if you recognize them promptly and do something about them, you can frequently turn the lemon into lemonade."

  • 如果我们能让人们提前做出承诺，他们往往会兑现承诺。例如，使人们在某些问题上采取自愿和公开的立场。

  • If we can get people committed in advance, they tend to live up to their commitment. For example, make people take a voluntary and public position on some issue.

  • 不要强迫人们公开做出您以后不希望有机会改变的承诺。

  • Don’t force people to publicly make commitments that you don’t later want the opportunity to change.

  • 当你被要求执行一项未来行动但不确定时，问问自己：如果我明天必须这样做，我会这样做吗？

  • When you are asked to perform a future action but are uncertain, ask yourself: Would I do this if I had to do it tomorrow?

  • 沃伦巴菲特说，“当你发现自己陷入困境时，最重要的事情就是停止挖掘。” 仅仅因为您在某个项目或投资上花费了金钱或时间并不意味着您必须在未来继续花费它。花费的时间、精力和金钱都没有了。决定应该基于你想去的地方。不是你去过的地方。根据当前情况和未来后果做出决策。过去发生的事情可能是估计未来发生某事的可能性的指南。问：我想达到什么目的？是什么原因造成的？考虑到我今天所知道的以及未来可能发生的事情，我应该如何行动来实现我的目标？投入的新资金和时间能否实现我的目标？假设我从来没有投资过这个，而且它是第一次出现在我面前，我今天会投资吗？如果不，然后停下来做点什么。正如查尔斯·芒格所说：

    伯克希尔从它[纺织业务]中提取了大量资金并将其投入其他地方。而且，如果伯克希尔试图用越来越多的资金来继续抗击该业务的衰退，它就会耗尽大部分资本。有战斗的时候，也有逃跑的时候。我最喜欢的故事之一，与这个故事有关，涉及南方的一个小镇。有一家大型杂货店，由一家大型全国连锁店拥有。他们是一个强大的竞争对手，多年来他们一直是这个镇上占主导地位的大型杂货店，而且销量很大。沃尔玛的山姆沃尔顿宣布他将开设一家更大更好的杂货店，以极低的价格出售许多其他优质产品。而现有的非常有经验和成功的连锁店，并没有等到山姆·沃尔顿的店开张。

  • Warren Buffett says,"The most important thing to do when you find yourself in a hole is to stop digging." Merely because you’ve spent money or time on some project or investment doesn’t mean you must continue to spend it in the future. Time, effort, and money spent are gone. Decisions should be based on where you want to be. Not where you’ve been. Base decisions on the present situation and future consequences. What happened in the past may be a guide for estimating how likely something is to happen in the future. Ask: What do I want to achieve? What causes that? Considering what I know today and what is likely to happen in the future, how should I act to achieve my goal? Will new money and time invested achieve my goal? Assume I never invested in this and it was presented to me for the first time, would I invest in it today? If not, then stop and do something about it. As Charles Munger says:

    Berkshire extracted a lot of capital out of it [the textile business] and put it elsewhere. And if Berkshire had tried to keep fighting the decline of that business with more and more money, it would have blown most of its capital. There’s a time to fight and there’s a time to run away. One of my favourite stories, relevant to this story, involves a town in the South. There was this huge grocery store owned by one of the great national chains. They’re a formidable competitor and they had the dominant big grocery store in this town for many, many years doing big volume. Sam Walton of Wal-Mart announced that he was opening a much bigger, better grocery store with a lot of other wonderful products at incredibly low prices. And the existing very experienced and successful chain, did not wait for Sam Walton’s store to open. They just closed their store right away.

  • 让没有承诺早先决定的人接管这个问题。

  • Let someone who wasn’t committed to an earlier decision take over the issue.

  • “事实不会因为被忽视而停止存在，”英国小说家奥尔道斯赫胥黎说。如果我们只是想确认我们的信念，我们永远不会发现我们是否错了。自我批评并忘记你最喜欢的想法。寻找否定想法和假设的证据。考虑替代结果、观点和答案。当你的想法不对时，请别人告诉你。沃伦巴菲特说，“查理和我相信，当你发现与你现有信念相矛盾的信息时，你有特殊的义务去审视它——而且要迅速。”

  • "Facts do not cease to exist because they are ignored," said British novelist Aldous Huxley. If we only look to confirm our beliefs, we will never discover if we’re wrong. Be self-critical and unlearn your best-loved ideas. Search for evidence that disconfirms ideas and assumptions. Consider alternative outcomes, viewpoints, and answers. Have someone tell you when your thinking is wrong. Warren Buffett says,"Charlie and I believe that when you find information that contradicts your existing beliefs, you’ve got a special obligation to look at it - and quickly."

  • 听从意大利艺术家和科学家列奥纳多·达·芬奇的建议：“我们很清楚，在别人的作品中比在自己的作品中更容易发现错误。当你绘画时，你应该拿一面平面镜，经常看你的作品。它，然后它会被保留下来，看起来出自其他大师之手，与其他任何方式相比，你将能够更好地判断它的缺点。”

  • Follow the advice of the Italian artist and scientist Leonardo da Vinci:"We know well that mistakes are more easily detected in the works of others than in one’s own. When you are painting you should take a flat mirror and often look at your work within it, and it will then be seen in reserve, and will appear to be by the hand of some other master, and you will be better able to judge of its faults than in any other way."

7.剥夺综合症

7. Deprival Syndrome

你不会改变人们喜欢的东西。

You don’t change something people love.

- Faith Popcorn

（美国未来学家）

- Faith Popcorn

(American futurist)

正如我们在第一部分中看到的，我们厌恶损失。我们不喜欢失去我们拥有的东西，而不是我们喜欢获得我们没有的东西。

As we’ve seen in Part One, we have an aversion to loss. We dislike losing the things we have more than we appreciate gaining the things we don’t have.

当我们喜欢的东西被（或有可能被）拿走时，我们通常会更看重它。剥夺人们的自由、地位、名誉、金钱或任何他们看重的东西，他们会感到不安。我们不想失去选择如何行动或相信或拥有什么的自由。例如，人们可能会反对剥夺他们长期享有的福利的限制性法律。我们越喜欢被拿走的东西，或者我们做出的承诺越大，我们就会变得越沮丧。这会造成仇恨、反抗、暴力和报复。

When something we like is (or threatens to be) taken away, we often value it higher. Take away people’s freedom, status, reputation, money or anything they value, and they get upset. We don’t like to lose the freedom to choose how to act or believe or what to have. For example, people are likely to fight a restrictive law that takes away a benefit they have enjoyed for a long time. The more we like what is taken away or the larger the commitment we’ve made, the more upset we become. This can create hatred, revolts, violence and retaliations.

当我们试图降低他们的收入时，人们会有什么反应？

How do people react when we try to lower their income?

查尔斯芒格在劳资谈判中谈判外卖时说明了剥夺的力量：

Charles Munger illustrates the power of deprival when negotiating takeaways in labour negotiations:

(A) 你正面临被剥夺的超级反应综合症——人们会发疯。(B) 工会代表必须向他的成员传达剥夺信息，并忍受由此产生的巴甫洛夫式的单纯联想仇恨。因此，他不会这样做——主要是出于这个原因。所以你有两种强大的心理影响让它变得地狱。

在 1800 年代末和 1900 年代初，平克顿警卫向人们开枪的所有罢工都是关于外卖的。到达的移民愿意廉价工作。资本家试图降低工资——有时是因为他们觉得必须这样做，因为他们的竞争对手正在这样做，有时是因为他们只是想赚更多的钱。无论如何，所有的谋杀和混乱都是被剥夺的超级反应综合症加上没有人愿意成为坏消息传播者这一现实的结果。

(A) You’re facing deprival super-reaction syndrome - people just go bananas. And (B) the union representative has to bring his members the deprival message and endure the Pavlovian mere-association hatred that results. Therefore, he won’t do it - largely for that reason. So you have two powerful psychological effects making it hell.

All of those strikes in the late 1800s and the early 1900s where Pinkerton guards were shooting people were about takeaways. Arriving immigrants were willing to work cheap. And capitalist proprietors tried to reduce wages — sometimes because they felt they had to because their competitors were doing it and sometimes because they simply wanted to make more money. At any rate, all of that murder and mayhem was the result of deprival super-reaction syndrome plus the reality that nobody wanted to be the carrier of bad news.

“我应该采取保守的做法。失败是令人尴尬的，可能会让我被解雇。”

"I should take the conservative approach. Failure is embarrassing and may get me fired."

人们对失败的厌恶可能使人过于保守或进行掩饰。

People’s aversion to losing may make people overly conservative or engage in cover-ups.

医生告诉玛丽：“如果你不改变你的行为，你可能会死。”

The doctor told Mary:"You may die if you do not change your behaviour."

我们对损失的厌恶使我们对对我们有负面影响的信息更加敏感。例如，与健康相关的信息既可以关注执行某项行为的好处（收益），也可以关注不执行该行为的可能成本（损失）。一项研究表明，当向女性提供的信息强调不进行自我检查可能带来的负面后果（失去健康、长寿）时，与关注这样做的好处的信息相比，女性更有可能进行乳房自我检查它。其他研究表明，在说服人们接受有风险的医疗程序时，关注积极结果（例如存活率）比关注消极结果（例如死亡率）更有效。

Our loss aversion makes us more sensitive to information that has negative implications for us. For example, health-related messages can either focus on the benefits of performing an act (gain) or the possible costs of not doing it (loss). One study showed that women were more likely to engage in breast self-examination when they were presented with information emphasizing the possible negative consequences (loss of good health, longevity) of not performing self-examination compared to information that focused on the benefits of doing it. Other studies show that when persuading people to undergo risky medical procedures, it is more effective to focus on positive outcomes (e.g. survival rate) than negative ones (e.g. mortality rate).

约翰告诉玛丽：“我现在不能卖股票。我必须等到它回到我买它的价位。无论如何，除非我卖掉，否则我不会亏本。”

John tells Mary:"I cant sell the stock now. I have to wait until it gets back up to what I paid for it. Anyway, I don’t realize a loss unless I sell."

我们不愿意承认我们亏了钱。我们对损失的厌恶会导致现状偏见——我们更愿意抓住我们拥有的东西。我们甚至对我们已经拥有的东西赋予更高的价值，而不是如果我们不拥有它们，我们愿意为同样的东西支付更高的价值（放弃它们感觉就像一种损失）。这就是为什么许多公司为其产品提供退款保证的原因。一旦我们占有了某些物品，我们就不太可能归还它。

We hate to admit we’ve lost money. Our loss aversion contributes to status quo bias — we prefer to hang on to what we have. We even put a higher value on the things we already own than we are willing to pay for the same things if we didn’t own them (giving them up feels like a loss). This is why many companies offer money-back guarantees on their products. Once we have taken possession of some item, we are not likely to return it.

查尔斯芒格说，“人类的被剥夺超级反应综合症有助于造成很多破坏，因为人们的认知由于他们遭受损失和看到有惊无险而被扭曲。” 我们讨厌卖出亏损的股票。这与向他人和我们自己承认我们犯了错误是一样的。因此，我们持有输家太久，过早卖出赢家。实际损失比在纸面上遭受同样的损失感觉更糟。对做出错误决定负责的痛苦也起到了一定的作用（后悔）。股票可能会在我们卖出后反弹。我们投入的金钱和努力越多，就越难放下。

Charles Munger says,"The deprival super-reaction syndrome of man helps cause much ruin as people’s cognition is distorted as a result of their suffering losses and seeing near misses." We hate to sell losing stocks. It is the same as admitting to others and ourselves that we’ve made a mistake. We therefore hold on to our losers too long and sell our winners too soon. A realized loss feels worse than suffering the same loss on paper. The pain of feeling responsible for making a bad decision also plays a role (regret). The stock may bounce back after we’ve sold. And the more money and effort we’ve put in, the harder it is to let it go.

我们也觉得失去赚钱的机会比失去同样多的钱更痛苦。但是失去赚取 100 美元的机会与实际损失 100 美元的价值相同。

We also feel that losing the opportunity to make money is less painful than losing the same amount of money. But a lost opportunity of making $100 has the same value as a real loss of $ 100.

约翰的朋友艾伦五年前以 20 万美元买了一栋房子。

John’s friend Allan bought a house five years ago for $200,000.

四年后，艾伦的公司搬到了另一个城市。当地房地产市场不景气。他得到了 170,000 美元，但他觉得自己不能承受损失。所以他又等了一年，这次出价是 150,000 美元。

Four years later, Allan’s company moves to another city. The local real estate market is depressed. He is offered $170,000 but feels he can’t afford a loss. So he waits another year and this time the offered price is $150,000.

对艾伦来说，专注于房子的价值而不是他付出的代价不是更好吗？

Isn’t it better for Allan to concentrate on what the house is worth rather than on what he paid?

约翰不停地往机器里投钱。

John kept pouring dollars in the machine."I got Cherry, Cherry, Bar. I’m close now."

当我们几乎拥有并失去它时，我们想要并赋予它更高的价值。查尔斯芒格说，“赛马、宾果游戏和这些东西一直如此受欢迎的一个原因是因为所有这些有惊无险。” 频繁的有惊无险就像是小小的援军，让我们想要再试一次。

We want and place higher value on something when we almost have it and lose it. Charles Munger says,"One reason why horse races, bingo and these things have always been so popular is because of all these near misses." Frequent near misses are like small reinforcements and make us want to try again and again.

正如人们在受到威胁时会冒更大的风险一样，在遭受损失后，我们想要追赶，所以我们最终会冒更多的风险来报复。但正如沃伦巴菲特和查尔斯芒格所说：

Just as people take larger risks when threatened, after a loss, we want to catch up, so we end up taking more risks to get even. But as Warren Buffett and Charles Munger say:

巴菲特：投资的一个非常重要的原则是你不必从失去的地方赚回来。事实上，试图让它回到失去的样子通常是错误的。

芒格：这就是为什么这么多人被赌博毁掉的原因——他们输了，然后他们觉得他们必须像失去的那样把它找回来。这是人性深处的一部分。舔它是非常聪明的-随意...

巴菲特：股票最重要的事情之一是股票不知道你拥有它。你对此有所有这些感受：你记得你付出了什么。你记得是谁告诉你的——所有这些小事。它根本不在乎。它只是坐在那里。如果一只股票的价格是 50 美元，那么有人支付了 100 美元并且感觉很糟糕；其他人已经支付了 10 美元并且感觉很棒 - 所有这些感觉。而且一点影响都没有...

Buffett: A very important principle in investing is that you don’t have to make it back the way you lost it. In fact, it’s usually a mistake to try to make it back the way you lost it.

Munger: That’s the reason so many people are ruined by gambling - they get behind and then they feel like they have to get it back the way they lost it. It’s a deep part of human nature. It’s very smart just to lick it - by will...

Buffett: One of the important things in stocks is that the stock does not know that you own it. You have all these feelings about it: You remember what you paid. You remember who told you about it - all these little things. And it doesn’t give a damn. It just sits there. If a stock’s at $50, somebody’s paid $100 and feels terrible; somebody else has paid $10 and feels wonderful - all these feelings. And it has no impact whatsoever...

约翰和玛丽的女儿不想要他们给她的玩具；她想要他们没有给她的玩具。

John and Mary’s daughter didn’t want the toy they gave her; she wanted the toy they didn’t give her.

米歇尔·德·蒙田 (Michel de Montaigne) 说：“禁止我们做某事就是让我们想要它。” 我们想要我们得不到的东西。紫禁果味道最好。马克吐温说，“并不是亚当为了苹果而吃苹果，而是因为它是被禁止的。如果蛇被禁止，对我们来说会更好——哦，对我们来说会更好。” 禁止某人做某事，他们会发现它比被禁止之前更有吸引力。例如，当迈阿密禁止使用磷酸盐洗涤剂时，人们转而走私物资和囤积（因为对稀缺的恐惧鼓励囤积），甚至对被禁产品的评价比以前更好。

Michel de Montaigne said:"To forbid us something is to make us want it." We want what we can’t have. Forbidden fruit tastes best. Mark Twain said,"It was not that Adam ate the apple for the apple’s sake, but because it was forbidden. It would have been better for us — oh infinitely better for us — if the serpent had been forbidden." Forbid someone to do something and they find it more attractive than they did before it was forbidden. For example, when Miami banned the use of phosphate-based detergents, people turned to smuggling in supplies and hoarding (since fear of scarcity encourages hoarding) and even rated the banned products as better than before.

“既然这片地段既难得又难得，我就想要。”

"Since a real estate lot in this area is both rare and hard to obtain, I want it."

我们想要并重视稀缺或独特的东西。我们想要（或威胁）不太可用的东西。它越不可用，我们就越渴望它。这就是我们订阅包含独家和受限信息的时事通讯的原因。以及为什么我们参与首次公开募股并在热门提示上购买股票。

We want and value more what is scarce or unique. We want what is (or threatens to be) less available. The less available it is, the more we desire it. That’s why we subscribe to newsletters containing exclusive and restricted information. And why we participate in initial public offerings and buy stocks on hot tips.

与一直稀缺的东西相比，我们更看重最近不太可用的东西。我们喜欢有限的报价和截止日期，例如，“报价在午夜结束。我们只剩下几个。这是最后的机会。” 通过降低商品的可用性，商家让它们看起来更有价值。

We value higher what has recently been less available than things that have been scarce all along. We fall for limited offers and deadlines like, "The offer ends at midnight. We only have a few left. This is the last chance."By making things less available, merchants make them seem more valuable.

“很多人都在拍卖会上争夺这件拍品。”

"A lot of people are competing for this lot at the auction."

我们如何创造需求？创造竞争。让人们感觉到该项目存在巨大的竞争，并限制可以参与竞标的人数。如果其他人想要稀缺的东西，我们就更想要它。

How do we create demand? Create competition. Make people perceive there is a huge competition for the item and limit the number of people that can participate in the bidding. If others want what’s scarce, we want it even more.

当我们得不到某样东西时，我们就会降低对它的看法。当我们能得到别人不想要的东西时，我们也不想要它。

When we can’t get something, we lower our opinion of it. When we can get something that others don’t want, we don’t want it either.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 了解您的目标和选择。问：我为什么要这个？出于情感还是理性原因？

  • Know your goals and options. Ask: Why do I want this? For emotional or rational reasons?

  • 你为房子、股票或汽车支付的费用与其价值无关。如果价值低于您支付的价值，则您不必报销。如果您以 100 美元购买了一只股票，现在它的价格是 50 美元，如果它的价值不超过 50 美元，您就应该卖掉它。问：假设我没有进行投资，我今天会以今天的价格进行这项投资吗？

  • What you paid for your house, stock, or car has no relevance to its value. If the value is below what you paid, you don’t have to get even. If you bought a stock for $ 100 and it is now $50, you should sell it, if it is not worth more than $50. Ask: Suppose I hadn’t made the investment, would I make this investment today at today’s price?

  • 请记住，人们会对眼前的危机和威胁做出反应。任何逐渐发生的事情，他们往往会推迟。如果我们想让人们冒险，我们应该让他们感到落后（失败）。如果我们希望他们保持现状或拒绝风险，我们应该让他们感到安全。

  • Remember that people respond to immediate crisis and threats. Anything that happens gradually, they tend to put off. If we want people to take a risk, we should make them feel behind (losing). If we want them to stay with the status quo or reject risk, we should make them feel safe.

  • 查尔斯·芒格展示了我们如何使用剥夺的力量来说服（出于正当理由）：

    在库克船长时代，他进行了这些长途航行。当时，坏血病是长途航行的恐惧。在坏血病中，你的活牙龈在你的嘴里腐烂——之后疾病变得令人不快并杀死你。和一群垂死的水手一起在一艘原始的帆船上是一件非常尴尬的事情。所以每个人都对坏血病非常感兴趣，但他们不知道维生素 C。好吧，库克船长是一个聪明的人，他采用多种模型的方法，他注意到在长途航行中，荷兰船只比英国船只更少患坏血病。所以他说，“荷兰人有什么不同之处？”

    他注意到他们有这么多桶酸菜。所以他想：“我要进行这些长途航行。而且非常危险。酸菜可能会有所帮助。” 所以他把所有这些酸菜都放进去，顺便说一下，酸菜恰好含有微量维生素 C。但是当时的英国水手是一群顽固、暴躁和危险的人。他们讨厌“krauts”。他们习惯了标准的食物和酒。那么如何让这样的英国水手吃酸菜呢？

    好吧，库克不想告诉他们他这样做是为了防止坏血病——因为如果他们认为他带他们航行的时间太长以至于很可能患坏血病，他们可能会叛变并接管这艘船.

    所以这就是他所做的：军官们吃了一个男人可以观察他们的地方。很长一段时间，他只给军官们提供酸菜，而不是给士兵们。然后，最后，库克船长说，“好吧，男人们可以一周玩一天。”

    在适当的时候，他让全体船员都吃酸菜。我认为这是对基础心理学非常有建设性的运用。它可能拯救了天知道多少生命，造成了天知道多少成就。

  • Charles Munger shows how we can use the force of deprival to persuade (for a reputable reason):

    In Captain Cooks day, he took these long voyages. At the time, scurvy was the dread of the long voyage. And in scurvy, your living gums putrefy in your mouth - after which the disease gets unpleasant and kills you. And being on a primitive sailing ship with a bunch of dying sailors is a very awkward business. So everybody was terribly interested in scurvy, but they didn’t know about Vitamin C. Well, Captain Cook, being a smart man with a multiple-model kind of approach, noticed that Dutch ships had less scurvy than English ships on long voyages. So he said,"What are the Dutch doing that’s different?"

    And he noticed they had all these barrels of sauerkraut. So he thought:"I’m going on these long voyages. And it’s very dangerous. Sauerkraut may help." So he laid in all this sauerkraut which, incidentally, happens to contain a trace of vitamin C. But English sailors were a tough, cranky and dangerous bunch in that day. They hated "krauts". And they were used to their standard food and booze. So how do you get such English sailors to eat sauerkraut?

    Well, Cook didn’t want to tell 'em that he was doing it in the hope it would prevent scurvy - because they might mutiny and take over the ship if they thought that he was taking them on a voyage so long that scurvy was likely.

    So here’s what he did: Officers ate one place where the men could observe them. And for a long time, he served sauerkraut to the officers, but not to the men. And then, finally, Captain Cook said,"Well, the men can have it one day a week."
