    In due course, he had the whole crew eating sauerkraut. I regard that as a very constructive use of elementary psychology. It may have saved God knows how many lives and caused God knows how much achievement.

8. 现状与无所事事综合症

8. Status Quo and Do-Nothing Syndrome

如果必须首先克服所有可能的反对意见，就永远不会尝试任何事情。

Nothing will ever be attempted if all possible objections must first be overcome.

- 塞缪尔约翰逊

- Samuel Johnson

当约翰和玛丽买了他们的新车时，他们坚持使用他们惯用的品牌。

When John and Mary bought their new car, they stuck to their usual brand.

我们更愿意让事情保持原样。我们抵制变化，更喜欢努力最小化。我们更喜欢常规行为而不是创新行为。

We prefer to keep things the way they are. We resist change and prefer effort minimization. We favour routine behaviour over innovative behaviour.

一个决定越情绪化，或者我们拥有的选择越多，我们就越喜欢现状。这就是为什么我们坚持原来的工作、汽车品牌等。即使在转换成本非常低的情况下也是如此。

The more emotional a decision is or the more choices we have, the more we prefer the status quo. This is why we stick with our old jobs, brand of car, etc. Even in cases where the costs of switching are very low.

“我担心如果我做出错误的选择会带来社会后果，所以我决定什么都不做。”

"I fear the social consequences if I make the wrong choice, so I decide to do nothing."

我们希望对自己做出的选择感觉良好，这样我们就可以为他人和自己证明我们的行为是正确的。与不作为造成的伤害相比，我们更担心行动带来的伤害。当我们因采取行动而失败时，比我们因无所作为而失败时，我们感觉更糟。

We want to feel good about the choices we make so we can justify our actions for others and ourselves. We are more bothered by harm that comes from action than harm that comes from inaction. We feel worse when we fail as a result of taking action than when we fail from doing nothing.

我们更喜欢默认选项，即自动选择的替代选项，除非我们更改它。在一项关于汽车保险费率的真实实验中，新泽西州和宾夕法尼亚州的汽车司机可以选择以有限的权利起诉痛苦和痛苦，以换取较低的保险费率。但是每个州的默认选项都不同。新泽西州的车主自动获得有限的权利，除非他们主动做出决定并表示不同意见。在宾夕法尼亚州，默认选项是起诉的全部权利。发生了什么？两个州的公民都更喜欢默认选项。79% 的新泽西州司机更喜欢有限的起诉权，而 70% 的宾夕法尼亚州司机更喜欢完全的起诉权。两个州的保险支出差异约为 2 亿美元。

We prefer the default option, i.e., the alternative that is selected automatically unless we change it. In a real-life experiment on auto insurance rates, car drivers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania were given the choice of a limited right to sue for pain and suffering in exchange for lower insurance rates. But the default option was different for each state. Car owners in New Jersey were automatically given the limited right unless they made an active decision and said differently. In Pennsylvania, the default option was the full right to sue. What happened? Citizens of both states preferred the default option. 79% of New Jersey drivers preferred the limited right to sue, whereas 70% of Pennsylvania drivers preferred the full right to sue. The difference in amount spent on insurance in the two states was about $200 million. The preference for defaults has also been found in decisions about organ donation, health care plans, and pension savings.

有时我们明知应该行动却不采取行动。我们忽略了沃伦巴菲特的诺亚原则：“预测下雨不算数；建造方舟才算数。”

Sometimes we don’t act when we know we should. We ignore Warren Buffett’s Noah principle:"Predicting rain doesn’t count; building arks does."

“为什么今天要在某件事上投入资源，因为我们不会因为阻止我们甚至不知道会发生的事情而得到任何荣誉。”

"Why invest resources in something today since we don’t get any credit for preventing something we don’t even know will happen."

我们常常忽视遥远的问题，也不愿意预防未来的威胁。沃伦巴菲特说：“诺亚花了 20 年时间建造了一艘方舟。人们说他很傻，因为天空很美。当然，在整个过程中，他看起来很傻——直到开始下雨。你可以花很长时间是时候造一艘方舟，而其他人都在外面享受阳光了。”

We often ignore distant problems and we are reluctant to prevent future threats. Warren Buffett says:"It took Noah 20 years to build an ark. And people said he was being silly because the skies were beautiful. And of course, the whole time, he looked stupid - until it started raining. You can spend a long time building an ark while everybody else is out there enjoying the sun."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 决定什么都不做也是一种决定。什么都不做的代价可能大于采取行动的代价。

  • Deciding to do nothing is also a decision. And the cost of doing nothing could be greater than the cost of taking an action.

  • 记住你想要达到的目标。

  • Remember what you want to achieve.

  • 一旦我们知道该做什么，我们就应该去做。19 世纪的英国生物学家托马斯·亨利·赫胥黎说：“也许所有教育最有价值的成果就是让自己在应该做的事情上去做你必须做的事情，不管你喜不喜欢。这是第一课这是应该学习的，无论一个人的训练开始得有多早，它都可能是一个人彻底学习的最后一课。”

  • Once we know what to do, we should do it. The 19th Century British biologist Thomas Henry Huxley said:"Perhaps the most valuable result of all education is the ability to make yourself do the thing you have to do when it ought to be done whether you like it or not. It is the first lesson that ought to be learned and however early a person’s training begins, it is probably the last lesson a person learns thoroughly."

9.急躁

9. Impatience

TransCorp 的首席执行官今天想要他的奖金，因此他决定以未来可能更大的利润为代价来增加今年的利润。

The CEO of TransCorp wants his bonus today and therefore he makes a decision that increases this year’s profit at the cost of a possibly larger profit in the future.

我们更重视现在而不是未来。我们以未来可能更好的代价为代价来寻求今天的快乐。我们更喜欢立即奖励而不是延迟但可能更大的奖励。我们今天花费了我们应该为明天节省的钱。这意味着我们可能会在未来付出高昂的代价来换取眼前的小额回报。例如，我们买信用卡买不起的东西。

We give more weight to the present than to the future. We seek pleasure today at a cost of what may be better in the future. We prefer an immediate reward to a delayed but maybe larger reward. We spend today what we should save for tomorrow. This means that we may pay a high price in the future for a small immediate reward. For example, we buy things we can’t afford on credit cards.

我们对短期不耐烦，对遥远的未来有耐心。研究表明，当奖励更直接时，我们往往会变得不那么耐心。我们的贴现率（我们赋予某物的价值）在短期内高于长期。例如，当明天到期的小奖励和一年后到期的较大奖励时，人们通常更喜欢即时的小奖励。但是，当小奖励在一年后到期而较大的奖励在两年后到期时，人们往往更喜欢较大的长期奖励。研究表明，对此的一种解释是人们认为未来发生的结果不太确定。

We are impatient in the short run and patient in the far away future. Studies show that we tend to become less patient when rewards are more immediate. Our discount rates (the values we assign to something) are higher in the short run than in the long run. For example, when a small reward is due tomorrow and a larger reward is due in one year, people often prefer the small immediate reward. But when the small reward is due in one year and the larger reward in two years, people tend to prefer the larger long-term reward. Studies show that one explanation for this is that outcomes occurring in the future are perceived as less certain.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 米歇尔·德·蒙田 (Michel de Montaigne) 说：“我认为，如果带来更大的痛苦，就应该避免快乐，而贪图痛苦会以更大的快乐告终。” 考虑决策的短期和长期后果。权衡现在的好/坏与未来的​​好/坏。短期的痛苦可能会带来长期的快乐。

  • Michel de Montaigne said:"I conceive that pleasures are to be avoided if greater pains be the consequence, and pains to be coveted that will terminate in greater pleasures." Consider both the short and long-term consequences of a decision. Weigh present good/bad against future good/bad. Short-term suffering may lead to long term pleasure.

10. 羡慕和嫉妒

10. Envy and Jealousy

人会做很多事来获得爱；

他会尽一切努力让自己受到嫉妒。

Man will do many things to get himself loved;

he will do all things to get himself envied.

- 马克吐温

- Mark Twain

亚里士多德说：“嫉妒是对他人好运的痛苦。” 我们通过比较我们所拥有的与他人所拥有的来评估我们自己的处境。亚里士多德继续说道：“我们羡慕那些在时间、地点、年龄或声誉上与我们接近的人。” 我们最羡慕的是与我们相似的人。金融历史学家查尔斯·P·金德伯格 (Charles P. Kindleberger) 在《 疯狂、恐慌和崩溃》(Manias, Panics, and Crashes)中说：“没有什么比看到朋友发财更能扰乱一个人的福祉和判断力了。” 例如，研究表明，我们的幸福程度在一定程度上取决于我们与相似的人相比所处的位置。19世纪的德国哲学家亚瑟·叔本华说：“正如霍布斯所观察到的，所有精神上的愉悦都在于能够将自己与他人进行比较，以取得自己的优势。”

Aristotle said:"Envy is pain at the good fortune of others." We evaluate our own situation by comparing what we have with what others have. Aristotle continues: "We envy those who are near us in time, place, age or reputation." It is people similar to us we envy most. Financial historian Charles P. Kindleberger says in Manias, Panics, and Crashes:"There is nothing so disturbing to one’s well-being and judgement as to see a friend get rich." For example, studies show that how happy we are is partly determined by where we stand in relation to similar others. The 19th Century German philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer said:"As Hobbes observes, all mental pleasure consists in being able to compare oneself with others to one’s own advantage."

当我们察觉到对宝贵关系的威胁时，我们会嫉妒。研究表明，嫉妒是杀人的三大动机之一。

We are jealous when we perceive a threat to a valued relationship. Studies show that jealousy is ranked among the top three motives for murder.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 伯特兰·罗素说，嫉妒是人类苦难的根本原因之一。18世纪法国哲学家、数学家孔多塞侯爵说：“享受自己的生活，不要与他人比较。” 只要你实现了自己的目标，其他人是否做得更好应该无关紧要。

  • Bertrand Russell said that envy is one of the fundamental causes of human suffering. The 18th Century French philosopher and mathematician Marquis de Condorcet said:"Enjoy your own life without comparing it with that of another." As long as you achieve your goals, it shouldn’t matter if someone else does better.

  • 研究表明，我们是否相信他人应得的成功很重要。亚里士多德说：“避免嫉妒的最好方法是你应得的成功。”

  • Studies show that it matters whether we believe that others deserve their success. Aristotle said:"The best way to avoid envy is to deserve the success you get."

  • 另一方面，18世纪的荷兰医生伯纳德曼德维尔说，贪婪、嫉妒和虚荣等罪恶都会通过鼓励进取心来实现公共利益。

  • On the other hand, the 18th Century Dutch physician Bernard de Mandeville said that vices such as greed, envy, and vanity all lead to public benefits by encouraging enterprise.

11.对比对比

11. Contrast Comparison

一桶装冷水，另一桶装热水，第三桶装室温水。将一只手放在冷水桶中，另一只手放在热水桶中。然后将双手放入盛有室温水的桶中。会发生什么？你会觉得你冰冷的手感觉更暖和，而你温暖的手感觉更冷。

Fill one bucket with cold water, another with hot water, and a third with water at room temperature. Put one hand in the bucket of cold water and the other hand in the bucket of hot water. Then put both your hands in the bucket of room temperature water. What happens? You will feel that your cold hand feels warmer and that your warm hand feels colder.

我们通过差异和变化而不是绝对幅度来判断刺激。例如，我们根据与参考点（先前或同时发生的刺激或我们已经习惯的）的对比或差异来评估温度、响度、亮度、健康状况、状态或价格等刺激。这个参考点随着新的经验和背景而改变。

We judge stimuli by differences and changes and not absolute magnitudes. For example, we evaluate stimuli like temperature, loudness, brightness, health, status, or prices based on their contrast or difference from a reference point (the prior or concurrent stimuli or what we have become used to). This reference point changes with new experiences and context.

这意味着我们如何评价事物取决于我们将它们与什么进行比较。

This means that how we value things depend on what we compare them with.

在约翰购买了价格公道的 1,500 美元西装之后，这条定价过高的 100 美元领带似乎很合理。

The grossly overpriced $100 tie seemed reasonable after John bought the fairly priced $1,500 suit.

事物呈现的顺序很重要。销售人员通常会尝试首先销售价格较高的商品。我们要出去买一台电脑和一些软盘。与 1,500 美元的电脑相比，10 美元的软盘似乎很划算。在我们购买大件商品后，相比较而言，附加组件显得便宜。

The order in which something is presented matters. Sales people often try to sell the more costly item first. We are out buying a computer and some diskettes. In comparison to $1,500 computer, diskettes at $10 seem like a bargain. After we buy the big ticket items, the add-ons seem cheap in comparison.

实验表明，我们穿越城镇是为了在时钟收音机上节省 10 美元，而不是为了在大屏幕电视上节省 10 美元。100 美元和 110 美元之间的差价似乎比 2850 美元和 2860 美元之间的差价节省更多。但同样节省 10 美元。

Experiments have shown that we go across town to save $10 on a clock radio but not to save $ 10 on a large-screen TV. The difference between $ 100 and $ 110 seems like a larger saving than the difference between $2850 and $2860. But it’s the same $10 saving.

约翰的朋友马克说：“我习惯于获得的社会福利是我衡量公平的标准。”

"What I am used to getting in social benefits is the norm against how I measure fairness,"says John’s friend Mark.

一家旅馆以每晚100美元的价格出租房间。飓风过后的第二天，酒店将价格提高到 150 美元。研究表明，我们认为这是不公平的。我们根据我们已经习惯的情况来确定什么是公平的或不公平的。这意味着具有习惯形成后果的政策如果被视为损失则可能难以逆转。

A hotel has been renting rooms for $ 100 a night. The day after a hurricane, the hotel raises its prices to $150. Studies show that we consider this unfair. We determine what is fair or not in reference to what we have been used to. This means that policies that have habit-forming consequences may be hard to reverse if they are seen as a loss.

TransCorp 的一家子公司开发了该机器的高价版本。即使它卖得不好，也有助于吸引顾客购买更便宜（但仍然昂贵）的版本。

One of TransCorp’s subsidiaries developed a high-priced version of the machine. Even if it doesn’t sell well, it will help induce customers to buy their cheaper (but still expensive) version.

同一个事物与不那么有吸引力的事物相比可能显得有吸引力，而与更有吸引力的事物相比可能显得没有吸引力。例如，研究表明，与极具吸引力的其他人相比，一个具有一般吸引力的人被认为没有吸引力。查尔斯·芒格举了另一个例子：“在我这一代，当女性在结婚前都住在家里，我看到一些非常令人向往的女性缔结了非常糟糕的婚姻，因为她们住在糟糕的家里。我还看到了一些糟糕的第二次婚姻，这些婚姻是因为他们比更糟糕的第一次婚姻略有改善。”

The same thing may appear attractive when compared to less attractive things and unattractive when compared to more attractive things. For example, studies show that a person of average attractiveness is seen as less attractive when compared to highly attractive others. Charles Munger gives another example:"In my generation, when women lived at home until they got married, I saw some perfectly terrible marriages made by highly desirable women because they lived in terrible homes. And I’ve seen some terrible second marriages which were made because they were slight improvements over an even worse first marriage."

在一个实验中，一组人被要求在 6 美元和一支优雅的钢笔之间做出选择。大多数选择现金。另一组人被要求在 6 美元、优雅的钢笔或劣质钢笔之间做出选择。大多数选择优雅的笔。通过添加一个较差的选项，另一个选项似乎更有吸引力。

In one experiment, a group of people was asked to choose between $6 and an elegant pen. Most choose the cash. Another group of people was asked to choose between $6, the elegant pen, or an inferior pen. Most choose the elegant pen. By adding an inferior option, another option seemed more attractive.

玛丽正在看房子。房地产经纪人知道他要卖给玛丽的房子状况不佳，地段也很差。他首先向玛丽展示了一个丑陋街区的不良房产。随后，他带她去了他一直想卖掉的房子。突然间，与她看到的其他房屋相比，这所房子和这个区域似乎很棒。

Mary is looking at houses. The real estate broker knows that the house he is trying to sell Mary is in poor shape and a bad area. He starts by showing Mary bad properties in an ugly neighbourhood. Afterwards, he takes her to the house he wanted to sell all along. Suddenly this house and the area seem great in comparison to the other houses she saw.

对比比较的另一个例子是当我们面试一个又一个求职者时。

Another example of contrast comparison is when we interview one job candidate after another.

“如果我们随着时间的推移慢慢地、逐渐地操纵这些数字，审计员就不会注意到它。”

"If we slowly and gradually over time manipulate the numbers, the auditors won’t notice it."

对比可能会使我们盲目改变，直到为时已晚。例如，如果随着时间的推移逐渐变坏，我们通常不会注意到他人的不良行为。

Contrasts may blind us to change until it’s too late. For example, we often don’t notice the bad behaviour of others if it goes sour gradually over time.

我们常常认为现实是不变的，尽管它会逐渐变化。刺激必须达到一个绝对阈值，我们才能检测到它。在我们注意到刺激发生变化之前，通常会发生某种相对变化。如果变化足够慢，我们不会注意到变化。我们检测刺激变化并对其做出反应的能力会随着刺激幅度的增加而降低。对于小刺激，只需添加少量即可。要有更大的刺激，必须加入大量。

Often we see reality as constant, although it gradually changes. A stimulus must reach an absolute threshold before we can detect it. Before we notice a change in a stimulus, a certain relative change most occur. If the change is slow enough, we don’t notice the change. Our ability to detect and react to changes in a stimulus decreases as its magnitude increases. To a small stimulus, only a small amount must be added. To a larger stimulus, a large amount must be added.

有时，对我们伤害最大的是微小的、渐进的、无形的变化。沃伦·巴菲特说：“社会的一个问题是，最重要的问题往往是这些渐进式的事情。” 他继续：

Sometimes it is the small, gradual, invisible changes that harm us the most. Warren Buffett says:"One of the problems in society is that the most important issues are often these incremental type things." He continues:

世界不会走到尽头，因为明天地球上的人口将比今天多 200 或 25 万人。这大约是它每天增长的数字……就像每天摄入的热量比消耗的热量多 300 卡路里；今天对你没有影响。你还没有从桌子上站起来，突然间每个人都说，“我的上帝，与你坐下时相比，你看起来很胖！” 但是，如果你随着时间的推移继续这样做，增量问题就很难解决，因为多吃一块馅饼似乎并没有什么不同。明天的 25 万人似乎没有什么不同，但他们的累积效应会随着时间的推移产生巨大的变化，就像暴饮暴食会随着时间的推移产生巨大的变化一样。解决这些问题的时机还早。

The world is not going to come to an end because tomorrow there are 200 or 250 thousand more people on the planet than there were today. That’s about the number it grows every day... it is like eating about 300 calories more each day than you burn up; it has no effect on you today. You don’t get up from the table and all of a sudden everybody says,"My God, you look fat compared to when you sat down!" But, if you keep doing it over time, the incremental problems are hard to attack because that one extra piece of pie doesn’t really seem to make a difference. The 250,000 people tomorrow don’t seem to make any difference, but the cumulative effects of them will make a huge difference over time, just like overeating will make a huge difference over time. The time to attack those problems is early.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 通过自身而不是对比来评价人和物。

  • Evaluate people and objects by themselves and not by their contrast.

12.锚定

12. Anchoring

首席执行官告诉约翰他告诉 TransCorp 董事会成员的话：“我们的成本超出预算一百万，但我告诉他们我们超过了三百万。当我后来告诉他们只有一百万时，他们很激动。我总是设定低目标超出预期。”

The CEO informs John what he told the board members of TransCorp:"Our costs were one million over budget but I told them we were three million over. They were thrilled when I later told them it was only one million. I always set low targets to exceed expectations."

我们过度受到某些信息的影响，这些信息充当未来判断的参考“锚”。

We are over-influenced by certain information acting as a reference"anchor" for future judgements.

“我做了一笔糟糕的投资，花 50 美元买了现在价值 40 美元的东西，”约翰说。

"I made a bad investment, paying $50 for something now worth $40,"says John.

我们不是根据它的价值而是根据它的相对价格来给一个东西定价。例如，如果我们以 50 美元的价格购买了一只股票，现价为 40 美元，我们将参考我们的购买价格来判断我们的决定有多好。或者，如果我们考虑购买的股票在一段时间内交易价格在 50 美元左右，然后跌至 35 美元，我们往往会锚定在 50 美元上，并自动假设 35 美元是便宜货。股票的当前价格相对于过去的一些报价没有任何意义。潜在的商业价值才是最重要的。

We don’t price a thing according to its value but its relative price. If we for example bought a stock for $50 with a present price of $40, we judge how good our decision was in reference to our purchase price. Or if a stock we consider buying trades around $50 for some time and drops to $35, we tend to get anchored on the $50 and automatically assume that $35 is a bargain. The present price of a stock in relation to some past quote doesn’t mean anything. The underlying business value is what matters.

TransCorp 的一名员工因回溯选择权而受审。“我要求 5 年徒刑，”检察官说。“我建议 4.5 年，”辩方反驳道。

One of TransCorp’s employees was on trial for backdating options."I demand a sentence of 5 years," said the prosecutor."I suggest 4.5 years," countered the defense.

 提供的初始数据也会影响法律决定。例如，诉讼和解的价值或法官在民事案件中判给的损害赔偿金。在法庭上拥有最终决定权有时是不利的。研究表明，辩方的量刑建议受检察官要求的强烈影响，进而推动司法量刑。

 The initial figures being presented can also influence legal decisions. For example, the value at which a lawsuit settles or the damages a judge awards in a civil case. Having the last word in court is sometimes disadvantageous. Studies show that the defense’s sentencing recommendation is strongly influenced by the prosecutor’s demand, which in turn drives judicial sentencing.

研究还表明，即使是随机确定的数字也可能影响经验丰富的法律专业人士。

Studies also show that even randomly determined numbers may influence experienced legal professionals.

约翰的朋友说：“作为一名二手车销售员，我将潜在买家定在一个高价上，然后慢慢降价。这样 1 得到一个好的最终价格，客户就会认为他得到了一笔划算的交易。”

John’s friend said:"As a used car salesman, I anchor a potential buyer to a high price and then slowly reduce it. This way 1 get a good final price and the customer perceives he got a good deal."

约翰和玛丽的一个朋友正在出售他的冰淇淋连锁店。买方商定了 1000 万美元的价格。但是卖家研究了类似商家的价格。他向买家概述了他的研究，并告诉他 1500 万美元的目标价。然后卖方开始就他的方法而不是价格进行谈判。1500 万美元与买方达成一致，作为进一步讨论的基础。卖家最终以 1300 万美元的价格卖掉了他的店铺。

A friend of John and Mary was selling his chain of ice cream stores. The buyer had discussed a price of $10 million. But the seller researched prices of similar businesses. He outlined his research for the buyer and told him his target price of $ 15 million. Then the seller started to negotiate on his methodology, not on the price. The $ 15 million got anchored with the buyer as the basis for further discussion. The seller finally sold his stores for $ 13 million.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 从零基础开始考虑选择并记住您想要实现的目标。

  • Consider choices from a zero base level and remember what you want to achieve.

  • 根据现实调整信息。

  • Adjust information to reality.

13. 生动度和新近度

13. Vividness and Recency

我们对体验的关注程度与其生动或有趣的特征成正比；众所周知，当时我们最感兴趣的是，在其他条件相同的情况下，我们记忆最深刻的东西。

The attention which we lend to an experience is proportional to its vivid or interesting character; and it is a notorious fact that what interests us most vividly at the time is, other things equal, what we remember best.

——威廉·詹姆斯

（美国心理学家和哲学家，1842-1910）

- William James

(American psychologist and philosopher, 1842-1910)

约翰根据精美的季度收益报告和有趣的演示文稿投资了一家公司。

John invests in a company based on a beautifully written quarterly earnings report and an entertaining presentation.

某些信息、事件或经历越戏剧化、突出、个人化、娱乐性或情绪化，我们受到的影响就越大。例如，越容易想象一个事件，我们就越有可能认为它会发生。

The more dramatic, salient, personal, entertaining, or emotional some information, event or experience is, the more influenced we are. For example, the easier it is to imagine an event, the more likely we are to think that it will happen.

当我们被告知故事时，我们很容易受到影响，因为我们与故事的联系比与逻辑或事实的联系更好。我们喜欢被娱乐。我们通过眼睛或耳朵直接接收到的信息比可能具有更多证据价值的信息更具影响力。来自朋友或家人的生动描述比真实证据更可信。统计数据经常被忽视。研究表明，陪审员会受到生动描述的影响。律师们试图提供戏剧性和令人难忘的证词。

We are easily influenced when we are told stories because we relate to stories better than to logic or fact. We love to be entertained. Information we receive directly, through our eyes or ears has more impact than information that may have more evidential value. A vivid description from a friend or family member is more believable than true evidence. Statistical data is often overlooked. Studies show that jurors are influenced by vivid descriptions. Lawyers try to present dramatic and memorable testimony.

“看到一个受苦的 9 岁女孩的脸，感觉很糟糕。”

"Seeing the face of a 9-year old girl who is suffering feels awful."

约瑟夫·斯大林说：“一个人的死亡是一场悲剧；一百万人的死亡是一个统计数字。” 使我们情绪激动的信息使我们更加关注事件本身，而不是其重要性。统计数据很少能激发我们的情绪。一个人的面孔和名字会。

Joseph Stalin said:"A single death is a tragedy; a million deaths is a statistic." Information that moves us emotionally makes us pay greater attention to the event itself than to its magnitude. Statistics rarely spark our emotions. An individual face and name will.

中国有句谚语：“杀一吓万”。我们常常高估不太可能发生的事件，仅仅因为它们在新闻中受到关注。戏剧和危险卖。媒体利用恐惧是因为其中有钱。重大事故，如飞机失事或鲨鱼袭击，无论发生的可能性如何，都会引起人们的注意并成为头条新闻。这使我们相信问题比实际情况要大。有时我们认为事件发生的频率增加了，因为我们看到它的次数更多了。但媒体可能只会报道更多。

A Chinese proverb says:"Kill one, frighten ten thousand." We often overestimate events that are unlikely to happen merely because they receive attention in the news. Drama and danger sells. The media capitalizes on fear because there is money in it. Major accidents, such as air-plane crashes or shark attacks, grab people s attention and make headlines regardless of their probability. This causes us to believe a problem is larger than it really is. Sometimes we believe an event has increased in frequency because we see it more. But the media may only cover it more.

自从媒体报道经济不佳消息后，约翰卖掉了他持有的所有股票。

John sold every stock he owned since the media reported bad economic news.

我们过分重视我们最近看到、听到、阅读或经历的信息。例如，在判断绩效时，我们会高估最近发生的事情，而低估或忽略长期证据或平均发生的事情（假设这些是现实的代表）。

We give too much weight to information we’ve seen, heard, read or experienced most recently. For example, when judging performance, we over-weigh what happened most recently and under-weigh or ignore the long term evidence or what on average happens (assuming those are representative of reality).

我们通过推断最近的趋势和条件来做出预测。股市跌入流鼻血区域，我们假设世界正在崩溃。坏事发生后，我们往往会高估它再次发生的可能性。例如，研究表明，地震发生后，购买地震保险的人数急剧增加。

We make predictions by extrapolating recent trends and conditions. The stock market falls into nose bleed territory and we assume the world is going under. After a bad event happens, we tend to overestimate the likelihood of it happening again. For example, studies show that after an earthquake, the number of people carrying earthquake insurance rises sharply.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 媒体有其弱点、偏见和易受操纵和欺骗的弱点。考虑在类似情况下什么是相关的和正常的结果。

  • The media has its weaknesses, biases and vulnerability to manipulation and deception. Consider what is relevant and the normal outcome in similar situations.

  • 准确的信息胜过戏剧性的信息。用事实和数字支持生动的故事。

  • Accurate information is better than dramatic information. Back up vivid stories with facts and numbers.

  • 将噪音和偶然事件与重要事件分开。问：有关系吗？是否有意义？是有代表性的证据吗？这是随机事件吗？

  • Separate noise and chance events from what is important. Ask: Is it relevant? Does it make sense? Is it representative evidence? Was it a random event?

  • 趋势可能是错误的。问：这是永久的还是暂时的影响？

  • Trends may be wrong. Ask: Is it a permanent or temporary effect?

14.遗漏和抽象盲目

14. Omission and Abstract Blindness

我们对个人遇到的刺激或引起我们注意的刺激做出反应。我们对具体和具体的反应比对抽象的反应更强烈。我们过度权衡个人经历而不是替代。我们只看到我们有名字的东西。我们倾向于只关注当前信息，而不关注可能丢失的信息。例如，在计划时，我们往往过分重视未来的具体事件，而对其他可能发生的事件及其可能导致事件延迟或不发生的后果不够重视。

We react to stimuli that we personally encounter or that grabs our attention. We react more strongly to the concrete and specific than to the abstract. We over-weigh personal experiences over vicarious. We see only what we have names for. We tend to focus only on the present information rather than what information may potentially be missing. For example, when planning, we often place too much importance on the specific future event and not enough on other possible events and their consequences that can cause the event to be delayed or not happen.

今天有 1400 万人没有中彩票。

Today 14 million people didn’t win the lottery.

我们将可能发生的事情建立在我们所看到的基础上。不是在我们看不到的地方。我们不知道会发生什么。我们看到获胜者是因为他们发声或可见并得到媒体报道。我们看不到安静的失败者。我们看到了成功的预测者。我们看不到那些预测不好的人。我们看到了成为头条新闻的那种风险。我们没有看到统计风险。我们看到了政府支出的好处。我们看不到资源替代使用的成本和收益。我们看不到纳税人的钱用于消费、储蓄或投资的其他用途。

We base what is likely to happen on what we see. Not on what we don’t see. We don’t see what could have happened. We see the winners because they are vocal or visible and get media coverage. We don’t see the quiet losers. We see the successful forecasters. We don’t see those who didn’t predict well. We see the kind of risk that makes headlines. We don’t see the statistical risk. We see the benefits of government expenditure. We don’t see the costs and benefits of resources alternative use. We don’t see the alternative uses of taxpayers money for consumption, saving or investing.

我们看到可用的信息。我们看不到未报告的内容。缺失的信息不会引起我们的注意。我们倾向于不考虑其他可能性、替代方案、解释、结果或属性。当我们试图找出一件事是否导致另一件事时，我们只会看到发生了什么，而看不到没有发生什么。我们看到程序何时起作用，而不是何时不起作用。当我们使用清单来找出某些事情不起作用的可能原因时，我们通常看不到首先不在清单上的可能是问题的原因。

We see the available information. We don’t see what isn’t reported. Missing information doesn’t draw our attention. We tend not to think about other possibilities, alternatives, explanations, outcomes or attributes. When we try to find out if one thing causes another, we only see what happened, not what didn’t happen. We see when a procedure works, not when it doesn’t work. When we use check-lists to find out possible reasons for why something doesn’t work, we often don’t see that what is not on the list in the first place may be the reason for the problem.

约翰问他的儿子亚当他想上哪所大学。玛丽反而问亚当他不喜欢哪所大学。Adam 既选择了又拒绝了大学 B。

John asks his son Adam which university he would like to attend. Mary instead asks Adam which university he doesn’t like. Adam both selects and rejects university B.

 为什么亚当既喜欢又不喜欢 B 大学？因为当我们选择时，我们比较的是正面属性，而当我们拒绝时，我们比较的是负面属性。由于 B 大学比其他学校有更多的优点和缺点，所以 Adam 选择了 B。

 Why would Adam both like and not like university B? Because when we choose, we compare positive attributes but when we reject, we compare negative attributes. Since university B had more positive and negative qualities than the other schools, Adam picked B.

研究表明，在决定哪一方父母应该单独抚养孩子时，陪审团会关注让一方父母看起来比另一方更好的信息。但是，在决定应该拒绝哪一位父母的监护权时，陪审团会关注那些让父母一方看起来不如另一方的信息。这意味着，如果一位父母的经济、社会和情感特征一般，而另一位父母的积极和消极特征更为显着，我们将同时选择和拒绝同一位父母。这意味着我们经常选择和拒绝比一般选项更引人注目或更复杂的选项。

Studies show that when deciding which parent should receive sole custody of a child, juries focus on information that makes one parent seem better than the other. But when deciding which parent should be denied custody, juries focus on information that makes one parent seem inferior to the other. This means that if one parent has average economic, social and emotional features and the other parent more striking positive and negative features, we will both choose and reject the same parent. This means that we often both choose and reject options that are of a more striking or complex nature over average ones.

约翰的母亲正专心致志地用手机通话，所以她没有看到另一辆车开过来。

Johns mother was concentrating on talking on her cellphone so she didn’t see the other car coming.

当我们专注于其他事物时，我们看不到很多经过我们眼睛的东西。我们只看到我们关注的东西。有时我们看不到眼前的事物。一项研究表明，一些经验丰富的飞行员试图在飞行模拟器中让飞机着陆，他们非常专注于飞行信息显示屏，他们没有看到第二架飞机挡住了他们的跑道。直到为时已晚，无法避免碰撞。

We don’t see much of what passes our eyes when we are focused on something else. We only see what we focus our attention on. Sometimes we don’t see what is right in front of us. One study showed that a few experienced pilots trying to land a plane in a flight simulator were so concentrated on the flight information display, they didn’t see that a second plane was blocking their runway. Until it was too late to avoid a collision.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 寻找其他解释。

  • Look for alternative explanations.

  • 考虑缺失信息。知道你想要达到什么。

  • Consider missing information. Know what you want to achieve.

  • 比较正面和负面的特征。

  • Compare both positive and negative characteristics.

15.往复运动

15. Reciprocation

没有比回报

善意更不可或缺的责任了。所有人都不相信一个忘记好处的人。

There is no duty more indispensable than that of returning

a kindness. All men distrust one forgetful of a benefit.

- Marcus Tullius Cicero

（罗马政治家和作家，公元前 106-43 年）

- Marcus Tullius Cicero

(Roman statesman and writer, 106-43 BC)

作为对 CEO 忠诚的回报，John 获得了晋升。

In return for his loyalty to the CEO, John received a promotion.

我们倾向于以实物回报他人为我们所做的一切——无论好坏。

We tend to repay in kind what others have done for us - good or bad.

你会退还圣诞贺卡吗？在一项研究中，研究人员向陌生人发送卡片。许多人寄回了卡片，尽管他们从未听说过这个人。每当有人为我们做某事时，我们都想做一些回报。难怪公司使用免费试用并发送免费样品。带有我们名字的礼物很难不回馈。

Do you return Christmas cards? In one study a researcher sent out cards to strangers. Dozens of people sent back cards, even though they’d never heard of the person. Whenever someone does something for us we want to do something back. No wonder companies use free trials and send out free samples. A gift with our name on it is hard not to reciprocate.

“我称赞他干得好，我收到了一名积极进取的员工。”

“我告诉他他的错误，他对我产生了敌意。”

"I praised him for a job well done, and I received a motivated employee."

"I told him about his mistake, and he became hostile towards me."

我们的反应与对待我们的方式相同。如果我们对别人不公平，人们也会不公平地回报。如果人们信任我们，我们就会倾向于信任他们。如果人们批评我们，我们也会批评他们。如果我们不喜欢的人帮了我们一个忙或不请自来的忙，我们无论如何都会回报。

We respond the same way as we are treated. If we are unfair to others, people are unfair back. If people trust us, we tend to trust them. If people criticize us, we criticize them back. If people we don’t like do us a favour or an uninvited favour, we reciprocate anyway.

沃伦巴菲特告诉我们伯克希尔如何对待管理层：

Warren Buffett tells us how Berkshire treats management:

我们四分之三的经理都非常富有。他们根本不需要起床去工作。他们中的大多数人都有数千万美元。所以我必须创造或者我必须维护一个环境，让他们在世界上最想做的事情就是当天和第二天去上班。而且，我对自己说，“什么会让我有那种感觉？” 一种方法是感觉你在进行自己的表演。如果有人整天对我进行后顾之忧，我会厌倦的。我会说，“我到底要这个干什么？” 而且，如果我四处批评他们或告诉他们如何经营业务，我们的经理就会有这种感觉。

Three quarters of our managers are independently wealthy. They don’t need to get up and go to work at all. Most of them have tens and tens of million of dollars. So I’ve got to create or I’ve got to maintain an environment where the thing they want to do most in the world is to go to work that day and the next day. And, I say to myself,"What would make me feel that way?" One way is to feel you are running your own show. If I had people second-guessing me all day, I would get sick of it. I would say,"What the hell do I need this for?" And, that’s exactly the way our managers would feel if I went around second-guessing them or telling them how to run their business.

休斯敦的一名妇女在酒店停车场抓住了她的丈夫和他的情妇，然后用她的车撞倒了丈夫。

A woman in Houston caught her husband and his mistress in a hotel parking lot, and proceeded to run the husband down with her car.

我们会回报不公平的行为，即使这会让我们付出代价。一些例子是：丑陋的离婚让人们付出大笔金钱、贸易报复、与工会谈判有关的代价高昂的罢工、受虐待的员工的破坏或在法律滋扰案件中未能达成一致。

We reciprocate unfair behaviour even if it costs us. Some examples are: ugly divorces that cost people large sums, trade retaliations, costly strikes in connection with union negotiations, sabotage by a mistreated employee or failure to agree in legal nuisance cases.

约翰正在谈判收购一家小企业。卖家要价高于约翰准备支付的价格，因此他拒绝了。然后卖方做出让步并降低价格。

John is negotiating to buy a small business. The seller asks a higher price than John is prepared to pay, so he declines. The seller then makes a concession and reduces the price.

 我们对先对我们让步的人让步。由于约翰将较低的价格视为一种让步，他觉得需要回报并接受较低的价格。这个价格本来就是卖家想要的。还涉及对比比较——卖家的第二个要求似乎更小，因此更好。这种夸大要求、接受小要求的方法在谈判中经常使用。这也增加了约翰履行交易的可能性，因为他觉得自己对“口述”最终条款负有责任。

 We make a concession to people who have first made a concession to us. Since John views the lower price as a concession, he feels a need to reciprocate and accepts the lower price. This price was what the seller wanted in the first place. Contrast comparison is also involved - the seller’s second request seems smaller and therefore much better. This method of making an exaggerated request and settling for a smaller one is often used in negotiations. It also increases the chance that John will live up to the deal since he feels responsible for having"dictated" the final terms.

“that's-not-all”技术与相互让步有关，经常用于电视广告中。例如，一家公司以 49.00 美元的价格展示一款产品，在客户做出回应之前，他们“免费”添加了一款额外的产品。

The"that’s-not-all" technique is related to reciprocal concessions and often used in infomercials. For example, a company presents a product at $49.00, and before the customer can respond, they add an additional product"for free."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 人们不想感到亏欠。如果我们不允许人们回馈我们给予他们的东西，我们就会不受欢迎。

  • People don’t want to feel indebted. We are disliked if we don’t allow people to give back what we’ve given them.

  • 当个人恩惠或礼物是个人的、重要的和出乎意料的时，它是最有效的。

  • A favour or gift is most effective when it is personal, significant, and unexpected.

  • 在你做出让步之前，想想你想要达到的目标。

  • Before you make concessions, think about what you want to achieve.

  • 美国汽车制造商亨利·福特说：“如果说有任何成功的秘诀，那就是能够从对方的角度和自己的角度看问题。”

  • The American car manufacturer Henry Ford said:"If there is any one secret of success, it lies in the ability to get the other person’s point of view and see things from his angle as well as from your own."

  • 学孔子：“己所不欲，勿施于人。以义报仇，以善报善。” 给人们你想要的回报。问：假设其他人和我一样，如果角色互换，我希望别人如何对待我？

  • Follow Confucius:"What you don’t want yourself, don’t do to others. Reward hostility with justice, and good deeds with good deeds." Give people what you want in return from them. Ask: Assuming others are like me, how would I like to be treated if the roles were reversed?

  • 树立正确榜样。用孔子的话来说：“榜样胜于法律。因为法律规定的地方，人们可以无耻地逃避惩罚。但是，榜样规定的地方，人们会感到羞耻并提高。”

  • Set the correct example. In Confucius words:"Example is better than law. For where the laws govern, the people are shameless in evading punishment. But where example governs, the people have a sense of shame and improve."

16. 喜好和社会接受度

16. Liking and Social Acceptance

人性中最深刻的原则是渴望被欣赏。

The deepest principle in human nature is the craving to be appreciated.

- 威廉詹姆斯

- William James

“约翰喜欢他的同事泰德，因为他们有相同的价值观并且喜欢相同类型的西装。”

"John likes his colleague, Ted, because they share the same values and prefer the same type of suits."

我们希望被喜欢和接受。我们相信、信任并同意我们认识和喜欢的人。我们为我们喜欢的人做事。我们喜欢喜欢我们的人（因为我们喜欢被喜欢。）如果我们觉得一个人喜欢我们，我们往往会喜欢他们。

We want to be liked and accepted. We believe, trust and agree with people we know and like. We do things for people we like. We like the people who like us (because we like to be liked.) And if we feel that a person likes us, we tend to like them back.

人们可以做些什么来让我们喜欢他们？我们倾向于喜欢我们的亲戚和恋人，以及在背景、观点、生活方式、兴趣、态度、外貌、价值观和信仰方面与我们相似的人。此外，那些外表有吸引力、受欢迎、合作或与我们有积极联系的人。我们也喜欢并信任任何熟悉的事物。

What can people do to make us like them? We tend to like our kin and romantic partners and people who are similar to us in background, opinion, lifestyle, interest, attitude, looks, values, and belief. Also, those who are physically attractive, popular, cooperative, or people we have positive associations with. We also like and trust anything familiar.

亚里士多德说：“个人美貌是比任何介绍信都更伟大的推荐。” 研究表明，我们认为相较于相貌平平或相貌平平的人，相貌出众的人拥有更令人向往的个性。实验表明，与丑陋的罪犯相比，有魅力的罪犯被认为攻击性较小，受到的惩罚也较轻。但正如 6 世纪希腊作家伊索所写，“外表往往是骗人的”。

Aristotle said:"Personal beauty is a greater recommendation than any letter of introduction." Studies show that we believe that physically attractive people have a more desirable personality than average-looking or unattractive people. Experiments show that attractive criminals are seen as less aggressive and get a milder punishment than ugly criminals. But like the 6th Century Greek writer Aesop wrote,"Appearances often are deceiving."

“我很喜欢奉承。”

"I am a sucker for flattery."

我们喜欢赞美我们的人——不管是真是假——让我们觉得自己很特别。引用英国首相兼小说家本杰明·迪斯雷利的话：“和一个人谈论他自己，他会听上几个小时。” 我们也喜欢那些给我们生活中所缺少的东西的人。

We like people who compliment us — true or not - and make us feel special. To quote the British Prime Minister and novelist Benjamin Disraeli:"Talk to a man about himself and he will listen for hours." We also like the people who give us what we are missing in life.

“为了让他们和我做生意，我把自己和有权有势的朋友联系在一起，并把自己和失败者联系起来。我也试图通过有信誉的人介绍。”

"To get them to do business with me, I associate myself with powerful friends and disassociate myself from losers. I also try to get introduced by someone of established credibility."

人们相信我们与我们交往的人具有相同的个性。信誉导致信任。

People believe we have the same personality as those we associate with. Credibility leads to trust.

“我们有一个共同的敌人。通过合作，我们都能获益。”

"We have a common enemy. By cooperating we both gain."

我们喜欢与我们合作的人。我们如何让人们合作？制造外部共同威胁或互利机会。

We like people who cooperate with us. How do we get people to cooperate? Create an external common threat or an opportunity for mutual gain.

“我相信她喜欢我，所以我喜欢她。”

"I believe she likes me, so I like her to."

我们以别人看我们的方式回报。如果我们察觉到别人不喜欢我们，我们就会倾向于不喜欢他们。

We reciprocate the way others see us. If we perceive others dislike us, we tend to dislike them.

“我请他帮我一个忙，赢得了对手的尊重和友谊。”

"I won the respect and friendship of my opponent by asking him to do me a favour."

向某人求助很可能会增加那个人对我们的好感。为什么？因为人们希望被视为与他们的行为一致。本杰明·富兰克林 (Benjamin Franklin) 告诉我们一句古老的格言：“曾经对您做过善事的人比您自己帮助过的人更愿意为您做另一件事。”

Asking a favour of someone is likely to increase that person’s liking for us. Why? Because people want to be seen as consistent with their behaviour. Benjamin Franklin tells us about an old maxim:"He that has once done you a kindness will be more ready to do you another, than he whom you yourself have obliged."

“因为我想被接受，所以我总是关注我在别人面前的样子。”

"Since I want to be accepted, I always focus on the way I appear to others."

我们希望被社会接受，而不是不喜欢或拒绝。我们强烈希望避免社会不赞成、排斥、羞辱、公开羞辱和失去地位。这有助于一致性。威廉詹姆斯说：“一个人的社会自我是他从他的伙伴那里得到的认可......没有比这更可怕的惩罚了。 “

We want to be socially accepted and not disliked or rejected. We have a strong desire for avoiding social disapproval, exclusion, humiliation, public shame and losing status. This contributes to conformity. William James says:"A man’s Social Self is the recognition which he gets from his mates...No more fiendish punishment could be devised.. .than that one should be turned loose in society and remain absolutely unnoticed by all the members thereof."

法国 17 世纪作家弗朗索瓦杜德拉罗什富科写道：“我们只承认我们的小错误，以说服人们我们没有大错误。” 我们调整我们的言行以适应我们的听众并创造他们想要的印象。我们像其他人一样行事，不说实话或公开质疑人们，因为害怕后果。我们不想成为脱颖而出的人。这就是为什么那些过分关心别人对他们的看法的人更喜欢和志同道合的人在一起的原因之一。这比站出来冒着被社会反对的风险要舒服得多。

The French 17th Century writer Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld wrote:"We only confess our little faults to persuade people that we have no big ones." We adapt what we say and do to suit our audience and create a desired impression. We behave like others do and don’t speak the truth or openly question people for fear of the consequences. We don’t want to be the person who stands out. This is one reason why people who are overly concerned about what others think about them prefer to be around like-minded people. It’s more comfortable than standing out and risking social disapproval.

“我不喜欢他，因为他自私、自卫、总是抱怨而且脾气暴躁。”

"I don’t like him because he is egoistic, defensive, always complains and has a bad temper."

我们不会向我们不喜欢的人学习，也不想与他们有联系。我们不喜欢的人是那些我们认为与我们不一样的人、我们的竞争者、我们认为有威胁的人，或者那些自我吸收、抱怨、贪婪的人等等。我们往往不喜欢那些已经被非人化——例如，被描述为邪恶或动物的人。

We don’t learn from people we don’t like and we don’t want to be associated with them. The people we don’t like are the ones we perceive as dissimilar to us, people we are in competition with, those we perceive as threatening, or people that are self-absorbed, complaining, greedy, etc. We tend to dislike people who have been dehumanized - for example, people who have been described as evil or animals.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 专注于问题和您想要实现的目标。

  • Concentrate on the issue and what you want to achieve.

  • 不要依赖别人的鼓励或批评。马库斯·奥勒留·安东尼努斯 (Marcus Aurelius Antoninus) 说：“不看邻居说的、做的或想的，他能节省多少时间。”

  • Don’t depend on the encouragement or criticism of others. Marcus Aurelius Antoninus said:"How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbour says or does or thinks."

  • 不要自动将人们的外表误认为是现实。它可能是一个社交面具。

  • Don’t automatically mistake people’s appearance for reality. It may be a social mask.

  • 社会认同是使人们行为正确的有效途径。为什么人们会避免某些行为？因为他们害怕这些行为可能引起的社会惩罚。

  • Social approval is an effective way to make people behave correctly. Why do people avoid certain actions? Because they are afraid of the social punishment these actions may cause.

  • 本杰明富兰克林写道：“爱你的敌人，因为他们告诉你你的错误。” Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld 补充说：“我们的敌人对我们的看法比我们自己的看法更接近事实。”

  • Benjamin Franklin wrote:"Love your enemies, for they tell you your faults." Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld adds:"Our enemies’ opinion of us comes closer to the truth than our own."

17.社会证明

17. Social Proof

如果 4000 万人说了一件愚蠢的话，那也不会变成明智的话。

If 40 million people say a foolish thing, it does not become a wise one.

——萨默塞特·毛姆

（英国小说家，1874-1965）

- Somerset Maugham

(British novelist, 1874-1965)

“但其他人都在这样做。”

"But everybody else is doing it."

您是否依赖他人的建议和行动？大多数人都这样做。美国哲学家埃里克·霍弗在《真正的信徒》一书中写道，“当人们可以自由地为所欲为时，他们通常会互相模仿。” 我们是群居动物，会受到我们看到的其他人的行为和信念的影响。我们相信别人比我们知道的更多。

Do you rely on others for advice and actions? Most people do. In True Believer, American philosopher Eric Hoffer wrote,"When people are free to do as they please, they usually imitate each other." We are social animals, influenced by what we see other people doing and believing. We believe that others know more than we do.

我们想要别人想要的。既然其他人都想要它，我们假设必须有一个原因。我们避免别人避免的事情。我们不假思索地模仿。尤其是当很多人或类似的人做的时候，当我们不确定的时候，在陌生的环境中，在人群中，缺乏知识的时候，或者当我们承受压力或自卑时。

We want what others want. Since everybody else wants it, we assume there has to be a reason. We avoid what others avoid. We imitate without thinking. Especially when many or similar people do it, when we are uncertain, in an unfamiliar environment, in a crowd, lack knowledge, or if we suffer from stress or low self-esteem.

时装、书籍、电影等的销售商都知道，如果有足够多的人喜欢某样东西，其他人最终就会效仿。我们相信我们认为与我们相似的人的推荐。

Sellers of fashion, books, movies, etc., know that if enough people like something, others will eventually follow. We trust testimonials from people that we see as similar to us.

沃伦·巴菲特说：“就像华尔街经常发生的那样，智者一开始做的事，最后都是傻瓜做的。” 他讲了一个很有启发性的故事：

Warren Buffett says:"As happens in Wall Street all too often, what the wise do in the beginning, fools do in the end." He tells an instructive story:

这位经营财产保险公司的朋友正在向他的董事解释他为什么要收购一家人寿保险公司。在对收购的经济和战略理由进行了相当缺乏说服力的喋喋不休之后，他突然放弃了剧本。带着顽皮的神情，他只是简单地说：“噢，伙计们，所有其他孩子都有一个。”

This friend, who ran a property-casualty insurer, was explaining to his directors why he wanted to acquire a certain life insurance company. After droning rather unpersuasively through the economics and strategic rationale for the acquisition, he abruptly abandoned the script. With an impish look, he simply said:"Aw, fellas, all the other kids have one."

“我不明白他们为什么不听我的，”TransCorp 的首席执行官说。

"I don’t understand why they don’t listen to me," said the CEO of TransCorp.

当我们不确定时，我们最有可能跟随与我们相似的人所做的事情。因此，如果 CEO 使用已经支持 CEO 的想法并且听众认为与他们相似的发言人（例如同事），他将更有可能听到他的信息。

When we are uncertain, we are most likely to follow what people similar to us do. The CEO would therefore be more likely to have his message heard if he used a spokesperson who already supported the CEO’s ideas and who the audience saw as similar to themselves, such as a colleague.

约翰的股票经纪人推荐与其他经纪人相同的股票。当约翰问他为什么时，他回答说：“我宁愿在一群人中犯错，也不愿自己纠正。”

John’s stockbroker recommends the same stock as other brokers. When John asked him why, he replied"I’d rather be wrong in a group than right by myself."

作为大多数人的一部分，我们感觉更自在。它起到保护免受批评的作用。如果我们错了，其他人也错了，我们就不会受到责备。引用 JM 凯恩斯的话：“世俗的智慧告诉我们，声誉以常规方式失败比以非常规方式获得成功更好。” 沃伦巴菲特补充道：

We feel more comfortable as part of a majority. It acts as a protection from criticism. If we are wrong and everybody else is too, we get less blame. To quote J.M. Keynes:"Worldly wisdom teaches that it is better for reputation to fail conventionally than to succeed unconventionally." Warren Buffett adds:

大多数经理都没有动力做出明智但有可能看起来像白痴的决定。他们的个人得失比太明显了：如果一个非常规的决定成功了，他们就会得到表扬，如果结果不佳，他们就会被解雇。（传统上失败是必经之路；作为一个群体，旅鼠的形象可能很糟糕，但没有一个旅鼠受到过负面报道。）

Most managers have very little incentive to make the intelligent-but-with-some-chance-of-looking-like-an-idiot decision. Their personal gain/loss ratio is all too obvious: if an unconventional decision works out well, they get a pat on the back and, if it works out poorly, they get a pink slip. (Failing conventionally is the route to go; as a group, lemmings may have a rotten image, but no individual lemming has ever received bad press.)

约翰投资了一个独家石油项目，因为有一群经验丰富的富有投资者参与其中。他们承诺他会在一年内将他的钱翻两番。一年后，他失去了一切。

John invested in an exclusive oil project since a group of sophisticated, wealthy investors were involved. They promised that he would quadruple his money in one year. A year later, he’d lost it all.

美国证券交易委员会前主席小亚瑟·莱维特说，“如果你愚蠢到基于厕所墙进行投资，你就活该赔钱。”

Former chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt, Jr. says,"If you are dumb enough to invest based on a lavatory wall, you deserve to lose money."

1900 年代初期，意大利移民查尔斯·庞兹通过承诺 40% 的国际邮政回邮优惠券回报率，为投资者筹集了 1000 万美元。他没有告诉新投资者的是，他们的钱被用来偿还早期投资者。最后，纸牌屋倒塌了。

In the early 1900s, Italian immigrant Charles Ponzi, took investors for $10 million by promising 40% returns on International Postal Reply Coupons. What he didn’t tell newer investors was that their money was being used to pay off earlier investors. In the end, the house of cards collapsed.

在新时代慈善基金会中，一些美国主要的慈善机构和捐助者相信他们可以在六个月内将资金增加一倍。New Era 使用一组人的捐款来还清另一组人的钱——直到没有钱为止。New Era 是一个价值 3.5 亿美元的庞氏骗局。查尔斯·芒格说，“大人们真的相信有一个牙仙子，只要他们同意把钱捐给慈善机构，他们的钱就会在六个月内翻一番。”

In the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy, some of the U.S.’s leading charities and donors believed they could double their money in six months. New Era used contributions from one group to pay off another — until there was no money left. New Era was a $350 million Ponzi Scheme. Charles Munger says,"Grown-up people actually believed that there was a tooth fairy out there that would double their money in six months provided they agreed to give it to charity."

盲目跟随他人可能会产生危险的后果。

Blindly following the lead of others can have dangerous consequences.

“天哪，他刺伤了我，求求你救救我！”

"Oh my God, he stabbed me. Please help me!"

在我们不确定是否存在危险以及我们不感到个人责任的情况下，我们倾向于不采取行动。此外，当我们想避免尴尬时以及当我们在陌生人中间时。人越多，我们就越看不到自己的责任。

We have a tendency to not act in situations where we are uncertain if there is danger and when we don’t feel individual responsibility. Also when we want to avoid embarrassment and when we’re among strangers. The more people, the more reduced we see our own responsibility.

1964 年 3 月 13 日凌晨 3 点刚过，在纽约市，28 岁的凯瑟琳·吉诺维斯 (Catherine Genovese) 下班回家时被人刺死。38 人在 25 分钟内从公寓窗户安全地目睹了凶手的三起袭击事件中的至少一次，而没有报警。

Just after 3 a.m., March 13, 1964 in New York City, Catherine Genovese, a 28-year old woman, was stabbed to death as she returned from her job. 38 people witnessed at least one of her killer’s three attacks from the safety of their apartment windows for 25 minutes without calling the police..

为什么邻居不帮忙？他们无动于衷吗？受惊？他们为什么要害怕从自己家中的安全报警？一对心理学教授找到了答案。仅仅因为有三十八名证人在场，就没有人提供帮助。当周围有其他人时，紧急情况的旁观者不太可能提供帮助。为什么？他们看到了两个原因。

Why didn’t the neighbours help? Were they indifferent? Frightened? Why should they be afraid of calling the police from the safety of their own homes? A pair of psychology professors found the answer. No one had helped just because thirty-eight witnesses were present. A bystander to an emergency is unlikely to help when there are other people around. Why? They saw two reasons for this.

首先，我们必须将事件解释为紧急情况。当我们不确定时，我们倾向于观察周围的人，看看他们的反应。如果其他人没有做出反应，我们就会将其解释为这不是紧急情况的证据，因此我们不会做出反应。我们不想成为在人群中脱颖而出并冒着在非紧急情况下采取行动而尴尬的人。但问题来了。如果每个人都以同样的方式推理，那么每个人都会得出同样的结论。“既然没有人担心，那就没什么事了，不可能是紧急情况。”  这被称为多元无知。

First, we must interpret an event as an emergency. When we are uncertain, we have a tendency to look at people around us to see how they react. If others don’t react, we interpret that as evidence that it is not an emergency, and we therefore don’t react. We don’t want to be the ones that stand out in a crowd and risk embarrassment for acting in a non-emergency situation. But here comes the problem. If each person reasons the same way, everyone draws the same conclusion."Since nobody is concerned, nothing is wrong. It can’t be an emergency." This is called pluralistic ignorance.

第二个原因称为责任分散。人越多，我们的个人责任就越少。我们经常通过说“可能是其他人报了警”来找借口。如果我们都这么想，就没有人会提供帮助。

The second reason is called diffusion of responsibility. The more people there are, the less personal responsibility we feel. We often rationalize by saying, "Someone else probably called the police."If we all think that way, no one will help.

我们周围的人越多，我们就越不可能提供帮助。我们不能强迫别人帮忙。如果我们惩罚不在紧急情况下提供帮助的人，我们只会激励人们通过不参与来避免受到惩罚。这将使他们将情况解释为非紧急情况。

The more people we see around us, the less likely we are to help. We can’t force people to help. If we punish people for not helping in an emergency, we will only create an incentive for people to avoid the punishment by not getting involved. This will cause them to interpret a situation as a non-emergency.

那么，如果我们在公共场所发生意外，需要帮助，应该如何应对呢？我们应该具体一点。“你在那儿，穿蓝色衬衫。这是紧急情况。请帮帮我！”

So, how should we act if we are involved in an accident in a public place and need help? We should be specific."You there, in the blue shirt. This is an emergency. Please help me!"

TransCorp 的董事会成员被问及是否有任何问题。他们环顾四周，看着其他成员。所有人都显得自信。约翰想知道并保持沉默。

The board members of TransCorp were asked if they had any questions. They looked around at the other members. All appeared confident."Am I the only one confused?" wondered John and kept quiet.

“既然没有人反对，我的想法似乎得到了所有人的支持，”首席执行官说。

"Since no one disagrees, my idea seems to have everyone’s support," the CEO said.

如果我们相信我们是唯一不明白的人，我们可能会保持沉默。直言不讳可能会导致尴尬。群体压力可能导致我们保持沉默。

If we believe that we are the only one who doesn’t understand, we may keep quiet. Speaking up may lead to embarrassment. Group pressure may contribute to our silence.

有时，相互的友谊和忠诚压倒了我们寻求替代行动方案的动机。这种群体思维已被发现是许多历史事件的一个因素，包括猪湾入侵、越南战争和珍珠港事件。

Sometimes mutual friendship and loyalty override our motivation to seek alternative courses of action. This type of group thinking has been found to be a factor in many historical events including the Bay of Pigs invasion, the Vietnam War and Pearl Harbor.

据报道，在已故经济学家彼得·F·德鲁克 (Peter F. Drucker) 的《有效执行官》一书中，通用汽车公司前董事长小阿尔弗雷德·P·斯隆 (Alfred P. Sloan, Jr.) 在一次管理会议结束时说：“先生们，我认为我们都在完全同意这里的决定”。桌旁的人都点头同意。“那么，”斯隆先生继续说道，“我建议我们推迟对此事的进一步讨论，以便给我们自己时间来解决分歧，或许可以对这个决定的全部内容有所了解。”

In the late economist Peter F. Drucker’s The Effective Executive, the former chairman of General Motors, Alfred P. Sloan, Jr., is reported to have said at the closing of a management meeting:"Gentlemen, I take it we are all in complete agreement on the decision here". Everyone around the table nodded assent. "Then," continued Mr. Sloan,"I propose we postpone further discussion of this matter to give ourselves time to develop disagreement and perhaps gain some understanding of what the decision is all about."

约翰参加了一个会议，会上提出了一项承诺 200% 回报的投资建议。与会30人全部投资，全部亏损。

John attended a meeting where an investment proposal promising a 200% return was presented. All 30 people present at the meeting invested and all lost money.

30个聪明人怎么会被愚弄？一些基础数学会告诉他们该项目注定要失败。每个人都会自动假设出席会议的其他 29 个人已经评估了该提案。如果有什么不好的，别人就会这么说。“既然他们投资，我就投资。” 事实证明，没有人花时间通读该提案。

How could 30 smart individuals be fooled? Some basic math would have told them that the project was doomed to fail. Each individual automatically assumed that the other 29 individuals present at the meeting had evaluated the proposal. If there was something bad, someone else would have said so."And since they invest, I invest." It turned out that no one had taken the time to read through the proposal.

“我奉承了他们，让他们觉得自己很特别。我给了他们目标和希望，他们吃掉了我的手。”

"I flattered them and made them feel special. I gave them purpose and hope, and they ate out of my hand."

在群体中，我们很容易被诱惑，因为我们需要社会认可。法国社会心理学家古斯塔夫·勒庞在《人群》中说，“群众从不渴望真理。他们避开不符合他们口味的证据，宁愿神化错误，如果错误引诱他们。谁能为他们提供幻想，谁就是很容易成为他们的主人；任何试图破坏他们幻想的人永远是他们的受害者。”

In a group we are easily seduced because of our need for social acceptance. The French social psychologist Gustave Le Bon said in The Crowd,"The masses have never thirsted after truth. They turn aside from evidence that is not to their taste, preferring to deify error, if error seduce them. Whoever can supply them with illusions is easily their master; whoever attempts to destroy their illusions is always their victim."

德裔瑞士哲学家弗里德里希·尼采说：“疯狂在个人身上是罕见的——但在团体、政党、民族和时代中却是常态。” 在一个群体中，我们感到匿名，这减少了我们的责任感。我们不能受到指责。这可能导致过度自信、冒险的行为。我们也可能变得冲动和具有破坏性。特别是在压力很大的情况下。本杰明·富兰克林说：“暴徒有足够的头脑，但没有头脑。”

German-Swiss philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche said:"Madness is a rare thing in individuals - but in groups, parties, peoples, and ages it is the rule." In a group, we feel anonymous, which reduces our feelings of responsibility. We can’t be blamed. This can lead to overconfident, risky behaviour. We may also become impulsive and destructive. Especially in situations of severe stress. Benjamin Franklin said:"A mob has heads enough but no brains."

模仿、服从权威和害怕与众不同是驱使人群的力量。团体不鼓励意见分歧。如果团体中的某个成员不同意，他可能会被视为不忠诚。一致优于独立思考。团体中的个人相互强化，相信他们集体是对的。他们专注于有利的后果而忽略不利的后果。

Imitation, obedience to authority, and the fear of being different are forces that drive crowds. Groups don’t encourage differences of opinion. If a member of the group disagrees, he may be seen as disloyal. Unanimity is better than independent thought. Individuals in the group reinforce each other into believing that they collectively are right. They focus on favourable consequences and ignore the downside.

模仿群体的倾向是否如此强烈，以至于人们会集体自杀？

Is the tendency for imitating the group so strong it can make people commit collective suicide?

1978 年，邪教领袖吉姆·琼斯及其人民圣殿教组织的 913 名追随者在南美洲圭亚那一个叫做琼斯镇的集体自杀和谋杀中丧生。死者中有 270 多名儿童。为什么？

In 1978, 913 followers of the cult leader Jim Jones and his People’s Temple organization died during a mass suicide and murder in a place called Jonestown in Guyana, South America. Among the dead: more than 270 children. Why?

人民圣殿教始于旧金山，1977年迁至圭亚那。

The People’s Temple started in San Francisco and moved to Guyana in 1977.

武装警卫包围了琼斯镇的定居点，食物匮乏，邪教成员被迫长时间工作并遵守严格的行为准则。邪教领袖吉姆琼斯让他的追随者一步一个脚印。他控制着信息、奖励和惩罚。1978 年，一名美国国会议员和其他三人前往琼斯镇执行实况调查任务，结果被谋杀。吉姆·琼斯认为他会卷入杀戮，而琼斯镇的孤立将导致邪教的终结。于是，他召集社区民众喝下掺有毒药的果汁饮料，参与集体自杀。

Armed guards surrounded the settlement in Jonestown, food was scarce, and the members of the cult were forced to work long hours and follow strict codes of behaviour. Cult leader Jim Jones committed his followers one step at a time. He controlled the information, the rewards, and the punishment. In 1978, an American congressman and three others went on a fact-finding mission to Jonestown and were murdered. Jim Jones thought that he would be implicated in the killings and that the isolation of Jonestown would result in the end of the cult. So he gathered the community to participate in an act of mass suicide by drinking a fruit drink mixed with poison.

心理学教授 Robert Cialdini 写道：

Psychology Professor Robert Cialdini writes:

他的 [Jones] 绝招是决定将 People's Temple 社区从它在旧金山市区的根基转移到赤道南美洲的偏远地区，那里的不确定性和排他性相似性的条件将使社会认同原则对他起作用也许别处。

Cialdini 继续说道：“在像圭亚那这样的国家，对于琼斯镇居民来说，没有类似的其他人，只有琼斯镇本身的人。”

His [Jones] master-stroke was the decision to move the People’s Temple community from its roots in urban San Francisco to the remoteness of equatorial South America, where the conditions of uncertainty and exclusive similarity would make the principle of social proof operate for him as perhaps nowhere else.

Cialdini continues:"In a country like Guyana, there were no similar others for a Jonestown resident but the people of Jonestown itself."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 19世纪的美国诗人拉尔夫·沃尔多·爱默生说：“在世上随从世人的意见很容易，在孤独中随自己的意见而活很容易；但伟大的人是在人群中与人保持一致的人。完美的甜蜜是孤独的独立。” 流行的并不总是正确的。如果你不喜欢别人正在做的事情，就不要去做。沃伦巴菲特说：“我们不会因为重要人物、有声望的人或很多人同意我们而感到安慰。如果他们不同意，我们也不会感到安慰。”

  • The 19th Century American poet Ralph Waldo Emerson said:"It is easy in the world to live after the world’s opinion; it is easy in solitude to live after our own; but the great man is he who in the midst of the crowd keeps with perfect sweetness the independence of solitude." What is popular is not always right. If you don’t like what other people are doing, don’t do it. Warren Buffett says: "We derive no comfort because important people, vocal people, or great numbers of people agree with us. Nor do we derive comfort if they don’t."

  • 不要管别人在做什么，自己想想。问：这有意义吗？记住金融分析院长本杰明格雷厄姆的建议：

    鼓起你的知识和经验的勇气。如果您从事实中得出结论，并且您知道自己的判断是正确的，请按此行事——即使其他人可能会犹豫或持不同意见。（你既不对也不错，因为人群不同意你。你是对的，因为你的数据和推理是正确的。）

  • Disregard what others are doing and think for yourself. Ask: Does this make sense? Remember the advice from Benjamin Graham, the dean of financial analysis:

    Have the courage of your knowledge and experience. If you have formed a conclusion from the facts and if you know your judgement is sound, act on it - even though others may hesitate or differ. (You are neither right nor wrong because the crowd disagrees with you. You are right because your data and reasoning are right.)

  • 我们孩子的很多性格特征和习惯都是在家庭之外形成的。孩子们从他们的朋友那里学习什么是可以接受的，什么是不可以接受的，所以要确保他们周围有正确的“同龄人”。

  • A lot of our children’s personality traits and habits are shaped outside the home. Children learn from their friends what is acceptable or not so make sure the right"peer group" surrounds them.

  • 当属于一个小组时，请记住参与者可能有不同的目标、信息和解释。寻找不同的观点并鼓励人们公开表达不同意见。在小组中指定某人质疑事物并指出风险和陷阱。使用选票来减少社会压力的风险。

  • When part of a group, remember that the participants may have different goals, information, and interpretations. Seek out alternative points of view and encourage people to openly disagree. Appoint someone in the group to question things and point out risks and pitfalls. Use ballots to reduce the risk of social pressure.

  • 让人们对自己的行为负责。但请记住，当所有人都负责时，就没有人负责。

  • Make people responsible for their actions. Remember though, when all are accountable, no one is accountable.

18.权威

18. Authority

在科学问题上，千人之权威抵不上一个人卑微的推理。

In questions of science, the authority of a thousand is not worth the humble reasoning of a single individual.

- Galileo Galilei

（意大利天文学家和物理学家，1564-1642）

- Galileo Galilei

(Italian astronomer and physicist, 1564-1642)

在闯入约翰办公室后，他说：“当然，我相信他是一名保安，因为他有制服。”

After the break-in at John’s office, he said:"Of course, I believed he was a security guard, since he had a uniform."

我们倾向于服从权威，尤其是当我们不确定、受到监督或我们周围的人都在做同样的事情时。我们最容易受到可靠权威的影响，这些权威在我们看来既知识渊博又值得信赖。

We tend to obey an authority, especially when we are uncertain, supervised, or when people around us are doing the same. We are most easily influenced by credible authorities, those we see as both knowledgeable and trustworthy.

“我在新英格兰医学杂志上读到过，所以它一定是正确的。”

"I read it in the New England Journal of Medicine, so it must be correct."

名字和声誉影响着我们。以及权力或地位的象征，如头衔、财产、等级、制服或漂亮的西装和领带。例如，在一项研究中，22 名医院护士接到一位陌生医生的电话，并被要求服用明显过量的未经授权的药物。除了一名护士外，所有人都服从了。

Names and reputation influence us. And symbols of power or status like titles, possessions, rank, uniforms, or a nice suit and tie. For example, in one study 22 hospital nurses got a telephone call from an unknown physician and were ordered to administer an obvious overdose of an unauthorized drug. All but one nurse obeyed.

另一个例子是广告商使用名人来为他们的产品背书。但出名并不会给人们带来特殊的专业知识。

Another example is when advertisers use famous people to endorse their products. But being famous doesn’t give people special expertise.

“越是不明白，越是相信专家。”

"The more I didn’t understand, the more I believed the expert."

当我们不理解专家时，专家有时更有说服力。有时我们对听起来很聪明的东西印象太深。例如，有些人只是因为不了解而购买投资。他们认为它一定是独一无二的。正如沃伦巴菲特所说，“笼罩在神秘之中的技术显然对投资建议的提供者有价值。毕竟，有哪个巫医仅仅通过建议‘服用两片阿司匹林’就获得了名利？”

Experts are sometimes more convincing when we don’t understand them. Sometimes we are too impressed by something that sounds clever. For example, some people buy into investments just because they don’t understand them. They assume it must be something unique. As Warren Buffett says,"Techniques shrouded in mystery clearly have value to the purveyor of investment advice. After all, what witch doctor has ever achieved fame and fortune by simply advising ‘Take two aspirins’?"

“我只是奉命行事。”

"I was only following orders."

盲目服从有时是一种为愚蠢行为合理化的方法。

Blind obedience is sometimes a way to rationalize dumb actions.

“我以为他搞错了，但我不敢告诉他，毕竟他是高手。”

"I believed he was making a mistake, but 1 didn’t dare tell him. After all, he is the expert."

一项涉及航空公司飞行员的研究指出，避免冲突是导致坠机的一个因素。官员们不愿意不同意飞行员的权威。例如，在 1978 年的一架 DC-8 坠毁事故中，飞行工程师告诉机长他们的燃油快用完了。机长解除了警告，飞机坠毁了。

A study involving airline pilots cited conflict avoidance as a contributing factor to crashes. Officers are reluctant to disagree with the authority of pilots. For example, in a crash of a DC-8 in 1978, the flight engineer told the captain that they were running out of fuel. The captain dismissed the warning and the plane crashed.

1997 年，苏格兰的一名女警官被指派调查一起谋杀案。法医调查人员后来在发现谋杀受害者的房子里发现了她的指纹。但该女子发誓坚称，她从未进过屋子。苏格兰犯罪记录办公室的四位专家说，这张照片是她的。她被停职并被指控作伪证。随后的事件表明指纹既不是她的也不是拇指的，而是食指的。因此，专家会犯错误。

In 1997, a female police officer in Scotland was assigned to a murder investigation. Forensic investigators later found her thumbprint in the house where the murder victim was found. But the woman insisted, under oath, she had never been inside the house. Four experts from the Scottish Criminal Record Office said that the print was hers. She was suspended and accused of perjury. Subsequent events showed that the fingerprint was neither hers nor from a thumb, but from a forefinger. Thus, experts make mistakes.

权威是如此强大，以至于我们可能会给其他人带来痛苦。英国小说家、科学家查尔斯·珀西·斯诺在《两种文化与科学革命》中说：“当你想到人类漫长而阴暗的历史时，你会发现以服从的名义犯下的骇人听闻的罪行比以往任何时候都多以叛乱的名义。”

Authority is so powerful that we may cause pain to other people to comply. The British novelist and scientist Charles Percy Snow said in The Two Cultures and the Scientific Revolution:"When you think of the long and gloomy history of man, you will find more hideous crimes have been committed in the name of obedience than have ever been committed in the name of rebellion."

在耶鲁大学的一项实验中，心理学教授斯坦利·米尔格拉姆 (Stanley Milgram) 伪装成权威来欺骗人们，让普通人将他们有充分理由相信的强烈痛苦强加给其他人。实验参与者被要求在回答错误的问题时电击另一个人。在实验过程中没有传递真正的疼痛。但它表明，当我们收到来自我们认为是合法权威的命令时，我们会服从，即使结果是我们最终伤害了他人。在后来的研究中，米尔格拉姆表明，服从性通过首先观察同伴服从而最大化，但当同伴反叛时，或者当受害者表现得像受虐狂要求受到电击时，服从性会急剧下降。米尔格拉姆在《服从权威》中说：“当一个人只是一系列邪恶行动中的一个直接环节时，在心理上很容易忽视责任。”

In one experiment at Yale University, Psychology Professor Stanley Milgram tricked people by posing as an authority and caused normal people to impose what they had every reason to believe was intense pain to other people. The participants in the experiment were instructed to shock another person if they answered a question wrong. No real pain was delivered during the experiment. But it showed that when we are given orders from what we believe to be a legitimate authority, we obey even if the result is that we end up hurting others. In later studies Milgram showed that obedience was maximized by first observing peers obey but dramatically reduced when peers rebelled, or when the victim acted like a masochist asking to be shocked. Milgram said in Obedience to Authority:"It is psychologically easy to ignore responsibility when one is only an immediate link in a chain of evil action."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 根据其基本事实评估陈述的真实性，而不考虑权威的个人品质或社会地位。

  • Evaluate the truth of a statement on the basis of its underlying facts, without regard to the authority’s personal qualities or social status.

  • 任何人都可以称自己为专家。区分真专家和假专家。

  • Anyone can call themselves an expert. Separate between real and false experts.

  • 权威人士可能有兴趣说服您相信符合他们利益的事情。始终考虑可靠性、可信度、敏感性和偏见。为了确保他们的可信度，当局经常在强项之前提及弱点，并提供似乎违背他们利益的信息。这种技巧经常被推销员和谈判人员使用。

  • An authority may have an interest in persuading you to believe something that is in their interest. Always consider reliability, credibility, sensibility and bias. To insure their trustworthiness, authorities often mention weaknesses before strengths and provide information that seems contrary to their interests. This technique is often used by salesmen and negotiators.

19. 意义建构

19. Sensemaking

“我们向后理解生活，但向前生活。”

"We understand life backwards but live it forwards."

- Soren Aabye Kierkegaard

（丹麦哲学家和神学家，1813-1855 年）

- Soren Aabye Kierkegaard

(Danish philosopher and theologian, 1813-1855)

“一定是有原因的！”

"There has to be a reason!"

19世纪的剧作家和诗人奥斯卡·王尔德说：“公众有一种永不满足的好奇心，想知道一切，除了那些值得知道的。”

The 19th Century playwright and poet Oscar Wilde said:"The public have an insatiable curiosity to know everything, except what is worth knowing."

我们不喜欢不确定性。我们需要理解和理解事件。我们拒绝接受未知。我们不喜欢不可预测性和无意义。因此，我们寻求解释事情发生的原因。特别是如果它们是新奇的、令人费解的或可怕的。通过寻找模式和因果关系，我们得到安慰并为未来学习

We don’t like uncertainty. We have a need to understand and make sense of events. We refuse to accept the unknown. We don’t like unpredictability and meaninglessness. We therefore seek explanations for why things happen. Especially if they are novel, puzzling or frightening. By finding patterns and causal relationships we get comfort and learn for the future

TransCorp 聘请了一组人来找出新产品失败的原因。

TransCorp hired a team of people to find out why the new product failed.

在这种情况下我们做错了什么？之间有区别：“为什么会发生？” 和“什么会导致这种情况发生？” 该团队寻找导致其新产品失败的具体因素。他们可能会从以下问题中学到更多：为什么新产品会失败？一般有哪些原因？影响产品故障的关键因素有哪些？

What did we do wrong in this case? There is a difference between:"Why did it happen?" and"What can cause this to happen?" The team looked for the specific factors that caused their new product to fail. They may learn more from asking: Why do new products fail? What general reasons are there? What key factors influence product failures?

“事后聪明很容易，”夏洛克·福尔摩斯在《雷神之桥》中如是说。我们将现在解读为过去。事件发生后，我们知道事情的结果。当试图理解发生的事情时，我们会构建一个符合结果的合理故事或解释。但是以后可以通过多种方式理解事件或行为。符合结果的因素可能有很多，可能有偶然性，或者我们猜测的原因也可能与其他结果一致，包括结果的相反或预防。问：我们对事件的解释能否帮助我们预测未来的类似事件？

"It is easy to be wise after the event,"says Sherlock Holmes in The Problem of Thor Bridge. We read the present into the past. After an event, we know how things turned out. When trying to make sense of what has happened, we construct a plausible story or explanation that fits the outcome. But there are many ways an event or behaviour can later be understood. There may be many contributing factors that fit the outcome, chance may be involved, or our guessed causes may also be consistent with other outcomes, including the opposite or prevention of the outcome. Ask: Could our explanation of the event help us predict future similar events?

这就是依赖基于案例的故事的危险。可能会选择故事来证明某些事情，并可能给我们一种错觉般的清晰感。关于结果的知识也可能对历史事件的重建产生一些怀疑（假设历史学家不在场）。历史往往是由各种事件汇集而成的。

This is the danger of relying on case-based stories. Stories may be selected to prove something and may give us a delusional sense of clarity. Knowledge about outcomes may also cast some doubt on reconstructions of historical events (given that the historian was not there). History is often composed of various events all coming together.

历史也可以通过在当下的历史学家中幸存下来的东西来解释。并非所有来源都存活下来。不是所有的事情都会被记录下来，记忆是不可靠的，证据可能会被销毁或故意忽略，有些事情可能会因为太尴尬而无法提及。当奥利弗·克伦威尔 (Oliver Cromwell) 的肖像画完成时，他告诉这位艺术家：“注意所有这些粗糙、丘疹、疣，以及你看到我时的一切，否则我永远不会为此付一分钱。”

History is also explained by what has survived into the historians present. Not all sources survive. Not everything gets recorded, memories are unreliable, evidence may be destroyed or deliberately ignored, and some things may be too embarrassing to mention. When Oliver Cromwell’s portrait was painted, he told the artist."Remark all these roughnesses, pimples, warts, and everything as you see me, otherwise I will never pay a farthing for it."

我们似乎也倾向于将过去的成就浪漫化。墨尔本大学医学史讲师约翰·沃勒 (John Waller) 在谈到爱因斯坦的运气中的科学发现时说：“许多传记似乎都是为了颂扬偶像、祖先、学科，甚至是科学家生活和工作的国家而写的”

We also seem to have a tendency for romanticizing past achievements. John Waller, Lecturer in the History of Medicine at the University of Melbourne, says on scientific discoveries in Einstein's Luck:"Many biographies seem to have been written to glorify idols, ancestors, disciplines, or even the nations in which the scientists lived and worked."

“他为什么这么蠢？他怎么能那样做？很明显，这会发生。”

"Why was he so stupid? How could he have done that? It was obvious it would happen."

19世纪的俄国作家陀思妥耶夫斯基说：“一切失败时都显得愚蠢。” 事后看来，一切似乎都是显而易见的。但我们应该在他们自己的时代背景下审视早期的决定。也许这些行动在当时是有道理的。我们不知道决策者面临哪些不确定性、条件或情境因素。好的决策可能会导致不好的结果，反之亦然。如果我们相信我们比过去更能预测过去，那么我们也可能相信我们能比我们能更好地预测未来。罗马尼亚戏剧家尤金·尤内斯库说：“你只能在事情发生后才能预测。”

The 19th Century Russian writer Fyodor Dostoevsky said:"Everything seems stupid when it fails." In hindsight, everything seems obvious. But we should look at earlier decisions in the context of their own time. Perhaps the actions made sense at the time. We don’t know what uncertainties, conditions, or situational factors faced the decision-maker. Good decision-making can lead to bad outcomes and vice versa. If we believe that we predicted the past better than we did, we may also believe that we can predict the future better than we can. The Romanian dramatist Eugene Ionesco said:"You can only predict things after they’ve happened."

“油价将稳定在 60 美元。”

"The oil price will stabilize at $60."

他们怎么知道的？在Cato Journal上，著名教授 Deirdre McCloskey 说：“如果你想搭便车去巴格达，这里有一条魔毯；如果你想杀死你的敌人，这里有一个魔法娃娃；如果你想拥有无限的财富，这里有一个预测利率。” 我们喜欢人们告诉我们未来会是什么样子。它减少了不确定性。没有一次可以预测未来并不重要，我们愿意为未来预言家的存在付出代价。

How do they know that? In the Cato Journal, Distinguished Professor Deirdre McCloskey said:"If you desire a ride to Baghdad, here is a magic carpet; if you desire your enemy dead, here is a magic doll; if you desire unlimited riches, here is a forecast of interest rates." We like it when people tell us what the future will look like. It reduces uncertainty. It doesn’t matter that no once can predict the future, we willingly pay for the existence of future-tellers.

Charles Munger 说：“在这里我会说，如果我们的预测比其他人的预测好一点，那是因为我们试图做出更少的预测。”

Charles Munger says:"Around here I would say that if our predictions have been a little better than other people’s, it’s because we’ve tried to make fewer of them."

“这不可能是偶然发生的，一定是有原因的。”

"It couldn't have happened by chance. There must be a reason."

我们在股票走势中看到墨迹中的面孔和模式。我们在巧合中找到意义。我们低估了机会的影响。我们想找到各种事件的原因——随机的或非随机的。如果我们找不到任何东西，我们就会建造它们。然后我们选择符合预期模式的事物并忽略其余的。研究表明，当我们被告知过程是随机的时，我们甚至会尝试找出一种模式。

We see faces in inkblots and patterns in the movements of stocks. We find meaning in coincidences. We underestimate the influence of chance. We want to find reasons for all kind of events — random or not. And if we don’t find any, we construct them. We then choose the things that fit an intended pattern and ignore the rest. Studies show that we even try to figure out a pattern when we are told a process is random.

在一项实验中，设置了两盏灯并以随机顺序闪烁。在每次试验之前，研究对象都试图猜测两种光中的哪一种会出现。研究表明，他们试图在他们的猜测中匹配之前出现的频率。类似的研究表明，老鼠或鸽子反而会选择最常出现的选项。如果我们假设红灯出现的频率为 80%，绿灯出现的频率为 20%，我们应该每次都押注最有可能的结果：红色。然后我们有 80% 的时间猜对了。尝试匹配频率只能给出 68% 的正确答案。

In one experiment, two lights were set up and flashed in a random sequence. Before each trial, research subjects tried to guess which of the two lights would appear. The studies showed that they tried to match the frequency of previous occurrences in their guesses. Similar studies showed that rats or pigeons instead chose the alternative that came up most frequently. If we assume that a red light occurs with a frequency of 80% and a green light with a frequency of 20%, we should bet on the most likely outcome every time: red. We then guess right 80% of the time. Trying to match the frequency only gave the right answer 68% of the time.

当我们使用不可靠的测试来评估人们时，我们倾向于看到不存在的模式的一个例子。如果在假设测试测量的特性随时间稳定的情况下重复时给出大致相同的结果，则该测试是可靠的。如果测试准确地测量了它声称要测量的内容，则该测试是有效的。以罗夏墨迹测验为例。一个问题是该测试将很大一部分正常人归类为心理障碍。我们可以通过研究一个人如何看待一系列墨迹来评估人格吗？采访者可以阅读他们希望看到的任何内容。该测试今天仍在使用，尽管研究表明它允许无数的解释并且没有预测价值。

An example of our tendency to see patterns that aren’t there is when we use unreliable tests for evaluating people. A test is reliable if it gives about the same result when repeated assuming the test measures a characteristic that is stable over time. A test is valid if it accurately measures what it claims to measure. Take the Rorschach inkblot test as an example. One problem is that the test classifies a large percentage of normal individuals as psychologically disordered. Can we evaluate personality by studying how an individual perceives a series of inkblots? Interviewers can read into it whatever they wish to see. This test is still used today although research has shown that it allows for countless interpretations and has no predictive value.

“从前在……的土地上”

"Once upon a time in the land of..."

我们很快就可以得出结论。作家兼企业家塞思戈丁在他的著作《所有营销人员都是骗子》中讲述了一个真实的故事。20世纪80年代，一些商人买了一些名牌立体声扬声器，装进了卡车。他们把卡车停在哈佛的一个宿舍后面，开始窃窃私语“嘘……嘿！你想买些扬声器吗？” 他们从未说过扬声器被偷了，但路人以为是。因此，他们必须讨价还价。商人很快就卖光了。即使扬声器的价格比当地商店的价格高一点。

We are quick to draw conclusions. Author and entrepreneur Seth Godin tells a true story in his book All Marketers Are Liars. In the 1980s, some businessmen bought some branded stereo speakers and packed them into a truck. They parked the truck behind a dorm at Harvard and started whispering"Pssst.. .Hey! You wanna buy some speakers?" They never said that the speakers were stolen but passer-bys assumed they were. They therefore had to be a bargain. The businessmen sold out in no time. Even if the speakers cost a little more than they did in the local store.

我们喜欢故事和讲故事。好的故事和戏剧会引起我们的注意。他们赋予事件以意义。我们通过给自己讲一些令人欣慰的故事来合理化决策并证明选择的合理性。我们使用故事来理解、记住和理解事件。但有时我们很难将真实故事与虚假故事区分开来。事件发生后，会创建一个故事，使事件有意义。请记住，一个故事可以有许多可能的开头（和结尾）。

We love stories and story-telling. Good stories and drama get our attention. They give meaning to events. We rationalize decisions and justify choices by telling ourselves comforting stories. We use stories to understand, remember and make sense of events. But sometimes we have a hard time separating a true story from a false one. After an event a story is created so that the event makes sense. Remember that a story can have many possible beginnings (and endings).

记住

Keep in mind

  • 寻找其他解释以及通常会发生的情况。考虑一般原因。

  • Look for alternative explanations and what normally happens. Think about general reasons.

  • 考虑其他可能的结果是如何发生的。不要低估机会。

  • Consider how other possible outcomes might have happened. Don’t underestimate chance.

  • 事后看来，一切似乎都是显而易见的。如果我们向前看，会有很多可能的结果。

  • In hindsight, everything seems obvious. If we look forward, there are many possible outcomes.

20. 尊重理性

20. Reason-respecting

“请你告诉我，”爱丽丝有点胆怯地说，“你的猫为什么笑成那样？”

“这是一只柴郡猫，”公爵夫人说，“这就是原因。”

"Please would you tell me," said Alice, a little timidly,"why your cat grins like that?"

"It’s a Cheshire Cat,"said the Duchess,"and that’s why."

- Lewis Carroll

（英国数学家和作家，1832-1898，出自《镜中奇遇记》）

- Lewis Carroll

(British mathematician and writer, 1832-1898, from Through the Looking Glass)

我们对理解的需求使我们甚至相信胡说八道。

Our need for making sense makes us even believe in nonsense.

在一个实验中，一位社会心理学家询问排队使用复印机的人，如果她可以走到他们前面，“请问，我有 5 页。我可以使用复印机吗，因为我必须复印一些？” 几乎所有人都同意了。

In one experiment a social psychologist asked people standing in line to use a copying machine if she could go in front of them,"Excuse me, I have 5 pages. May I use the Xerox machine because I have to make some copies?" Nearly all agreed.

当人们向我们求助时，如果他们给我们一个理由，我们就更有可能照办——即使我们不明白这个原因或原因是错误的。通常重要的不是理由本身，而是理由的措辞方式。有时，没有合理的理由，“因为”这个词就是最重要的。我们需要解释，而“因为”这个词暗示了一种解释。

When people ask us for a favour we are more likely to comply if they give us a reason — even if we don’t understand the reason or it is wrong. Often it isn’t the reason itself that is important, but the way the reason is phrased. Sometimes the word"because," without a sensible reason, is all that matters. We want explanations and the word"because" imply an explanation.

CF Braun Engineering Company 的创始人 Carl Braun 明白告诉人们“为什么”的重要性。查尔斯·芒格给我们讲了一个故事：

Carl Braun, the creator of CF Braun Engineering Company, understood the importance of telling people"why." Charles Munger tells us the story:

他对 Braun 公司所有通信的规则被称为五个 W——你必须说出谁将做什么、在哪里、何时以及为什么。如果你在博朗公司写了一封信或指示告诉某人做某事，但你没有告诉他原因，你可能会被解雇。事实上，如果你这样做两次，你就会被解雇。

你可能会问为什么这如此重要？好吧，这又是一条心理学规则。就像如果你把知识排列在一堆模型上，这些模型基本上是问题的答案，你会想得更好，为什么，为什么，为什么，如果你总是告诉人们为什么，他们会更好地理解它，他们会认为它更重要，他们将更有可能遵守。即使他们不理解您的理由，他们也更有可能遵守。

所以有一条铁律，就像你想通过问为什么、为什么、为什么开始获得世俗智慧一样，在与其他人交流任何事情时，你要包括为什么、为什么、为什么。

His rule for all the Braun Company’s communications was called the five W’s - you had to tell who was going to do what, where, when and why. And if you wrote a letter or directive in the Braun Company telling somebody to do something, and you didn’t tell him why, you could get fired. In fact, you would get fired if you did it twice.

You might ask why that is so important? Well, again that’s a rule of psychology. Just as you think better if you array knowledge on a bunch of models that are basically answers to the question, why, why, why, if you always tell people why, they’ll understand it better, they’ll consider it more important, and they’ll be more likely to comply. Even if they don’t understand your reason, they’ll be more likely to comply.

So there’s an iron rule that just as you want to start getting worldly wisdom by asking why, why, why in communicating with other people about everything, you want to include why, why, why.

“我们为什么要这样做？为什么我们要这样做？”“因为我们一直都是这样做的。”

"Why should we do this? Why should we do it this way?""Because this is how we always have done it."

我们不仅应该给人们做事的理由，还应该鼓励灵活性。让他们质疑程序，以及看似不言而喻的事实是否真的对企业有利。问为什么，问为什么，再问为什么。第三个为什么经常涉及真正的问题。

We should not only give people reasons for what to do but should also encourage flexibility. Ask them to question procedures and whether what appear to be self-evident truths are really good for the business. Ask why, ask why, and ask why again. The third why often gets down to the real issue.

“我怎么能用我不明白的东西呢？”

"How can I use what I don’t understand?"

了解原因是学习的一个重要因素。要学习、记忆、组织和使用思想，我们必须了解“为什么”和“如何”。记住我们不理解的东西是没有用的。如果我们不理解一个想法的含义，我们就不会使用它。我们不使用的东西，我们忘记了。我们还需要有学习的动力。如果我们不明白为什么我们需要学习一些东西，我们就不会有动力。我们需要看看它的实际用途。

Understanding reasons is an important factor in learning. To learn, remember, organize, and use ideas, we must understand the"why" and"how." There’s no use memorizing what we don’t understand. If we don’t understand the meaning of an idea, we don’t use it. What we don’t use, we forget. We also need to be motivated to learn. And we can’t be motivated if we don’t understand why we need to learn something. We need to see its practical use.

理解是关于看到模式的能力——想法和事物是如何联系在一起的。可以在各种情况下使用的知识。

Understanding is about the ability of seeing patterns - how ideas and things relate and hang together. Knowledge that can be used in a variety of situations.

我们的大脑更喜欢具体和实用的东西，而不是抽象和理论的东西。我们特别擅长记忆图像和空间信息。因此，如果通过图片和简单、清晰和生动的现实生活故事来说明想法和模式的使用，我们会学得更好。关于什么有效什么无效的故事可以提高我们记住所学知识的能力。

Our brains favour the concrete and practical over the abstract and theoretical. We are especially good at remembering images and spatial information. We therefore learn better if the use of ideas and patterns are illustrated through pictures and simple, clear and vivid real-life stories. Stories on what works and what doesn’t work increase our ability to retain what we’ve learned.

亚里士多德说：“对于我们在做之前必须学习的事情，我们通过做来学习。” 这意味着我们需要在各种情况下练习我们所学的知识。

Aristotle said:"For the things we have to learn before we can do them, we learn by doing them." This means we need to practice what we have learnt in various situations.

我们还需要一个组织框架，以便更好地检索和使用知识。Charles Munger 补充道：“如果你只记住孤立的事实并尝试将它们反击，你就无法真正了解任何事情。如果事实没有在理论的格子结构上联系在一起，你就没有可用的形式”

We also need an organizing framework in order to better retrieve and use knowledge. Charles Munger adds:"You can’t really know anything if you just remember isolated facts and try and bang ‘em back. If the facts don’t hang together on a latticework of theory, you don’t have them in a usable form."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 人们不能被他们不理解的东西说服。我们低估了给人们理由的重要性。以有确凿证据支持的充分解释的理由，通常更容易让人们做出改变。告诉他们，让他们理解为什么需要采取特定行动、预期目标是什么以及您认为该行动正确的原因。

  • People can’t be persuaded by what they don’t understand. We underestimate the importance of giving people a reason. It is often easier to get people to change with a well-explained reason backed by solid evidence. Tell them so they understand why a specific action is needed, what the expected objective is, and why you think the action is right.

  • 当然，这并非在所有情况下都有效。有时，你不会通过向人们灌输逻辑来改变他们的观点。用乔纳森·斯威夫特的话来说：“你不能说服一个人脱离他一开始就没有说服自己的立场。” 亚里士多德补充说：“因为基于知识的论证意味着指导，而有些人是无法指导的。” 有时诉诸情感比诉诸理性更好，因为人们更容易被自己的感受所感动，而不是被自己的理解所感动。

  • Of course, this doesn’t work in every case. Sometimes you don’t change people’s opinions by showering them with logic. In Jonathan Swift’s words: "You cannot reason a person out of a position he did not reason himself into in the first place." Aristotle adds:"For argument based on knowledge implies instruction, and there are people whom one cannot instruct."
