Sometimes it is better to appeal to emotions than to reason since people are more moved by what they feel than by what they understand.

21. 先相信后怀疑

21. Believe First and Doubt Later

“我们的新产品非常适合您，原因如下……”

"Our new product is very good for you for the following reasons..."

我们开始假设该产品对我们有益，并寻找证实这一点的证据。当人们给我们理由时，我们相信他们。我们相信人们在告诉我们真相，即使事实并非如此。

We start assuming that the product is good for us and look for evidence that confirms it. We believe people when they give us reasons. We believe that people are telling us the truth, even when they are not.

我们不是天生的怀疑论者。我们发现很容易相信，但很难怀疑。怀疑是积极的，需要付出努力。伯特兰·罗素说：“相信似乎是我们所做的最精神的事情。” 为什么？因为我们必须相信才能理解。

We are not natural skeptics. We find it easy to believe, but difficult to doubt. Doubting is active and takes effort. Bertrand Russell said:"Believing seems the most mental thing we do." Why? Because we have to believe in order to understand.

研究表明，为了理解某些信息，我们必须首先接受它是真实的。17 世纪的哲学家本尼迪克特斯·德·斯宾诺莎 (Benedictus de Spinoza) 认为，理解和相信只是同一心理过程的两个不同词。我们首先相信我们了解的所有信息，然后才努力评估，如果有必要，不相信它。研究表明斯宾诺莎是对的。我们不自觉地毫不费力地相信我们所看到和听到的，只有在事后（有时）努力我们才会怀疑并提出问题。心理学教授丹尼尔吉尔伯特在他的研究“心理系统如何相信”中说：“在理解并接受一个想法之后，斯宾诺莎认为人们完全可以自由选择不接受或证明它。”

Studies show that in order to understand some information we must first accept it as true. The 17th Century philosopher Benedictus de Spinoza argued that understanding and believing are simply two different words for the same mental process. We first believe all information we understand and only afterwards and with effort do we evaluate, and if necessary, un-believe it. Studies show that Spinoza was right. We automatically and effortlessly believe what we see and hear and only afterwards (sometimes) with effort do we doubt and ask questions. Psychology Professor Daniel Gilbert says in his study How Mentals Systems Believe:"Having comprehended and accepted an idea, Spinoza considered persons entirely free either to unaccept or to certify it."

研究还表明，我们分心或压力越大（因此无法深入思考），我们就越有可能相信我们通常会觉得可疑的事情。我们是否想清楚事情取决于我们的动机和能力。

Studies also show that the more distracted or pressured we are (and therefore prevented from thinking things through), the more likely we believe in something we normally would find dubious. Whether we think things through or not depends on our motivation and ability.

相信错误的事情有时可能会带来好处。例如，研究表明，如果学生被告知他们在某个科目上高于平均水平，他们会做得更好。

Believing something that is false may sometimes come with a benefit. For example, studies show that if students are told they are above average on a subject, they will do better.

人们欺骗我们有多成功？

How successful are people at deceiving us?

我们能抓住骗子吗？我们似乎不善于从谎言中辨别真相。研究表明，人们——甚至是专业人士——在区分真假方面略胜于偶然。我们似乎更善于判断人们何时说真话而不是何时说谎。米歇尔·德·蒙田说：“如果谎言和真相一样，只有一张脸，我们的状态会更好。因为我们会把骗子所说的相反的东西当成确定的。但真相的反面有十万种形状和无限领域。”

Can we catch a liar? We don’t seem to be good at telling a truth from a lie. Studies show that people - even professionals - are slightly better than chance at distinguishing truths from lies. We seem to be better at judging when people are telling the truth than when they are telling a lie. Michel de Montaigne said:"If falsehood, like truth, had only one face, we would be in better shape. For we would take as certain the opposite of what the liar said. But the reverse of truth has a hundred thousand shapes and a limitless field."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 处理重要问题时，三思而后行，避免分心。

  • When dealing with important issues think things through and avoid distraction.

22. 内存限制

22. Memory Limitations

每个人都抱怨他的记忆力，没有人抱怨他的判断力。

Everyone complains of his memory, and no one complains of his judgement.

- Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld

- Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld

我们的记忆是有选择性的。我们会记住某些事情，而扭曲或忘记其他事情。每当我们回忆起一个事件时，我们都会重建我们的记忆。我们只记得我们过去真实经历的片段。受我们所学、我们的经历、信念、情绪、期望、压力和偏见影响的片段。

Our memory is selective. We remember certain things and distort or forget others. Every time we recall an event, we reconstruct our memories. We only remember fragments of our real past experiences. Fragments influenced by what we have learned, our experiences, beliefs, mood, expectations, stress, and biases.

某些经历会产生强烈的感受，因此比其他经历更令人难忘。戏剧性或可怕的经历或事件会留在我们的记忆中。情绪化的事件比非情绪化的事件更容易被记住。这就是为什么如果信息与生动的故事联系在一起，我们会学得更好。学习也与情绪有关。我们在积极的情绪中学得更好。这就是为什么教学应该以在学生中产生强大的积极情绪的方式进行。

Certain experiences create strong feelings and are therefore more memorable than others. Dramatic or fearful experiences or events stick in our memories. Emotional events are better remembered than unemotional ones. That is why we learn better if information is tied to a vivid story. Learning is also tied to mood. We learn better in a positive mood. That is why teaching should be performed in a way that creates powerful positive emotions among students.

心理学教授 Daniel Schacter 在《记忆的七大罪》中提出，我们的记忆故障可分为七大“罪”。

Psychology Professor Daniel Schacter, proposes in The Seven Sins of Memory that our memory’s malfunctions can be divided into seven "sins."

  1. 随着时间的推移，我们的记忆力会减弱，我们会失去记忆。
  2. Our memory weakens and we lose memory over time.
  3. 我们全神贯注于分散注意力的问题，而没有将注意力集中在我们需要记住的事情上。
  4. We are preoccupied with distracting issues and don’t focus attention on what we need to remember.
  5. 我们搜索我们可能拼命想检索的信息——我们知道我们知道的东西——但被阻止了。
  6. We search for information that we may be desperately trying to retrieve — something we know that we know — but are blocked.
  7. 我们将内存分配给了错误的来源。
  8. We assign memory to the wrong source.
  9. 当我们试图唤起过去的经历时，作为引导性问题、评论或建议的结果，记忆就会被植入。
  10. Memories are implanted as a result of leading questions, comments, or suggestions when we try to call up a past experience.
  11. 我们现在的知识会影响我们如何记住我们的过去。我们经常编辑或完全重写我们以前的经历。
  12. Our present knowledge influences how we remember our pasts. We often edit or entirely rewrite our previous experiences.
  13. 我们回忆起我们宁愿从脑海中完全消除的令人不安的事件：记住我们不能忘记的事情，即使我们希望我们可以。
  14. We recall disturbing events that we would prefer to eliminate from our minds altogether: remembering what we cannot forget, even though we wish that we could.

不同的人对同一件事的记忆不同。我们会记住从未发生过的事件，或者将发生的事情归咎于错误的地点、时间或人。研究表明，情感经历的记忆往往与实际发生的事情不同。我们误解了我们所看到的。这就是为什么目击者的说法存在差异。很多案例表明，目击证人的指认证据一直是误判的重要原因。尤其是陌生人目击鉴定的准确性。

Individuals remember the same things differently. We remember events that never happened or assign what happened to the wrong place, time or person. Studies show that memories of emotional experiences are often different from what actually happened. We misinterpret what we saw. That is why there are variations in eyewitness accounts. Many cases show that eyewitness identification evidence has been a significant cause of wrongful convictions. Especially the accuracy of eyewitness identification of strangers.

“我永远不会忘记一张脸。”

"I never forget a face."

澳大利亚心理学家唐纳德·汤姆森 (Donald Thomson) 出现在电视直播辩论中，讨论目击者证词的不可靠性。他后来被警察带走，排成一排，一名受害者认出他就是强奸她的人。但汤姆森有无懈可击的不在场证明。强奸是在他上电视时发生的。后来证明，强奸犯袭击了这名女子，当时她正在观看汤姆森出现的节目。

Australian psychologist Donald Thomson appeared on a live TV debate about the unreliability of eyewitness testimony. He was later picked up by the police, placed in a line-up, and identified by a victim as the man who had raped her. But Thomson has an airtight alibi. The rape had occurred while he was on TV. It later turned out that the rapist had attacked the woman as she was watching the very show on which Thomson had appeared.

研究表明，我们记得一张脸，但错误地记得我们看到它的时间和地点。引导性和暗示性的问题可能会导致错误识别，并受到事后获得的信息的影响。研究表明，很容易让目击者相信他们看到了什么，而实际上他们并没有看到。只是让他们的观察和提问之间经过一些时间。然后向他们提供有关该事件的虚假或情绪化信息。心理学教授伊丽莎白·洛夫特斯 (Elisabeth Loftus) 的研究表明，人们可以被引导去记住相当熟悉和常见的经历，即使这些经历并未发生。例如，她的研究表明，人们可以相信童年经历从未发生过。

Studies show that we remember a face but wrongly remember the time and place we saw it. Leading and suggestive questions can cause misidentification, and influence by information obtained after the event. Studies show that it is easy get a witness to believe they saw something when they didn’t. Merely let some time pass between their observation and the questioning. Then give them false or emotional information about the event. Psychology Professor Elisabeth Loftus’ work has shown that people can be led to remember rather familiar and common experiences, even when they had not happened. For example, her studies show that people can believe that a childhood experience had happened when it never happened.

研究表明，即使后来证明证人的身份不正确，陪审员也会相信证人。目击者可能非常不准确，但看起来很自信。作为证人出庭的人越自信，陪审员就会越相信他们。他们对情况的记忆越详细，陪审员就越信任他们。证词证据生动，因此更可信。

Studies show that jurors believe witnesses even when they are later shown to have made an incorrect identification. Eyewitnesses can be highly inaccurate but appear confident. The more confident people are when they appear as witnesses, the more believable the jurors will find them. The more detailed their memory of a situation is, the more the jurors trust them. Testimonial evidence is vivid and therefore more believable.

儿童证人在法庭上总是值得信任的吗？

Is a child witness always to be trusted in a courtroom?

采访问题儿童的心理学家会错误地灌输他们发生了一件坏事的想法吗？

Can a psychologist who interviews a troubled child falsely implant the idea that a bad event happened to them?

童年的记忆是不可靠的，会受到幻想和暗示的影响。实验表明，正常儿童对建议的反应如何。植入的虚假故事会产生巨大的影响。孩子们实际上可以相信从未发生过的事件或对事件进行错误的叙述。随着时间的推移，他们的故事可能会变得详尽且充满生动的细节，从而使他们更加可信。

Childhood memories are unreliable and influenced by fantasies and suggestions. Experiments have shown how normal children behave in response to suggestions. Implanted false stories can have a huge impact. Children can actually believe an event that never happened or produce false narratives for the event. Over time, their stories may become elaborate and filled with vivid details, making them more believable.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 记录重要事件。

  • Keep records of important events.

23.做某事综合症

23. Do-something Syndrome

我常说，人不快乐的唯一原因是他不知道如何安静地坐在他的房间里。

I have often said that the sole cause of mans unhappiness is that he does not know how to sit quietly in his room.

- 布莱斯帕斯卡

- Blaise Pascal

当约翰问为什么公司在很多收购都变坏的情况下继续进行收购时，首席执行官回答说：“我所有的同事都这样做。如果我不忙的话，我怎么能保住我的工作和所有的津贴呢？”

When John asked why the company continued making acquisitions when so many of them turned sour, the CEO replied:"All my colleagues do deals like this. Plus how can I keep my job and all my perks if I don’t keep busy?"

布莱斯·帕斯卡 (Blaise Pascal) 说：“没有什么比完全休息、没有激情、没有工作、没有消遣、没有努力更令人难以忍受的了。” 我们有时会采取行动，因为我们无法坐以待毙。我们感到无聊、不耐烦、受到威胁或有压力，或者我们只是渴望兴奋和刺激。我们的行为没有合理的理由。解释做某事似乎比主动什么都不做更容易。

Blaise Pascal said:"Man finds nothing so intolerable as to be in a state of complete rest, without passions, without occupation, without diversion, without effort." We sometimes act because we can’t sit still. We feel bored, impatient, threatened or pressured or we simply desire excitement and stimulation. We act without a sensible reason. It seems easier to explain doing something than actively doing nothing.

沃伦巴菲特讲述了为什么 CEO 喜欢收购：

Warren Buffett tells why CEOs like acquisitions:

可悲的事实是，大多数重大收购都显示出严重的不平衡：它们对被收购方的股东来说是一笔财富；它们增加了收购方管理层的收入和地位；他们是双方投资银行家和其他专业人士的蜜罐……首席执行官经常询问战略规划人员、顾问或投资银行家，一两次收购是否有意义。这就像询问您的室内设计师您是否需要 50,000 美元的地毯。

收购问题通常因生物学偏见而变得更加复杂：许多 CEO 获得职位的部分原因是他们拥有丰富的动物精神和自我。如果一位高管非常具有这些品质——应该承认，这些品质有时会带来优势——当他达到最高层时，这些品质就不会消失。当这样一位 CEO 被他的顾问鼓励进行交易时，他的反应就像一个十几岁的男孩被他父亲鼓励过正常的性生活一样。这不是他需要的推动力。

The sad fact is that most major acquisitions display an egregious imbalance: They are a bonanza for the shareholders of the acquiree; they increase the income and status of the acquirer’s management; and they are a honey pot for the investment bankers and other professionals on both sides.. .often the CEO asks a strategic planning staff, consultants or investment bankers whether an acquisition or two might make sense. That’s like asking your interior decorator whether you need a $50,000 rug.

The acquisition problem is often compounded by a biological bias: Many CEO’s attain their positions in part because they possess an abundance of animal spirits and ego. If an executive is heavily endowed with these qualities - which, it should be acknowledged, sometimes have their advantages - they won’t disappear when he reaches the top. When such a CEO is encouraged by his advisors to make deals, he responds much as would a teenage boy who is encouraged by his father to have a normal sex life. It’s not a push he needs.

沃伦巴菲特还提供了保险界的一个例子，说明为什么做正确的事比简单地做某事更重要：

Warren Buffett also provides an example from the insurance world on why it is more important to do what is right than to simply do something:

我们听到很多保险经理谈论愿意减少数量以承保盈利，但我们发现很少有人真正这样做。Phil Liesche [National Indemnity Company 的保险业务经理] 是个例外：如果生意有意义，他就写；如果没有，他会拒绝。我们的政策是不裁员，因为这种自愿的数量变化会导致工作负荷的大幅波动。我们宁愿时不时地在组织中松懈，也不愿让每个人都忙于撰写我们将要赔钱的业务。

We hear a great many insurance managers talk about being willing to reduce volume in order to underwrite profitably, but we find that very few actually do so. Phil Liesche [manager National Indemnity Company’s insurance operation] is an exception: if business makes sense, he writes it; if it doesn’t, he rejects it. It is our policy not to lay off people because of the large fluctuations in work load produced by such voluntary volume changes. We would rather have some slack in the organization from time to time than keep everyone terribly busy writing business on which we are going to lose money.

持续的重组可能是危险的。罗马讽刺作家 Petronius Arbiter 在 1 世纪说：“我们刻苦训练，但似乎每次我们开始组队时，我们都会重新组织起来。我在后来的生活中了解到，我们往往会遇到任何新情况重组，这是一种多么美妙的方法，可以在制造混乱、效率低下和士气低落的同时制造进步的幻觉。”

Continuous reorganization may be dangerous. The Roman satirist Petronius Arbiter said in the 1st Century:"We trained hard, but it seemed that every time we were beginning to form into teams we would be reorganized. I was to learn later in life that we tend to meet any new situation by reorganizing, and what a wonderful method it can be for creating the illusion of progress while producing confusion, inefficiency, and demoralization."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 19世纪美国作家亨利大卫梭罗说：“光是忙碌是不够的，蚂蚁也一样。问题是：我们在忙什么？” 不要将活动与结果混淆。本来就不应该做的事情，没有理由去做好。

  • The 19th Century American writer Henry David Thoreau said:"It is not enough to be busy; so are the ants. The question is: What are we busy about?" Don’t confuse activity with results. There is no reason to do a good job with something you shouldn’t do in the first place.

  • 查尔斯芒格说，“我们有很大的灵活性和一定的纪律，即不要为了活跃而做一些愚蠢的事情——避免仅仅因为你不能忍受不活动而做任何该死的事情。”

  • Charles Munger says,"We’ve got great flexibility and a certain discipline in terms of not doing some foolish thing just to be active — discipline in avoiding just doing any damn thing just because you can’t stand inactivity."

  • 你想要完成什么？正如沃伦巴菲特所说，“如果你走错了路，再跑也没有用。”

  • What do you want to accomplish? As Warren Buffett says,"There’s no use running if you’re on the wrong road."

24. 说某事综合症

24. Say-something Syndrome

智者说话，因为他们有话要说；

傻瓜，因为他们必须说些什么。

Wise men talk because they have something to say;

fools, because they have to say something.

——柏拉图

- Plato

“我是个大人物；人们希望我对各种事情发表评论。”

"I am a big shot; people expect me to comment on all kind of things."

人们往往会说话，即使他们没有任何贡献。马克吐温写道：“如果你无话可说，那就什么也别说。”

People tend to speak even if they have nothing to contribute. Mark Twain wrote:"If you have nothing to say, say nothing."

为什么我们总是需要给出答案？说“我不知道”不是更好吗？希腊哲学家苏格拉底说，对无知的觉察是智慧的开端。

Why do we always need to give an answer? Isn’t it better to say,"I don’t know?" Greek philosopher Socrates said that awareness of ignorance is the beginning of wisdom.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 智慧是一个有两个头的野兽。公元前 1 世纪，罗马剧作家 Publilius Syrus 写道：“我常常后悔自己的言论，而不是我的沉默。”

  • Wisdom is a two-headed beast. Roman dramatist Publilius Syrus wrote in 1st Century BC:"I have often regretted my speech, never my silence."

  • 本杰明·富兰克林说：“想要生活在和平与安逸中的人，一定不要说出他所知道的一切，也不要评判他所看到的一切。”

  • Benjamin Franklin said:"He that would live in peace and at ease, must not speak all he knows, nor judge all he sees."

25 - 情绪

25 - Emotions

人心有其原因，而原因本身一无所知。

The heart has its reasons of which reason itself knows nothing.

- 布莱斯帕斯卡

- Blaise Pascal

“我在激情的热潮中结婚了。对不起爸爸，”约翰的女儿说。

"I got married in the heat of passion. Sorry dad,"Johns daughter said.

弗朗西斯·培根说：“感官的罪恶有两种，要么使我们穷困潦倒，要么欺骗我们。” 情绪先于理性。通常，当我们做出决定时，我们的感觉会占上风。我们首先听到坏消息。在强烈情绪的影响下，我们有时会做出通常不会做出的仓促判断和选择。例如，我们买不起的东西，我们有无保护的性行为，我们暴饮暴食，吸毒。研究还表明，当我们处于更理性平静的状态时，我们会低估我们在经历强烈情绪时的感受和行为。

Francis Bacon said:"The guilt of Senses is of two sorts, either it destitutes us, or else deceives us." Emotions come before reason. Often when we make a decision our feelings take over. We hear bad news first. Under the influence of intense emotions we sometimes make hasty judgements and choices we would normally never do. For example, we buy things we can't afford, we have unprotected sex, we overeat, and use drugs. Studies also show that when we are in a state of more rational calm, we underestimate how we will feel and act when we experience intense emotions.

“我今天过得很糟糕，”玛丽说，“所以我现在要去购物了。”

"I had a really bad day today,"said Mary,"So I’m going shopping now."

一项研究试图找出厌恶和悲伤如何影响经济决策。该研究的所有参与者在进行金融交易之前立即观看了一部电影。有些人看了一部悲伤的电影。其他人是一部恶心的电影，第三组是一部情绪中性的电影。参与者坚称，他们的感受不会影响他们愿意为某物支付的价格或他们愿意接受的价格。研究表明并非如此。厌恶降低了他们的买卖价格。悲伤降低了他们的销售价格，但提高了他们的购买价格。

One study tried to find out how disgust and sadness influenced economic decisions. All participants in the study watched a movie immediately before conducting financial transactions. Some watched a sad movie. Others a disgusting movie and a third group an emotionally neutral movie. Participants insisted that their feelings didn’t affect what they were willing to pay for something or what price they were willing to accept. The study showed otherwise. Disgust reduced their selling and buying prices. Sadness cut their selling prices but raised their buying prices.

我们看到，在损失厌恶和被剥夺的情况下，我们对已经拥有的事物的评价要高于对不拥有的事物的评价。悲伤逆转了这种影响，使我们愿意接受更少的钱来卖我们愿意为同样的东西支付的钱。

We saw under loss aversion and deprival that we put a higher value on things we already own than on the same things if we don’t own them. Sadness reverses this effect, making us willing to accept less money to sell something that we would pay for the same thing.

这意味着，当我们感到悲伤时，这通常反映出无助和失落，我们可能想改变我们的环境，让我们感觉更好。这可能会导致我们为某些东西多付钱或购买我们不需要的东西。这就是玛丽疯狂购物的原因。她需要一些购物疗法。当我们感到厌恶时，我们可能不愿意购买任何新东西，除非我们发现它真的很划算。当我们感到悲伤或厌恶时，我们可能想摆脱我们拥有的东西，并以低于其价值的价格出售它们。

This means, that when we feel sad, which often reflects helplessness and loss, we may want to change our circumstances so we feel better. This may cause us to overpay for something or buy things we don’t need. That is why Mary went on a shopping spree. She needed some retail therapy. When we feel disgust we may be reluctant to buy anything new unless we find it is a real bargain. When we feel sadness or disgust we may want to get rid of things we have and sell them for less than what they are worth.

“不管问题有多大，感觉都不好。”

"It doesn’t matter how large the problem is. It doesn’t feel good."

风险是一种感觉。我们会根据我们对刺激的感受自动判断刺激的好坏。当某件事产生强烈的情绪时，我们会高估其后果而低估其发生的可能性。我们将收获与美好的感受联系在一起。例如，研究表明，无论中奖概率是千万分之一还是万分之一，我们对中彩票的感觉都是一样的。

Risk is a feeling. We automatically judge how good or bad a stimulus is based on how we feel about it. When something produces strong emotions, we over-weigh its consequences and under-weigh its chance of happening. We associate gains with great feelings. For example, studies show that our feelings toward winning the lottery are the same whether the chance of winning is one in 10 million or one in 10,000.

约翰正在购买一辆新跑车。他很兴奋。但是一年后他会有什么感觉呢？

John is buying a new sports car. He is all excited. But how will he feel one year from now?

我们预计，如果未来发生好事或坏事，它们会让我们感觉更好或更糟，时间比实际情况要长得多，也更强烈。所以约翰的新车可能没有约翰预期的那么令人兴奋。它也不会像约翰预期的那样让他兴奋。为什么？因为我们倾向于适应大多数好的和坏的事物和环境并使它们变得平凡（适应并非不可避免 - 个体差异和条件很重要，一些重大生活事件会产生持久或持久的生活满意度变化）。除了特定的未来事件本身，我们的感受还受到许多其他事物和人的影响。此外，我们在考虑未来感受时所做的比较往往不是我们在经历事件时所做的比较。

We expect that if good or bad things happen to us in the future, they will make us feel better or worse much longer and more intensively than they actually turn out to be. So John’s new car will probably be less exciting than John expects. Neither will it excite John as long as he expected. Why? Because we tend to adapt to most good and bad things and circumstances and make them ordinary (adaptation is not inevitable - individual differences and conditions matter and some major life events produce long lasting or enduring changes in life satisfaction). Our feelings are also influenced by so many other things and people than the specific future event itself. Furthermore, the comparisons we make when we think about our future feelings are often not the comparisons we make when we experience the event.

如果我们改用过去的良好经验来决定我们想要什么，会怎么样？我们可以相信我们的记忆来指导我们吗？记忆可能具有欺骗性。我们也低估了我们的品味和偏好将如何改变。罗马诗人提图斯·卢克莱修·卡鲁斯说：“只要我们还没有它，我们渴望的对象就似乎比什么都重要；一旦我们享受它，我们就会以同样的渴望渴望不同的东西。”

What about if we instead use our past good experiences to decide what we want? Can we trust our memories to guide us? Memories can be deceptive. We also underestimate how our tastes and preferences will change. The Roman poet Titus Lucretius Carus said:"As long as we do not have it, the object of our desire seems greater than anything else; as soon as we enjoy it, we long for something different with an equal craving."

我们可以做什么呢？当我们做出重大决定时，我们可以将我们预期的感受与今天有类似经历的人的感受进行比较。从这个意义上说，我们并不像我们认为的那样独特。

What could we do instead? When we make big decisions, we could compare our expected feelings with those of people who have similar experiences today. In that sense, we are not as unique as we think we are.

记住

Keep in mind

  • 了解您的情绪及其对您行为的影响。问：我的行为背后有合理的理由吗？

  • Understand your emotions and their influence on your behaviour. Ask: Is there a rational reason behind my action?

  • 记住谚语：“智者控制自己的脾气。他知道愤怒会导致错误。”

  • Remember the proverb:"A wise man controls his temper. He knows that anger causes mistakes."

  • 当我们刚刚经历过一段情感经历时，我们应该推迟做出重要的决定。

  • When we have just gone through an emotional experience, we should hold off on important decisions.

  • 冷静期的好处迫使我们仔细考虑问题。

  • The benefits of cooling-off periods force us to think things through.

26.压力

26. Stress

你无法改变生活给你的牌，

但你可以决定打牌的方式。

You cant change the cards life has dealt you,

but you can determine the way you’ll play them.

- Ty Boyd

（美国励志演说家）

- Ty Boyd

(American motivational speaker)

太多信息、缺乏可预测性或控制、太多选择、睡眠不足、社会孤立、工作状况、危机、灾难、恐惧等都会造成压力。我们认为自己对生活的控制力越少，我们就越容易成为压力的受害者。我们承受的压力越大，我们就越倾向于做出短期决定。

Too much information, lack of predictability or control, too many choices, lack of sleep, social isolation, job status, crisis, catastrophes, fear, etc. cause stress. The less control we perceive we have over our lives, the easier we fall victim to stress. The more stress we experience, the more we tend to make decisions that are short-term.

我们的大脑解释为威胁的一切都会影响我们的生物学。我们的祖先承受的压力并不比我们少。但他们的压力是不同的。他们遇到了需要快速身体反应的危险。我们的压力本质上更多是社会和心理上的。

Everything our brain interprets as a threat influences our biology. Our ancestors didn’t suffer less stress than we did. But their stress was different. They met dangers that demanded fast physical reactions. Our stress is more social and psychological in nature.

对失去工作和社会地位的恐惧使玛丽经常感到头疼。

The fear of losing both her job and social position caused Mary to suffer constant headaches.

压力会影响注意力和记忆力。长期承受压力会扰乱大脑的化学平衡。压力可能导致高血压、心脏病、糖尿病、背部和胃部问题、头痛和抑郁。研究表明，当我们感到压力时，血液中皮质醇的浓度会升高。皮质醇的作用之一是抑制我们免疫系统的运作。这使我们更容易感染疾病。压力还会抑制胰岛素（处理血糖的激素）的产生，导致修复过程减慢。研究表明，情绪压力会使我们的身体恢复时间更长，并且可能比非情绪压力事件（如体育锻炼）对我们的健康危害更大。

Stress affects concentration and memory. Long-term stress exposure upsets the brains chemical balance. Stress may cause high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, back and stomach problems, headache, and depression. Studies show that when we feel stress the concentration of cortisol rises in the bloodstream. One effect of cortisol is to suppress the workings of our immune system. This makes us more vulnerable to diseases. Stress also counteracts the production of insulin (the hormone that processes blood sugar), causing the process of repair to slow down. Studies show that emotional stress creates longer recovery times in our bodies and may be more harmful to our health than non-emotional stress events like physical exercise.

当人们暴露于身心疲惫、困惑、身体疼痛、情绪紧张或恐惧时会发生什么？

What happens when people are exposed to physical and mental exhaustion, confusion, physical pain, emotional tension or fear?

压力增加了我们的暗示性。伊万·巴甫洛夫 (Ivan Pavlov) 表明，可以通过让动物承受压力来建立或消除动物行为。例如，他可以让一只狗对它曾经非常忠诚的看守人做出攻击性反应。人们也会发生同样的事情。所有人对压力都有一定程度的耐受力。一旦通过，人们开始崩溃，他们以前相信和喜欢的东西很容易改变。这可能发生在战俘身上。它也被用来进行宗教和政治皈依，并被警察用来逼供。

Stress increases our suggestibility. Ivan Pavlov showed that animal behaviour could be established or erased by exposing the animal to stress. For example, he could make a dog react aggressively to a caretaker with whom the dog was once very loyal. The same can happen to people. All people have a certain level of tolerance to stress. Once it is passed, people begin to break down and what they earlier believed and liked are easily changed. This can happen to prisoners of war. It has also been used to make religious and political conversions, and by police forces to elicit confessions.

“我已经失去了对局势的控制。”

"I have lost control over the situation."

我们越相信自己在掌控之中，就越不容易受到压力的负面影响。研究表明，那些认为自己能够控制压力情况的人，他们的心脏和循环系统所承受的压力较小。

The more we believe we are in control, the less vulnerable we are to the negative effects of stress. Studies show that people who perceive themselves to be in control over a stressful situation experience less stress on their hearts and circulatory system.

我们的工作状况很重要。涉及 17,000 名公务员的 Whitehall II 研究表明，对工作环境的控制力低的人或组织结构中低层的人患心血管疾病的风险增加。我们的皮质醇水平会根据其他人对我们的要求程度而上升。随着我们攀登社会等级，健康状况得到改善。在基因组学中，科普作家马特·里德利 (Matt Ridley) 博士评论白厅的研究：“从事低级工作的人，例如看门人，心脏病发作的可能性几乎是高层常任秘书的四倍”

The status of our job matters. The Whitehall II study involving 17,000 civil servants showed that people with low perceived control over the work environment or people low in the organizational structure have an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. Our cortisol levels rise in response to the degree other people order us about. As we climb the social hierarchy health status improves. In Genome, science writer Dr. Matt Ridley comments on the Whitehall study:"Somebody in a low-grade job, such as a janitor, was nearly four times as likely to have a heart attack as a permanent secretary at the top of the heap."

在另一项研究中，研究人员试图找出因承受高压力而生病的企业高管与未因高压而生病的企业高管之间的区别。他们发现，保持健康的高管对工作和家庭有责任感，有控制感，并对挑战持积极态度。他们将挑战视为生活的一部分和成长的机会，而不是威胁。

In another study researchers tried to find out the differences between business executives who became sick from exposure to high stress and those who didn’t. They found that executives who stayed healthy had a sense of commitment to work and families, felt in control, and had a positive attitude toward challenges. They saw challenges as part of life and an opportunity for growth rather than as a threat.

沃伦巴菲特说，“我没有任何压力——零。我每天都可以做我喜欢做的事。我周围都是很棒的人。” 他继续说道，“我经营的所有企业都不会占用我 5% 的时间。我们没有定期召开员工会议之类的。如果你有好的企业和合适的经理，你就不需要那种的事情——如果你不这样做，他们就没有帮助。”

Warren Buffett says,"I have no stress whatsoever — zero. I get to do what I love to do every day. I’m surrounded by people that are terrific." He continues,"All the businesses I run don’t take 5% of my time. We don’t have regular staff meetings and the like. If you’ve got good businesses and the right managers, you don’t need that sort of thing — and if you don’t, they don’t help."

记住

Keep in mind

  • 压力本身并无好坏之分。这取决于情况和我们的解释。压力可以通过我们的态度来控制。奥地利医生汉斯·塞利博士在《没有痛苦的压力》一书中说，伤害我们的不是压力，而是痛苦。我们需要挑战。他继续说道，“没有压力，就没有生命……完全摆脱压力就是死亡。”

  • Stress is neither good nor bad in itself. It depends on the situation and our interpretation. Stress can be controlled by our attitudes. The Austrian physician Dr. Hans Selye says in Stress without Distress that it is not stress that harms us but distress. We need challenges. He continues,"Without stress, there would no life.. .Complete freedom from stress is death."

  • 公元一世纪的哲学家埃比克泰德说：“幸福和自由始于对一个原则的清晰认识：有些事情在我们的控制范围内，有些事情则不然。只有当你正视这个基本规则并学会区分之后在你能控制和不能控制的事情之间，内在的平静和外在的有效性成为可能。”

  • The 1st Century philosopher Epictetus said:"Happiness and freedom begin with a clear understanding of one principle: Some things are within our control, and some things are not. It is only after you have faced up to this fundamental rule and learned to distinguish between what you can and can’t control that inner tranquility and outer effectiveness become possible."

  • 如果能解决问题，就不用担心了。要做的就是纠正它。如果情况无法解决，我们也不应该担心。我们对此无能为力。马克吐温说：“我一生中遭受了很多灾难。其中大部分从未发生过。” 有时让自己忙于其他事情可能会让我们停止担心。

  • If a problem can be solved, there is no need to worry. The thing to do is to correct it. If a situation can’t be solved, we shouldn’t worry about that either. We can’t do anything about it. Mark Twain says:"I’ve suffered a great many catastrophes in my life. Most of them never happened." Sometimes keeping ourselves busy with something else may cause us to stop worrying.

27. 疼痛、化学品和疾病

27. Pain, Chemicals and Diseases

痛苦会扰乱并摧毁感受它的人的本性。

Pain upsets and destroys the nature of the person who feels it.

- 亚里士多德

- Aristotle

“我无法清晰地思考，因为我喝醉了。我不在乎如果我采取暴力行为的后果。”

"I can’t think clearly because lam. drunk. I don’t care about the consequences if I act violent."

当我们感到疼痛、受到化学品的影响或患有身体或精神疾病时，我们会感到困惑。身体和精神上的痛苦可能会导致恐惧、愤怒和压力。化学变化会加剧疼痛并导致抑郁。

We become confused when we are in pain, under the influence of chemicals or have a physical or mental illness. Physical and mental pain may cause fear, anger and stress. Chemical changes magnify the pain and can cause depression.

药物、兴奋剂（如尼古丁、酒精或咖啡）和镇静剂会扭曲我们的感官。

Drugs, stimulants (like nicotine, alcohol or coffee), and depressants distort our senses.

28. 多重倾向

28. Multiple Tendencies

当你让两个或三个这些心理学原理一起运作时，你就会真正地获得巨大的非理性。

When you get two or three of these psychological principles operating together, then you really get irrationality on a tremendous scale.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 就偷窃问题举了一个很有启发性的例子：

Charles Munger gives an illuminating example on the issue of stealing:

如果 (A) 偷窃非常容易，并且 (B) 几乎没有被抓到的机会，那么世界上有很大一部分人会偷窃。一旦他们开始偷窃，一致性原则很快就会与操作性条件反射相结合，使偷窃成为习惯。所以，如果你经营一家企业，因为你的方法很容易偷窃，那么你正在对为你工作的人造成极大的道德伤害......

创建难以欺骗的人类系统非常非常重要。否则你就是在毁掉你的文明，因为这些巨大的激励会产生激励引起的偏见，人们会合理化认为不良行为是可以的。

然后，如果其他人这样做，那么现在您至少掌握了两个心理学原理：激励引起的偏见和社会认同。不仅如此，你还会得到 Serpico 效应：如果有足够多的人在做错事的普遍社会氛围中获利，那么如果你试图揭发他们，他们就会攻击你并成为危险的敌人。

A very significant fraction of the people in the world will steal if (A) it’s very easy to do and, (B) there’s practically no chance of being caught. And once they start stealing, the consistency principle will soon combine with operant conditioning to make stealing habitual. So if you run a business where it’s easy to steal because of your methods, you’re working a great moral injury on the people who work for you...

It’s very, very important to create human systems that are hard to cheat. Otherwise you’re ruining your civilization because these big incentives will create incentive-caused bias and people will rationalize that bad behaviour is OK.

Then, if somebody else does it, now you’ve got at least two psychological principles: incentive-caused bias plus social proof. Not only that, but you get Serpico effects: If enough people are profiting in a general social climate of doing wrong, then they’ll turn on you and become dangerous enemies if you try and blow the whistle.

弗兰克·塞尔皮科 (Frank Serpico) 因在 1970 年代揭露纽约警察局的腐败行为而出名。当 Frank Serpico 于 1960 年进入纽约警察部队时，贿赂和回扣在该部门十分猖獗。

Frank Serpico became known after exposing corruption at the New York Police Department in the 1970s. When Frank Serpico entered the New York Police force in 1960, pay-offs and kickbacks were rampant in the department.

当他拒绝收钱时，他的同事们将他视为潜在的危险。然后他吹响了他们的哨子，成为了他们的敌人。在 1971 年纳普委员会的证词中，塞尔皮科说：“我希望未来的警察不会因为我试图举报腐败......我们营造了一种氛围，让诚实的官员害怕不诚实的官员，而不是相反。”

When he refused to take money, his fellow officers saw him as a potential danger. Then he blew the whistle on them, and became their enemy. In a 1971 testimony before the Knapp commission, Serpico said:"I hope that police officers in the future will not experience the same frustration and anxiety that I was subjected to for the past five years at the hands of my superiors because of my attempt to report corruption...We create an atmosphere in which the honest officer fears the dishonest officer, and not the other way around."

John 的收购经历给他带来了压力，并让 TransCorp 付出了金钱。

John’s acquisition experience caused him stress and cost TransCorp money.

约翰说，“我对去年为 TransCorp 做的太少感到不满。所有其他人都进行了收购。如果我能找到一个好的收购，也许我可以晋升。我需要晋升。

John said,"I was dissatisfied having done so little for TransCorp last year. All of the other guys made acquisitions. If I could find a good acquisition, maybe I could move up the ranks. I needed a promotion.

我找到了一家看起来不错的公司，并看到了让 TransCorp 赚大钱的可能性。该公司的首席执行官是一个好人，我们总是在他们轻松的会议室见面。与过去的利润相比，要价较低。我有专家告诉我这是一家多么伟大的公司。我收到了有关新产品的有趣信息。这位投资银行家促成这笔交易帮了我一个忙，我想报答。

I found a good-looking business, and saw the possibility of making TransCorp a lot of money. The CEO of the business was a nice guy and we always met in their relaxing conference room. The asking price was low in relation to past profits. I had experts telling me what a great company it was. I was presented entertaining information on new products. The investment banker did me a favour by bringing the deal and I wanted to reciprocate.

银行家告诉我，我敬佩的其他人会抓住这个机会。我向金融家做出了承诺，并将这笔交易告诉了 TransCorp 的首席执行官。我公开承诺并感到有必要跟进。我将搜索集中在证实这笔交易伟大的证据上。我否认现实，认为不会发生任何不好的事情。我没有说出我的想法，因为害怕社会不赞成。我一直想收购的公司的首席执行官给了我进行交易的充分理由。我为这笔交易付出的努力越多，我就越觉得我必须这样做。我终于在文件上签了名。当现实开始，交易变坏时，我陷入了大麻烦。TransCorp 也是如此。”

The banker told me that other people I admire would jump at the opportunity. I made a commitment to the financiers and told TransCorp’s CEO about the deal. I committed myself publicly and felt a need to follow-through. I concentrated my search on evidence that confirmed the greatness of the deal. I denied reality and thought nothing bad could happen. I didn’t say what I thought for fear of social disapproval. The CEO of the company I wanted to acquire continuously gave me good reasons to pursue the deal. The more effort I put into the deal, the more I felt I had to do it. I finally signed the papers. When reality kicked in and the deal turned sour, I was in deep trouble. And so was TransCorp."

“我不想与首席执行官作对，并冒着失去 25 万美元董事费的风险。”

"I don't want to go against the CEO and risk losing my $250,000 directors fee."

董事会是应对 CEO 平庸的有效纠正器吗？Charles Munger 说：“董事会制度的心理特性使其成为让人们服从 CEO 领导的理想制度。”

Is the board of directors an effective corrector to deal with CEO mediocrity? Charles Munger says:"The psychological nature of the board of directors system makes it an ideal system for causing people to follow the lead of the CEO."

董事会可能是一种合法的创造，但它是一种社会动物。沃伦巴菲特说：

A board may be a legal creation, but it is a social animal. Warren Buffett says:

当人们每隔几个月碰面一次，来自全国不同地区时——他们有正常的社交本能——他们不喜欢召开屁股会议或在别人背后议论纷纷。所以这在一个团队中是非常困难的——特别是如果是像查理这样的团队，其中很多人的董事费用对他们的福祉很重要，他们很乐意被推荐到另一个董事会并增加另一美元他们每年的收入增加 100,000 美元——有人突然在例行会议上带头，或者试图安排某种形式的臀部会议说，“我们认为坐在桌子首位的人不好。 “

因此，如果你是董事会成员，处理平庸——或者，就像我说的，比平庸高出一个档次——是一个难题……

我上过 19 个董事会。在 19 家公司中，董事的费用对他们很重要，我从未见过任何董事反对收购提议或 CEO 的薪酬。

When people meet every couple of months and come from different parts of the country — and they have the normal social instincts - they don’t like to have rump meetings or sort of talk behind people’s backs. So it’s very difficult in a group - particularly if it’s a group like Charlie described where the directors’ fees for a significant number of them are important to their well-being, and they’d love to be recommended for another board and add another $ 100,000 a year to their income - for someone to lead a charge all of a sudden at a regular meeting or to try to arrange a rump meeting of some sort to say,"We think the guy at the head of the table is no good."

So dealing with mediocrity - or, like I say, a notch above it - is a difficult problem if you’re a board member...

I’ve been on 19 boards. And I’ve never seen a director on any of the 19, where the director’s fees were important to them, object to an acquisition proposal or a CEO’s compensation.

TransCorp 的首席执行官告诉他的董事会：“这是决定，现在让我们开始讨论。”

The CEO of TransCorp tells his board:"This is the decision, now let’s start the discussion."

除了激励引起的偏见、喜好和社会认可之外，还有哪些其他趋势在这里运作？权威——首席执行官是董事倾向于信任和服从的权威人物。他也可能让那些质疑他的人感到为难。社会证明——首席执行官在做蠢事，但没有人反对，所以所有董事集体保持沉默——沉默等于同意；群体无懈可击的幻想和群体压力（忠诚度）也可能有所贡献。互惠——不受欢迎的信息被隐瞒，因为首席执行官提高了董事的费用，给他们津贴，带他们旅行或让他们使用公务机。协会和波斯信使综合症——一个导演不想成为坏消息的载体。自利倾向和乐观——自信和乐观的感觉：许多董事会还会选择与他们非常相似的新董事；具有相似的意识形态观点。剥夺——董事不想失去收入和地位。尊重理由，无论多么不合逻辑——CEO 都会给他们理由。先相信后怀疑——相信 CEO 所说的话，即使不是真的，尤其是在分心的时候。一致性——董事们希望与之前的决定保持一致——无论愚蠢与否。

Apart from incentive-caused bias, liking and social approval, what are some other tendencies that operate here? Authority — the CEO is the authority figure who directors tend to trust and obey. He may also make it difficult for those who question him. Social proof - the CEO is doing dumb things but no one else is objecting so all directors collectively stay quiet — silence equals consent; illusions of the group as invulnerable and group pressure (loyalty) may also contribute. Reciprocation - unwelcoming information is withheld since the CEO is raising the directors fees, giving them perks, taking them on trips or letting them use the corporate jet. Association and Persian Messenger Syndrome - a single director doesn’t want to be the carrier of bad news. Self-serving tendencies and optimism - feelings of confidence and optimism: many boards also select new directors who are much like themselves; that share similar ideological viewpoints. Deprival - Directors don’t want to lose income and status. Respecting reasons no matter how illogical - the CEO gives them reasons. Believing first and doubting later - believing what the CEO says even if not true, especially when distracted. Consistency—directors want to be consistent with earlier decisions — dumb or not.

我们能摆脱坏 CEO 吗？沃伦巴菲特和查尔斯芒格说：

Can we get rid of a bad CEO? Warren Buffett and Charles Munger says:

巴菲特：当某些由知名人士组成的董事会因媒体关注而公开尴尬时，我认为这对其他一些董事会来说是一种预警信号，因为大人物——他们经常在装扮董事会方面寻找大人物——不喜欢看起来很愚蠢，至少在公开场合...

芒格：……就董事对首席执行官的反抗而言，它往往会在一两种情况下发生：一种是他们减少董事的津贴——大多数首席执行官都很明智，不会这样做。另一种情况是情况变得如此糟糕，以至于有可能让董事蒙羞。但是你很少看到人们在受到耻辱威胁之前采取行动。

Buffett: When certain boards consisting of prominent people are embarrassed publicly by the media attention, I think that acts as kind of an early warning signal to some other boards because big shots - and they look for big shots frequently in terms of dressing up boards - do not like to look foolish, at least publicly...

Munger: ...in terms of the director’s actually rebelling against the CEO, it tends to happen in one or two cases: One is when they reduce the directors’ perks - which most CEOs are wise enough not to do. The other is when the situation gets so bad that it threatens to disgrace the directors. But you rarely see people taking action before they’re threatened with disgrace.

沃伦巴菲特说，我们需要真正独立于董事，即：“当出现问题或愚蠢时，愿意挑战强势的首席执行官。” 他继续说道：“除了独立之外，董事还应具备商业头脑、股东导向和对公司的真正兴趣。”

Warren Buffett says that we need true independence from directors i.e. a:"willingness to challenge a forceful CEO when something is wrong or foolish." He continues:"In addition to being independent, directors should have business-savvy, a shareholder orientation and a genuine interest in the company."

查尔斯·芒格补充道：

Charles Munger adds:

正确的系统是 Elihu 根系统。Elihu Root，如果我没记错的话，曾担任过三个不同的内阁任命，他说没有人不适合担任公职，除非他在任何时候都非常愿意离开。如果 Elihu Root 不赞成政府要求他做的事情，他随时可以回去成为世界上最受欢迎的律师。他有一个身份可以回去——所以他不需要政府的薪水。

好吧，我认为这也应该是对公司董事职位的更多考验。一个不愿意随时离开办公室的董事真的适合做艰难的决定吗？我的回答是否定的。

The correct system is the Elihu Root System. Elihu Root, who had three different cabinet appointments, if I remember right, said no man was fit to hold public office who wasn’t perfectly willing to leave it at any time. And if Elihu Root didn’t approve of something the government asked him to do, he could always go back and be the most sought-after lawyer in the world. He had an identity to go back to - so he didn’t need the government’s salary.

Well, I think that also ought to be more the test in corporate directorships. Is a director really fit to make tough calls who isn’t perfectly willing to leave the office at any time? My answer is no.

语境影响

Contextual Influences

大多数社会行为都必须在其环境中得到理解，如果孤立则失去意义。在思考社会事实时，没有比看不到它们的位置和功能更严重的错误了。

Most social acts have to be understood in their setting, and lose meaning if isolated. No error in thinking about social facts is more serious than the failure to see their place and function.

——所罗门·阿施

（美国社会心理学家，1907-1996）

- Solomon Asch

(American social psychologist, 1907-1996)

我们的行为受到社会情境因素、条件和环境、问题或选择的结构或描述以及我们的愿望、情绪和期望的影响。

Our behaviour is influenced by social situational factors, conditions and circumstances, the structure or description of a problem or choice, and our desires, mood and expectations.

当我们解释他人的行为时，我们往往会高估个人特征和动机。我们低估了社会压力、角色或无法控制的事情等情境因素。一个例子是，将失败归咎于个人而不是设计不当的系统。机会也很重要。也许我们有时会把太多的责任归咎于运气不好的人，而把太多的功劳归功于那些幸运的人。

We tend to overestimate personal characteristics and motives when we explain the behaviour of others. We underestimate situational factors like social pressure, roles or things over which there are no control. An example is, blaming an individual rather than a poorly designed system for failure. Chance also matters. Maybe we sometimes give too much blame to people who had bad luck, and too much credit to those who were simply lucky.

我们希望人们的行为始终如一。但是我们在不同的情况下表现不同。例如，我们在家里、学校、工作和朋友之间的行为不同；独自一人和一群人时；当看到和匿名时。

We expect people to be consistent in their behaviour. But we behave differently in different situations. For example, we behave differently at home, in school, at work, and among friends; when alone and when in a group; when seen and when anonymous.

“我不应该这么快就把他定性为坏人。谁知道，如果放在同样的情况下，我可能也会做出同样的事情。”

"I shouldn’t have been so fast judging him as a bad person. Who knows, I may have done the same if put in the same situation."

极端的环境和条件会导致人们做出在正常情况下绝不会做的事情。把好人置于糟糕的境地，他们的正常行为就会改变。斯坦福大学的津巴多监狱实验研究了人们在监狱环境中扮演的角色。在为期两周的时间里，学生们被随机分配到囚犯和看守的角色。测试表明，所有学生都是正常人，身心健康。他们创建了一个模拟监狱环境来模仿现实生活中的监狱条件，他们在那里住了几天。扮演警卫的学生表现出攻击性，扮演囚犯的学生表现得无助。看守们很快开始像对待非人类一样对待囚犯。囚犯们开始表现得很沮丧，并表现出极度的压力。犯人越是表现得像非人类，看守越虐待他们。实验在六天后结束。

Extreme circumstance and conditions can cause people to do things they would never do under normal circumstances. Put good people in a bad situation and their normal behaviour changes. The Zimbardo prison experiment at Stanford studied the roles people play in prison situations. Students were randomly assigned to the roles of prisoners and guards for a two-week period. Tests showed that all students were normal people and physically and mentally healthy. A simulated prison environment was created to mimic real-life prison conditions, where they lived for several days. Students playing guards behaved aggressively and students playing prisoners behaved helplessly. Guards rapidly began to treat the prisoners as if they were non-humans. The prisoners began acting depressed and showed extreme stress. The more the prisoners acted like non-humans, the more the guards mistreated them. The experiment ended after six days.

在为美国众议院司法委员会准备的一份声明中，该实验的发起人菲利普津巴多说：“我们感到震惊，因为我们看到一些男孩对待其他男孩就像对待卑鄙的动物一样，以残忍为乐，而其他男孩则变成了奴性的、非人化的机器人，他们只想着逃跑、他们自己的生存，以及他们对守卫日益增长的仇恨。”

In a statement prepared for the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on the Judiciary, the originator of the experiment, Philip Zimbardo, said:"We were horrified because we saw some boys treat other boys as if they were despicable animals, taking pleasure in cruelty, while other boys became servile, dehumanized robots who thought only of escape, of their own individual survival, and of their mounting hatred of the guards."

通常当我们处于一个角色中时，我们往往会按照别人的期望行事。津巴多说：“即使他们认为自己不必满足任何人的期望，狱警的角色也决定了他们的行为。”

Often when we are in a role, we tend to act as others expect. Zimbardo said:"Even when they thought they didn’t have to meet anyone’s expectations, the role of prison guard determined their actions."

美国印第安人有句谚语：“穿着鹿皮鞋走了两个月之前，不要评判一个人。” 如果我们是匿名的，是一个群体的一部分，疲惫不堪，而其他人被贴上敌人、邪恶或毫无价值的标签，我们会如何表现？

An American Indian proverb says:"Don’t judge a man until you’ve walked two moons in his moccasins." How would we behave if we were anonymous, part of a group, tired and exhausted, and others had been labelled as enemies, evil or worthless?

“当人们观看他的高尔夫挥杆动作时，为什么约翰会紧张？”

"Why is John tense when people watch his golf swing?"

我们的行为是否被观察到？人们可能仅仅因为被观察而改变他们的行为。

Are our actions observed or not? People may change their behaviour merely because they are being observed.

“没有人能看到我。”

"No one can see me."

匿名会产生破坏性行为。研究表明，当和平的学生通过掩盖他们的身份而感到匿名时，他们会变得好斗。

Anonymity can create destructive behaviour. Studies show that peaceful students can become aggressive when they are made to feel anonymous by having their identity masked.

我们对一个问题的了解越少，我们就越受其框架的影响。

The less knowledgeable we are about an issue, the more influenced we are by how it is framed.

我们得到的答案取决于我们提出的问题。英国哲学家赫伯特·斯宾塞说：“被误用的词语常常会产生误导性的想法。” 考虑陈述、问题、结果或疑问是如何呈现的。它是如何措辞的？它的背景是什么？我们是否考虑了某些特征而忽略了其他特征？情绪化的、选择性的和吸引人的框架影响着我们。

The answers we get depend on the questions we ask. The British philosopher Herbert Spencer said:"How often misused words generate misleading thoughts." Consider how a statement, problem, consequence, or question is presented. How is it worded? What is its context? Are we considering certain features and ignoring others? Emotional, selective and appealing frames influence us.

选择的呈现方式会影响我们的偏好。例如，我们更喜欢标示为“95% 不含脂肪”而不是“5% 脂肪”的产品。我们会根据某件事是以收益还是以损失的形式呈现而做出不同的反应。成功几率为 40% 的外科手术似乎比失败几率为 60% 的手术更具吸引力。

How a choice is presented influences our preferences. For example, we prefer a product that is presented as"95% fat free" rather than"5% fat". We respond differently depending on whether something is presented in terms of gains or in terms of losses. A surgical procedure that has a 40% chance of success seems more appealing than one that has a 60% chance of failure.

频率吸引我们的情绪。精神病人在出院后 6 个月内实施暴力行为的几率有多大？研究表明，当暴力风险以相对频率呈现时（例如，估计 100 名与患者相似的罪犯中有 20 名罪犯对他人施暴……），经验丰富的心理学家和精神病学家判断患者的危险性高于当存在暴力风险时以概率形式呈现（例如，据估计，相似的患者有 20% 的机会对他人施暴……）。一项研究表明，一种导致 10,000 人中有 1,286 人死亡的疾病 (12.86%) 被评为比导致 100 人中有 24.14 人死亡 (24.14%) 的疾病风险更高。

Frequencies appeal to our emotions. What is the chance that a mental patient commits an act of violence within 6 months after discharge? Studies show that experienced psychologists and psychiatrists judge the patient as more dangerous when the risk of violence were presented as relative frequencies (e.g., 20 criminals out of 100 similar to the patient are estimated to be violent to others...) than when the risk was presented as a probability (e.g., it is estimated that similar patients has a 20% chance of being violent to others ...). One study showed that a disease that kills 1,286 of 10,000 people (12.86%) was rated as riskier than one that kills 24.14 of 100 people (24.14%).

我们受到演示发生的顺序的影响，首先或最后。关键变量是将演示文稿分开的时间量，我们必须做出判断的时间，以及最容易记住的演示文稿。

We are influenced by the order, first or last, in which a presentation happens. The key variable is the amount of time that separates the presentations, the time when we have to make a judgement, and which presentation is the most easily remembered.

假设两位总统候选人正在就一个问题发表讲话，一个紧接着另一个。如果在我们必须做出判断之前过了一段时间，我们可能会更多地受到第一次展示的影响。现在假设第一次和最后一次呈现之间有一段时间过去，但我们必须在最后一次呈现之后立即做出判断。那么我们就更有可能受到上次介绍的影响。

Assume that two presidential candidates are speaking on an issue, one directly after the other. If some time passes before we have to make a judgement, we are likely to be more influenced by the first presentation. Assume now that some time passes between the first and last presentations, but we have to make a judgement immediately after the last presentation. Then we are more likely to be influenced by the last presentation.

“我把薪水以 4% 的利息存入银行，并以 10% 的利息借钱买车。”

"I put my paycheck in the bank at 4% interest, and borrowed money for a car loan at 10% interest."

我们通过进行心理账户来创建自己的框架。我们根据资产的来源或重要性对相同价值的资产进行不同的处理。我们对同一块钱赋予不同的价值，比起挣来的钱，我们更愿意拿赢来的钱去冒险。从玩轮盘赌中获得的 1,000 美元的价值低于通过努力工作获得的 1,000 美元的价值。“我没有用我的1000美元去赌博，我只是在赌场用10001美元去赌博。” 但这是同样多的钱。

We create our own frames by doing mental accounting. We treat assets of the same value differently depending on where they come from or their importance. We put different values on the same dollar, and are more willing to risk money we have won than money we have earned. A gain of $ 1,000 from playing roulette has less value than $ 1,000 earned from hard work."I didn’t gamble with my $1,000, I only gambled with the $1,0001 won on the casino." But it is the same amount of money.

在一项实验中，心理学家发现，在去剧院的路上丢了一张 10 美元剧院票的人不愿意再买第二张票。而那些在购买 10 美元剧院门票的途中丢失了 10 美元钞票的人认为钱的丢失与购买门票无关，因此他们会购买门票。但是，在这两种情况下，损失是相同的。

In one experiment psychologists found that people who lost a $10 theatre ticket on the way to the theatre were reluctant to buy a second ticket. Those who instead lost a $10 bill on the way to buy a $10 theatre ticket saw the loss of the money and the purchase of the ticket as unrelated, so they would buy the ticket. But, in both cases, the loss was the same.

我们应该从整体的角度来看待我们的资产。一美元是一美元，与它来自哪里无关。重要的是我们从口袋里掏出什么。

We should view our assets in terms of their entirety. A dollar is a dollar independent of where it comes from. What counts is what we put in or take out of our pocket.

无论我们是与认识的人、陌生人还是在实验者的注视下打交道，行为都会有所不同。

There is a difference in behaviour whether we deal with someone we know and a stranger or under the eye of an experimenter.

“我希望你明白我在说什么。我知道你能做到。”

"I expect you to understand what I’m saying. 1 know you can do this."

“事情并不总是他们看起来的那样，”1 世纪的罗马哲学家 Phaedrus 说。我们的行为会受到他人期望的影响——老师、教练、老板等。例如，为了取悦观察者，研究对象可能会阅读期望的结果。患者可能希望以他们认为正确的方式对治疗做出反应。我们不辜负对我们的期望。

"Things are not always what they seem," said the 1 st Century Roman philosopher Phaedrus. Our behaviour can be influenced by the expectations of others — teachers, coaches, bosses, etc. For example, to please the observer, a research subject may read in a desired result. A patient may wish to respond to a treatment in what they see as the correct way. We live up to what is expected of us.

研究表明，与护士相比，接受医生检查的患者心跳更快、血压更高。

Studies show that patients can have faster heartbeats and higher blood pressure when examined by a doctor compared to a nurse.

我们经常看到我们想要或期望看到的东西。医生可能会在患者身上看到效果，因为他希望看到它。我们经常看不到我们不希望看到的东西。

We often see what we want or expect to see. A doctor may see an effect in a patient because he expects to see it. We often don’t see what we don’t expect to see.

我们是否按照我们的期望对待他人？

Do we treat people according to our expectations?

假设玛丽正在去见某人的路上，这是她第一次见某人。如果这个人被描述为友善或情绪冷漠，这有关系吗？是的，它会改变玛丽对那个人的期望并改变她的行为。玛丽会期待友善或敌意，并按照她的期望行事。这个人可能会以证实她的期望的方式对玛丽做出反应。我们像我们期望的那样对待人们。如果我们期望人们不好，我们就会以某种方式对待他们，这可能会导致他们表现不好。

Assume Mary is on her way to meet someone for the first time. Does it matter if this person has been described as friendly or emotionally cold? Yes, it produces a change in Mary’s expectations of that individual and a change in her behaviour. Mary will expect friendliness or hostility and behave according to her expectations. The person may react to Mary in a way that confirms her expectations. We treat people like we expect them to be. If we expect people to be bad, we treat them in a certain way, which may cause them to behave badly.

假设一位新老师被告知班上一半的人智商高，一半人智商低。老师被告知所谓的聪明孩子和不那么聪明的孩子的名字。实际上，有人随机选择了这两组。到年底，实验前提将成为一个自我实现的预言。老师认为智商高的孩子会比智商低的孩子做得更好。这在小学生的研究中得到了证实。当教师对学生有很高的期望时，他们的教学就会好得多。

Assume that a new teacher is told that half of the class has high IQs and half has low IQs. The teacher is given the names of the supposed intelligent kids and the supposed not so intelligent ones. In reality, someone has randomly selected the two groups. By the end of the year, the experimental premise will become a self-fulfilling prophecy. The kids the teacher thought had high IQs will be doing better than the kids with supposedly low IQs. This has been demonstrated in studies of elementary school students. Teachers taught much better when they expected a lot from their students.

一种情况下的非理性行为可能会在另一种情况下产生良好的结果。

Irrational behaviour in one context may cause good results in another.

我们并不傻——判断通常是上下文的函数。他人的判断可以提供信息，服从权威对秩序很重要，小心卷入危险情况可能会挽救我们的生命。

We aren’t stupid - judgements are often a function of context. The judgements of others can be informative, obedience to an authority is important for order, being careful in getting involved in a dangerous situation may save our life.

实验室实验的所有证据呢？

What about all the evidence from lab experiments?

实验室实验不能与现实相似。

Lab experiments cant resemble reality.

现实生活与实验室的受控且有些人为的环境之间存在差异。在某些实验室实验中发生的事情在自然情况下可能不会发生。例如，许多实验通常是匿名进行的，没有重复。问题的结构是什么？环境？假设？重要性？犯错的代价？通常存在不止一个正确答案。任务的上下文很重要。在更现实、更具体、更社会化的情境中，很多任务往往都能得到正确解决。

There is a difference between real life and the controlled and somewhat artificial context of the lab. What is happening in some lab experiments may not happen in a natural situation. For example, many experiments are often played anonymously without repetition. What is the structure of the problem? The environment? Assumptions? Importance? Cost of being wrong? Often there exists more than one right answer. The context of the task matters. In a more realistic, concrete, and social context, many tasks are often solved correctly.

研究表明我们过于自信。这是否意味着我们总是过于自信？不，研究仅表明有些人在特定情况下对某些任务过于自信。

Studies show that we are overconfident. Does this mean we are always overconfident? No, the studies only show that some people are overconfident in some tasks in a certain context.

查尔斯·芒格的一些最后建议

Some Final Advice From Charles Munger

遵循 Charles Munger 的以下三点建议：

Follow these three pieces of advice from Charles Munger:

  1. 我不希望你认为我们有任何学习或行为方式，所以你不会犯很多错误。我只是说你可以学会比其他人少犯错误——以及当你犯错误时 如何更快地改正错误。但是，如果不[犯]很多错误，你就不可能过上充实的生活。事实上，生活中的一个诀窍就是学会处理错误。无法处理心理上的否认是人们破产的常见方式：你对某事做出了巨大的承诺。你已经投入了精力和金钱。你投入的越多，整个一致性原则就越让你想到，“现在它必须起作用了。如果我只投入一个再多一点，就可以了。”

    被剥夺的超级反应综合症也会出现：如果你不多投入一点，你就会失去一切。人们就那样破产了——因为他们无法停下来，重新思考并说，“我有能力注销这件事，然后活着再战。我不必把追求这件事当作一种痴迷——以一种会打破我。” 您必须学习的部分内容是如何处理错误和改变胜算的新事实。生活，在某种程度上，就像一场扑克牌游戏，有时当你握着一手深爱的牌时，你必须学会​​放弃。

  2. I don’t want you to think we have any way of learning or behaving so you won’t make a lot of mistakes. I’m just saying that you can learn to make fewer mistakes than other people — and how to fix your mistakes faster when you do make them. But there’s no way that you can live an adequate life without [making] many mistakes. In fact, one trick in life is to get so you can handle mistakes. Failure to handle psychological denial is a common way for people to go broke: You’ve made an enormous commitment to something. You’ve poured effort and money in. And the more you put in, the more that the whole consistency principle makes you think,"Now it has to work. If I put in just a little more, then it’ll work."

    And deprival super-reaction syndrome also comes in: You’re going to lose the whole thing if you don’t put in a little more. People go broke that way — because they can’t stop, rethink and say,"I can afford to write this one off and live to fight again. I don’t have to pursue this thing as an obsession — in a way that will break me." Part of what you must learn is how to handle mistakes and new facts that change the odds. Life, in part, is like a poker game, wherein you have to learn to quit sometimes when holding a much-loved hand.

  3. 我已经做到了，所以我现在使用一种双轨分析。首先，经过理性思考，真正支配所涉及利益的因素是什么？其次，大脑在潜意识水平上自动做这些事情的潜意识影响是什么——这些事情大体上是有用的，但往往会出错。一种方法是理性——解决桥梁问题的方法：通过评估实际利益、实际概率等。另一个是评估导致潜意识结论的心理因素——其中许多是错误的。

  4. I’ve gotten so that I now use a kind of two-track analysis. First, what are the factors that really govern the interests involved, rationally considered? And second, what are the subconscious influences where the brain at a subconscious level is automatically doing these things - which by and large are useful, but which often misfunction. One approach is rationality — the way you’d work out a bridge problem: by evaluating the real interests, the real probabilities and so forth. And the other is to evaluate the psychological factors that cause subconscious conclusions - many of which are wrong.

  5. 从心理学中获取所有主要模型，并将它们用作检查复杂系统结果的清单。没有一个飞行员不经过他的检查清单就起飞：A、B、C、D……并且没有一个需要两个额外技巧的桥牌玩家在没有检查他的检查清单并弄清楚如何去做的情况下玩一手牌。 .而且，为了强调，你必须特别注意产生 lollapalooza 后果的组合效应。

  6. Take all the main models from psychology and use them as a check-lists in reviewing outcomes in complex systems. No pilot takes off without going through his check-lists: A, B, C, D... And no bridge player who needs two extra tricks plays a hand without going down his check-lists and figuring out how to do it...And, to repeat for emphasis, you have to pay special attention to combinatorial effects that create lollapalooza consequences.

我们的感受、本能或直觉难道不能帮助我们避免误判吗？

Don’t our feelings, instincts or our intuition help us avoid misjudgements?

自然选择为我们提供了适应人类大部分时间所处环境的特征。爱、同情、愤怒、恐惧、嫉妒和尴尬等感觉可以用生物学来解释。它们的存在是有原因的——帮助我们生存和繁衍。萨默塞特·毛姆说：“爱情只是为了实现物种的延续而对我们开的卑鄙把戏。” 为什么性感觉很好？因为它让我们繁殖。如果性感到痛苦，我们今天就不会在这里。我们的情绪也是人类整体的一部分。没有我们的“坏”情绪，我们的“好”情绪就不会好。

Natural selection equipped us with traits adapted for the environment in which humans spent most of their time. Feelings like love, compassion, anger, fear, jealousy, and embarrassment can be explained biologically. They exist for a reason - to help us survive and reproduce. Somerset Maugham said:"Love is only a dirty trick played on us to achieve a continuation of the species." Why does sex feel good? Because it makes us reproduce. If sex felt painful, we wouldn’t be here today. Our emotions are also part of the human whole. Our"good" emotions wouldn’t be good without our"bad" emotions.

感觉和直觉帮助我们的祖先在世界上航行。祖先的环境在思想之前奖励行动，在理性之前奖励情感。快速的直觉和快速的反应是生物体的重要反应。花时间思考可能是危险的。

Feelings and instincts helped our ancestors navigate in the world. The ancestral environment rewarded actions before thought, emotion before reason. Fast intuitions and quick reactions are vital responses for organisms. Spending time pondering may be dangerous.

问题是感情是可以扭曲的。直觉是不一致的，感情有时会失控。尤其是当我们感到不确定、分心或有压力时。

The problem is that feelings can be twisted. Intuition is inconsistent and feelings can sometimes get out of control. Especially when we feel uncertain, distracted or stressed.

记住中国哲学家老子（公元前 604-531 年）：“知人者智，自知者明，胜人者力，胜己者强。”

Remember Chinese philosopher Lao-Tsu (604-531 BC):"He who knows men is clever; He who knows himself has insight; He who conquers men has force; He who conquers himself is truly strong."

在第三部分，我们将研究我们做出错误判断的其他原因。这些部分植根于我们的心理构成；我们倾向于使用粗略的经验法则，并做出仓促的判断和其他在第二部分中讨论的心理倾向。他们的根源还在于缺乏考虑物理和数学的一些基本思想。

In Part Three we will study other reasons why we make misjudgements. These are partly rooted in our psychological make-up; our tendency to use crude rules of thumb, and make hasty judgements and other psychological tendencies discussed in Part Two. They also have their roots in a lack of considering some basic ideas from physics and mathematics.

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 就了解物理学方法的价值给了我们一些介绍性的评论：

Charles Munger gives us some introductory remarks on the value of knowing the methods of physics:

对我影响最大的一件事是学习物理……如果我掌管着世界，那些有资格做物理的人将不会被允许选择放弃学习。我认为，即使是那些不 [期望] 接近物理学和工程学 [在他们计划的职业中] 的人也会学到一种在其他任何地方都学不到的物理学思维系统。物理学让我大开眼界。

始终以最基本的可用方式寻找答案的传统——这是一个伟大的传统，它为这个世界节省了大量时间。而且，当然，这些问题已经够难了，你必须学会​​拥有一些人所说的勤奋。好吧，我一直很喜欢这个词——因为对我来说它意味着你坐下来直到你完成它。

One of the things that influenced me greatly was studying physics.. .If I were running the world, people who are qualified to do physics would not be allowed to elect out of taking it. I think that even people who aren’t [expecting to] go near physics and engineering [in their planned profession] learn a thinking system in physics that is not learned so well anywhere else. Physics was a total eye-opener.

The tradition of always looking for the answer in the most fundamental way available — that is a great tradition and it saves a lot of time in this world. And, of course, the problems are hard enough that you have to learn to have what some people call assiduity. Well, I’ve always liked that word — because to me it means that you sit down on your ass until you’ve done it.

第三部分：

误判的物理和数学

Part Three:

The Physics And Mathematics Of Misjudgements

总有一天，数学上的无知，就像在公共场合吸烟一样，将变得不为社会所接受。

There will come a time when mathematical ignorance, like public smoking, will become socially unacceptable.

- Jerry King

（数学教授，来自数学艺术）

- Jerry King

(Professor of Mathematics, from The Art of Mathematics)

第三部分简而言之

Part Three In A Nutshell

这部分说明了可以通过考虑物理和数学的一些基本原理来减少误判和错误的原因。重要的想法是用商业、投资、法律、医学等方面的例子来解释的。在第二部分中，我们从误判和错误的原因列表开始。列表中的每一项都将在接下来的章节中进行解释。

This part illustrates reasons for misjudgements and mistakes that can be reduced by considering some basic principles from physics and mathematics. The big ideas are explained using examples from business, investing, law, medicine, etc. As in Part Two, we begin with a list of the causes of misjudgements and mistakes. Each item on the list will be explained over the next chapters.

1.系统思考

1. Systems thinking

  • 没有考虑到行动会产生预期和意外的后果。包括未能考虑次要和更高级的后果和不可避免的影响。

  • Failing to consider that actions have both intended and unintended consequences. Includes failing to consider secondary and higher order consequences and inevitable implications.

  • 未能考虑发生行动和反应的整个系统、构成系统的重要因素、它们之间的关系以及变化对系统结果的影响。

  • Failing to consider the whole system in which actions and reactions take place, the important factors that make up the system, their relationships and effects of changes on system outcome.

  • 没有考虑他人可能的反应——最好的做法可能取决于他人的做法。

  • Failing to consider the likely reactions of others - what is best to do may depend on what others do.

  • 没有考虑中标的影响——高估价值和付出太多。

  • Failing to consider the implications of winning a bid — overestimating value and paying too much.

  • 高估预测能力或使用不可知因素进行预测。

  • Overestimating predictive ability or using unknowable factors in making predictions.

2. 规模和限制

2. Scale and limits

  • 没有考虑到大小或时间的变化会影响形式、功能和行为。

  • Failing to consider that changes in size or time influence form, function and behaviour.

  • 没有考虑断点、临界阈值或限制

  • Failing to consider breakpoints, critical thresholds or limits

  • 没有考虑约束——系统的性能受到其最薄弱环节的限制。

  • Failing to consider constraints — that a system’s performance is constrained by its weakest link.

三、成因

3. Causes

  • 不了解导致预期结果的原因。

  • Not understanding what causes desired results.

  • 相信原因类似于它的结果——一个大的结果一定有一个大的或复杂的原因。

  • Believing cause resembles its effect — that a big effect must have a big or complicated cause.

  • 低估了随机性对坏结果或好结果的影响。

  • Underestimating the influence of randomness in bad or good outcomes.

  • 将结果误认为其原因。包括没有考虑到许多影响可能源于一个共同的根本原因。

  • Mistaking an effect for its cause. Includes failing to consider that many effects may originate from one common root cause.

  • 当有多种原因时，将结果归因于单一原因。

  • Attributing outcome to a single cause when there are multiple causes.

  • 将相关性误认为原因。

  • Mistaking correlation for cause.

  • 没有考虑到结果可能与其他解释一致。

  • Failing to consider that an outcome may be consistent with alternative explanations.

  • 从选择性数据中得出有关原因的结论。包括识别错误的原因，因为它似乎是基于单一观察结果的显而易见的原因。也没有考虑缺失的信息或证据。

  • Drawing conclusions about causes from selective data. Includes identifying the wrong cause because it seems the obvious one based on a single observed effect. Also failing to consider information or evidence that is missing.

  • 在解释结果时，不比较类似情况下消极结果和积极结果在条件、行为和因素方面的差异。

  • Not comparing the difference in conditions, behaviour and factors between negative and positive outcomes in similar situations when explaining an outcome.

4. 数字及其意义

4. Numbers and their meaning

  • 查看孤立的数字——没有考虑关系和大小。包括不使用基础数学来计数和量化。也不区分相对风险和绝对风险。

  • Looking at isolated numbers — failing to consider relationships and magnitudes. Includes not using basic maths to count and quantify. Also not differentiating between relative and absolute risk.

  • 低估了指数增长的影响。

  • Underestimating the effect of exponential growth.

  • 低估了金钱的时间价值。

  • Underestimating the time value of money.

5. 可能结果的概率和数量

5. Probabilities and number of possible outcomes

  • 在相对频率（或可比数据）和/或后果的大小未知或随时间变化的情况下低估风险暴露。

  • Underestimating risk exposure in situations where relative frequency (or comparable data) and/or magnitude of consequences is unknown or changing over time.

  • 低估了不需要的事件的可能结果的数量。包括低估罕见或极端事件的可能性和严重性。

  • Underestimating the number of possible outcomes for unwanted events. Includes underestimating the probability and severity of rare or extreme events.

  • 高估罕见但广泛宣传和高度情绪化事件的可能性，低估常见但较少宣传的事件的可能性。

  • Overestimating the chance of rare but widely publicized and highly emotional events and underestimating the chance of common but less publicized events.

  • 未能同时考虑概率和后果（预期值）。

  • Failing to consider both probabilities and consequences (expected value).

  • 相信机会发挥作用的事件是自我纠正的——独立事件的先前结果在确定未来结果方面具有预测价值。

  • Believing events where chance plays a role are self-correcting — that previous outcomes of independent events have predictive value in determining future outcomes.

  • 相信一个人可以控制涉及机会的事件的结果。

  • Believing one can control the outcome of events where chance is involved.

  • 通过评估收益和损失而不是财富和个人价值的最终状态来判断财务决策。

  • Judging financial decisions by evaluating gains and losses instead of final state of wealth and personal value.

  • 没有考虑错误的后果。

  • Failing to consider the consequences of being wrong.

6.场景

6. Scenarios

  • 高估了必须实现所有一系列步骤才能获得预期结果的场景的可能性。还低估了失败的机会以及类似情况下通常会发生的事情。

  • Overestimating the probability of scenarios where all of a series of steps must be achieved for a wanted outcome. Also underestimating opportunities for failure and what normally happens in similar situations.

  • 低估系统故障的可能性 - 由许多部分组成的场景，系统故障可能以一种或另一种方式发生。包括没有考虑时间范围变化的概率。还假设独立性不存在和/或假设事件不存在时同样可能发生。

  • Underestimating the probability of systems failure - scenarios composed of many parts where system failure can happen one way or another. Includes failing to consider that time horizon changes probabilities. Also assuming independence when it is not present and/or assuming events are equally likely when they are not.

  • 不为已知和未知风险增加安全系数。因素的大小取决于失败的后果、对风险的理解程度、系统特征和控制程度。

  • Not adding a factor of safety for known and unknown risks. Size of factor depends on the consequences of failure, how well the risks are understood, systems characteristics and degree of control.

7. 巧合与奇迹

7. Coincidences and miracles

  • 低估惊喜和不可能发生的事件，如果他们有足够的机会（足够大的规模或时间）发生，在某个地方，某个时间，某人。

  • Underestimating that surprises and improbable events happen, somewhere, sometime, to someone, if they have enough opportunities (large enough size or time) to happen.

  • 寻找意义、寻找原因并为偶然事件编造模式，尤其是具有情感暗示的事件。

  • Looking for meaning, searching for causes and making up patterns for chance events, especially events that have emotional implications.

  • 没有考虑涉及没有因果关系的案例。

  • Failing to consider cases involving the absence of a cause or effect.

八、案件证据的可靠性

8. Reliability of case evidence

  • 过度权衡个案证据和低估先验概率（在考虑可能改变事件的新证据之前对事件的概率估计）考虑例如基本比率（代表性比较组中属性或事件的相对频率），或来自许多类似案例的证据。包括没有考虑随机匹配的概率，以及假阳性和假阴性的概率。也没有考虑具有我们正在寻找的特征的相关比较人群。

  • over-weighing individual case evidence and under-weighing the prior probability (probability estimate of an event before considering new evidence that might change it) considering for example, the base rate (relative frequency of an attribute or event in a representative comparison group), or evidence from many similar cases. Includes failing to consider the probability of a random match, and the probability of a false positive and false negative. Also failing to consider a relevant comparison population that bears the characteristic we are seeking.

9. 虚假证据

9. Misrepresentative evidence

  • 在使用过去的证据预测未来可能的结果时，没有考虑因素、背景或条件的变化。包括不寻找过去结果发生原因的解释，让过去的记录继续下去需要什么，以及什么力量可以改变它。

  • Failing to consider changes in factors, context or conditions when using past evidence to predict likely future outcomes. Includes not searching for explanations to why past outcome happened, what is required to make past record continue, and what forces can change it.

  • 高估来自单个案例或小样本或不具代表性的样本的证据。

  • Overestimating evidence from a single case or small or unrepresentative samples.

  • 低估机会对绩效（成功和失败）的影响。

  • Underestimating the influence of chance in performance (success and failure).

  • 只看到积极的结果——很少或根本不关注消极的结果和先验概率。

  • Only seeing positive outcomes — paying little or no attention to negative outcomes and prior probabilities.

  • 没有考虑结果的可变性及其频率。

  • Failing to consider variability of outcomes and their frequency.

  • 不考虑回归——在任何涉及偶然性的事件系列中，独特的结果往往会回归到平均结果。

  • Failing to consider regression - in any series of events where chance is involved unique outcomes tends to regress back to the average outcome.

一：系统思考

One: Systems Thinking

想要的和不想要的后果

Wanted and unwanted consequences

在伊索寓言之一中，讲述了以下故事：

In one of Aesop’s fables the following story is told:

一个独自住在乡下的穷寡妇养了一只忠实的母鸡。每天早上，母鸡都会下一个棕色的大鸡蛋作为女人的早餐。有一天，寡妇心想：“现在，如果我给母鸡喂食大麦的数量增加一倍，她每天就会给我生两个鸡蛋，而不是一个。” 于是她开始给她的比迪喂双份量的谷物，很快这只母鸡开始变得又胖又圆滑又懒惰。没过多久，她就完全停止躺下了。

A poor widow living alone in the country kept a faithful hen. Each morning the hen laid a big, brown egg for the woman’s breakfast. One day the widow thought to herself:"Now if I were to double my hen’s allowance of barley, she would lay me two eggs a day instead of one." So she started feeding her biddy a double measure of grain, and soon the hen began to grow fat and sleek and lazy. It wasn’t long before she stopped laying altogether.

每个动作都有后果。既是有意的，也是无意的。无论我们计划得多么周密，我们都无法预料到一切。我们常常没有考虑由于某些行为而可能发生的其他事件。政治、医学、福利计划、技术、军事行动和法律会产生意想不到的后果。无论我们做什么（或不做什么），都会产生多重后果。他们可能不是我们所期望的。在一项研究中，交通工程师发现增加新路线（如更直接的道路）可能会使交通变慢。在并道期间，汽车彼此靠得更近，因此减速。此外，对汽车安全的研究表明，系好安全带会让司机更有安全感，从而使他们开得更快或更鲁莽。

Every action has consequences. Both intended and unintended. No matter how carefully we plan, we can’t anticipate everything. Often we fail to consider what other events are likely to occur as a result of some action. Politics, medicine, welfare programs, technology, military actions and laws generate unintended consequences. Whatever we do (or don’t do), there are multiple consequences. They might not be what we expect. In one study, traffic engineers found that adding new routes (like a more direct road) could make traffic go slower. During merging, cars drive closer to each other and therefore slow down. Furthermore, studies of car safety show that wearing seat belt makes drivers feel more secure, making them drive faster or more recklessly.

通过解决一个问题，我们会产生另一个问题，有时甚至会产生更糟糕的问题。

By solving one problem, we generate another one and sometimes create an even worse one.

校园里的老鼠有问题。消灭老鼠的解决方案是每交付一只死老鼠就付给学生 1 美元。有效！直到同学们为了赚更多的钱，开始饲养老鼠。

There was a problem with mice on campus. The solution for exterminating the mice was to pay students $1 for every dead mouse they delivered. It worked! Until the students began breeding the mice in order to make more money.

行动有后果，后果有进一步的影响。查理芒格举了一个关于医疗保险的例子：

Actions have consequences and consequences have further effects. Charles Munger gives an example regarding Medicare:

他们进行了所有这些精算研究，表明成本将是 X。结果成本超过 1 OX……他们没有考虑到影响有影响的事实……他们没有仔细考虑他们改变规则的方式的激励效果。他们

创建了一个系统，在该系统中，他们实际上是在成本加成本的基础上向医生和医院报销。他们这样做的那一刻，医院和医生找到了绝妙的方法来说服病人购买各种报销的医疗服务……对医院和医生都有好处，但对病人和纳税人不利。

They had all these actuarial studies that showed the cost would be X. And the cost turned out to be more than 1 OX...They didn’t factor in the fact that effects have effects...they didn’t think through the incentive effects of the way they were changing the rules. They

created a system wherein they were reimbursing both doctors and hospitals, in effect, on a cost plus percentage of cost basis. The minute they did that, the hospitals and doctors found wonderful ways to talk the patients into buying all kinds of care that got reimbursed.. .good for the hospital and good for the doctor, but bad for the patient and bad for the taxpayers.

善意应该消除不良后果吗？不。结果不是源于意图，意图的定义仅适用于预期的结果。但正如塞缪尔约翰逊所说，“通往地狱的道路是用善意铺成的。” 找出结果是否好比找出原因是否好更重要吗？问：我们想改进什么？可以合理预期会发生什么？净效应是正面的还是负面的？

Should good intentions eliminate bad consequences? No. Outcomes don’t follow from intentions and intentions by definition apply only to intended consequences. But as Samuel Johnson said,"The road to hell is paved with good intentions." Isn’t it more important to find out if the consequences are good rather than if the reasons are good? Ask: What are we trying to improve? What can reasonably be expected to happen? Are the net effects positive or negative?

良好的思想胜于良好的意图。18世纪，法国国民议会代表皮埃尔·S·杜邦说：“坏逻辑学家非自愿犯罪比坏人故意犯罪多。”

Good thinking is better than good intentions. In the 18th Century, Pierre S. du Pont, a deputy to the French National Assembly said:"Bad logicians have committed more involuntary crimes than bad men have done intentionally."

但即使是好的想法也会产生不良后果。查尔斯·芒格举了一个例子：

But even good thinking can have undesired consequences. Charles Munger gives an example:

看似专业的过度行为往往最终会严重伤害你，因为那些谨慎的程序本身往往会导致对其结果过度自信......长期资本管理公司，著名的对冲基金最近因其本金对他们高度杠杆化的方法过于自信。尽管那些校长的平均智商必须达到 160 或更高，但它还是崩溃了……聪明、勤奋的人也不能免于过度自信导致的职业灾难。通常他们只是在更艰难的航程中搁浅，他们根据自我评价选择踏上航程，在这些航程中他们得出结论认为自己具有卓越的才能和方法。当然，令人恼火的是，在思考时格外小心并不都是好事——它还会引入额外的错误。但大多数好东西都有不希望有的“副作用”。思维也不例外。

An excess of what seems like professionalism will often wind up hurting you horribly precisely because those careful procedures themselves often lead to overconfidence in their outcome... Long Term Capital Management, the well-known hedge fund recently collapsed as a result of its principals’ overconfidence in their highly leveraged methods. And it collapsed despite those principals having IQs that must have averaged 160 or more...Smart, hard-working people aren’t exempt from professional disasters resulting from overconfidence. Often they just go aground in the more difficult voyages on which they choose to embark based on self appraisals in which they conclude that they have superior talents and methods. It is, of course, irritating that extra care in thinking isn’t all good — that it also introduces extra error. But most good things have undesired"side effects." And thinking is no exception.

减少意外后果的一种方法是停止关注孤立的因素，而是考虑我们的行为如何影响整个系统。

One way to reduce unintended consequences is to stop focusing on isolated factors and instead consider how our actions affect the whole system.

整个系统

The whole system

销量下降，约翰建议：“我们为什么不降价呢？这是赢回客户和促进销量的必经之路。我们用销量弥补了价格上的损失，从而增加了我们的市场份额。利润肯定会上升。”

Sales volume dropped and John suggested:"Why don’t we reduce price? It’s a sure-fire way to win back customers and boost sales. We make up on volume what we lose on price and as a result we increase our market share. Profits will surely rise."

 “我们哪里出了问题？我们失去了市场份额。利润和股价都下降了。”

 "Where did we go wrong? We lost market share. Profits and stock price declined."

 为什么 TransCorp 的利润没有增加？他们忘了考虑影响结果的所有因素。他们没有预料到降价的后果。他们没有考虑影响企业价值的其他因素和条件。由于 TransCorp 决定降低价格以应对更高的销量，因此部分价格发生了变化。数量增加会影响成本和行为以及对运营资产投资的需求。由于技术限制或降价不足以让客户放弃竞争，也可能存在生产问题。

 Why didn’t TransCorp’s profit increase? They forgot to think about all the factors that influenced the outcome. They didn’t anticipate the consequences of cutting prices. They didn’t consider other factors and conditions that influenced the value of the business. Some were changed as a consequence of TransCorp’s decision to reduce prices in anticipation of higher volumes. Volume increases affect costs and behaviour and need for investments in operating assets. There may also have been production problems due to technical constraints or the price decrease wasn’t enough to make customers switch from the competition.

系统的行为方式是构成和影响系统的所有因素（人和非人）的函数。

How a system behaves is a function of all the factors (human and non-human) that make up and influence the system.

系统是作为一个整体协同工作的部分的集合。以企业为例。它是零件的集合，但作为一个完整的系统工作。有供应商、员工、客户、需求、竞争等变量。有采购、制造、仓储、物流和分销等活动。开展业务需要技术系统和设备。所有这些部分一起工作。

A system is a collection of parts working together as a whole. Take a business as an example. It is a collection of parts but works as a complete system. There are variables like suppliers, employees, customers, demand, competition, etc. There are activities like purchasing, manufacturing, warehousing, logistics, and distribution. There are technological systems and equipment needed to conduct the business. All these parts work together.

TransCorp 解雇了 200 人以削减成本。

TransCorp fired 200 people to cut costs.

我们一次优化一个组件而不是优化整体（我们最终想要完成的）。TransCorp 忘记考虑变更如何影响整个系统。削减成本不会自动转化为更高的价值。TransCorp 裁员的决定造成了制造和交付问题，进而导致客户生产延误。这造成了客户和声誉的损失。最终结果是利润下降。

We optimize one component at a time instead of optimizing the whole (what we finally want to accomplish). TransCorp forgot to consider how a change influences the whole system. Cost cutting doesn’t automatically translate into higher value. TransCorp’s decision to fire people caused manufacturing and delivery problems, which in turn caused delays in customer production. This created a loss of customers and reputation. The end result was lower profits.

为什么要降价？什么目的？TransCorp 最终想要实现什么？

Why reduce prices? What is the purpose? What does TransCorp ultimately want to achieve?

系统根据反馈进行调整。积极的反馈会放大效果，而消极的反馈会削弱效果。以股票市场为例，正反馈。股市下跌导致抛售。这会产生进一步抛售和价格下跌的连锁反应。相反的情况发生在股市泡沫中。恒温器是负反馈的一个例子。

Systems adjust in response to feedback. A positive feedback amplifies an effect, while a negative dampens it. Take the stock market as an example of a positive feedback. The stock market falls causing a sell-off. This creates a ripple effect of further sell-off and price declines. The opposite occurs in a stock market bubble. A thermostat is an example of negative feedback.

尝试优化整体而不是系统的各个部分。想一想当我们改变系统中的一个因素时，其他变量可能会发生什么变化。追踪拟议行动的数量和影响的短期和长期后果，看看最终结果是否符合我们的最终目标。

Try to optimize the whole and not a system’s individual parts. Think through what other variables may change when we alter a factor in a system. Trace out the short and long-term consequences in numbers and effects of a proposed action to see if the net result agrees with our ultimate goal.

问：哪些关键因素影响系统的结果，这些因素如何相互作用？由于某些行动，还有哪些其他事情可能会发生变化？鉴于这些条件，考虑到影响系统或属于系统的所有相关因素，拟议的行动可能会对系统产生什么后果（想要的和不想要的）？最终结果会是我们想要的吗？例如，经理可以问：考虑到影响业务价值的重要因素，业务价值可能发生怎样的变化？

Ask: What key factors influence the outcome of the system and how do these factors interact? What other things may change as a consequence of some action? Given these conditions, what likely consequences (wanted and unwanted) will the proposed action have on the system, considering all the relevant factors that influence or are part of the system? Will the net result be what we want? A manager can for example ask: How is the value of the business likely to change considering important factors that influence business value?

考虑整体包括预测他人的反应。

Considering the whole includes anticipating the reactions of others.

别人的反应

The reaction of others

博弈论是对有思想的和潜在的欺骗对手之间冲突的研究。

Game theory is a study of conflict between thoughtful and potential deceitful opponents.

- 威廉庞德斯通

（来自囚徒困境）

- William Poundstone

(from Prisoner’s Dilemma)

TransCorp 降价并减少了销量。

TransCorp cut the price and lost volume.

发生了什么？TransCorp 的竞争对手也相应降价。竞争对手可以匹配降价甚至降价以重新获得、保持或增加市场份额。

What happened? TransCorp’s competitors matched the price cut. Competitors can match price cuts or even go below it to regain, keep or increase market share.

在考虑后果时，请考虑其他人可能会做什么。由于我们的利益可能会与他人发生冲突，因此我们决定的最终结果往往取决于他人的做法。其他人做什么可能取决于他们认为我们会做什么、他们可用的选择、兴趣以及他们的想法——包括他们的错误判断。正如我们所知，人类并不总是理性行事。

When thinking through consequences, consider what other people are likely to do. Since our interests may conflict with others, the final outcome of our decision often depends on what others will do. What other people do may depend on what they think we will do, their available choices, interests, and how they are thinking - including their misjudgements. As we have learned, humans don’t always act rationally.

博弈论研究的是当个人或群体为实现目标而相互影响时会发生什么。我们在第一部分（囚徒困境）中看到了博弈论的一个例子。它也适用于谈判。

Game theory deals with what happens when individuals or groups of people interact with one another to achieve their goals. We saw an example of game theory in Part One (Prisoners Dilemma). It also applies to negotiations.

决定谈判最终结果的因素有：

Factors that decide the final outcome of a negotiation are:

  1. 参加人数，
  2. the number of participants,
  3. 如果我们以后再遇到参与者，
  4. if we meet the participants again in the future,
  5. 中间的时间流逝，
  6. the time lapse in between,
  7. 匿名和交流的程度，以及
  8. the degree of anonymity and communication, and
  9. 我们的相对优势地位，包括我们的其他选择、备用选择和达成协议的需要。
  10. our relative position of strength which includes our other options, back-up alternatives and need to reach an agreement.

胜利者的诅咒

The winner’s curse

我给俱乐部发了一封电报说，“请接受我的辞职。

我不想加入任何愿意让我成为会员的俱乐部。”

I sent the club a wire stating,"Please accept my resignation.

I don’t care to belong to any club that will have me as a member."

- 格劳乔马克思

- Groucho Marx

包括 TransCorps 子公司之一 MineCorp 在内的几家矿业公司正在竞标白银开采权。

Several mining firms including MineCorp, one of TransCorps subsidiaries, are bidding on the right to mine silver.

没有公司确切地知道有多少白银，因此也不知道真正的价值是多少。他们各自聘请专家进行有根据的猜测。根据定义，这些专家猜测的范围从太低到太高。一些公司的专家可能会很接近。但他们不会赢。获胜的公司是 MineCorp，因为他们的专家对价值的估计最为乐观（卖方接受最高出价）。但矿山中的白银比他们的专家猜测的要少，价值也比 MineCorp 为权利支付的价格要低。这意味着中标者被诅咒，因为出价高于价值。后来表明，MineCorp 也低估了其生产成本。
