No firm knows for certain how much silver there is and hence what the true value is. They each hire an expert to make an educated guess. By definition, these expert guesses will range from too low to too high. Some firm’s expert will probably be close. But they won’t win. The winning firm was MineCorp since their expert had the most optimistic estimate of the value (the seller accepts the highest bid). But there was less silver in the mine than their expert guessed and less value than what MineCorp paid for the rights. This means that the winning bidder was cursed since the bid was higher than the value. Later it was shown that MineCorp also underestimated its costs of production.

Atlantic Richfield 的三位工程师 Capen、Clapp 和 Campbell 在对竞标油田的公司进行研究时介绍了赢家诅咒背后的想法。他们的基本想法是（Journal of Petroleum Technology，1971 年 6 月），即“租赁赢家往往是最能高估储量潜力的投标人”。

Three Atlantic Richfield engineers, Capen, Clapp and Campbell, introduced the idea behind the Winner’s Curse when they did a study of companies bidding for oil fields. Their basic idea was (Journal of Petroleum Technology, June 1971), that "a lease winner tends to be the bidder who most overestimates reserve potential."

假设 TransCorp 有 10 个部门的 10 个项目可供选择。他们只有时间和金钱来投资一个项目。他们最有可能选择哪一个？当然是看起来最吸引人的那个。但所有部门经理都有动机让自己的项目成为最具吸引力的项目。因此，风险在于 TransCorp 选择了预测最乐观的项目，因此更有可能令人失望。

Let’s say TransCorp has 10 projects from 10 divisions to choose from. They only have time and money to invest in one project. Which one are they most likely to pick? Of course, the one that looks most attractive. But all division managers have an incentive to make their own project the most attractive one. The risk is therefore that TransCorp chooses the project with the most optimistic forecast and therefore more likely to disappoint.

“万岁，我赢得了拍卖！”约翰说。

“你赢得的是为某样东西支付比其他人认为的价值更高的权利，”玛丽说。

"Hurray, I won the auction!,"said John.

"What you ‘won was the right to pay more for something than everyone else thought it was worth," said Mary.

获胜是一个信息丰富的事件，告诉我们谁的估计是最乐观的。当我们对房屋、公司、项目出价或谈判购买某物时，我们没有意识到接受我们的报价意味着什么。我们可能高估了它的价值，因此付出了太多。

Winning is an informative event, telling us whose estimate was most optimistic. When we place a bid on a house, company, project, or negotiate to buy something, we don’t realize what is implied by an acceptance of our offer. That we may have overestimated its value and therefore paid too much.

研究表明，越多的竞标者为有限的物品竞争，每个人都拥有相同的信息，其价值越不确定，我们就越有可能多付钱。相反，如果我们的目标是创造价值，那么投标人越多，我们的投标就应该越保守。这也意味着，与其他投标人相比，我们掌握的信息越少，或者我们对潜在价值的不确定性越大，我们应该出价越低。如果我们参加拍卖，我们必须确定所售物品的真实价值或它对我们的价值。

Research shows that the more bidders there are competing for a limited object, each having the same information, and the more uncertain its value is, the more likely we are to overpay. Instead, if our objective is to create value, the more bidders there are, the more conservative our bidding should be. This also implies that the less information we have compared to other bidders or the more uncertain we are about the underlying value, the lower we should bid. If we participate in auctions, we must ascertain the true value of what’s being sold or its value to us.

当我们与一方谈判并希望接受报价时，另一方可能具有信息优势。对方最有可能在对我们最不利的情况下接受我们的提议，尤其是在一次性关系或对方匿名的情况下。

When we negotiate with one party and want an acceptance for an offer, the other party may have an informational advantage. The other party is most likely to accept our offer when it is least favourable to us, especially if it is a one-time relationship or if the other party is anonymous.

考虑卖家的角度。问：他们为什么要卖？如果我站在对方的角度去思考，我会如何推理？为什么我会比掌握所有信息的人做出更好的决定？

Consider the seller’s perspective. Ask: Why are they selling? How would I reason if I think it through from the viewpoint of the other person? Why would I make a better decision than someone who has all the information?

预测

Predictions

因此，不要指望我会做出任何预言：如果我知道明天会发现什么，我早就发表了，以确保优先权。

Do not, therefore, expect any prophecy from me: had I known what one will discover tomorrow, I would have published it long ago, to secure priority.

- Henri Poincare

（法国数学家和科学家，1854-1912）

- Henri Poincare

(French mathematician and scientist, 1854-1912)

当被问及企业对社会问题的责任时，查尔斯·芒格回答说：

When asked about corporate responsibility for social problems, Charles Munger answered:

我完全赞成解决社会问题。我完全赞成对不幸的人慷慨解囊。我完全赞成做一些事情，基于稍微占优势的证据，你猜它可能利大于弊......

我反对的是非常自信和感觉你肯定知道你的特定干预会利大于弊，因为你正在处理高度复杂的系统，其中一切都与其他一切相互作用。

I’m all for fixing social problems. I’m all for being generous to the less fortunate. And I’m all for doing things where, based on a slight preponderance of the evidence, you guess that it’s likely to do more good than harm...

What I’m against is being very confident and feeling that you know, for sure, that your particular intervention will do more good than harm given that you’re dealing with highly complex systems wherein everything is interacting with everything else.

希腊哲学家赫拉克利特写道：“Nothing enders but change”。世界太复杂了，无法预测某些行为的所有影响。也许企业可以预测需求减少和竞争加剧等情况，但有些事件的发生时间、规模或后果是无法预测的。

Greek philosopher Heraclitus wrote:"Nothing endures but change." The world is too complicated to predict all the effects of some action. Maybe a business can predict scenarios like reduction in demand and intensified competition, but some events, their timing, magnitude or consequence, are impossible to anticipate.

马克吐温说：“预言的艺术非常难，尤其是关于未来。” 当我们不（或不能）预见或理解整个系统如何运作、涉及哪些关键变量、它们的属性、它们如何相互影响以及它们的影响时，很难预测某些事情。即使我们知道关键变量，也可能无法估计它们的值。它们也可能随时间而变化，并取决于上下文。也可能无法估计它们将如何作为一个整体相互作用。

Mark Twain said:"The art of prophecy is very difficult, especially with respect to the future." It is hard to predict something when we don’t (or can’t) foresee or understand how an entire system works, what key variables are involved, their attributes, how they influence one another and their impact. Even if we know the key variables, their values may be impossible to estimate. They may also change over time and be dependent on context. It may also be impossible to estimate how they will interact as a whole.

涉及的部分越多，它们相互作用的越多，发生的事情就越多，就越难确定个人行为的后果。

The more parts involved and the more they interact, the more can happen, and the harder it is to determine consequences of individual actions.

根据 Gerald Edelman 博士的说法，大脑是一个复杂系统的例子：

According to Dr. Gerald Edelman, the brain is an example of a complex system:

复杂系统是指其中较小的部分形成一组或多或少独立的异构组件的系统。但随着这些部分在越来越大的聚合体中相互连接，它们的功能趋于整合，产生依赖于这种高阶整合的新功能。事实上，这正是大脑中发生的事情。

A complex system is one in which smaller parts form a heterogeneous set of components which are more or less independent. But as these parts connect with each other in larger and larger aggregates, their functions tend to become integrated, yielding new functions that depend on such high order integration. This is, in fact, just what happens in the brain.

随着变量数量的增加，可能的交互数量增长得更快。假设两个子系统 A 和 B 导致系统的行为。

As the number of variables grows, the number of possible interactions grows even faster. Assume that two subsystems, A and B, cause the behaviour of a system.

每个子系统由 5 个部分组成。如果我们只考虑部分之间的双向交互，则 A 部分之间有 10 次交互，B 部分之间有 10 次交互，A 部分和 B 部分之间有 25 次交互。这意味着系统的行为由 55 个决定因素组成（5A 部分 + 5B 部分 +10 个 A 部分之间的交互 ​​+10 个 B 部分之间的交互 ​​+ 25 个 A 和 B 部分之间的交互）。所有决定因素的 18%（5 个中的 10 个，5 个）来自 A 和 B 中各部分的个体效应，而约 82%（55 个中的 45 个）来自相互作用。现在想象一个系统，其中 A 和 B 各包含 100 个部分。现在有 20,100 个决定因素（100+100+4,950+4,950+10,000）和 19,900 个相互作用，这意味着 99%（20,100 中的 19,900）的系统决定因素来自相互作用。

Each subsystem consists of 5 parts. If we only consider two-way interactions among parts, there are 10 interactions between A-parts, 10 between B-parts, and 25 interactions between A and B parts. This means that the behaviour of the system is composed of 55 determinants (5A-parts + 5B-parts +10 interactions between A-parts +10 interactions between B-parts + 25 interactions between A and B parts). 18% (10 of 5 5) of all determinants derive from individual effects of parts in A and B while about 82% (45 of 55) derive from interactions. Now imagine a system where A and B each consists of 100 parts. There are now 20,100 determinants (100+100+4,950+4,950+10,000) and 19,900 interactions meaning that 99% (19,900 of 20,100) of system determinants derive from interactions.

我们常常很少注意变量如何相互作用。以经济为例。有很多因素需要考虑。它们包括利率、货币汇率、贸易平衡数据、失业率、消费者信心、政治因素、股市、商业周期、偏见等。这些因素相互关联，很难说哪个最重要。除此之外，人们的行为并不是固定的。我们是情绪化的动物，我们的偏好会改变，我们会对彼此的实际或预期决定做出反应。预测也可能使我们改变我们的期望和行为，使预测或多或少成为现实的可能性。

We often take too little notice of how variables interact. Take the economy as an example. There are many factors to consider. They include interest rates, currency exchange rates, balance of trade figures, unemployment rates, consumer confidence, political factors, the stock market, business cycles, biases, etc. These factors are interconnected, and it is hard to tell which is most important. Add to this that people’s behaviour isn’t fixed. We are emotional creatures, our preferences change, and we react to each other’s actual or expected decisions. A prediction may also make us change our expectations and behaviour, making the prediction more or less likely to come true.

查尔斯芒格说：“我们试图预测哪些个人投资会顺应潮流。然后我们倾向于接受潮流的影响，因为这些影响会下降。”

Charles Munger says:"We try and predict what individual investments will swim well in relation to the tide. And then we tend to accept the effects of the tide as those effects fall."

“如果有人能预测股市，他们为什么要通过 100 美元的时事通讯出售建议？”

"If someone could forecast the stock market, why are they selling advice through $100 newsletters?"

富达前任经理彼得林奇在《华尔街风云》中说：“美国有 60,000 名经济学家，其中许多人全职工作，试图预测经济衰退和利率，如果他们能够连续两次成功，他们到现在都成了百万富翁……据我所知，他们中的大多数人仍然有收入，这应该告诉我们一些事情。”

Fidelity’s former manager Peter Lynch said in One Up on Wall Street:"There are 60,000 economists in the U.S., many of them employed full-time trying to forecast recessions and interest rates, and if they could do it successfully twice in a row, they’d all be millionaires by now... As far as I know, most of them are still gainfully employed, which ought to tell us something."

对未来的预测通常只是对过去曲线和当前趋势的预测。这是很自然的，因为我们对未来的预测是在现在做出的。因此，我们假设未来会很像现在。但是未来在它到来之前是不可知的。它取决于我们看不到的事件。例如，在 1900 年，谁能预见到第一次和第二次世界大战、1929 年股市崩盘、切尔诺贝利事故或电视、激光、计算机、互联网或 DVD 等技术？许多重要的发明都是出于偶然和智慧而产生的。例如，1867 年阿尔弗雷德·诺贝尔偶然发现，当硝化甘油滴在硅藻土（一种由海洋动物的小化石遗骸制成的矿物）上时，它会形成一种稳定的糊状物，比单独使用液态硝化甘油更安全。他称之为炸药。

Predictions about the future are often just projections of past curves and present trends. This is natural since our predictions about the future are made in the present. We therefore assume the future will be much like the present. But the future can’t be known until it arrives. It is contingent on events we can’t see. For example, who in the year 1900, could foresee events like World War I and II, the 1929 stock market crash, Chernobyl or technologies like the television, laser, computer, internet or the DVD? Many key inventions happened by accident and sagacity. For example, in 1867 Alfred Nobel accidentally discovered that when nitroglycerin dripped on kieselguhr (a mineral made of small, fossilized remains of sea animals), it formed a stable paste that was safer to use than liquid nitroglycerin alone. He called it dynamite.

不要相信那些说他们可以预测不可预见的变量的人。没有人可以预测利率或汇率、GDP、经济转折点、股市等。大量信息、先进的计算机或花哨的数学公式都无济于事。沃伦巴菲特说，我们往往过于依赖计算机模型及其预测的精确度：“我们认为他们预测的精确度是一种幻想。事实上，这样的模型可以让决策者产生一种错误的安全感，从而增加他们犯一个非常大的错误的机会。”

Don’t believe people that say they can forecast unforeseeable variables. Nobody can forecast interest or currency rates, the GDP, turning points in the economy, the stock market, etc. Massive amounts of information, advanced computers or fancy mathematical formulas don’t help. Warren Buffett says that we tend to put too much comfort in computer models and the precision they project:"We believe the precision they project is a chimera. In fact, such models can lull decision-makers into a false sense of security and thereby increase their chances of making a really huge mistake."

经济学不像物理学。没有可靠或精确的公式可以让我们轻松填写各种经济因素的值，然后完成工作。查尔斯芒格说：“经济学涉及一个过于复杂的系统......经济学应该效仿物理学的基本精神，但它在经济学中寻求类似物理学公式的精确性几乎总是错误的。” JM 凯恩斯补充道：“将模型转换为定量公式就是破坏其作为思维工具的有用性。”

Economics isn’t like physics. There are no reliable or precise formulas where we easily can fill in the values of various economic factors, and then have the work done. Charles Munger says:"Economics involves too complex a system.. .economics should emulate physics’ basic ethos, but its search for precision in physics-like formulas is almost always wrong in economics." J.M. Keynes adds:"To convert a model into a quantitative formula is to destroy its usefulness as an instrument of thought."

金融作家 Roger Lowenstein 在When Genius Failed中写道：“下一次 Merton [Robert Merton，1997 年诺贝尔奖获得者开发数学风险管理公式] 提出了一个优雅的模型来管理风险和预测赔率，下一次计算机具有完美的据说对过去的记忆可以量化未来的风险，投资者应该——并且迅速地——转向另一条路。”

Financial writer Roger Lowenstein writes in When Genius Failed:"The next time a Merton [Robert Merton, 1997 Nobel Laureate for developing mathematical risk-management formulas] proposes an elegant model to manage risks and foretell odds, the next time a computer with a perfect memory of the past is said to quantify risks in the future, investors should run — and quickly — the other way."

一个事件以前发生过很多次，并不意味着它会继续发生。仅仅因为某件事以前从未发生过，并不意味着它将来不会发生。以灾难性事件为例。谁能预料到 2001 年 9 月 11 日发生在世贸中心的恐怖袭击？同时劫持四架飞机并用它们攻击美国是不可能的。然而它发生了。

That an event has happened many times before, doesn’t mean that it will continue to happen. And just because an event has never happened before, doesn’t mean it can’t happen in the future. Take catastrophic events as an example. Who could have predicted the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center? Hijacking four planes simultaneously and using them to attack the U.S. was improbable. Yet it happened.

现代史教授理查德·埃文斯 (Richard Evans) 在《捍卫历史》一书中写道：“事实一次又一次地证明，历史对未来事件的预测非常糟糕。这是因为历史永远不会重演；人类社会中没有任何事情……在完全相同的情况下不会发生两次条件或以完全相同的方式。”

Modern History Professor Richard Evans wrote in In Defence of History:"Time and again, history has proved a very bad predictor of future events. This is because history never repeats itself; nothing in human society.. .ever happens twice under exactly the same conditions or in exactly the same way."

有时我们可以猜测某些事情一定会发生，但我们无法预测它们何时会发生。

Sometimes we can guess that certain things are bound to happen, but we can’t predict when they will happen.

两周后会下雨吗？

Will it rain two weeks from now?

有些事情可以短期预测，但无法预测长期。随着时间的推移，微小的变化会产生很大的不同。长期天气预报就是一个例子。许多因素决定了天气。无法提前可靠测量的因素。海洋温度和压力的微小变化可能导致风暴系统未来发展的巨大变化。天气预报越远就越不准确。

Some things are possible to predict short-term but impossible to predict long-term. Small changes make a big difference over time. Long-term weather forecasts are an example. Many factors determine the weather. Factors that can’t be reliably measured ahead of time. Small changes in the temperature and pressure over the ocean can lead to large variations in the future development of storm systems. Weather predictions become more inexact the further out they are.

难点在于初始条件的不确定性和模型误差。例如，变量初始值中的小错误会增加并在预测中产生错误。初始数据也可能存在差距。但即使我们完全了解初始条件，模型也不是完美的。物理或数值中的小模型误差也会增长并产生不同的状态。例如，并非所有的大气过程都被理解。此外，所有天气模型都在有限网格或有限区域上运行，通常在 10 到 100 公里的数量级，具体取决于研究区域。这意味着数值分辨率和表示是有限的。但是许多影响天气的物理过程和特征发生在比网格解析的更小的尺度上。例如，能量在表面转移，小的大气过程（如孤立的雷暴）、地形、湖泊和植被。该模型必须处理或“参数化”这些“子网格”特征对解析尺度的影响。这些参数化是简化和近似，也可能是许多模型误差的原因。因此，即使我们知道天气背后的所有原理以及大气层的主宰因素，基本的局限性也使得我们很难做出准确的预测。

The difficulty lies in initial condition uncertainties and model error. For example, small errors in the initial values of variables can grow and produce errors in the forecast. There may also be gaps in the initial data. But even if we know the initial conditions perfectly, the models are not perfect. Small model errors either in physics or numerics can also grow and produce different states. For example, not all atmospheric processes are understood. Furthermore, all weather models operate on a finite grid or limited area, typically in the order of 10 to 100 kilometers, depending on the study area. This means that the numerical resolution and representation is finite. But many physical processes and features that influence the weather occur on smaller scales than those resolved by the grid. For example, energy transfers at the surface, small atmospheric processes (such as isolated thunderstorms), topography, lakes, and vegetation. The model must treat or"parameterize" the effects of these"sub-grid" features’ effects on the resolved scale. These parameterizations are simplifications and approximations and may also account for many of the model errors. So even if we know all the principles behind the weather and what governs the atmosphere, fundamental limitations make it hard to make accurate predictions.

许多气象学家知道他们无法做出完美的预测，因此放弃了预测未来几天是否会下雨。相反，他们改变了方法并尝试量化预测中的不确定性（“本周六降水概率为 20%”）。这种不确定性在交货时间短时较小，而在交货时间较长时较大。它还随天气情况、位置和预测覆盖区域的大小而变化。当气象学家做出两周后的预报时，他们会查看降水的气候频率，这是根据过去发生的事情的历史来确定的。

Many meteorologists know they can’t make a perfect forecast and have therefore given up on predicting whether it will or will not rain beyond a few days into the future. Instead, they have altered their approach and try to quantify the uncertainty in the prediction ("The probability of precipitation is 20% this Saturday"). This uncertainty is small at short lead times and greater at longer lead times. It also varies with the weather situation, the location and the size of the area the prediction covers. When meteorologists make forecasts two weeks out, they look at the climatological frequency of precipitation, determined from a history of what has happened in the past.

所有预测本质上都是不确定的，我们有责任告诉人们我们预测的不确定性和我们过去的错误率。阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦在 1954 年 3 月 14 日的一封信中写道：“探寻真理的权利……也意味着一种责任；一个人不得隐瞒任何已被确认为真实的部分。”

All prediction is inherently uncertain, and we have a duty to tell people about the uncertainties of our predictions and our past error rates. Albert Einstein wrote in a March 14, 1954, letter:"The right to search for truth... implies also a duty; one must not conceal any part of what one has recognized to be true."

二：规模和限制

Two: Scale and Limits

大小和时间尺度

Scale of size and time

大小或时间的变化会影响形式、功能和行为。如果某个尺寸的东西变大或变小，它可能不会以同样的方式工作。有些事情变得更好，有些则变得更糟。例如，生物体大小的变化会影响其强度、表面积、复杂性、新陈代谢、寿命和运动速度。

Changes in size or time influences form, function and behaviour. If something of a certain size is made bigger or smaller, it may not work the same way. Some things get better and others get worse. For example, changes in the size of an organism affect its strength, surface area, complexity, metabolism, longevity, and speed of movement.

当我们改变尺寸时，重量、强度和表面积如何变化？

How do weight, strength and surface area change when we change size?

如果我们将形状相似的物体的长度加倍，则表面积增加 4 倍，体积增加 8 倍。表面积以长度的平方增加，体积以长度的立方增加（为了得到面积，我们将两个长度相乘，而为了得到体积，我们将三个长度相乘）。

If we double the length of a similarly shaped object, surface area increases 4 times and volume 8 times. Surface area increases at the square of length and volume at the cube of length (to get areas we multiply two lengths together, and to get volumes we multiply three lengths).

随着我们增加尺寸，体积总是比表面积增长得更快，这与物体的形状无关。这限制了事物的大小。

Volume always grows faster than surface area as we increase size, independent of an object’s shape. This places limitations on the size of things.

如果我们使用一个冰块（体积 8）或 8 个较小的冰块（总体积 8），融化时间会有什么不同吗？

Does it make any difference in melting time if we use one ice cube (volume 8) or 8 smaller ones (total volume 8)?

如果我们增加尺寸，体积会比表面积增长得更快。这是什么意思？当我们增加尺寸时，表面积和体积之间的关系会减小。这也意味着当我们减小尺寸时，关系会增加。以冰块为例。假设较大的边长为 2，较小的边长为 1。

If we increase size, volume grows faster than surface area. What does this mean? The relationship between surface area and volume decreases when we increase the size. It also means that the relationship increases when we decrease the size. Take ice cubes as an example. Let’s assume the larger one has a side length of 2 and the smaller ones a side length of 1.

  小冰块 大冰块
边长 1个 2个
截面积（边长）2 1个 4个
总表面积（6 面） 6个 24
体积（边长）3 1个 8（重量）
总表面积与体积之比 6个 3个

正如我们所见，大冰块的每单位体积表面积小于 8 个小冰块。总表面积是冰块所有 6 个表面的总面积。

As we can see, the large ice cube has less surface area per unit volume than 8 small ice cubes. Total surface area is the total area of all 6 surfaces of the ice cube.

这意味着 8 个冰块的表面积为 48 (8 x 6)，而较大的冰块为 24。这也意味着 8 个小冰块比一个大冰块融化得更快，因为一个冰块可以吸收的热量取决于它的表面积（融化过程发生在表面）。每当我们使物体变小时，每单位体积的表面积就会增加。例如，由于铁暴露在空气中会生锈，并且生锈发生在表面，因此钢刀比钢丝绒生锈更慢。

This means that 8 ice cubes have a surface area of 48 (8 x 6) versus 24 for the larger ice cube. This also means that 8 small ice cubes melt faster than one large ice cube, since the amount of heat an ice cube can absorb depend on its surface area (the melting process occurs at the surface). Whenever we make objects smaller, we get more surface area per unit volume. For example, since iron rusts when exposed to air and rusting occur at the surface, a steel knife rusts more slowly than steel wool.

为什么恐龙的头相对于它们的身体这么小？

Why did the dinosaurs have such small heads in relation to their bodies ?

生物是由基本的数学原理塑造和约束的。重量取决于体积和强度或面积的承重能力。肌肉或骨骼的强度是横截面积的函数。强度不会以与重量和体积相同的速度增加。当我们增加尺寸时，重量的增加速度快于强度。放大一个生物体，迟早它会变得太弱而无法支撑自己的重量。体积是小型恐龙的两倍——长、宽和高是原来的两倍——重量是以前的 8 倍。我们现在需要一个比以前强 8 倍的脖子，因为它必须承受 8 倍的重量。但由于颈部的强度与其横截面积成正比，颈部的强度只有 4 倍。有一个地方脖子断了。

Living things are shaped and constrained by basic mathematical principles. Weight depends on volume and strength or load-bearing ability on area. The strength of a muscle or a bone is a function of cross-section area. Strength does not increase at the same rate as weight and volume. When we increase size, weight increases faster than strength. Scale up an organism and sooner or later it will be too weak to support its own weight. Double the size of a small dinosaur — twice as long, wide and high - and it weighs 8 times as much as before. We now need a neck that is 8 times stronger than before since it must hold 8 times the weight. But since the strength of the neck is proportional to its cross-section area, the neck is only 4 times stronger. There comes a point where the neck breaks.

我们在电影中看到的巨人呢？

What about the giants we see in the movies?

假设我们把人造得比正常人大 10 倍。这意味着他现在长了 10 倍，宽了 10 倍，高了 10 倍。他现在的体重增加了 1,000 倍，但他的力量却只增加了 100 倍（因为肌肉力量与肌肉的横截面积成正比）。由于骨骼的承重能力以相同的方式缩放，因此他的骨骼承受的压力是正常人的十倍。他需要更厚的骨头来支撑更多的重量。否则他的腿会被压扁。这就是为什么大象有如此粗短的腿来支撑它们的重量。巨人身体上的肉多 1,000 倍，但只有 100 倍的皮肤才能将其固定在一起，这意味着它的皮肤承受的压力是其十倍（因为压力与面积成正比）。这也就意味着，他的皮肤表面积太小，无法带走他庞大身体散发出来的热量。

Assume we make a human 10 times larger than normal. This means he is now 10 times longer, 10 times wider, and 10 times higher. He now weighs 1,000 times more but he is only 100 times stronger (as muscular strength is proportional to the cross section area of a muscle). Since the load-bearing capacity of bones scales in the same manner his bones would be subject to ten times more stress than normal. He needs thicker bones to support more weight. Otherwise his legs will crush. This is why elephants have such thick stumpy legs to support their weight. The giant has 1,000 times more meat on the body but only 100 times the skin to hold it together meaning ten times the pressure on its skin (since pressure is proportional to area). This also means that his skin surface area is too small to remove the heat emitted from his huge body. He would suffer from overheating since the amount of heat his body produces is proportional to the cube of his length (1,000), while the amount of heat he dissipates through the skin is proportional to the square of his length (100).

英国生物学家 D'Arcy Wentworth Thompson 爵士在《论生长与形态》中说：“大自然无处不在按比例运作，因此一切事物都有其适当的尺寸。人与树、鸟与鱼、星星与星系，都有其合适的尺寸，以及它们或多或少狭窄的绝对幅度范围。”

The British biologist Sir D'Arcy Wentworth Thompson said in On Growth and Form: "Everywhere nature works true to scale, and everything has its proper size accordingly. Men and trees, birds and fishes, stars and star-systems, have their appropriate dimensions, and their more or less narrow range of absolute magnitudes."

无论我们观察它们的比例如何，自然界中的某些事物都具有大致相同的形状或图案。花椰菜的一小部分看起来与整朵花非常相似。其他例子包括云、蕨类植物、雪花、河流网络、血管系统和海岸线结构。

Some things in nature have about the same shape or pattern regardless of the scale we view them. A small part of a cauliflower looks much the same as the entire flower. Other examples include clouds, ferns, snowflakes, river networks, systems of blood vessels and the structure of coastlines.

“约翰需要聘请一名新助理，然后问他的老板：‘我同意你的意见吗？在工资单上增加 20,000 美元应该是无关紧要的。

"John needs to hire a new assistant and ask his boss: ‘Do I have your OK? Adding $20,000 to the payroll should be inconsequential.

比例的概念也适用于时间——事物如何随时间变化或何时重复。沃伦巴菲特会告诉约翰什么？“该提案应该被评估为一项 300 万美元的决定，因为考虑到加薪、福利和其他费用，考虑到一个额外的人在他的一生中可能至少花费这个数额。”

The concept of scale also applies to time — how things change over time or when something is repeated. What would Warren Buffett have told John?"The proposal should be evaluated as a $3 million decision, given that an additional person would probably cost at least that amount over his lifetime, factoring in rises, benefits and other expenses."

长时间运行的小而缓慢的变化可能会产生巨大的后果。例如，我们已经看到随着时间的推移，微小的基因变化会产生重大的解剖学影响。

Small, slow changes operating over long periods can have great consequences. For example, we have seen how small genetic changes can have major anatomical effects over time.

断点、临界阈值和限制

Breakpoints, critical thresholds and limits

在一定规模下，系统达到临界质量或系统行为可能发生巨大变化的极限。它可能工作得更好，更坏，停止工作或改变属性。

At a certain scale, a system reaches a critical mass or a limit where the behaviour of the system may change dramatically. It may work better, worse, cease to work or change properties.

随着时间的推移，小的相互作用会慢慢累积成临界状态——不稳定程度会增加。一个小事件可能会引发像地震这样的巨大变化。

Small interactions over time slowly accumulate into a critical state — where the degree of instability increases. A small event may then trigger a dramatic change like an earthquake.

在达到临界阈值之前，一个小的变化可能不会对系统产生影响。例如，一种药物可能在达到某个阈值之前无效，然后变得有效，或者它可能变得越来越有效，但随后变得有害。

A small change may have no effect on a system until a critical threshold is reached. For example, a drug may be ineffective up until a certain threshold and then become effective, or it may become more and more effective, but then become harmful.

另一个例子来自化学。当一个化学系统达到一定程度的相互作用时，该系统就会发生巨大的变化。一个因素的微小变化可能会产生不明显的影响，但进一步的变化可能会导致系统达到临界阈值，从而使系统运行得更好或更差。

Another example is from chemistry. When a system of chemicals reaches a certain level of interaction, the system undergoes a dramatic change. A small change in a factor may have an unnoticeable effect but a further change may cause a system to reach a critical threshold making the system work better or worse.

当系统的属性突然从一种订单类型变为另一种订单时，系统也可能达到阈值。例如，当铁磁体被加热到临界温度时，它会失去磁化。当它冷却回该温度以下时，磁性就会恢复。

A system may also reach a threshold when its properties suddenly change from one type of order to another. For example, when a ferromagnet is heated to a critical temperature it loses its magnetization. As it is cooled back below that temperature, magnetism returns.

一家公司可能达到一定的临界规模，并在经验、采购、营销、制造、管理、研究、物流、分销等方面获得规模优势。例如，费用可以分摊到更大的数量上，从而降低平均成本。这些优势通常允许更大的专业化，使人们在他们所做的事情上做得更好。

A company may reach a certain critical size and get advantages of scale in experience, purchasing, marketing, manufacturing, administration, research, logistics, distribution, etc. For example, expenses can be spread out over larger amounts of volume, lowering average costs. These advantages often permit greater specialization, making people better at what they do.

沃伦巴菲特在讨论私人飞机公司 Netjets® 时说，规模很重要：

Scale matters, says Warren Buffett discussing the private jet company Netjets®:

我们和我们的客户都从我们成为部分所有权业务的领先者中获得了显着的运营利益。我们有 300 多架飞机在美国不断地运行，因此可以在很短的时间内在客户需要我们的任何地方提供服务。我们车队的无处不在也将我们的“定位”成本降低到低于拥有较小车队的运营商所产生的成本。这些规模优势以及我们拥有的其他优势，使 NetJets 在竞争中具有显着的经济优势。

Both we and our customers derive significant operational benefits from our being the runaway leader in the fractional ownership business. We have more than 300 planes constantly on the go in the U.S. and can therefore be wherever a customer needs us on very short notice. The ubiquity of our fleet also reduces our"positioning" costs below those incurred by operators with smaller fleets. These advantages of scale, and others we have, give NetJets a significant economic edge over competition.

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 告诉我们另一种规模优势：

Charles Munger tells us about another kind of advantage of scale:

在一些企业中，事情的本质是某种程度上导致一家公司的压倒性主导地位。最明显的是日报。美国几乎没有城市，除了一些非常大的城市，那里有不止一份日报……一旦我获得了大部分发行量，我就得到了大部分广告。一旦我获得了大部分的广告和发行量，为什么会有人想要更薄的信息更少的纸呢？因此，它往往会形成赢者通吃的局面。

In some businesses, the very nature of things is to sort of cascade toward the overwhelming dominance of one firm. The most obvious one is daily newspapers. There’s practically no city left in the U.S., aside from a few very big ones, where there’s more than one daily newspaper... Once I get most of the circulation, I get most of the advertising. And once I get most of the advertising and circulation, why would anyone want the thinner paper with less information in it? So it tends to cascade to a winner-take-all situation.

“我们增加了产量，但员工的注意力、服务和积极性却下降了。”

"We increased production volume but employee focus, service, and motivation went down."

在某些时候，企业规模的劣势可能会吞噬优势。例如，成本和投资增加，单位成本增加，系统变得过于复杂、官僚主义和低效等。

At some point the disadvantages of business size may eat into the advantages. For example, increased costs and investments, per-unit cost increases, systems become too complicated, bureaucratic and inefficient, etc.

当我们改变一个群体的规模时，人们的行为可能会改变。在一个规模的群体中行之有效的方法可能在另一个规模的群体中根本行不通。加勒特·哈丁 (Garrett Hardin) 在考察美国西北部的宗教哈特派社区时说明了这一点：

People’s behaviour may change when we change the scale of a group. What works well in a group of one size may not work at all in a group of another size. Garrett Hardin illustrates this as he examines the religious Hutterite communities in the north-western U.S.:

随着群体规模的扩大，个体“根据自己的需要”要求分享生产份额的倾向增加，而他“根据自己的能力”工作的渴望减弱。监督者（传教士或老板）的效率也会降低。然后，随着缩小的增加，那些不太愿意“偷懒”的人开始羡慕他们目前加入的无人机兄弟会。

As a colony grows in size, the propensity of the individual to claim a share of production"according to his needs" increases, while his eagerness to work"according to his ability" diminishes. The effectiveness of the overseers (preachers or bosses) also diminishes. Then, as shrinking increases, those less inclined to"goof off" begin to envy the brotherhood of drones, whom they presently join.

Hutterites 了解到每个决策单元的规模或人数很重要。每个殖民地最多150人，系统可由耻辱之力管理。超过这个规模，对良心的呼吁就会失去效力，个人开始需要的超过他们的贡献。研究表明，大约 150 人的群体在狩猎采集者的氏族和军事单位中很常见。

The Hutterites learned that scale or the number of people in each decision unit is important. Up to 150 people per colony, the system can be managed by the force of shame. Above this size an appeal to conscience loses its effectiveness and individuals begin to need more than they contribute. Studies show that groups of about 150 individuals are common in clans of hunter-gatherers, and military units.

行为和思想的传播取决于规模。在我们跟随他们的领导之前，必须有一定比例或最小数量的人（阈值）做出选择。一些例子是是否加入罢工或骚乱、采纳一个想法、购买产品或股票、就某个问题发表意见，或者离开一个无聊的聚会。一个临界阈值可能会引起大规模的社会模仿。

The spread of behaviour and ideas depends on scale. A certain proportion or minimum number of people (a threshold) must make a choice before we follow their lead. Some examples are whether to join a strike or riot, adopt an idea, buy a product or stock, speak out on an issue, or leave a boring party. A critical threshold may cause massive social imitation.

考虑技术、物理、人类、生物和数学方面的约束和限制。我们发送信号的速度不能超过光速。事物的大小是有限制的。英特尔创始人之一戈登·摩尔 (Gordon Moore) 在 1965 年预测，可以经济地生产并放置在硅芯片上的晶体管数量每 18 个月就会翻一番。1995 年，他将预测更新为每两年一次。但最终，物理、工程或经济限制可能会阻止这种情况发生。

Consider technological, physical, human, biological and mathematical constraints and limits. We can’t send signals faster than the speed of light. There are limits to how small or large something can be. Gordon Moore, one of the founders of Intel, predicted in 1965 that the number of transistors that could be economically produced and placed on a silicon chip would double every 18 months. In 1995 he updated his prediction to once every two years. Eventually though, physical, engineering or economic limits may stop this from happening.

大小和频率

Size and frequency

小地震很常见，大地震很少见。

Small earthquakes are common while big ones are rare.

统计数据表明，某些事件和属性的频率与其大小成反比。或大或小的事情都可能发生，但它们变得越大或越极端，它们发生的频率就越低。例如，有一些大的地震、火灾、雪崩或城市，但有很多小的。亿万富翁很少，但百万富翁很多。

Statistics show that the frequency of some events and attributes are inversely proportional to their size. Big or small things can happen but the bigger or more extreme they get, the less frequent they are. For example, there are a few large earthquakes, fires, avalanches, or cities, but many small ones. There are a few billionaires but many millionaires.

这些事件和属性的大小和频率有一个统计模式——一种与大小无关的比例关系（我们之前看到冰块边长与其体积之间存在比例关系）。例如，地震震级和频率之间存在比例关系。根据 1990 年的观测，美国地质调查局估计 8 级及以上地震的年平均频率为 1 级，7-7.9 级为 17 级，6-6.9 级为 134 级，5-5.9 级为 1319 级地震。尽管如此，这些模式还是基于过去的统计数据和估计。它们无法帮助我们准确预测未来事件。例如，灾难是随机发生的。我们不知道下一个大事件何时会发生。

The size and frequency of these events and attributes has a statistical pattern — a scaling relationship that is about the same independent of size (we saw earlier that there is a scaling relationship between the length of the ice cube’s sides and its volume). For example there is a scaling relationship between earthquake magnitude and frequency. Based on observations from 1990, U.S. Geological Survey estimates the average annually frequency of magnitude 8 and higher earthquakes to 1, magnitude 7-7.9 to 17, magnitude 6-6.9 to 134, and magnitude 5-5.9 to 1319 earthquakes. Still, the patterns are based on past statistics and estimates. They don’t help us to precisely predict future events. For example, catastrophes occur randomly. We don’t know when the next big one will occur.

该部门 85% 的利润来自 25% 的产品。

85% of the profits from the division came from 25% of the products.

意大利经济学家和社会学家维尔弗雷多·帕累托 (Vilfredo Pareto) 指出，他生产的 80% 豌豆仅由 20% 的豌豆荚生产。他还观察到，20% 的人拥有意大利 80% 的土地。通常一些事情会产生很大的影响。例如，少数缺陷会导致大部分问题，或者少数人会导致大部分问题。少数罪犯犯下了大部分罪行。据估计，约有 5% 的电影赚取了电影行业约 80% 至 90% 的利润。这种不平衡在许多其他情况下也很常见，例如医疗保健支出、事故或图书销售。

The Italian economist and sociologist Vilfredo Pareto noted that 80% of his peas were produced by only 20% of the pea-pods. He also observed that 20% of the people owned 80% of Italy’s land. Often a few things cause much of an effect. For example, a few defects produce most of the problem, or a few individuals cause most of the problems. A few criminals commit most of the crime. It is estimated that about 5% of movies earn about 80 to 90% of profits in the movie industry. This unevenness is also common in many other situations like healthcare spending, accidents, or book sales.

沃伦·巴菲特说：“没有必要做非凡的事情才能获得非凡的结果。” 少数产品或少数客户产生了大部分利润，或者少数销售人员产生了大部分销售额。在许多商业活动中，一些事情可以产生很大的价值。问：我们如何分配时间、工作、注意力和金钱？我们能确定几件真正重要的事情吗？

Warren Buffett says:"It is not necessary to do extraordinary things to get extraordinary results." A few products or a few customers produce most of the profit or a few in the sales staff produce most of the sales. In many business activities a few things can produce much of the value. Ask: How do we allocate our time, work, attention and money? Can we identify the few things that really matter?

约束条件

Constraints

“增加产量！”

"Increase production!"

优化一个变量可能会导致整个系统的工作效率降低。为什么？大多数系统的性能都受到其最薄弱环节性能的限制。限制系统实现其目标或最佳性能的变量。例如，产量的增加可能会受到其中一台机器的生产能力的物理限制。如果由两台机器组成的生产线中的一台机器可以生产 100 件产品，而另一台机器可以生产 90 件产品，则产量会受到第二台机器的物理限制。

Optimization of one variable may cause the whole system to work less efficiently. Why? The performance of most systems is constrained by the performance of its weakest link. A variable that limits the system from achieving its goal or optimum performance. An increase in production may for example be physically constrained by the production capacity on one of the machines. If one machine in a production line of two machines can produce 100 items and the second 90, the output is physically constrained by the second machine.

我们要达到什么目的！什么能阻止这种情况发生！为什么！

What do we want to achieve! What will prevent this from happening! Why!

在尝试提高系统性能时，首先要找出系统的关键约束——可能是物理的（容量、材料、市场）或非物理的（政策、规则、测量）——及其因果关系与系统的关系。也许约束是基于可以纠正的错误假设。然后尝试“加强”或改变最薄弱的环节。当心其他效果——想要的或不想要的——因此弹出。始终考虑对整个系统的影响。

When trying to improve the performance of a system, first find out the system’s key constraint(s) - which may be physical (capacity, material, the market) or non-physical (policies, rules, measurements) - and its cause and effect relationship with the system. Maybe the constraint is based on faulty assumptions that can be corrected. Then try to"strengthen" or change the weakest link. Watch out for other effects — wanted or unwanted — that pop up as a consequence. Always consider the effects on the whole system.

三：成因

Three: Causes

“我们通过生产的钢铁数量来衡量和奖励绩效。”

"We measure and reward performance by the quantity of steel produced."

我们想要完成什么？如果我们不了解导致结果发生的原因，就很难取得结果。为了解决问题或实现目标，我们必须首先了解导致我们想要完成的结果的原因。首先检查构成系统的因素以及它们如何连接。然后，定义决定结果的关键因素。

What do we want to accomplish? It’s hard to achieve a result if we don’t understand what causes the result to happen. In order to solve problems or achieve goals, we must first understand what causes the result we want to accomplish. Start with examining what factors make up the system and how they connect. Then, define the key factors that determine outcome.

如果一家企业以生产的钢材数量来衡量绩效，那么他们将生产大量的钢材。但生产的公斤钢量只是方程式的一部分。最好问：实现我们想要实现的目标的方程式是什么？什么因素导致了我们想要达到的目标？在什么情况下？是什么导致商业价值？我们有需要的因素吗？方程式中必须改变什么才能实现我们想要的？我们是否考虑过我们的行为可能产生的其他影响？

If a business measures performance by the amount of steel produced, they will get a lot of steel produced. But the amount of produced kilo steel is only one part of the equation. It’s better to ask: What is the equation that achieves what we want to accomplish? What factors cause what we want to achieve? Under what circumstances? What causes business value? Do we have the factors needed? What must be changed in the equation to achieve what we want? Have we thought through what other effects our actions may have?

大效果

Large effects

一只鸟飞进了飞机的引擎，灾难降临了。

A bird flies into the engine of an aircraft and disaster strikes.

我们相信原因与其结果相似——例如，大的或重要的影响一定有大的原因，或者复杂的结果有复杂的潜在原因。但影响的大小可能与其原因不成正比。小事情可能会破坏一个大系统。1988 年，一列开往伦敦的通勤列车撞上静止列车的尾部，造成 35 人死亡、113 人受伤。事故是由错误的接线工作引起的。一名机械师工作了 12 多个小时，中间只有 5 分钟的休息时间，在安装新的铁路信号系统时忘记从旧开关上拆下一根小电线。

We believe that cause resembles its effect - for example, that large or important effects must have large causes or that complicated outcomes have complicated underlying reasons. But the size of an effect may not be proportional to its cause. Small things may break a large system. In 1988, 35 people died and 113 were injured when a London-bound commuter train crashed into the back of a stationary train. The accident was caused by faulty wiring work. A mechanic worked more than 12 hours with only a 5-minute break and forgot to remove a small wire from an old switch when installing a new rail signalling system.

1999 年 9 月 23 日，火星气候轨道飞行器消失了。

On September 23, 1999, the Mars Climate Orbiter spacecraft disappeared.

发生了什么？核心原因是英制单位（磅）转换为公制单位（牛顿）失败。制造商以磅为单位测量了小型控制推进器的力，但太空官员期望以牛顿为单位。一个误解使航天器离火星太近了大约 56 英里，使其消失在火星大气层中。一个简单的错误导致价值 1.25 亿美元的航天器损失。

What happened? The core cause was the failed conversion of English units (pounds) to metric units (newton). The manufacturer measured the force of small control thrusters in pounds but the space officials expected newtons. A misunderstanding that sent the spacecraft about 56 miles too close to Mars, making it disappear into the Martian atmosphere. A simple mistake caused the loss of a $ 125 million spacecraft.

洗手可以挽救生命。

Washing hands save lives.

脏手会导致严重的健康问题。在通过每半小时自我分裂进行繁殖的细菌中，一个细菌可以在 12 小时内产生大约 1700 万个后代。美国疾病控制与预防中心 (CDC) 的记录显示，美国每年有近 200 万人（每年入院人数为 3500 万人）在医院感染。在这些人中，约有 90,000 人死于感染。主要原因是不卫生的环境、充满细菌的仪器和未洗手等不良卫生习惯。CDC 和美国卫生与公众服务部估计，仅严格遵守清洁手政策就可以挽救 20,000 名患者的生命。

Dirty hands can cause major health problems. Among bacteria that reproduce by dividing themselves every half hour, a single one can generate about 17 million offspring within 12 hours. Records at the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) show that every year close to 2 million people (out of 35 million admissions annually) in the U.S. pick up an infection in the hospital. Of those people, about 90,000 die as a result of their infection. And the major reason is bad hygiene like unsanitary conditions, germ-laden instruments and unwashed hands. CDC and the U.S. Department and Health and Human Services estimate that strict adherence to clean-hand policies alone could save the lives of 20,000 patients.

1847 年，匈牙利妇科医生 Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis 发现洗手可以挽救生命。在维也纳医院妇产科工作时，他观察到医学生接生的产妇死亡率很高，而助产士实习生接生的产褥热发生率很低。区别？医学生在对这些女性进行检查之前已经做过病理解剖，或者接触过尸体。Semmelweis 引入了在每次检查前用氯化石灰溶液洗手的做法，死亡率直线下降。

That washing hands saved lives was discovered in 1847 by the Hungarian gynaecologist Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis. When working at the Maternity Department of the Vienna Hospital, he observed that women delivered by medical students had high mortality rates while those delivered by midwife trainees had low rates of child-bed fever. The difference? The medical students had made pathological dissections, or had come into contact with dead bodies before the examination of the women. Semmelweis introduced the practice of washing hands in a solution of chlorinated lime before every examination and mortality rates plummeted.

随机事件

Random events

“我们供应商的工厂发生火灾，导致组件交付出现问题。我们在竞争中失去了市场份额，造成了巨大的损失。这种结果是不可预见的，因为我们无法提前预测到火灾。”

"A fire in our supplier’s factory caused delivery problems of components. We lost market share to competition, which resulted in huge losses. This outcome was unforeseeable since we couldn’t have predicted the fire in advance."

当坏事发生时，我们试图找到因果解释或归咎于某些事情。我们发现事件越出乎意料或越消极，我们就越有可能寻找解释。我们低估了随机性的影响。

When bad things happen, we try to find causal explanations or something to blame. The more unexpected or negative we find an event, the more likely we are to look for explanations. We underestimate the influence of randomness.

这里我们将随机事件定义为由于缺乏知识而无法预测的事件。当我们没有足够的信息来提前确定事件的结果时，事件就是随机的。

Here we define a random event as an event that can’t be predicted because of a lack of knowledge. An event is random when we don’t have enough information to determine its outcome in advance.

根据症状采取行动

Acting on symptoms

除去因，果就会消失。

Take away the cause, and the effect ceases.

- 米格尔德塞万提斯

（来自堂吉诃德）

- Miguel De Cervantes

(from Don Quixote)

有时我们会把结果误认为是原因。有一个故事，讲的是一个男人正在河边行走，突然一个尖叫的女孩从身边飘过。男人跳进河里救了她。五分钟后，另一个尖叫的女孩飘了过来。他再次跳进去救了女孩。同样的事情一遍又一遍地发生。问题出在河的上游一点。有一个男人从桥上扔女孩。我们的英雄解决了症状，但没有解决问题的原因。

Sometimes we mistake an effect for its cause. There is a story about a man that was walking by a river when suddenly a screaming girl floated by. The man jumped in the river and saved her. After five minutes, another screaming girl floated by. He jumped in again and saved the girl. The same thing happened over and over again. The problem was a little further up the river. There was a man throwing girls from a bridge. Our hero solved the symptoms but not the cause of the problem.

“我们有很多问题。我们正在失去客户，我们无法按时交货，我们的库存系统不起作用。”

"We have tons of problems. We are losing customers, we can’t deliver on time, our inventory system doesn’t work."

造成这些问题的核心原因是什么？很多时候，当我们遇到很多问题时，它们可能都有一个共同的原因。在处理问题时，我们必须专注于我们想要实现的目标，并确保我们解决根本原因，而不是表面上看起来像是原因的症状。也许症状是由于错误的政策或测量工具或目标等引起的。

What is the core cause of these problems? Many times when we have a lot of problems, there may be one common reason for them all. When dealing with problems we must focus on what we want to achieve and make sure that we address the underlying cause and not act on symptoms that may look like causes. Maybe the symptoms were due to wrong policies or measuring instruments or goals, etc.

多种原因

Multiple causes

当有多种原因时，我们将结果归因于单一原因。我们假设 A 导致 B，但 A 可能不是导致 B 的唯一原因。给定结果可能有很多原因。

We attribute an outcome to a single cause when there are multiple causes. We assume that A causes B but A may not be the only thing that causes B. There may be many causes for a given effect.

例如，行为是由多种心理和非心理因素、个人特征和特定情况决定的。有时这些因素相互作用并相互加强。在解释行为时，考虑多种原因。例如，查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 在谈到第二部分中讨论的米尔格拉姆实验时说（在该实验中，一组研究对象仅仅因为权威人物的指示而进行电击）：

For example, behaviour is determined by a multitude of psychological and non-psychological factors, individual characteristics and the given situation. Sometimes these factors interact and reinforce each other. When explaining behaviour, think in terms of multiple causes. For example, Charles Munger says on the Milgram experiment discussed in Part Two (where a group of research subjects delivered electric shocks simply because they were told to do so by an authoritative figure):

多年来，它在心理学书籍中作为权威的证明——权威如何被用来说服人们做可怕的事情。当然，这只是先入为主的偏见。这不是完整和正确的解释。权威是其中的一部分。然而，也有相当多的其他心理学原则[一致性、对比、尊重理性]，都在同一个方向上运作，正是因为它们共同作用于同一个目的，才实现了这种 lollapalooza 效应。

For years it was in the psychology books as a demonstration of authority — how authority could be used to persuade people to do awful things. Of course, that’s mere first-conclusion bias. That’s not the complete and correct explanation. Authority is part of it. However, there was also quite a few other psychological principles [consistency, contrast, reason-respecting], all operating in the same direction, which achieved that lollapalooza effect precisely because they acted in combination toward the same end.

将相关性误认为原因

Mistaking correlation for cause

相关性是指两个或多个变量之间的关系或关联。我们倾向于假设，当两件事同时发生时，一件事会导致另一件事。一个变量的变化与另一个变量的变化密切相关或紧随其后并不自动意味着一个变量会导致另一个变量。某些第三个因素可能导致它们两者。假设我们发现金钱和幸福之间存在高度相关性。但这并没有告诉我们是金钱导致幸福，幸福是否导致金钱，或者是否有第三个因素导致两者。

Correlation means a relationship or association between two or more variables. We tend to assume that when two things happen together, that one causes the other. That a change in one variable is strongly correlated or followed by a change in another doesn’t automatically mean that one causes the other. Some third factor may cause them both. Assume we detect a high correlation between money and happiness. But that doesn’t tell us if money causes happiness, if happiness causes money, or if some third factor causes them both.

统计滥用的一个例子是 1992 年，据报道有 28 名经常玩“龙与地下城”(D&D) 游戏的青少年自杀。应该得出什么结论？青少年自杀和游戏之间有联系吗？

An example of statistical misuse is from 1992 when it was reported that 28 teenagers who frequently played the game of"Dungeons and Dragons" (D&D) committed suicide. What conclusion should be drawn? Is there a link between teenage suicide and the game?

美国数学家约翰·艾伦·保罗斯 (John Allen Paulos) 在 Innumeracy 中告诉我们，要通过考虑另外两个事实来正确看待这一说法。该游戏售出数百万份，约有 300 万青少年玩过。在那个年龄段，年自杀率约为每 10 万人中有 12 人自杀。这意味着我们可以预期 360 名玩 D&D 的青少年（12/100,000 x 300 万玩家）会自杀。

The American mathematician John Allen Paulos tells us in Innumeracy to put this statement into the right perspective by considering two more facts. The game sold millions of copies and about 3 million teenagers played it. In that age group the annual suicide rate is about 12 people per 100,000. This means that we can expect 360 D&D playing teenagers (12/100,000 x 3 million players) to commit suicide.

替代解释

Alternative explanations

“玛丽发烧了，所以她感冒了。”

"Mary has a fever and therefore she has a cold."

对于给定的结果可能有多种解释。但我们常常仓促下结论而没有考虑其他解释。给定的结果可能与一系列原因一致，并不能帮助我们找到问题的核心原因。

There may be many explanations for a given outcome. But we often jump to conclusions and fail to consider alternative explanations. A given effect may be consistent with a range of causes and don’t help us find the core cause of a problem.

玛丽发烧告诉我们她身体不舒服，但并没有告诉我们她为什么生病。一系列疾病都可能引起发烧。问：还有什么可以解释这个结果？

That Mary has a fever tells us that she is not well but it doesn’t tell us why she is ill. Fever can occur from a range of diseases. Ask: What else can explain this outcome?

选择性数据和适当的比较

Selective data and appropriate comparisons

没有什么比显而易见的事实更具有欺骗性了。

There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact.

- 夏洛克·福尔摩斯

（亚瑟·柯南·道尔，博斯科姆谷之谜）

- Sherlock Holmes

(Arthur Conan Doyle, The Boscombe Valley Mystery)

我们确定了错误的原因，因为它似乎是基于单个观察到的效果的显而易见的原因。正如伯特兰·罗素所说：“显而易见永远是正确的敌人。”

We identify the wrong cause because it seems the obvious one based on a single observed effect. As Bertrand Russell says:"Obviousness is always the enemy to correctness."

当有人对法国作家伏尔泰说“生活是艰难的”时，他反驳道，“与什么相比？” 我们倾向于忽略替代方案，因此我们无法进行适当的比较。通常我们只考虑提供的或可用的信息或证据，而不考虑可能丢失的信息。

When someone remarked to the French writer Voltaire,"Life is hard," he retorted,"Compared to what?" We tend to ignore alternatives, and therefore we fail to make appropriate comparisons. Often we only consider information or evidence that is presented or available and don’t consider that information may be missing.

“通过研究成功的企业，我发现他们成功的秘诀就是专注，”TransCorp 的首席执行官说。

"By studying successful businesses, I have found that their secret to success is focus," said the CEO of TransCorp.

但许多失败的企业也有重点。那么，成功是由于强大的文化、有远见的领导者还是其他原因？也许失败的企业也有强大的文化和有远见的领导者。要了解哪些品质导致成功，我们需要将商业成功与失败进行比较。我们必须包括以相同质量起步但失败的公司。但问题是，故障数据经常会消失。此外，在一种情况下有效的方法在另一种情况下可能会失败。

But many failed businesses also had focus. Is success, then, due to strong culture, visionary leaders, or something else? Maybe failed enterprises also had strong cultures and visionary leaders. To understand what qualities cause success, we need to compare business successes with failures. We must include companies that started with the same quality but failed. The problem though, is that the data for failures often disappears. Furthermore, what works in one situation may fail in another.

通过采访致命航空事故的幸存者，一篇 1986 年的Discover文章提出了一些关于如何提高我们在飞机失事中幸存的机会的技巧。但正如心理学教授罗宾·道斯 (Robyn Dawes) 所指出的那样，没有评估所有乘客中有多少百分比做了幸存者所做的事情。也许那些死去的人也做了同样的事情。当然，我们不能采访那些没有活下来的乘客。

By interviewing survivors of fatal airline accidents, a 1986 Discover article presented some tips on how we could improve our chances of surviving plane crashes. But as noted by Psychology Professor Robyn Dawes, there was no evaluation of what percent of all passengers did what the survivors did. Maybe those who died also had done the same. Of course, we can’t interview the passengers who didn’t survive.

通常使用相同的属性来解释成功和失败。例如，当一家公司成功时，媒体说这是因为它的专注和出色的领导。当业绩下降时，他们报告说公司变得不那么专注，其领导层也在恶化。虽然可能有证据表明该公司比以前更不专注或领导能力更差，但也可能是竞争变得更好了。经营业绩是相对的，不是绝对的。企业的业绩总是受到其竞争对手行为的影响。即使一家公司在许多领域变得更好，如果竞争对手做得更好，市场份额和利润也可能会下降。即使一家公司在许多领域变得更糟，如果竞争使事情变得更糟，市场份额和利润也可能会增加。

Often the same attributes are used to explain both success and failure. For example, when a company is successful, the media say that it is because of its focus and great leadership. When performance goes down, they report that the company became less focused and its leadership deteriorated. While there may be evidence that the company is less focused or has worse leadership than before, it could just as well be that the competition has gotten better. Business performance is relative, not absolute. The performance of a business is always influenced by what its competitors do. Even if a company gets better in many areas, market share and profits may decline if the competition does things even better. And even if a company gets worse in many areas, market share and profits may increase if competition does things even worse.

“看看弹孔在哪里，在其他地方加装额外的装甲。”

"Look at where the bullet holes are and put extra armour every place else."

第二次世界大战期间，统计学家亚伯拉罕沃尔德试图确定应该在何处为飞机增加额外的装甲。根据返航飞机的弹孔样式，他建议对未被击中的部位加装额外的装甲进行保护。他是怎么得出这个结论的？因为他还考虑了没有返回的飞机。假设所有飞机都或多或少均匀地被击中。一些在标记区域被击中的飞机仍然能够返回。这意味着没有返回的飞机很可能在其他地方被击中——在没有标记的地方。这些是需要更多装甲的区域。

During World War II, the statistician Abraham Wald tried to determine where one should add extra armour to air-planes. Based on the patterns of bullet holes in returning air-planes, he suggested that the parts not hit should be protected with extra armour. How could he reach that conclusion? Because he also considered planes that didn’t return. Assume that all planes had been hit more or less uniformly. Some planes hit in marked areas were still able to return. This means that planes that didn’t return were most likely hit somewhere else - in unmarked places. These were the areas that needed more armour.

“自从我使用了它之后，这种药显然起了作用，并且变得更好了。”

"The drug obviously worked since I used it and got better."

但如果不服用药物，同样的结果也可能发生。我们需要同时考虑证实和否定证据。问：与否定案例相比，支持案例的频率是多少？这种情况或疾病在人群中的相对频率是多少？

But the same outcome could have happened without taking the drug. We need to consider both confirming and dis-confirming evidence. Ask: What is the frequency of supporting cases compared to dis-confirming cases? What is the relative frequency of this condition or disease in the population?

例如，在研究一种新疗法的有效性时，人们往往会忽略非治疗的结果，而只关注大量成功的治疗，并因此得出治疗有效的结论。但我们还必须查看以下情况的人数：a) 使用治疗但未改善，b) 未使用治疗但有所改善，c) 未使用治疗且未改善。

For example, when studying the effectiveness of a new treatment, people often ignore the outcome of a non-treatment, and focus only on a large number of successful treatments, and therefore conclude that the treatment is effective. But we also have to look at the number of people who a) use the treatment and don’t improve, b) don’t use the treatment and improve, and c) don’t use the treatment and don’t improve.

在一项研究中，人们被要求根据以下实验数据来判断治疗的有效性：

In one study people were asked to judge the effectiveness of a treatment based on the following data from an experiment:

  改进 没提升
治疗 200人 75
没有 治疗 50 15

大多数受试者认为治疗是有效的。但它是相当无效的。为什么？我们需要将未治疗组的结果与治疗组的结果进行比较。65 人中有 50 人 (50+15) 或约 77%，在没有任何治疗的情况下有所改善，而 275 人中有 200 人 (200+75) 或约 73% 在接受治疗后有所改善。

Most subjects believed the treatment was effective. But it is rather ineffective. Why? We need to compare the outcome for the no treatment group with the outcome for the treatment group. 50 of 65 people (50+15) or about 77%, improved without any treatment versus 200 of 275 (200+75) people or about 73% who improved with the treatment.

心理学教授 Thomas Gilovich 在How We Know What Isn't So中说：“由于身体能够如此有效地自我治愈，即使医生没有采取任何有益措施，许多寻求医疗帮助的人也会获得积极的结果。因此，即使是毫无价值的治疗也可以当基本成功率如此之高时显得有效。”

Psychology Professor Thomas Gilovich says in How We Know What Isn’t So: "With the body so effective in healing itself, many who seek medical assistance will experience a positive outcome even if the doctor does nothing beneficial. Thus, even a worthless treatment can appear effective when the base-rate of success is so high."

是什么导致了 TransCorp 的客户投诉？

What caused customer complaints at TransCorp?

在我们知道发生了什么之后，我们会寻找明显的原因并查看特定情况下出现的条件和行为。但是我们应该观察通常发生的事情。大多数结果都取决于上下文。

We look for obvious causes and look at the conditions and behaviour that were present in the particular situation after we know what happened. But we should observe what is normally happening. Most outcomes are context-dependent.

TransCorp 不应专注于客户投诉之前的情况和行为，而应检查无投诉和有投诉的销售情况，并询问：客户未投诉时的基本情况和行为是什么？是否存在可以解释投诉的差异？

Instead of concentrating on conditions, and behaviour preceding the customer complaint, TransCorp should examine both sales without complaints and with complaints and ask: What were the underlying conditions and behaviour when customers didn’t complain? Are there differences that can explain the complaints?

对于类似情况，问：与什么相比？将消极结果与积极结果进行比较。哪些因素不同？与事情正常时的条件和行为相比，坏事发生的潜在条件和行为是什么？什么区分情况？不要从可能是独特或随机的事件中得出结论。

For similar situations, ask: Compared with what? Compare negative outcomes with positive. What factors differ? What were the underlying conditions and behaviour where something bad happened compared to the conditions and behaviour when things worked? What differentiates the situations? Don’t draw conclusions from what may have been a unique or random event.

四：数字及其意义

Four: Numbers and Their Meaning

使用基础数学计算、量化和理解关系

Use basic maths to count, quantify, and understand relationships

约翰买了所有他能买的股票，因为它的价格只有 1 美元。

John bought all the stock he could since it was priced at only $1.

某物仅相对于另一物而言便宜或昂贵。如果投资者称一只股票“便宜”，那么它相对于什么东西便宜呢？100,000 股定价为 1 美元的股票与 1,000 股定价为 100 美元的股票具有相同的市场估值。相关问题是：相对于其价格，该公司的价值是多少？

Something is only cheap or expensive in relation to something else. If an investor refers to a stock as"cheap," what is it cheap in relation to? 100,000 shares of stock priced at $1 have the same market valuation as 1,000 shares priced at $100. The relevant question is: What is the company worth in relation to its price?

TransCorp 赚取了 10 亿美元的“巨额”利润。

TransCorp made a"huge" $1 billion in profits.

像“大”或“小”这样的词本身没有任何意义。一个数字只有相对于另一个数字的大小。除非我们将它与产生它所需的资本进行比较，否则 10 亿美元对经济表现毫无意义。如果 TransCorp 需要 1000 亿美元的股权和债务来经营业务怎么办？那只是1%的回报。

Words like"big" or"small" have no meaning in themselves. A number has only a size in relation to another number. $1 billion says nothing about economic performance unless we compare it with how much capital was needed to generate it. What if TransCorp needed $ 100 billion in equity and debt to run the business? That’s only a 1% return.

“研究表明，这种新药可将患这种疾病的风险降低 25%。”

"Research shows that the new drug reduces the risk of getting the disease by 25%."

服用这种新药可以预期有什么好处？假设统计数据显示如下：如果没有药物，1,000 人中有 20 人会患病。通过服药，这一数字下降到千分之十五。如果我们看一下从这种疾病中拯救出来的绝对人数，这种药物的有效性如何？绝对风险的降低是 1,000 人中有 5 人 (20-15) 或 0.5%。相对风险的降低或从疾病中获救的相对人数为 25% (5/20)。25% 的减少只有在很多人得救的情况下才有意义。

What benefits can be expected by taking the new drug? Assume statistics show the following: Without the drug 20 people in 1,000 get the disease. By taking the drug, the figure drops to 15 people in 1,000. How efficient is the drug if we look at the absolute number of people saved from the disease? The reduction in absolute risk is 5 people in 1,000 (20-15) or 0.5%. The reduction in relative risk or the relative number of people saved from the disease is 25% (5/20). A 25% reduction only means something if many people are saved.

为了使一个人免于疾病，需要多少人服药？由于每 1,000 人中有 5 人（或 200 人中有 1 人）因服药而免于疾病，因此服药的 200 人中只有 1 人会得救。对于其他 199 人，药物没有任何积极作用。

How many people need to take the drug in order to save one individual from the disease? Since 5 people in 1,000 (or 1 in 200) are saved from the disease by taking the drug, only one person out of 200 that take the drug will be saved. For the other 199 people the drug does not have any positive effect.

我们怎么知道研究结果是真的？流行病学调查（影响健康和疾病的因素的研究）表明，由于偏差和随机误差，许多研究人员的说法在医学试验中无法复制。例如，两个被驳回的说法是阿司匹林对男性和女性的心脏病都有很强的保护作用，维生素 E 可以降低心血管死亡率。卫生与流行病学教授 John Ioannidis 的研究表明，研究规模越小；效应量越小；场地越热；利息越大；数据库越大；分析的灵活性越大，研究声明错误的可能性就越大。真正的重复是科学的基石，假设消除了偏见，越多的研究人员重复发现，

How do we know that research findings are true? Surveys of epidemiological studies (studies of factors affecting health and illness) show that many researchers’ claims don’t replicate in medical trials because of bias and random error. For example, two refuted claims are that aspirin is highly protective against heart disease in both men and women and that vitamin E reduces the chance of cardiovascular mortality. Studies by Hygiene and Epidemiology Professor John Ioannidis show that the smaller the studies; the smaller the effect sizes; the hotter the field; the greater the interest; the larger the databases; and the greater the flexibility in analyses, the higher the chance that a research claim is false. True replication is the cornerstone of science, and assuming that biases are weeded out, the more researchers reproduce a finding, the better chance it has of being true.

我们的太阳距离我们有 9300 万英里，这意味着什么？

What does it mean that our sun is 93 million miles away?

通常我们需要将数字翻译成更容易理解的东西。光以每秒 186,281 英里的平均速度传播。这意味着太阳光到达地球大约需要 8 分钟。半人马座阿尔法星距离我们有 4.35 光年。一光年是光在一年内传播的距离。即使光年测量距离，它也意味着时间。如果我们骑在一束光上，我们需要 4.35 年才能到达离我们最近的恒星。当我们仰望天空时，我们看到了过去——4.35 年前出现的恒星。

Often we need to translate a number to something more understandable. Light travels at an average speed of 186,281 miles per second. This means that it takes sunbeams about 8 minutes to reach the earth. The star Alpha Centauri is 4.35 light-years away. A light-year is the distance light travels in one year. Even if light-year measures distance, it implies time. If we were to ride on a beam of light, it would take us 4.35 years to reach our closest star. When we look up in the sky we see the past - the star as it appeared 4.35 years ago.

始终查看数字的含义。例如，问：量级有意义吗？关于什么？另外，想想什么是重要的——而不是如何计算的。物理学家阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦在普林斯顿的办公室里挂着一块牌子，上面写着：“Not everything that counts can be counted, and not everything that can be counted counts.”

Always look at what numbers mean. For example, ask: Does the magnitude make sense? In relation to what? Also, think about what counts — not how it is counted. There was a sign hanging in the physicist Albert Einstein’s office at Princeton that said:"Not everything that counts can be counted, and not everything that can be counted counts."

指数增长的影响

The effect of exponential growth

约翰的儿子大卫提出了一个建议，“我一个月每天都倒垃圾，你今天只要付我一分钱，以后每天我要的是前一天的两倍。”

John’s son David made a proposal,"I take out the garbage every day for a month, and you only have to pay me a penny today and then every day afterwards I want double as much as I got the day before."

数字 2、4、8、16 的序列呈指数增长。第 2 天，他的儿子将有 2 美分，第 3 天，4 美分。27 天后，他将拥有 130 万美元。个人成长是恒定的——每天 100%——但总和变得越来越快。这就是倍增的力量。

The sequence of numbers 2, 4, 8, 16 grows exponentially. Day 2 his son would have 2 cents, day 3, 4 cents. After 27 days, he would have $1.3 million dollars. The individual growth is constant — 100% a day — but the sum gets higher faster and faster. This is the power of doubling.

正如我们所见，长期增长是有限度的。以细菌为例。假设某种细菌菌株在一分钟内分裂。我们在上午 11 点将细菌放入瓶子中，中午瓶子就装满了。什么时候瓶子是半满的？— 上午 11:59。就在一分钟前。

As we have seen there are limits to prolonged growth. Take bacteria as an example. Assume that a certain strain of bacteria divide in one minute. We put the bacteria in a bottle at 11 am and the bottle is full at noon. When was the bottle half full? — 11:59 am. Just one minute earlier.

即使是少量的稳定增长最终也会导致翻倍和再翻倍。例如，一个国家的人口每年增长 2%，人口在 35 年内翻一番，并在 70 年内再翻一番。通过将 70 除以每年的增长率，可以找到一个计算翻倍时间的简单公式。

Even a small number of steady growth leads eventually to doubling and redoubling. For example, a country whose population grows by 2% a year, double in size in 35 years and redoubles in 70 years. A simple formula for doubling time is found by dividing 70 by the percent growth per year.

复利指的是“利息加利息”。如果我们以每年 6% 的回报率投资 1,000 美元，我们在第一年会收到 60 美元。如果我们将这 60 美元再投资，明年我们会从最初的 1,000 美元投资中再获得 60 美元，再加上我们再投资的 60 美元中的 3.6 美元。如果我们将所有回报再投资，5 年后我们最初的 1,000 美元投资的总价值为：1,000 美元 x 1.06 x 1.06 x 1.06 x 1.06 x 1.06 = 1,338 美元。

Compounding refers to"interest on interest." If we invest $1,000 with a return of 6% a year, we receive $60 in the first year. If we reinvest that $60, next year we get another $60 from our original $1,000 investment, plus $3.6 from the $60 we reinvested. If we reinvest all our returns, the total value of our original $1,000 investment after 5 years is: $1,000 x 1.06 x 1.06 x 1.06 x 1.06 x 1.06 = $1,338.

时间是复利的关键。在短期内，复合会产生一些额外的回报。在很长一段时间内，它会产生巨大的影响。每年投资 2,500 美元，持续 40 年，回报率为 10%，您将成为百万富翁。

Time is the key to compound interest. Over short periods, compounding produces a little extra return. Over long periods, it has an enormous effect. Invest $2,500 each year for 40 years at 10% return and you will be a millionaire.

金钱的时间价值

The time value of money

可以掌握的小东西，胜过没有把握的大东西。

A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

- 伊索

- Aesop

为什么我们必须减少未来收到的钱的价值？

Why must we reduce the value of money we receive in the future?

未来支付的钱比今天支付的钱更不值钱。今天收到的一美元比明天收到的一美元更值钱。如果我们今天有一美元，我们可以将其投资并赚取利息，使该美元在未来变得比一美元更有价值。这意味着货币是有价格的，而这个价格就是利息。

Money paid in the future is worth less than money paid today. A dollar received today is worth more than a dollar received tomorrow. If we have a dollar today, we can invest it and earn interest making that dollar worth more than a dollar in the future. This means that money has a price and that price is interest.

我们今天应该为从现在起每年收到 1,000 美元的权利支付多少钱？或者，我们今天需要投资多少才能从现在起每年拥有 1,000 美元？这是同一个问题。答案取决于利率。如果利率为 6%，则答案为 943 美元。如果我们今天以 6% 的利率投资 943 美元，一年后我们就有 1,000 美元。943 美元是从现在起一年后 1,000 美元的现值。我们已将 1,000 美元折价或减价至其今天的价值。我们收到 1,000 美元的时间越晚或利率越高，现值就越低。

How much should we pay today for the right of receiving $1,000 a year from now? Or, how much do we need to invest today in order to have $ 1,000 a year from now? It’s the same question. The answer depends on the interest rate. If the rate is 6%, then the answer is $943. If we invest $943 today at 6%, we have $ 1,000 one year from now. $943 is the present value of $ 1,000 a year from now. We have discounted or reduced $ 1,000 to its value today. The further out in time we receive the $1,000 or the higher the interest rate is, the less the present value is.

五：可能结果的概率和数量

Five: Probabilities And Number of Possible Outcomes

概率是生活的指南。

Probability is the very guide of life.

——马库斯·图留斯·西塞罗

- Marcus Tullius Cicero

我们相信某些事件会发生的可能性有多大？概率就像猜测。但正如理查德·费曼在他的加州理工学院物理讲座中所说：“有好的猜测，也有坏的猜测。概率论是一个可以做出更好猜测的系统。”

How likely do we believe it is that some event will occur? Probabilities are like guesses. But as Richard Feynman said in his Caltech Lectures on Physics:"There are good guesses and there are bad guesses. The theory of probability is a system for making better guesses."

我们可以根据其相对频率（事件在过去类似情况下发生的次数的比例）来估计概率，或者我们可以使用过去的经验或任何可用的重要和相关信息和证据进行有根据的猜测。

We can either estimate the probability based on its relative frequency (proportion of times the event happened in similar situations in the past) or we can make an educated guess using past experiences or whatever important and relevant information and evidence that is available.

我们还可以计算可能的结果。只有在我们知道所有可能的结果并且所有结果的可能性均等的情况下，我们才能提前（通过大量试验）计算出事件的确切概率。这适用于投掷硬币或掷骰子等机会游戏。无论我们如何使用概率的概念，我们都需要遵循它的基本规则。

We can also count possible outcomes. The only time we can calculate the exact probability of an event in advance (over a large number of trials) is in cases where we know all possible outcomes and where all outcomes are equally likely. This is applicable for games of chance such as tossing a coin or rolling a die. However we use the notion of probability, we need to follow its basic rules.

飓风袭击德克萨斯州的可能性有多大？

How likely is it that a hurricane strikes Texas?

根据美国国家飓风中心的数据，从 1900 年到 1996 年，得克萨斯州发生了 36 次飓风袭击。根据过去的经验，在条件不变的情况下，我们可以估计飓风发生的可能性约为 37% (36/97)将在任何一年袭击德克萨斯州。这个数字 - 36/97 - 也称为结果的基本频率（德克萨斯州的飓风）。

According to the National Hurricane Center, there have been 36 hurricane strikes in Texas from 1900 to 1996. Based on past experience and barring no change in conditions, we can estimate that there is about a 37% (36/97) chance that a hurricane will strike Texas in any given year. This figure - 36/97 - is also called the base rate frequency of outcomes (hurricanes in Texas).

我们必须确保产生相对频率的条件可以预期几乎相同，然后才能将其用作未来的指南。

We must make sure that the conditions that produced the relative frequency can be expected to be pretty much the same before we can use it as a guide for the future.

我们还必须查看结果和严重程度的变化（一个事件可能造成多大的损害）。以龙卷风为例。根据国家气候数据中心的数据，从 1950 年到 1999 年，美国平均每年发生 810 次龙卷风，但 1950 年有 201 次龙卷风（造成 70 人死亡），1975,919 次（造成 60 人死亡），1999 年, 1,342 次龙卷风（造成 94 人死亡）。

We must also look at variations of outcome and severity (how much damage an event may cause). Take tornadoes as an example. According to the National Climatic Data Center, between 1950 to 1999 there has been an average of 810 tornadoes yearly in the U.S. But in 1950 there was 201 tornadoes (causing 70 deaths), in 1975,919 (causing 60 deaths), and in 1999, 1,342 tornadoes (causing 94 deaths).

一位医生说，“我第一次见到这种病，我估计病人有50-50的机会活下来。”

A doctor says,"This is the first time I’ve seen this disease. I estimate there is a 50-50 chance that the patient will survive."

该声明只有两种可能的结果。病人要么死，要么不死。如果没有过去的数据或其他证据作为概率的基础，说“50-50 的机会”真的有意义吗？它真的告诉我们什么吗？如果没有历史的、可比较的或有代表性的数据或其他证据作为估计的基础，则概率数字只能衡量医生对事件结果的信念。

This statement has only two possible outcomes. Either the patient dies or not. Does it really make any sense to say"a 50-50 chance" if there are no past data or other evidence to base the probability on? Does it really tell us something? If there are no historical, comparable or representative data or other evidence to base an estimate on, the probability figure only measures the doctor’s belief in the outcome of the event.

另一位医生说，“根据类似病例的病历，在相同条件下，50%的患者存活了五年或更长时间。”

Another doctor says,"According to medical records of similar cases, under the same conditions, 50% of the patients survived five years or longer."

我们拥有的背景数据或证据越有代表性，我们对概率的估计就越好。

The more representative background data or evidence we have the better our estimate of the probability.

为了进一步缩小概率数字，我们需要一个相关的比较组，即一个频率所指的组。在飓风示例中，我们定义了特定比较组的概率，指的是飓风发生的相对频率（在我们有数据的 97 年中，德克萨斯州发生了 37 次）。

To narrow down the probability figure even more, we need a relevant comparison group, i.e., a group to which a frequency refers. In the hurricane example, we defined the probability for a specific comparison group, referring to the relative frequency with which hurricanes have occurred (37 times in Texas during the 97 years for which we have data).

事件发生的频率可能很高，也可能很少。有些事件是不可重复的，有些事件以前从未发生过。对于某些事件，过去的经验可能不具有代表性。其他人的特点是过去频率低和严重程度高。在我们的实际风险（衡量脆弱性和潜在成本或损失）未知的情况下，会发生不可预见的事件。有时人们通过在未来避免或阻止事件来对事件做出反应，从而导致事件未来概率的变化。其他时候，一件坏事可能会增加另一件坏事发生的可能性。例如，地震可能会导致山体滑坡、洪水或停电。不确定性越大，就越难找到有意义的概率数。相反，我们的估计必须限于一系列可能的结果及其概率。

Events may happen with great frequency or rarely. Some events are not repeatable and some events have never happened before. For certain events, past experience may not be representative. Others are characterized by low past frequency and high severity. Unforeseen events occur where our actual exposure (measures vulnerability and potential cost or loss) is unknown. Sometimes people react to an event by avoiding or preventing it in the future causing a change of the events future probability. Other times one bad event may increase the chance of another. For example, an earthquake may cause landslides, floods, or power blackouts. The more uncertainty there is, the harder it is to find a meaningful probability number. Instead our estimate must be constrained to a range of possible outcomes and their probabilities.

不确定性增加了保险公司对飓风或地震等灾难进行适当定价的难度。沃伦巴菲特说：

Uncertainty increases the difficulty for insurers to appropriately price catastrophes, such as hurricanes or earthquakes. Warren Buffett says:

巨灾保险公司不能简单地推断过去的经验。例如，如果真的发生“全球变暖”，可能性就会发生变化，因为大气条件的微小变化会导致天气模式发生重大变化。此外，近年来美国沿海地区的人口和保险价值激增，这些地区特别容易受到飓风的影响，飓风是超级猫的头号创造者。20 年前造成 x 美元损失的飓风现在很容易造成 10 倍的损失。

偶尔也会发生不可想象的事情。例如，谁会猜到南卡罗来纳州的查尔斯顿会发生大地震？（它袭击了 1886 年，估计里氏震级为 6.6，并造成 60 人死亡。）

Catastrophe insurers can’t simply extrapolate past experience. If there is truly"global warming," for example, the odds would shift, since tiny changes in atmospheric conditions can produce momentous changes in weather patterns. Furthermore, in recent years there has been a mushrooming of population and insured values in U.S. coastal areas that are particularly vulnerable to hurricanes, the number one creator of super-cats. A hurricane that caused x dollars of damage 20 years ago could easily cost 10x now.

Occasionally, also, the unthinkable happens. Who would have guessed for example, that a major earthquake could occur in Charleston, S.C.? (It struck in 1886, registered an estimated 6.6 on the Richter scale, and caused 60 deaths.)

但仍有可能合理定价。沃伦巴菲特说：

But it may still be possible to price sensibly. Warren Buffett says:

即使无法完美地评估风险，保险公司也可以明智地承保。毕竟，您不需要知道一个人的确切年龄就可以知道他已经到了可以投票的年龄，也不需要知道他的确切体重就可以知道他需要节食。

Even if perfection in assessing risks is unattainable, insurers can underwrite sensibly. After all, you need not know a man’s precise age to know that he is old enough to vote nor know his exact weight to recognize his need to diet.

沃伦巴菲特还考虑了最坏的情况：

Warren Buffett also considers a worst case scenario:

考虑到我们接受的风险，Ajit [Ajit Jain; 伯克希尔再保险业务经理]，我一直关注我们的“最坏情况”，当然，我知道很难判断这是什么情况，因为可以想象，你可能会遇到长岛飓风、加利福尼亚地震和 Super Cat X都在同一年。此外，保险损失可能伴随着非保险问题。例如，如果我们因南加州大地震而遭受巨额损失，那么我们持有的 See's、Wells Fargo 和 Freddie Mac 的价值很可能会大幅下跌……

不过，我们确实会监控我们的总体风险敞口，以便将我们的“最坏情况”保持在让我们感到舒服的水平。

Given the risks we accept, Ajit [Ajit Jain; manager of Berkshire’s reinsurance operations] and I constantly focus on our"worst case," knowing, of course, that it is difficult to judge what this is, since you could conceivably have a Long Island hurricane, a California earthquake, and Super Cat X all in the same year. Additionally, insurance losses could be accompanied by non-insurance troubles. For example, were we to have super-cat losses from a large Southern California earthquake, they might well be accompanied by a major drop in the value of our holdings in See’s, Wells Fargo and Freddie Mac...

We do, though, monitor our aggregate exposure in order to keep our"worst case" at a level that leaves us comfortable.

过去的经验对预测未来的可靠性如何？在 Against the Gods 中，彼得·伯恩斯坦 (Peter Bernstein) 提到了 1703 年德国数学家戈特弗里德·威廉·冯·莱布尼茨 (Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz) 写给瑞士科学家兼数学家雅各布·伯努利 (Jacob Bernoulli) 的一封信，信中提到了死亡率：“新疾病席卷人类，因此无论您进行多少次实验对尸体所做的一切，你并没有因此对事件的性质施加限制，以便它们在未来不会发生变化。” 即使有最好的经验证据，也没有人确切知道未来会发生什么。

How reliable is past experience for predicting the future? In Against the Gods, Peter Bernstein refers to a 1703 letter written by German mathematician Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz to the Swiss scientist and mathematician Jacob Bernoulli referring to mortality rates:"New illnesses flood the human race, so that no matter how many experiments you have done on corpses, you have not thereby imposed a limit on the nature of events so that in the future they could not vary." Even with the best empirical evidence, nobody knows precisely what will happen in the future.

在 2001 年 9 月 11 日的灾难之后，沃伦巴菲特写道关注实际风险的重要性以及使用过去的经验有时可能是危险的：

After the September 11, 2001, catastrophe, Warren Buffett wrote on the importance on focusing on actual exposure and how using past experience sometimes may be dangerous:

在定价和评估聚合风险时，我们要么忽略了，要么忽略了大规模恐怖主义损失的可能性。例如，在为财产保险定价时，我们回顾了过去，只考虑了我们可能预期的成本招致风暴、火灾、爆炸和地震。但历史上最大的保险财产损失（加上相关的业务中断索赔后）并非来自这些力量。简而言之，我们这个行业的所有人都犯了一个根本性的承保错误，即关注经验而不是风险，从而承担了巨大的恐怖主义风险，而我们却没有收到任何保险费。

当然，经验是承保大多数保险的一个非常有用的起点。

例如，对于编写加利福尼亚地震保单的保险公司而言，重要的是要了解该州在上个世纪发生了多少次里氏 6.0 级或更大的地震。这些信息不会告诉您明年发生大地震的确切概率，也不会告诉您该州可能发生地震的地点。但该统计数据具有实用性，特别是如果您正在编写一项庞大的全州政策......

然而，在某些时候，以经验为指导来定价不仅毫无用处，而且实际上是危险的。例如，在牛市后期，董事和高级职员责任保险 (“D&O”) 造成的巨额损失可能相对较少。当股票上涨时，缺乏可起诉的目标，而有问题的会计和管理欺诈往往未被发现。在那个时候，高限 D&O 的经验可能看起来很棒。

但这恰恰是在荒谬的公开募股、盈利操纵、类似连锁信的股票促销活动以及其他各种令人不快的活动中，风险敞口可能会爆炸式增长的时候。当股市下跌时，这些罪恶就会浮出水面，给投资者带来高达数千亿美元的损失。

In setting prices and also in evaluating aggregation risk, we had either overlooked or dismissed the possibility of large-scale terrorism losses.. .In pricing property coverages, for example, we had looked to the past and taken into account only costs we might expect to incur from wind-storm, fire, explosion and earthquake. But what will be the largest insured property loss in history (after adding related business interruption claims) originated from none of these forces. In short, all of us in the industry made a fundamental underwriting mistake by focusing on experience, rather than exposure, thereby assuming a huge terrorism risk for which we received no premium.

Experience, of course, is a highly useful starting point in underwriting most coverages.

For example, it’s important for insurers writing California earthquake policies to know how many quakes in the state during the past century have registered 6.0 or greater on the Richter scale. This information will not tell you the exact probability of a big quake next year, or where in the state it might happen. But the statistic has utility, particularly if you are writing a huge state-wide policy...

At certain times, however, using experience as a guide to pricing is not only useless, but actually dangerous. Late in a bull market, for example, large losses from directors and officers liability insurance ("D&O") are likely to be relatively rare. When stocks are rising, there are a scarcity of targets to sue, and both questionable accounting and management chicanery often go undetected. At that juncture, experience on high-limit D&O may look great.

But that’s just when exposure is likely to be exploding, by way of ridiculous public offerings, earnings manipulation, chain-letter-like stock promotions and a pot-pourri of other unsavoury activities. When stocks fall, these sins surface, hammering investors with losses that can run into the hundreds of billions.

即使对于某些事件我们无法估计它们的概率，也可能有一些证据告诉我们它们的概率是在增加还是在减少。问：我了解可能导致事件的力量吗？关键因素是什么？事件发生的机会更多吗？

Even if we for some events can’t estimate their probability, there may be some evidence telling us if their probabilities are increasing or decreasing. Ask: Do I understand the forces that can cause the event? What are the key factors? Are there more opportunities for the event to happen?

沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 谈到恐怖主义时说：

Warren Buffett says on terrorism:

没有人知道今年主要大都市地区发生核爆炸的可能性……也没有人有把握地评估今年或另一年致命的生物或化学制剂被同时引入的可能性……多个办公楼和制造厂...

这是我们所知道的：

  1. 发生这种令人难以置信的灾难的可能性虽然目前可能非常低，但并非为零。
  2. 随着那些希望我们生病的人可以获得知识和材料，这种可能性正在以一种不规则和不可估量的方式增加。

No one knows the probability of a nuclear detonation in a major metropolis area this year...Nor can anyone, with assurance, assess the probability in this year, or another, of deadly biological or chemical agents being introduced simultaneously...into multiple office buildings and manufacturing plants...

Here’s what we do know:

  1. The probability of such mind-boggling disasters, though likely very low at present, is not zero.
  2. The probabilities are increasing, in an irregular and immeasurable manner, as knowledge and materials become available to those who wish us ill.

与可能发生的事情（所有可能的结果）相关的事件发生的机会（可能想要或不想要的结果）越多，它发生的可能性就越大。

The more opportunities (possible wanted or unwanted outcomes) an event has to happen in relation to what can happen (all possible outcomes), the more likely it is to occur.

可能结果的数量

Number of possible outcomes

抛硬币一次。会发生什么？有两种可能的结果。掷骰子一次。有 6 种可能的结果。所有的可能性都一样。掷骰子两次。会发生什么？每次掷骰有 6 种可能的结果，因此掷两次骰子时有 36 种可能的组合或结果。掷骰子 3 次。有 216 种可能的结果。

Toss a coin once. What can happen? There are 2 possible outcomes. Roll a die once. There are 6 possible outcomes. All equally likely. Roll a die twice. What can happen? There are 6 possible outcomes on each roll and therefore 36 possible combinations or outcomes when rolling a die twice. Roll a die 3 times. There are 216 possible outcomes.

这是一种简化的说法，即事件的可能结果越多（在数量或时间上），特定结果的可能性就越小（例如只有一个结果满足想要的事件：“掷骰子一次并观察到六” ) 并且某些结果的可能性越大（有 6 种可能的结果可供选择）。

This is a simplified way of saying that the more possible outcomes an event has (in number or time), the less likely a specific outcome is (for example only one outcome satisfies the wanted event:"roll a die once and observe a six") and the more likely some outcome is (there are 6 possible outcomes to choose from).

特定事件的可能结果越多，它们就越不受欢迎，实现场景所需的独立事件越多，想要的场景发生的可能性就越小。有些结果可能比其他结果更不可能（例如，由于约束或限制）。

The more possible outcomes a specific event has, and the more they are unwanted, and the more independent events that are needed to achieve a scenario, the less likely it is that the wanted scenario happens. Some outcomes may be less likely than others (for example, due to constraints or limits).

将掷骰子 3 次视为 3 个独立的事件，其中每个事件都是“观察 6”。我们从上面看到的是，实现某些场景或想要的结果（“连续 3 个六”）必须发生的事件越多，场景发生的可能性就越小。观察到“除了连续 3 个六之外的任何东西”都是不受欢迎的事件。在 216 种不希望的事件中，有 215 种结果或方式发生。这意味着很可能发生不希望的事件。

Treat rolling a die 3 times as 3 separate events where each event is"observe a six". What we see from the above is that the more events that must happen to achieve some scenario or wanted outcome ("3 sixes in a row"), the less likely the scenario is to happen. Observing"anything but 3 sixes in a row" is an unwanted event. There are 215 outcomes or ways for this unwanted event to happen out of 216. This means that it is very likely that the unwanted event happens.

我们谈论从长远来看可能发生的事情。我们可能很幸运，连续掷出 3 个六。我们还必须考虑不良结果的后果。

We talk about what is likely to happen in the long run. We might be lucky and roll 3 sixes in a row. We must also consider the consequences of an unwanted outcome.

这是什么意思？如果达到坏结果的方法多于获得好结果的方法，则出现坏结果的可能性就更高。破坏一个系统比创建一个系统更容易，仅仅因为破坏的机会多于创建的机会。

What does this mean? If there are more ways of reaching a bad outcome than a good outcome, the probability of a bad outcome is higher. It is easier to destroy a system than to create one merely because there are more opportunities for destruction than creation.

这意味着惊喜、巧合、罕见事件和事故会发生在某个地方、某个时间，并且发生在某人身上，如果他们有机会发生的话。

It means that surprises, coincidences, rare events and accidents happen, somewhere, sometime, and to someone if they have opportunities to happen.

这也意味着消除风险比找出风险所在更可取（因为出现意外结果的机会太多了）。例如，我们可以通过增加想要的可能结果的数量、减少不需要的可能结果的数量、降低后果的严重程度或避免某些情况来降低风险。

It also means that eliminating risk is preferable to finding out where the risk lies (since there are so many opportunities for an unwanted outcome). For example, we can reduce risk by increasing the number of wanted possible outcomes, reducing the number of unwanted possible outcomes, reducing the magnitude of consequences or avoiding certain situations.

问一些相关问题：

Ask some relevant questions:

事件：事件类型？经常？独特的？

Event: Type of event? Frequent? Unique?

原因：什么可以引发和导致事件？什么因素起作用？必须具备什么条件和情况？随着时间的推移，原因是否发生了变化？

Causes: What can initiate and cause the event? What factors contribute? What conditions and circumstances must be present? Have the causes changed over time?

曝光：已知？可衡量的？可能的后果？后果/损失的严重程度？可能发生的最坏情况是什么？

Exposure: Known? Measurable? Possible consequences? Magnitude of consequences/loss? What’s the worst that can happen?

概率：随着时间的推移可能结果的分布？稳定的？相对频率或相关的过去经验？观察次数？不同损失大小的相对可能性？平均频率是如何产生的？结果和严重程度的可变性？取决于人为因素？
