由于 John 被告知他检测呈阳性，因此他需要的信息是检测呈阳性并患有疾病的人的频率（真阳性）以及检测呈阳性但未患病的人的频率（假阳性）。

Since John is told he tested positive, the information he needs is the frequency of people that test positive and have the disease (true positives) and the frequency of people that test positive but don’t have the disease (false positives).

   鉴于疾病  鉴于不是疾病 全部的
测试呈阳性 97 (100 X 0.97) 4,995 (99,900 X 0.05) 5,092

在与约翰属于同一风险群体的每 1,000 人中，我们可以预期有 19 人患有这种致命疾病，因为他们的检测呈阳性 (97/5,092)。鉴于约翰检测呈阳性，他患上这种致命疾病的可能性约为 1.9% 或非常低。在 5,092 项测试中，大多数是假阳性，表明没有疾病。

Out of every 1,000 people belonging to the same risk group as John, we can expect that 19 people have the deadly disease given they test positive (97/5,092). The probability that John has the deadly disease given he tested positive is about 1.9% or very low. Out of 5,092 tests, most are false positives indicating the disease when there is no disease.

如果随机测试的人测试呈阴性怎么办？有 3 个假阴性和 94,905 个真阴性，这意味着此人没有患病的可能性超过 99.9%。

What if a randomly tested person tests negative? There are 3 false negatives and 94,905 true negatives, meaning that there is more than a 99.9% chance that the person doesn’t have the disease.

“检测呈阳性”这个标签可能很吓人，但请记住，检测不是疾病。测试可能属于误报组。但哪个最糟糕？属于假阳性组 - 被诊断为患有疾病但没有患病，或假阴性 - 被诊断为没有患病但患有疾病？

The label"tested positive" can be scary but remember that the test is not the disease. A test could fall in the group of false positives. But which is worst? To belong to the group of false positives - diagnosed as having the disease without having it, or false negatives - diagnosed as not having the disease but having it?

先验概率越高或疾病越常见，测试结果就越可靠。相反，先验概率越低或疾病越罕见，测试结果就越不可靠。如果它测试的是一种相当罕见的疾病，即使是高度准确的测试也可能会产生不可靠的结果。这是假设接受测试的个体不属于患病风险较高的人群。

The higher the prior probability or the more common a disease, the more reliable the outcome of the test. Conversely, the lower the prior probability or the more rare the disease, the less reliable the outcome of the test. Even a highly accurate test can yield an unreliable result if it tests for a rather uncommon disease. This assumes that the individual tested does not belong to a group of people at higher risk of having the disease.

问：在我考虑具体病例证据之前，相关比较人群中患有这种疾病的人的频率是多少？医学测试的准确性如何？

Ask: What is the frequency of people with the disease in the relevant comparison population before I consider specific case evidence? How accurate is the medical test?

上述推理可用于帮助评估诊断测试或筛选程序的可靠性。一些例子是筛查或诊断乳腺癌、前列腺癌、结直肠癌、艾滋病毒或吸毒。

The above reasoning can be used to help evaluate the reliability of diagnostic tests or screening procedures. Some examples are screening for or diagnosis of breast cancer, prostate cancer, colorectal cancer, HIV or drug use.

在评估测谎仪测试（用于刑事调查或筛选员工）和识别系统的可靠性时，估计误报和漏报的频率也很重要。

Estimating the frequency of false positives and false negatives are also important when evaluating the reliability of polygraph tests (used in criminal investigations or for screening employees) and identification systems.

在测谎仪测试中，当发现无辜者具有欺骗性时，就会出现误报。当发现有罪的人没有欺骗性时，就会出现漏报。

In polygraph tests, false positives occur when innocent persons are found deceptive. False negatives occur when guilty persons are found non-deceptive.

在识别系统中，当系统接受一个没有匹配项的匹配项时，就会出现误报。当系统无法识别存在的匹配项时，就会出现漏报。

In identification systems, a false positive occurs when a system accepts a match where there is none. A false negative occurs when a system fails to recognize a match where there is one.

在评估 DNA 图谱证据的价值时，误报的概率也是一个需要考虑的因素。这意味着比尔案中的陪审团还需要考虑误报率。陪审团需要问：实验室报告两个不匹配样本匹配的概率是多少？报告的匹配并不一定意味着真正的匹配。错误发生。法医匹配的一个可能解释可能是由于污染（意外或故意）、证据处理不当或更换样本造成的错误。例如，在一起强奸案中，休斯顿警方犯罪实验室的技术人员告诉陪审团，他们在强奸犯的 DNA 和一名男性嫌疑人之间发现了 DNA 匹配。该男子于 1999 年被定罪并入狱 25 年。2003年，

The probability of false positives is also a factor to consider when evaluating the value of DNA profile evidence. This means that the jury in Bill’s case also needs to consider the false positive rate. The jury needs to ask: What is the probability that the laboratory reports a match between two samples that don’t match? A reported match doesn’t necessarily mean a true match. Errors happen. A possible explanation for the forensic match may be error due to contamination (accidental or deliberate), mishandling the evidence, or switching the samples. For example, in one rape case, technicians from the Houston police crime laboratory told the jury that they found a DNA match between a rapist’s DNA and a male suspect. The man was convicted in 1999 and sent to prison for 25 years. In 2003, the Houston Police Department said that the DNA was not from the convicted man.

在评估案例证据时，我们必须考虑先验概率、随机匹配概率和误报概率。

When evaluating case evidence we must consider the prior probability, the probability of a random match, and the probability of a false positive.

九：虚假证据

Nine: Misrepresentative Evidence

条件、环境和情况发生变化

Conditions, environments and circumstances change

人们喜欢寻找在过去 20 年左右一直有效的系统。如果你能根据过去 20 年行之有效的方法赚钱，那么所有最富有的人都会成为图书管理员。

People like to look for systems that have worked over the past 20 years or so. If you could make money based on what has worked the past 20 years, all of the richest people would be librarians.

- 沃伦·巴菲特

- Warren Buffett

伯特兰·罗素在《哲学问题》中说：“终其一生每天都喂鸡的人最后反而拧断了它的脖子。” 通常，过去是未来的良好指南——但并非总是如此。统计数据是对过去的记录，而不是对未来的预测。我们不能自动假设未来将反映过去。流程和环境会发生变化。沃伦巴菲特说：“与技术和人类行为的各个方面相关的条件可能会使未来与过去大不相同。”

Bertrand Russell said in Problems of Philosophy:"The man who has fed the chicken every day throughout its life at last wrings its neck instead." Often the past is a good guide to the future - but not always. Statistics are a record of the past, not a prediction of the future. We can’t automatically assume that the future will mirror the past. Processes and circumstances change. Warren Buffett says: "Conditions relating to technology and all aspects of human behaviour can make the future a lot different than the past."

在使用过去的证据预测未来可能的结果之前，我们需要考虑条件的变化。例如，企业的性质和经济状况会发生变化。竞争和需求变化。如果有更多的方法来创造竞争或减少需求，我们就必须改变方程式。问：为什么过去的经验是这样的？有什么理由认为未来会与过去相似？环境变了吗？条件相似吗？造成过去的背景和情况是否仍然存在？

We need to consider changes in conditions before using past evidence to predict likely future outcomes. For example, it’s in the nature of businesses and economic conditions to change. Competition and demand changes. If there are more ways for creating competition or less demand, we have to change the equation. Ask: Why was past experience the way it was? What reason is there to suppose that the future will resemble the past? Has the environment changed? Are the conditions similar? Are the context and circumstances that caused the past still present?

如果我们忽视过去的表现可能是在与今天截然不同的情况下取得的，我们也会犯错误。正如沃伦巴菲特所说，“棒球经理会犯同样的错误，即根据他一生的击球率来判断一名 42 岁中外野手的未来前景。”

We also make mistakes if we ignore that past performance may have been achieved under far different circumstances than today. As Warren Buffett says, "The same mistake that a baseball manager would were he to judge the future prospects of a 42-year-old center fielder on the basis of his lifetime batting average."

管理绩效也可能取决于环境。使个人在一种环境中取得成功的因素并不能保证在另一种环境中取得成功。问：公司或经理处理逆境的能力如何？

Management performance may also be conditioned on environment. What makes an individual successful in one environment does not guarantee success in another. Ask: What is the company’s or manager’s ability to handle adversity?

“如果我们销售疾病而不是药物，我们可以卖得更多。” TransCorp 制药部门的经理说。

"We can sell more if we market the illness rather than the drug." said the manager of TransCorp’s pharmaceutical division.

疾病的频率真的在增加吗？在得出事件发生频率发生变化的结论之前，我们需要考虑其他因素。例如，一种疾病的诊断可能比过去更正确。通常我们只看到我们有名称的东西——以前被归类为“疾病 X”或“原因不明”的疾病现在可能会被重新分类或得到一个名称。在数据的收集和报告方面也可能有技术改进。工作中可能还有商业激励。例如，通过创造新条件、重新定义疾病或夸大轻微疾病来扩大市场，从而让更多人被标记为患有某种疾病。

Is the frequency of a disease really increasing? We need to consider other factors before we conclude that the frequency of an event has changed. For example, a disease may be more correctly diagnosed than it was in the past. Often we only see what we have names for - a disease that was formerly classified as"disease X" or"cause unknown" may now be re-classified or get a name. There may also be technological improvements in the collection and reporting of data. There may also be business incentives at work. For example, widening a market by creating a new condition, redefining a disease or exaggerating a minor one, thereby having more people labelled as having a disease.

如果情况发生变化，我们必须更新我们的假设以反映当前环境。在我们将变化用作可能发生的事情的证据之前，请问：发生了什么变化？有没有更多的方式让一些不希望的事件发生？改变是永久的还是暂时的？

If conditions change, we must update our assumptions to reflect the present environment. Before we use the change as evidence for what is likely to happen, ask: What has changed? Are there more ways for some undesirable event to happen? Is the change permanent or temporary?

单一个案或不具代表性的样本

The single case or unrepresentative samples

五分之四的医生推荐这种药物。

Four out of five doctors recommend the drug.

如果我们不知道有多少医生被观察过，那么这个声明并不能告诉我们任何信息。也许只有 10 个；无法推断包括所有医生的观察结果。样本量小没有预测价值。样本越小，统计波动越大，我们就越有可能找到偶然事件。我们需要有代表性的比较组、足够大的样本量和足够长的时间段。

This statement doesn’t tell us anything if we don’t know how many doctors were observed. Maybe it was just 10; an observation that can’t be extrapolated to include all doctors. A small sample size has no predictive value. The smaller the sample is, the more statistical fluctuations and the more likely it is that we find chance events. We need a representative comparison group, large enough sample size, and long enough periods of time.

小样本会使我们相信风险低于或高于现实。为什么？一个小样本增加了我们找不到存在的特定关系或找不到它不存在的特定关系的机会。

Small samples can cause us to believe a risk is lower or higher than reality. Why? A small sample increases the chance that we won’t find a particular relationship where it exists or find one where it doesn’t exist.

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 举例说明了获取代表性数据的重要性——即使它是近似值：

Charles Munger gives an example of the importance of getting representative data - even if it’s approximate:

加利福尼亚州的供水系统是根据相当短的天气历史来设计的。如果他们愿意记录不那么完美的记录，并回顾一百年前，他们就会发现他们的设计并没有正确应对完全有可能出现的干旱情况。

你一次又一次地看到——人们有一些他们可以很好地计算的信息，而他们有一些更难计算的信息。所以他们只根据他们能算得好的东西来做决定。他们忽略了更重要的信息，因为它在计算能力方面的质量较低——尽管它在达到正确的认知结果方面非常重要。我只能告诉你，在 Wesco 和 Berkshire 周围，我们尽量不那样做。我们有凯恩斯勋爵的态度，沃伦经常引用这句话：“我们宁愿大致正确，也不愿精确错误。” 换句话说，如果某件事非常重要，我们会猜测它，而不是仅仅根据碰巧容易计算的事情做出判断。

The water system of California was designed looking at a fairly short period of weather history. If they’d been willing to take less perfect records and look an extra hundred years back, they’d have seen that they weren’t designing it right to handle drought conditions which were entirely likely.

You see that again and again - that people have some information they can count well and they have other information much harder to count. So they make the decision based only on what they can count well. And they ignore much more important information because its quality in terms of numeracy is less — even though it’s very important in terms of reaching the right cognitive result. All I can tell you is that around Wesco and Berkshire, we try not to be like that. We have Lord Keynes’ attitude, which Warren quotes all the time:"We’d rather be roughly right than precisely wrong." In other words, if something is terribly important, we’ll guess at it rather than just make our judgement based on what happens to be easily countable.

机会与表现

Chance and performance

没有胜利者相信机会。

No victor believes in chance.

——弗里德里希·威廉·尼采

- Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche

过去的表现并不能保证将来的结果。考虑描述在大多数相似情况下或大多数人身上发生的事情的证据。

Past performance is no guarantee of future results. Consider evidence that describes what happens in most similar situations or to most people.

有时，业绩记录并不能很好地指示未来可能发生的事情。它可能会出现在运气中。想象一个房间里有 1,000 只猴子。每个人都试图预测利率的方向（向上或向下）。在 10 次预测结束时，一只猴子在预测利率方向方面拥有完美的记录。他被认为是天才和历史上最伟大的经济学家。哪怕只是偶然。一旦我们有大量预测者预测机会发挥作用的事件，就会有人是正确的，得到媒体报道并被描绘成英雄。他将举行讲座并作出明智的解释。

Sometimes a track record is not a good indicator of what is likely to happen in the future. It may show up by luck. Imagine a room filled with 1,000 monkeys. Each is trying to predict the direction (up or down) of interest rates. At the end of 10 predictions, one monkey has a perfect record of predicting the direction of interest rates. He is considered a genius and the greatest economist in history. Even if it was just by chance. As soon as we have a large population of forecasters that predict events where chance plays a role, someone will be right, get press coverage and be presented as a hero. He will hold lectures and give sensible explanations.

有时我们只看到表现出色的人。部分原因是获胜者倾向于出现（一只猴子）。失败者不会（999 只猴子）。无论如何，我们通常对失败者不感兴趣。但是，如果有大量人口可供选择，我们不应该对获胜者感到惊讶。10,000 只猴子，我们发现 10 个天才。

Sometimes we only see the good performers. Partly because winners have a tendency to show up (one monkey). Losers don’t (999 monkeys). Often we aren’t interested in the losers anyway. But we shouldn’t be amazed to see winners if there is a large population to choose from. 10,000 monkeys and we find 10 geniuses.

当我们衡量绩效时，我们必须同时考虑成功的数量（一只猴子）、失败的数量（999 只猴子）以及它们来自的相关比较种群的规模（1,000 只猴子）。越多的人（或猴子）参与其中的机会发挥作用，一些人就越有可能只是偶然地表现出色。一个例外是在一群高绩效者中，我们可以观察到一些共同特征，这些特征可能是因果关系而不是运气。

When we measure performance we must consider both the number of successes (one monkey), the number of failures (999 monkeys), and the size of the relevant comparison population they came from (1,000 monkeys). The more people (or monkeys), involved in something where chance plays a role, the more likely it is that some people have great performances just by chance. An exception is in a group of high performers where we can observe some common characteristics that may be a causal factor and not luck.

当人们仅根据效果得出结论而忽略机会的影响时，可能会发生同样的错误。想想 100 只猴子。他们每人掷一次骰子。选择掷出 6 的 16 只猴子 (1/6 x 100)。为了治愈他们的“掷六”倾向，我们给他们一种新药。服药后，他们再次掷骰子。现在只有 2 或 3 只猴子 (1/6 x 16) 掷出了 6。其余的都“治愈”了。我们的错误结论是：“药物显然有效。”

The same mistakes may happen when people base their conclusions on mere effects and ignore the influence of chance. Think about 100 monkeys. They each roll a die once. Select those 16 monkeys (1/6 x 100) who rolled a six. As a cure for their"roll-a-six" tendency we give them a new drug. After taking the drug they roll the die again. Now only 2 or 3 monkeys (1/6 x 16) rolled a six. The rest were "cured." Our false conclusion:"The drug obviously worked."

骗子设下陷阱。他打电话给约翰，给了他一个小费。“注意这只股票。它会上涨的。” 在 3 次正确预测后，约翰将钱汇给他。骗子消失了。

A con artist sets up a trap. He calls John with a tip."Watch this stock. It will go up." After 3 correct predictions, John sends him his money. The con artist disappears.

约翰不知道的是，骗子给 80 个人打了同样的电话。

What John didn’t know was that the con artist made the same call to 80 people.

他告诉其中一半股票会上涨，另一半股票会下跌。他的预测之一肯定是正确的。40 人印象深刻。在第二个电话中，有 20 个人对他印象深刻，在他的第三次也是最后一次电话中，有 10 个人认为他是天才，他们都给他寄了钱。

He told half of them the stock would go up, and the other half the stock would go down. And one of his predictions is sure to be right. 40 people were impressed. At the second call 20 people were impressed and at his third and last call he was considered a genius by 10 people who all sent him their money.

忽略失败

Ignoring failures

必须从一段时间内成功和失败的频率中得出证据。通常我们只考虑成功和支持的结果。流行病学文献将此称为生存偏差。研究中仅包括所研究疾病或结果的幸存者的特征。那些在研究结束前死亡的人被排除在外。如果这些患者具有更严重的风险因素，则该研究会减少风险因素与结果之间的明显关联。生存偏差在结果发生后进行的所有研究中也很常见（包括回溯检验）。他们只关注幸存的病例或患者。死亡人员不在样本池中。人们也可以通过只发布积极的结果而忽略消极的结果来选择或省略某些信息。

Evidence must be drawn from the frequency of both success and failure over time. Often we only consider the successful and supporting outcomes. The epidemiological literature refers to this as survival bias. Only the characteristics of the survivors of a disease or outcome under study are included in the study. Those who have died before the end of the study are excluded. If these are patients with more severe risk factors, the study reduces an apparent association between risk factors and outcomes. Survival bias is also common in all studies made after the outcomes have occurred (including back testing). They only focus on surviving cases or patients. The people who have died are not in the sampling pool. People may also select or omit certain information by only publishing positive outcomes and omitting negative ones.

如果我们只研究成功者或幸存者，绩效记录可能看起来比实际情况要好。查尔斯芒格说我们对失败的关注太少：

If we only study successes or survivors, a performance record may look better than it really is. Charles Munger says that we give too little attention to failures:

许多商学院毕业生和几乎所有顾问都认为，一家公司可以通过购买不相关或微弱相关的业务来轻松改善其结果。根据这种广泛认同的观点，只要采取了明显的步骤，如果采用了正确的“使命宣言”并聘请了正确的“专家”，那么每条铁路都不会被新形式的铁路束缚竞争以及过时和敌对的法律和工会规则，将成为另一个联邦快递，另一个联合包裹服务公司，甚至是艾默生电气模式下​​的另一个出色表现。

我们的实际经验和替代经验使我们对通过业务收购获得的简单解决方案不太乐观。我们认为过度乐观的出现是因为成功的记录引起了太多关注。如果我在仅限于 Ivan Lendl 和 Steffi Graf 的观察后预测顶级网球的良好前景，或者在限制对获胜者的观察后在加利福尼亚彩票中预测良好的前景，那么许多人就会像我一样推理。反之亦然，甚至更是如此。对最糟糕的公司收购示例（例如 CBS-DuMont、Xerox-Scientific Data Systems、General Electric-Utah International、Exxon-Reliance Electric...和雅芳产品。

It is assumed by many business school graduates, and by almost all consultants, that a corporation can easily improve its outcome by purchasing unrelated or tenuously related businesses. According to this widely shared view, if only the obvious steps had been taken, if the right"mission statement" had been adopted and the right"experts" hired, then each rail-road, instead of remaining bound in chains by new forms of competition and obsolete and hostile laws and union rules, would have become another Federal Express, another United Parcel Service, or even another brilliant performer in the mode of Emerson Electric.

Our experience, both actual and vicarious, makes us less optimistic about easy solutions through business acquisition. We think undue optimism arises because successful records draw too much attention. Many people then reason as I would if I forecasted good prospects in big-time tennis after observation limited to Ivan Lendl and Steffi Graf, or good prospects in the California lottery after limiting observations to winners. The converse is also true, only more so. Far too little attention is given to the terrible effects on shareholders (or other owners) of the worst examples of corporate acquisitions such as CBS-DuMont, Xerox-Scientific Data Systems, General Electric-Utah International, Exxon-Reliance Electric.. .and Avon Products.

1999年，人们说：“互联网生意做得很好”。

In 1999, people said:"Internet businesses are doing great."

我们常常只看到做得好的企业而忽略了失败的企业。特别是在成功得到广泛宣传的牛市中。问：我们衡量 5 年绩效的相关比较人群是多少（假设 100 家互联网企业）？有多少做得好（假设 5）。有多少表现不佳（假设 80）。有多少人倒闭了（假设 15 个）。由此我们可以得出结论，上述说法是错误的。

Often we see only the businesses that do well and ignore the failures. Especially in bull markets where successes get wide publicity. Ask: What is the relevant comparison population from which we measure 5-year performance (assume 100 Internet businesses)? How many are doing well (assume 5). How many are not performing well (assume 80). How many have gone out of business (assume 15). From this we can draw the conclusion that the above statement is false.

TransCorps 技术部门开发了一种新的防御系统，并声称成功率为 80%。当约翰观察了 10 次测试时，他看到了 8 次失败，只有 2 次成功。

TransCorps technical department developed a new defense system and claims a success rate of 80%. When John observed 10 tests, he witnessed 8 failures and only 2 successes.

 1992 年，麻省理工学院科学与国家安全教授西奥多·波斯托尔 (Theodore Postol) 衡量了爱国者反导弹系统在海湾战争中的有效性（不是在心理和政治影响方面）。基于对涉及 25 次失误和 1 次命中的 26 次爱国者/飞毛腿交战录像带的研究，他告诉政府运作委员会，“视频证据提供了一个压倒性的间接案例，即爱国者在沙特没有接近实现 80% 的拦截率阿拉伯。” 五角大楼报告向飞毛腿发射了 47 枚爱国者导弹，起初声称成功率为 80%。后来的一份国会报告得出结论，爱国者队只成功击落了 4 架飞毛腿。

 In 1992, Theodore Postol, a professor of science and national security at MIT, measured the effectiveness (not in terms of its psychological and political impact) of the Patriot anti-missile system in the Gulf War. Based on studying videotapes of 26 Patriot/Scud engagements involving 25 misses and 1 hit, he told the Committee on Government Operations that,"the video evidence makes an overwhelming circumstantial case that Patriot did not come close to achieving a 80 percent intercept rate in Saudi Arabia." The Pentagon reported firing 47 Patriot missiles at Scuds, at first claiming an 80% success rate. A congressional report later concluded that Patriots succeeded in downing only 4 Scuds.

如果我们假设 John 的观察结果代表有效的随机测试样本，那么如果技术部门的说法是正确的，他准确观察到 2 个“命中”和 8 个“未命中”的可能性有多大？

If we assume that John’s observations represent a valid random sample of tests, how likely is it that he would observe exactly 2"hits" and 8"misses" if the technical department’s claim was true?

这是二项式实验的一个例子。它描述了具有重复、相同试验的实验，其中每个试验只能有两种可能的结果（例如成功或失败）。假设独立交战，概率仅为 0.007%。如果该部门的说法属实，那么约翰目睹的事件发生的概率非常低。他们的说法更有可能是错误的。

This is an example of a binomial experiment. It describes experiments with repeated, identical trials where each trial can only have two possible outcomes (e.g. success or failure). Assuming independent engagements, the probability is only 0.007%. If the departments claim was true, then John witnessed an event of a very low probability. It is more likely that their claim was false.

变化性

Variability

例如，你永远无法预测任何人会做什么，但你可以准确地说出一个人的平均水平。个体不同，但百分比保持不变。统计学家如是说。

You can, for example, never foretell what any man will do, but you can say with precision what an average number will be up to. Individuals vary, but percentages remain constant. So says the statistician.

- 亚瑟·柯南·道尔

（来自《四的符号》）

- Arthur Conan Doyle

(from The Sign of Four)

在评估可能的结果时，查看可能结果的整体分布——平均结果、可变性以及极端结果及其后果的概率。我们所说的可变性是指个体结果从平均结果中分散的程度。分布越广，变化越大。问：过去发生了什么事？结果在平均值附近波动多少？哪些因素导致了过去的可变性？他们改变了吗？

When evaluating likely outcomes, look at the whole distribution of possible outcomes — average outcome, variability, and the probability of an extreme outcome and its consequences. What we mean by variability is how much the individual outcomes are spread out from the average outcome. The more spread out, the more variability. Ask: What has happened in the past? How much do the outcomes fluctuate around the average? What factors contribute to past variability? Have they changed?

正态分布曲线显示了结果的频率分布，有时可以帮助我们找到最频繁的结果和变化。

The normal distribution curve shows a frequency distribution of outcomes and may sometimes help us find the most frequent outcomes and the variations.

有许多方法可以展开或分配一组结果。但有些结果比其他结果更频繁。许多由独立随机因素产生的特征具有钟形频率分布。这意味着最常见的结果将位于分布的中间，而其他结果将落在中间的任一侧。任何结果离中间越远，出现的频率就越低。

There are many ways a set of outcomes can be spread out or distributed. But some outcomes are more frequent than others. Many characteristics resulting from independent random factors have a bell-shaped frequency distribution. This means that the most frequent outcomes will be in the middle of the distribution, and the other outcomes will fall on either side of the middle. The further away any outcome is from the middle, the less frequent it is.

正态分布结果的例子有成年人的身高或体重（取决于基因、饮食或环境等因素）、温度、车祸、死亡率或灯泡的寿命。

Examples of normally distributed outcomes are heights or weights of adults (which depend on factors such as genes, diet, or environment), temperatures, car accidents, mortality rates, or the length of life of a light bulb.

成年女性的平均身高是多少？

What is the average height of female adults?

如果我们随机选择一千名成年女性并测量她们的身高，我们最终会得到一个看起来像钟形曲线的结果分布。他们的身高将以他们的平均身高为中心，曲线的宽度表示身高围绕这个平均值的变化程度。将一名极高的女性添加到大样本中并不会真正改变平均身高。

If we randomly select one thousand adult females and measure their height, we end up with a distribution of outcomes that look like a bell-shaped curve. Their heights will center around their average height, and the breadth of the curve indicates how variable around this average the heights are. Adding one extremely tall woman to a large sample doesn’t really change the average height.

同样的推理也适用于汽车保险公司。保险公司玩同一游戏的次数越多，平均值作为指导的效果就越好。添加一个极其昂贵的车祸并没有真正改变这一点。平均值具有代表性，具有预测能力。

The same reasoning can be applied to an auto insurance company. The more of the same game the insurance company plays, the better the average becomes as a guide. Adding an extremely expensive car accident doesn’t really change this. The average is representative and has predictive power.

但是对于那些涉及巨大和不寻常风险的保险类别，我们不能使用正态分布曲线。对于专门为独特事件提供保险的保险公司而言，结果的可能可变性是关键。

But we can’t use the normal distribution curve for those classes of insurance that involve mammoth and unusual risks. For an insurance company specializing in insuring unique events, the possible variability in outcomes is key.

TransCorp 的新计算机软件占据了 90% 的市场份额。

TransCorp’s new computer software grabbed 90% of the market.

在许多情况下，正态分布曲线可能无法为我们提供真实的现实情况。一个有利或不利的极端事件可能会产生巨大影响并显着改变平均值。我们之前在大小和频率方面看到了这种不均匀分布类型的示例。次数越少或时间越短或单个事件对平均的影响越大，考虑可变性就越重要，某些因素就越不可预测。例如，假设书籍的平均销售额为 200,000 美元。但是，如果我们的样本包含一本极端畅销书（哈利波特 书籍），则平均值将无法帮助我们预测一本新书的平均售价。其他例子是电影销售（电影泰坦尼克号)，金融市场的价格变化（货币突然大幅贬值，飓风（卡特里娜飓风）造成的损害，或创新的影响（TransCorp 的新软件）。例如，没有典型的软件，过去的平均值没有任何意义。

In many cases, the normal distribution curve may not give us a true picture of reality. One single favourable or unfavourable extreme event can have a large impact and dramatically change the averages. We saw examples of this uneven type of distribution earlier with size and frequency. The less number of times or the shorter the time or the more impact a single event may have on the average, the more important it is to consider the variability, and the more unpredictable some factor becomes. For example, suppose the average sales of books are $200,000. But if our sample contains one extreme best-seller (the Harry Potter books), the average will not help us predict what a new book on average may sell for. Other examples are movie sales (the movie Titanic), price changes in financial markets (a sudden large depreciation of a currency, damages from hurricanes (Katrina), or impact from innovations (TransCorp’s new software). For example, there is no typical software and past averages don’t mean anything.

我们看到过去发生的事情。我们不知道最大的飓风将是什么或发生的可能性。当我们回顾过去时，我们只会看到有记载的过去最大的飓风是什么。

We see what has happened in the measured past. We don’t know what the biggest hurricane will be or its likelihood of occurring. When we look back, we only see what the biggest hurricane was in the documented past.

我们无法使用过去的统计数据来预测这些罕见且影响大的事件。我们不知道它们的时间、频率或影响程度。我们无法准确地弄清楚它们的属性或开发一个公式。我们只知道它们会发生并且会产生巨大的影响。在某些情况下，我们可能有一些证据告诉我们概率是否正在发生变化。此外，许多事件不是独立的，而是相互关联的。金融市场就是一个例子；市场有记忆，资产可能相互关联，一个坏事件可能导致另一个坏事件。随机性认识论者纳西姆·尼古拉斯·塔勒布 (Nassim Nicholas Taleb) 在他的著作《黑天鹅》 (The Black Swan)中详细描述了在一个巨大事件可以显着改变现实的情况下使用正态分布曲线的危险。

We can’t use past statistics to predict these rare and high-impact events. We don’t know their timing, frequency, or degree of impact. We can’t exactly figure out their properties or develop a formula. We only know that they happen and that they can have a huge impact. In some cases, we may have some evidence telling us if the probabilities are changing. Also, many events are not independent but are instead interconnected. Financial markets are one example; markets have memories, assets may be correlated and one bad event may cause another. The danger of using the normal distribution curve in cases where one huge event can dramatically change reality is well described at length by the Epistemologist of Randomness Nassim Nicholas Taleb in his book The Black Swan.

10个人的总财富为1000万美元，即人均财富为100万美元。

10 people have a total wealth of$10 million i.e. the average wealth per person is $1 million.

如果一个人有 1000 万美元而九个一无所有怎么办？人均收入怎么可能飙升？假设十个中产阶级人士乘坐公共汽车。一个人下车，一个亿万富翁上车。

What if one person has $10 million and nine nothing? How can the average income soar? Suppose ten middle-class people are riding on a bus. One gets off the bus and a billionaire gets on.

约翰可以选择玩两种游戏中的一种。每场比赛都有三个同样可能的结果。游戏可以是机会、保险、投资等游戏之一。

John has an option to play one of two games. Each game has three equally likely outcomes. The game may be one of chance, insurance, investing, etc.

  结果 平均结果 可能性  期望值
游戏 1 30 40 50 40 1 / 3 1 / 3 1 / 3  40
游戏 2

 		0 20 100 40 1 / 3 1 / 3 1 / 3  40

如果他一遍又一遍地玩每场比赛，那么两场比赛的期望值都是 40，所以他选择玩什么游戏应该无关紧要。但是如果约翰只玩一次这个游戏呢？他应该玩第 1 场比赛，因为它的可变性较小。

If he plays each game over and over, the expected value is 40 for both, so it shouldn’t matter what game he chooses to play. But what about if John only plays this game once? He should play game 1 since it has less variability.

约翰被邀请投资一家私人风险投资基金。这位风险投资经理的往绩记录是过去五年的平均回报率为 25%。

John has been offered to invest in a private venture capital fund. The venture manager’s track record is an average rate of return of 25% over the last five years.

 如果我们不看底层性能是如何产生的，这并不能说明什么。通过仔细观察这种回报是如何产生的，约翰发现风险投资经理已经完成了 10 笔交易。一笔交易取得了惊人的成功，其余的都失败了。这笔交易是因为运气吗？

 This doesn’t say much if we don’t look at how the underlying performance was produced. By looking closely at how this return was produced John found that the venture manager had done 10 deals. One deal had been a spectacular success and the rest failures. Had this one deal been due to luck?

请记住，有些人在报告他们的表现时会遗漏数据。

Remember that some people leave out data when reporting their performance.

玛丽在报纸上读到房子的平均价格是 1,000,000 美元。

Mary reads in the paper that the average price of a house is $1,000,000.

但这可能会使她对现实产生错误的认识。假设有 100 栋房屋，其中 90 栋售价为 500,000 美元，10 栋“城堡”售价为 550 万美元。我们必须注意变化。

But this may cause her to get a false picture of reality. Assume there are 100 houses and 90 of them are priced at $500,000 and 10"castles" at $5.5 million. We have to watch out for the variations.

一位企业高管告诉我们，他的公司在过去 3 年的平均收益为 5000 万美元。但当我们仔细观察时，我们会发现业绩记录存在很大的可变性和下降趋势：1998 年：1 亿美元，1999 年：5000 万美元，2000 年：0 美元。

A business executive tells us that his company had average earnings of $50 million over the last 3 years. But when we look closer we find great variability and a downward trend in the performance record: 1998: $100 million, 1999: $50 million, 2000: $0.

中位数是分布的中间，其中一半结果高于中位数，一半低于中位数。如果 9 个人每人拥有 100 万美元，而一个人拥有 10 亿美元，则平均财富约为 1.01 亿美元，但中位数为 100 万美元。

The median is the middle of a distribution where half the outcomes are above the median and half below. If 9 people have $ 1 million each and one has $ 1 billion, the average wealth is about $ 101 million, but the median amount is $ 1 million.

1982 年，斯蒂芬·杰伊·古尔德 (Stephen Jay Gould) 被诊断出患有一种罕见且致命的癌症，发现后的平均死亡率为 8 个月。他战胜了癌症20年。

In 1982, Stephen Jay Gould was diagnosed with a rare and deadly form of cancer with a median mortality of 8 months after discovery. He beat the cancer for 20 years.

8 个月的中位死亡率是否意味着一个人将在 8 个月内死亡？古尔德了解到，8 个月的中位死亡率意味着一半的人会在 8 个月内死亡，而一半的人会活得更长。但他发现 8 个月后结果的分布比之前更广泛。这是有道理的，因为与 8 个月后相比，8 个月期间结果的传播存在下限。没有人会在 8 个月的期限开始之前死亡，但那些幸存下来的人可以活得比 8 个月长得多。我们不能将平均数或中位数视为任何个人最有可能的结果。查看所有结果之间的差异。这意味着应该根据个体的结果可能好于还是差于中位数来确定治疗方法。

Does an 8 month median mortality mean that a person will be dead in 8 months? Gould learned that an 8 month median mortality means half the people die before 8 months and half will live longer. But he found that there was a wider spread of outcomes after 8 months than before. This makes sense since there is a lower limit to the spread of outcomes during an 8 month period than after 8 months. No person will die before the start of the 8 month period but those who survive can live considerably longer than 8 months. We can’t treat the average or the median as the most likely outcome for any single individual. Look at the variation between all outcomes. This means that a treatment ought to be determined based on whether an individual is likely to have an outcome better or worse than the median.

回归的影响

Effects of regression

“均值回归”是弗朗西斯·加尔顿爵士（查尔斯·达尔文的堂兄）提出的概念。它说，在任何涉及偶然性的事件系列中，非常好的或糟糕的表现、高分或低分、极端事件等通常都会出现更平均的表现或不太极端的事件。如果我们做得非常好，下一次我们可能会做得更糟，而如果我们做得不好，下一次可能会做得更好。但回归均值并不是自然法则。仅仅是一种统计趋势。它可能需要很长时间才能发生。

"Regression to the mean" is a notion worked out by Sir Francis Gal ton (Charles Darwin’s first cousin). It says that, in any series of events where chance is involved, very good or bad performances, high or low scores, extreme events, etc. tend on the average, to be followed by more average performance or less extreme events. If we do extremely well, we’re likely to do worse the next time, while if we do poorly, were likely to do better the next time. But regression to the mean is not a natural law. Merely a statistical tendency. And it may take a long time before it happens.

约翰对新员工的表现不满意，将他们纳入技能提升计划。他在项目结束时衡量员工的技能。

Dissatisfied with the new employees’ performance, John put them into a skill enhancing program. He measures the employees’ skills at the end of the program.

他们的分数现在比第一次测试时高。约翰的结论：“技能提升计划导致了技能的提高。” 这不一定是真的。他们的较高分数可能是回归均值的结果。由于这些人被测量为处于技能等级的低端，即使他们没有参加技能增强计划，他们也会表现出进步。他们早期的表现可能有很多原因——压力、疲劳、疾病、分心等。他们真正的能力可能没有改变。

Their scores are now higher than they were on the first test. John’s conclusion:"The skill-enhancing program caused the improvement in skill." This isn’t necessarily true. Their higher scores could be the result of regression to the mean. Since these individuals were measured as being on the low end of the scale of skill, they would have shown an improvement even if they hadn’t taken the skill-enhancing program. And there could be many reasons for their earlier performance - stress, fatigue, sickness, distraction, etc. Their true ability perhaps hasn’t changed.

我们的表现总是围绕着一些平均真实表现而变化。极端表现往往会在下一次变得不那么极端。为什么？测试测量永远不可能准确。所有测量均由一份真实部分和一份随机误差部分组成。当测量结果极端时，它们很可能部分是偶然造成的。在我们第二次衡量绩效时，机会的贡献可能会减少。

Our performance always varies around some average true performance. Extreme performance tends to get less extreme the next time. Why? Testing measurements can never be exact. All measurements are made up of one true part and one random error part. When the measurements are extreme, they are likely to be partly caused by chance. Chance is likely to contribute less on the second time we measure performance.

如果我们仅仅因为不成功而从一种做事方式切换到另一种做事方式，那么下一次我们很可能会做得更好，即使新的做事方式相同或更差。

If we switch from one way of doing something to another merely because we are unsuccessful, it’s very likely that we do better the next time even if the new way of doing something is equal or worse.

第二部分和第三部分处理误判的原因和减少误判的想法。在我们进入第四部分之前，让我们总结一下如何从过去的错误中吸取教训。

Part Two and Three dealt with reasons for misjudgements and ideas for reducing them. Before we enter Part Four let’s conclude with how we can learn from past mistakes.

验尸

Post Mortem

西班牙裔美国哲学家乔治·桑塔亚纳曾说过：“那些不记得过去的人注定要重蹈覆辙。” 如果不参考过去，我们怎么能理解发生在我们身上的事情呢？我们很容易忘记记录我们的错误。但他们应该被强调。我们应该承认我们的错误并从中吸取教训。我们应该调查它们的原因并采取措施防止它们再次发生。问：

Spanish-American philosopher George Santayana once said:"Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it." How can we understand what is happening to us without any reference to the past? We conveniently forget to record our mistakes. But they should be highlighted. We should confess our errors and learn from them. We should look into their causes and take steps to prevent them from happening again. Ask:

  • 我做某事的最初原因是什么？我知道什么，我的假设是什么？当时我有什么选择？

  • What was my original reason for doing something? What did I know and what were my assumptions? What were my alternatives at the time?

  • 与我最初的猜测相比，现实情况如何？什么有效，什么无效？

  • How did reality work out relative to my original guess? What worked and what didn’t?

  • 鉴于可用的信息，我是否应该能够预测将要发生的事情？

  • Given the information that was available, should I have been able to predict what was going to happen?

  • 什么效果好？我应该怎么做？我做错了什么？我错过了什么？我必须学习什么？我必须停止做什么？

  • What worked well? What should I do differently? What did I fail to do? What did I miss? What must I learn? What must I stop doing?

我们为什么不做尸检？查尔斯芒格说：

Why don’t we do post mortems? Charles Munger says:

当声誉因记忆而受到威胁时，您往往会忘记自己的错误。正是出于这个原因，一家非常明智的公司——强生公司——有一个系统，在他们进行一些大型收购后两年左右，他们会进行事后分析。他们带回了最初的预测和进行交易的最初原因。他们确定提出论点的人以及你有什么。然后他们将它们与交易的结果进行比较。

You tend to forget your own mistakes when reputation is threatened by remembering. For that very reason, one very wise company — Johnson & Johnson — has a system whereby two years or so after they’ve made some big acquisition they have a post-mortem. And they bring back the original projections and the original reasons for doing the deal. They identify the people who made the arguments and what have you. Then they compare them with how the deal worked out.

沃伦巴菲特说，“胜利被吹嘘，但愚蠢的决定要么没有后续行动，要么被合理化。” 他继续：

Warren Buffett says that,"Triumphs are trumpeted, but dumb decisions either get no follow-up or are rationalized." He continues:

经理们往往不愿意查看他们仅在一两年前向董事会详细提议的资本项目或收购的结果。而且他们不想把实际情况与预测相关的数字贴在那里。这就是人性。

但我认为如果你偶尔去病理科看看你会是一个更好的医生。而且我认为，如果你审视你做出的每一个重要决定，看看哪些成功了，哪些没有成功——并计算出你的成功率，你就是一个更好的经理人或投资者。然后，如果您的安打率太差，您最好将决策权交给其他人。

Managers tend to be reluctant to look at the results of the capital projects or the acquisitions that they proposed with great detail only a year or two earlier to a board. And they don’t want to actually stick the figures up there as to how the reality worked out relative to the projections. That’s human nature.

But I think you’re a better doctor if you drop by the pathology department occasionally. And I think you’re a better manager or investor if you look at each decision that you’ve made of importance and see which ones worked out and which ones didn’t - and figure your batting average. Then, if your batting average gets too bad, you better hand the decision-making over to someone else.

我们还可以使用事前分析来帮助我们预测问题和关键漏洞。例如，在做出重要决定之前，想象一下确实出了问题的失败并问：这可能是什么原因造成的？

We could also use pre-mortems to help us anticipate problems and key vulnerabilities. For example, before making an important decision, imagine a failure where things really have gone wrong and ask: What could have caused this?

有哪些指导方针和工具可以更好地思考？查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 为我们提供了第四部分的一些介绍性评论：

What guidelines and tools are there to better thinking? Charles Munger gives us some introductory remarks for Part Four:

伯克希尔基本上是一个非常老式的地方，我们试图通过纪律来保持这种状态。我不是说老式的愚蠢。我指的是永恒的真理：基本数学、基本马感、基本恐惧、对人性的基本诊断，从而对人类行为做出可能的预测。如果你只是在一定程度的纪律下这样做，我认为它可能会取得很好的效果。

Berkshire is basically a very old-fashioned kind of a place and we try to exert discipline to stay that way. I don’t mean old-fashioned stupid. I mean the eternal verities: basic mathematics, basic horse sense, basic fear, basic diagnosis of human nature making possible predictions regarding human behaviour. If you just do that with a certain amount of discipline, I think it’s likely to work out quite well.

第四部分：

更好思考的指南

Part Four:

Guidelines to Better Thinking

大脑可以像肌肉一样得到发展，只要你不厌其烦地训练大脑去思考。

The brain can be developed just the same way as the muscles can be developed, if one will only take the pains to train the mind to think.

- Thomas Alva Edison

（美国发明家，1847-1931）

- Thomas Alva Edison

(American inventor, 1847-1931)

一：探索为理性思考提供基础的工具

One: Explore Tools That Provide A Foundation For Rational Thinking

孙子兵法中说：“兵之胜者，未战先于庙中。”

Sun Tzu said in The Art of War:"The general who wins a battle makes many calculations in his temple before the battle is fought."

这部分的目的是探索为理性思考提供基础的工具。在实现目标、解释“为什么”、防止和减少错误、解决问题和评估陈述时帮助我们的想法。

The purpose of this part is to explore tools that provide a foundation for rational thinking. Ideas that help us when achieving goals, explaining"why," preventing and reducing mistakes, solving problems, and evaluating statements.

将讨论以下 12 种工具。

The following 12 tools will be discussed.

  1. 现实模型。
  2. Models of reality.
  3. 意义。
  4. Meaning.
  5. 简化。
  6. Simplification.
  7. 规则和过滤器。
  8. Rules and filters.
  9. 目标。
  10. Goals.
  11. 备择方案。
  12. Alternatives.
  13. 结果。
  14. Consequences.
  15. 量化。
  16. Quantification.
  17. 证据。
  18. Evidence.
  19. 思维落后。
  20. Backward thinking.
  21. 风险。
  22. Risk.
  23. 态度。
  24. Attitudes.

现实模型

Models of reality

受过教育的人优于未受过教育的人，就像生者优于死者一样。

Educated, men are as superior to uneducated men as the living are to the dead.

- 亚里士多德

- Aristotle

学习、理解和使用可以解释世界运作方式的重要思想和一般原则。当有人问查尔斯·芒格他应该问自己的最佳问题是什么时，他说：

Learn, understand and use the big ideas and general principles that explain a lot about how the world works. When Charles Munger was asked what would be the best question he should ask himself, he said:

如果你问的不是投资问题，而是你的个人生活，我认为最好的问题是，“我能做些什么来让我的整个生活和整个心理过程变得更好吗？” 我要说的是，养成掌握构成现实基础的多种模型的习惯是你能做的最好的事情……这太有趣了——而且效果很好。

If you ask not about investment matters, but about your personal lives, I think the best question is,"Is there anything I can do to make my whole life and my whole mental process work better?" And I would say that developing the habit of mastering the multiple models which underlie reality is the best thing you can do.. .It’s just so much fun — and it works so well.

模型是一种想法，可以帮助我们更好地理解世界是如何运作的。模型说明后果并回答诸如“为什么”和“如何”之类的问题。以社会认同模型为例。会发生什么？当人们不确定时，他们通常会不假思索地做别人做的事，而不会考虑正确的做法。这个想法有助于解释“为什么”并预测人们在某些情况下可能的行为“如何”。

A model is an idea that helps us better understand how the world works. Models illustrate consequences and answer questions like"why" and"how". Take the model of social proof as an example. What happens? When people are uncertain they often automatically do what others do without thinking about the correct thing to do. This idea helps explain"why" and predict"how" people are likely to behave in certain situations.

模型帮助我们避免问题。假设我们被告知地球由无限资源组成。通过了解有关限制的概念，我们知道该陈述是错误的。有人向我们提出了一个与物理定律相矛盾的项目的投资建议。远离任何没有科学意义的事物可以避免多少痛苦？

Models help us avoid problems. Assume that we are told that the earth consists of infinite resources. By knowing the idea about limits, we know the statement is false. Someone gives us an investment proposal about a project that contradicts the laws of physics. How much misery can be avoided by staying away from whatever doesn’t make scientific sense?

有用模型的特征是什么？

What characterizes a useful model?

如果一个模型与现实相符，那么它很可能是真的。一种与现实相符的生物学观点是“人们的行为通常是出于自身利益”。但不是“人的性格可以用罗夏墨迹测验来评估”的想法。它不能预测人的性格。问：潜在的大创意是什么？我了解它在实际生活中的应用吗？它能帮助我了解世界吗？它是如何工作的？为什么它有效？它在什么条件下工作？它有多可靠？它有什么局限性？它与其他模型有何关系？

If a model agrees with reality, it is most likely true. One idea from biology that agrees with reality is that"people on average act out of self-interest." But not the idea that"people’s personalities can be evaluated by using the Rorschach ink-blot test." It can’t predict people’s personalities. Ask: What is the underlying big idea? Do I understand its application in practical life? Does it help me understand the world? How does it work? Why does it work? Under what conditions does it work? How reliable is it? What are its limitations? How does it relate to other models?

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 举例说明了化学中的一个有用想法——自催化：

Charles Munger gives an example of a useful idea from chemistry — autocatalysis:

如果你在化学中进行某种过程，它会自行加速。因此，您在不断尝试做的事情上得到了惊人的提升。现在，物理定律不会永远运行下去。但它运行了很长一段时间。所以你得到了巨大的提升。你完成了 A——突然之间，你暂时获得了 A + B + C。

If you get a certain kind of process going in chemistry, it speeds up on its own. So you get this marvellous boost in what you’re trying to do that runs on and on. Now, the laws of physics are such that it doesn’t run on forever. But it runs on for a goodly while. So you get a huge boost. You accomplish A — and, all of a sudden, you’re getting A + B + C for awhile.

他继续告诉我们如何应用这个想法：

He continues telling us how this idea can be applied:

迪斯尼是自动催化的一个了不起的例子……他们把所有那些电影都装在罐子里了。他们拥有版权。就像可口可乐在制冷出现时繁荣发展一样，当录像带被发明时，迪斯尼不需要发明任何东西或做任何事情，只需把东西从罐子里拿出来贴在录像带上。

Disney is an amazing example of autocatalysis... They had all those movies in the can. They owned the copyright. And just as Coke could prosper when refrigeration came, when the video-cassette was invented, Disney didn’t have to invent anything or do anything except take the thing out of the can and stick it on the cassette.

哪些型号最可靠？查理芒格回答：

Which models are most reliable? Charles Munger answers:

来自硬科学和工程的模型是地球上最可靠的模型。工程质量控制——至少对你我和非专业工程师来说很重要的核心——在很大程度上是基于费马和帕斯卡的初等数学：它的成本如此之高，而你获得成功的可能性却大大降低如果你花这么多，它会崩溃......

当然，备份系统的工程理念是一个非常强大的理念。断点的工程理念——这也是一个非常强大的模型。来自物理学的临界质量概念是一个非常强大的模型。

The models that come from hard science and engineering are the most reliable models on this Earth. And engineering quality control - at least the guts of it that matters to you and me and people who are not professional engineers — is very much based on the elementary mathematics of Fermat and Pascal: It costs so much and you get so much less likelihood of it breaking if you spend this much...

And, of course, the engineering idea of a backup system is a very powerful idea. The engineering idea of breakpoints - that’s a very powerful model, too. The notion of a critical mass - that comes out of physics - is a very powerful model.

一个有价值的模型可以对未来可能发生的后果做出有意义的解释和预测，因为错误的代价很高。

A valuable model produces meaningful explanations and predictions of likely future consequences where the cost of being wrong is high.

模型应该易于使用。如果它很复杂，我们不使用它。

A model should be easy to use. If it is complicated, we don’t use it.

它几乎每天都有用。如果不使用它，我们就会忘记它。如果我们不使用它，知识又有什么用呢？

It is useful on a nearly daily basis. If it is not used, we forget it. And what use is knowledge if we don’t use it?

考虑许多想法有助于我们获得整体观点

Considering many ideas help us achieve a holistic view

喜爱智慧的人，必定是许多事的探究者。

Those who love wisdom must be inquirers into many things indeed.

- 赫拉克利特

- Heraclitus

什么可以帮助我们看到大局？我们如何考虑一个问题的多个方面？使用来自许多学科的知识和见解。大多数问题都需要从不同的角度来研究。查尔斯芒格说，“在大多数复杂的人类问题中，你必须能够使用所有重要的想法，而不仅仅是其中的几个。”

What can help us see the big picture? How can we consider many aspects of an issue? Use knowledge and insights from many disciplines. Most problems need to be studied from a variety of perspectives. Charles Munger says,"In most messy human problems, you have to be able to use all the big ideas and not just a few of them."

世界是多学科的。物理学并不能解释一切；生物学或经济学也没有。例如，在企业中，了解规模如何改变行为、系统如何崩溃、供应如何影响价格以及激励如何导致行为是很有用的。

The world is multidisciplinary. Physics doesn’t explain everything; neither does biology or economics. For example, in a business it is useful to know how scale changes behaviour, how systems may break, how supply influences prices, and how incentives cause behaviour.

由于没有哪一门学科可以解决所有问题，因此我们需要理解和使用来自所有重要学科——数学、物理学、化学、工程学、生物学、心理学——的重要思想，并按照它们的可靠性对它们进行排序和使用。查尔斯·芒格说明了这一点的重要性：

Since no single discipline has all the answers, we need to understand and use the big ideas from all the important disciplines — mathematics, physics, chemistry, engineering, biology, psychology, and rank and use them in order of their reliability. Charles Munger illustrates the importance of this:

假设您想在合约桥牌中擅长庄家游戏。好吧，你知道合同——你知道你必须实现什么。你可以通过放下你的高牌和无敌的王牌来计算你有哪些确定的赢家。

但是，如果您缺少一两个技巧，您将如何获得其他所需的技巧？好吧，只有六种左右不同的标准方法：您已经建立了长套。你有技巧。你有掷界外球比赛。你有 cross-ruffs。你有压力。你有各种各样的方法来误导防守方犯错误。所以它的型号数量非常有限。但是，如果您只知道其中的一两个模型，那么您将成为庄家游戏中的马蹄声……

如果你没有完整的曲目，我向你保证你会过度使用你所拥有的有限的曲目——包括使用不合适的模型，因为它们在你心目中的有限库存中可供你使用。

Suppose you want to be good at declarer play in contract bridge. Well, you know the contract — you know what you have to achieve. And you can count up the sure winners you have by laying down your high cards and your invincible trumps.

But if you’re a trick or two short, how are you going to get the other needed tricks? Well, there are only six or so different, standard methods: You’ve got long-suit establishment. You’ve got finesses. You’ve got throw-in plays. You’ve got cross-ruffs. You’ve got squeezes. And you’ve got various ways of misleading the defense into making errors. So it’s a very limited number of models. But if you only know one or two of those models, then you’re going to be a horse’s patoot in declarer play...

If you don’t have the full repertoire, I guarantee you that you’ll over-utilize the limited repertoire you have — including use of models that are inappropriate just because they’re available to you in the limited stock you have in mind.

假设我们有一个问题问：什么可以解释这个？我们怎样才能做到这一点？那么我们如何使用不同的想法呢？查尔斯·芒格告诉我们如何去做：

Suppose we have a problem and ask: What can explain this? How can we achieve this? How can we then use different ideas? Charles Munger tells us how to do it:

拥有一套完整的工具…….在你的脑海中以检查列表的方式浏览它们……你永远无法做出任何可以用最基本的方式以外的任何其他方式以更基本的方式做出的解释。而且您总是完全归因于您需要使用的最基本的想法。当你使用物理学时，你说你正在使用物理学。当你使用生物学时，你说你正在使用生物学。

Have a full kit of tools.. .go through them in your mind check-lists-style.. .you can never make any explanation that can be made in a more fundamental way in any other way than the most fundamental way. And you always take with full attribution to the most fundamental ideas that you are required to use. When you’re using physics, you say you’re using physics. When you’re using biology, you say you’re using biology.

我们还需要了解不同的想法是如何相互作用和结合的。查尔斯芒格说：

We also need to understand how different ideas interact and combine. Charles Munger says:

当两个、三个或四个力都在同一个方向上运作时，你会得到lollapalooza效果。而且，通常，您不会得到简单的加法。它通常就像物理学中的临界质量，如果您达到某个质量点，就会发生核爆炸——如果您没有达到该质量，您就不会得到任何值得一看的东西。

有时，力只是像普通数量一样相加，有时它们会在断点或临界质量的基础上结合……更常见的是，来自……模型的力在某种程度上是相互冲突的。你会得到巨大的、痛苦的权衡……所以你[必须]有模型，你[必须]看到相关性和相关性的影响。

You get lollapalooza effects when two, three or four forces are all operating in the same direction. And, frequently, you don’t get simple addition. It’s often like a critical mass in physics where you get a nuclear explosion if you get to a certain point of mass - and you don’t get anything much worth seeing if you don’t reach the mass.

Sometimes the forces just add like ordinary quantities and sometimes they combine on a break-point or critical-mass basis... More commonly, the forces coming out of.. .models are conflicting to some extent. And you get huge, miserable trade-offs... So you [must] have the models and you [must] see the relatedness and the effects from the relatedness.

英国数学家和哲学家阿尔弗雷德·诺斯·怀特海说：“教育的问题是让学生通过树木看到森林。” 我们需要从一个问题的多个方面去考虑，综合整合。我们需要了解它们如何组合在一起形成一个连贯的整体。综合一词来自古典希腊语，字面意思是“放在一起”。以下是如何将其用于解决问题的一些示例。

The British mathematician and philosopher Alfred North Whitehead said:"The problem of education is to make the pupil see the wood by means of the trees." We need to consider many aspects of an issue and synthesize and integrate them. We need to understand how it all fits together to form a coherent whole. The term synthesis comes from classical Greek and means literally"to put together." Below are some examples of how this can be used in problem-solving.

我们可以在一门学科内结合想法。我们在第二部分看到了心理倾向如何结合起来并产生 Lollapalooza 效果。

We can combine ideas within a discipline. We saw in Part Two how psychological tendencies can combine and give Lollapalooza effects.

我们可以尝试找到想法之间的联系，或者从这些联系中推导出新的想法。现代进化综合是生物学中几种思想的统一。

We can try to find connections between ideas or derive new ideas from these connections. The modern evolutionary synthesis was a unification of several ideas within biology.

我们可以结合来自不同学科的想法。来自数学的扩展思想、来自物理学的系统和约束以及来自微观经济学的竞争优势通常解释了商业价值是如何创造或破坏的。

We can combine ideas from different disciplines. The ideas of scaling from mathematics, systems and constraints from physics, and competitive advantage from microeconomics often explain how business value is created or destroyed.

我们可以尝试看到现象之间的关系，并尝试找到一个可以解释所有现象的原理。英国物理学家詹姆斯·克拉克·麦克斯韦 (James Clark Maxwell) 在一个模型中结合了电磁定律和光的行为定律。这个单一模型解释了光、电和磁现象。

We can try to see relationships between phenomena, and try to find one principle that can explain them all. The British physicist James Clark Maxwell combined in one model the laws of electricity and magnetism with the laws of behaviour of light. This single model explained optical, electrical and magnetic phenomena.

我们可以在学科内部或学科之间找到相似之处或功能等价物。化学中粘度的功能等价物是经济学中的粘性。

We can find similarities or functional equivalents within or between disciplines. The functional equivalent of viscosity from chemistry is stickiness in economics.

我们怎样才能学习一个想法，让它留在我们的记忆中？

How can we learn an idea so it sticks in our memory?

塞缪尔·约翰逊说：“他是人类的恩人，他将生活中的伟大规则浓缩成简短的句子，很容易在记忆中留下深刻印象，并因此习惯性地浮现在脑海中。”

Samuel Johnson said:"He is a benefactor of mankind who contracts the great rules of life into short sentences, that may be easily impressed on the memory, and so recur habitually to the mind."

理查德·费曼在他的一次物理讲座中回答了以下问题：

Richard Feynman answered the following question in one of his physics lectures:

如果在某种灾难中，所有的科学知识都被摧毁，只有一句话传给了下一代的生物，那么什么陈述会用最少的文字包含最多的信息？我相信这是原子假说（或原子事实，或任何你想称呼它的东西），即所有事物都是由原子构成的——小粒子以永恒的运动四处移动，当它们相距一小段距离时相互吸引，但是相互排斥。在那句话中，你会看到，如果只运用一点想象力和思考，就会发现关于世界的信息量是巨大的。

If, in some cataclysm, all of scientific knowledge were to be destroyed, and only one sentence passed on to the next generations of creatures, what statement would contain the most information in the fewest words? I believe it is the atomic hypothesis (or the atomic fact, or whatever you wish to call it) that all things are made of atoms—little particles that move around in perpetual motion, attracting each other when they are a little distance apart, but repelling upon being squeezed into one another. In that one sentence, you will see, there is an enormous amount of information about the world, if just a little imagination and thinking are applied.

处理big ideas的时候可以用费曼的“一句话解释”。来自心理学的一句话想法的一个例子是：“我们得到了我们的奖励。” 物理学的一句话是：“能量既不被创造也不被消灭——只是从一种形式转变为另一种形式。”

We can use the Feynman"one sentence explanation" when dealing with big ideas."What sentence contains the most information in the fewest words?" An example of a one-sentence idea from psychology is:"We get what we reward for." A sentence from physics is:"Energy is neither created nor destroyed — only changed from one form into another."

理解模型的另一种方法是给它一个“钩子”。将模型与戏剧性的现实生活故事、类比、个人或图片相关联。例如，要记住社会证明，我们可以考虑纽约市的吉诺维斯凶杀案（见第二部分）。

Another way to understand a model is to give it a"hook." Associate the model with a dramatic real-life story, analogy, individual, or picture. For example to remember social proof, we can think about the Genovese homicide in New York City (see Part Two).

一句中国谚语说，“闻之忘，见之记，行之知”。由于学习某物的最佳方式是通过实践，我们必须定期将模型应用于不同的情况。像任何技能一样，这需要练习和纪律。

A Chinese proverb says,"I forget what I hear; I remember what I see; I know what I do." Since the best way to learn something is by doing it, we must apply models routinely to different situations. Like any skill, this takes both practice and discipline.

搜索解释

Search for explanations

会发生什么，为什么会发生？

What happens and why does it happen?

迫使我们学习模型以更好地应对现实的一种方法是睁开眼睛，看看我们周围看到的事物，并问“为什么”事情正在发生（或为什么事情没有发生）。举一些简单的例子，如“苹果为什么往下掉？” 或“为什么我们滑倒时会摔倒？” 或者“我们为什么不从地球上掉下来？” 英国数学家和物理学家艾萨克·牛顿爵士的万有引力定律可以解释这一点。

One way of forcing us to learn models to better deal with reality is to open our eyes and look at the things we see around us and ask"why" things are happening (or why things are not happening). Take some simple examples as"why do apples fall downward?" or"why do we fall down when we slip?" or"why don’t we fall off the earth?" The English mathematician and physicist Sir Isaac Newton’s law of gravitation can explain this.

牛顿第一定律告诉我们，运动中的物体倾向于以稳定的速度沿直线继续运动，静止的物体倾向于保持静止，除非物体受到外力作用。

Newton’s 1st law tells us that an object in motion tends to continue in motion at a steady speed in a straight line, and an object at rest tends to stay at rest, unless the object is acted upon by an outside force.

这意味着只有 3 种方法可以改变一个物体：静止的物体可以开始运动，以稳定速度运动的物体可以加速或减速，直线运动的物体可以改变方向. 改变物体的运动需要什么？力。

This means that there are only 3 ways to change an object: an object at rest can start to move, an object in motion at a steady speed can go up or down in speed, and an object in motion in a straight line can change direction. And what is needed to change an object’s motion? A force.

运动的所有变化都是响应力的作用而发生的。我们所说的力是指作用在物体上的推力或拉力。当我们打开一扇门或扔一个棒球时，我们正在使用力量（肌肉力量）。我们所做的几乎所有事情都涉及力量。

All change in motion happens in response to the action of force(s). By forces, we mean a push or a pull that acts on an object. When we open a door or throw a baseball, we are using forces (muscular effort). Almost everything we do involves forces.

牛顿第二定律告诉我们，力是质量和加速度的乘积。加速度是速度和/或方向的任何变化。它取决于物体的质量（衡量物体抵抗其运动状态变化的能力）以及作用在其上的力的大小和方向。我们在给定质量下使用的力越大，加速度就越大。但是质量越大，物体越能抵抗加速度。例如，我们扔棒球时用力越大，球的加速度就越大。如果我们增加质量，我们必须增加更多的力才能产生相同的加速度。

Newton’s 2nd law tells us that force is the product of mass and acceleration. Acceleration is any change in speed and/or direction. It depends on the mass (measures an object power to resist change in its state of motion) of an object and the magnitude and direction of the force acting on it. The more force we use at a given mass, the greater the acceleration. But the more mass, the more an object resists acceleration. For example, the more force we use to throw a baseball, the greater the acceleration of the ball. If we increase mass, we have to add more force to produce the same rate of acceleration.

牛顿第三定律是力成对作用。一个物体对第二个物体施加力，但第二个物体也施加一个与作用在其上的力（第一个物体）大小相等且方向相反的力。正如牛顿在 《自然哲学的数学原理》中所说：“如果你用手指压一块石头，那么手指也被石头压住。” 如果我们扔棒球，球也会以同样的力“抛”我们或推回我们的手。

Newton’s 3rd law is that forces work in pairs. One object exerts a force on a second object, but the second object also exerts a force equal and opposite in direction to the force acting on it — the first object. As Newton said in Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica:"If you press a stone with your finger, the finger is also pressed by the stone." If we throw a baseball, the ball also "throws" us or pushes back on our hand with the same force.

现在我们来谈谈重力。受约翰内斯·开普勒关于行星运动的研究和伽利略·伽利莱关于自由落体的研究的影响，牛顿发现存在一种力可以将两个物体相互吸引。有两个因素会影响吸引力的程度。质量和距离。两个物体的质量越大或它们之间的距离越近，它们之间的吸引力就越大。这也意味着物体之间的距离越大，引力就越弱。例如，如果我们将距离加倍，则力的强度为第四。

Now we come to the force of gravity. Influenced by Johannes Kepler’s work on planetary motion and Galileo Galilei’s work on freely falling objects, Newton found out that there was a force that attracts two objects to each other. Two factors influence the degree of attraction. Mass and distance. The greater the mass of two objects or the closer the distance between them, the greater the attraction between them. This also means that the greater the distance between the objects, the weaker the force of gravity. If we for example double the distance, the force is as fourth as strong.

在数学上，我们可以将吸引力或引力表示为一个物体的质量乘以另一个物体的质量除以物体之间距离的平方。所有这些都乘以一个常数（数值不变的数字）- g（每秒 9.8 米或 9.8 m/s 2）。我们可以将 g 称为地球表面附近的重力加速度。

Mathematically we can state the force of attraction or gravitation as equal to the mass of one object multiplied with the mass of the other object divided by the square of the distance between the objects. All this is multiplied with a constant (a number that doesn’t change in value) - g (9.8 meters per second each second or 9.8 m/s2). We can call g, the acceleration of gravity near the surface of the Earth.

正是重力使苹果落向地球。

It is the force of gravity that makes an apple fall toward the Earth.

地球吸引苹果的力与其质量成正比，与它们之间距离的平方成反比。但是牛顿第三定律说，苹果对地球也施加了一个相等但相反的力。地球对苹果的引力与苹果对地球的引力相同。因此，即使在我们看来苹果落到地球上，地球和苹果都会向彼此落下。力是相同的，但正如我们从牛顿第二定律看到的那样，而不是加速度。它们的质量不同。与苹果相比，地球的质量是如此之大，以至于我们看到苹果“掉落”。苹果从静止开始落向地球，因为它们的质量小于地球，这意味着它们向地球加速（改变速度）比地球向苹果加速（改变速度）更多。

The Earth attracts the apple with a force that is proportional to its mass and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. But Newton’s third law says that the apple also exerts an equal and opposite force on the Earth. The force of attraction on the apple by the Earth is the same as the force of attraction on the Earth by the apple. So even if it looks to us like the apple falls to the Earth, both the Earth and apple fall toward each other. The force is the same but as we see from Newton’s second law, not the acceleration. Their masses differ. The Earth’s mass is so large compared to the apple that we see the apple "falling." Apples fall, starting at rest, to the Earth since they have less mass than the Earth, meaning they accelerate (change speed) more toward the Earth than the Earth does toward the apple. The Earth’s great mass also explains why we fall toward the Earth when we slip.

同样的力将月球吸引到地球。但是，是什么让月球绕地球运行而不是撞向地球呢？

The same force draws the Moon to the Earth. But what keeps the Moon in orbit around the Earth instead of crashing into the Earth?

牛顿知道一定有某种力量将月球拉向地球。否则，根据第一定律，月球将继续以稳定的速度沿直线运动，而不是更椭圆的运动。必须有某种力量不断将月球拉出其直线运动并改变其方向。由于月球的轨道是圆形的，这种力一定来自地球的中心。为什么？牛顿知道向心力（指向固定中心的任何力）控制物体围绕固定点做圆周运动。

Newton knew that there must be some force pulling the Moon toward the Earth. Otherwise according to the 1st law the Moon would continue in motion in a straight line at a steady speed instead of its more elliptical motion. Some force must continuously pull the Moon out of its straight-line motion and change its direction. And since the Moon’s orbit is circular, this force must originate from the center of the Earth. Why? Newton knew that a centripetal force (any force directed toward a fixed center) controls objects going in a circle around a fixed point.

那个力就是重力。它通过不断改变朝向地球中心的方向来改变月球的加速度，从而导致月球弯曲成圆周运动。当月球沿与地球切线（接触曲线的直线）的方向水平移动时，在其路径上的每个点，重力将其向内拉向地球中心，结果是月球在圆形轨道上。

That force is gravity. It changes the Moons acceleration by continually changing its direction toward the center of the Earth causing the Moon to curve into circular motion. As the Moon moves horizontally in a direction tangent (the straight line that touches a curve) to the Earth, at each point along its path, gravity pulls it inward toward the center of the Earth and the result is a Moon in circular orbit.

月球的速度足以确保它的下落距离与地球的曲率相匹配。月球与地球保持相同的距离，因为地球以与月球“坠落”相同的速度弯曲。当月球向地球下降一定距离时，它已经横向移动了大约相同的距离。如果它的速度低得多，引力会逐渐迫使月球靠近地球，直到它们相互碰撞。如果它的速度高得多，月球就会摆脱引力并远离我们。

The Moon’s speed is great enough to ensure that its falling distance matches the Earth’s curvature. The Moon remains at the same distance above Earth since the Earth curves at the same rate as the Moon"falls." By the time the Moon has fallen a certain distance toward Earth, it has moved sideways about the same distance. If its speed were much lower, the pull of gravity would gradually force the Moon closer to the Earth until they crash into each other. If its speed where much higher, the Moon would escape the force of gravity and move away from us.

由于月球与地球的距离（引力较弱），月球的加速度没有苹果快。在其轨道上运行的月球距地球中心的距离大约是苹果距地球中心的距离的六十倍。

The Moon doesn’t accelerate as much as the apple, because of its distance to Earth (the force of gravity is weaker). The Moon in its orbit is about sixty times as far away from the Earth’s center as the apple is.

牛顿万有引力定律不足以描述速度接近光速的物体的运动。为什么？根据爱因斯坦的相对论，物体的质量不是一个常数。它随着速度接近光速而增加。当引力场比地球上发现的大得多时，牛顿的理论和相对论也不同。不过，在大多数情况下，牛顿定律和他的万有引力理论是足够的。

Newton’s law of gravitation isn’t enough to describe the motion of objects whose speed is near the speed of light. Why? According to Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity, the mass of an object is not a constant. It increases as its speed approaches the speed of light. Newton’s theories and the theory of relativity also differ when gravitational fields are much larger than those found on Earth. Under most conditions, though, Newton’s laws and his theory of gravitation are adequate.

重力的相对影响因大小和规模而异。

The relative influence of gravity varies with size and scale.

为什么从高树上掉下来不会伤害昆虫？

Why does falling from a high tree not harm an insect?

伽利略·伽利莱在《两门新科学》中写道：“谁不知道马从三四肘高处摔断骨头，狗或猫从八十肘高处摔断。不会受伤吧？”

In Two New Sciences, Galileo Galilei wrote:"Who does not know that a horse falling from a height of three or four cubits will break his bones, while a dog falling from the same height or a cat from a height of eight or ten cubits will suffer no injury?"

想象一下，如果将一只老鼠、一匹马和一个人从 1,000 码外的飞机上抛出。会发生什么？生物学家 JBS Haldane 在On Being the Right Size（转载于 The World of Mathematics）中说：“你可以将一只老鼠从 1000 码长的矿井中扔下去；当它到达底部时，它会受到轻微的震动然后走开，前提是地面相当松软。老鼠死，人碎，马溅。”

Imagine if a mouse, a horse and a human were to be thrown out of an air-plane from 1,000 yards. What happens? The biologist J.B.S. Haldane said in On Being the Right Size (reprinted in The World of Mathematics):"You can drop a mouse down a thousand-yard mine shaft; and, on arriving at the bottom, it gets a slight shock and walks away, provided that the ground is fairly soft. A rat is killed, a man is broken, a horse splashes."

物理力对动物的作用不同。重力对大东西的影响比对小东西的影响更大。重力对我们的影响很大，但对较小的动物影响不大。由于人体表面积很小，重力作用在我们的体重上。但是对于具有高表面积体积比的非常小的动物来说，重力可以忽略不计。那么主导力是表面力。霍尔丹说：“将一只动物的长、宽、高各除以十，它的重量减为千分之一，但它的表面积只减为百分之一。所以小动物的坠落阻力相对大十倍比[重力]的驱动力。”

Physical forces act on animals differently. Gravity has a more powerful effect on bigger things, than on smaller things. Gravity is a major influence on us, but is of minor significance to smaller animals. Since human surface area is so small, gravitational forces act upon our weight. But gravity is negligible to very small animals with high surface area to volume ratios. The dominant force is then surface force. Haldane says:"Divide an animal’s length, breadth, and height each by ten; its weight is reduced to a thousandth, but its surface only to a hundredth. So the resistance to falling in the case of the small animal is relatively ten times greater than the driving force [of gravity]."

当存在空气阻力时，重量会影响速度。

Weight affects speed when air resistance is present.

在较小的尺度上，与空气阻力相比，重力变得越来越不重要。将一只老鼠从飞机上扔下来，它会随着作用在其表面的摩擦力克服重力的影响而漂浮下来。

On smaller scales, gravity becomes less and less important compared with air resistance. Throw a mouse off the plane and it floats down as frictional forces acting on its surface overcome the influence of gravity.

下落的物体下落的速度越来越快，直到沿相反方向作用的空气阻力（由空气阻力产生）等于其重量。空气阻力取决于表面积（下落物体下落时必须穿过的空气量）和下落物体的速度。由于鼠标的表面积与其重量相比非常大，因此在向上作用的空气阻力累积到其向下作用的重量之前，它不必下落得非常快。然后鼠标上的净力为零，鼠标停止加速。

A falling object falls faster and faster, until the force of air drag acting in the opposite direction (arising from air resistance) equals its weight. Air drag depends on the surface area (the amount of air the falling object must plow through as it falls) and the speed of the falling object. Since a mouse has so much surface area compared to its small weight, it doesn’t have to fall very fast before the upward-acting air drag builds up to its downward-acting weight. The net force on the mouse is then zero and the mouse stops accelerating.

空气对落马的阻力远大于对老鼠的阻力。发生这种情况是因为马犁过的空气比老鼠多。越重的马在空中落得越快，空气阻力就越大。在空气阻力等于马的重量之前，马下落的速度比人快，因此马会先落地。

The force of air resistance against the falling horse is much greater than the force against the mouse. This happens because the horse plows through more air than the mouse does. The heavier horse falls faster through the air, increasing air resistance even more. The horse falls faster than the human before the air drag equals its weight and will therefore reach the ground first.

马的表面积比老鼠大，但老鼠的体积比马的表面积大。老鼠遵循与人类相同的万有引力定律，也遵循相同的空气阻力定律。但是引力对人类来说是关键，而空气阻力对老鼠来说是最重要的。

The horse has a greater surface area than the mouse, but the mouse has a greater surface area for its volume than the horse has. A mouse obeys the same law of gravitation as a human, and also the same law of air-resistance. But gravitation is key for humans, while air-resistance is all-important for the mouse.

另一方面，由于表面张力，小鼠从水池中爬出时会遇到问题。霍尔丹告诉我们，湿老鼠必须承受自身重量的水。想象一下，如果我们身上背着与我们体重相等的水，要从浴缸里出来是多么困难。

On the other hand, due to surface tension, the mouse will have problems when climbing from a pool of water. Haldane tells us a wet mouse has to carry its own weight of water. Imagine how hard it would be to get out of the bathtub if we carried on our body a weight of water equal to our weight.

这些例子展示了我们如何通过观察和询问“为什么”事情发生来更好地处理现实。所以环顾四周，提出问题并记住发明家和工程师查尔斯·普罗透斯·斯坦梅茨的话：“没有愚蠢的问题，没有人在停止提问之前就变成了傻瓜。”

These examples show how we can better deal with reality by observing and ask"why" things happen. So look around, ask questions and remember the words of inventor and engineer Charles Proteus Steinmetz:"There are no foolish questions and no man becomes a fool until he has stopped asking questions."

假设大想法是真实的，直到学习否则。随着新证据的出现，所有知识都可能发生变化。这意味着我们必须不断学习和重新学习。

Assume that the big ideas are true until learning otherwise. All knowledge is subject to change as new evidence arrives. This mean we have to continuously learn and re-learn.

保持知识的活力并随着时间的推移增加知识会带来额外的好处。“就像铁会因为不用而生锈，死水会腐烂，或者当寒冷变成冰时，我们的智力也会浪费，除非它一直被使用，”列奥纳多·达·芬奇写道. 加州大学伯克利分校综合生物学教授 Marian Cleeves Diamond 的研究表明，刺激的环境、好奇心和教育是大脑的营养，因此是健康的。我们给大脑的刺激越多，我们就越好。在《今日心理学》  （1984 年）中，她说，“我寻找 88 岁后仍然非常活跃的人。我发现使用大脑的人并没有失去大脑。就这么简单。”

Keeping knowledge alive and adding knowledge over time comes with an extra benefit."Just as iron rusts from disuse, and stagnant water putrefies, or when cold turns to ice, so our intellect wastes unless it is kept in use," wrote Leonardo da Vinci. Research by Integrative Biology Professor Marian Cleeves Diamond at the University of California, Berkeley, reveals that a stimulating environment, curiosity and education are nourishment to the brain and therefore healthy. The more stimulation we give our brains, the better off we are. In Psychology Today (1984) she says,"I looked for people who were extremely active after 88 years of age. I found that the people who use their brains don’t lose them. It was that simple."

记住，如果我们不理解它的含义，知道一个定义或记住一个想法是没有用的。Alfred North Whitehead 在The Aims of Education中说：“教育应该是有用的，无论你的人生目标是什么。”

Remember, knowing a definition or memorizing an idea is useless if we don’t understand its meaning. Alfred North Whitehead said in The Aims of Education: "Education should be useful, whatever your aim in life."

二：意义

Two: Meaning

坏的。术语是良好思维的敌人。

Bad. terminology is the enemy of good thinking.

- 沃伦·巴菲特

- Warren Buffett

词语、定义、命题、陈述或目标不会告诉我们任何信息。我们需要明白他们的意思。知识也是一样。知识只有在有用时才有价值，而某些东西只有在我们理解它的含义时才有用。

Words, definitions, propositions, statements, or goals don’t tell us anything. We need to understand what they mean. It is the same with knowledge. Knowledge is only valuable if it’s useful and something is only useful if we understand what it means.

理查德·费曼 (Richard Feynman) 的父亲梅尔维尔 (Melville) 教导他的儿子，知道事物的名称和知道发生了什么之间的区别：

Richard Feynman’s father, Melville, taught his son, the difference between knowing the name of something and knowing what goes on:

看到那只鸟了吗？这是一种褐喉画眉，但在德国它被称为halzenfugel，而在中文中他们称它为chung ling即使你知道所有这些名字，你仍然对这只鸟一无所知。你只对人有所了解；他们怎么称呼这只鸟。

现在这只画眉会唱歌，会教它的幼鸟飞翔，它会在夏天飞到那么多英里以外的国家，没人知道它是怎么找到路的。

See that bird? It’s a brown-throated thrush, but in Germany it’s called a halzenfugel, and in Chinese they call it a chung ling and even if you know all those names for it, you still know nothing about the bird. You only know something about people; what they call the bird.

Now that thrush sings, and teaches its young to fly, and flies so many miles away during the summer across the country, and nobody knows how it finds its way.

这不是在学习的意义上告诉我们一些事情吗？单词或名称不构成知识。知道某物的名称并不能帮助我们理解它。由于理解意味着行动和成就，理解的一种方式是看会发生什么。费曼举例说明：

Doesn’t this tell us something in the sense of learning? Words or names don’t constitute knowledge. Knowing the name of something doesn’t help us understand it. Since understanding implies action and accomplishment, one way of understanding is to see what happens. Feynman illustrates:

有一张狗的图片，一只可以缠绕的玩具狗，一只手伸到缠绕器上，狗就可以动了。在最后一张图片下面，它写着“是什么让它移动？”……我想知道的答案是“能量让它移动”。...

说“上帝使它移动”或“精神使它移动”或“移动性使其移动”同样好。（事实上​​，我们同样可以说“能量让它停止”。）

这样看：那只是能量的定义。它应该被逆转。我们可能会说什么东西能动就是它里面有能量，但不是说“动的就是能量”……

如果你问孩子是什么让玩具狗动起来，你应该想想普通人会怎么回答。答案是你给弹簧上了发条；它试图放松并推动齿轮。这是开始科学课程的好方法。拆开玩具；看看它怎么运作...

我认为，对于第一课，学习神秘的回答问题的公式是非常糟糕的。

There is a picture of a dog, a windable toy dog, and a hand comes to the winder, and then the dog is able to move. Under the last picture, it says"What makes it move?"... the answer I was trying to learn is that"energy makes it move." ...

It would be equally well to say that"God makes it move," or"spirit makes it move," or"movability makes it move." (In fact one could equally well say"energy makes it stop.")

Look at it this way: That’s only the definition of energy. It should be reversed. We might say when something can move that it has energy in it, but not"what makes it move is energy."...

If you ask a child what makes the toy dog move, you should think about what an ordinary human being would answer. The answer is that you wound up the spring; it tries to unwind and pushes the gear around. What a good way to begin a science course. Take apart the toy; see how it works...

I think, for lesson number one, to learn a mystic formula for answering questions is very bad.

费曼给出了另一个空洞定义的例子：“你的鞋底因为摩擦而磨损。” 真正的知识是：“鞋革磨损是因为它与人行道摩擦，人行道上的小凹口和凸起会抓住碎片并将它们拉下来。”

Feynman gives another example of an empty definition:"the soles of your shoes wear out because of friction." Real knowledge is:"Shoe leather wears out because it rubs against the sidewalk and the little notches and bumps on the sidewalk grab pieces and pull them off."

费曼提供了一个测试来检验我们的理解：

Feynman provides a test we can do to check our understanding:

不要使用你刚刚学过的新词，试着用你自己的语言重新表述你刚刚学过的东西。不用“能量”这个词，告诉我你现在对狗的运动了解多少。

Without using the new word which you have just learned, try to rephrase what you have just learned in your own language. Without using the word"energy," tell me what you know now about the dog’s motion.

理解“意义”需要我们观察并提出基本问题。一些问题的例子是：

Understanding"meaning" requires that we observe and ask basic questions. Examples of some questions are:

  • 词义：这些词是什么意思？它们意味着什么？他们有什么意思吗？我们能否将文字、想法或陈述转化为可以告诉我们一些事情的普通情况？表达式总是相对的。我们必须根据某些东西来判断和衡量它。

  • Meaning of words: What do the words mean? What do they imply? Do they mean anything? Can we translate words, ideas or statements into an ordinary situation that tells us something? An expression is always relative. We have to judge and measure it against something.

  • 事件的意义：产生什么影响？使用普通话到底发生了什么？它在做什么？完成了什么？它在什么条件下发生？这还有什么意思？

  • Meaning of an event: What effect is produced? What is really happening using ordinary words? What is it doing? What is accomplished? Under what conditions does it happen? What else does it mean?

  • 原因：这里发生了什么，为什么？这管用吗？为什么或者为什么不？为什么会这样？为什么它在这里起作用但在那里不起作用？怎么会发生？背后的机制是什么？是什么让它发生？

  • Causes: What is happening here and why? Is this working? Why or why not? Why did that happen? Why does it work here but not there? How can it happen? What are the mechanisms behind? What makes it happen?

  • 启示：这个观察、事件或经历的结果是什么？这意味着什么？

  • Implications: What is the consequence of this observation, event, or experience? What does that imply?

  • 目的：我们为什么要这样做？我为什么要发生这种情况？

  • Purpose: Why should we do that? Why do I want this to happen?

  • 原因：为什么这个比那个好？

  • Reason: Why is this better than that?

  • 有用性：这个的适用性是什么？这对我想要实现的目标有什么意义吗？

  • Usefulness: What is the applicability of this? Does it mean anything in relation to what I want to achieve?

丹麦物理学家尼尔斯·玻尔说：“永远不要比你想象的更清楚地表达自己。” 在描述某事时，如实讲述，使用人们理解的词语，并根据他们熟悉的想法。阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦说：“如果你不能简单地解释它，你就还不够了解它。” 开门见山。问：我想说什么？沟通不畅的一个原因可能是这些词对你来说意味着一回事，而对你正在与之交谈的人来说意味着另一回事。

Danish physicist Niels Bohr said:"Never express yourself more clearly, than you are able to think." When describing something, tell it as it is and use words that people understand, and in terms of ideas with which they are familiar. Albert Einstein said:"If you can’t explain it simply, you don’t understand it well enough." Get to the point. Ask: What do I want to say? One reason for miscommunication can be that the words mean one thing to you and something else to the person you’re talking to.

问“发生了什么事？”

Ask "What happens?"

为什么沃伦巴菲特和查尔斯芒格在过去 42 年中成功地将伯克希尔哈撒韦公司的账面价值增加了​​ 3700 倍？为什么很多人投资亏本？

Why have Warren Buffett and Charles Munger successfully compounded the book value of Berkshire Hathaway 3700 times over the last 42 years? Why do many people lose money investing?

我们投资企业、公寓楼、农场或债券等经济资产的原因是为了赚钱。但是，这是什么意思？什么是赚钱？当我们赚钱时会发生什么？

The reason we invest in an economic asset like a business, apartment building, farm, or bond is to make money. But what does that mean? What is making money? What happens when we make money?

关注现金。“我能拿到多少现金，什么时候能拿到？”

Follow the cash."How much cash do I get and when do I get it?"

当我们赚钱时会发生的事情是，我们在未来得到的回报比我们今天投资的要多。例如，我们投资 100 美元并收回 150 美元。

What happens when we make money is that we get more money back in the future than we invest today. For example, we invest $100 and get back $150.

是什么决定了我们投资经济资产的回报？我们支付的价格、我们收回的金额以及何时收回。如果我们在 2 年或 10 年内收回 150 美元，情况就会大不相同。年回报率的差异是 22% 和 4%。我们的回报可以根据其他可用投资机会的预期回报来衡量。这意味着经济资产的价值受利率影响。如果兴趣改变，价值就会改变。利率越高，价值越低。

What determines our return from investing in an economic asset? The price we pay, how much money we get back, and when we get it back. It makes a huge difference if we get $150 back in 2 years or 10 years. The difference in yearly return is 22% versus 4%. Our return can be measured against the expected returns from other available investment opportunities. This means that the value of an economic asset is influenced by interest rates. If interest changes, value changes. The higher the rates, the less the value.

如果我们确定我们将在 5 年内每年获得 10 美元现金，并且我们使用 6% 的无风险政府债券利率作为贴现率，那么该资产的价值约为 42 美元。这意味着如果我们支付 42 美元，我们将获得 6% 的平均年回报率。如果我们支付 30 美元，我们的回报率会上升到 20%。一项经济资产的价值（例如 42 美元）与我们支付的价格之间的差异越大，我们的年回报就越高。

If we knew for certain we would get $10 in cash every year for 5 years and we use a risk-free government bond rate of 6% as the discount rate, then the asset has a value of about $42. This means that if we pay $42, we get a 6% average yearly rate of return. If we pay $30, our return rises to 20%. The larger the difference between an economic asset’s value (e.g. $42) and the price we pay, the higher our yearly return becomes.

沃伦巴菲特说，“我们使用无风险利率只是为了将一个项目与另一个项目等同起来。换句话说，我们正在寻找最有吸引力的东西。为了估计任何东西的现值，我们将使用一个数字。显然，我们总是可以购买政府债券。因此，这成为了衡量标准……来简单地比较各种投资机会：油井、农场，无论它是什么。”

Warren Buffett says,"We use the risk-free rate merely to equate one item to another. In other words, we’re looking for whatever is the most attractive. In order to estimate the present value of anything, we’re going to use a number. And, obviously, we can always buy government bonds. Therefore, that becomes the yardstick rate... to simply compare all kinds of investment opportunities across the spectrum: oil wells, farms, whatever it may be."

不要付出比你得到的价值更多的钱。

Don’t pay more than what you get back in value.

本杰明富兰克林说：“我认为人类的大部分苦难都是由于他们对事物价值的错误估计以及他们为口哨付出太多而给他们带来的。” Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld 的格言之一是：“能力的高度在于对事物真正价值的透彻了解。”

Benjamin Franklin said:"I conceive that great part of the miseries of mankind are brought upon them by the false estimates they have made of the value of things, and by their giving too much for their whistles." One of Francois Due de la Rochefoucauld’s maxims was:"The height of ability consists in a thorough knowledge of the true value of things."

将资金投资于经济资产时，我们应该问的关键问题是：我们可以取出的预期未来现金是多少，它什么时候出现？我们还能如何知道一项资产的价值以及在给定价格下我们可以期待什么样的回报？沃伦巴菲特说：“最后，你必须决定的是，你是要对一家企业进行 4 亿美元、6 亿美元还是 8 亿美元的估值——然后将其与价格进行比较。”

The key question we should ask when investing money in economic assets is: What is the expected future cash we can take out and when does it appear? How else can we know what an asset may be worth and what kind of return we can expect at a given price? Warren Buffett says:"In the end, what you have to decide is whether you’re going to value a business at $400 million, $600 million or $800 million - and then compare that with the price."

约翰想买一家冰激凌店（不管是小冰激凌店还是十亿美元企业的100股，相关道理都是一样的）。

John wants to buy an ice cream store (it doesn’t matter if it is a small ice cream store or 100 shares in a billion dollar business, the relevant reasoning is the same).

这是一笔好交易吗？这取决于约翰支付的价格，以及在冰淇淋店剩余寿命期间可以从冰淇淋店取出的现金的折现值。约翰可以取出多少现金？他什么时候可以拿出来？这取决于商店产生的自由现金流的数量和时间，或者他可以（以及何时）取出多少现金而不损害商店目前的竞争地位。

Is this a good deal? It depends on the price John pays, and the discounted value of the cash that can be taken out of the ice cream store during its remaining life. How much cash can John take out? When can he take it out? This depends on the amount and timing of the free cash flow that is generated by the store or how much cash he can take out (and when) without hurting the store’s present position against competition.

沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 谈到华尔街报告中经常出现的“现金流量”数字时说：

Warren Buffett says of the"cash flow" numbers that are often set forth in Wall Street reports:

这些数字通常包括 (a) [报告收益] 加上 (b) [折旧、损耗、摊销和某些其他非现金费用] - 但不减去 (c) [厂房和设备资本化支出的年均金额等] 大多数投资银行家的销售手册也有这种欺骗性的介绍。这意味着所提供的业务是金字塔的商业对应物——永远是最先进的，永远不需要更换、改进或翻新。

These numbers routinely include (a) [reported earnings] plus (b) [depreciation, depletion, amortization, and certain other non-cash charges] - but do not subtract (c) [the average annual amount of capitalized expenditures for plant and equipment, etc.] Most sales brochures of investment bankers also feature deceptive presentations of this kind. These imply that the business being offered is the commercial counterpart of the Pyramids — forever state-of-the-art, never needing to be replaced, improved or refurbished.

总是需要一些现金用于工厂和设备的资本支出以及营运资金的再投资，仅仅是为了使企业能够继续经营或维持其单位数量和长期竞争地位。一个典型的例子是一家零售店需要安装空调，因为其他商店已经投资了。它不会产生任何额外的业务，但如果没有它，商店可能会因竞争而失去客户。

Some cash is always needed for reinvestment in capital expenditures for plant and equipment and working capital merely to enable a business to stay in business or maintain its unit volume and long-term competitive position. A classic example is a retail store that needs to install air-conditioning because other stores have made the investment. It doesn’t generate any extra business, but without it, the store may lose customers to competition.

巴菲特还表示，我们必须注意某些数字：“当公司或投资专业人士使用诸如“EBITDA”和“预估”等术语时，他们希望你不假思索地接受存在危险缺陷的概念。”

Buffett also says that we have to watch out for certain figures:"When companies or investment professionals use terms such as"EBITDA" and"pro forma," they want you to unthinkingly accept concepts that are dangerously flawed."

他继续：

He continues:

吹嘘 EBITDA（息税折旧摊销前利润）是一种特别有害的做法。这样做意味着折旧并不是真正的费用，因为它是一种“非现金”费用。那是胡说八道。事实上，折旧是一项特别没有吸引力的费用，因为它代表的现金支出是在所收购的资产为企业带来任何利益之前预先支付的。想象一下，如果你愿意的话，在今年年初，一家公司向所有员工支付了未来十年的服务费用（就像他们为固定资产支付现金以使用十年一样）。在接下来的九年里，补偿将是一项“非现金”费用——今年建立的预付补偿资产的减少。

Trumpeting EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) is a particularly pernicious practice.
