Doing so implies that depreciation is not truly an expense, given that it is a"non-cash" charge. That’s nonsense. In truth, depreciation is a particularly unattractive expense because the cash outlay it represents is paid up front, before the asset acquired has delivered any benefits to the business. Imagine, if you will, that at the beginning of this year a company paid all of its employees for the next ten years of their service (in the way they would lay out cash for a fixed asset to be useful for ten years). In the following nine years, compensation would be a"non-cash" expense — a reduction of a prepaid compensation asset established this year. Would anyone care to argue that the recording of the expense in years two through ten would be simply a bookkeeping formality?

但对股东来说重要的不是收益吗？约翰·伯尔·威廉姆斯 (John Burr Williams) 在其 1938 年的著作《投资价值理论》中写道：

But isn’t it earnings that matter for stockholders? John Burr Williams wrote in his 1938 book, The Theory of Investment Value:

如果未派发股息的收益全部以复利的形式成功地为股东利益进行再投资……那么这些收益应该会在以后产生股息；如果没有，那么他们就亏钱了……收入只是达到目的的一种手段，不应将手段误认为是目的。因此我们必须说，一只股票的价值来自于它的股息，而不是它的收益，简而言之，一只股票的价值只是你能从中得到的……因为我们讨论的是永久投资，而不是投机交易，股息是为了未来的岁月，不是暂时的收入。

If earnings not paid out in dividends are all successfully reinvested at compound interest for the benefit of the stockholder.. .then these earnings should produce dividends later; if not, then they are money lost....Earnings are only a means to an end, and the means should not be mistaken for the end. Therefore we must say that a stock derives its value from its dividends, not its earnings, In short, a stock is worth only what you can get out of it... for we are discussing permanent investment, not speculative trading, and dividends for years to come, not income for the moment only.

沃伦巴菲特补充道，“如果有人将他们所有的现金流进行再投资，他们最好有一些非常大的数字在未来出现，因为金融资产有一天必须给你更多的现金才能证明你为它投入现金是合理的现在。”

Warren Buffett adds,"If somebody’s reinvesting all their cash flow, they better have some very big figures coming in down the road because a financial asset has to give you back a lot more cash one day in order to justify your laying out cash for it now."

价值是一个精确的数字吗？

Is value a precise figure?

沃伦巴菲特说：

Warren Buffett says:

内在价值是一个估计而不是一个精确的数字，而且如果利率变动或对未来现金流量的预测被修改，它也是一个必须改变的估计。此外，两个查看同一组事实的人——这甚至适用于查理和我——几乎不可避免地会得出至少略有不同的内在价值数字。

事实上，使用精确的数字是愚蠢的；处理各种可能性是更好的方法。

Intrinsic value is an estimate rather than a precise figure, and it is additionally an estimate that must be changed if interest rates move or forecasts of future cash flows are revised. Two people looking at the same set of facts, moreover - and this would apply even to Charlie and me - will almost inevitably come up with at least slightly different intrinsic value figures.

Using precise numbers is, in fact, foolish; working with a range of possibilities is the better approach.

我们对不同企业的估值有区别吗？

Is there a difference between how we value different businesses?

无论一家公司是生产电信设备、汽车还是糖果，它仍然是同一个问题：我们什么时候能拿到多少现金？现金上的名字无关紧要。沃伦巴菲特说：

No matter whether a company makes Telecom equipment, cars, or candy, it’s still the same question: How much cash do we get and when? The name attached to the cash doesn’t matter. Warren Buffett says:

你要做的是查看一家企业从现在到判决日之间将产生的所有现金，并使用适当的贴现率将其贴现到现在，然后购买比这便宜得多的现金。钱是从银行来的，还是互联网公司来的，还是砖家公司来的……钱花的都是一样的。为什么要为电信业务支付比实体业务更多的费用？钱不知道从哪里来。如果你得到相同数量的钱，但为它付出更多，那么为迷人的企业付出更多是没有意义的。这与您可以以更低的成本从制砖公司获得的钱相同。问题是银行、互联网公司或实体公司的经济特征是什么。这将告诉你他们在未来很长一段时间内产生了多少现金。

What you’re trying to do is to look at all the cash a business will produce between now and judgement day and discount it back to the present using an appropriate discount rate and buy a lot cheaper than that. Whether the money comes from a bank, an Internet company, a brick company...the money all spends the same. Why pay more for a Telecom business than a brick business? Money doesn’t know where it comes from. There’s no sense in paying more for a glamorous business if you’re getting the same amount of money, but paying more for it. It’s the same money that you can get from a brick company at a lower cost. The question is what are the economic characteristics of the bank, the Internet company or the brick company. That’s going to tell you how much cash they generate over long periods in the future.

如果约翰需要在店里投入更多现金怎么办？

What if John needs to invest more cash in the store?

我们必须考虑进出商店的现金数量和时间。许多“成长型”公司的投资者都非常清楚，一些企业似乎需要源源不断的新现金供应。沃伦巴菲特说，“如果在项目或企业的早期需要超过这些资产在以后几年产生的现金贴现值的现金投入，那么增长可能会破坏价值。增长只是一个组成部分——通常是一个组成部分加号，有时是减号——在价值等式中。”

We have to consider the amount and timing of both cash into and from the store. As many investors in"growth" companies are well aware of, some businesses seem to need a never-ending supply of new cash. Warren Buffett says,"Growth can destroy value if it requires cash inputs in the early years of a project or enterprise that exceed the discounted value of the cash that those assets will generate in later years.. .Growth is simply a component — usually a plus, sometimes a minus — in the value equation."

但是，估计未来流入和流出企业的现金流量的数量和时间不是很容易出错吗？

But isn’t it easygoing wrong in estimating the amount and timing of future cash flows in and out of a business?

在伯克希尔，他们以两种方式处理这个问题。沃伦巴菲特说：

At Berkshire, they deal with this problem in two ways. Warren Buffett says:

首先，我们努力坚持我们认为我们理解的业务。这意味着它们必须相对简单和稳定。如果企业很复杂或经常变化，我们就没有足够的智慧来预测未来的现金流量。顺便说一下，这个缺点并不困扰我们。对大多数投资人来说，重要的不是他们知道多少，而是他们对自己不知道的事情的定义有多现实。投资者需要做的事情很少，只要他或她能避免大的错误。

其次，同样重要的是，我们坚持购买价格的安全边际。如果我们计算出一只普通股的价值仅略高于其价格，我们就没有兴趣购买。我们相信，本·格雷厄姆 (Ben Graham) 如此强烈强调的安全边际原则是投资成功的基石。

First, we try to stick to businesses we believe we understand. That means they must be relatively simple and stable in character. If a business is complex or subject to constant change, we’re not smart enough to predict future cash flows. Incidentally, that shortcoming doesn’t bother us. What counts for most people in investing is not how much they know, but rather how realistically they define what they don’t know. An investor needs to do very few things right as long as he or she avoids big mistakes.

Second, and equally important, we insist on a margin of safety in our purchase price. If we calculate the value of a common stock to be only slightly higher than its price, were not interested in buying. We believe this margin-of-safety principle, so strongly emphasized by Ben Graham, to be the cornerstone of investment success.

沃伦巴菲特还说，“我们试图......保持我们的估计保守。” 他继续：

Warren Buffett also says that,"we try...to keep our estimates conservative." He continues:

...采用所有变量并合理保守地计算它们...不要过分关注每个变量在贴现率和增长率等方面的极端保守主义；但尽量在这些数字上尽可能现实，任何错误都在保守的一面。然后当你全部通过时，你就应用了安全边际。

... take all of the variables and calculate ‘em reasonably conservatively... don't focus too much on extreme conservatism on each variable in terms of the discount rate and the growth rate and so on; but try to be as realistic as you can on these numbers, with any errors being on the conservative side. And then when you get all through, you apply the margin of safety.

这与伯克希尔在保险业所做的一样。巴菲特举了一个例子：

It’s the same thing Berkshire does in insurance. Buffett gives an example:

如果我们试图弄清楚我们应该收取什么费用，比如说，加利福尼亚发生 6.0 级地震的可能性，我们知道在上个世纪，我认为加利福尼亚有 26 次左右的地震记录在 6.0 或更高。让我们忘记它们是否发生在偏远地区。假设我们正在编写一项保单，在加利福尼亚发生 6.0 级或更大的地震时获得回报，无论它是否发生在沙漠中并且没有造成任何损失。好吧，我们会看看历史，然后说，“嗯，上个世纪有 26 次。”

我们可能会假设下个世纪的数字会更高一些。那只是我们的本性。但是，我们不会假设 50——因为如果我们这样做，我们就不会写任何业务。但我们可能会假设更高一点。如果我自己给它定价，我可能会说，好吧，我假设会有 30 个——或者 32 个或类似的数量。

然后，当我完成所有工作时，我会想在它上面加上一个包含安全边际的溢价。换句话说，如果我计算出 32 的适当费率是 100 万美元，我可能想要收取超过 100 万美元的费用以建立安全边际。但我想在所有层面上都保持保守——然后我想在最后有很大的安全边际。

If were trying to figure out what we should charge for, say, the chances of a 6.0 earthquake in California, we know that in the last century I think there have been 26 or so earthquakes in California that registered 6.0 or greater. And let’s forget about whether they occur in remote areas. Let’s just say we were writing a policy that paid off on a 6.0 or greater quake in California, regardless of whether it occurred in a desert and did no damage. Well, we would look at the history and we’d say,"Well, there have been 26 in the last century."

And we would probably assume a little higher number in the next century. That’d just be our nature. However, we wouldn’t assume 50 — because if we did, we wouldn’t write any business. But we might assume a little higher. If I were pricing it myself, I’d probably say, well, I’ll assume that there are going to be 30 — or maybe 32 or something like that.

And then when I’m all through, I’ll want to put a premium on it that incorporates a margin of safety. In other words, if I were to figure that the proper rate for 32 was $1 million, I would probably want to charge something more than $ 1 million to build in that margin of safety. But I want to be conservative at all the levels — and then I want to have that significant margin of safety at the end.

约翰可以合理地期望商店值多少钱？

What can John reasonably expect the store to be worth?

约翰应该为商店支付多少钱？可以合理预期未来的自由现金流量是多少？约翰什么时候可以取出多少现金？

How much should John pay for the store? What future free cash flow can rationally be expected? How much cash can John take out and when?

沃伦巴菲特说，“你会试着弄清楚你目前的布局是什么，随着时间的推移你可能会得到什么，你对得到它的信心如何，以及它与其他选择相比如何。” 他继续说道：“对于我们的贴现率，我们基本上根据长期政府利率来考虑……但在利率看起来非常低的时候，我们可能会使用更高一点的利率。” 巴菲特还说，“而且这种贴现率并没有给你带来它需要的高利率。”

Warren Buffett says,"You’d try to figure out what you were laying out currently and what you’re likely to get back over time, how certain you felt about getting it and how it compared to other alternatives." He continues:"For our discount rate, we basically think in terms of the long-term government rate.. .But in times of what seem like very low rates, we might use a little higher rate." Buffett also says,"And that discount rate doesn’t pay you as high a rate as it needs to."

2003 年，沃伦巴菲特说，“我们喜欢拥有普通股——如果它们能以有吸引力的价格购买……然而，除非我们看到至少 10% 的税前回报率的可能性非常高，否则我们将坐在边线。”

In 2003, Warren Buffett said,"We love owning common stocks - if they can be purchased at attractive prices... Unless, however, we see a very high probability of at least 10% pre-tax returns, we will sit on the sidelines."

让我们假设，根据商店的历史并预计未来情况相同，约翰估计他每年可以拿出 300,000 美元的现金。知道他总是可以购买无风险的政府债券，约翰使用 6% 的债券利率作为贴现率。他还知道他可以以 6% 的利率将他从商店中取出的任何现金进行再投资。商店的价值是 500 万美元 ($300,000/0.06)。

Let’s assume based on the store’s history and expecting the same conditions in the future, John estimates that he can take out $300,000 in cash every year. Knowing he can always buy a risk-free government bond, John uses a bond rate of 6% as the discount rate. He also knows he can reinvest whatever cash he can take out from the store at 6%. The value of the store is then $5 million ($300,000/0.06).

无论他能支付多少低于这个数字，都会增加他的预期回报。但既然来自企业的现金不如来自政府债券的现金那么确定，约翰为什么要支付 500 万美元？为什么约翰要花时间和精力投资于能给他带来与无所事事相同回报的事情？由于约翰不确定预期的现金流量是否会像他预期的那样出现，因此他应该以给他带来巨大安全边际的价格购买这家商店。

Whatever he can pay below this figure increases his expected return. But since cash from a business can’t be as certain as cash from a government bond, why should John pay $5 million? Why should John take time and effort investing in something that gives him the same return as doing nothing? And since John can’t know for certain whether expected cash flows will turn out as he expects, he should buy the store at a price that gives him a huge margin of safety.

如果约翰要求的回报率为 10%，则商店的价值为 300 万美元。每个人应该使用他自己要求的回报率。但无论我们使用何种贴现率，我们都应该始终要求对估计值进行大幅折扣，以证明进行投资的合理性。

If John’s required rate of return is 10%, the value of the store is $3 million. Each person should use his own required rate of return. But whatever discount rate we use, we should always require a substantial discount from the estimated value in order to justify making the investment.

我们不应该从事虚假的精确性。沃伦巴菲特说，“我们相信，如果你能准确定位它，那你就是在自欺欺人。因此，我们认为，当我们做出决定时，应该有这样的安全边际——它应该如此有吸引力——以至于你不必须保留三位小数。” 他继续说道：“我们非常不精确......我们有多确定是最重要的部分......你会惊讶于我们是多么不精确。” 查尔斯芒格说，“我们从不坐下来，计算出这些数字并将它们贴现回净现值......这个决定应该是显而易见的。”

We shouldn’t engage in false precision. Warren Buffett says,"We believe that if you can pinpoint it, you’re kidding yourself. Therefore, we think that when we make a decision there ought to be such a margin of safety - it ought to be so attractive - that you don’t have to carry it out three decimal places." He continues:"We are very inexact...How certain we are is the most important part.. .You’d be amazed at how inexact we are." Charles Munger says,"We never sit down, run the numbers out and discount them back to net present value.. .The decision should be obvious."

我们可以使用我们需要的任何贴现率，并且我们始终可以将投资机会与长期国债利率进行比较。但是计算不可预测的值是没有意义的。我们需要一些确定性。问：我对这些数字有多大信心？

We can use whatever discount rate we require and we can always compare investment opportunities with the long-term Treasury rate. But there is no point in calculating the value of the unpredictable. We need some certainty. Ask: How much confidence do I have in the numbers?

我们无法用更高的贴现率来补偿我们无法预测的东西。沃伦巴菲特说：

We can’t compensate what we can’t predict with a higher discount rate. Warren Buffett says:

当我们展望企业的未来时，我们将风险视为一种可行/不可行的阀门。换句话说，如果我们认为我们根本不知道未来会发生什么，那并不意味着它对每个人都有风险。这意味着我们不知道——这对我们来说是有风险的。对于了解业务的其他人来说，这可能没有风险。

然而，那样的话，我们只能放弃了。我们不会试图预测这些事情。我们不会说，“好吧，我们不知道会发生什么。因此，我们会将一些我们甚至不知道的现金流贴现为 9% 而不是 7%。” 这不是我们处理它的方式。

一旦它通过了我们非常确定的门槛测试，我们就会倾向于对所有事物应用相同的折扣因子。我们尽量只购买我们非常确定的企业。

When we look at the future of businesses, we look at riskiness as being sort of a go/no-go valve. In other words, if we think that we simply don’t know what’s going to happen in the future, that doesn’t mean it’s risky for everyone. It means we don’t know — that it’s risky for us. It may not be risky for someone else who understands the business.

However, in that case, we just give up. We don’t try to predict those things. We don’t say,"Well, we don’t know what’s going to happen. Therefore, we’ll discount some cash flows that we don’t even know at 9% instead of 7%." That is not our way to approach it.

Once it passes a threshold test of being something about which we feel quite certain, we tend to apply the same discount factor to everything. And we try to only buy businesses about which we’re quite certain.

约翰是否应该总是拿出他能拿出的所有现金？

Should John always take out whatever cash he can?

这取决于将现金留在企业中的回报是否高于约翰将其取出并投资于其他地方所获得的回报。如果约翰能够以高于 6% 的回报率将现金再投资于企业，他为什么要将其取出？如果他不能以高于 6% 的回报率将现金再投资于业务，他为什么不取出现金呢？

That depends on if the return for keeping the cash in the business is higher than the return John gets if he takes it out and invests somewhere else. Why should John want to take it out if he could reinvest the cash in the business at a higher return than 6%? And why should he not take the cash out if he can’t reinvest it in the business at a higher return than 6%?

由 John 控制的公司与 John 仅拥有部分业务的上市公司之间存在很大差异。他无法控制何时从上市公司提取现金。无论是在私营公司还是上市公司，现金可能会以平庸的回报或投入到行不通的想法中进行再投资。历史表明，多次将现金再投资是在浪费金钱，而支出本来会更好。

Here is a big difference between a company controlled by John and a public company where John only owns a part of the business. He doesn’t control when to take the cash out in a public company. Both in private and public companies, cash may be reinvested at a mediocre return or into ideas that don’t work. History has shown that many times reinvested cash has been wasted money and that a pay-out would have been better.

商店将产生多少现金流主要取决于三个变量：

How much cash flow the store will generate is mainly determined by three variables:

  1. 销量——冰淇淋的售价是多少？
  2. Sales — how many units of ice cream will be sold at what price?
  3. 运营成本——制作冰淇淋和开展业务的成本是多少？
  4. Operating costs - how much does it cost to make the ice cream and conduct the business?
  5. 投资资本——开展业务需要多少资本？这些资本在多大程度上是通过债务而不是股权融资的，成本是多少？
  6. Invested capital - how much capital is needed to conduct the business? To what degree is this capital financed with debt rather than equity and at what cost?

这些变量决定了企业从投资于商店的资本中获得的回报。销售、成本和资本需求在很大程度上取决于需求、来自类似或替代产品的竞争、竞争优势及其可持续性、成本和资本效率以及执行中的运营效率。这是什么意思？让我们把它转化为一个简单的问题：冰淇淋店是否有人们现在和将来需要或想要的东西（需求），而其他人没有（竞争优势）或者现在和将来可以复制或获得（可持续）这些优势能否转化为商业价值？

These variables determine what return the business earns on the capital that is invested in the store. Sales, costs, and capital need are largely determined by demand, competition from similar or substituting products, advantages against competition and their sustainability, cost and capital efficiency, and operational effectiveness in execution. What does this mean? Let’s translate it into a simple question: Does the ice cream store have something people need or want now and in the future (demand), that no one else has (competitive advantage) or can copy or get now and in the future (sustainable) and can these advantages be translated into business value?

例如，为什么顾客选择从这家商店而不是从其他地方购买冰淇淋？是位置、品种、口味、服务还是价格？他们将商店及其产品与什么联系起来？什么对客户重要？他们为什么回来？这些年来他们的动机是否发生了变化，或者他们是否有可能在未来 10 年内发生变化？哪些激励措施会导致顾客转向或离开商店？有哪些威胁？

For example, why do customers choose to buy ice cream from this store rather than from somewhere else? Is it location, assortment, taste, service, price? What do they associate the store and its products with? What is important to customers? Why do they come back? Have their motivations changed over the years or are they likely to change over the next 10 years? What incentives can cause customers to switch to or away from the store? What threats are there?

沃伦巴菲特阐述了他的想法：

Warren Buffett illustrates his thinking:

如果你和我正在研究口香糖业务（我们没有 Wrigley's，所以我在课堂上经常使用它），你会选择一个你希望在未来 10 年内增长的口香糖单位数量的数字 - 20 年后，你会告诉我你对 Wrigley 的定价灵活性有多大以及 Wrigley 的市场份额可能会大幅减少的危险有多大的期望——你会经历所有这些……我们正在评估护城河，以某种方式与护城河相互作用的价格弹性，未来单位需求发生变化的可能性，或者管理层要么对他们开发的现金非常聪明，要么对它非常愚蠢......

我想说的是，随着时间的推移，你几乎可以通过其经理在确定价格上涨是否可以持续时所经历的痛苦来衡量企业的实力......你可以通过观察价格行为。

If you and I were looking at the chewing gum business (and we own no Wrigley’s, so I use it fairly often in class), you’d pick a figure that you would expect unit volumes of chewing gum to grow in the next 10-20 years and you’d give me your expectations about how much pricing flexibility Wrigley’s has and how much danger there is that Wrigley’s market share might be dramatically reduced — you’d go through all of that.. .We’re evaluating the moat, the price elasticity that interacts with the moat in certain ways, the likelihood of unit demand changing in the future or management being either very bright with the cash that they develop or very stupid with it...

I would say you can almost measure the strength of a business over time by the agony its managers go through in determining whether a price increase can be sustained...You can learn a lot about the durability of the economics of a business by observing the price behaviour.

竞争对手能否使商店的产品过时或复制其优势？

Can competitors make the store’s product obsolete or copy its advantages?

如果有人将一家商店放在 John's 旁边，而顾客看不到两家商店的产品和服务有任何区别，那么顾客很可能会购买价格最低的商店中的冰淇淋。

If someone puts a store next to John’s and customers don’t see any difference between two stores products and services, then customers are likely to buy the ice cream in the store with the lowest prices.

约翰还能以最低的价格赚钱吗？是的，如果供不应求，或者如果约翰能够以比竞争对手更低的成本生产和销售他的冰淇淋，当然假设竞争对手不想亏本经营。约翰必须以相对于竞争对手的极端成本和资本效率来经营这家商店。更低的成本和更好的资金使用，让他能够保持最低价，还能赚钱。

Could John still make money having the lowest price? Yes, if demand exceeds supply or if John can produce and sell his ice cream at a lower cost than competition assuming of course competition doesn’t want to run its business at a loss. John must run the store with extreme cost and capital efficiency relative to the competition. Lower costs and better use of capital allows him to keep the lowest price and still make money.

门店管理有多重要？

How important is store management?

多少现金以及约翰何时获得现金也是管理层能力和完整性的函数。管理层可以通过影响企业的回报来影响所有者的回报。它可以影响资本的使用地点，以及在什么条件下将资金进行再投资。

How much cash and when John gets it is also a function of the ability and integrity of management. Management can influence owners’ return by influencing the return of the business. It can influence where capital is being employed, and under what conditions money is to be reinvested.

谈到诚信，沃伦巴菲特说得最好：

When it comes to integrity, Warren Buffett says it best:

我的一位朋友说，在招聘时，他们看重三样东西：智力、活力和品格。如果他们没有最后一个，前两个会杀了你，因为，这是真的，如果你要雇用一个没有品格的人，你最好希望他们是愚蠢和懒惰的，因为，如果他们聪明又精力充沛，他们会给你带来各种麻烦。

One friend of mine said that in hiring they look for three things: intelligence, energy, and character. If they don’t have the last one, the first two will kill you because, it’s true, if you are going to hire somebody that doesn’t have character, you had really better hope they are dumb and lazy, because, if they are smart and energetic, they’ll get you in all kinds of trouble.

一个企业可能看起来在价格上有很大的安全边际，但如果没有一个能干和诚实的管理，这个边际可能最终成为一种幻想。历史上充满了伟大企业因管理不善而毁于一旦的故事。问：公司是否配备了注重价值的称职和诚实的管理层？他们会为了所有者的利益而使用自由现金流吗？

A business may look to have a huge margin of safety in price but without an able and honest management this margin may end up as an illusion. History is filled with stories about great businesses that were destroyed by poor management. Ask: Is the company equipped with a competent and honest management that focuses on value? Will they use free cash flow for the benefit of the owners?

但在某些企业中，即使是出色的管理也无济于事。沃伦巴菲特分享他的经历：

But in some businesses, not even brilliant management helps. Warren Buffett shares his experiences:

根据我自己的经验和对其他企业的大量观察，我得出的结论是，良好的管理记录（以经济回报衡量）更多地取决于你进入什么样的商业船，而不是你划船的效率（尽管智慧和努力）当然，在任何业务中，无论好坏，帮助都很大）。几年前，我写道：“当一个以卓越着称的管理层处理一个以糟糕的基础经济学着称的企业时，保持完好无损的是企业的声誉。” 从那以后，没有什么能改变我对那件事的看法。如果您发现自己身处一艘长期漏水的船上，那么用于更换船只的精力可能比用于修补泄漏的精力更有效率。

My conclusion from my own experiences and from much observation of other businesses is that a good managerial record (measured by economic returns) is far more a function of what business boat you get into than it is of how effectively you row (though intelligence and effort help considerable, of course, in any business, good or bad). Some years ago I wrote:"When a management with a reputation for brilliance tackles a business with a reputation for poor fundamental economics, it is the reputation of the business that remains intact." Nothing has since changed my point of view on that matter. Should you find yourself in a chronically-leaking boat, energy devoted to changing vessels is likely to be more productive than energy devoted to patching leaks.

让我们再举一个“发生了什么”的例子。这次我们描述了一个来自化学的模型，并给出了一个被误用的词的例子——熵。

Let’s take another example of"what happens". This time we describe a model from chemistry and give an example of a misused word — entropy.

凌晨 3 点 54 分，洛杉矶市在 6.5 级地震中醒来。

At 3.54 a.m. the city of Los Angeles woke up to a 6.5 earthquake.

为什么地震会摧毁如此多的建筑物并导致如此多的人死亡？为什么热咖啡不热？这些问题的答案是我们生活中每一个自发的（在化学中是指“自身，没有能量输入”）物理或化学事件的核心。热饮料的温暖是由于快速移动的分子。它们与（相对较冷的）环境中运动较慢的分子发生碰撞，并导致较慢的分子加速。能量从热液体传播到杯子、空气，并通过气流传播到远处。这就是能量的本质。

Why does an earthquake crush so many structures and cause so many deaths? Why doesn’t hot coffee stay hot? The answer to these questions gets to the heart of every spontaneous (means in chemistry"by itself, without energy input") physical or chemical event in our lives. The warmth in a hot beverage is due to fast moving molecules. They collide with slower moving molecules in the (relatively colder) environment and cause the slower ones to speed up. Energy is spread out from the hot liquid to the cup, the air, and by the currents of the air, to distant places. That is the nature of energy.

当我们把球扔到地板上的那一刻，它的能量就变成了动能或由于运动而产生的能量。但术语并不重要。发生的事情是。如果没有受到阻碍，所有的能量都会扩散、变得分散。这就解释了为什么铁会生锈，为什么会有飓风，为什么物体会破碎等等。为什么超速行驶的卡车撞到砖墙上会造成巨大的破坏？它的动能不仅趋于散开；它灾难性地蔓延开来。

The instant we drop a ball on the floor its energy becomes kinetic energy or energy due to movement. But the term isn’t important. What happens is. All energy tends to spread, to become dispersed, if it is not hindered from doing so. That explains why iron rusts, why there are hurricanes, why objects break, etc. Why does a speeding truck running into a brick wall cause enormous destruction? Its kinetic energy not only tends to spread out; it spreads out catastrophically.

地震也是一样。漂浮在其炽热且充满能量的地核上的地壳缓慢运动造成的地球压力突然扩散。随着地球的运动，它的势能瞬间转变为动能。当如此巨大的能量扩散时，它会震动震中周围数英里的一切。由于这种能量分散，不仅建筑物倒塌，而且生命也会缩短。

The same with the earthquake. Stress in the earth caused by the slow movement of the earth’s crust floating on its hot molten energy-filled core suddenly spreads. Its potential energy is instantly changed to kinetic energy as the earth moves. When such gigantic energy spreads, it shakes everything for miles around an epicenter. Because of that energy dispersal, not only buildings collapse, but lives are cut short.

我们的生活基于能量分散。每一秒，我们体内的化学物质（从我们吃的食物和呼吸的氧气在我们体内转化而来）都在保持我们的心脏跳动。我们的肺将氧气泵入我们体内并排出二氧化碳。我们是能量加工机器。我们必须不断散发能量以保持温暖，并不断制造化学物质以使我们的心脏跳动、肌肉工作和肺部发挥功能。如果这些过程被严重中断——就像在地震等任何重大事故中一样——我们就会死去。

Our lives are based on energy dispersal. Each second, chemicals in our body (converted within us from the food we eat and oxygen we breathe) keep our hearts beating. Our lungs pump oxygen into us and carbon dioxide out. We are energy processing machines. We must keep spreading out energy so that we are warm and keep making chemicals so our hearts beat and muscles work and our lungs function. If these processes are seriously interrupted - as they are in any major accident like an earthquake — we die.

当我们听到这是一场 6.5 级地震时，这意味着什么（会发生什么）？

What does it mean (what happens) when we hear it was a magnitude 6.5 earthquake?

里氏震级是由地球物理学家查尔斯·E·里氏开发的一种对数尺度，它通过地震仪记录的地震波测量地震的振幅（大小）。比例尺每增加一个单位，地面运动就会增加 10 倍。7.5 级地震产生的地震动是 6.5 级地震的 10 倍。但由于能量会导致损坏，重要的区别在于能量释放。每增加一个单位，能量释放就会增加约 32 倍。7.5 级地震释放的能量大约是 6.5 级地震的 32 倍。

The Richter scale is a logarithmic scale developed by the geophysicist Charles E Richter and measures the amplitude (size) of an earthquake from the recording of earthquake waves made on a seismograph. Each unit increase in the scale corresponds to a 10-fold increase in ground motion. A magnitude 7.5 earthquake produces 10 times more ground motion than a magnitude 6.5 earthquake. But since energy causes the damage, the important difference lies in the energy release. For every unit increase, energy release increases by a factor of about 32. A 7.5 earthquake releases about 32 times more energy than a 6.5.

1900年以来，美国最大的一次地震发生在1964年的阿拉斯加，震级为9.2级。9.2 级地震和 6.5 级地震在强度或能量上有什么区别？大约 11,220 次。这意味着需要 11,220 次 6.5 级地震才能等于 9.2 级地震释放的能量。这解释了大地震的破坏力。

Since 1900, the biggest earthquake in the U.S. occurred in Alaska in 1964. It had a magnitude of 9.2. What is the difference in strength or energy between a magnitude 9.2 earthquake and a 6.5 earthquake? About 11,220 times. This means that it would take 11,220 earthquakes of magnitude 6.5 to equal the energy released by a 9.2 earthquake. This explains the destructive power of big quakes.

“跟随能量。”

"Follow the energy."

熵衡量在特定温度下过程中散布了多少能量，或者散布的范围有多广。熵是一个被误用的词，常被用来解释各种“无序”。无序无疑是我们生活中许多情况的特征——失败的人际关系、社会问题、凌乱的办公桌、无序的卧室等等。然而，熵与这些事情无关。唯有科学衡量身体能量从集中到分散的流动。

Entropy measures how much energy is spread out in a process, or how widely spread out it becomes — at a specific temperature. Entropy is a misused word, often used to explain all kinds of"disorder." Disorder is certainly characteristic of many of our situations in life - failed relationships, social problems, messy desks, disorderly bedrooms, etc. However, entropy has no relevance to these things. Only to the scientific measure of physical energy flow from being concentrated to being spread out.

房间本身不会变得凌乱。需要一些外部能量。集中在我们肌肉中的能量正在扩散，导致我们的办公桌乱七八糟。报纸本身并没有散布能量。正如化学教授弗兰克·兰伯特所说，“自然界中没有任何‘物体变得杂乱无章的倾向’，就像银行出纳员没有‘没有枪就把钱给强盗的倾向’一样。”

A room doesn’t have a tendency to get messy by itself. Some outside energy is needed. It is the energy concentrated in our muscles that is being spread and causes our desks to be messed up. There is no energy being spread out in the papers themselves. As Chemistry Professor Frank Lambert says,"There isn’t any ‘tendency of objects to become disorganized’ in nature any more than bank tellers have a ‘tendency to give money to robbers’ without a gun."

这种能量倾向于传播，这解释了为什么金属会生锈，为什么东西会破裂和磨损。由于能量总是从集中流向不太集中；物理对象和化学系统会变质、破裂或被毁坏。但这些事情不会立即或自发发生。必须考虑时间和精力的重复。需要一个小的推动力（或活化能）来开始反应。汽油需要火花或火焰才能与氧气发生反应。我们需要一根火柴来生火。例如，氢气和氧气之间只需要一个火花就可以引发反应，从而导致飞艇兴登堡燃烧。它需要风的运动和来自热带海洋的温暖湿气才能形成飓风。铁生锈需要氧气和水分。木头腐烂需要能量。而且这个过程可以延迟。例如，如果我们给铁涂漆以防止生锈，就会发生这种情况。绘画使氧气远离铁，因此不会发生反应。

That energy tends to spread explains why metal rusts, why things break and wear down. Since energy always flows from being concentrated to less concentrated; physical objects and chemical systems deteriorate, break or become destroyed. But these things don’t happen immediately or spontaneously. The repetition of time and energy must be considered. A small push (or activation energy) is needed to start a reaction. Gasoline needs a spark or flame to react with oxygen. We need a match to light a fire. For example, it took a single spark to initiate the reaction between hydrogen gas and oxygen, causing the airship Hindenburg to burn. It takes movements of wind and warm moisture from a tropical ocean to form a hurricane. It takes oxygen and moisture to make iron rust. It takes energy to make wood rot. And this process can be delayed. This happens if we for example paint iron to prevent rusting. Painting keeps oxygen away from the iron so a reaction can’t happen.

这些例子展示了如何通过观察“发生了什么”我们可以更好地理解现实。

These examples show how by observing"what happens" we can better understand reality.

三：简化

Three: Simplification

我们热衷于让事情变得简单。

We have a passion for keeping things simple.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

约翰担心简单会降低他的重要性。

John fears that being simple reduces his importance.

通用电气前 CEO 杰克·韦尔奇说：“你无法相信人们要简单有多么困难，他们有多么害怕简单。他们担心如果他们简单，人们会认为他们头脑简单。现实中当然恰恰相反，心胸清晰的人，才是最单纯的。”

Former General Electric CEO Jack Welch said:"You can’t believe how hard it is for people to be simple, how much they fear being simple. They worry that if they’re simple, people will think they’re simple-minded. In reality, of course, it’s just the reverse. Clear tough-minded people are the most simple."

沃伦巴菲特同意：“我们没有成功，因为我们有一些伟大的、复杂的系统或我们应用的神奇公式或任何类似的东西。我们所拥有的只是简单本身。” 查尔斯·芒格补充道：“如果某件事太难了，我们就会继续做其他事情。还有什么比这更简单的呢？”

Warren Buffett agrees:"We haven’t succeeded because we have some great, complicated systems or magic formulas we apply or anything of the sort. What we have is just simplicity itself." Charles Munger adds:"If something is too hard, we move on to something else. What could be more simple than that?"

简化我们做事的方式

Simplify the way we do things

令人惊讶的是，即使在今天，人们仍然可以使用计算机来完成一些您可以在更短的时间内用铅笔和纸完成的事情。

It’s amazing how people even today use a computer to do something you can do with a pencil and paper in less time.

- 理查德费曼

（来自 No Ordinary Genius）

- Richard Feynman

(from No Ordinary Genius)

让问题更容易解决。把复杂的问题变成简单的问题。消除除必需品以外的所有东西。将问题分解成它的组成部分，但从整体上看问题。画出问题的图片。将关键因素及其关系写在纸上。查尔斯芒格说：“我通常会尝试通过首先处理简单的决定来处理复杂的任务。”

Make problems easier to solve. Turn complicated problems into simpler ones. Eliminate everything except the essentials. Break down a problem into its components but look at the problem holistically. Draw a picture of the problem. Put down on a paper the key factors and their relationship. Charles Munger says: "I generally try to approach complex tasks by first disposing of the easy decisions."

以问题为导向。不面向方法。使用任何有效的方法。为什么？因为结果才是最重要的，而不是我们用来达到结果的方法。

Be problem-oriented. Not method-oriented. Use whatever works. Why? Because the result is what matters, not the method we use to arrive at it.

寻找适合手头问题的足够好的解决方案。不是完美和美丽。

Look for good enough solutions appropriate to the problem at hand. Not perfection and beauty.

做出更少但更好的决定。为什么？因为它迫使我们对每个决定进行更多思考，从而减少我们犯错的机会。沃伦巴菲特给出了另一个令人信服的理由：

Make fewer and better decisions. Why? Because it forces us to think more on each decision and thereby reduces our chance of mistakes. Warren Buffett gives another compelling reason:

查理和我很久以前就决定，在投资的一生中，要做出数百个明智的决定实在是太难了。随着伯克希尔的资本如雨后春笋般涌现，以及可能对我们的业绩产生重大影响的投资范围急剧缩小，这一判断变得越来越有说服力。因此，我们采用了一种策略，该策略只需要很少几次就需要我们聪明——而且不太聪明。

Charlie and I decided long ago that in an investment lifetime, it’s just too hard to make hundreds of smart decisions. That judgement became ever more compelling as Berkshire’s capital mushroomed and the universe of investments that could significantly affect our result shrank dramatically. Therefore, we adopted a strategy that required our being smart - and not too smart at that - only a very few times.

威廉詹姆斯说：“聪明的艺术就是知道要忽视什么的艺术。” 查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 告诉我们消除废话的重要性：“我认为，[拥有不寻常的感觉] 的一部分是能够调出愚蠢，以区别于识别智慧。你有所有类别的东西，你只是避开这样你的大脑就不会被它们塞满。这样，你就能更好地选择一些明智的事情去做。”

William James said:"The art of being wise is the art of knowing what to overlook." Charles Munger tells us about the importance of eliminating nonsense:"Part of that [having uncommon sense], I think, is being able to tune out folly, as distinguished from recognizing wisdom. You’ve got whole categories of things you just bat away so your brain isn’t cluttered with them. That way, you’re better able to pick up a few sensible things to do."

沃伦巴菲特同意：

Warren Buffett agrees:

是的，我们不考虑很多愚蠢的事情。我的意思是，我们很快就摆脱了他们......只是摆脱了废话 - 只是弄清楚如果人们打电话给你说，“我有这个好主意”，你不会花 10 分钟一旦你在第一句话中知道这不是一个伟大的、绝妙的主意……不要客气并完成整个过程。

Yeah, we don’t consider many stupid things. I mean, we get rid of 'em fast.. .Just getting rid of the nonsense — just figuring out that if people call you and say,"I’ve got this great, wonderful idea", you don’t spend 10 minutes once you know in the first sentence that it isn’t a great, wonderful idea.. .Don’t be polite and go through the whole process.

我们经常试图获取太多信息，包括错误信息，或无用的信息来解释或预测。我们还关注细节以及无关紧要或不可知的事物，而忽略了显而易见的事实。处理重要的事情迫使我们区分优先次序。通常只有少数几个行动会产生我们想要实现的大部分目标。只有几个真正重要的决定。

Often we try to get too much information, including misinformation, or information of no use to explain or predict. We also focus on details and what’s irrelevant or unknowable and overlook the obvious truths. Dealing with what’s important forces us to prioritize. There are often just a few actions that produce most of what we are trying to achieve. There are only a few decisions of real importance.

更多的信息并不等于更多的知识或更好的决策。请记住，今天我们不仅可以获得更多信息，还可以获得错误信息。查尔斯芒格说：“你越努力，你就越有信心。但你可能正在努力做一些错误的事情。”

More information doesn’t equal more knowledge or better decisions. And remember that today we not only have access to more information, but also misinformation. Charles Munger says:"The harder you work, the more confidence you get. But you may be working hard on something that is false."

在亚瑟柯南道尔的The Reigate Puzzle中，夏洛克福尔摩斯说：“侦探艺术中最重要的是能够从大量事实中识别出哪些是偶然的，哪些是重要的。”

In Arthur Conan Doyle's The Reigate Puzzle, Sherlock Holmes says:"It is of the highest importance in the art of detection to be able to recognize, out of a number of facts, which are incidental and which vital."

关掉噪音或无关紧要的东西，看看大局。问：我为什么要这样做？真正重要的是什么？什么对我想要实现的目标重要？更多信息会影响我的决定吗？不要随意收集数据。首先从为什么需要特定信息开始。

Turn off the noise or what’s irrelevant and look at the big picture. Ask: Why am I doing this? What really matters? What is important for what I want to achieve? Will more information affect my decision? Don’t collect data randomly. Start with why the particular information is needed in the first place.

当被问及他是否使用过电脑时，查尔斯·芒格说：

When asked if he used a computer, Charles Munger said:

我是我所谓的托马斯亨特摩根学派的追随者。摩根是世界历史上最伟大的生物学家之一，他在一个所谓的“飞行​​室”中用非常有限的资源解决了很多遗传学问题[摩根确定染色体携带遗传单位]——先是在哥伦比亚大学，然后是在加州理工学院。当摩根到达加州理工学院时，他做了一件非常奇特的事。他禁止生物系使用 Friden 计算器——那是那个时代的计算机。加州理工学院的其他人无休止地使用 Friden 计算器来计算各种统计相关性等等。摩根禁止了它。

他们问，“你为什么要这样做？” 他说，“我在生活中如此定位，以至于我就像 1848 年的金矿工人，他可以沿着河岸走，用有组织的常识捡起巨大的金块。只要我能做到这点，我不会在砂矿开采中使用稀缺资源。”

好吧，这就是我的生活方式。我认为，如果您通过有条理的常识获得要点，那么您永远不必进行砂矿开采真是太神奇了……

但是，不需要计算机的有组织的常识仍然可以带来巨大的收益吗？我认为答案是“是的”。过于纠结于使用计算机的细枝末节以至于错过有条理的常识是否有危险？存在巨大的危险。总会有巨大的危险。人们计算太多，想得太少。

I’m a follower of what I call the Thomas Hunt Morgan school. Morgan was one of the great biologists in the history of the world who figured out a lot of genetics [Morgan established that chromosomes carried the units of inheritance] with very slender resources in a so-called"fly room" - first at Columbia and then at Caltech. And when Morgan reached Caltech, he did something that was very peculiar. He banned the Friden calculator - which was the computer of that age - from the biology department. Everybody else at Caltech used the Friden calculator endlessly for all kinds of statistical correlations and much else. Morgan banned it.

And they asked,"Why are you doing this?" He said,"I’m so located in life that I’m like a gold miner in 1848 who could just walk along the banks of the river and pick up enormous nuggets of gold with organized common sense. And as long as I can do this, I’m not going to use scarce resources in placer mining."

Well, that’s the way I go at life. I think if you get the big points with organized common sense, it’s amazing the placer mining you never have to do...

But is there still enormous gain to be made with organized common sense that doesn’t require a computer? I think the answer is"yes." Are there dangers in getting too caught up in the minutiae of using a computer so that you miss the organized common sense? There are huge dangers. There’ll always be huge dangers. People calculate too much and think too little.

避免某些事情

Avoid certain things

有些事情我们要远离。

我们就像那个说他桌上有三个篮子的人：进、出和太强硬。

我们的办公室里有这样的篮子——精神篮子。

很多东西都放在“太难”的篮子里。

There are things that we stay away from.

We're like the man who said he had three baskets on his desk: in, out and too tough.

We have such baskets — mental baskets — in our office.

An awful lot of stuff goes in the"too tough" basket.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

通过知道要避免什么来处理生活中的情况。通过了解要避免哪些领域、情况和人来减少错误，通常比寻找新的成功方法更能节省时间。此外，预防某事往往比解决它更简单。13 世纪的法学家和牧师 Henry de Bracton 说：“一盎司的预防胜过一磅的治疗。”

Deal with the situations in life by knowing what to avoid. Reducing mistakes by learning what areas, situations and people to avoid is often a better use of time than seeking out new ways of succeeding. Also, it is often simpler to prevent something than to solve it. 13th Century jurist and priest Henry de Bracton said: "An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure."

沃伦巴菲特描述了他和查尔斯芒格是如何做到的：

Warren Buffett describes how he and Charles Munger do it:

轻而易举。经过 25 年的收购和监督各种各样的业务，查理和我还没有学会如何解决困难的业务问题。我们学到的是避免它们。就我们的成功而言，这是因为我们专注于确定我们可以跨过的一英尺障碍，而不是因为我们获得了清除七英尺障碍的能力。这一发现可能看起来不公平，但在商业和投资中，简单地坚持简单明了的事情通常比解决困难的事情更有利可图。

我们基本上的态度是，你不能和坏人做一笔好交易。我们不会试图通过合同或各种尽职调查来保护自己——我们只是忘记了它。随着时间的推移，我们可以与我们喜欢、钦佩和信任的人打交道。

而坏演员会试图以这种或那种方式引诱你。但你不会赢。避开他是值得的。我们以这种态度开始。但是，一两次经历让我们更加确信，那就是玩游戏的方式。

Easy does it. After 25 years of buying and supervising a great variety of businesses, Charlie and I have not learned how to solve difficult business problems. What we have learned is to avoid them. To the extent we have been successful, it is because we concentrated on identifying one-foot hurdles that we could step over rather than because we acquired any ability to clear seven-footers. The finding may seem unfair, but in both business and investments it is usually far more profitable to simply stick with the easy and obvious than it is to resolve the difficult.

We basically have the attitude that you can’t make a good deal with a bad person. We don’t try to protect ourselves by contracts or all kinds of due diligence - we just forget about it. We can do fine over time dealing with people we like and admire and trust.

And the bad actor will try to tantalize you in one way or another. But you won’t win. It pays to just avoid him. We started out with that attitude. However, one or two experiences have convinced us even more so that that’s the way to play the game.

查尔斯芒格跟进：

Charles Munger follows up with:

我从沃伦很小的时候就听沃伦说过，好企业和坏企业的区别在于，好的企业会做出一个又一个简单的决定，而坏的企业会给你可怕的选择——极其艰难的决定使：“它可以工作吗？”“它值这个钱吗？”

确定哪个是好企业，哪个是坏企业的一种方法是，一次又一次地看哪一个在管理上犯错误——令人愉快的、无需思考的决定。

I’ve heard Warren say since very early in his life that the difference between a good business and a bad one is that a good business throws up one easy decision after another, whereas a bad one gives you horrible choices — decisions that are extremely hard to make:"Can it work?""Is it worth the money?"

One way to determine which is the good business and which is the bad one is to see which one is throwing management bloopers - pleasant, no-brainer decisions - time after time after time.

专注导致理解和效率

Focus leads to understanding and efficiency

那些获得卓越成就的人通常会在某个单一的追求中度过一生，因为卓越往往不是通过更容易的条件获得的。

Those who attain to any excellence commonly spend life in some single pursuit, for excellence is not often gained upon easier terms.

- 塞缪尔约翰逊

- Samuel Johnson

我们的大脑不可能同时考虑太多事情并期望做好。在任务之间转移我们的注意力会花费时间和理解力，尤其是当我们在更复杂和不熟悉的任务之间切换时。

It is impossible for our brain to think too many things at the same time and expect to do well. Shifting our mental attention between tasks costs time and comprehension, especially when we switch between more complicated and unfamiliar tasks.

当我们一次专注于一件事时，行动和决定会更简单。Publilius Syrus 说：“同时做两件事就是什么都不做。” 如果我们只关注一件事，我们往往会把它做好并积累知识。

Actions and decisions are simpler when we focus on one thing at the time. Publilius Syrus said:"To do two things at once is to do neither." If we only have one thing to focus on, we tend to do it well and build knowledge.

始终牢记目标。问：我想达到或避免什么？专注在商业和管理中重要吗？沃伦巴菲特说：

Always think with a purpose in mind. Ask: What do I want to achieve or avoid? Is focus important in business and for management? Warren Buffett says:

一个......当一家伟大公司的管理层在收购其他马马虎虎或更糟的企业时偏离轨道并忽视其出色的基础业务时，就会出现严重问题......（你会相信几十年前他们在养殖虾吗？可口可乐和在吉列勘探石油？）当我们考虑投资于总体上看起来很出色的企业时，查理和我最担心的是注意力不集中。很多时候，我们看到价值在傲慢或无聊的存在下停滞不前，这导致经理们的注意力分散......

我喜欢专注的管理......当你失去专注时 - 它表明......GEICO 实际上在 1980 年代初期开始在许多事情上胡闹。他们为此付出了代价——实际上是一个非常大的代价。他们为这些事情付出了直接的成本——因为他们几乎都做得很糟糕。然后他们在失去对主要业务的关注方面付出了额外的代价。

A... serious problem occurs when the management of a great company gets sidetracked and neglects its wonderful base business while purchasing other businesses that are so-so or worse... (Would you believe that a few decades back they were growing shrimp at Coke and exploring for oil at Gillette?) Loss of focus is what most worries Charlie and me when we contemplate investing in businesses that in general look outstanding. All too often, we’ve seen value stagnate in the presence of hubris or of boredom that caused the attention of managers to wander...

I love focused management... And when you lose that focus — it shows... GEICO actually started fooling around in a number of things in the early 1980s. And they paid a price for it — actually a very big price. They paid a direct price in terms of the cost for those things - because they almost all worked out badly. And then they paid an additional price in terms of the loss of focus on the main business.

专注于你所知道的，这会有所作为

Focus on what you can know and that makes a difference

在解决问题之前，先问问它是否值得解决或花时间解决。沃伦巴菲特解释了他和查尔斯芒格在生活和商业上取得成功的原因之一：

Before attacking a problem ask if it is worth solving or spending time on. Warren Buffett explains one of the reasons for his and Charles Munger’s success in life and business:

在考虑您将要做出的决定时，您会问自己两个问题。A）它是可知的吗？B) 重要吗？如果它不可知，如你所知，有各种重要但不可知的事情，我们就会忘记那些。如果它不重要，无论它是否可知，都不会产生任何影响。我们不在乎。

There are two questions you ask yourself as you look at the decision you’ll make. A) is it knowable? B) is it important? If it is not knowable, as you know there are all kinds of things that are important but not knowable, we forget about those. And if it’s unimportant, whether it’s knowable or not, it won’t make any difference. We don’t care.

什么是可知的和重要的？什么可以转化为有用的行动？一些重要的事情我们无法知道。就像股市的走向一样。其他我们可以知道但并不重要的事情。

What’s knowable and important? And what can be translated into useful action? Some important things we can’t know. Like where the stock market is going. Other things we can know but they are not important.

问正确的问题

Ask the right questions

问题的表述通常比其解决方案更重要，这可能只是数学或实验技能的问题。

The formulation of a problem is often more essential than its solution, which may be merely a matter of mathematical or experimental skill.

- 艾尔伯特爱因斯坦

- Albert Einstein

有时理解一个问题比解决它更难。提出重要问题可能会有所帮助。从基本问题开始，例如：这是什么意思？最简单的例子是什么？第一个问题是什么？我怎么知道答案是否正确？我可以举一个例子来说明问题是什么吗？

Sometimes it is harder to understand a problem than to solve it. Asking the important questions may help. Start with basic questions like: What does it mean? What is the simplest example? What is the number one question? How can I tell if the answer is right? Can I come up with an example that makes it clear what the problem is?

但仅仅提出正确的问题是不够的。我们必须看对地方，问对人。我们不能过分依赖假设，因为我们不能确定别人的假设与我们的相同，除非我们要求他们解释。

But it is not enough to ask the right questions. We must look at the right place and ask the right person. We can’t rely too much on assumptions since we can’t be sure that someone else’s assumptions are the same as ours, unless we ask them to explain.

耐心

Patience

并不是说我很聪明；只是我在问题上停留的时间更长。

It’s not that I’m so smart; it’s just that I stay with problems longer.

- 艾尔伯特爱因斯坦

- Albert Einstein

最好的思考通常是在没有压力、时间限制、威胁或判断的情况下进行的。思考需要时间，当我们做其他事情时，简单的真理往往会自行显现。

The best thinking is often done when there is no stress, time limit, threats, or judging. Thinking takes time and the simple truths often reveal themselves when we’re doing something else.

如果我们暂时搁置问题并让我们的潜意识发挥作用，我们更有可能解决特定问题或获得新的见解。物理学家 Albert Einstein 和 Leopold Infeld 很好地说明了这一点：

We are more likely to solve a specific problem or gain new insight if we leave the problem alone for awhile and let our subconscious mind work. This is well illustrated by the physicists Albert Einstein and Leopold Infeld:

自柯南道尔令人钦佩的故事以来，几乎每一部侦探小说都会有这样一个时刻：调查员至少在他的问题的某个阶段收集了他需要的所有事实。这些事实常常看起来很奇怪、不连贯，而且完全不相关。然而，这位大侦探意识到目前不需要进一步调查，只有纯粹的思考才能将收集到的事实联系起来。所以他拉小提琴，或者躺在扶手椅上享受着烟斗，突然间，天哪，他拥有了！

In nearly every detective novel since the admirable stories of Conan Doyle there comes a time where the investigator has collected all the facts he needs for at least some phase of his problem. These facts often seem quite strange, incoherent, and wholly unrelated. The great detective, however, realizes that no further investigation is needed at the moment, and that only pure thinking will lead to a correlation of the facts collected. So he plays his violin, or lounges in his armchair enjoying a pipe, when suddenly, by Jove, he has it!

罗杰·洛温斯坦在《巴菲特：美国资本家的成长》中这样描述沃伦·巴菲特：“巴菲特的天才很大程度上是性格上的天才——耐心、纪律和理性……他的才华源于他无与伦比的思想独立性和专注于工作的能力并将世界拒之门外。”

Roger Lowenstein describes Warren Buffett in Buffett: The Making of an American Capitalist:"Buffett’s genius was largely a genius of character - of patience, discipline and rationality...His talent sprang from his unrivaled independence of mind and ability to focus on his work and shut out the world."

耐心等待机会。抵制总是做某事的诱惑。如果我们匆忙，就更容易做出错误判断。这是投资的关键。沃伦巴菲特说，“在分配资本时，活动与成就无关。事实上，在投资和收购领域，狂热的行为往往适得其反。” 他继续说道：“如果你觉得你必须每天投资，你就会犯很多错误。这不是那种生意。你必须等待成功的机会。”

Have patience in waiting for opportunities. Resist the temptation to always do something. If we are in a hurry, it’s easier to make misjudgements. This is key in investing. Warren Buffett says,"In allocating capital, activity does not correlate with achievement. Indeed, in the fields of investments and acquisitions, frenetic behaviour is often counterproductive." He continues:"If you feel like you have to invest every day, you’re going to make a lot of mistakes. It isn’t that kind of a business. You have to wait for the fat pitch."

查尔斯·芒格补充道：

Charles Munger adds:

一些重大的机会，如此清晰可辨，通常会降临到一个不断寻找和等待的人身上，带着好奇的心，热爱诊断涉及多个变量。然后，所需要的只是在赔率非常有利时愿意下重注，利用过去因审慎和耐心而获得的可用资源。

A few major opportunities, clearly recognizable as such, will usually come to one who continuously searches and waits, with a curious mind, loving diagnosis involving multiple variables. And then all that is required is a willingness to bet heavily when the odds are extremely favourable, using resources available as a result of prudence and patience in the past.

四：规则和过滤器

Four: Rules and Filters

规矩是愚者的服从，智者的指引。

Rules are for the obedience of fools and the guidance of wise men.

- David Ogilvy

（广告主管，1911-1999）

- David Ogilvy

(Advertising executive, 1911-1999)

什么可以帮助我们避免问题并在做决定时起到指导作用？基于我们对现实的了解和我们的个人情况，我们应该建立一些“做什么”和“避免什么”的规则。

What can help us avoid problems and act as guidelines when making decisions? Based on our knowledge of reality and our personal situation we should establish some"what to do" and"what to avoid" rules.

Charles Munger 举了一个规则的例子：

Charles Munger gives an example of a rule:

任何时候有人向您提供高额佣金和 200 页的招股说明书，请不要购买。有时候，如果你采用“芒格法则”，你就会错了。然而，在一生中，你会遥遥领先——你会错过很多不愉快的经历，否则这些经历可能会减少你对同胞的爱。

Any time anybody offers you anything with a big commission and a 200-page prospectus, don’t buy it. Occasionally, you’ll be wrong if you adopt"Munger’s Rule". However, over a lifetime, you’ll be a long way ahead - and you will miss a lot of unhappy experiences that might otherwise reduce your love for your fellow man.

另一条规则来自本杰明·富兰克林：“勤奋地投入到我手头的任何事业中，不要通过任何突然致富的愚蠢计划将我的注意力从我的事业上转移；因为勤奋和耐心是致富的最可靠途径。”

Another rule comes from Benjamin Franklin:"To apply myself industriously to whatever business I take at hand, and not divert my mind from my business by any foolish project of growing suddenly rich; for industry and patience are the surest means of plenty."

其他规则可能是，“远离任何我不理解、无法量化或不起作用的东西。只与我信任的人打交道。”

Other rules could be, "Walk away from, anything I don’t understand or can’t quantify or doesn’t work. Only deal with people I trust."

沃伦巴菲特为我们提供了如何在保险业取胜的指南，这也适用于其他领域：

Warren Buffett provides us with guidelines on how to win in insurance, which applies to other areas as well:

在这项业务中重要的是承保纪律。获胜者是那些始终坚持三个关键原则的人：

  1. 他们只接受那些他们能够正确评估的风险（保持在他们的能力范围内），并且在他们评估了包括远程损失场景在内的所有相关因素之后，他们期望获得利润。这些保险公司忽视了市场份额的考虑，并且对失去提供愚蠢价格或政策条件的竞争对手的业务持乐观态度。

  2. 他们以一种方式限制他们接受的业务，以保证他们不会因单一事件或威胁其偿付能力的相关事件而遭受损失的汇总。他们不断地寻找看似无关的风险之间可能存在的关联。

  3. 他们避免涉及道德风险的业务：无论利率如何，试图与坏人签订良好合同都是行不通的。虽然大多数保单持有人和客户都是正直且有道德的，但除了少数例外，做生意通常很昂贵，有时甚至非常昂贵。

    我知道 Ajit [Ajit Jain] 撰写的几乎所有保单的细节……而且我从未见过他违反我们的三项承保规则中的任何一项。当然，他非凡的纪律并不能消除损失；但是，它确实可以防止愚蠢的损失。这就是关键：就像投资一样，保险公司主要通过避免愚蠢的决定而不是做出明智的决定来产生出色的长期结果。

What counts in this business is underwriting discipline. The winners are those that unfailingly stick to three key principles:

  1. They accept only those risks that they are able to properly evaluate (staying within their circle of competence) and that, after they have evaluated all relevant factors including remote loss scenarios, carry the expectancy of profit. These insurers ignore market-share considerations and are sanguine about losing business to competitors that are offering foolish prices or policy conditions.

  2. They limit the business they accept in a manner that guarantees they will suffer no aggregation of losses from a single event or from related events that will threaten their solvency. They ceaselessly search for possible correlation among seemingly-unrelated risks.

  3. They avoid business involving moral risk: No matter what the rate, trying to write good contracts with bad people doesn’t work. While most policyholders and clients are honorable and ethical, doing business with the few exceptions is usually expensive, sometimes extraordinarily so.

    I have known the details of almost every policy that Ajit [Ajit Jain] has written.. .and never on even a single occasion have I seen him break any of our three underwriting rules. His extraordinary discipline, of course, does not eliminate losses; it does, however, prevent foolish losses. And that’s the key: Just as in the case of investing, insurers produce outstanding long term results primarily by avoiding dumb decisions, rather than by making brilliant ones.

过滤器

Filters

我们真的可以在 10 秒左右的时间内对 90% 以上的事情说不，仅仅是因为我们有这些过滤器。

We really can say no in 10 seconds or so to 90% + of all the things that come along simply because we have these filters.

- 沃伦·巴菲特

- Warren Buffett

过滤器帮助我们确定优先级并找出有意义的东西。

Filters help us prioritize and figure out what makes sense.

当我们知道我们想要什么时，我们需要标准来评估备选方案。问：哪些是最关键（和已知）的因素会导致我想要实现或避免什么？标准必须以证据为基础并具有合理的预测性，即我们必须依靠它们比偶然性做得更好。尝试使用尽可能少的标准来做出判断。然后按照它们的重要性对它们进行排序，并将它们用作过滤器。以最小化错误警报和错误（在投资中，选择错误的投资或错过良好的投资）的可能性的方式设置决策阈值。考虑错误的后果。例如，在医学中，阈值取决于多种因素，例如疾病的普遍程度、严重程度、纠正措施的可用性以及误报的情感和经济成本。

When we know what we want, we need criteria to evaluate alternatives. Ask: What are the most critical (and knowable) factors that will cause what I want to achieve or avoid? Criteria must be based on evidence and be reasonably predictive, i.e., we must do better than chance by relying on them. Try to use as few criteria as necessary to make your judgement. Then rank them in order of their importance and use them as filters. Set decision thresholds in a way that minimizes the likelihood of false alarms and misses (in investing, choosing a bad investment or missing a good investment). Consider the consequences of being wrong. For example, in medicine, a threshold depends on factors such as the prevalence of a condition, its seriousness, the availability of corrective measures, and the emotional and financial costs of false alarms.

在预测假释成功方面，过去的犯罪记录和监狱记录比专家犯罪学家更可靠。

Past criminal and prison records are more reliable than expert criminologists in predicting success on parole.

研究表明，在某些领域，当基于相同的证据时，涉及少量相关变量的更机械的预测过程比训练有素且经验丰富的专家的预测更可靠。这已在医疗状况诊断、学业成绩预测、确定赌博几率以及贷款和信用风险方面得到体现。为什么效果更好？因为我们人类并不总是一致的。正如我们所见，最近的经历、建议或信息的呈现方式可能会影响我们。再加上我们在记忆、注意力和处理方面的自然局限性。

Studies show that in some fields, when based on the same evidence, a more mechanical prediction process involving a small number of relevant variables is more reliable than the predictions of trained and experienced experts. This has been shown in diagnoses of medical conditions, predictions of academic performance, in determining gambling odds, and loan and credit risk. Why does it work better? Because we humans are not always consistent. As we have seen, recent experiences, suggestions, or how information is presented may influence us. Add to this our natural limitations in memory, attention, and processing.

更多信息并不意味着我们会过得更好。有时额外的信息是无用且令人困惑的。

More information doesn’t mean we are better off. Sometimes extra information is useless and confusing.

一名男子因心脏病发作被紧急送往医院。医生需要决定是否应将受害人作为低风险或高风险患者进行治疗。

A man is rushed to a hospital in the throes of a heart attack. The doctor needs to decide whether the victim should be treated as a low risk or high-risk patient.

标准不必很多或很复杂。加州大学伯克利分校的已故统计学教授 Leo Breiman 及其同事开发了一种方法，最多仅使用 3 个变量对高危心脏病发作患者进行分类。血压、年龄和窦性心动过速（心跳加快）。

Criteria don’t have to be numerous or complicated. Late Statistics Professor Leo Breiman and colleagues at University of California, Berkeley, developed a method to classify high-risk heart attack patients using only a maximum of 3 variables. Blood pressure, age and sinus tachycardia (rapid heartbeat).

如果患者在最初 24 小时内的最低收缩压低于 91，他将立即被归类为高风险。如果不是，第二个变量是年龄。如果患者超过 62.5 岁，则需要多一个变量——窦性心动过速——来将他归类为高风险或低风险。如果患者表现出窦性心动过速，则他被归类为高风险。因此，医生需要回答三个是-否问题才能做出决定。该方法在对高危心脏病患者进行分类时比复杂的统计分类方法更准确。

If a patient’s minimum systolic blood pressure over the initial 24-hour period is less than 91, he is immediately classified as high risk. If not, the second variable is age. If the patient is over 62.5 years old, then one more variable - sinus tachycardia — is needed to classify him as high or low risk. If the patient displays sinus tachycardia he is classified as high risk. Thus, the doctor needs to answer three yes-no questions to reach a decision. The method is more accurate in classifying high risk heart attack patients than complex statistical classification methods.

在 2001 年的一次新闻发布会上，当沃伦巴菲特被问及他如何评估新的商业创意时，他说他使用了 4 个标准作为过滤器。

At a press conference in 2001, when Warren Buffett was asked how he evaluated new business ideas, he said he used 4 criteria as filters.

  • 我能看懂吗？如果它通过了这个过滤器，
  • Can I understand it? If it passes this filter,
  • 它看起来是否具有某种可持续的竞争优势？如果它通过了这个过滤器，
  • Does it look like it has some kind of sustainable competitive advantage? If it passes this filter,
  • 管理层是否由能干诚实的人组成？如果它通过了这个过滤器，
  • Is the management composed of able and honest people? If it passes this filter,
  • 价格合适吗？如果它通过了这个过滤器，那么我们写一张支票
  • Is the price right? If it passes this filter, then we write a check

沃伦巴菲特所说的“理解”是什么意思？可预测性：“我们对理解的定义是认为我们有合理的可能性能够评估 10 年后的业务状况。” 他继续：

What does Warren Buffett mean by"understanding?" Predictability:"Our definition of understanding is thinking that we have a reasonable probability of being able to assess where the business will be in 10 years." He continues:

我们知道如何赚钱的唯一方法是尝试和评估企业。如果我们不能评估一家碳钢公司，我们就不会购买。这并不意味着它不好买。这并不意味着它的售价不低于其价值的一小部分。这只是意味着我们不知道如何评估它。如果我们不能评估在巴西建设化工厂或其他东西的意义，我们就不会这样做......

我们了解产品。我们了解它对人们的作用。我们只是不知道 10 年后[它的经济状况会如何]……你可以理解钢铁。你可以理解家庭建设。但如果你观察一家房屋建筑商，并试图思考它的经济效益在 5 年或 10 年内会达到什么水平，那就是另一个问题了。这不是了解他们生产的产品的问题，也不是他们用来分发产品的方式的问题——所有这些——而是 10 年后经济形势的可预测性。

The only way we know how to make money is to try and evaluate businesses. And if we can’t evaluate a carbon steel company, we don’t buy it. It doesn’t mean it isn’t a good buy. It doesn’t mean it isn’t selling for a fraction of what its worth. It just means that we don’t know how to evaluate it. If we can’t evaluate the sense of putting in a chemical plant or something in Brazil, we don’t do it...

We understand the product. We understand what it does for people. We just don’t know [what its economics will be] 10 years from now...You can understand steel. You can understand home building. But if you look at a home builder and try to think where the economics of it is going to be in five or 10 years, that’s another question. It’s not a question of understanding the product they turn out, the means they use to distribute it - all of that sort of thing - it’s the predictability of the economics of the situation 10 years out.

让我们举一个结合规则和过滤器的例子。现实往往表明，问题的根源之一是与错误的人打交道。因此，规则可以是：“避免低素质的人。” 因此，过滤器可能是：“良好的业绩记录和性格特征。” 然后我们寻找线索并提出旨在回答以下问题的问题：“高等级还是低等级个体？”

Let’s take an example where we combine rules and filters. Reality often shows that one cause of problems is getting involved with wrong people. A rule could therefore be:"Avoid low quality people." As a consequence a filter may be:"Good track record and character traits." Then we look for clues and ask questions designed to answer the question:"High or low grade individual?"

消除

Elimination

消除是努力的重要保护者。例如，将举证责任放在与基本科学思想相矛盾的陈述上。消除可能导致巨大悲伤的情况，不重要或不可知的事情，不可能发生或无法实现的事情，无法有效预测或解释的事情，无法测试的事情，已经被推翻的事情，简单的决定，错误的假设，我们无能为力的事情或我们没有任何能力的问题。

Elimination is a great conservator of effort. For example, place the burden of proof on statements that contradict basic scientific ideas. Eliminate situations that may cause great sorrow, what is not important or knowable, what can’t happen or be achieved, what can’t usefully be predicted or explained, what can’t be tested, what is already disproved, the easy decisions, the wrong assumptions, what we can’t do something about or problems where we don’t have any competence.

科学通过消除起作用。为了避免淹没在低信息观察或实验中，科学家们会提前考虑最重要和最具决定性的实验是什么：我们试图实现或证明什么，我们如何才能达到这些目的？什么事不能发生？这样，他们缩小了可能性。这类似于沃伦巴菲特在第一部分中告诉我们的 - 消除可能性并着眼于少数有成功机会的人。寻找某些可以缩小可能性的东西。

Science works by elimination. To avoid drowning in low-information observations or experiments, scientists think in advance about what the most important and conclusive experiments would be: What are we trying to achieve or prove, and how can we reach these ends? What can’t happen? This way, they narrow down the possibilities. It is similar to what Warren Buffett told us in Part One - eliminate possibilities and get down to the few that have any chance of success. Look for certain things that narrow down the possibilities.

清单程序

check-lists procedures

将审查航空公司驾驶舱检查单，以确保每份清单都能在起飞前立即提醒机组，所有对安全飞行至关重要的项目都已完成。

Air carrier cockpit check-lists to be reviewed in an effort to ensure that each list provides a means of reminding the crew, immediately prior to take-off, that all items critical for safe flight have been accomplished.

- 国家运输安全委员会，1969 年

- National Transportation Safety Board, 1969

1987年，西北航空公司255航班起飞后不久坠毁。机上 155 人全部遇难，预计有 1 人遇难。一份联邦报告得出的结论是，事故的可能原因是机组人员未能使用滑行检查单来确保襟翼和缝翼在起飞时展开。造成事故的原因是飞机起飞警告系统没有电源，因此无法警告机组人员飞机没有正确配置起飞。

In 1987, Northwest Airlines flight 255 crashed shortly after take-off. All 155 persons aboard expect one were killed. A federal report concluded that the probable cause of the accident was the flight crew’s failure to use the taxi check-lists to ensure that the flaps and slats were extended for take-off. Contributing to the accident was the absence of electrical power to the air-planes take-off warning system, which consequently could not warn the flight crew that the air-plane was not configured properly for take-off.

使用清单程序。它们与其他工具一起帮助我们减少伤害的机会。专注于关键项目。如果我们不检查它们，我们可能会受到伤害。飞行员称这些为“杀手级物品”。

Use check-lists procedures. Together with other tools they help us reduce the chance of harm. Concentrate on the critical items. If we don’t check for them we may get harmed. Pilots call these the"killer items."

Charles Munger 建议以检查列表的方式使用模型：

Charles Munger suggests using models in a check-lists fashion:

一般来说，我认为你需要心智模型——我称之为检查列表程序——你需要一个有价值的模型列表并直接运行它们：“这是这里吗？那是这里吗？” 等等……现在，如果有两三个非常重要的项目不在您的检查清单上——好吧，如果您是一名飞机驾驶员，您可能会坠毁。同样，如果你试图在没有使用足够的清单的情况下分析一家公司，你可能会做出非常糟糕的投资。

Generally speaking, I think you need mental models — and what I call check-lists procedures - where you take a worthwhile list of models and run right down them:"Is this here? Is that here?" and so on and so on...Now if there are two or three items that are very important that aren’t on your check-lists — well, if you’re an air-plane pilot, you can crash. Likewise, if you’re trying to analyze a company without using an adequate check-lists, you may make a very bad investment.

设计清单时需要考虑的一些问题是：

Some issues to think about when designing check-lists are:

  • 不同的问题需要不同的检查表。
  • Different issues need different check-lists.
  • 检查清单必须包括“安全”和避免“事故”所必需的每个关键项目，因此我们不需要依靠记忆来检查项目。
  • A check-lists must include each critical item necessary for"safety" and avoiding"accidents" so we don’t need to rely on memory for items to be checked.
  • 易于使用且易于使用。
  • Readily usable and easy to use.
  • 同意现实。
  • Agree with reality.

造成事故的原因是机长过度依赖自动飞行系统。

Contributing to the accident was the captains over-reliance on automated flight systems.

避免过度依赖清单。它们有时会给我们一种虚假的安全感。只要可以预见可能发生的事情，核对清单就很有效。但有时会发生意想不到的事情。未提及的项目可能是问题的核心原因。

Avoid excessive reliance on check-lists. They may sometimes give us a false sense of security. check-lists work well as long as what may happen can be foreseen. But the unexpected sometimes happens. An unmentioned item may be the core cause of a problem.

根据预先制定的规则、过滤器和清单做某事通常比纯粹出于情感做某事更有意义。但是我们不能有太多的规则、过滤器或项目而不加思索。我们必须始终了解我们正在努力实现的目标。

Doing something according to pre-established rules, filters and check-lists often makes more sense than doing something out of pure emotion. But we can’t have too many rules, filters or items without thinking. We must always understand what we’re trying to accomplish.

五：目标

Five: Goals

我们的计划因没有目标而流产。当一个人不知道他要去的是什么港口时，没有风就是对的风。 

Our plans miscarry because they have no aim. When a man does not know what harbor he is heading for, no wind is the right wind. 

——卢修斯·安奈乌斯·塞内卡

- Lucius Annaeus Seneca

“为什么我们的员工汤姆表现不好？”

"Why doesn’t our employee, Tom, perform well?"

当人们的表现不如我们预期时，我们常常会感到惊讶。

Often we are surprised when people don’t perform as we expect.

汤姆如何看待他被衡量和奖励？他认为对他的期望是什么？我们是否给他混合信息？他需要什么技能、知识和信息？他有那些吗？我们对他的表现有何回应？

How does Tom perceive he is being measured and rewarded? What does he perceive is expected of him? Do we give him mixed messages? What skills, knowledge and information does he need? Does he have those? What response do we give him about his performance?

汤姆：“我有正确的知识并理解目标。我也知道如何实现目标以及为什么我的方法最有意义。我有权做出相关决定并可以持续衡量结果。如果我实现了目标，我会得到奖励，奖励的多少由我决定。如果我没有完成目标，我就会失去工作。既然我有责任，我就应该承担后果。”

Tom:"I have the right knowledge and understand the goal. I also know how to achieve the goal and why my way makes the most sense. I have the authority to make the relevant decisions and can measure the outcome continuously. If I achieve the goal, I will be rewarded. I decide the amount of reward I will get. If I don’t accomplish the goal, I lose my job. Since I have the responsibility, it is only right that I face the consequences."

有导致我们想要完成的目标。我们知道我们想要实现什么以及为什么吗？正如亚里士多德所说：“如果我们有一个目标，我们是不是更有可能击中目标？” 如果我们不知道我们想要实现什么，我们如何做出正确的决定？即使我们不知道自己想要什么，我们也常常知道自己不想要什么，这意味着我们的目标可以是避免某些事情。

Have goals that cause what we want to accomplish. Do we know what we want to achieve and why? As Aristotle said:"Are we not more likely to hit the mark if we have a target?" How can we make the right decision if we don’t know what we want to achieve? Even if we don’t know what we want, we often know what we don’t want, meaning that our goal can be to avoid certain things.

有意义的目标需要有理由支持，作为测试我们设定正确目标的一种方式。目标应该是：

Meaningful goals need to be backed by reasons as a way of testing that we set the right goal. Goals should be:

  • 明确规定。不要说：“我想要更好的生活。” 要具体。例如：“我想要一辆新沃尔沃。”
  • Clearly defined. Don’t say:"I want to have a better life." Be concrete. For example:"I want a new Volvo."
  • 专注于结果。
  • Focused on results.
  • 现实和合乎逻辑的是什么可以实现，什么不能实现？低目标可能会导致低绩效，不切实际的目标可能会导致人们作弊。Lucius Annaeus Seneca 说我们应该：“永远不要为无用的目标或不可能实现的目标而工作。”
  • Realistic and logical what can and can’t be achieved? Low goals may produce low performance and unrealistic goals may cause people to cheat. Lucius Annaeus Seneca said we should:"Never work either for useless goals, or impossible ones."
  • 可衡量的。
  • Measurable.
  • 根据我们的个性化需求量身定制。
  • Tailored to our individual needs.
  • 可调整的。问：考虑到我们目前的目标，最好的行动方案是什么？
  • Subject to change. Ask: Given our current objective, what is the best course of action to take?

目标还需要目标日期和控制站来衡量目标实现的程度。

Goals also need target dates and control stations measuring the degree to which the goal is being achieved.

我们知道是什么导致我们的目标得以实现吗？如果我们不了解是什么让它发生，我们就无法实现我们想要的。我们确定我们的目标是我们最终想要实现的目标吗？

Do we know what causes our goal to be achieved? We can’t achieve what we want if we don’t understand what makes it happen. And are we sure our goal is the right one for what we finally want to achieve?

沃伦巴菲特和查尔斯芒格在 2001 年伯克希尔哈撒韦公司年会上详细阐述了能源危机的问题：

Warren Buffett and Charles Munger elaborated on the issue of the energy crisis at the 2001 Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting:

在电力系统中，我们需要容量过剩。我们如何得到它？通过激励人们拥有额外的能力。电力企业不能因为没有产能过剩而受到惩罚，也不能因为产能不足而受到奖励。

我们需要三件事才能避免这种情况再次发生。一是我们需要合理的运营效率。其次，由于它在许多情况下确实倾向于具有垄断特征，我们希望能够产生公平回报的东西，但不是很高的资本回报——足以吸引新资本。第三，我们需要一定的安全边际或比需要多一点的容量。我们需要整个等式。

In power systems we need surplus of capacity. And how do we get that? By giving people an incentive for having extra capacity. A power business can’t be punished for not having excess capacity and can’t be rewarded for having less then what is needed.

We need three things for this not to happen again. One is that we need reasonable efficiency in operations. Secondly, since it does tend to have in many situations monopoly characteristics, we want something that produced a fair return, but not a great return, on capital — enough to attract new capital. And third, we need a margin of safety or a little more capacity than needed. And we need the whole equation.

总是问：我想要什么最终结果？是什么原因造成的？哪些因素对结果有重大影响？哪个单一因素影响最大？我是否拥有实现目标所需的变量？实现我的目标的最佳方法是什么？我是否考虑过我的行为会产生哪些影响最终结果的其他影响？

Always ask: What end result do I want? What causes that? What factors have a major impact on the outcome? What single factor has the most impact? Do I have the variable(s) needed for the goal to be achieved? What is the best way to achieve my goal? Have I considered what other effects my actions will have that will influence the final outcome?

当我们解决问题并知道我们想要实现什么时，我们需要优先考虑或关注正确的问题。我们应该先做什么？问：问题有多严重？它们可以修复吗？最重要的问题是什么？他们背后的假设是否正确？我们是否考虑了问题的相互关联性？长期后果？

When we solve problems and know what we want to achieve, we need to prioritize or focus on the right problems. What should we do first? Ask: How serious are the problems? Are they fixable? What is the most important problem? Are the assumptions behind them correct? Did we consider the interconnectedness of the problems? The long-term consequences?

由于当我们优化某些因素或结合许多因素时会产生重大影响（无论好坏），因此我们应该使用任何必要的因素来实现我们的目标。

Since big effects — bad or good — happen when we optimize some factors or combine many factors, we should use whatever factors necessary to achieve our goal.

六：备选方案

Six: Alternatives

如果你有两个真正渴望拥有你的追求者，而且一个比另一个好得多，你就不必花太多时间在另一个身上。这就是我们过滤掉购买机会的方式。

If you’ve got two suitors who are really eager to have you and one is way the hell better than the other, you do not have to spend much time with the other. And that’s the way we filter out buying opportunities.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

“把钱拨给我们！”

"Allocate the money to us!"

我们应该如何最好地分配我们的稀缺资源？TransCorp 有十个不同的项目可供选择。他们应该全部投资吗？每个项目是否应该获得相同数量的资金？人、钱、时间、人才等资源都是有限的。它们也有其他用途。有些选项也比其他选项更好。

How should we best allocate our scarce resources? TransCorp has ten different projects to choose from. Should they invest in all? Should each project get the same amount of funding? People, money, time, talent and other resources are limited. They also have alternative uses. Some options are also better than others.

机会成本

Opportunity cost

“我会权衡我对资金和时间的使用与其他可用的替代用途。”

"I weigh my use of capital and time against other available alternate uses."

一个可以用来衡量相互选择的过滤器是我们自己的个人机会成本。我们的时间和金钱是有限的。如果我们决定做一件事，我们就决定不做其他可用的事情。我们选择花在一件事上的每一分钟，都会有一分钟无法花在其他事情上。我们投资的每一美元都是其他可用投资无法获得的美元。如果我们决定今天花钱而不是为未来投资，我们就放弃了在未来花更多钱的机会。如果我今天决定打高尔夫球，我将错过按时完成本书的机会。如果我写作，我就会错过与孩子们共度时光的机会。因为孩子长大了，这个机会是有时间限制的。

One filter that can be used to measure choices against each other is our own personal opportunity cost. Our time and money are limited. If we make a decision to do one thing we are deciding not to do some other available thing. Every minute we choose to spend on one thing is a minute unavailable to spend on other things. Every dollar we invest is a dollar unavailable for other available investments. If we decide to spend money today instead of investing for the future we give up the opportunity to spend more in the future. If I decide to play golf today I miss the opportunity to finish this book on time. If I write, I miss the opportunity to spend time with my children. Since children grow up, this opportunity has a time limit.

选择是有代价的。即使理解也有机会成本。如果我们很好地理解一件事，我们可能会更好地理解其他事情。为特定目的使用有限资源（如时间、精力和金钱）的成本可以衡量为不以最佳可用替代用途（假设它实现相同目的）使用它而损失的价值或机会。

Choices have costs. Even understanding has an opportunity cost. If we understand one thing well we may understand other things better. The cost of using a limited resource like time, effort and money for a specific purpose, can be measured as the value or opportunity lost by not using it in its best available alternative use (assuming it achieves the same purpose).

你选择工作还是上大学！

Do you choose to work or go to college!

选择一种替代方案以支持另一种替代方案的实际成本是多少？举一个沃伦巴菲特的例子：没有接受过大学教育的真正成本是多少？受过教育与未受过教育在一生中的收入有什么区别？如果我们忽略接受教育的非经济收益，那么这种贴现到毕业日的收入差异就是教育的价值或不接受教育的实际成本。

What is the real cost of choosing one alternative in favour of another? To use a somewhat changed example from Warren Buffett: What is the real cost of not having a college education? What is the difference in income over a lifetime between having an education or not? If we ignore the non-economic benefits of having an education, this difference in income discounted to graduation day is the value of the education or the real cost of not having an education.

我们的时间值多少钱？我们是花十个小时修理房子还是请木匠？自己进行维修的实际成本是我们做其他事情本可以赚到的钱。

What is our time worth? Do we spend ten hours doing repairs on our house or do we use a carpenter? The real cost of doing the repairs ourselves is the money that we would have earned doing something else.

“免费医疗”是真的免费吗？

Does"free health care" mean it is really free?

不，如果它不是免费的，用于提供免费医疗保健的资源本可以用于其他用途。通常我们只看到政府支出的好处。我们没有看到什么被阻止发生或资源被从其他用途转移。

No, had it not been free, the resources used for providing free health care could have been used for something else. Often we only see the benefits of government spending. We don’t see what is prevented from happening or that resources are diverted from alternative uses.

“在蒙大拿再雇用 3 名销售代表。”

"Employ 3 more sales representatives in Montana."

TransCorp 是否应该花时间、金钱和人才在蒙大拿州建立市场影响力？这样做的真正成本是用于最佳替代用途的时间、金钱和人才的价值。也许在他们已经拥有市场份额的州增加他们的存在可以创造更多价值。有时，在公司已经拥有基础设施的情况下略微增加成本会更有利可图。他们在哪些方面获得了最大的资源利用优势？总是问：采取特定行动的价值变化是什么？从价值的角度来说，把资源投到哪里最好？

Should TransCorp take the time, money and talent to build a market presence in Montana? The real cost of doing that is the value of the time, money and talent used in its best alternative use. Maybe increasing their presence in a state where they already have a market share is creating more value. Sometimes it is more profitable to marginally increase a cost where a company already has an infrastructure. Where do they marginally get the most leverage on resources spent? Always ask: What is the change of value of taking a specific action? Where is it best to invest resources from a value point of view?

约翰的投资回报率仅为 1%。

John’s return from the investment was a meagre 1 %.

对私人合伙企业的 10 年 100,000 美元投资承诺年回报率为 15%。约翰当时下一个最好的投资是收益率为 6% 的长期美国政府债券。10 年后，现实开始了。他拿回了 110,000 美元。他的年回报率只有1%。如果他当时没有进行投资，而是获得了与政府债券相当的回报，约翰现在将拥有 179,000 美元（税前）而不是 110,000 美元（税前）。他做这项投资的实际成本是 69,000 美元。投资的钱在其他方面与他联系在一起。这还不包括他在旅途中承受的精神压力。

The 10-year $100,000 investment in the private partnership promised a yearly return of 15%. John’s next best available investment at the time was a long-term U.S. government bond yielding 6%. 10 years later reality kicked in. He got back $110,000. His yearly return was only 1%. If he hadn’t made the investment back then, but had earned returns comparable with the government bond, John would now have $179,000 (pre-tax) instead of the $110,000 (pre-tax). His real cost of doing this investment was $69,000. The money invested tied him in other ways. This doesn’t include the mental stress he experienced during the ride.

我们都有很多我们喜欢的东西：我们的配偶、工作、房子、汽车、投资等等。当我们决定是否改变某件事时，我们应该根据我们已有的最好的东西来衡量它。

We all have a lot of things we like: our spouse, job, house, car, investments, etc. When we decide whether to change something, we should measure it against the best of what we already have.

评估备选方案的补充过滤器是列出它们各自的优缺点，然后权衡所有要点。查尔斯达尔文这样做是为了决定是否结婚。沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 告诉我们要在配偶身上寻找什么：“寻找一个会无条件地爱你，会巧妙地鼓励你变得比你想象的更好的人。”

A complementary filter to evaluate alternatives is to list their respective pros and cons and then weigh all the points. Charles Darwin did this in order to decide whether to marry. Warren Buffett tells us what to look for in a spouse:"Look for someone who will love you unconditionally and will subtly encourage you to be better than you thought you can be."

我们也可以像本杰明富兰克林那样权衡备选方案。列出支持和反对的理由，并为它们分配权重。

We can also weigh alternatives the way Benjamin Franklin did. Make up a list of reasons for and against and assign them weights.

并非所有决定都同等重要。有些决定对我们的生活有更大的影响。我们今天做出的决定将影响我们十年后的生活，远比今天才影响我们的决定重要得多。如果我们在选择错误的假期时犯了错误，随着时间的推移，后果很可能会很小。但是，例如，如果我们选择了错误的配偶、错误的教育、错误的职业、错误的朋友或投资，它可能会困扰我们很久很久。

All decisions are not equally important. Some decisions have a greater influence on our lives. A decision we make today that will influence our lives ten years from now is far more important than one that will influence us only today. If we make a mistake in choosing the wrong vacation, the consequences over time will most likely be minor. But if, for example, we choose the wrong spouse, the wrong education, career, friends, or investment, it may haunt us a long, long time.

七：后果

Seven: Consequences

经济学中的关键是，无论何时有人向你提出断言，总是要问，“然后呢？” 实际上，向它询问所有事情并不是一个坏主意。但你应该总是问，“然后呢？”

The key thing in economics, whenever someone makes an assertion to you, is to always ask,"And then what?" Actually, it’s not such a bad idea to ask it about everything. But you should always ask,"And then what?"

- 沃伦·巴菲特

- Warren Buffett

约翰告诉 TransCorp 的首席执行官：“我们看到了机器投资的直接好处。我们没有看到竞争行为，所有的好处都让给了客户。”

John told the CEO of TransCorp:"We see the immediate benefits of investment in machines. We don’t see competitive actions and that all the benefits go to the customer."

“在经济部门，一项行为、一种习惯、一项制度、一项法律，不仅会产生一种影响，还会产生一系列的影响，”法国记者经济学家克劳德·弗雷德里克·巴斯夏 (Claude Frederic Bastiat) 在其 1850 年的论文《那是什么》中写道已见，未见。他继续：

"In the department of economy, an act, a habit, an institution, a law, gives birth not only to an effect, but to a series of effects," wrote the French journalist economist Claude Frederic Bastiat in his 1850 essay, That Which is Seen, and That Which is Not Seen. He continues:

在这些影响中，只有第一个是立竿见影的；它与它的原因同时显现——它被看到了。其他的接连展开——它们是看不见的……在一个好经济学家和一个坏经济学家之间，这构成了全部区别——一个考虑了可见的效果；另一个考虑了可见的效果；另一种方法既考虑了可见的影响，也考虑了需要预见的影响。

Of these effects, the first only is immediate; it manifests itself simultaneously with its cause — it is seen. The others unfold in succession — they are not seen... Between a good and a bad economist this constitutes the whole difference — the one takes account of the visible effect; the other takes account both of the effects which are seen, and also of those which it is necessary to foresee.

考虑行动的次要和长期影响。查尔斯·芒格指出，在商品业务或收益低于标准的业务中，

Consider secondary and long-term effects of an action. Charles Munger points out that in a commodity business or in a business earning substandard returns,

重大改进带来的所有优势都将流向客户......销售机器的人 - 总的来说，甚至是敦促你购买设备的内部官僚 - 向你展示你的预测金额'将使用新技术以当前价格节省。然而，他们不进行分析的第二步——即确定有多少会留在家里，有多少只会流向客户。

在我的生活中，我从未见过包含第二步的单一投影。我总是看到他们。相反，他们总是这样写：“这项资本支出将为您节省大量资金，三年内即可收回成本。” 所以你继续购买三年后可以收回成本的东西。经过 20 年的经营，不知怎的，你每年的回报率只有 4% 左右。那就是纺织业。

并不是说机器不好。只是积蓄没有给你。成本的降低来得很顺利。但是成本降低的好处并没有给购买设备的人。

All of the advantages from great improvements are going to flow through to the customers...the people who sell the machinery - and, by and large, even the internal bureaucrats urging you to buy the equipment — show you projections with the amount you’ll save at current prices with the new technology. However, they don’t do the second step of the analysis — which is to determine how much is going to stay home and how much is just going to flow through to the customer.

I’ve never seen a single projection incorporating that second step in my life. And I see them all the time. Rather, they always read:"This capital outlay will save you so much money that it will pay for itself in three years." So you keep buying things that will pay for themselves in three years. And after 20 years of doing it, somehow you’ve earned a return of only about 4% per annum. That’s the textile business.

And it isn’t that the machines weren’t better. It’s just that the savings didn’t go to you. The cost reductions came through all right. But the benefit of the cost reductions didn’t go to the guy who bought the equipment.

沃伦巴菲特告诉我们虚幻的好处：

Warren Buffett tells us about the illusionary benefits:

我们的许多竞争对手……正在加紧进行同样的支出，一旦有足够多的公司这样做，他们降低的成本就成为全行业降价的基准。单独来看，每家公司的资本投资决策都显得合算且合理；从整体上看，这些决定相互抵消，是不合理的。

Many of our competitors.. .were stepping up to the same kind of expenditures and, once enough companies did so, their reduced costs became the baseline for reduced prices industry-wide. Viewed individually, each company’s capital investment decision appeared cost-effective and rational; viewed collectively, the decisions neutralized each other and were irrational.

每当我们制定政策、采取行动或评估声明时，我们都必须追踪后果。这样做时，我们必须记住四个关键事项：

Whenever we install a policy, take an action or evaluate statements, we must trace the consequences. When doing so, we must remember four key things:

  1. 关注整个系统。直接和间接影响，
  2. Pay attention to the whole system. Direct and indirect effects,
  3. 后果具有影响或更多后果，其中一些可能是不需要的。我们无法估计所有可能的后果，但至少有一个我们应该寻找的不良后果。
  4. Consequences have implications or more consequences, some which may be unwanted. We can’t estimate all possible consequences but there is at least one unwanted consequence we should look our for.
  5. 考虑反馈、时间、规模、重复、临界阈值和限制的影响，
  6. Consider the effects of feedback, time, scale, repetition, critical thresholds and limits,
  7. 不同的替代方案在成本和收益方面具有不同的后果。估计随着时间的推移产生的净影响，以及这些与我们想要实现的目标相比有多理想。
  8. Different alternatives have different consequences in terms of costs and benefits. Estimate the net effects over time and how desirable these are compared to what we want to achieve.

我们不能不劳而获。

We can't get something for nothing.

以替代能源问题为例。考虑替代方案时的一些相关标题：使用的能源与生产的可用能源（考虑整个生产过程）？基础设施要求？可扩展？运输和储存？成本（考虑补贴）？谁付钱？环境效益和成本？可持续性？时间长了会有什么后果？正确评估所有相关因素的难易程度？错误的后果？

Take the issue on alternative energy sources. Some relevant headlines when thinking about alternatives: Energy used versus usable energy produced (considering the entire production process)? Infrastructure requirements? Scalable? Transport and storage? Costs (considering subsidies)? Who pays? Environmental benefits and costs? Sustainability? Consequences over time? Degree of difficulty in properly evaluating all the factors involved? Consequences of being wrong?

在考虑整个系统的情况下，根据一段时间内的净后果来判断一项行动。通过确定系统的其余部分将如何随时间响应来跟进单个变量的变化。降低一个领域的风险可能会增加另一个领域的风险。一个变量的变化可能会改变整个系统。一种变化可能导致另一种变化导致另一种变化，等等。这包括考虑短期和长期后果，因为一个行动和它的全部效果之间可能有很长的时间。

Judge an action by its net consequences over time considering the whole system. Follow up changes in individual variables by determining how the rest of the system will respond over time. Reducing risk in one area may increase it in another. Changes in one variable may change the entire system.
