One change may cause another change causing another, etc. This includes considering short and long-term consequences since there may be a long time between an action and its full effects.

Marcus Tullius Cicero 说：“极端的正义就是极端的不正义”。如果某些系统能为我们所有人带来更好的结果，就应该故意让它们变得有点不公平。查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 向我们讲述了海军模型——一个具有净收益的规则：

Marcus Tullius Cicero said:"Extreme justice is extreme injustice." Some systems should be made deliberately a little unfair if they carry better consequences for us all. Charles Munger tells us about the Navy model - a rule with net benefits:

如果你是海军的一名船长，你已经连续 24 小时起床，不得不睡觉，然后你在恶劣的条件下将船交给一位称职的大副，然后他将船搁浅——显然没有过错你的- 他们不向你求婚，但你的海军生涯结束了。

拿破仑说他喜欢幸运的将军——他不喜欢支持失败者。好吧，海军喜欢幸运的船长。

你可以说，“那太难了。那不是法学院。那不是正当程序。” 好吧，海军模型在其背景下比法学院模型更好。海军模型确实迫使人们在条件艰苦时注意 - 因为他们知道没有任何借口。很简单，如果你的船搁浅了，你的职业生涯就结束了。

“这是否是你的错并不重要。没有人对你的错感兴趣。这只是我们碰巧拥有的规则——为了所有人的利益，考虑所有的影响。”

我喜欢这样的一些规则——我认为文明在其中一些无过错规则下运作得更好。但这些东西往往是法学院的诅咒。“这不是正当程序。你并不是在真正寻求正义。”

好吧，当我为海军规则辩护时，我是在寻求正义——为了减少搁浅船只的正义。考虑到净收益，我不在乎一个船长在他的生活中是否有一些不公平。毕竟，这不像是在法庭上指挥他。他只需要寻找一份新的工作。他保留既得养老金权利等等。所以这不像是世界末日。

If you’re a captain in the Navy and you’ve been up for 24 hours straight and have to go to sleep and you turn the ship over to a competent first mate in tough conditions and he takes the ship aground — clearly through no fault of yours - they don’t court martial you, but your naval career is over.

Napoleon said he liked luckier generals - he wasn’t into supporting losers. Well, the Navy likes luckier captains.

You can say,"That’s too tough. That’s not law school. That’s not due process." Well, the Navy model is better in its context than would be the law school model. The Navy model really forces people to pay attention when conditions are tough - because they know that there’s no excuse. Very simply, if your ship goes aground, your career is over.

"It doesn’t matter whether it was your fault or not. Nobody’s interested in your fault. It’s just a rule that we happen to have — for the good of all, all effects considered."

I like some rules like that — I think that the civilization works better with some of these no-fault rules. But that stuff tends to be anathema around law schools."It’s not due process. You’re not really searching for justice."

Well, I am searching for justice when I argue for the Navy rule — for the justice of fewer ships going aground. Considering the net benefit, I don’t care if one captain has some unfairness in his life. After all, it’s not like he’s being court marshalled. He just has to look for a new line of work. And he keeps vested pension rights and so on. So it’s not like it’s the end of the world.

八：量化

Eight: Quantification

讲道理，就是讲量。说国家很大是没有用的，

——有多大？说镭稀缺是没有用的，

- 稀缺到什么程度？

To talk sense, is to talk in quantities. It is no use saying that the nation is large,

- How large? It is no use saying that radium is scarce,

- How scarce?

- Alfred North Whitehead

（来自教育的目标）

- Alfred North Whitehead

(from The Aims of Education)

我们生活的大多数方面都取决于我们量化和理解模式和关系、比例或大小的能力。数学有什么作用？它帮助我们得出结果，并在事情有意义时进行评估。数学是稳定的。二加二等于四在 100 万年前是正确的，100 万年后也将是正确的。

Most aspects of our life depend on our ability to quantify and understand patterns and relationships, proportions, or magnitudes. What does maths do? It helps us develop consequences, and evaluate when things make sense. And maths is stable. Two plus two is four was true 1 million years ago and will be true 1 million years from today.

当我们将某些东西转化为数字时，我们可以进行比较。如果我们不能根据相关且重要的标准来衡量一个决定，我们如何评估它是否明智？

When we translate something into numbers we can make comparisons. How can we evaluate if a decision is intelligent or not if we can’t measure it against a relevant and important yardstick?

有些东西无法准确测量，因此估计范围是次佳选择。

Some things can’t be measured exactly, so estimating a range is the next best alternative.

“粗略正确总比精确错误好，”JM 凯恩斯说。不要过度衡量可以计算的东西，也不要低估不能计算的东西。提防虚假的具体性——我们通常认为基于带有很多小数位的数字的数据比单独的文字更准确。查尔斯芒格说：

"It is better to be roughly right than precisely wrong," said J.M. Keynes. Don’t over-weigh what can be counted and under-weigh what cannot. Beware of false concreteness — often we believe that data based on figures with lots of decimal places are more accurate than words alone. Charles Munger says:

你有一个复杂的系统，它会吐出很多美妙的数字，使你能够衡量一些因素。但是还有其他一些非常重要的因素，您无法对这些因素进行精确的编号。你知道它们很重要，但你没有数字。好吧，实际上每个人都过度权衡了可以编号的东西，因为它屈服于他们在学术界教授的统计技术，并且没有混入可能更重要的难以衡量的东西。

You’ve got a complex system, and it spews out a lot of wonderful numbers that enable you to measure some factors. But there are other factors that are terribly important and there’s no precise numbering you can put to these factors. You know they’re important but you don’t have the numbers. Well, practically everybody over-weighs the stuff that can be numbered, because it yields to the statistical techniques they’re taught in academia, and doesn’t mix in the hard-to-measure stuff that may be more important.

让我们用商业和投资领域的例子来说明量化的重要性。

Let’s illustrate the importance of quantification with examples from the world of business and investing.

产生一美元的现金流需要多少资本？

How much capital is needed to produce a dollar of cash flow?

投资资本回报率有影响吗？假设有两家公司 — X

Does return on invested capital make a difference? Assume two businesses — X

和 Y - 产生相同的 1000 万美元现金收益和 5% 的“永久”增长。区别在于他们使用多少资本来产生这些收益。X 需要 1 亿美元，Y 需要 4000 万美元。这意味着他们的投资资本回报率分别为 10% 和 25%。这也意味着它们在自由现金流（再投资后）或产生的可分配现金方面存在差异。X 产生 500 万美元，Y 产生 800 万美元。投资资本回报率会影响价值。

and Y - generate the same cash earnings of $ 10 million and"perpetual" growth of 5%. The difference lies in how much capital they use to produce these earnings. X needs $100 million and Y $40 million. This means that their return on invested capital is 10% respective 25%. This also means that they differ in the free cash flow (after reinvesting) or distributable cash they generate. X generates $5 million and Y $8 million. Return on invested capital makes a difference in value.

  业务 X 业务 Y
投入资金 100 40
自由现金流 10 10
再投资资本 -5 -2
再投资资本回报率 10% 25%
可供分配的可用现金流量 5个 8个
10% 贴现率的价值 100 ( 5 / (0.1-0.05) ) 160

沃伦巴菲特描述了最好拥有的企业：

Warren Buffett describes what businesses are best to own:

撇开价格问题不谈，最好拥有的企业是能够在很长一段时间内以非常高的回报率使用大量增量资本的企业。拥有的最糟糕的企业是必须或将会做相反的事情——即持续以极低的回报率使用越来越多的资本。

Leaving the question of price aside, the best business to own is one that over an extended period can employ large amounts of incremental capital at very high rates of return. The worst business to own is one that must, or will, do the opposite - that is, consistently employ ever-greater amounts of capital at very low rates of return.

更高的收入应该自动给我们留下深刻印象吗？

Should higher earnings automatically impress us?

沃伦巴菲特举了伯克希尔旗下一家子公司的例子：

Warren Buffett gives an example from one of Berkshire’s subsidiaries:

虽然收入从 800 万美元增加到 7200 万美元听起来很了不起——而且通常是这样——但你不应该自动假设情况就是这样。您必须首先确保基准年的收入没有下降。相反，如果它们相对于所使用的资本来说是可观的，则必须检查一个甚至更重要的问题：需要多少额外资本才能产生额外收益？

While an increase in earnings from $8 million to $72 million sounds terrific - and usually is — you should not automatically assume that to be the case. You must first make sure that earnings were not depressed in the base year. If they were instead substantial in relation to capital employed, an even more important point must be examined: how much additional capital was required to produce the additional earnings?

我们需要了解数字背后的含义。沃伦巴菲特说，“期初股本回报率”是“衡量单一年度管理业绩的最合适的衡量标准。然而，明智地使用该标准需要了解许多因素，包括会计政策、资产的历史账面价值、财务杠杆和行业状况。”

We need to understand what is behind the numbers. Warren Buffett says that,"return on beginning equity capital" is"the most appropriate measure of single year managerial performance. Informed use of that yardstick, however, requires, an understanding of many factors, including accounting policies, historical carrying values of assets, financial leverage, and industry conditions."

随着时间的推移，我们不能期望获得比基础业务在其投资资本上产生的更高的投资回报。查尔斯芒格说：

We can’t expect to get a higher return on investment over time than the underlying business produces on its invested capital over time. Charles Munger says:

从长远来看，一只股票很难获得比其背后的业务更好的回报。如果企业在 40 年内赚取 6% 的资本回报率，而你持有它 40 年，那么你获得的回报率与 6% 的回报率没有太大区别——即使你最初以大幅折扣购买它。相反，如果一家企业在 20 年或 30 年内的资本收益率为 18%，即使您付出看起来很昂贵的价格，您最终也会获得不错的结果。

Over the long term, it’s hard for a stock to earn a much better return than the business which underlies it earns. If the business earns 6% on capital over 40 years and you hold it for that 40 years, you’re not going to make much different than a 6% return - even if you originally buy it at a huge discount. Conversely, if a business earns 18% on capital over 20 or 30 years, even if you pay an expensive looking price, you’ll end up with a fine result.

很少有公司能够在 10 到 20 年的时间里，在将全部或大部分收益进行再投资的同时，保持 20% 或更高的投资资本回报率。竞争领域、购买者习惯和环境的变化几乎可以确定这一点。

Few companies can manage, over a ten to twenty-year period, to keep earning high returns on 20% or more on invested capital while reinvesting all or most of their earnings. Changes in the competitive arena, buyer habits, and the environment will make that almost a certainty.

沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 揭示了收益增长的局限性以及高尚的预测如何导致愚蠢的行为：

Warren Buffett reveals the limits of earnings growth and how lofty predictions lead to dumb behaviour:

例如，检查 1970 年或 1980 年以来收入最高的 200 家公司的记录，并列出自这些日期以来每年每股收益增长 15% 的公司有多少。你会发现只有少数人拥有。我敢打赌，在 2000 年最赚钱的 200 家公司中，只有不到 10 家公司的每股收益在未来 20 年内实现 15% 的年增长率。

Examine the record of, say, the 200 highest earning companies from 1970 or 1980 and tabulate how many have increased per-share earnings by 15% annually since those dates. You will find that only a handful have. I would wager you a very significant sum that fewer than 10 of the 200 most profitable companies in 2000 will attain 15% annual growth in earnings-per-share over the next 20 years.

他继续：

He continues:

最后，对鼓吹盈利预测和增长预期的公司持怀疑态度。企业很少在平静、没有意外的环境中运营，收益也不会顺利增长（当然，投资银行家的发行簿除外）。

查理和我不仅今天不知道我们的企业明年会赚多少——我们甚至不知道他们下个季度会赚多少。我们对那些经常声称他们确实知道未来的 CEO 表示怀疑——如果他们始终如一地达到他们宣布的目标，我们就会变得彻头彻尾的怀疑。总是承诺“制造数字”的经理人有时会忍不住编造数字。

Finally, be suspicious of companies that trumpet earnings projections and growth expectations. Businesses seldom operate in a tranquil, no-surprise environment, and earnings simply don’t advance smoothly (except, of course, in the offering books of investment bankers).

Charlie and I not only don’t know today what our businesses will earn next year - we don’t even know what they will earn next quarter. We are suspicious of those CEOs who regularly claim they do know the future - and we become downright incredulous if they consistently reach their declared targets. Managers that always promise to"make the numbers" will at some point be tempted to make up the numbers.

需求突然下降，价格竞争加剧。

Suddenly demand goes down and price competition rises.

增长率的变化如何改变商业价值？商业价值是未来现金流量和时间的函数。如果现金流量减少和/或出现在未来更远的地方，商业价值就会下降。

How does a change in growth rate change business value? Business value is a function of the amount and timing of future cash flows. If cash flows decreases and/or appears further off in the future, business value declines.

沃伦巴菲特说明了当增长预期被修正时估值必须如何变化：

Warren Buffett illustrates how valuations must change when growth expectations are revised:

几年前，传统观点认为，报纸、电视或杂志资产的收益将永远以每年 6% 左右的速度增长，而且无需动用额外资本，因为折旧费用将大致与资本支出相匹配，而营运资金需求将很小。因此，报告的收益（在无形资产摊销之前）也是可自由分配的收益，这意味着媒体财产的所有权可以解释为类似于拥有每年增长 6% 的永久年金。接下来，假设使用 10% 的贴现率来确定该收益流的现值。然后可以计算出，为当前税后收入为 100 万美元 [1/0.1-0.06] 的房产支付高达 2500 万美元是合适的，

现在改变假设，假设 100 万美元代表“正常的盈利能力”，盈利将围绕这个数字周期性波动。大多数企业确实存在“周而复始”的模式，只有当所有者愿意投入更多资本（通常以留存收益的形式）时，它们的收入流才会增长。根据我们修改后的假设，100 万美元的收益，按同样的 10% 贴现，转化为 1000 万美元的估值。因此，假设的看似适度的转变会使该物业的估值降至税后收益的 10 倍。

A few years ago the conventional wisdom held that a newspaper, television or magazine property would forever increase its earnings at 6% or so annually and would do so without the employment of additional capital, for the reason that depreciation charges would roughly match capital expenditures and working capital requirements would be minor. Therefore, reported earnings (before amortization of intangibles) were also freely-distributable earnings, which meant that ownership of a media property could be construed as akin to owning a perpetual annuity set to grow at 6% a year. Say, next, that a discount rate of 10% was used to determine the present value of that earnings stream. One could then calculate that it was appropriate to pay a whopping $25 million for a property with current after-tax earnings of $1 million [1/0.1-0.06],

Now change the assumption and posit that the $ 1 million represents"normal earning power" and that earnings will bob around this figure cyclically. A"bob-around" pattern is indeed the lot of most businesses, whose income stream grows only if their owners are willing to commit more capital (usually in the form of retained earnings). Under our revised assumption, $1 million of earnings, discounted by the same 10%, translates to a $ 10 million valuation. Thus a seemingly modest shift in assumptions reduce the property’s valuation to 10 times after-tax earnings.

我们是否为有债务融资的企业和没有债务的企业支付相同的价格？

Do we pay the same price for a business financed with debt as for a business with no debt?

假设玛丽有兴趣购买一家家具店。业务稳定，没有增长，自由现金流为 15，以股权融资 75。价格 100 (15/0.15) 会给她 15% 的回报。债务有影响吗？是的，卖家可以在出售之前通过利用业务赚取额外的钱。如果卖方以 50 的债务为企业再融资（企业可以以 6% 的利息借款）并提取 50 作为股息，则扣除利息后的收入将为 12 (15-3)。如果 Mary 然后以 80 (12/0.15) 的价格买下这家商店，卖方将额外赚取 30 (50+80100)，而企业的基本运营不会发生任何变化。

Assume Mary is interested in buying a furniture store. The business is stable with no growth, free cash flow of 15 and financed with 75 in equity. A price of 100 (15/0.15) will give her a 15% return. Does debt make a difference? Yes, the seller could then make extra money by leveraging the business before selling it. If the seller refinances the business with 50 in debt (and the business can borrow at 6% interest) and withdraws 50 as a dividend, income after interest would be 12 (15-3). If Mary then buys the store for 80 (12/0.15) the seller would have made an extra 30 (50+80100) without any change in the underlying operations of the business.

相反，Mary 应该假设她收购了一家无债务企业并调整 50 的债务并支付 50 (15/0.15-50)。她还应该纠正（添加到价格中）多余的现金——开展业务不需要的现金或现金资产。

Instead Mary should assume she acquires a debt-free business and adjust for 50 of debt and pay 50 (15/0.15-50). She should also correct (add to the price) for excess cash — cash or cash assets that aren’t needed to conduct the business.

这与我们买房子时的推理类型相同。例如，如果我们以 500,000 美元买房子，然后将自己的积蓄中的 200,000 美元投入其中，然后将剩余的 300,000 美元抵押，那么房子的价格仍然是 500,000 美元。

This is the same type of reasoning as when we buy a house. If we for example buy a house for $500,000 and put in $200,000 of our own saved money and mortgage the rest or $300,000, the price of the house is still $500,000.

“我们期望从合并中产生的协同效应从未实现。它们只是幻想。”

"The synergies we expected from the merger never materialized. They were mere illusions."

进行收购时不要忘记量化后果。拿收购公司和目标公司的损益表和资产负债表。计算公司合并时数量、价格、成本和投资资本的变化，同时考虑员工、供应商、客户和竞争的后果和行为变化。商业价值如何变化？现实点。研究表明，大多数合并未能为收购公司的所有者创造价值。主要原因是买方为不真实的协同效应付出了太多。

Don’t forget to quantify consequences when making acquisitions. Take the profit & loss statement and balance sheet of the acquiring company and the target company. Calculate what happens with volume, prices, cost, and invested capital when the companies combine, considering consequences and behavioural changes of employees, suppliers, customers, and competition. How does business value change? Be realistic. Studies show that most mergers fail to generate value for the acquiring company’s owners. The main reason is that the buyer paid too much for synergies that weren’t real.

“但是，有一点是肯定的，”沃伦巴菲特说，“如果一位首席执行官热衷于一项特别愚蠢的收购，他的内部员工和他的外部顾问都会提出任何需要的预测来证明他的立场是正确的。只有在童话是皇帝被告知他们赤身裸体。”

"Of one thing, however, be certain," says Warren Buffett,"If a CEO is enthused about a particularly foolish acquisition, both his internal staff and his outside advisors will come up with whatever projections are needed to justify his stance. Only in fairy tales are emperors told they are naked."

约翰读报。一家公司宣布了一份 1000 万美元的合同，其市值跃升了 10 亿美元。

John reads the paper. A company announced a $10 million contract and its market capitalization jumped $1 billion.

这有意义吗？如果我们假设合同产生 15% 的利润率，则隐含的市场价值增加为 150 万美元。如果需要大量资金和人力资源，即使是高利润项目也可能成为失败者。

Does this make sense? If we assume the contract generates a 15% profit margin, the implied market value increase is $1.5 million. And even a high-margin project can be a loser if it requires a lot of capital and human resources.

如果不同企业的现值相同，派息的时间是否重要？

If present value is the same for different businesses, does the timing of the dividend matter?

假设有 2 家不同的企业 - X 和 Y - 具有以下预测股息。第 5 年后，两家公司倒闭。

Assume there are 2 different businesses - X and Y - with the following forecasted dividends. After year 5 the two companies close down.

 年 1个 2个 3个 4个 5个
来自 X 的股息 10 10 10 10 10
来自 Y 的股息 0 0 0 0 61

X 产生的所有现金每年都分配给其所有者。Y 产生的自由现金流被再投资，直到五年后才支付。假设我们想要 10% 的回报，X 各自 Y 的股息的现值相同或约为 38。但这假设我们可以将 X 的股息以 10% 的比例进行再投资，这样 5 年后我们就有 61。它还假设 Y 可以按照 5 年后股息为 61 的利率对其现金流进行再投资。但在这两种情况下，未来的结果都可能与预期不同。商业环境可能发生变化，竞争加剧，使得 X 和 Y 的股息与我们预期的不同。我们的计算越依赖于遥远未来的现金流，发生意外事件的机会就越多，我们的预期回报就越不确定。

All cash generated by X is each year distributed to its owners. The free cash flow generated by Y is reinvested and not paid out until after the five year period. Assuming we want a 10% return, the present value of X’s respective Y’s dividends are the same or about 38. But this assumes that we can reinvest our dividends from X at 10% so that we have 61 after 5 years. It also assumes that Y can reinvest their cash flow at rates that cause the dividend to be 61 after 5 years. But in both cases the future may turn out different than expected. The business environment may change and competition increase making the dividends from X and Y come out differently from what we expect. The more our calculation depends on cash flows far out in the future, the more opportunities there are for unwanted events, and the more uncertain our expected return.

做数学题！

Do the maths!

我们可以做一个简单的练习来测试我们投资一家公司可能带来的回报，以及它的市场估值是否合理。想想隐含的数学。

We can do a simple exercise to test our possible return from investing in a company and if its market valuation makes sense. Just think about the maths implicit.

下面是一些我们忽略了股息和期权的例子（实际上我们需要适当地考虑期权并确保公司的会计反映现实和真实的经营业绩。）将股票视为企业的一部分并记住小假设的变化会极大地改变价值。

Below are some examples where we have ignored dividends and options (in reality we need to properly account for options and make sure that the company’s accounting reflects reality and the true operational performance.) Think of a stock as part of a business and remember that small changes in assumptions can dramatically change value.

约翰正在考虑购买市值 10 亿美元且没有债务或资产负债表外债务的上市冰淇淋制造商的 1,000 股股票。约翰应该如何推理？

John is thinking of buying 1,000 shares of stock in a public ice cream manufacturer with a market value of $ 1 billion and no debt or off-balance sheet obligations. How should John reason?

我的估计年回报率是多少？

What is my estimated annual rate of return?

约翰预测未来价值，然后将该价值与 10 亿美元的当前市场价值进行比较。他的隐含年回报率是多少？付出的代价能给他足够的回报吗？

John projects the future value, and then compares that value with the present market value of $1 billion. What is his implied annual rate of return? Will the price paid give him an adequate return?

该企业的初始现金收益（收益 + 商誉摊销）为 4000 万美元，假设 10 年的现金收益平均年增长率为 10%。这转化为第 10 年的 1.04 亿美元现金收入。假设市场为此类业务支付的平均倍数为 15。这意味着第 10 年的市场价值为 15.6 亿美元。如果约翰将该数字与当前市场价值进行比较，则他的隐含年回报率为 4.5%。约翰将此回报与其他可用投资机会的回报进行了比较。一家企业可能拥有良好的业绩记录，但如果数学不起作用，请远离。

The business has initial cash earnings (earnings + amortization of goodwill) of $40 million and an assumed average annual growth rate in cash earnings of 10% for 10 years. This translates into $ 104 million in cash earnings in year 10. Assume the market pays an average multiple of 15 for this type of business. This implies $1.56 billion in market value in year 10. If John compares this figure with the present market value, his implied yearly return is 4.5%. John compares this return with the return from other available investment opportunities. A business may have a great track record, but if the maths doesn’t work, stay away.

什么场景能达到15%的年收益率？

What scenario achieves a 15% annual rate of return?

冰淇淋制造商必须赚多少钱才能为约翰产生 15% 的年回报率？如果当前市值复合 15%，这意味着什么，是否合理？

How much must the ice cream manufacturer earn to generate a 15% annual rate of return for John? If the present market value compounds at 15%, what does this imply and is it reasonable?

当前市值为 10 亿美元，年回报率为 15%，这意味着第 10 年的市值为 40 亿美元。如果每年增长 15%，这就是 10 亿美元在 10 年后将增长到的水平。15 的平均倍数意味着第 10 年的现金收入为 2.7 亿美元。这意味着现金收入的年均增长率为 21%（基数为 4000 万美元）。15% 的利润率意味着第 10 年的销售额为 18 亿美元。他可以继续暗示未来的销售额、用户数量和使用情况、市场份额等。

A present market value of $1 billion and an annual return of 15% imply $4 billion in market value in year 10. This is what $1 billion will grow to in 10 years if it grows 15% per year. An average multiple of 15 implies $270 million in cash earnings in year 10. This translates into an average annual growth rate in cash earnings of 21% (from a base of $40 million). A profit margin of 15% implies $1.8 billion in sales year 10. He can continue with implied future sales volume, number of users and usage, market share, etc.

约翰接着问：是什么导致了这个未来价值？这在今天的数字中意味着什么？关于增长、收益、利润率、市场规模/数量增长、市场份额、竞争优势等方面的跟踪记录证据是否合理？哪个因素对未来的现金收益和价值影响最大？什么力量可以改变这种情况？公司怎么会失去优势呢？

John then asks: What causes this future value? What does this imply in numbers today? Is it reasonable regarding evidence of track record in growth, earnings, profit margins, market size/volume growth, market share, competitive advantage, etc? Which factor has the greatest impact on future cash earnings and thereby value? What forces can change this scenario? How can the company lose its advantages?

如果公司今天不赚钱，如果我想要 10% 的回报，他们的市场价值意味着未来的自由现金流量是多少？

If the company doesn’t make money today, what future free cash flow is implied by their market value if I want a 10% return?

在互联网狂热中，沃伦巴菲特说：

In the midst of the Internet mania, Warren Buffett said:

当我们购买股票时，我们总是从购买整个企业的角度来考虑，因为它使我们能够像商人而不是股票投机者一样思考。因此，让我们以一家前景广阔的公司为例，在您以 5000 亿美元的估值购买它时，现在不支付任何费用……例如，假设在企业开始付款之前只会有一年的延迟给你，你想获得 10% 的回报。如果你支付了 5000 亿美元，那么 550 亿美元的现金就是它必须年复一年地流出给你的金额。为此，它必须在税前赚取 800 亿美元或接近 800 亿美元。环顾世界上的企业，看看有多少企业税前收入达到 800 亿美元——700 亿美元、60 美元、50 美元、40 美元，甚至 300 亿美元。你不会找到任何。

When we buy a stock, we always think in terms of buying the whole enterprise because it enables us to think as businessmen rather than stock speculators. So let’s just take a company that has marvellous prospects, that paying you nothing now where you buy it at a valuation of $500 billion.. .For example, let’s assume that there’s only going to be a one-year delay before the business starts paying out to you and you want to get a 10% return. If you paid $500 billion, then $55 billion in cash is the amount that it’s going to have to be able to disgorge to you year after year after year. To do that, it has to make perhaps $80 billion, or close to it, pre-tax. Look around at the universe of businesses in this world and see how many are earning $80 billion pre-tax - or $70 billion or $60 or $50 or $40 or even $30 billion. You won’t find any.

无论一家企业是卖钉子还是卖电信设备，如果流出的钱多于进来的钱，按现值计算，它就一文不值。正如沃伦巴菲特所说，“任何在其生命周期内亏损的企业，无论其中期估值可能达到多高，都是在破坏价值，而不是创造价值。”

Whether a business sells nails or Telecom equipment, if more money is going out than coming in, on a present value basis, it is worthless. As Warren Buffett says,"Value is destroyed, not created, by any business that loses money over its lifetime, no matter how high its interim valuation may get."

他继续：

He continues:

短期内，市盈率上升和人们玩会计游戏等方面有很多魔力。但最终，从现在到企业消亡之间，你​​无法从一家企业中得到比这家企业创造的更多的东西。实际上，你赚的钱会少一些，这取决于你的业务经理是谁、证券的周转频率以及你支付给投资经理的费用等等。

There’s plenty of magic in short term in rising P/E multiples and the games people play with accounting and so on. But in the end, you can’t get more out of a business between now and its extinction than the business makes. And actually you’ll make something less depending on who your business managers are, how often there’s turnover in the security and how much you pay the investment manager and so on.

九：证据

Nine: Evidence



当没有任何理由假设它为真时，相信一个命题是不可取的。

It is undesirable to believe a proposition when there

is no ground whatsoever for supposing it true.

——伯特兰·罗素

- Bertrand Russell

证据帮助我们证明可能发生的事情或可能是真或假的事情。证据来自事实、观察、经验、比较和实验。

Evidence helps us prove what is likely to happen or likely to be true or false. Evidence comes from facts, observations, experiences, comparisons, and experiments.

科学的方法

The methods of science

事实上有两件事：科学和意见；前者产生知识，后者产生无知。

There are in fact two things: science and opinion; the former begets knowledge, the latter ignorance.

- 希波克拉底

- Hippocrates

“我可以做什么实验来解决这个问题？”

"What experiment can 1 do to figure this out?"

1986 年，挑战者号航天飞机在发射时爆炸，机上所有宇航员遇难。灾难发生后，美国宇航局组建了一个委员会，理查德·费曼 (Richard Feynman) 证明燃料助推火箭在温度较低时并不安全。起飞时的温度为华氏 32 度。在发射过程中，振动会导致火箭接头移动。火箭接头内部有橡胶O形圈，用于航天飞机燃料输送系统的某个关键阶段。

In 1986, the space shuttle Challenger exploded on launch, killing all astronauts aboard. After the disaster, NASA put together a commission where Richard Feynman showed that the fuel booster rockets were not safe when the temperature was cold. The temperature at take-off was 32 F. During a launch, vibrations cause the rocket joints to move. Inside the rocket joints there were rubber O-rings that are used in a certain key stage in the space shuttles fuel delivery system.

理查德·费曼 (Richard Feynman) 用挑战者号火箭上的橡胶 O 型圈做了一个简单的实验。他用 C 型夹挤压环，然后将它们浸入一杯冰水（华氏 32 度）中，结果表明橡胶没有膨胀。由于橡胶在 32 F 时没有弹性，因此 O 形圈无法填充膨胀的火箭助推器接头中的间隙。结果导致助推器和航天飞机爆炸。

Richard Feynman did a simple experiment with a rubber O-ring from the Challenger rocket. He squeezed the rings in a C-clamp and dipped them in a glass of ice water (32 F) and showed that the rubber didn’t expand. Since there was no resilience in the rubber at 32 F, the O-ring could not fill the gap in the expanding rocket booster joints. It consequently caused an explosion of the booster and the space shuttle.

这也说明了实验不一定要复杂。

This also illustrates that an experiment doesn’t have to be complicated.

做科学家所做的事：力求客观。科学家们试图描述世界的本来面目，而不是他们想要的样子。他们寻求回答“为什么”和“如何”的问题，并试图通过使用科学完整性的方法来预测自然现象和过程。亚当·斯密在《国富论》中说：“科学是对付狂热和迷信毒药的良药。”

Do what scientists do: Strive for objectivity. Scientists try to describe the world as it is, not as they want it to be. They seek to answer"why" and"how" questions and try to predict natural phenomena and processes by using methods of scientific integrity. Adam Smith said in An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations:"Science is the great antidote to the poison of enthusiasm and superstition."

科学过程包括以下步骤（当然，反复试验、运气和直觉也很重要——科学家使用任何能帮助他们解决问题的方法）：

The scientific process involves the following steps (of course, trial and error, luck and intuition also matters - scientists use any methods that help them solve a problem):

问题或观察——我们试图弄清楚一些事情。我们遇到问题或者我们观察到一些现象并想知道发生了什么以及为什么（重要的是实际发生了什么）。

Problem or observation—We try to figure something out. We have a problem or we observe some phenomena and wonder what happens and why (what matters is what actually happens).

猜猜为什么——我们试图找到一个可能的解决方案或解释（关于为什么或如何发生某事的假设），可以通过对实验和观察进行测试来证明或反驳。也许一些规则或模型可以解决问题或解释我们的观察。我们的猜测必须是可测量的，并且符合自然和已证实的证据。

Guess why— We try to find a possible solution or an explanation (a hypothesis of why or how something happens) that can be proved or disproved by testing it against experiment and observation. Maybe some rule or model can solve the problem or explain our observation. Our guess must be measurable and agree with nature and proven evidence.

预测后果——我们计算出我们猜测的所有逻辑后果，看看如果我们的猜测是正确的会暗示什么。

Predict consequences — We work out all logical consequences of our guess and see what would be implied if our guess was right.

测试——“如果我这样做，会发生什么？” 可测试性是关键。我们将我们猜测的隐含后果与实验、证据和观察进行比较。我们针对错误、欺诈、巧合以及情况或环境的变化重复实验。我们诚实地报告我们的结果。与我们的猜测一致的证据越多，猜测就越有可能是正确的。如果猜测与实验或证据不一致，那就错了。正如理查德·费曼所说：

Test - "If I do this, what will happen?" Testability is key. We compare the implied consequences of our guess with experiment, evidence and observation. We repeat the experiment against error, fraud, coincidence, and change in circumstances or environment. We report our results honestly. The more evidence that agrees with our guess, the more likely the guess was right. If the guess disagrees with experiment or evidence, it is wrong. As Richard Feynman says:

你的猜测有多漂亮都没有关系。你有多聪明，是谁猜的，或者他的名字是什么，都没有任何区别——如果它与实验不一致，那就是错误的。

It does not make any difference how beautiful your guess is. It does not make any difference how smart you are, who made the guess, or what his name is — if it disagrees with experiment it is wrong.

达尔文意识到，要使观察有任何用处，就必须对理论、假设或模型进行验证或反对（如果我们不“猜为什么”，就无法进行实验，因为测试没有任何指导意义） . 在 HMS Beagle 号上，达尔文在给他的朋友 Henry Fawcett 的一封信中写道：

Darwin realized that for an observation to be of any use, it must be tested for or against a theory, hypothesis or model (if we don’t"guess why", there can be no experiments since a test has nothing to guide it). On board the HMS Beagle, in a letter to his friend Henry Fawcett, Darwin wrote:

大约 30 年前，有很多说法认为地质学家应该只观察而不是理论化；我清楚地记得有人说过，以这种速度，一个人还不如走进一个砾石坑，数数鹅卵石并描述颜色。多么奇怪，任何人都不应该看到所有的观察都必须支持或反对某种观点，如果它要有用的话！

About thirty years ago there was much talk that geologists ought only to observe and not to theorize; and I well remember someone saying that at this rate a man might as well go into a gravel pit and count the pebbles and describe the colours. How odd it is that anyone should not see that all observation must be for or against some view if it is to be of any service!

我们不只是观察某些行为；我们带着某种目的或根据某种理论或某些关于寻找重要内容的背景进行观察。我们搜索信息时也是如此。查尔斯芒格说：

We don’t merely observe some behaviour; we observe with some purpose in mind or in light of some theory or with some background about what is important to look for. It is the same when we search for information. Charles Munger says:

.. .您必须知道为什么要查找信息。不要像 Francis Bacon 所说的那样阅读年度报告……您只是在其中收集无穷无尽的 [大量] 数据，然后才尝试理解它。你必须从一些现实的想法开始。然后你必须看看你所看到的是否符合那个基本的思维结构。

.. .you have to have some idea of why you’re looking for the information. Don’t read annual reports the way Francis Bacon said you do science...where you just collect endless [amounts of] data and then only later do you try to make sense of it. You have to start with some ideas of reality. And then you have to look to see whether what you’re seeing fits in with that basic thought structure.

奥卡姆剃刀原则是 14 世纪逻辑学家威廉·奥卡姆提出的原则：“实体不应不必要地相乘。” 如果我们面临做出相同预测的两种可能的解释，那么在出现更多证据之前，基于最少数量的未经证实的假设的解释是可取的。奥卡姆不排除其他解释。套用阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦的话：“理论应该尽可能简单，但不能更简单。”

Occam’s Razor is a principle attributed to the 14th Century logician William of Occam:"Entities should not be multiplied unnecessarily." If we face two possible explanations which make the same predictions, the one based on the least number of unproven assumptions is preferable, until more evidence comes along. Occam doesn’t rule out other explanations. To paraphrase Albert Einstein:"Theories should be as simple as possible, but no simpler."

从过去寻找证据

Finding evidence from the past

如果你想预测未来，就研究过去。

Study the past if you would divine the future.

——孔子

- Confucius

约翰正在考虑聘请一位新经理。经理过去的记录重要吗？

John is thinking of hiring a new manager. Does the manager’s past record matter?

沃伦巴菲特说：

Warren Buffett says:

我们能对管理能力做出的最佳判断并不取决于人们所说的，而仅仅是记录所显示的。在伯克希尔哈撒韦公司，当我们购买一家企业时，我们通常会留下经营它的人，所以我们已经有了一个成功率。以经营我们家具市场的 B 夫人为例。在 50 年的时间里，我们看到她将 500 美元变成了一项税前收入为 1800 万美元的企业。所以我们知道她是有能力的……显然，这里的教训是过去的记录是最好的单一指南。

然后你遇到了 14 岁马的问题。假设您购买了 The Daily Racing Form，它显示这匹马在四岁时赢得了肯塔基赛马会。根据过去的表现，你知道这是一匹马的地狱。但现在他 14 岁了，几乎不能动了。所以你必须问问自己，“关于过去的记录，是否有任何东西使其成为预测未来的糟糕指南？”

The best judgement we can make about managerial competence does not depend on what people say, but simply what the record shows. At Berkshire Hathaway, when we buy a business we usually keep whoever has been running it, so we already have a batting average. Take the case of Mrs. B. who ran our Furniture Mart. Over a 50-year period, we’d seen her take $500 and turn it into a business that made $ 18 million pre-tax. So we knew she was competent...Clearly, the lesson here is that the past record is the best single guide.

Then you run into the problem of the 14-year-old horse. Let’s say you buy The Daily Racing Form and it shows that the horse won the Kentucky Derby as a four-year-old. Based on past performance, you know this was one hell of a horse. But now he’s 14 and can barely move. So you have to ask yourself,"Is there anything about the past record that makes it a poor guideline as a forecaster of the future?"

以下问题帮助我们确定过去的证据是否代表未来：

The following questions help us decide if past evidence is representative for the future:

观察：过去/现在的行为会继续吗？还能持续多久？

Observation: Will past/present behaviour continue? How long can it continue?

解释: 为什么它发生在过去或现在发生？它是怎么发生的？我们必须了解过去结果发生的原因。关键因素是什么？这要求我们理解方程式——涉及的关键变量及其关系。从一个假设开始。将我们对原因的解释的隐含后果与适当的证据进行比较——支持和反对。

Explanation: Why did it happen in the past or why does it happen now? How did it happen? We must understand the reasons why a past outcome occurred. What are the key factors? This demands that we understand the equation — the key variables involved and their relationships. Start with a hypothesis. Compare the implied consequences of our explanation of causes with appropriate evidence — for and against.

可预测性：过去/现在的证据对未来可能发生的事情的预测（代表性）程度如何？现在和将来的情况是否可能改变？确保证据不是随机的。过去起作用的可能是偶然的结果。

Predictability: How predictive (representative) is the past/present evidence for what is likely to happen in the future? Are the conditions now and in the future likely to change? Make sure that the evidence isn’t random. What worked in the past could have been the result of chance.

延续和改变：要使过去/现在的记录继续或实现目标（再看一次等式）需要什么？必须发生什么？什么事不能发生？什么力量可以改变它或导致我们不想要的东西？可能吗？对我们不想发生的事情的解毒剂？

Continuation and Change: What is required to make the past/present record continue or to achieve the goal (look at the equation again)? What must happen? What must not happen? What forces can change it or cause what we don’t want? Likely? Antidotes to what we don’t want to happen?

确定性和后果：我有多确定？我押注哪一个事件一定会发生或不会发生？错误的后果是什么？

Certainty and Consequences: How certain am I? What single event am I betting on that must happen or not happen? What are the consequences of being wrong?

伪造和反驳

Falsify and disprove

我们所有的常识性想法都应该随时接受批评。

All our common-sense ideas should always be open to criticism.

- 卡尔·波普尔

（奥地利-英国哲学家，1902-1994）

- Karl Popper

(Austrian-British philosopher, 1902-1994)

科学结果总是有一定的可能性。明天可能会带来新的证据。与其验证一个陈述，有时不如证明它是假的。支持一个陈述的单一证据并不能证明它的真实性——它只是支持它。但只要有一个证据可以证明它是错误的。阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦说：“没有多少实验可以证明我是对的；一个实验就可以证明我是错的。”

Scientific results always have some probability attached to them. Tomorrow may bring new evidence. Instead of verifying a statement, it is sometimes better to prove it false. A single piece of evidence in favour of a statement does not prove its truth - it only supports it. But a single piece of evidence against it will show that it is false. Albert Einstein said:"No number of experiments can prove me right; a single experiment can prove me wrong."

“所有的天鹅都是白色的。”

"All swans are white."

我们如何测试这个声明？我们可以睁开眼睛，出去寻找非白天鹅。如果我们发现一只不是白色的天鹅，我们就反驳了这个说法。我们发现越多的天鹅是白色的，该声明得到的支持就越多。但它没有被证明。一只黑天鹅，声明被拒绝。

How could we test this statement? We could open our eyes, and go out looking for non-white swans. If we find one swan that is not white we have disproved the statement. The more swans we find to be white, the more support the statement has. But it is not proven. One black swan and the statement is rejected.

“宇宙的年龄不过一万年。”

"The universe is no more than 10,000 years old."

我们可以进行什么实验来证伪这个说法？我们可以仰望天空，观察数百万光年之外的星星。这意味着我们看到的是数百万年前的样子。

What experiment can we perform to falsify this statement? We can look up at the sky and observe stars that are millions of light-years away. This means we are seeing them as they were millions of years ago.

“药物治疗有效。我痊愈了。” “与什么相比？”

"The medical treatment worked. I’m cured.""Compared to what?"

我们如何检验治愈是由于治疗、良好的推销、建议的力量还是患者的想象力？为减少错误和偏差，医学研究采用随机双盲安慰剂对照研究。研究对象被随机分为年龄、身体状况和其他因素相互匹配的两组。一组接受治疗，另一组接受安慰剂。研究对象和研究人员都不知道谁在接受治疗或安慰剂。然后研究人员比较效果。

How can we test whether a cure is due to treatment, good salesmanship, the power of suggestion, or the patient’s imagination? To reduce error and bias, medical research uses a randomized, double blind placebo-controlled study. Research subjects are randomly divided in two groups that match each other in age, physical status and other factors. One group receives the treatment and the other group the placebo. Neither the research subjects nor the researchers know who’s getting the treatment or the placebo. Then the researchers compare the effects.

“使用这种药物没有风险。”

"There is no risk in using this medicine."

没有证据表明有害（或有益）与证明某物安全（或有害）的证据不同。根据我们目前所知，只有安全（或有害）。比较考古学——某些东西没有被发现并不意味着它不会被发现。

That there is no evidence of harm (or benefit) isn’t the same as evidence that something is safe (or harmful). Only safe (or harmful) based on what we know so far. Compare archaeology — just because something hasn’t been found doesn’t mean it won’t be found.

反驳想法。查尔斯·达尔文总是关注他错了的可能性：

Disprove ideas. Charles Darwin always looked at the possibility that he was wrong:

多年来，我也一直遵循一条金科玉律，即每当我想到一个已发表的事实、一个新的观察或想法，如果与我的一般结果相反，就一定要立即记下来：因为我根据经验发现，这样的事实和想法比有利的更容易从记忆中逃脱。由于这个习惯，很少有人反对我的观点，我至少没有注意到并试图回答......

我想我在猜测正确的解释和设计实验测试方面变得更有技巧了；但这可能只是实践和大量知识储备的结果。我一如既往地难以清晰简洁地表达自己的意思；这个困难使我浪费了很多时间。但它有一个补偿优势，它迫使我对每一个句子进行长时间和专心的思考，因此我被引导去发现推理和我自己或其他人的观察中的错误。

I had, also, during many years, followed a golden rule, namely, that whenever a published fact, a new observation or thought came across me, which was opposed to my general results, to make a memorandum of it without fail and at once: for I had found by experience that such facts and thoughts were far more apt to escape from the memory than favourable ones. Owing to this habit, very few objections were raised against my views which I had not at least noticed and attempted to answer...

I think that I have become a little more skilful in guessing right explanations and in devising experimental tests; but this may probably be the result of mere practice, and of a larger store of knowledge. I have as much difficulty as ever in expressing myself clearly and concisely; and this difficulty has caused me a very great loss of time; but it has had the compensating advantage of forcing me to think long and intently about every sentence, and thus I have been led to see errors in reasoning and in my own observations or those of others.

“既然有很多证据都符合我的解释，那我肯定是对的。”

"Since a lot of evidence agrees with my explanation, I must be right."

不一定，同样的证据可能与其他解释一致。寻找反驳你的解释的证据。

Not necessarily, the same evidence may agree with other explanations. Look for evidence that disproves your explanation.

不要花时间在已经被反驳或无法反驳的想法或论点上。问：什么试验可以证明这一点？例如，有人告诉我们 Zeta 星球上有生命。这个无法测试。这并不意味着地球上没有生命。只能说明我们今天没法测试了。

Don’t spend time on already disproved ideas or arguments or those that can’t be disproved. Ask: What test can disprove this? For example, someone tells us that there is life on planet Zeta. This can’t be tested. That doesn’t mean there is no life on the planet. It only means that there is no way we can test it today.

基于观察的理论优先于单独的理论，因为观察可以反驳理论。伽利略·伽利莱 (Galileo Galilei) 的理论基于对太阳是否围绕地球旋转的争论中的观察。

Theories based on observations have priority over theories alone since observations can disprove theories. Galileo Galilei based his theories on observations in the debate whether the sun revolved around the Earth.

进行自我批评。质疑你的假设。解释你的信念的反面。问：假设我错了，我怎么知道？为什么相反的理论可能是正确的？假设我的回答是正确的，什么会导致我改变主意？然后，寻找证据。

Engage in self-criticism. Question your assumptions. Explain the opposite of your beliefs. Ask: Assume I’m wrong, how will I know? Why may an opposite theory be correct? Assuming my answer is correct, what would cause me to change my mind? Then, look for that evidence.

通常我们看不到自己的弱点，因此没有动力去改进。因此，鼓励合适的人提供客观的反馈，这将有助于我们改进。

Often we don’t see our weaknesses and thus are not motivated to improve. Therefore, encourage the right people to give objective feedback that will help us improve.

回顾过去并根据最初的期望衡量您的表现。尽早发现您的错误并在它们造成伤害之前迅速纠正它们。

Look back and measure how you are doing against your original expectations. Find your mistakes early and correct them quickly before they cause harm.

下一个工具迫使我们客观。查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 谈到逆向思维时说：

The next tool forces us to be objective. Charles Munger says on backward thinking:

逆向思考的心理习惯迫使客观性——因为你逆向思考事物的一种方式是你接受你最初的假设并说，“让我们试着推翻 它。”

大多数人最初的假设并不是这样。他们尝试并确认它。

这是心理学中的一种自动倾向——通常称为“先下结论偏见”。但这只是一种趋势。你可以训练自己在很大程度上远离这种倾向。您只是不断地采用自己的假设并尝试反驳它们。

The mental habit of thinking backward forces objectivity — because one of the ways you think a thing through backward is you take your initial assumption and say,"Let’s try and disprove it."

That is not what most people do with their initial assumption. They try and confirm it.

It’s an automatic tendency in psychology - often called"first-conclusion bias". But it’s only a tendency. You can train yourself away from the tendency to a substantial degree. You just constantly take your own assumptions and try and disprove them.

十：逆向思维

Ten: Backward Thinking

生活中的许多成功和商业上的成功都来自于知道你真正想要避免什么——比如早逝和不幸的婚姻。

A lot of success in life and success in business comes from knowing what you really want to avoid— like early death and a bad marriage.

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

避免导致与您想要实现的目标相反的原因。

Avoid what causes the opposite of what you want to achieve.

“你必须始终反转，”19 世纪德国数学家卡尔雅各比在被问及他的数学发现的秘密时说。每当我们试图实现一个目标、解决问题、预测可能发生的事情或可能是对还是错的事情时，我们都应该逆向思考。

"You must always invert," said the 19th Century German mathematician Karl Jacobi when asked the secret of his mathematical discoveries. Whenever we try to achieve a goal, solve problems, predict what is likely to happen or likely to be true or false, we should think things through backwards.

在与他的经理举行的每周会议上，约翰问道：“我们公司可以采取什么行动来在尽可能短的时间内摧毁尽可能多的价值？”

At the weekly meeting with his managers, John asked:"What actions could our company take to destroy as much value as possible in as short time as possible?"

 “虐待员工。奖励糟糕的工作。不要诉诸于员工的自身利益，而是为了一个没人理解的目标。不要告诉人们公司的立场、适用的规则以及违反这些规则的后果。让肯定的人不知道他们的责任范围。把合适的人放在错误的地方。不要让人们知道他们是否实现了目标。一切都应该是无法衡量的。永远不要告诉人们为什么要做某事。

 "Treat the employees badly. Reward bad work. Don’t appeal to the employee’s self interests but to a goal no one understands. Don’t inform people what the company stands for, what rules apply, and the consequences for breaking them. Make sure people don’t know their areas of responsibility. Put the right person in the wrong place. Don’t let people know if they achieve a goal. Everything should be impossible to measure. Never tell people why something should be done.

CEO 周围都是困惑、没有动力的下属。给关键客户生气的理由。延迟和错误的交付、延误和傲慢会有所帮助。让客户将业务与痛苦联系起来，并确保这种感觉在与公司的每次接触中得到强化。”

Surround the CEO with confused, unmotivated subordinates. Give key customers reasons to be angry. Late and wrong deliveries, delays, and arrogance will help. Let the customers associate the business with misery and make sure that this feeling gets reinforced at every contact with the company."

向后思考，我们可以确定必须避免哪些行为。正如查尔斯芒格所说，“如果你被世界银行聘用来帮助印度，那么确定增加印度人的痛苦年数的三种最佳方法将非常有帮助 - 然后转身避免这些方法。 “

Thinking backwards, we can determine what actions must be avoided. As Charles Munger says,"If you were hired by the World Bank to help India, it would be very helpful to determine the three best ways to increase man-years of misery in India - and, then, turn around and avoid those ways."

我们不问我们如何才能实现目标，而是问相反的问题：我不想实现什么（非目标）？什么原因导致非目标？我怎样才能避免这种情况？我现在想要达到什么目的？我怎样才能做到这一点？例如，他们没有寻找约翰和玛丽如何改善他们的婚姻，而是问：“哪些品质会破坏我们的婚姻？” 一种品质是不诚实。现在他们又把问题倒过来问：“我们怎样才能改善我们的婚姻？” 说实话。（另请参见附录一中查尔斯芒格关于保证痛苦的处方的精彩演讲）。

Instead of asking how we can achieve a goal, we ask the opposite question: What don’t I want to achieve (non-goal)? What causes the non-goal? How can I avoid that? What do I now want to achieve? How can I do that? For example, instead of searching for how John and Mary can improve their marriage, they ask: "What qualities will destroy our marriage?" One quality is dishonesty. Now they reinvert the question back and ask:"How can we improve our marriage?" Be honest. (See also Charles Munger’s brilliant speech on prescriptions for guaranteed misery in Appendix One).

查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 提供了一个启发性示例，说明愚蠢的系统如何导致愚蠢的行为：

Charles Munger provides an enlightening example on how dumb systems cause dumb behaviour:

比方说，你有做公共服务的愿望。作为你计划的自然组成部分，你会反过来思考并问：“我能做些什么来破坏我们的文明？” 这很容易。如果你想做的是破坏你的文明，那就去立法机关通过法律，建立人们可以轻易作弊的制度。它会完美地工作。以加州的工人赔偿制度为例。压力是真实的。它的痛苦可能是真实的。所以你想补偿人们在工作场所的压力。这似乎是一件高尚的事情。

但这种补偿做法的问题在于，要删除大量作弊实际上是不可能的。一旦你奖励作弊，你就会让不正当的律师、不正当的医生、不正当的工会等参与推荐计划。你得到了灾难性行为的总瘴气。而且这种行为使所有人在这样做时变得更糟。所以你试图帮助你的文明。但你所做的是造成巨大的损失，净值。因此，让一些事情没有补偿——让生活变得艰难——比创建容易作弊的系统要好得多。

Let’s say you have a desire to do public service. As a natural part of your planning, you think in reverse and ask,"What can I do to ruin our civilization?" That’s easy. If what you want to do is to ruin your civilization, just go to the legislature and pass laws that create systems wherein people can easily cheat. It will work perfectly. Take the workers’ compensation system in California. Stress is real. And its misery can be real. So you want to compensate people for their stress in the workplace. It seems like a noble thing to do.

But the trouble with such a compensation practice is that it’s practically impossible to delete huge cheating. And once you reward cheating, you get crooked lawyers, crooked doctors, crooked unions, etc. participating in referral schemes. You get a total miasma of disastrous behaviour. And the behaviour makes all the people doing it worse as they do it. So you were trying to help your civilization. But what you did was create enormous damage, net. So it’s much better to let some things go uncompensated — to let life be hard — than to create systems that are easy to cheat.

“不要考虑红色！”

"Don’t think about the color red!"

如果有人告诉你不要去想红色，你可能会不自觉地想到那种颜色。为什么？因为为了知道不该去想什么，你的大脑必须先去想它。当约翰在高尔夫球场上试图越过果岭前的水障碍时，他并没有对自己说，“我不想在水中击球，”而是“我想击球”果岭上的球。” 因此，当我们告诉人们要避免什么时，我们应该以我们希望他们实现的目标结束。

If someone told you not to think of the color red, you might automatically think of that color. Why? Because in order to know what not to think about, your brain must first think about it. When John is on a golf course trying to hit over a water hazard in front of the green, he doesn’t say to himself,"I don’t want to hit the ball in the water," but instead"I want to hit the ball on the green." So when we tell people what to avoid, we should end with what we want them to achieve.

学习错误。

Study errors.

Marcus Porcius Cato 写道：“聪明人从傻瓜那里得到的收益比傻瓜从聪明人那里得到的收益更多；因为聪明人会避开傻瓜的错误，但傻瓜不会模仿聪明人的成功。”

Marcus Porcius Cato wrote:"Wise men profit more from fools than fools from wise men; for the wise men shun the mistakes of the fools, but fools do not imitate the successes of the wise."

为了减少错误，我们应该研究后果严重的失败。无论是在事业上，还是在生活中。我们应该随着时间的推移查看它们的原因，看看它们是否没有改变。

To reduce mistakes, we should study failures with severe consequences. Both in business and in life. We should look at their causes over time and see if they are unchanged.

通常，我们从理解某事为什么行不通中学到的东西比从它为什么行得通中学到的更多。研究还表明，戏剧性的错误故事训练是一种有效的学习方法。错误是显着的和令人难忘的。研究错误鼓励努力思考，并提高我们处理变化和新的或不寻常情况的能力。问：为什么会这样？为什么某些企业会亏损或倒闭？为什么聪明人会做出愚蠢的行为？为什么会发生某些事故？导致性能不佳的错误是什么？出现了什么情况？教训是什么？

Often we learn more from understanding why something doesn’t work than from why it does. Studies also show that dramatic error-story training is an effective method of learning. Errors are salient and memorable. Studying errors encourage effortful thinking, and improves our capacity to deal with change and new or unusual situations. Ask: Why did that happen? Why do certain businesses lose money or fail? Why do smart people engage in foolish behaviour? Why do certain accidents happen? What was the mistake that caused bad performance? What circumstances were present? What’s the lesson?

当我们知道这一点时，我们应该问：哪些人或企业正在做历史证明会导致失败的事情？我们怎样才能最好地避免我们不想发生的事情？我们如何才能创造最好的条件来避免错误？我们如何预防无法消除的原因？我们如何限制我们想要避免的后果？我们如何限制我们想要避免的事情的可能性？

When we know this, we should ask: What people or businesses are doing things that history has proven causes failure? How can we best avoid what we don’t want to happen? How can we create the best conditions to avoid mistakes? How can we prevent causes that can’t be eliminated? How can we limit the consequences of what we want to avoid? How can we limit the probability of what we want to avoid?

我们可以使用如下表来组织错误研究。

We can organize the study of errors, by using a table like the one below.

避免什么 原因 解药
错误是什么？ 为什么会发生这些？

主要的风险因素是什么？

What are the major risk factors?

具体错误如何演变？

How do specific errors evolve?

什么因素起作用？

What factors contribute?
愚蠢/非理性 有助于解释和预测的好主意？

什么是理性？

What is rational?

我怎样才能创造最好的条件来做出正确的

决定？

How can I create the best conditions to make good

decisions?

什么可以消除

或预防？

What can be eliminated

or prevented?

化消极为优势。

Turn the negative into an advantage.

1796年，英国医生爱德华詹纳发现了疫苗接种。他注意到感染了一种温和的、通常非致命的痘病毒——牛痘——的挤奶女工似乎对这种致命的天花病毒免疫。然后，他采集了一名挤奶女工的病变样本，并为一名小男孩接种了牛痘。这个男孩在他的免疫系统中建立了抗体，防止他感染天花并随后在流行病中幸存下来。

In 1796, British physician Edward Jenner discovered vaccination. He noticed that milkmaids who had contracted a mild and usually non-lethal form of the pox virus - cowpox - seemed to be immune to the lethal form of the virus, smallpox. He then took samples of a milkmaid’s lesions and inoculated a young boy with cowpox. The boy built up antibodies in his immune system that prevented him from getting smallpox and subsequently survived the epidemic.

开始就要考虑如何结束。

Begin with the end in mind.

公元 4 世纪，亚历山大港的希腊数学家帕普斯写道：“让我们从正在寻找的东西开始，并假设我们已经找到了它。” 假设我们已经实现了目标，然后问：目的是什么？这是我想要的吗？如果是这样，我从哪个较早的位置到达那里？实现这一目标需要什么？然后从头开始。通过向后工作，我们可以更容易地了解某些事情如何以及是否可行。这方面的一个例子是回顾性疾病研究。研究人员研究这种疾病，然后回过头来看看有哪些先验条件与之相关。

In the 4th Century the Greek mathematician Pappus of Alexandria wrote:"Let us start with what is being seeked and assume that we already found it." Assume we’ve achieved our goal, then ask: What was the purpose? Was this what I wanted? If so, from which earlier position do I get there? What is needed to achieve this? Then work backward to the beginning. By working backwards we can easier see how and if something may work. An example of this is retrospective disease studies. Researchers study the disease then work backward to see what prior conditions are associated with it.

“我们需要学校纪律。”

"We need discipline in schools."

如果这个陈述是错误的，会有什么后果？倒转一个陈述，表明相反的情况更糟。后果是什么？令人难以置信还是消极的？假设学校没有纪律，会不会有更多我们不想要的行为？

What would be the consequences if this statement were false? Turn a statement backwards and show that the opposite is worse. What are the consequences? Unbelievable or negative? Suppose there was no discipline in schools, would there be more behaviour we don’t want?

当我们相信我们做出了正确的判断时，我们应该考虑什么可能导致我们的预测相反——我们不希望发生的事情。假设我们做出性格判断，得出的结论是这个人性格很好，我们想进入一段关系。问：什么会破坏这段关系？是什么导致我误判性格？

When we believe we have arrived at the right judgement, we should consider what could cause the opposite of our prediction - what we don’t want to happen. Suppose we make a personality judgement and conclude that the individual is of good character and we want to enter a relationship. Ask: What can ruin this relationship? What causes me to misjudge character?

逆向思维的其他用途是：研究暗示与正常情况相反的证据并问“为什么”。使用“负面”规则——告诉人们他们不能做什么。练习零基础思维——从一张白纸开始问：如果我们还没有做我们正在做的事情，我们如何才能最好地实现我们的目标？

Other uses of backward thinking are: Study evidence that implies the opposite of what is normal and ask"why." Use"negative" rules - tell people what they can’t do. Practice zero base thinking — start with a clean sheet of paper and ask: If we weren’t already doing what we do, how can we best achieve our goal?

下一章是关于风险或损失的可能性。如果我们把头伸进狮子的嘴里，被它咬掉，我们不应该感到惊讶。

Next chapter is about risk or the possibility of loss. If we put our head in the lion’s mouth, we shouldn’t be surprised if it’s bitten off.

十一：风险

Eleven: Risk

没有冒险的生活可能不会令人满意，但允许冒险采取任何形式的生活肯定是短暂的。

A life without adventure is likely to be unsatisfying, but a life in which adventure is allowed to take whatever form it will, is sure to be short.

- Bertrand Russell

（来自权威与个人）

- Bertrand Russell

(from Authority and the Individual)

“你为什么要买这只股票？投资成功必须发生什么？不利因素是什么？”

"Why do you want to buy this stock? What must happen for the investment to succeed? What is the downside?"

反思可能会出错的地方。问：什么可能导致这变成一场灾难？潜在的不利因素是什么？我应该担心什么？可能损失的可能性和严重程度是多少？可能发生的最糟糕的事情是什么？我能做些什么来防止它？如果发生了我该怎么办？

Reflect on what can go wrong. Ask: What may cause this to turn into a catastrophe? What is the potential downside? What should I worry about? What is the likelihood and magnitude of a possible loss? What’s the worst thing that could happen? What can I do to prevent it? What will I do if it happens?

我们在投资时需要看到不利的一面。根据福布斯杂志，查尔斯·芒格的推理方式是：

We need to look at the downside when we invest. According to Forbes Magazine, Charles Munger’s way of reasoning is:

一个简单的事实是，除非您考虑所有可能的负面因素，否则您无法判断一个想法是否可行……好吧，这是一家好公司。但是价格够低吗？管理层是由芒格和巴菲特喜欢的人组成的吗？如果便宜到可以买，那么便宜是出于错误的原因还是出于正确的原因？正如芒格所说：“另一面是什么，有什么我没见过的错误？”

The simple fact is that you can’t tell whether an idea is likely to work unless you consider all the possible negatives... Okay, it’s a good company. But is the price low enough? Is the management made up of people Munger and Buffett are comfortable with? If it is cheap enough to buy, is it cheap for the wrong reason or the right reason? As Munger puts it: "What’s the flip side, what can go wrong that I haven’t seen?"

错误会导致实际损失和机会成本。投资时，我们可能会损失本金——我们投资 10 并收回 5——或者我们得到的回报不足——例如 3% 对 6% 的债券。沃伦·巴菲特 (Warren Buffett) 对商业风险有何看法？

Being wrong causes both an actual loss and an opportunity cost. When investing, we can either lose our capital — we invest 10 and get back 5 — or we get an inadequate return — for example 3% versus 6% from a bond. What does Warren Buffett say about business risk?

当我们审视企业时，我们会尝试着眼于当今的好企业，并思考可能出现的问题。我们根据五年、十年或十五年后可能发生的事情来考虑商业风险，这些事情将破坏、改变或削弱我们认为目前存在于企业中的经济实力。对于某些企业来说，这是无法计算的——至少我们无法计算——我们甚至都没有考虑过。如果我们能想到很多可能出错的地方，我们就会忘记它。

When we look at businesses, we try to look at businesses that are good businesses today and think about what can go wrong. We think of business risk in terms of what can happen five, 10 or 15 years from now that will destroy, modify or reduce the economic strengths we believe currently exist in the business. And for some businesses, that’s impossible to figure - at least it’s impossible for us to figure - and we don’t even think about it. If we can think of very much that can go wrong, we just forget it.

沃伦·巴菲特说“最小化风险的最好方法是思考”。他还告诉我们伯克希尔如何降低风险：

Warren Buffett says that"the best way to minimize risk is to think". He also tells us how Berkshire reduces risk:

在股票方面，我们希望每一项承诺都能取得成功，因为我们专注于具有强大竞争优势、由能干诚实的人经营的保守融资企业。如果我们以合理的价格买入这些公司，亏损应该很少见。事实上，在我们管理公司事务的 38 年里，我们管理的伯克希尔股票（即不包括 General Re 和 GEICO 管理的股票）的收益超过损失的比例约为 100 比 1。

In stocks, we expect every commitment to work out well because we concentrate on conservatively financed businesses with strong competitive strengths, run by able and honest people. If we buy into these companies at sensible prices, losses should be rare. Indeed, during the 38 years we have run the company’s affairs, gains from the equities we manage at Berkshire (that is, excluding those managed at General Re and GEICO) have exceeded losses by a ratio of about 100 to one.

我们需要冒很多风险才能在生活中取得成功吗？查尔斯·芒格讲过一个故事：

Do we need to take a lot of risks to get ahead in life? Charles Munger tells a story:

我有一个姻亲，他在 80 多岁时去世了。而且我认为他从未有过损失。他一生只做了大约八件事。他从一个小戳开始，如果不是很容易，他就不会这么做。他过得很好，死时也很富有。我认为很多人都有可能过上这样的生活，那里没有太多的灾难风险，而且他们几乎肯定会取得合理的进步。这需要大量的判断力、大量的纪律和缺乏多动症。通过这种方法，我认为大多数聪明人都可以从生活中冒很多风险。

I had a relative by marriage who died in his late 80s. And I don’t think he ever had a loss. He only did about eight things in his lifetime. He started with a small poke, and if something wasn’t a near cinch, he didn’t do it. He lived well and died rich. I think it’s possible for a great many people to live a life like that where there isn’t much risk of disaster and where they’re virtually sure to get ahead a reasonable amount. It takes a lot of judgement, a lot of discipline and an absence of hyperactivity. By this method, I think most intelligent people can take a lot of risk out of life.

一个傻瓜和他的钱很快就会分开

A fool and his money are soon parted

优秀的长线投资者需要具备哪些特质？沃伦巴菲特在伯克希尔哈撒韦公司 2006 年董事长的信中为我们提供了一些线索，他在信中提到伯克希尔打算在需要时聘请某人接替他担任伯克希尔的首席投资官：

What traits are necessary to be an outstanding long-term investor? Warren Buffett gives us some clues in Berkshire Hathaway’s 2006 Chairman’s letter, where he mentions Berkshire’s intention of hiring someone to succeed him as Berkshire’s chief investment officer when the need arises:

选择合适的人不是一件容易的事。当然，要找到聪明的人并不难，他们当中有令人印象深刻的投资记录。但是，成功的长期投资远不止是最近表现良好的头脑和表现。

随着时间的推移，市场会做出异常的，甚至是奇怪的事情。一个单一的大错误可能会抹杀一连串的成功。因此，我们需要基因编程的人来识别和避免严重的风险，包括那些以前从未遇到过的风险。金融机构目前普遍采用的模型无法发现投资策略中潜伏的某些风险。

气质也很重要。独立思考、情绪稳定以及对人类和机构行为的敏锐理解对于长期投资成功至关重要。

Picking the right person(s) will not be an easy task. It’s not hard, of course, to find smart people, among them individuals who have impressive investment records. But there is far more to successful long-term investing than brains and performance that has recently been good.

Over time, markets will do extraordinarily, even bizarre things. A single, big mistake could wipe out a long string of successes. We therefore need someone genetically programmed to recognize and avoid serious risks, including those never before encountered. Certain perils that lurk in investment strategies cannot be spotted by use of the models commonly employed today by financial institutions.

Temperament is also important. Independent thinking, emotional stability, and a keen understanding of both human and institutional behaviour is vital to long-term investment success.

错误的后果

The consequences of being wrong

如果我们不能容忍可能的后果，即使它可能很遥远，我们也会避免播下它的种子。

If we can’t tolerate a possible consequence, remote though it may be, we steer clear of planting its seeds.

- 沃伦·巴菲特

- Warren Buffett

经验告诉我，未来将与过去相似。

Experience tells me that the future will be similar to the past.

它可能会也可能不会。我们不知道未来。如果错误的后果是可怕的并且会给我们带来巨大的伤害怎么办？如果决定很重要，我们应该在很大程度上忽略过去发生的事情，并关注错误的后果。

It may or may not. We don’t know the future. What if the consequences of being wrong are terrible and can cause us great harm? If the decision is important, we should largely ignore what has happened in the past and focus on the consequences of being wrong.

我们为什么要给房子投保？我们这样做是因为错误的后果——一场火灾——是毁灭性的，相比之下，保险成本相对较小。例如，1.000 美元的保费成本几乎不会降低我的幸福感，而 300,000 美元的潜在损失将导致相当大的痛苦。问：可能会出什么问题？如果伤害发生，我能做些什么来防止伤害或处理？

Why do we insure our houses? We do it because the consequences of being wrong — a fire — is devastating, and the cost of insurance is relatively minor in comparison. For example, the cost of a $ 1.000 premium decreases my happiness very little, while the potential loss of $300,000 would lead to considerable misery. Ask: What could go wrong? What can I do to prevent harm or to deal with it if it happens?

约翰想再买一家冰淇淋店。

John wants to buy another ice cream store.

他押注的关键变量是“单位数量将增加”。如果他错了会有什么后果？

The key variable he’s betting on is that"Unit volume will increase." What are the consequences if he is wrong?

错误的后果越严重，我们就越不愿意采取具体行动，或者我们需要更多的证据来支持某事。

The worse the consequence of being wrong, the less inclined we must be to take a specific action or the more evidence we need in favour of something.

问：与其他投资机会相比，错误的成本与正确的收益分别是多少？成本：约翰可能会损失金钱、名誉和精神压力。这也将使他的注意力从其他业务上移开。好处：有可能在一段时间内赚更多的钱。备选方案：更多时间专注于当前业务或其他机会。

Ask: What is the cost of being wrong versus the benefit of being right compared to other investment opportunities? Cost: John may lose money, reputation, and experience mental stress. It will also take his focus away from other business. Benefit: Possibility to make more money over a period of time. Alternative: More time to concentrate on the present business or other opportunities.

或者换句话说：如果我这样做是因为我打赌单位数量会增加，但我错了（由于需求减少、竞争加剧或环境不利，数量保持不变或减少）会有什么后果？我能应付他们吗？它们是可逆的吗？如果我不这样做是因为我打赌单位体积会下降或保持不变，但我错了，后果是什么？在哪种选择中我损失更少？

Or stated another way: If I do this because I bet that unit volume will increase but I’m wrong (volume remains the same or decreases due to less demand and more competition or unfavourable environment) what are the consequences? Can I handle them? Are they reversible? If I don’t do this because I bet that unit volume will go down or stay the same, but I’m wrong, what are the consequences? In which alternative do I lose less?

安全边际

Margin of safety

“我们努力安排[我们的事务]，这样无论

发生什么，我们都不必‘回去’。”

"We try to arrange [our affairs] so that no matter

what happens, we’ll never have to"go back to go."

- 查尔斯·芒格

- Charles Munger

阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦说：“无论谁承诺将自己定位为真理和知识的判断者，都会在众神的笑声中沉没。” 我们无法预测生活中会发生什么。永远不要低估罕见事件发生的可能性。

Albert Einstein said:"Whoever undertakes to set himself up as a judge of truth and knowledge is shipwrecked by the laughter of the gods." We can’t predict what is going to happen in life. Never underestimate the chance of rare events.

为了保护我们免受前方所有未知因素的影响，我们可以避免某些情况，做出适用于广泛结果的决定，有后备力量或巨大的安全边际。例如，在投资资金时，以下几点可以指导我们：了解潜在的商业价值，不要使用杠杆，进入管理层能干和诚实的情况，并在巨大的安全边际下进行投资。

To protect us from all the unknowns that lie ahead we can either avoid certain situations, make decisions that work out for a wide range of outcomes, have backups or a huge margin of safety. For example, when investing money the following can guide us: know the underlying business value, don’t use leverage, enter situations where the management is able and honest, and invest with a huge margin of safety.

我们需要多少安全边际？沃伦巴菲特回答：

How much margin of safety do we need? Warren Buffett answers:

如果你了解一家企业——如果你能完美地预见它的未来——那么，很明显，你几乎不需要安全边际。反之，可能发生的事情越多，不确定性就越大，企业就越脆弱或者改变的可能性就越大，你需要的安全边际就越大......

如果您驾驶一辆重达 9,800 磅的卡车穿过一座自称承载 10,000 磅的桥梁，而该桥仅离地面约六英寸，那么您可能会感觉还好。但是，如果这座桥横跨大峡谷，那么您可能需要更大一点的安全边际。因此，您只能驾驶 4,000 磅重的卡车穿越。因此，这取决于潜在风险的性质。

If you understand a business - if you can see its future perfectly - then, obviously, you need very little in the way of margin of safety. Conversely, the more things that can happen, the more uncertainty there is, the more vulnerable the business is or the greater the possibility of change, the larger margin of safety you require...

If you’re driving a 9,800 pound truck across a bridge that says it holds 10,000 pounds and the bridge is only about six inches above the ground, then you may feel OK. However, if the bridge is over the Grand Canyon, then you may want a little larger margin of safety. And, therefore, you may only drive a 4,000 pound truck across. So it depends on the nature of the underlying risk.

还有什么重要的？如果我们有正确的态度并遵循某些价值观，我们就有更好的机会避免误判和改善我们的生活。

What else is important? We have a better chance of avoiding misjudgement and improving our lives if we have the right attitude and follow certain values.

在作家珍妮特·洛 (Janet Lowe) 为查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 撰写的精彩传记中，我们可以从他的继子哈尔·博斯维克 (Hal Borthwick) 那里了解到查尔斯·芒格对价值观和行为的一些看法：

In writer Janet Lowe’s wonderful biography of Charles Munger, Damn Right!, we can learn some of Charles Munger’s views on values and behaviour from his stepson, Hal Borthwick:

查理鼓吹一个人应该永远“做你能做的最好的事情。永远不要说谎。如果你说你要去做，那就去做吧。没有人会在乎借口。离开吧早点开会。不要迟到，但如果你迟到了，也不要费心给别人找借口。只要道歉......迅速回电话。另一件事是五秒钟不。你必须让你的小心点。你不会让人们悬着的。”

Charlie drummed in the notion that a person should always"Do the best that you can do. Never tell a lie. If you say you’re going to do it, get it done. Nobody gives a shit about an excuse. Leave for the meeting early. Don’t be late, but if you are late, don’t bother giving people excuses. Just apologize...Return your calls quickly. The other thing is the five-second no. You’ve got to make your mind up. You don’t leave people hanging."

十二：态度

Twelve: Attitudes

活着的时候要快乐，因为你已经死了很久了。

Be happy while you’re living, for you are a long time dead.

- 苏格兰谚语

- Scottish proverb

如果我们知道如何使用它，生命就会很长

Life is long if we know how to use it

罗马哲学家 Lucius Annaeus Seneca 在他的道德散文中告诉我们，并不是我们的时间太少，而是我们浪费了太多时间：

The Roman philosopher Lucius Annaeus Seneca tells us in his Moral Essays that it’s not that we have so little time but that we waste much of it:

为什么我们抱怨大自然？她表现得很友善；生命，如果你知道如何使用它，就会很长。但是一个人被无法满足的贪婪所占据，另一个人则被一种对无用的任务的辛勤奉献所占据；一个人沉迷于酒，另一个人因懒惰而瘫痪；一个人因总是取决于他人决定的野心而精疲力竭，另一个人则被商人的贪婪所驱使，被获利的希望所驱使，走遍了所有的陆地和海洋……许多人要么忙于追求别人的财富或抱怨自己的财富；许多人没有固定的目标，变化无常，反复无常，心存不满，他们的反复无常使他们陷入了不断更新的计划中。有些人没有固定的原则来指导他们的课程，但是当他们懒洋洋地打哈欠时，命运却出其不意地抓住了他们——这肯定会发生，以至于我无法怀疑最伟大的诗人用所有的神谕来表达的那句话的真实性：“我们真正生活的生活部分很小。 “ 因为存在的所有其余部分都不是生命，而仅仅是时间。

Why do we complain of Nature? She has shown herself kindly; life, if you know how to use it, is long. But one man is possessed by an avarice that is insatiable, another by a toilsome devotion to tasks that are useless; one man is besotted with wine, another is paralyzed by sloth; one man is exhausted by an ambition that always hangs upon the decision of others, another, driven on by the greed of the trader, is led over all lands and all seas by the hope of gain...many are kept busy either in the pursuit of other men’s fortune or in complaining of their own; many, following no fixed aim, shifting and inconstant and dissatisfied, are plunged by their fickleness into plans that are ever new; some have no fixed principle by which to direct their course, but Fate takes them unawares while they loll and yawn - so surely does it happen that I cannot doubt the truth of that utterance which the greatest of poets delivered with all the seeming of an oracle:"The part of life we really live is small." For all the rest of existence is not life, but merely time.

他继续说道：“你的生活就好像你注定要永远活着，你的脑子里从来没有想过你的脆弱，你对已经过去了多少时间毫不在意。”：

He continues:"You live as if you were destined to live forever, no thought of your frailty ever enters your head, of how much time has already gone by you take no heed.":

你浪费时间，就好像你从充足的供应中抽取一样，尽管你给予某人或某物的那一天可能一直是你的最后一天。你有凡人的所有恐惧，也有所有的仙人之欲。你会听到许多人说：“五十岁之后我将退休，六十岁时我将不再担任公职。” 祈祷，你有什么保证你的生命会持续更长的时间？谁会容忍你的课程像你计划的那样？只为自己保留生命的残余，只为智慧留出不能用于任何事务的时间，你不感到羞耻吗？就在我们必须停止生活的时候开始生活有多晚！将健康的计划推迟到五十和六十年，是多么愚蠢的生死攸关的遗忘，

You squander time as if you drew from a full and abundant supply, though all the while that day which you bestow on some person or thing is perhaps your last. You have all the fears of mortals and all the desires of immortals. You will hear many men saying:"After my fiftieth year I shall retire into leisure, my sixtieth year shall release me from public duties." And what guarantee, pray, have you that your life will last longer? Who will suffer your course to be just as you plan it? Are you not ashamed to reserve for yourself only the remnant of life, and to set apart for wisdom only that time which cannot be devoted to any business? How late it is to begin to live just when we must cease to live! What foolish forgetfulness of mortality to postpone wholesome plans to the fiftieth and sixtieth year, and to intend to begin life at a point to which few have attained!

生命太短，不能浪费。塞缪尔约翰逊说：“重要的不是一个人如何死去，而是他如何活着。死亡的行为并不重要，它持续的时间太短了。”

Life is too short to waste. Samuel Johnson said:"It matters not how a man dies, but how he lives. The act of dying is not of importance, it lasts so short a time."

我们只有一个生命，所以我们应该努力创造我们喜欢的生活。喜剧演员乔治伯恩斯说：“你可以做你喜欢做的事，也可以热爱你所做的事。我认为没有其他选择。”

We only have one life so we should try to create a life we enjoy. Comedian George Burns said:"You can either do what you love or love what you do. I don’t see there’s any other choice."

我们每天都有 24 小时。我们不能节省时间，只能花在明智或愚蠢的地方。我们如何使用我们的时间？什么是最好的用途？我们想从生活中得到什么？我们的生活方式是否使这成为可能？列表越短，就越有可能专注于重要的事情。知道我们想要什么，不想要什么。我们是做我们想做的事，还是做别人希望我们做的事？谁或什么在我们的生活中最重要？我们有意义吗？

We all have 24 hours in the day. We can’t save time, only spend it wisely or foolishly. How do we use our time? What is the best use? What do we want out of life? Do we live in a way to make that possible? The shorter the list, the more likely it is to focus on things that matter. Know what we want and don’t want. Do we do what we want to do or what others expect us to do? Who or what is most important in our life? Do we have a sense of meaning?

避免错误判断和改善我们的生活的一部分是对生活有正确的态度。由于人是不同的，所以没有一刀切的策略。我们每个人都必须弄清楚自己的风格。但是有适用于我们所有人的准则。

Part of avoiding misjudgements and improving our lives is having the right attitude toward life. Since people are different, there is no one-size-fits-all strategy. We each must figure out our own style. But there are guidelines that apply to us all.

我们应该以符合我们的本性、优势和局限性的方式行事，我们应该建立（并遵循）一些价值观。

We should act in a way that agrees with our nature, advantages and limitations and we should establish (and follow) some values.

我们怎么能指望在一个我们不了解的领域取得成功呢？如果我们处理符合我们本性的事情，以及我们理解并做得很好的事情，我们就会减少犯错误的可能性。如果它们在我们的能力范围内，我们就有更好的机会解决问题和评估陈述。孔子说：“知之为知之，不知为不知，才是真知。” 我们必须确定我们的能力和局限性。我们需要知道我们不知道或不能知道的东西，并避开这些领域。正如沃伦巴菲特所说：

How can we expect to succeed in a field we don’t understand? We reduce the likelihood of making mistakes if we deal with things that agree with our nature, and things we understand and do well. We have a better chance solving problems and evaluating statements if they are within our area of competence. Confucius said:"To know that we know what we know, and that we do not know, what we do not know; that is true knowledge." We must determine our abilities and limitations. We need to know what we don’t know or are not capable of knowing and avoid those areas. As Warren Buffett says:

你必须坚持我所说的你的能力圈。你必须知道什么是你理解的，什么是你不理解的。圆有多大并不重要。但是知道周界在哪里是非常重要的。

You have to stick within what I call your circle of competence. You have to know what you understand and what you don’t understand. It’s not terribly important how big the circle is. But it’s terribly important that you know where the perimeter is.

查尔斯·芒格补充道：

Charles Munger adds:

我们宁愿处理我们所理解的。为什么我们要在一个我们没有优势（也许是劣势）的领域玩竞技游戏，而不是在我们有明显优势的领域玩？

你们每个人都必须弄清楚自己的才能在哪里。而且你必须利用你的优势。但如果你试图在你最不擅长的事情上取得成功，你的职业生涯将会非常糟糕。我几乎可以保证。否则，您将不得不购买中奖彩票或在其他地方获得非常幸运的机会。

We’d rather deal with what we understand. Why should we want to play a competitive game in a field where we have no advantage — maybe a disadvantage — instead of playing in a field where we have a clear advantage?

Each of you will have to figure out where your talents lie. And you’ll have to use your advantages. But if you try to succeed in what you’re worst at, you’re going to have a very louse career. I can almost guarantee it. To do otherwise, you’d have to buy a winning lottery ticket or get very lucky somewhere else.

问：我的本性是什么？是什么激励着我？我对痛苦和风险的容忍度是多少？过去是什么让我快乐和不快乐？我对哪些事和人感到舒服？我的天赋和技能是什么？我知道我想要什么和我擅长什么之间的区别吗？我比别人有什么优势？我的局限性是什么？

Ask: What is my nature? What motivates me? What is my tolerance for pain and risk? What has given me happiness and unhappiness in the past? What things and people am I comfortable with? What are my talents and skills? Do I know the difference between what I want and what I’m good at? Where do I have an edge over others? What are my limitations?

如果我们没有任何价值观，我们怎么能做重要的事情呢？如果我们不代表某事，我们就会爱上任何事。

How can we do what is important if we don’t have any values? If we don’t stand for something, we fall for anything.

说实话

Be honest

诚实是智慧书的第一章。

Honesty is the first chapter of the book of wisdom.

- 托马斯·杰斐逊

（美国总统 1743-1826）

- Thomas Jefferson

(American President 1743-1826)

举止光荣。听听马克吐温的话：“永远做对的事。这会让一些人满意，让其他人惊讶。”

Act honorably. Listen to the words of Mark Twain:"Always do right. This will gratify some people and astonish the rest."

说实话。遵循 Lou Vincenti 的规则（Wesco 前董事长）：“如果你说真话，你就不必记住你的谎言。”

Tell the truth. Follow Lou Vincenti’s rule (former Chairman of Wesco):"If you tell the truth you don’t have to remember your lies."

诚实付出。查尔斯·芒格说：“更多的时候，我们靠道德赚了额外的钱。本·富兰克林对我们来说是对的。他没有说诚实是最好的道德，他说这是最好的政策。”

Honesty pays. Charles Munger says:"More often we’ve made extra money out of morality. Ben Franklin was right for us. He didn’t say honesty was the best morals, he said that it was the best policy."

以诚信和个性行事。赫拉克利特说：“你性格的内容是你的选择。日复一日，你所选择的、你所想的、你所做的，就是你成为的人。你的正直是你的命运……它是指引你前进道路的明灯”

Act with integrity and individuality. Heraclitus said:"The content of your character is your choice. Day by day, what you choose, what you think, and what you do is who you become. Your integrity is your destiny...it is the light that guides your way."

每个人都是独一无二的，所以我们有权与众不同。为什么诚信才是真正的自由？因为如果我们没有什么可隐瞒的，我们就没有什么好害怕的。

Every human being is unique so we have the right to be different. Why is integrity the real freedom? Because if we have nothing to hide we have nothing to fear.

查尔斯芒格说：

Charles Munger says:

我们认为，在……您愿意做的事情和您可以做的事情之间应该有很大的差距，而不会遭受刑事处罚或造成损失的重大风险。我们相信你不应该靠近那条线。你应该有一个内部指南针。所以应该有各种各样的事情你不会做，即使它们是完全合法的。这就是我们尝试运作的方式。

We think there should be a huge area between ... what you are willing to do and what you can do without a significant risk of suffering criminal penalty or causing losses. We believe you shouldn’t go anywhere near that line. You ought to have an internal compass. So there should be all kinds of things you won’t do even though they’re perfectly legal. That’s the way we try to operate.

远离任何有问题的事情，与尊贵的人打交道。使用沃伦巴菲特的“头版测试”：“我是否愿意看到我的行为立即被一位消息灵通且持批评态度的记者描述在我当地报纸的头版上，供我的配偶、孩子和朋友阅读？”

Stay out of anything questionable and deal with honorable people. Use the Warren Buffett"front-page test:""Would I be willing to see my action immediately described by an informed and critical reporter on the front page of my local paper, there to be read by my spouse, children and friends?"

相信人是有效率的。查尔斯·芒格说：“好性格非常有效率。如果你能信任别人，你的系统就会简单得多。好性格会带来 巨大的效率，坏性格会降低效率。”

Trusting people is efficient. Charles Munger says:"Good character is very efficient. If you can trust people, your systems can be way simpler. There’s enormous efficiency in good character and dis-efficiency in bad character."

以身作则

Act as an exemplar

财富对于知道如何使用它的人来说是一种祝福，对于那些不知道如何使用它的人来说是一种诅咒。

Wealth is a blessing to those who know how to use it, a curse to those who don’t.

- 普布利乌斯·特伦蒂乌斯

- Publius Terentius

观察你发出的信号。查尔斯·芒格告诉我们，有些人有责任塑造正确的形象：“一个在军队中地位高的人或成为最高法院法官的人都应该成为榜样，那么为什么在一个大职位上地位不高的人不应该成为榜样呢？公司作为榜样？”

Observe what signals you send out. Charles Munger tells us that some people have a duty to create the right appearance:"A person who rises high in the Army or becomes a Supreme Court justice is expected to be an exemplar, so why shouldn’t someone who rises high in a big corporation act as an exemplar?"

他继续：

He continues:

你不希望你的一年级老师在地板上淫乱或在教室里喝酒。同样，我认为您不希望您的证券交易所因为其可悲的过剩而成为头条新闻。而且我当然不认为你想把这个国家的主要证券交易所变成比现在更像一个赌场。

You don’t want your first grade teacher to be fornicating on the floor or drinking booze in the classroom. Similarly, I don’t think you want your stock exchange to be all over the headlines because of its wretched excess. And I certainly don’t think that you want to turn the country’s major stock exchange into even more of a casino than it is already.

军方有正确的模式。芒格继续说道：

The military has the right model. Munger continues:

其中一件被严重忽视的事情是这样的概念，即军事等价物的行为不符合军官的标准。当你在一个文明中上升到一定程度时，你应该有责任以身作则。你最后一次在董事会听到“这符合我们作为榜样的职责吗？”是什么时候？我的意思是，这个词本身就带有古色古香的韵味——“典范”。但这正是可怕的缺乏。

每个人都可以看到这是必需的。军官不当行为的军事概念是一个重要的概念。你的责任是不要引起怨恨和嫉妒以及许多其他事情。作为榜样，你肩负着重大责任。”

One of the things that’s been horribly underdone is the concept where the military equivalent is conduct unbecoming an officer. When you rise to a certain point in a civilization, you ought to have a duty to behave as an exemplar. When is the last time you heard in a boardroom, ‘Is this consistent with our duties as exemplars?’ I mean the very word has an antique ring to it — ‘exemplar’. But that’s exactly what is horribly lacking.

And everybody can see that that’s what’s required. The military concept of conduct unbecoming an officer is an important one. Your duty is to not cause resentment and envy and a lot of other things. You have a big duty as an exemplar."

我们如何教导道德？查尔斯芒格说：

How can we teach ethics? Charles Munger says:

我认为教授道德的最好方法就是以身作则。这意味着如果你接纳那些在所有日常行为中都表现出适当道德框架的人，我认为这会对观看它的人产生巨大影响。相反，如果你的道德下滑，如果人们因道德下滑而受到奖励，那么我认为你的道德会以非常非常快的速度下降。

我认为道德非常重要，但我认为最好以身作则来间接教授道德。如果你只是学习一些规则并记住它们足以通过考试，我的猜测是它对人们的道德没有多大帮助。但是如果你看到你敬佩的人以某种方式行事——尤其是在压力下——1 认为你可能会记住并受其影响很长很长一段时间。

I think the best single way to teach ethics is by example. And that means if you take in people who demonstrate in all their daily conduct an appropriate ethical framework, I think that has enormous influence on the people who watch it. Conversely, if your ethics slip, and if people are being rewarded for ethical slips, then I think your ethics cascade downward at a very, very rapid rate.

I think ethics are terribly important, but I think they’re best taught indirectly by example. If you just sort of learn a few rules and remember 'em well enough to pass a test, my guess is it doesn’t do all that much for people’s ethics. But if you see people you admire behaving a certain way - particularly under stress -1 think you’re likely to remember and be affected by that for a long, long time.

公平待人

Treat people fairly

沃伦巴菲特说：“被爱的唯一方式就是被爱。你得到的总是比你付出的多。如果你不付出任何东西，你就不会得到任何东西。” 老子说：“即使对不明智的对待也要做出明智的反应。” 对人友善，如果他们对你不好——不要刻薄——以后就避开他们。遵循查尔斯·达尔文的建议——避免争议：

Warren Buffett says that:"The only way to be loved is to be lovable. You always get back more than you give away. If you don’t give any you won’t get any." Lao-Tsu said:"Respond intelligently even to unintelligent treatment." Be nice to people and if they are not nice to you — don’t be nasty — just avoid them in the future. Follow the advice of Charles Darwin — avoid controversies:

我很高兴我避免了争论，这要归功于 Lyell，多年前，他在提到我的地质工作时，强烈建议我永远不要卷入争论，因为这很少有任何好处，而且会造成可悲的损失时间和脾气...

我所认为的是，你 [给 E. Haeckel 的信] 会激起愤怒，而这种愤怒完全蒙蔽了每个人的双眼，以至于你的论点没有机会影响那些已经反对我们观点的人。

I rejoice that I have avoided controversies, and this I owe to Lyell, who many years ago, in reference to my geological works, strongly advised me never to get entangled in a controversy, as it rarely did any good and caused a miserable loss of time and temper...

All that I think is that you [letter to E. Haeckel] will excite anger, and that anger so completely blinds every one that your arguments would have no chance of influencing those who are already opposed to our views.

不要把生活看得太认真

Don’t take life too seriously

生命太重要了，不能认真对待。

Life is too important to be taken seriously.

- 奥斯卡·王尔德

- Oscar Wilde

有远见。记住塞缪尔约翰逊的话：“距离对心灵的影响与对眼睛的影响相同。” 当我们失败时，我们应该将其视为一种学习经验。

Have perspective. Remember Samuel Johnson’s words:"Distance has the same effect on the mind as on the eye." When we fail we should view it as a learning experience.

有一个积极的态度。梅奥诊所的研究人员报告说，乐观者比悲观者报告的身心功能水平更高。梅奥诊所的研究还表明，乐观者比悲观者活得更长。拥有积极的态度也会使身体产生一种叫做内啡肽的镇痛激素，其作用类似于吗啡。

Have a positive attitude. Mayo Clinic researchers report that optimists report a higher level of physical and mental functioning than pessimists. Studies at the Mayo Clinic also show that optimists live longer than pessimists. Having a positive attitude also causes the body to produce pain-suppressing hormones, called endorphins, which work like morphine.

沃伦巴菲特谈到热情的价值时说：

Warren Buffett says on the value of enthusiasm:

我确实认为热情通常是一种很好的品质。它帮助了我……我喜欢我们企业中充满热情的经理。这些人对他们的工作充满热情，就像人们对高尔夫充满热情一样，这会转化为成果。如果你从事的是一份你不热衷的工作，那就找点别的。你对自己没有任何好处，对你的雇主也没有任何好处，无论如何你都会在某个时候做出改变。我们在地球上只有一次，除非雪莉麦克雷恩是对的，所以你应该做一些你喜欢的事情，并且可以热衷于此。

I do think enthusiasm is a good quality to have generally. It has helped me... I like managers in our businesses that are enthusiastic. These people are enthusiastic about their work in the same way people can get enthusiastic about golf, and that translates into results. If you are in a job that you are not enthusiastic about, find something else. You’re not doing yourself any favour, and you’re not doing your employer any favour and you’re going to make a change anyway at some point. We’re here on earth only one time, unless Shirley MacLaine is right, so you ought to be doing something that you enjoy as you go along, and can be enthusiastic about.

他还说我们应该做我们喜欢做的事：“做让你兴奋的事情。做一些如果你拥有世界上所有的钱，你仍然会做的事情。你必须有一个跳出来的理由早上睡觉……不要找钱。找你喜欢的东西，如果你做得好，钱就会来。”

He also says that we should do what we enjoy:"Do what turns you on. Do something that if you had all the money in the world, you’d still be doing it. You’ve got to have a reason to jump out of bed in the morning... Don’t look for the money. Look for something you love, and if you’re good, the money will come."

有合理的期望

Have reasonable expectations

不抱任何期望的人是有福的，因为他永远不会失望。

Blessed is he that expects nothing, for he shall never be disappointed.

- 本杰明·富兰克林

- Benjamin Franklin

如果我们不抱太大希望，现实往往会出乎我们的意料。如果我们总是期望最好的或有不切实际的期望，我们常常会感到失望。我们感觉更糟，做出错误的判断。

If we don’t hope for much, reality often beats our expectations. If we always expect the best or have unreal expectations, we are often disappointed. We feel worse and make bad judgements.

期待逆境。无论我们在生活中选择做什么，都会遇到逆境。查尔斯·芒格 (Charles Munger) 给出了他的人生铁剂处方：

Expect adversity. We encounter adversity in whatever we choose to do in life. Charles Munger gives his iron prescription for life:

每当你认为某些情况或某人正在毁掉你的生活时，实际上是你在毁掉你的生活……感觉自己是受害者是一种完全灾难性的生活方式。如果你只是抱着这样的态度，不管它有多么糟糕，它总是你的错，你只要尽力解决它——所谓的“铁处方”——我认为这确实有效。

Whenever you think that some situation or some person is ruining your life, it is actually you who are ruining your life...Feeling like a victim is a perfectly disastrous way to go through life.
