If you just take the attitude that however bad it is in any way, it’s always your fault and you just fix it as best you can — the so-called"iron prescription" - I think that really works.

当坏事发生时，问：这还有什么意思？将生活中的障碍视为暂时的挫折，而不是灾难。马克·吐温说：[我们的]种族，在其贫困中，毫无疑问拥有一种真正有效的武器——笑声……没有什么能抵挡笑声的攻击。

When bad things happen, ask: What else does this mean? See life’s obstacles as temporary setbacks, not disasters. Mark Twain says:"[Our] race, in its poverty, has unquestionably one really effective weapon - laughter.. .Against the assault of laughter nothing can stand."

活在当下

Live in the present

君子不浪费自己在遥远的事物上，在不存在的事物上。他站在此时此地，在真实的情况下。

The superior man does not waste himself on what is distant, on what is absent. He stands in the here and now, in the real situation.

——孔子

- Confucius

我们往往过于强调目的地，而错过了旅程。活在当下，享受今天的生活。布莱斯帕斯卡写道：

Often we tend to emphasize the destination so much that we miss the journey. Stay in the present and enjoy life today. Blaise Pascal wrote:

让我们每个人检查一下自己的想法；他会发现他们完全关心过去或未来。我们几乎从不考虑现在，如果我们考虑它，也只是为了看看它对我们未来的计划有何启示。现在永远不是我们的终点。过去和现在是我们的手段，只有未来才是我们的目的。因此，我们从来没有真正生活过，而是希望生活，而且由于我们总是在计划如何快乐，所以我们永远不应该快乐是不可避免的。

Let each of us examine his thoughts; he will find them wholly concerned with the past or the future. We almost never think of the present, and if we do think of it, it is only to see what light it throws on our plans for the future. The present is never our end. The past and the present are our means, the future alone our end. Thus we never actually live, but hope to live, and since we are always planning how to be happy, it is inevitable that we should never be so.

保持好奇心和开放的心态。总是问“为什么”

Be curious and open-minded. Always ask"why"

好奇心是充满活力的头脑的永久和某些特征之一。

Curiosity is one of the permanent and certain characteristics of a vigorous mind.

- 塞缪尔约翰逊

- Samuel Johnson

托马斯·亨利·赫胥黎说：“像孩子一样在事实面前坐下，准备好放弃每一个先入为主的观念，谦虚地跟随自然引向的任何地方和任何深渊，否则你将一无所获。” 一个孩子很好奇，问“为什么？” 作为成年人，我们似乎忘记了“为什么”而接受别人说的话。我们都应该再次成为孩子，就像通过一个没有成见的好奇孩子的眼睛一样看世界。

Thomas Henry Huxley said:"Sit down before facts like a child, and be prepared to give up every preconceived Notion, follow humbly wherever and to whatever abysses Nature leads, or you shall learn nothing." A child is curious and asks "why?" As grown-ups we seem to forget the"whys" and accept what others say. We should all be children again and see the world as if through the eyes of a curious child without preconceptions.

结束

The End

我承认我一直像鼹鼠一样盲目，但晚学智慧总比不学好。

I confess that I have been as blind as a mole, but it is better to learn wisdom late than never to learn it at all.

- 夏洛克福尔摩斯

（亚瑟柯南道尔，扭曲嘴唇的男人）

- Sherlock Holmes

(Arthur Conan Doyle, The Man with the Twisted Lip)

我希望这本书有助于理解和提高你的思维。我也希望你能继续寻找智慧。我们仍然会做出错误判断（至少我仍然会这样做），但我们可以改进。

I hope this book is helpful in both understanding and improving your thinking. I also hope that you will continue in your search for wisdom. We are still going to make misjudgements (at least I still do them), but we can improve.

附录

Appendix

附录一 - Charles T. Munger 哈佛大学

毕业典礼演讲

- 1986 年 6 月 13 日

Appendix One - Charles T. Munger Harvard School

Commencement Speech

- June 13, 1986

保证生活中痛苦的处方

Prescriptions for Guaranteed Misery in Life

既然 Berrisford 校长已经选择了一位年龄最大、服务时间最长的受托人来发表毕业典礼演讲，演讲者有必要在每个人心目中解决两个问题：

Now that Headmaster Berrisford has selected one of the oldest and longest-serving trustees to make a commencement speech, it behooves the speaker to address two questions in every mind:

  1. 为什么做出这样的选择？和，
  2. Why was such a selection made? and,
  3. 演讲要持续多长时间？
  4. How long is the speech going to last?

我将根据与 Berrisford 一起的长期经验来回答第一个问题。他正以自豪地展示他能数到七的马的人的方式为我们学校寻求更高的声誉。这个人知道数到七算不上什么数学上的壮举，但考虑到表演者是一匹马，他希望得到认可，因为这样做值得称赞。

I will answer the first question from long experience alongside Berrisford. He is seeking enhanced reputation for our school in the manner of the man who proudly displays his horse which can count to seven. The man knows that counting to seven is not much of a mathematical feat but he expects approval because doing so is creditable, considering that the performer is a horse.

第二个问题，关于发言的长度，我不提前回答。它会让你仰起的脸上失去活泼的好奇心和明显的热切期待，而我宁愿保留这些，不管来源如何。

The second question, regarding length of speech, I am not going to answer in advance. It would deprive your upturned faces of lively curiosity and obvious keen anticipation, which I prefer to retain, regardless of source.

但我会告诉你我对演讲长度的考虑是如何创造演讲本身的主题的。当被邀请发言时，我很自负。虽然没有重要的公开演讲经验，但我确实拥有大胆的黑带，而且，我立即将 Demosthenes 和 Cicero 视为榜样，并期待着像 Cicero 在被问及他最喜欢 Demosthenes 的演讲中哪一个时给予的赞美。西塞罗回答说：“最长的一个。”

But I will tell you how my consideration of speech length created the subject matter of the speech itself. I was puffed up when invited to speak. While not having significant public speaking experience, I do hold a black belt in chutzpah, and, I immediately considered Demosthenes and Cicero as role models and anticipated trying to earn a compliment like Cicero gave when asked which was his favourite among the orations of Demosthenes. Cicero replied:"The longest one."

然而，对于这些听众来说幸运的是，我还想到了塞缪尔约翰逊在谈到弥尔顿的诗《失乐园》时的著名评论，他正确地说：“没有人希望它更长。” 这让我开始思考，在我听过的所有 20 场哈佛毕业演讲中，我希望听得更久一些。只有一次这样的演讲，由约翰尼·卡森 (Johnny Carson) 发表，详细说明了卡森为保证生活中的苦难开出的处方。因此，我决定重复卡森的演讲，但以扩展的形式加上我自己的一些额外建议。

However, fortunately for this audience, I also thought of Samuel Johnsons famous comment when he addressed Miltons poem, Paradise Lost, and correctly said:"No one ever wished it longer." And that made me consider which of all the twenty Harvard School graduation speeches I had heard that I wished longer. There was only one such speech, that given by Johnny Carson, specifying Carsons prescriptions for guaranteed misery in life. I therefore decided to repeat Carson’s speech but in expanded form with some added prescriptions of my own.

毕竟，我比卡森说话时年长得多，而且比年轻时说话的迷人幽默家更频繁地失败和痛苦更多，方式更多。我显然有资格扩展卡森的主题。

After all, I am much older than Carson was when he spoke and have failed and been miserable more often and in more ways than was possible for a charming humorist speaking at younger age. I am plainly well-qualified to expand on Carson’s theme.

卡森所说的是，他无法告诉毕业班的人如何快乐，但他可以从亲身经历告诉他们如何保证痛苦。卡森对确定的痛苦的处方包括：

What Carson said was that he couldn’t tell the graduating class how to be happy, but he could tell them from personal experience how to guarantee misery. Carson’s prescriptions for sure misery included:

  1. 摄入化学品以改变情绪或感知；
  2. Ingesting chemicals in an effort to alter mood or perception;
  3. 嫉妒; 和
  4. Envy; and
  5. 怨恨。
  6. Resentment.

我仍然记得卡森在讲述他如何一次又一次地尝试这些事情并且每次都变得痛苦时的绝对信念。

I can still recall Carson’s absolute conviction as he told how he had tried these things on occasion after occasion and had become miserable every time.

很容易理解卡森的第一个治疗痛苦的处方——摄入化学物质。我加上我的声音。我年轻时最亲密的四个朋友都是非常聪明、有道德、幽默的类型，在个人和背景上都受到青睐。两个人早就死了，酒精是一个促成因素，第三个是活着的酒鬼——如果你称之为活着的话。虽然易感性各不相同，但通过一个微妙的过程，我们任何人都可能会上瘾，在这个过程中，退化的纽带太轻而无法感觉到，直到它们太强而无法被打破。我还没有遇到过任何人，在六年多的生命中，他们的生活因过度恐惧和过度避免这种欺骗性的破坏途径而恶化。

It is easy to understand Carson’s first prescription for misery - ingesting chemicals. I add my voice. The four closest friends of my youth were highly intelligent, ethical, humorous types, favoured in person and background. Two are long dead, with alcohol a contributing factor, and a third is a living alcoholic - if you call that living. While susceptibility varies, addiction can happen to any of us, through a subtle process where the bonds of degradation are too light to be felt until they are too strong to be broken. And I have yet to meet anyone, in over six decades of life, whose life was worsened by overfear and overavoidance of such a deceptive pathway to destruction.

当然，嫉妒与化学物质一起为造成苦难赢得某种数量价格。早在它在摩西律法中受到负面报道之前，它就已经造成了严重破坏。如果你想保留嫉妒对苦难的贡献，我建议你永远不要阅读那个善良的基督徒塞缪尔约翰逊的任何传记，因为他的生活以一种诱人的方式展示了超越嫉妒的可能性和优势。

Envy, of course, joins chemicals in winning some sort of quantity price for causing misery. It was wreaking havoc long before it got a bad press in the laws of Moses. If you wish to retain the contribution of envy to misery, I recommend that you never read any of the biographies of that good Christian, Samuel Johnson, because his life demonstrates in an enticing way the possibility and advantage of transcending envy.

怨恨一直对我有用，就像对卡森一样。如果你想要痛苦，我怎么推荐都不为过。约翰逊说得好，他说生活是难以忍受的，如果不压在怨恨的苦果里的话。

Resentment has always worked for me exactly as it worked for Carson. I cannot recommend it highly enough to you if you desire misery. Johnson spoke well when he said that life is hard enough to swallow without squeezing in the bitter rind of resentment.

对于那些想要痛苦的人，我还建议不要采取迪斯雷利妥协的做法，该妥协专为那些发现无法摆脱怨恨冷火鸡的人而设计。迪斯雷利在成为最伟大的总理之一后，学会了放弃报复作为行动的动力，但他确实保留了一些发泄怨恨的渠道，他把冤枉他的人的名字写在抽屉里的纸片上。然后，他时不时地回顾一下这些名字，并乐于注意到这个世界是如何在没有他帮助的情况下打倒他的敌人的。

For those of you who want misery, I also recommend refraining from practice of the Disraeli compromise, designed for people who find it impossible to quit resentment cold turkey. Disraeli, as he rose to become one of the greatest Prime Ministers, learned to give up vengeance as a motivation for action, but he did retain some outlet for resentment by putting the names of people who wronged him on pieces of paper in a drawer. Then, from time to time, he reviewed these names and took pleasure in noting the way the world had taken his enemies down without his assistance.

好吧，卡森的三个处方到此为止。以下是芒格的另外四种处方：

Well, so much for Carson’s three prescriptions. Here are four more prescriptions from Munger:

第一，不可靠。不要忠实地做你约定要做的事。如果你只掌握这一个习惯，你将远远抵消你所有美德的综合影响，无论这些美德多么伟大。如果你喜欢被不信任和排斥在最好的人类贡献和公司之外，这个药方适合你。掌握了这一个习惯，你就可以一直扮演寓言中的兔子的角色，只不过你不会被一只漂亮的乌龟跑得过，而是会被成群结队的平庸的乌龟，甚至是一些拄着拐杖的平庸的乌龟跑得过。

First, be unreliable. Do not faithfully do what you have engaged to do. If you will only master this one habit you will more than counterbalance the combined effect of all your virtues, howsoever great. If you like being distrusted and excluded from the best human contribution and company, this prescription is for you. Master this one habit and you can always play the role of the hare in the fable, except that instead of being outrun by one fine turtle you will be outrun by hordes and hordes of mediocre turtles and even by some mediocre turtles on crutches.

我必须警告你，如果你不遵循我的第一个处方，即使你一开始处于不利地位，也可能很难以悲惨的结局告终。我在大学里有一个室友，他曾经有过严重的阅读障碍。但他也许是我所认识的最可靠的人。到目前为止，他过着美好的生活，出色的妻子和孩子，一家价值数十亿美元的公司的首席执行官。如果你想避免这种传统的、主流文化的、建立的结果，如果你坚持可靠，你就不能指望你的其他障碍会阻止你。

I must warn you that if you don’t follow my first prescription it may be hard to end up miserable, even if you start disadvantaged. I had a roommate in college who was and is severely dyslexic. But he is perhaps the most reliable man I have ever known. He has had a wonderful life so far, outstanding wife and children, chief executive of a multibillion dollar corporation. If you want to avoid a conventional, main-culture, establishment result of this kind, you simply can’t count on your other handicaps to hold you back if you persist in being reliable.

在这里，我不能不提及被描述为“迄今为止美好”的生活，而不通过重复曾经是世界上最富有的国王克洛伊索斯的话来强化人类状况的“到目前为止”方面。后来，在可耻的囚禁中，当他准备被活活烧死时，他说：“现在我想起了历史学家梭伦的话：“没有人的生命应该被认为是幸福的，直到它结束。

I cannot here pass by a reference to a life described as"wonderful so far," without reinforcing the"so far" aspects of the human condition by repeating the remark of Croesus, once the richest king in the world. Later, in ignominious captivity, as he prepared to be burned alive, he said:"Well now do I remember the words of the historian Solon:"No man’s life should be accounted a happy one until it is over."

我对痛苦的第二个处方是从你自己的个人经历中学习你可能学到的一切，尽量减少你从他人的好坏经历中间接学到的东西，无论是生的还是死的。这个药方肯定会导致痛苦和二流成就。

My Second prescription for misery is to learn everything you possibly can from your own personal experience, minimizing what you learn vicariously from the good and bad experience of others, living and dead. This prescription is a sure-shot producer of misery and second-rate achievement.

只要环顾四周，您就能看到不从别人的错误中吸取教训的后果。人类共同的灾难——酒驾致死、鲁莽驾驶致残、无法治愈的性病、聪明的大学生变成被洗脑的僵尸成为破坏性邪教的成员、因重复前人犯下的明显错误而导致的企业失败、各种人群愚蠢的形式，等等。我推荐现代谚语作为记忆线索，从粗心大意的非原创错误中找到解决真正麻烦的方法：“如果一开始你没有成功，那么滑翔就到此为止了。”

You can see the results of not learning from others’ mistakes by simply looking about you. How little originality there is in the common disasters of mankind - drunk driving deaths, reckless driving maimings, incurable venereal diseases, conversion of bright college students into brainwashed zombies as members of destructive cults, business failures through repetition of obvious mistakes made by predecessors, various forms of crowd folly, and so on. I recommend as a memory clue to finding the way to real trouble from heedless, unoriginal error the modern saying:"If at first you don’t succeed, well, so much for hang gliding."

避免替代智慧的另一个方面是不从你之前完成的最好的工作中学习的规则。处方是尽可能地没有受过教育。

The other aspect of avoiding vicarious wisdom is the rule for not learning from the best work done before yours. The prescription is to become as non-educated as you reasonable can.

如果我提供一个简短的历史记录，也许你会更好地看到你可以避免的那种不悲惨的结果。曾经有一个人孜孜不倦地掌握了他最好的前辈们的工作，尽管在解析几何方面起步不佳且经历了非常艰难的时期。最终他自己的原创作品引起了广泛关注，他谈到那部作品时说：

Perhaps you will better see the type of non-miserable result you can thus avoid if I render a short historical account. There once was a man who assiduously mastered the work of his best predecessors, despite a poor start and very tough time in analytic geometry. Eventually his own original work attracted wide attention and he said of that work:

“如果我比别人看得更远一点，那是因为我站在巨人的肩膀上。”

"If I have seen a little farther than other men it is because I stood on the shoulders of giants."

那个人的骸骨现在埋葬在威斯敏斯特教堂，上面刻着一段不同寻常的铭文：

The bones of that man lie buried now, in Westminster Abbey, under an unusual inscription:

“这里埋葬着艾萨克·牛顿爵士所有凡人的遗骸。”

"Here lie the remains of all that was mortal in Sir Isaac Newton."

我对痛苦的第三个处方是当你在人生的战斗中遇到第一次、第二次或第三次严重的挫折时，要低头并保持低调。因为世上有那么多的逆境，即使是幸运的和聪明的，这也保证了你会在适当的时候永远陷入痛苦的泥潭。不惜一切代价忽略埃比克图斯为自己写的准确墓志铭中包含的教训：“这里躺着埃比克图斯，一个奴隶，身体残废，极度贫困，并受到众神的宠爱。”

My Third prescription for misery is to go down and stay down when you get your first, second, or third severe reverse in the battle of life. Because there is so much adversity out there, even for the lucky and wise, this will guarantee that, in due course, you will be permanently mired in misery. Ignore at all cost the lesson contained in the accurate epitaph written for himself by Epicetus:"Here lies Epicetus, a slave, maimed in body, the ultimate in poverty, and favoured by the Gods."

我给你的最后一个处方是，不要理会我小时候他们告诉我的一个关于一个乡下人的故事，他说：“我希望我知道我将死在哪里，然后我永远不会去那里。” 大多数人（就像你一样）对乡下人的无知微笑，而忽略了他的基本智慧。如果我的经验有任何指导意义，那么一心想受苦的人应该不惜一切代价避免这种乡下人的做法。为了帮助失败，你应该将乡下人的方法视为纯粹的怪癖，没有任何有用的信息，这与卡森演讲中使用的方法相同。

My Final prescription to you for a life of fuzzy thinking and infelicity is to ignore a story they told me when I was very young about a rustic who said:"I wish I knew where I was going to die, and then I’d never go there." Most people smile (as you did) at the rustic’s ignorance and ignore his basic wisdom. If my experience is any guide, the rustic’s approach is to be avoided at all cost by someone bent on misery. To help fail you should discount as mere quirk, with no useful message, the method of the rustic, which is the same one used in Carson’s speech.

卡森所做的是通过将问题倒过来来研究如何创建 X，即通过研究如何创建非 X。伟大的代数学家雅各比采用与卡森完全相同的方法，并以不断重复一句话而闻名：“反转，永远反转。” 正如雅各比所知，事物的本质是许多难题只有在向后解决时才能得到最好的解决。例如，当几乎所有人都试图修改麦克斯韦的电磁定律以使其与牛顿的运动定律一致时，爱因斯坦发现了狭义相对论，他进行了 180 度大转弯并修改了牛顿定律以适应麦克斯韦定律。

What Carson did was to approach the study of how to create X by turning the question backward, that is, by studying how to create non-X. The great algebraist, Jacobi, had exactly the same approach as Carson and was known for his constant repetition of one phrase: "Invert, always invert." It is in the nature of things, as Jacobi knew, that many hard problems are best solved only when they are addressed backward. For instance, when almost everyone else was trying to revise the electromagnetic laws of Maxwell to be consistent with the motion laws of Newton, Einstein discovered special relativity as he made a 180 degree turn and revised Newton’s laws to fit Maxwell’s.

我认为，作为一个经过认证的传记迷，查尔斯·罗伯特·达尔文在 1986 年哈佛大学毕业班中的排名应该接近中游。但他现在在科学史上很有名。如果你一心想把你自己的捐赠的结果降到最低，你就应该从这类型的例子中学到任何东西。

It is my opinion, as a certified biography nut, that Charles Robert Darwin would have ranked near the middle of the Harvard School graduating class of 1986. Yet he is now famous in the history of science. This is precisely the type of example you should learn nothing from if bent on minimizing your results from your own endowment.

达尔文的结果在很大程度上归功于他的工作方法，这违反了我关于苦难的所有规则，并特别强调了一种向后的扭曲，因为他总是优先关注那些倾向于否定他已经拥有的任何珍贵和来之不易的理论的证据。相比之下，大多数人很早就形成并在后来强化了一种处理新的和不确定的信息的倾向，因此任何原始结论都保持不变。他们成为了菲利普·怀利 (Philip Wylie) 观察到的人：“你无法在他们已经知道的和他们永远不会学到的东西之间挤出一毛钱。”

Darwin’s result was due in large measure to his working method, which violated all my rules for misery and particularly emphasized a backward twist in that he always gave priority attention to evidence tending to disconfirm whatever cherished and hard-won theory he already had. In contrast, most people early achieve and later intensify a tendency to process new and disconfirming information so that any original conclusion remains intact. They become people of whom Philip Wylie observed:" You couldn’t squeeze a dime between what they already know and what they will never learn."

达尔文的一生展示了乌龟如何在极端客观性的帮助下跑得比野兔快，这有助于客观的人最终成为钉驴游戏中唯一没有蒙住眼睛的玩家。

The life of Darwin demonstrates how a turtle may outrun the hares, aided by extreme objectivity, which helps the objective person end up like the only player without blindfold in a game of pin-the-donkey.

如果你最小化客观性，你不仅会忽视达尔文的教训，也会忽视爱因斯坦的教训。爱因斯坦说他成功的理论来自于：“好奇心、专注力、毅力和自我批评。而自我批评他的意思是检验和摧毁他自己深受喜爱的想法。

If you minimize objectivity, you ignore not only a lesson from Darwin but also one from Einstein. Einstein said that his successful theories came from:"Curiosity, concentration, perseverance and self-criticism. And by self-criticism he meant the testing and destruction of his own well-loved ideas.

最后，尽量减少客观性将帮助您减轻拥有世俗物品的妥协和负担，因为客观性不仅仅适用于伟大的物理学家和生物学家。它还为伯米吉的管道承包商的工作增加了动力。因此，如果你将忠于自己理解为要求你保留你年轻时的每一个想法，那么你将安全地进行，不仅是为了最大限度地无知，而且是为了通过不愉快的商业经历获得的任何痛苦。

Finally, minimizing objectivity will help you lessen the compromises and burdens of owning worldly goods, because objectivity does not work only for great physicists and biologists. It also adds power to the work of a plumbing contractor in Bemidji. Therefore, if you interpret being true to yourself as requiring that you retain every notion of your youth you will be safely underway, not only toward maximizing ignorance, but also toward whatever misery can be obtained through unpleasant experiences in business.

现在，一种落后的演讲以一种落后的祝酒词结束是很合适的，灵感来自 Elihu Root 反复讲述狗是如何去多佛的，“leg over leg”。致 1986 级：

It is fitting now that a backward sort of speech end with a backward sort of toast, inspired by Elihu Root’s repeated accounts of how the dog went to Dover,"leg over leg." To the class of 1986:

先生们，愿你们每个人在漫长的人生中每一天都以低调为目标，从而高升。

Gentlemen, may each of you rise high by spending each day of a long life aiming low.

附录二：查尔斯·T·芒格和沃伦·E·巴菲特的智慧

Appendix Two: Wisdom from Charles T. Munger and Warren E. Buffett

关于如何改变人

On how to change people

假设您有一位真正想要进行税务欺诈的客户。如果他不把税法推到底线之外，他就受不了。如果他认为有任何他没有做过的作弊行为，他就不能在早上刮胡子。还有这样的人。他们只是觉得自己的生活不够积极。

Suppose you’ve got a client who really wants to commit tax fraud. If he doesn’t push the tax law away beyond the line, he can’t stand it. He can’t shave in the morning if he thinks there’s been any cheating he could get by with that he hasn’t done. And there are people like that. They just feel they aren’t living aggressively enough.

你可以通过以下两种方式中的任何一种来处理这种情况：(A) 你可以说，“我不会为他工作”，然后回避它。或者，(B) 你可以说，“嗯，我的生活环境要求我为他工作。我为他做的事情不涉及我的作弊。因此，我会做的。”

You can approach that situation in either of two ways: (A) you can say,"I just won’t work for him," and duck it. Or, (B) you can say,"Well, the circumstances of my life require that I work for him. And what I’m doing for him doesn’t involve my cheating. Therefore, I’ll do it."

如果你看到他想做一些非常愚蠢的事情，告诉他“你这样做很糟糕，我的道德水平比你高”可能不会奏效。

And if you see he wants to do something really stupid, it probably won’t work to tell him,"What you’re doing is bad. I have better morals than you."

那冒犯了他。你年轻。他卖了。因此，与其被说服，他更有可能做出反应，“你到底是谁来建立全世界的道德准则？”

That offends him. You’re young. He’s old. Therefore, instead of being persuaded, he’s more likely to react with,"Who in the hell are you to establish the moral code of the whole world?"

但相反，你可以对他说，“如果你下面的其他三个人不知道，你就不能这样做。因此，你让自己受到勒索。你在拿你的名誉冒险。你 在拿你的家人冒险，你的钱等等。”

But instead, you can say to him,"You can’t do that without three other people beneath you knowing about it. Therefore, you’re making yourself subject to blackmail. You’re risking your reputation. You’re risking your family, your money, etc."

这很可能奏效。你告诉他一些真实的事情。你想花很多时间为那些你必须使用这样的方法让他们表现良好的人工作吗？我认为答案是否定的。但是如果你迷上了它，作为人类说服的问题，吸引兴趣可能比吸引其他任何东西更有效。这又是一个具有深厚生物学根源的强大心理学原理。

That is likely to work. And you’re telling him something that’s true. Do you want to spend a lot of time working for people where you have to use methods like that to get them to behave well? I think the answer is no. But if you’re hooked with it, appealing to interest is likely to work better as a matter of human persuasion than appeal to anything else. That, again, is a powerful psychological principle with deep biological roots.

我看到所罗门公司彻底颠覆了这一心理原则。Salomon 的总委员会知道，首席执行官 Gutfreund 应该立即将所罗门的所有交易不当行为告知联邦当局，但 Gutfreund 并未参与这些交易，也不是他造成的。总法律顾问敦促 Gutfreund 这样做。实际上，他告诉 Gutfreund，“你可能没有法律要求这样做，但这是正确的做法。你真的应该这样做。”

I saw that psychological principle totally blown at Salomon. Salomon’s general council knew that the CEO, Gutfreund, should have promptly told the Federal authorities all about Salomon’s trading improprieties in which Gutfreund didn’t participate and which he hadn’t caused. And the general counsel urged Gutfreund to do it. He told Gutfreund, in effect,"You’re probably not legally required to do that, but it’s the right thing to do. You really should."

但它没有用。这项任务很容易被推迟——因为它令人不快。这就是 Gutfreund 所做的——他推迟了。

But it didn’t work. The task was easy to put off - because it was unpleasant. So that’s what Gutfreund did - he put it off.

除了CEO 之外，总法律顾问在所罗门公司内部几乎没有支持者。如果 CEO 垮台，总法律顾问也会跟着他一起垮台。因此，他的整个职业生涯都岌岌可危。因此，为了挽救自己的职业生涯，他需要说服拖延的 CEO 做正确的事。

And the general counsel had very little constituency within Salomon except for the CEO. If the CEO went down, the general counsel was going down with him. Therefore, his whole career was on the line. So to save his career, he needed to talk the dilatory CEO into doing the right thing.

正确完成这项工作本来就是儿戏。总法律顾问所要做的就是告诉他的老板，“约翰，这种情况可能会毁了你的生活。你可能会失去你的财富。你可能会失去你的声誉......”而且它会奏效。首席执行官们不喜欢被毁掉、丢脸和被解雇的想法。（Charles T. Munger 在斯坦福大学法学院对 William Lazier 教授的学生的演讲，杰出投资者文摘，1998 年 3 月 13 日，第 59 页。）

It would’ve been child’s play to get that job done right. All the general counsel had to do was to tell his boss,"John, this situation could ruin your life. You could lose your wealth. You could lose your reputation..."And it would have worked. CEOs don’t like the idea of being ruined, disgraced and fired. (Lecture by Charles T. Munger to the students of Professor William Lazier at Stanford Law School, Outstanding Investor Digest, March 13, 1998, p.59.)

关于管理者不做出理性决策的一些原因

On some reasons to why managers don’t make rational decisions

我最令人惊讶的发现：一种看不见的力量在商业中具有压倒性的重要性，我们可以称之为“制度规则”。在商学院，我没有得到任何关于命令式存在的暗示，进入商业世界时我也没有直观地理解它。当时我认为体面、聪明和经验丰富的经理会自动做出理性的商业决策。但随着时间的推移，我了解到事实并非如此。相反，当制度规则开始发挥作用时，理性往往会枯萎。

My most surprising discovery: the overwhelming importance in business of an unseen force that we might call"the institutional imperative." In business school, I was given no hint of the imperatives existence and I did not intuitively understand it when I entered the business world. I thought then that decent, intelligent, and experienced managers would automatically make rational business decisions. But I learned over time that isn’t so. Instead, rationality frequently wilts when the institutional imperative comes into play.

例如： (1) 就像受牛顿第一运动定律支配一样，一个机构将抵制其当前方向的任何变化；(2) 正如工作扩展以填补可用时间一样，公司项目或收购将实现以吸收可用资金；(3) 领导者的任何商业渴望，无论多么愚蠢，都将很快得到其部下准备的详细回报率和战略研究的支持；(4) 同行公司的行为，无论是扩张、收购、设置高管薪酬还是其他，都会被盲目模仿。

For example: (1) As if governed by Newton’s First Law of Motion, an institution will resist any change in its current direction; (2) Just as work expands to fill available time, corporate projects or acquisitions will materialize to soak up available funds; (3) Any business craving of the leader, however foolish, will be quickly supported by detailed rate-of-return and strategic studies prepared by his troops; and (4) The behaviour of peer companies, whether they are expanding, acquiring, setting executive compensation or whatever, will be mindlessly imitated.

制度动力，而不是唯利是图或愚蠢，使企业走上了这些经常被误导的道路。在因为忽视命令的力量而犯了一些代价高昂的错误之后，我试图以最小化其影响的方式组织和管理伯克希尔。此外，查理和我试图将我们的投资集中在那些似乎对这个问题保持警惕的公司。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司， 致股东的信，1989 年，第 62 页。）

Institutional dynamics, not venality or stupidity, set businesses on these courses, which are too often misguided. After making some expensive mistakes because I ignored the power of the imperative, I have tried to organize and manage Berkshire in ways that minimize its influence. Furthermore, Charlie and I have attempted to concentrate our investments in companies that appear alert to the problem. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Letters to Shareholders, 1989, p.62.)

关于更换CEO的难度

On the difficulty of replacing a CEO

大多数组织依靠上级的自身利益来淘汰二流的下级。如果我是一名销售经理，并且手下有很多糟糕的销售人员，这会影响我的表现，而且可能会影响我的收入，以保持低于标准的表现。如果足球教练能找到更好的四分卫或任何其他球员，那么他肯定会伤害他。在几乎所有的工作中，都有一个奖励或惩罚制度，使上级积极思考他手下的人是否做得一流，如果不是，就采取措施。

Most organizations depend on the self-interest of the superior to weed out the second-rate inferior. If I’m a sales manager and I’ve got lots of lousy salesmen, it hurts my performance and it probably hurts my income to keep on the sub-par performers. It certainly hurts a football coach to keep a sub-par quarterback or any other player in there if he can get a better one. In almost all jobs, there is a reward or penalty system that causes the superior to think actively about whether the people beneath him are doing a first-class job and to do something about it if they aren’t.

这一直适用于首席执行官。但首席执行官的上级是上市公司的董事。如果 CEO 表现不佳，公司的董事是否会受到影响？可能只有当他们感到尴尬时。在那种情况下，这就是你伤害上级的方式。你不会拿走他的董事费。实际上，您不会经常更换董事。因此，唯一可以与足球教练或销售经理的问题相提并论的系统可能是在心理上伤害低级主管的位置——这会奏效。否则，纠正 CEO 问题的动机并不强烈，除非董事之间有很大的所有权——即使这样也并不总是完美的。

That works all the way up to the CEO. But the CEO’s superiors are the directors of the publicly held company. And are the directors of the company going to suffer if the CEO is sub-par? Probably only if they’re embarrassed. That’s the way you hurt the superior in that case. You don’t take away his directors’ fee. And as a practical matter, you don’t displace directors very often. So the only system that’s comparable to the problem of the football coach or the sales manager is probably to hurt psychically the position of the inferior director - and that will work. Otherwise, the motivation to correct the CEO problem is not strong unless there’s a big ownership among directors - and even that doesn’t always work perfectly.

更换董事通常需要大股东的行动。它不会以任何其他方式发生。对于以某种方式选择其他弱势董事进行变革的管理层或一组董事来说，这是一个非常尴尬的局面。在会议上走到某个人面前——他没有造成任何伤害，坐在那里就像一个盆栽的手掌——然后转身对他说，“我们都考虑过了，这违反了所有自然的社会规范。而你，真的不是什么好东西。” 它只是没有发生。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司年会，1993 年，杰出投资者文摘，1993 年 6 月 30 日，第 32 页。）

To change directors usually takes the action of big shareholders. It doesn’t happen any other way. It’s a very awkward situation for a management or a group of directors, who have somehow selected other weak directors, to make changes. It goes against all the natural societal norms to walk up to some guy at a meeting—who isn’t causing any harm and is sitting there like a potted palm — and turn to him and say,"We’ve all thought it over. And you’re really not any good." It just doesn’t happen. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 1993, Outstanding Investor Digest, June 30, 1993, p.32.)

关于我们应该与什么样的人做生意

On the kind of people we should do business with

许多人问我 Blumkins [内布拉斯加州家具市场] 给他们的生意带来了什么秘密。这些都不是很深奥。家庭的所有成员： (1) 以让本·富兰克林和霍雷肖·阿尔杰看起来像辍学生的热情和精力投入工作；(2) 以非凡的现实主义态度界定他们的特殊能力领域，并对其中的所有事项采取果断行动；(3) 甚至忽略不属于该特殊能力领域的最诱人的提议；(4) 与他们打交道的每个人都始终保持高尚的举止。（B 夫人将其归结为“低价出售并说实话”。）（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司，致股东的信，1984 年，第 87 页。）

I have been asked by a number of people just what secrets the Blumkins [Nebraska Furniture Mart] bring to their business. These are not very esoteric. All members of the family: (1) apply themselves with an enthusiasm and energy that would make Ben Franklin and Horatio Alger look like dropouts; (2) define with extraordinary realism their area of special competence and act decisively on all matters within it; (3) ignore even the most enticing propositions falling outside of that area of special competence; and (4) unfailingly behave in a high-grade manner with everyone they deal with. (Mrs. B boils it down to"sell cheap and tell the truth".) (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Letters to Shareholders, 1984, p.87.)

我们真的不想收购任何我们认为首先会缺乏这种品质 [知识诚实] 的组织——因为我们真的不相信通过收购组织来改变它们。我们可能会稍微改变一下补偿系统或类似的东西......

We really don’t want to buy into any organization that we felt would be lacking that quality [intellectual honesty] in the first place — because we really don’t believe in buying into organizations to change them. We may change the comp system a little or something of the sort...

我们希望加入我们的人已经是那种面对现实并且基本上 [不仅] 告诉我们真相，而且告诉自己真相的人 - 这更重要。一旦你得到一个自欺欺人的组织——而且有很多这样的组织——我认为你会遇到各种各样的问题。整个组织的人们都知道这一点，他们采用他们认为在他们之上发生的事情的规范。特别是在金融组织中——实际上在任何组织中，但尤其是在金融组织中——随着时间的推移，这就是死亡。我们不会购买我们认为有问题的东西，我们会纠正它的想法 - 因为我们不会。我们对一些遇到此类问题的组织有一些经验。而且它是不可纠正的 - 至少基于人类的寿命。承诺太多了。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司年会，2000 年，杰出投资者文摘，OID.Com，从 2000 年 12 月 18 日和 2000 年年终版继续。）

We want people joining us who already are the type that face reality and that basically [not only] tell us the truth, but tell themselves the truth - which is even more important. Once you get an organization that lies to itself — and there are plenty that do - I just think you get into all kinds of problems. And people know it throughout the organization and they adopt the norms of what they think is happening up above them. Particularly in a financial organization — really in any organization, but particularly in a financial organization - that is death over time. We wouldn’t buy into something that we felt had that problem with the idea that we would correct it - because we wouldn’t. We’ve had a little experience with some organizations that have had that sort of problem. And it’s not correctable - at least based on the life span of humans. It’s too much to commit to. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 2000, Outstanding Investor Digest, OID.Com, continued from December 18, 2000 & Year End 2000 Editions.)

当主人关心时，我们发现它很有意义关于他卖给谁。我们喜欢与热爱他的公司的人做生意，而不仅仅是销售给他带来的钱（尽管我们当然理解他为什么也喜欢这样）。当这种情感依恋存在时，它表明在企业中可能会发现重要的品质：诚实的会计、对产品的自豪感、对客户的尊重以及一群具有强烈方向感的忠诚员工。反之亦然。当所有者拍卖他的企业时，表现出对接下来的事情完全不感兴趣时​​，您会经常发现它已被装扮成待售，特别是当卖方是“金融所有者”时。如果所有者的行为对他们的企业和员工漠不关心，他们的行为往往会影响整个公司的态度和做法。年度报告，第 7 页。）

We find it meaningful when an owner cares about whom he sells to. We like to do business with someone who loves his company, not just the money that a sale will bring him (though we certainly understand why he likes that as well). When this emotional attachment exists, it signals that important qualities will likely be found within the business: honest accounting, pride of product, respect for customers, and a loyal group of associates having a strong sense of direction. The reverse is apt to be true, also. When an owner auctions off his business, exhibiting a total lack of interest in what follows, you will frequently find that it has been dressed up for sale, particularly when the seller is a"financial owner." And if owners behave with little regard for their business and its people, their conduct will often contaminate attitudes and practices throughout the company. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., 2000 Annual Report, p.7.)

关于选择正确的性格特征

On picking up the right character traits

巴菲特：拥有正确的模型确实值得......1认为，如果你复制你所仰慕的人，特别是如果你在足够早的时候这样做，这是有道理的......如果你影响五岁或八岁或十岁的榜样，那么它将产生巨大的影响。

Buffett: It does pay to have the right models.. .1 think that it just stands to reason that if you copy the people that you look up to - particularly if you do it at an early enough age.. .If you influence the role models of a five-year old or an eight-year old or a ten-year old, then it’s going to have a huge impact.

当然，几乎每个人开始时的初始模型都是他们的父母。所以他们是那些将对他们产生巨大影响的人。如果那个父母被证明是一个伟大的榜样，我认为这对孩子来说将是一个巨大的优势。我认为拥有合适的模特比生活中的很多其他事情都重要……

And of course, virtually everybody starts out with their initial models being their parents. So they are the ones that are going to have a huge effect on ‘em. And if that parent turns out to be a great model, I think it’s going to be a huge plus for the child. I think it beats a whole lot of other things in life to have the right models around...

但你必须早点开始。以后很难改变行为。我在课堂上告诉学生，“只要挑出班上你最钦佩的人，坐下来写下你钦佩他的原因，然后试着找出为什么你们不能拥有相同的品质。” 毕竟，他们不像将足球扔出 60 码或在 10 秒内跑完 100 码之类的能力。它们是可以效仿的个性、性格和气质的品质。

But you’ve got to start early. It’s very tough to change behaviour later on. I tell the students in classes,"Just pick out the person you admire the most in the class, and sit down and write the reasons why you admire him and then try and figure out why you can’t have the same qualities." After all, they’re not like the ability to throw a football 60 yards or run the 100 in ten seconds flat or something like that. They’re qualities of personality, character and temperament that can be emulated.

你可以按照查理的理论反过来应用它：你可以找到你不喜欢的人并说，“我不喜欢这些人的什么地方？” 这需要一点性格上的力量，但你可以向内看，然后说，“我身上有这样的力量吗？”

And you can apply the reverse of it following Charlie’s theory: You can find the people you don’t like and say,"What don’t I like about these people?" It takes a little strength of character, but you can look inwards and say,"Have I got some of that in me?"

这并不复杂。本·格雷厄姆做到了，本·富兰克林做到了。没有什么比尝试弄清楚你觉得令人钦佩的地方然后决定你真正想要钦佩的人是你自己更简单的了。而你要做到这一点的唯一方法就是吸收你钦佩的其他人的品质。

It’s not complicated. Ben Graham did it, Ben Franklin did it. And nothing could be more simple than to try and figure out what you find admirable and then decide that the person you really would like to admire is yourself. And the only way you’re going to do it is to take on the qualities of other people you admire.

芒格：另外，没有理由只寻找活生生的模型。杰出的死者在事物的本质上是周围最好的模型。如果你想要一个模型，你最好不要把自己局限于生活。一些最好的模型已经死了很长时间。（Berkshire Hathaway 年会，2000 年，杰出投资者文摘，2000 年年底版，第 62-63 页。）

Munger: Also, there is no reason to look only for living models. The eminent dead are in the nature of things some of the best models around. And if a model is all you want, you’re really better off not limiting yourself to the living. Some of the very best models have been dead for a long time. (Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 2000, Outstanding Investor Digest, Year End 2000 Edition, pp.62-63.)

关于过度自信

On overconfidence

大约 99% 的美国管理人员认为，如果他们擅长做一件事，那么他们在做其他事情时也会很出色。他们就像下雨时池塘里的鸭子——他们在世界上上升。他们开始认为他们是导致自己崛起的人。所以他们走到不下雨的地方，就坐在地上。但是没有任何反应。然后他们通常会解雇他们的二号人物或聘请顾问。他们很少看到真正发生的事情是他们已经离开了他们的能力范围......

About 99% of American management thinks that if they’re wonderful at doing one thing that they’ll be wonderful at doing something else. They’re like a duck on a pond when it’s raining - they’re going up in the world. They start thinking that they’re the ones that are causing themselves to rise. So they go over to some place where it isn’t raining and they just sit there on the ground. But nothing happens. Then they usually fire their number two in command or hire a consultant. They very seldom see what really happens is that they have left their circle of competence...

如果你以美国最大公司的首席执行官为例，他们不知道自己的能力范围是多少。这就是他们进行如此多愚蠢收购的原因之一。他们之所以成为企业的高层，是因为他们是出色的推销员、出色的生产人员等等。突然之间，他们经营着一家价值数十亿美元的企业，而他们的工作就是分配资本和收购企业。他们一生中从未购买过企业。他们不知道这是怎么回事。

If you take the CEOs of America’s largest corporations, they do not know what their circle of competence is. That’s one of the reasons they make so many dumb acquisitions. They rise to the top of the business because they’re great salesmen, great production people or whatever. All of a sudden, they’re running a multi-billion dollar business and their job is to allocate capital and to buy businesses. They’ve never bought a business in their life. They don’t know what it’s all about.

所以他们通常会做一两件事。要么他们设立一个内部部门，雇佣一群人，让他们告诉他一些事情要做。当然，伙计们知道，如果他们不告诉他一些事情要做，那么就没有工作。所以你可以想象到那时会发生什么活动。或者他们出去雇用从交易中获得报酬的投资银行家。（沃伦巴菲特，1990 年 3 月 23 日在斯坦福大学法学院的演讲，杰出投资者文摘，1990 年 4 月 18 日，第 13-14 页。）

So they usually do one or two things. Either they set up an internal department, hire a bunch of guys and have them tell him something to do. Of course, the guys know if they don’t tell him something to do, then there will be no jobs. So you can imagine what activity takes place then. Or they go out and hire investment bankers who get paid by the transaction. (Warren Buffett, lecture at Stanford Law School, March 23, 1990, Outstanding Investor Digest, April 18, 1990, pp.13-14.)

不良贷款为何如此频繁发生的一些原因

On some reasons to why bad lending happen so often

假设存在不正当的激励措施，在我们目前的系统下，导致广泛不良贷款（较高的利率不能充分弥补增加的损失风险）的操作机制是什么？毕竟，不良贷款虽然在成本压力下对银行家来说表面上是合理的，但从定义上讲是不合理的，至少对于放贷银行和更广泛的文明而言是这样。那么不良贷款为何如此频繁发生呢？

Granting the presence of perverse incentives, what are the operating mechanics that cause widespread bad loans (where the higher interest rates do not adequately cover increased risk of loss) under our present system? After all, the bad lending, while it has a surface plausibility to bankers under cost pressure, is, by definition, not rational, at least for the lending banks and the wider civilization. How then does bad lending occur so often?

它的发生（部分）是因为作为社会动物的人之间存在可预测的非理性。现在很清楚（在实验社会心理学中）处于两难境地的人，这是我们的系统将我们的银行家置于困境的地方，更有可能对其他人的行为做出不明智的反应，现在被广泛称为“社会证明” ” 因此，一旦某个银行家通过不明智的放贷明显（但并非真正）解决了他的成本压力问题，就会自然而然地出现大量依赖“社会证明”的模仿性“群体愚蠢”。额外的大量非理性借贷是由愚蠢行为的“强化”引起的，愚蠢行为是由不明智的会计惯例以本文稍后讨论的方式引起的。

It occurs (partly) because there are predictable irrationalities among people as social animals. It is now pretty clear (in experimental social psychology) that people on the horns of a dilemma, which is where our system has placed our bankers, are extra likely to react unwisely to the example of other people’s conduct, now widely called"social proof." So, once some banker has apparently (but not really) solved his cost-pressure problem by unwise lending, a considerable amount of imitative"crowd folly," relying on the"social proof," is the natural consequence. Additional massive irrational lending is caused by"reinforcement" of foolish behaviour, caused by unwise accounting convention in a manner discussed later in this letter. It is hard to be wise when the messages which drive you are wrong messages provided by a mal-designed system...

许多著名的“专家”不同意我们关于将 (1) “自由市场”利率定价与 (2) 政府支付担保相结合的系统性不负责任的观点。如果许多著名的“专家”都错了，怎么会发生这样的事情？我们的解释是，“专家们”对来自亚当·斯密的令人钦佩、强大的预测模型着迷了。那些可自由支配的存款利率具有“自由市场”形象，因此很容易自动得出结论，即自由支配利率与其他自由市场过程一样，一定是好的。事实上，即使与政府存款保险（一种激进的非自由市场因素）相结合，它们仍被认为是良好的。

Many eminent"experts" would not agree with our notions about systemic irresponsibility from combining (1)"free-market" pricing of interest rates with (2) government guarantees of payment. If many eminent"experts" are wrong, how could this happen? Our explanation is that the"experts" are over-charmed with an admirable, powerful, predictive model, coming down from Adam Smith. Those discretionary interest rates on deposits have a"free-market" image, making it easy to conclude, automatically, that the discretionary rates, like other free-market processes, must be good. Indeed, they are appraised as remaining good even when combined with governmental deposit insurance, a radical non-free-market element.

这种不合逻辑的思维表现出标准的愚蠢，困扰着任何软科学中的“专家”角色：人们倾向于只使用自己学科领域的模型，而忽略或低估其他学科。此外，任何模型越强大和有用，它就越容易因过度自信的误用而产生更多错误。

Such illogical thinking displays the standard folly bedeviling the"expert" role in any soft science: one tends to use only models from one’s own segment of a discipline, ignoring or under-weighing others. Furthermore, the more powerful and useful is any model, the more error it tends to produce through overconfident misuse.

这让我想起了本格雷厄姆的自相矛盾的观察，即好的想法比坏的想法导致更多的投资恶作剧。他是对的。对我们所有人来说，将一个非常好的想法推向可悲的过度是很容易的，就像佛罗里达土地泡沫或“漂亮的五十”公司股票的情况一样。然后混合一点“社会证明”（来自其他专家），大脑（包括我们的）通常会变成糊状。如果伟大的旧模型永远不会欺骗我们就好了，但是，唉，“有些梦想不是这样的。” 连爱因斯坦晚年都被骗了……

This brings to mind Ben Graham’s paradoxical observation that good ideas cause more investment mischief than bad ideas. He had it right. It is so easy for us all to push a really good idea to wretched excess, as in the case of the Florida land bubble or the"nifty fifty" corporate stocks. Then mix in a little"social proof" (from other experts), and brains (including ours) often turn to mush. It would be nice if great old models never tricked us, but, alas,"some dreams are not to be." Even Einstein got tricked in his later years...

我们认为当前对许多高利率贷款的会计处理对银行系统造成了可怕的后果。本质上，它“前端”进入报告的收入收入，如果采用更保守的会计方法，这些收入将被推迟到很久以后，在风险赌注更明显地赢得之后。这种做法将许多银行家变成了 BF Skinners 鸽子的人类版本，因为他通过在短期内看到好数字的乐趣而“强化”到继续和扩大不良贷款。良好的数字在头脑中很好地替代了不存在的潜在制度良好，部分是通过最初由巴甫洛夫证明的过程，在该过程中，我们对单纯的联想做出反应，因为它通常预示着一种现实，可以使反应正确。（查尔斯·芒格，韦斯科金融公司。年度报告。Berkshire Hathaway Inc.， 致股东的信，1987-1995，第 205-208 页。）

We think current accounting for many high-interest-rate loans has terrible consequences in the banking system. In essence, it"front ends" into reported income revenues that would have been deferred until much later, after risky bets were more clearly won, if more conservative accounting had been employed. This practice turns many a banker into a human version of one of B.F. Skinners pigeons, since he is"reinforced" into continuing and expanding bad lending through the pleasure of seeing good figures in the short term. The good figures substitute nicely in the mind for nonexistent underlying institutional good, partly through the process, originally demonstrated by Pavlov, wherein we respond to a mere association because it has usually portended a reality that would make the response correct. (Charles Munger, Wesco Financial Inc., 1990 Annual Report. Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Letters to Shareholders, 1987-1995, pp.205-208.)

关于数学的价值

On the value of math

世界股票市值的 53% 在美国好吧，如果美国 GDP [国内生产总值] 以每年 4-5% 的速度增长，而通货膨胀率为 1-2% - 这将是一个相当不错的结果，事实上这将是一个非常好的结果——那么我认为企业利润的增长速度不太可能超过这个速度。企业利润占 GDP 的百分比已经偏高——而且企业利润的增长速度不可能一直快于 GDP。显然，最终，它们会大于 GDP。

53% of the world’s stock market value is in the U.S. Well, if U.S. GDP [gross domestic product] grows at 4-5% a year with 1-2% inflation - which would be a pretty good, in fact it would be a very good result - then I think it’s very unlikely that corporate profits are going to grow at a greater rate than that. Corporate profits as a percent of GDP are on the high side already - and corporate profits can’t constantly grow at a faster rate than GDP. Obviously, in the end, they’d be greater than GDP.

就像有人说纽约——律师比人多。如果你说利润可以比 GDP 大，你就会在前进的过程中遇到某些冲突。因此，如果你的情况是，多年来你对企业利润增长的最高期望是 4-5%，那么认为股票——毕竟是这些企业利润的资本化——怎么可能合理呢？每年增长15%？这是废话，坦率地说......

It’s like somebody said about New York - that it has more lawyers than people. You run into certain conflicts as you go along if you say profits can get bigger than GDP. So if you have a situation where the best you can hope for in corporate profit growth over the years is 4-5%, how can it be reasonable to think that equities — which, after all, are a capitalization of those corporate profits - can grow at 15% a year? It’s nonsense, frankly...

前几天，我查看了财富500 强。名单上的公司年末收入为 3340 亿美元，市值为 9.9 万亿美元——现在可能至少达到 10.5 万亿美元。好吧，从长远来看，投资者唯一能赚到的钱就是企业赚的钱。没有添加任何内容。政府不投入任何东西。没有人加入。人们从摩擦成本——投资管理费、经纪佣金和所有这些方面——中获利。但 3340 亿美元是投资的全部收益。

The other day, I looked at the Fortune 500. And the companies on that list earned $334 billion and had a market capitalization of $9.9 trillion at year end - which would probably be up to at least $10.5 trillion now. Well, the only money investors are going to make in the long run is what the businesses make. There’s nothing added. The government doesn’t throw in anything. Nobody’s adding to the pot. People take out from the pot in terms of frictional costs - investment management fees, brokerage commissions and all of that. But $334 billion is all that the investment earns.

如果你拥有一个农场，那么农场生产的就是你将从农场获得的全部。如果它每英亩产生 50 美元的净利润，您将获得每英亩 50 美元的净利润。它没有任何东西可以以某种神奇的形式改变它。如果你拥有所有财富500 强——如果你拥有 100%——你将赚取 3340 亿美元。如果你为此支付了 10.5 万亿美元，那么，这并不是一个很好的投资回报。

If you own a farm, what the farm produces is all you’re going to get from the farm. If it produces $50 an acre of net profit, you’ll get $50 an acre of net profit. And there’s nothing about it that transforms that in some miraculous form. If you owned all of the Fortune 500 - if you owned 100% of it - you’d be making $334 billion. And if you paid $ 10.5 trillion for that, well, that’s not a great return on investment.

然后你可能会说，“这 3340 亿美元能在五年内翻一番吗？” 好吧，它不可能在 GDP 以每年 4% 或类似的数字增长的情况下在五年内翻一番。就美国经济的经验而言，它只会产生如此不正常的事情，以至于它不会发生。每当你卷入这些事情时，如果你追溯其中的数学原理，你就会遇到荒谬的事情，那么你最好稍微改变一下你的期望。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司年会，1999 年，杰出投资者文摘，1999 年 12 月 10 日，第 52 页。）

Then you might say,"Can that $334 billion double in five years?" Well, it can't double in five years with GDP growing at 4% a year or some number like that. It would just produce things so out of whack in terms of experience in the American economy that it won’t happen. Any time you get involved in these things where if you trace out the mathematics of it, you bump into absurdities, then you better change your expectations somewhat. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 1999, Outstanding Investor Digest, December 10,1999, p.52.)

关于规模优势

On advantages of scale

就哪些企业成功和哪些企业失败而言，规模优势非常重要。例如，世界上所有商学院教授的规模的一大优势是沿着所谓的经验曲线降低成本。仅仅做 越来越多的复杂事情，就可以使那些试图改进并受到资本主义激励的人类能够越来越有效地做这件事。

In terms of which businesses succeed and which businesses fail, advantages of scale are ungodly important. For example, one great advantage of scale taught in all of the business schools of the world is cost reductions along the so-called experience curve. Just doing something complicated in more and more volume enables human beings, who are trying to improve and are motivated by the incentives of capitalism, to do it more and more efficiently.

事情的本质是，如果你通过你的关节获得大量的体积，你就会更好地处理该体积。这是一个巨大的优势。它与企业的成功和失败有很大关系……

The very nature of things is that if you get a whole lot of volume through your joint, you get better at processing that volume. That’s an enormous advantage. And it has a lot to do with which businesses succeed and fail....

让我们通过一个列表——尽管是规模可能带来的优势的不完整列表。有些来自简单的几何。如果你正在建造一个伟大的球形水箱，显然当你把它建造得更大时，你在表面使用的钢材数量会随着正方形的增加而增加，而立方体的体积会随着立方体的增加而增加。因此，随着尺寸的增加，每单位面积的钢材可以容纳更多的体积。还有各种各样的东西，简单的几何形状——简单的现实——给你带来规模优势。

Let’s go through a list - albeit an incomplete one of possible advantages of scale. Some come from simple geometry. If you’re building a great spherical tank, obviously as you build it bigger, the amount of steel you use in the surface goes up with the square and the cubic volume goes up with the cube. So as you increase the dimensions, you can hold a lot more volume per unit area of steel. And there are all kinds of things like that where the simple geometry — the simple reality — gives you an advantage of scale.

例如，您可以从电视广告中获得规模优势。当电视广告第一次出现时——当会说话的彩色图片第一次进入我们的客厅时——它是一种令人难以置信的强大的东西。在早期，我们拥有三个拥有一切的网络——比如说 90% 的观众。

For example, you can get advantages of scale from TV advertising. When TV advertising first arrived - when talking color pictures first came into our living rooms - it was an unbelievably powerful thing. And in the early days, we had three networks that had whatever it was - say 90% of the audience.

好吧，如果你是宝洁公司，你就可以负担得起使用这种新的广告方式。你可以负担得起网络电视的昂贵费用，因为你卖了那么多该死的罐头和瓶子。有些小家伙不能。而且没有办法部分购买。所以，他不能用。实际上，如果你没有大音量，你就不能使用网络电视广告——这是最有效的技术。

Well, if you were Proctor & Gamble, you could afford to use this new method of advertising. You could afford the very expensive cost of network television because you were selling so damn many cans and bottles. Some little guy couldn’t. And there was no way of buying it in part. Therefore, he couldn’t use it. In effect, if you didn’t have a big volume, you couldn’t use network TV advertising — which was the most effective technique.

因此，当电视出现时，已经很大的品牌公司得到了巨大的顺风。事实上，他们繁荣昌盛，繁荣昌盛，直到他们中的一些人变得肥胖和愚蠢，这种情况随着繁荣而发生——至少对某些人而言……

So when TV came in, the branded companies that were already big got a huge tail wind. Indeed, they prospered and prospered and prospered until some of them got fat and foolish, which happens with prosperity — at least to some people....

您的规模优势可以成为信息优势。如果我去一些偏远的地方，我可能会看到 Wrigley 口香糖和 Glotz 口香糖。好吧，我知道 Wrigley 是令人满意的产品，而我对 Glotz 的产品一无所知。因此，如果一个是 0.40 美元，另一个是 0.30 美元，我是否会拿一些我不知道的东西放进嘴里——毕竟这是一个非常私人的地方——为了一毛钱？

And your advantage of scale can be an informational advantage. If I go to some remote place, I may see Wrigley chewing gum alongside Glotz’s chewing gum. Well, I know that Wrigley is a satisfactory product, whereas I don’t know anything about Glotz’s. So if one is $.40 and the other is $.30, am I going to take something I don’t know and put it in my mouth — which is a pretty personal place, after all — for a lousy dime?

规模的另一个优势来自心理学……我们都受到我们看到别人所做和认可的事情的影响——潜意识和某种程度上是有意识的。因此，如果每个人都在买东西，我们认为它更好。我们不喜欢成为一个不合时宜的人。

Another advantage of scale comes from psychology.. .We are all influenced - subconsciously and to some extent consciously - by what we see others do and approve. Therefore, if everybody’s buying something, we think it’s better. We don’t like to be the one guy who’s out of step.

同样，其中一些是在潜意识层面，而另一些则不是。有时，我们会自觉地、理性地想，“哎呀，我对这个了解不多，他们比我知道的多，所以，我为什么不跟着他们走呢？”

Again, some of this is at a subconscious level and some of it isn’t. Sometimes, we consciously and rationally think,"Gee, I don’t know much about this. They know more than I do. Therefore, why shouldn’t I follow them?"

来自心理学的社会认同现象为规模化提供了巨大的优势——例如，分布非常广泛，这当然很难获得。可口可乐的优势之一是它几乎在世界任何地方都可以买到。

The social proof phenomenon which comes right out of psychology gives huge advantages to scale — for example, with very wide distribution, which of course is hard to get. One advantage of Coca-Cola is that it’s available almost everywhere in the world.

好吧，假设你喝了一点汽水。你究竟如何让它在地球上可用？全球分销设置——大企业慢慢赢得——将成为一个巨大的优势……如果你想一想，一旦你获得了足够的这种类型的优势，任何人都很难赶走你。

Well, suppose you have a little soft drink. Exactly how do you make it available all over the Earth? The worldwide distribution setup - which is slowly won by a big enterprise - gets to be a huge advantage... And if you think about it, once you get enough advantages of that type, it can become very hard for anybody to dislodge you.

规模化还有另一种优势。在一些企业中，事情的本质是某种程度上导致一家公司的压倒性主导地位。

There’s another kind of advantage to scale. In some businesses, the very nature of things is to sort of cascade toward the overwhelming dominance of one firm.

最明显的是日报。除了一些非常大的城市外，美国几乎没有城市有超过一份日报。

The most obvious one is daily newspapers. There’s practically no city left in the U.S., aside from a few very big ones, where there’s more than one daily newspaper.

再一次，这是一个规模的事情。一旦我获得了大部分发行量，我就获得了大部分广告。一旦我获得了大部分的广告和发行量，为什么会有人想要更薄的信息更少的纸呢？因此，它往往会形成赢者通吃的局面。这是规模现象优势的另一种形式。

And again, that’s a scale thing. Once I get most of the circulation, I get most of the advertising. And once I get most of the advertising and circulation, why would anyone want the thinner paper with less information in it? So it tends to cascade to a winner-take-all situation. And that’s a separate form of the advantages of scale phenomenon.

同样，所有这些巨大的规模优势使得公司内部更加专业化。因此，每个人都可以在他所做的事情上做得更好......

Similarly, all these huge advantages of scale allow greater specialization within the firm. Therefore, each person can be better at what he does...

关于规模优势这个话题，我觉得连锁店挺有意思的。考虑一下。连锁店的概念是一项引人入胜的发明。你获得了巨大的购买力——这意味着你的商品成本更低。你有一大堆小实验室，你可以在里面进行实验。你得到专业化。

On the subject of advantages of economies of scale, I find chain stores quite interesting. Just think about it. The concept of a chain store was a fascinating invention. You get this huge purchasing power - which means that you have lower merchandise costs. You get a whole bunch of little laboratories out there in which you can conduct experiments. And you get specialization.

如果一个小家伙试图购买受旅行推销员影响的 27 种不同商品类别，他将做出很多愚蠢的决定。但是如果你的采购是在总部为一大群商店完成的，你可以让非常聪明的人来做采购，他们对冰箱等有很多了解。

If one little guy is trying to buy across 27 different merchandise categories influenced by traveling salesmen, he’s going to make a lot of dumb decisions. But if your buying is done in headquarters for a huge bunch of stores, you can get very bright people that know a lot about refrigerators and so forth to do the buying.

一个人负责所有采购的小商店证明了相反的情况。这就像关于小商店的古老故事，里面满是盐。一个陌生人走进来对店主说，“你一定卖了很多盐。” 他回答说，“不，我不知道。但你应该去看看那个卖盐给我的人。” （Charles T. Munger 于 1994 年 4 月 14 日在南加州大学商学院对 Guilford Babcock 教授的学生发表的演讲，杰出投资者文摘，1995 年 5 月 5 日，第 52-54 页。）

The reverse is demonstrated by the little store where one guy is doing all the buying. It’s like the old story about the little store with salt all over its walls. And a stranger comes in and says to the store owner,"You must sell a lot of salt." And he replies,"No, I don’t. But you should see the guy who sells me salt." (Lecture by Charles T. Munger to the students of Professor Guilford Babcock at the University of Southern California School of Business on April 14, 1994, Outstanding Investor Digest, May 5, 1995, pp.52-54.)

关于规模的劣势

On disadvantages of scale

例如，我们——我指的是伯克希尔哈撒韦公司——是 Capital Cities/ABC 的最大股东。我们在那里的贸易出版物被谋杀了——我们的竞争对手打败了我们。他们打败我们的方式是进入更窄的专业领域。

For example, we — by which I mean Berkshire Hathaway — are the largest shareholder in Capital Cities/ABC. And we had trade publications there that got murdered - where our competitors beat us. And the way they beat us was by going to a narrower specialization.

我们会有一本商务旅行的旅游杂志。因此，有人会创建一个仅在公司差旅部门处理的问题。就像一个生态系统，你的专业化范围越来越窄。

We’d have a travel magazine for business travel. So somebody would create one which was addressed solely at corporate travel departments. Like an ecosystem, you’re getting a narrower and narrower specialization.

好吧，他们变得更有效率了。他们可以将更多信息告诉经营公司差旅部门的人。此外，他们不必浪费墨水和纸张来邮寄公司差旅部门没有兴趣阅读的内容。这是一个更有效的系统。当我们依赖我们更广泛的杂志时，他们把我们的大脑打得七零八落。

Well, they got much more efficient. They could tell more to the guys who ran corporate travel departments. Plus, they didn’t have to waste the ink and paper mailing out stuff that corporate travel departments weren’t interested in reading. It was a more efficient system. And they beat our brains out as we relied on our broader magazine.

《星期六晚报》和所有那些事情就是这样发生的。他们走了。我们现在拥有的是Motorcross - 一群喜欢参加比赛的疯子会在摩托车上翻筋斗。但他们关心它。对他们来说，这是生活的主要目的。一本名为Motorcross的杂志对这些人来说是必不可少的。它的利润率会让你垂涎三尺。想一想这种发布的范围是多么狭窄。所以偶尔，缩小规模和加强规模会给你带来很大的优势。更大并不总是更好。

That’s what happened to The Saturday Evening Post and all those things. They’re gone. What we have now is Motorcross - which is read by a bunch of nuts who like to participate in tournaments where they turn somersaults on their motorcycles. But they care about it. For them, it’s the principal purpose of life. A magazine called Motorcross is a total necessity to those people. And its profit margins would make you salivate. Just think of how narrowcast that kind of publishing is. So occasionally, scaling down and intensifying gives you the big advantage. Bigger is not always better.

当然，规模的巨大缺陷使游戏变得有趣——大人物并不总是赢——当你变大时，你就会有官僚作风。官僚主义带来了地域性——这又是基于人性的。

The great defect of scale, of course, which makes the game interesting - so that the big people don’t always win - is that as you get big, you get the bureaucracy. And with the bureaucracy comes the territoriality - which is again grounded in human nature.

而且这些激励措施是不正当的。例如，如果你在我那个时代为 AT&T 工作，那是一个很大的官僚机构。究竟是谁在真正考虑股东或其他任何事情？在官僚机构中，当工作从你的收件箱中进入别人的收件箱时，你认为工作已经完成。但是，当然不是。直到 AT&T 提供它应该提供的服务后，它才算完成。所以你会得到庞大、肥胖、愚蠢、没有动力的官僚机构。

And the incentives are perverse. For example, if you worked for AT&T in my day, it was a great bureaucracy. Who in the hell was really thinking about the shareholder or anything else? And in a bureaucracy, you think the work is done when it goes out of your in-basket into somebody’s else’s in-basket. But, of course, it isn’t. It’s not done until AT &T delivers what it’s supposed to deliver. So you get big, fat, dumb, unmotivated bureaucracies.

他们也往往变得有些腐败。换句话说，如果我有一个部门，你也有一个部门，并且我们共享管理这件事的权力，就会有一条不成文的规定：“如果你不打扰我，我就不会打扰你我们都很开心。” 因此，您获得了无人需要的管理层级和相关成本。然后，当人们为所有这些层次辩护时。完成任何事情都需要永远。他们做决定的速度太慢，而更敏捷的人则绕着他们转圈。

They also tend to become somewhat corrupt. In other words, if I’ve got a department and you’ve got a department and we kind of share power running this thing, there’s sort of an unwritten rule:"If you won’t bother me, I won’t bother you and we’re both happy." So you get layers of management and associated costs that nobody needs. Then, while people are justifying all these layers. It takes forever to get anything done. They’re too slow to make decisions and nimbler people run circles around them.

规模的持续诅咒是它会导致庞大、愚蠢的官僚主义——当然，在激励措施非常糟糕的政府中，官僚主义达到了最高和最糟糕的形式。这并不意味着我们不需要政府——因为我们需要。但让大型官僚机构守规矩是一个可怕的问题。（Charles T. Munger 于 1994 年 4 月 14 日在南加州大学商学院对 Guilford Babcock 教授的学生发表的演讲，杰出投资者文摘，1995 年 5 月 5 日，第 53 页。）

The constant curse of scale is that it leads to big, dumb bureaucracy - which, of course, reaches its highest and worst form in government where the incentives are really awful. That doesn’t mean we don’t need governments — because we do. But it’s a terrible problem to get big bureaucracies to behave. (Lecture by Charles T. Munger to the students of Professor Guilford Babcock at the University of Southern California School of Business on April 14, 1994, Outstanding Investor Digest, May 5, 1995, p.53.)

关于如何获得世间智慧

On how to get worldly wisdom

我一直相信某个系统——几乎任何聪明人都能学会的系统比大多数人使用的系统运行得更好。正如我在南加州大学商学院所说，你需要的是头脑中的心智模型网格。你把你的实际经验和你的替代经验（你从阅读等中得到的）挂在这个强大模型的网格上。而且，有了这个系统，事物逐渐以一种增强认知的方式融合在一起。

I’ve long believed that a certain system - which almost any intelligent person can learn works way better than the systems that most people use. As I said at the U.S.C. Business School, what you need is a latticework of mental models in your head. And you hang your actual experience and your vicarious experience (that you get from reading and so forth) on this latticework of powerful models. And, with that system, things gradually get to fit together in a way that enhances cognition.

你需要模型——不仅仅是来自一两个学科，而是来自所有重要学科的模型。你需要最好的 100 个左右的模型，这些模型来自微观经济学、生理学、心理学，尤其是初等数学、硬科学和工程学 [等等]。

And you need the models - not just from one or two disciplines, but from all the important disciplines. You need the best 100 or so models from microeconomics, physiology, psychology particularly, elementary mathematics, hard science and engineering [and so on].

您不必是任何这些领域的专家。你所要做的就是接受真正伟大的想法，并尽早好好学习它们。

You don’t have to be a huge expert in any of those fields. All you’ve got to do is take the really big ideas and learn them early and well.

你无法像许多学生那样学习你真正需要的 100 个大创意——在那里你学得很好，可以把它们还给教授并得到你的成绩，然后你把它们清空，就像清空浴缸一样这样你下次就可以多喝水了。如果这就是您学习所需的 100 个大模型的方式，那么 [您将] 成为人生游戏中的“also ran”。您必须学习这些模型，以便它们成为您经常使用的曲目的一部分。（Charles T. Munger 在斯坦福大学法学院对 William Lazier 教授的学生的演讲，杰出投资者文摘，1997 年 12 月 29 日，第 24 页。）

You can’t learn those 100 big ideas you really need the way many students do - where you learn 'em well enough to bang ‘em back to the professor and get your grade and then you empty them out as though you were emptying a bathtub so you can take in more water next time. If that’s the way you learn the 100 big models you’re going to need, [you’ll be] an"also ran" in the game of life. You have to learn the models so that they become part of your ever-used repertoire. (Lecture by Charles T. Munger to the students of Professor William Lazier at Stanford Law School, Outstanding Investor Digest, December 29, 1997, p.24.)

关于某事的真正含义

On what something really mean

就其性质而言，美国存在巨大的商品贸易逆差。如果您从世界其他地方购买的商品多于您出售的商品 - 根据定义，当您出现贸易逆差时就会发生这种情况 - 您必须平衡收支。他们必须得到一些东西——一些资本资产——作为交换：他们可能会得到政府债券。他们可能会得到美国企业的一部分。但他们必须得到一些东西。

By its nature, the U.S. is running a substantial merchandise trade deficit. If you buy more from the rest of the world than you’re selling them - which is what happens by definition when you’re running a trade deficit - you have to balance the books. They have to get something - some capital asset - in exchange: They may get a government bond. They may get a piece of a U.S. business. But they have to get something.

经济学中的关键是，无论何时有人向你提出断言，总是要问，“然后呢？” 实际上，什么事都问问它也不是什么坏主意。但你应该总是问，“然后呢？”

The key thing in economics, whenever someone makes an assertion to you, is to always ask,"And then what?" Actually, it’s not such a bad idea to ask it about everything. But you should always ask,"And then what?"

那么，当您读到商品贸易逆差为 90 亿美元时，这还意味着什么？这意味着我们一定还以某种方式交易了 90 亿美元的资本资产——（未来）对我们生产的索取权——并将它们交给了世界上的其他人。所以他们必须投资。他们别无选择。当有人说，“如果日本人卖掉他们所有的政府债券，那会不会很糟糕？” 好吧，他们不能不换取另一项美国资产。没有其他方法可以做到这一点。他们可以把它卖给法国人，但法国人也有同样的问题。

So when you read that the merchandise trade deficit is $9 billion, what else does that mean? It means that somehow we must also have traded $9 billion of capital assets — (future) claims on our production — and given them to somebody else in the world. So they have to invest. They don’t have any choice. And when somebody says,"Won’t it be terrible if the Japanese sell all of their government bonds?" Well, they can’t without getting another American asset in exchange. There’s simply no other way to do it. They could sell it to the French, but then the French have the same problem.

因此，每当您谈论经济学中的任何具体行为时，都可以通过圈子上的交易进行追踪。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司年会，1997 年，杰出投资者文摘，1997 年 8 月 8 日，第 23 页。）

So trace through the transactions on the circle whenever you talk about any specific action in economics. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 1997, Outstanding Investor Digest, August 8, 1997, p.23.)

关于 3 个永恒的投资理念

On 3 timeless ideas for investing

他的 [Benjamin Graham] 三个基本思想——它们都不复杂，也不需要任何数学天赋或任何类似的东西：

His [Benjamin Graham] three basic ideas — and none of them are complicated or require any mathematical talent or anything of that sort are:

  1. 你应该将股票视为企业所有权的一部分，
  2. that you should look at stocks as part ownership of a business,
  3. 你应该根据他的“市场先生”的例子来看待市场波动，通过从愚蠢中获利而不是参与其中，使他们成为你的朋友而不是你的敌人，最后，
  4. that you should look at market fluctuations in terms of his"Mr. Market" example and make them your friend rather than your enemy by essentially profiting from folly rather participating in it, and finally,
  5. 投资中最重要的三个词是“安全边际”——...如果你要驾驶 10,000 磅重的卡车穿过它，请务必建造一座 15,000 磅重的桥梁...
  6. the three most important words in investing are"margin of safety" - ...always building a 15,000 pound bridge if you’re going to be driving 10,000 pound truck across it...

所以我认为这归结为这些想法——尽管它们听起来如此简单和司空见惯，以至于上学并获得博士学位似乎有点浪费。在经济学中，让一切回到那个。这有点像在神学院度过八年，然后有人告诉你十诫才是最重要的。有一种自然倾向会忽视任何简单而重要的事情。（沃伦巴菲特，纽约证券分析师协会演讲，1994 年 12 月 6 日，杰出投资者文摘，1995 年 5 月 5 日，第 3 页。）

So I think that it comes down to those ideas — although they sound so simple and commonplace that it kind of seems like a waste to go to school and get a Ph.D. in Economics and have it all come back to that. It’s a little like spending eight years in divinity school and having somebody tell you that the ten commandments were all that counted. There is a certain natural tendency to overlook anything that simple and important. (Warren Buffett, speech at New York Society of Security Analysts, December 6, 1994, Outstanding Investor Digest, May 5, 1995, p.3.)

关于如何评估企业

On how to evaluate businesses

撇开税收因素不谈，我们用于评估股票和企业的公式是相同的。事实上，自从公元前 600 年左右一位非常聪明的人首次提出该公式以来（尽管他不够聪明，不知道那是公元前 600 年），为获得经济利益而购买的所有资产的估值公式一直没有改变。

Leaving aside tax factors, the formula we use for evaluating stocks and businesses is identical. Indeed, the formula for valuing all assets that are purchased for financial gain has been unchanged since it was first laid out by a very smart man in about 600 B.C. (though he wasn’t smart enough to know it was 600 B.C.).

先知是伊索，他经久不衰但有些不完整的投资见解是“一鸟在手胜于二鸟在林”。要充实这一原则，您只需回答三个问题。你有多确定灌木丛中确实有鸟？他们什么时候会出现，会有多少？无风险利率（我们认为是美国长期债券的收益率）是多少？如果你能回答这三个问题，你就会知道灌木丛的最大价值——以及你现在拥有的最多应该为它提供的鸟的数量。当然，不要真的认为鸟类。想想美元。

The oracle was Aesop and his enduring, though somewhat incomplete, investment insight was"a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush." To flesh out this principle, you must answer only three questions. How certain are you that there are indeed birds in the bush? When will they emerge and how many will there be? What is the risk-free interest rate (which we consider to be the yield on long-term U.S. bonds)? If you can answer these three questions, you will know the maximum value of the bush - and the maximum number of the birds you now possess that should be offered for it. And, of course, don’t literally think birds. Think dollars.

伊索的投资公理，因此扩展并转换为美元，是不变的。它适用于农场、石油特许权使用费、债券、股票、彩票和制造厂的支出。蒸汽机的出现、电力的利用和汽车的发明都没有改变一级方程式赛车——互联网也不会。只需输入正确的数字，您就可以对整个宇宙中所有可能的资本用途的吸引力进行排名。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司，2000 年年度报告，第 13 页。）

Aesop’s investment axiom, thus expanded and converted into dollars, is immutable. It applies to outlays for farms, oil royalties, bonds, stocks, lottery tickets, and manufacturing plants. And neither the advent of the steam engine, the harnessing of electricity nor the creation of the automobile changed the formula one iota - nor will the Internet. Just insert the correct numbers, and you can rank the attractiveness of all possible uses of capital throughout the universe. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., 2000 Annual Report, p. 13.)

关于商品业务

On commodity businesses

产能严重过剩和“商品”产品（在性能、外观、服务支持等因素方面在任何对客户重要的方面都没有差异化）的行业中的企业是利润问题的主要候选对象。如果以某种方式管理价格或成本并因此至少部分地与正常的市场力量隔离开来，那么这些可能是真实的。这种管理可以 (a) 通过政府干预合法地进行（直到最近，这一类别包括卡车司机的定价和金融机构的存款成本），（b）通过勾结非法，或（c）通过欧佩克“非法”风格的外国卡特尔化（为国内非卡特尔运营商提供附加利益）。

Businesses in industries with both substantial over-capacity and a"commodity" product (undifferentiated in any customer-important way by factors such as performance, appearance, service support, etc.) are prime candidates for profit troubles. These may be escaped, true, if prices or costs are administered in some manner and thereby insulated at least partially from normal market forces. This administration can be carried out (a) legally through government intervention (until recently, this category included pricing for truckers and deposit costs for financial institutions), (b) illegally through collusion, or (c)"extra-legally" through OPEC-style foreign cartelization (with tag-along benefits for domestic non-cartel operators).

然而，如果成本和价格是由全面竞争决定的，那么产能就绰绰有余，而买家并不关心他使用的是谁的产品或分销服务，那么行业经济学几乎肯定不会令人兴奋。它们很可能是灾难性的。

If, however, costs and prices are determined by full-bore competition, there is more than ample capacity, and the buyer cares little about whose product or distribution services he uses, industry economics are almost certain to be unexciting. They may well be disastrous.

因此，每个供应商都在不断努力建立和强调产品或服务的特殊品质。这适用于糖果棒（顾客按品牌名称购买，而不是要求“两盎司的糖果棒”）但不适用于糖（你多久听到一次，“我要一杯加奶油的咖啡和 C & H 糖，请”）。

Hence the constant struggle of every vendor to establish and emphasize special qualities of product or service. This works with candy bars (customers buy by brand name, not by asking for a"two-ounce candy bar") but doesn’t work with sugar (how often do you hear,"I’ll have a cup of coffee with cream and C & H sugar, please").

在许多行业中，差异化根本没有意义。如果这些行业中的一些生产商具有广泛且可持续的成本优势，他们可能会一直做得很好。根据定义，此类例外情况很少，而且在许多行业中不存在。对于绝大多数销售“商品”产品的公司来说，一个令人沮丧的商业经济学方程式盛行：没有管理价格（或成本）的持续产能过剩等于盈利能力差。

In many industries, differentiation simply can’t be made meaningful. A few producers in such industries may consistently do well if they have a cost advantage that is both wide and sustainable. By definition such exceptions are few, and, in many industries, are non-existent. For the great majority of companies selling"commodity" products, a depressing equation of business economics prevails: persistent over-capacity without administered prices (or costs) equals poor profitability.

当然，随着产能收缩或需求扩大，产能过剩最终可能会自我纠正。不幸的是，对于参与者来说，这样的更正往往会延迟很长时间。当它们最终出现时，繁荣的反弹常常会产生普遍的扩张热情，这种热情在几年内再次造成产能过剩和新的无利可图的环境。换句话说，没有什么比成功更失败。

Of course, over-capacity may eventually self-correct, either as capacity shrinks or demand expands. Unfortunately for the participants, such corrections often are long delayed. When they finally occur, the rebound to prosperity frequently produces a pervasive enthusiasm for expansion that, within a few years, again creates over-capacity and a new profitless environment. In other words, nothing fails like success.

最终决定这些行业长期盈利水平的是供应紧张与供应充足年份的比率。这个比例通常很低。（似乎我们纺织业务最近的供应紧张时期——发生在几年前——持续了一个上午的大部分时间。）

What finally determines levels of long-term profitability in such industries is the ratio of supply-tight to supply-ample years. Frequently that ratio is dismal. (It seems as if the most recent supply-tight period in our textile business - it occurred some years back - lasted the better part of a morning.)

然而，在某些行业，产能紧张的情况可能会持续很长时间。有时，需求的实际增长会在很长一段时间内超过预测增长。在其他情况下，增加产能需要很长的准备时间，因为必须规划和建造复杂的制造设施。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司，致股东的信，1982 年，第 56-57 页。）

In some industries, however, capacity-tight conditions can last a long time. Sometimes actual growth in demand will outrun forecasted growth for an extended period. In other cases, adding capacity requires very long lead times because complicated manufacturing facilities must be planned and built. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Letters to Shareholders, 1982, pp.56-57.)

关于支付现金或将其保留在业务中

On paying cash out or keeping it in the business

当我们手头有资金时，我们会面临三个问题……首先，“将资金支付给股东是否比将其留在公司内部更有意义？” 子问题是，“如果我们支付，通过回购还是通过股息来支付更好？” 我们是否以股息形式支付的测试是，“我们能否通过保留而不是支付它来用那美元在公司内创造超过一美元的价值？”

When we have capital around, we have three questions.. .First,"Does it make more sense to pay it out to the shareholders than to keep it within the company?" The sub-question on that is,"If we pay it out, is it better off to do it via repurchases or via dividend?" The test for whether we pay it out in dividends is,"Can we create more than a dollar of value within the company with that dollar by retaining it rather than paying it out?"

你永远不知道答案。但到目前为止，根据我们的结果判断，答案是“是的，我们可以”。我们认为我们可以做到。但这是我们的希望。过去的历史在一定程度上证明了这一点，但这并不确定。

And you never know the answer to that. But so far, the answer, as judged by our results, is,"Yes, we can". And we think that prospectively we can. But that’s a hope on our part. It’s justified to some extent by past history, but it’s not a certainty.

一旦我们跨过了那个门槛，我们就会问自己，“我们应该回购股票吗？” 好吧，很明显，如果你能以相对于保守计算的内在价值的显着折扣购买你的股票，并且你能购买合理数量，那是对资本的明智使用。

Once we’ve crossed that threshold, then we ask ourselves,"Should we repurchase stock?" Well, obviously, if you can buy your stock at a significant discount from conservatively calculated intrinsic value and you can buy a reasonable quantity, that's a sensible use for capital.

除此之外，问题就变成了，“如果你有资本并且你认为你可以创造超过一美元，你如何以最小的风险创造最大的价值？” 这会带来业务风险…….1 可以通过查看业务、业务所在的竞争环境等来确定它。

Beyond that, the question becomes,"If you have the capital and you think that you can create more than a dollar, how do you create the most value with the least risk?" And that gets to business risk.. .1 can determine it by looking at the business, the competitive environment in which it operates and so on.

因此，一旦我们跨过决定我们可以部署资本以便为保留的每一美元创造超过一美元的现值的门槛，那么这就是做你能找到的最聪明的事情的问题。我们所做的每笔交易的成本都是根据给定时间第二好的交易来衡量的——包括做更多我们已经参与的事情。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司年会，2001 年，杰出投资者文摘，2001 年底版，第 38-39 页。）

So once we cross the threshold of deciding that we can deploy capital so as to create more than a dollar of present value for every dollar retained, then it’s just a question of doing the most intelligent thing you can find. And the cost of every deal that we do is measured by the second best deal that’s around at a given time — including doing more of some of the things we’re already in. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 2001, Outstanding Investor Digest, Year End 2001 Edition, pp.38-39.)

关于如何避免问题

On how to avoid problems

我们处理谈判的方式与任何人都不同。我们买喜诗糖果的时候，我在那里呆了一个小时。我们通过一个电话购买的每一项业务。在 Borsheim 的交易中，我去了艾克·弗里德曼 (Ike Friedman) 的房子半个小时。他给我看了一些未经审计的数字，这些数字是用铅笔写在一张纸上的。

We handle negotiations way different than anybody. When we bought See’s Candy, I spent an hour there. Every business we’ve bought on one call. On the Borsheim’s deal, I dropped over to Ike Friedman's house for half an hour. He showed me some figures that weren’t audited penciled on a piece of paper.

如果我需要一个律师和会计师团队，那将不是一笔好交易……我们从来没有就任何事情与任何人进行过长时间的谈判。那不是我们的风格。如果是那样的话，我不想和他们打交道——因为它迟早会毁了我的生活。所以我们走开。（沃伦巴菲特，1990 年 3 月 23 日在斯坦福大学法学院的演讲，杰出投资者文摘，1990 年 4 月 18 日，第 18 页。）

If I need a team of lawyers and accountants, it isn’t going to be a good deal.... We’ve never had an extended negotiation with anybody about anything. That’s just not our style. If it’s going to be that way, I don't want to deal with them — because it’s going to ruin my life sooner or later. So we just walk away. (Warren Buffett, lecture at Stanford Law School, March 23, 1990, Outstanding Investor Digest, April 18, 1990, p. 18.)

巴菲特：有些企业比其他企业更容易理解。查理和我不喜欢困难的问题。如果某事难以计算……我们宁愿乘以 3 而不是乘以 7t。

Buffett: Some businesses are a lot easier to understand than others. And Charlie and I don’t like difficult problems. If something is difficult to figure... We’d rather multiply by 3 than by 7t.

芒格：这是很明显的一点。然而，很多人认为，如果他们只雇用具有适当标签的人，他们就可以做一些非常困难的事情。这是人类可能拥有的最危险的想法之一。各种各样的事情都会因复杂性而产生问题。前几天我正在处理一个问题——那是一座新建筑。我说，“这个问题让我学会了害怕三样东西——建筑师、承包商和一座山。”

Munger: That’s such an obvious point. Yet so many people think that if they just hire somebody with the appropriate labels, they can do something very difficult. That is one of the most dangerous ideas a human being can have. All kinds of things can create problems by causing complexity. The other day I was dealing with a problem - it was a new building. And I said,"This problem has three things I’ve learned to fear - an architect, a contractor and a hill."

如果你像那样度过一生，我认为你至少会比那些认为他们可以做任何事情的人犯更少的错误，无论多么复杂，只需雇用一个有信誉标签的人。如果你保持简单，你就不必费尽心思......

If you go through life like that, I think you’ll at least make fewer mistakes than people who think they can do anything, no matter how complex, by just hiring somebody with a credible label. You don’t have to hire out your thinking if you keep it simple...

巴菲特：如果你从事一些复杂的业务，你会得到一份 1000 页厚的报告，而且你可以让博士来研究它。但这并不意味着什么。你会得到一份报告。但是您不会更好地了解该业务以及 10 年或 15 年后的情况。最重要的是避免犯错。（Berkshire Hathaway 年会，1994 年，杰出投资者文摘，1994 年 6 月 23 日，第 23 页。）

Buffett: If you get into some complicated business, you can get a report that’s 1,000 pages thick and you can have Ph.D.’s working on it. But it doesn’t mean anything. What you’ll have is a report. But you won’t have any better understanding of that business and what it’s going to look like in 10 or 15 years. The big thing to do is to avoid being wrong. (Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting, 1994, Outstanding Investor Digest, June 23, 1994, p.23.)

关于投资的真正风险

On the real risk of investing

我们认为，投资者必须评估的真正风险是，他从一项投资中获得的总税后收入（包括他在出售时收到的收入）是否会在他的预期持有期内至少给他带来与他之前一样多的购买力首先，加上初始股份的适度利率。虽然这种风险无法用工程精度计算，但在某些情况下可以用有用的准确度来判断。影响此评估的主要因素是：

In our opinion, the real risk that an investor must assess is whether his aggregate after-tax receipts from an investment (including those he receives on sale) will, over his prospective holding period, give him at least as much purchasing power as he had to begin with, plus a modest rate of interest on that initial stake. Though this risk cannot be calculated with engineering precision, it can in some cases be judged with a degree of accuracy that is useful. The primary factors bearing upon this evaluation are:

  1. 评估企业长期经济特征的确定性；
  2. The certainty with which the long-term economic characteristics of the business can be evaluated;
  3. 可以评估管理层的确定性，包括其实现业务全部潜力和明智地利用现金流的能力；
  4. The certainty with which management can be evaluated, both to its ability to realize the full potential of the business and to wisely employ its cash flows;
  5. 可以指望管理层将企业回报分配给股东而不是自身的确定性；
  6. The certainty with which management can be counted on to channel the rewards from the business to the shareholders rather than to itself;
  7. 企业收购价格：
  8. The purchase price of the business:
  9. 将经历的税收和通货膨胀水平将决定投资者的购买力回报从其总回报中减少的程度。（沃伦巴菲特，伯克希尔哈撒韦公司，致股东的信，1993 年，第 135 页。）
  10. The levels of taxation and inflation that will be experienced and that will determine the degree by which an investor’s purchasing power return is reduced from his gross return. (Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Letters to Shareholders, 1993, p. 135.)

论发展公平社会制度的困难

On the difficulty of developing a fair social system

让我们这么说吧，桑迪，在你出生前 24 小时，一个精灵出现了，说“桑迪，你看起来像个赢家。我对你充满信心，我要做的就是让你为你将出生的社会制定规则。你可以制定经济规则、社会规则，以及你制定的任何规则将在你的一生和你的孩子的一生中适用。”

Let’s just say, Sandy, that it was 24 hours before you were born, and a genie appeared, and said"Sandy, you look like a winner. I have enormous confidence in you, and what I’m going to do is let you set the rules of the society into which you will be born. You can set the economic rules, the social rules, and whatever rules you set will apply during your lifetime, and your children’s lifetimes."

你会说，“嗯，这很好，但有什么问题呢？”

And you’ll say,"Well, that’s nice, but what’s the catch?"

精灵说，“这里有一个陷阱。你不知道你出生时是富有的还是贫穷的，是白人还是黑人，是男性还是女性，是强壮的还是体弱的，聪明的还是弱智的。你所知道的就是你会从一个桶里拿出一个球，比如说，里面有 58 亿个球。” 你将参加我称之为卵巢彩票的活动。这是你生命中最重要的事情，但你无法控制它。它所决定的远不止你在学校的成绩或发生在你身上的任何其他事情。

And the genie says,"Here’s the catch. You don’t know if you’re going to be born rich or poor, white or black, male or female, able-bodied or infirm, intelligent or retarded. All you know is that you’re going to get one ball out of a barrel with, say, 5.8 billion balls in it." You're going to participate in what I call the Ovarian Lottery. And it’s the most important thing that will happen to you in your life, but you have no control over it. It’s going to determine far more than your grades at school or anything else that happens to you.

现在，你想要什么规则？我不会告诉你规则，也没有人会告诉你；你必须自己弥补。但它们会影响您如何看待您在遗嘱中所做的事情以及诸如此类的事情。那是因为你会希望拥有一个能够提供大量商品和服务的系统，这样你的孩子就能比你以前过得更好，你的孙子也能比你的孩子过得更好。你会想要一个系统，让比尔·盖茨、安迪·格罗夫和杰克·韦尔奇在他们不需要工作之后还能继续工作很长时间。你会想要最能干的人每天工作超过 12 小时。所以你必须有一个系统来激励他们，结果是好的。

Now, what rules do you want to have? I’m not going to tell you the rules, and nobody will tell you; you have to make them up for yourself. But they will affect how you think about what you do in your will and things of that sort. That’s because you’re going to want to have a system that turns out great quantities of goods and services, so that your kids can live better than you did, and so that your grandchildren can live better than your kids. You’re going to want a system that keeps Bill Gates and Andy Grove and Jack Welch working long, long after they don’t need to work. You’re going to want the most able people working more than 12 hours a day. So you’ve got to have a system that incentives them, and that turns out goods.

但是你也需要一个系统来处理坏球，那些不走运的球。如果您的系统能够提供足够的商品和服务，您就可以照顾好它们。你想要一个人们在某种程度上没有恐惧的系统。你不希望人们担心晚年生病，或害怕晚上回家。所以你会尝试设计一些东西，假设你有商品和服务来解决这类事情。你会希望机会均等——一个良好的公立学校系统——让你觉得那里的每一位天才都会有同样的机会做出贡献。您的税收制度将根据您的推理得出。而你用你赚的钱做什么是另一回事。当你解决这个问题时，每个人都会想出一些不同的东西。我只是建议你玩那个小游戏。（沃伦·巴菲特，“巴菲特与盖茨的成功之路”，KCTS/Seatde，1998 年 5 月，抄本第 12 页。）

But you’re also going to want a system that takes care of the bad balls, the ones that aren’t lucky. If you have a system that is turning out enough goods and services, you can take care of them. You want a system where people are free of fear to some extent. You don’t want people worrying about being sick in their old age, or fearful about going home at night. So you’ll try to design something, assuming you have the goods and services to solve that sort of thing. You’ll want equality of opportunity — a good public school system — to make you feel that every piece of talent out there will get the same shot at contributing. And your tax system will follow from your reasoning on that. And what you do with the money you make is another thing to think about it. As you work through that, everybody comes up with something a litde different. I just suggest you play that little game. (Warren Buffett,"Buffett & Gates on Success", KCTS/Seatde, May 1998, transcript p. 12.)

有关投资、商业经济和管理的其他问题，请阅读伯克希尔哈撒韦公司 ( www.berkshirehathaway.com ) 的年度报告并订阅杰出投资者文摘 ( www.oid.com )

For other issues regarding investing, business economics and managing, read the annual reports of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (www.berkshirehathaway.com) and subscribe to Outstanding Investor Digest, (www.oid.com)

伯克希尔哈撒韦公司

Berkshire Hathaway Inc.

徒劳的杰出投资者文摘

Futile Outstanding Investor Digest

附录三：概率

Appendix Three: Probability

布莱斯·帕斯卡 (Blaise Pascal) 和皮埃尔·费马 (Pierre Fermat) 在 1654 年开始的一系列往来信件中发展了概率的基本原理。

Blaise Pascal and Pierre Fermat developed the fundamental principles of probability in a series of letters exchanged starting in the year 1654.

定义

Definitions

实验是获得观察结果的过程。例如：抛两次硬币，观察会发生什么。
